column245: REGARDING PART C5:  SECTIONS OF THIS LINE WERE BLOCKED IN DUE TO WORK DOWNSTREAM TO IDENTIFY A LEAK WITHIN THE SAME PIPELINE EASEMENT.  DURING THE DAYLIGHT HOURS, THE SUNLIGHT WAS SUFFICIENT TO HEAT THE PIPELINE AND ITS CONTENTS CAUSING AN OVERPRESSURE CONDITION FOR A DURATION OF 2.5 HOURS.  ACCORDING TO PRESSURE TRANSMITTER READINGS RECORDED PER MINUTE, THE LEAK APPEARS TO HAVE OCCURRED IN THE FIRST FIVE MINUTES OF THE OVERPRESSURE CONDITION.  THE LINE PRESSURE WAS RECORDED AT ZERO PSIG 6.5 HOURS LATER, INDICATING THAT THE LINE HAD BEEN BLOCKED AT THAT TIME.  THE LEAK WAS ASSUMED TO OCCUR OVER THE ENTIRE 6.5 HOUR DURATION.  REGARDING PARTS H5 A-G:  THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION DOCUMENTATION IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR REFERENCE DUE TO SEVERAL OWNERSHIP CHANGES FOR THIS LINE.  IN LIGHT OF THIS FACT, THE WORST CASE SCENARIO OF NO PRESSURE TESTING DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION IS ASSUMED.  UPON EXCAVATION OF THIS FLANGE JOINT, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE CONNECTION HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY TIGHTENED TO SPECIFIED TORQUE REQUIREMENTS.  SUBSEQUENTLY, NINE OTHER CONNECTIONS WERE EXCAVATED AND ALSO FOUND TO BE INADEQUATELY TIGHTED.  ALL TEN AFFECTED FLANGE CONNECTIONS WERE REPAIRED AND CORRECTLY TIGHTENED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON JANUARY 24,2002 MOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY INCURRED A 10 BARREL LEAK RESULTING FROM A LEAKING GASKET.  CONTRIBUTARY CAUSE OF THE LEAKING GASKET WAS AN INCREASED PRESSURE ON STATION PIPING DUE TO IMPROPER VALVE ALIGNMENT.  THIS LEAK WAS ON STATION PIPING.  THE MOP OF THE MAINLINE SYSTEM WAS NOT EXCEEDED AT ANY TIME DURING THIS INCIDENT.  ON THE DATE THE LEAK OCCURRED THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION, OIL AND GAS DIVISION WAS NOTIFIED IN A TIMELY MANNER AND THE LEAK WAS THOUGHT TO BE CONTAINED.  IT WAS LATER DISCOVERED THAT THE LEAK LEFT THE CONTAINMENT AND DID REACH WATER AS IT WAS RAINING HEAVILY.  A TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS MADE TO THE NRC.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: A RELEASE OCCURED IN A REMOTE AREA ON THE 8" EL PASO TO ALBUQUERQUE PRODUCTS SYSTEM @ MILEPOST 89. ON 01/05/02 @ 09:00 AM MST , A CHEVRON PIPE LINE, CUSTOMER SERVICE CENTER CONTROLLER, NOTIFIED EL PASO TEAM LEADER OF A POSSIBLE PROBLEM ON EL PASO-ALBUQUERQUE PRODUCT SYSTEM. THE CONTROLLER WAS CONCERNED WITH THE THE "OVER/SHORT" VOLUMES ON THE SYSTEM. THE LINE WAS FLOWN, BUT NO PRODUCT RELEASE WAS FOUND BY THE AERIAL SURVEILLANCE PILOT. THE PILOT ONLY OBSERVED WHAT HE TOUGHT WAS A SMALL RELEASE OF WATER FROM A RANCHER'S WATER SYSTEM. IT WASN'T UNTIL 01/07/02 @ 11:25AM THAT THE PRODUCT RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED AT 89 MILES NORTH OF EL PASO (TSP17S R1E BLOCK 9). THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AT THAT POINT. AN INVESTIGATION WAS INITIATED AND NOTIFICATIONS TO AGENCIES WERE MADE WITH PRELIMINARY RELEASE VOLUME ESTIMATES. THE FINAL VOLUMES WERE DETERMINED TO BE 250 BBLS OF DIESEL AND 700 BBLS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE. NO PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED IN THE CONVENTIONAL MEANS. RESIDUAL SOIL CONTAMINATION WILL BE CLEANED UP.    IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE FOR THE RELEASE WAS A PIPE WELD FAILURE. THE WELD WAS MADE DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION  IN 1954. THE POTENTIAL PROBLEM WAS NOT DETECTED IN THE LATEST IN-LINE TOOL INSPECTION, CONDUCTED ON THIS LINE IN 2000.    AGENCIES NOTIFIED: NRC CONTACTED 1/7/02 @ 2:00 PM (OFFICER TRUMAN - RPT # 590400). NM DEPT. OF ENVIRO CONTACTED @ 2:45 PM (RUDY ALVAREZ) DEPT OF HAZ WASTE WAS ALSO NOTIFIED (RON TRUEBLOOD).

column245: AN EXCAVATOR, INSTALLING DRAIN TILE, HIT AND PUNCTURED THE LINE. THE EXCAVATOR DID NOT CALL THE ILLINOIS ONE-CALL AGENCY, SO THE LINE WAS NOT MARKED AND THE COMPANY WAS NOT ABLE TO HAVE PERSONNEL AT THE SITE TO PREVENT THE DAMAGE. UPON NOTIFICATION THAT THE LINE WAS PUNCTURED, THE LINE WAS SECURED BY CLOSING THE VALVES ON EITHER SIDE OF THE PUNCTURE, IN ACCORDANCE WITH COMPANY PROCEDURES, AN INCIDENT COMMAND WAS ESTABLISHED AND A SAFETY ZONE WAS ESTABLISHED. AS A PRECAUTION 30 PERSONS WERE EVACUATED UNTIL LINE WAS REPARED WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE AND RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 100 HOURS ON JANUARY 31.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AT 9:15 A.M. ON FEBRUARY 13, 2002, A CINIZA PIPE LINE OPERATOR DISCOVERED CRUDE OIL LEAKING FROM THE ABOVEGROUND STORAGE TANK AT STAR LAKE STATION. THE TANK MIXER WAS TURNED OFF AND THE STATION WAS BYPASSED. OUR MAINTENANCE CREW WAS NOTIFIED, AND SMALL SUMPS WERE INSTALLED AROUND THE TANK TO CATCH THE CRUDE OIL SEEPING FROM UNDER THE TANK. THE OIL WAS PUMPED FROM THE SUMPS BACK INTO THE TANK. THE TANK WAS EMPTIED AND IS CURRENTLY BEING CLEANED FOR INSPECTION AND REPAIR.

column245: ONE-INCH RELIEF LINE ON BREAKOUT TANK MANIFOLD WAS DISCOVERED BROKEN AT A THEREADED FITTING. THERE WAS NO CORROSION AND SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION DID NOT DETERMINE THE CAUSE. THERE IS A POSSIBILITY THAT THE LINE COULD HAVE BEEN DAMAGED BY ICE CHUNKS OR SNOW FALLING FROM THE TANK ROOF AND HITTING IT. THE LINE WAS PROMPTLY REPAIRED WITH NEW SCHEDULE 40 PIPE. FREE PHASE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED WITH A VACUUM EXTRACTION TRAILER AND IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND DISPOSED OF AT THE IOWA CITY LANDFILL IN ACCORDANCE WITH ACCEPTABLE ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICES.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: MARTINSVILLE STATION VALVE IS9 (12" 150 ANSI PLUG VALVE) FAILED APPROXIMATELY TWO HOURS AFTER A DELIVERY WAS INITIATED THROUGH THE VALVE.  THIS VALVE ISOLATES A STORAGE TANK FROM A TANK MANIFOLD.  THIS VALVE HAD BEEN OUT OF SERVICE SINCE JULY 2001.  THE VALVE WAS VISUALLY MONITORED DURING THE COMMISSIONING, AND THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED IMMEDIATELY UPON OCCURRENCE, AND RESPONSE ACTIONS WERE INITIATED. THE DELIVERY WAS STOPPED AND MANUAL VALVES WERE CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LEAKING VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH STRAIGHT PIPE.  THE VALVE FLANGE CRACKED AT THE SIX O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE TANK SIDE OF THE VALVE.  IT WILL BE ANALYZED BY KEIFNER AND ASSOCIATES TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ARE LIMITED TO IMPACTED SOIL REMEDIATION TO IL-EPA CLEAN UP STANDARDS. THE ORIGINIAL 7000-1 REPORT ON THIS INCIDENT WAS FILED 3-18-2002.      4/13/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC REVIEW.  PLOTTED COORDINATES AND IDENTIFIED LOCATION DID NOT FALL ON A LINE OR AT A STATION.  UPDATED TO THE COORDINATES FOR MARTINSVILLE STATION.  PREVIOUSLY REPORTED COORDINATES WERE 39.3261 AND 87.8968.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A PIPELINE CONTROLLER AT CHEVRON PIPELINE COMPANY'S (CPL) CUSTOMER SERVICE CENTER IN HOUSTON, TX NOTICED THE DISCHARGE PRESSURE ON THE #1 OIL LINE AT SALT LAKE STATION HAD DROPPED FROM 1831 TO 119 PSI.  THIS IS AN 8" LOW SULPHUR DIESEL PIPELINE.  THE CONTROLLER SHUTDOWN THE SALT LAKE STATION #1 OIL LINE.  THE PIPELINE LEAK SITE WAS CONFIRMED AT 6:14PM TO BE JUST OUTSIDE THE SALT LAKE REFINERY BOUNDARY FENCE NEAR HIGHWAY I-215 AT MILEPOST 0.28.  THE INITAL VOLUME REPORTED WAS 200 BARRELS OF DIESEL/GASOLINE MIX.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION ON FEBRUARY 7, REVEALED CORROSION DAMAGE TO THE PIPE FROM WHAT APPEARED TO BE A SECOND PATCH OF EXTERNAL PIPE COATING THAT WAS MADE OVER THE ORIGINAL COATING, AT POINT OF FAILURE.  ANOTHER PIPELINE, NOT BELONGING TO CPL, CROSSED BELOW OUR PIPELINE AT THE POINT WHERE THE COATING PATCH WAS FOUND. THE FAILURE OCCURRED ABOUT 9 FEET FROM AN UPSTREAM WELD, RESULTING IN AN APPRX 14 TO 15 INCH RUPTURE.  ON FEBRUARY 8 AT 5:00PM, CPL BEGAN THE GRADUAL STARTUP OF THE PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY (OPS) REQUIRED CPL TO HOLD PRESSURE BETWEEN 200 TO 400 PSI FOR 1 HOUR.  THE STARTUP PROCESS WAS APPROVED BY OPS AT 7:45PM.  THE FINAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS DETERMINED TO BE 348 BARRELS AND THE RECOVERED VOLUME WAS 141 BARRELS.  THE NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION SAFETY BOARD (NTSB) HAS ORDERED A LAB ANALYSIS OF THE FAILED PIECE OF PIPE TO ASCERTAIN THE CAUSE.  CPL EXPECTS THE RESULTS FROM THIS ANALYSIS BY THE FIRST WEEK OF APRIL 2002.

column64: ABOVE GROUND LINE BREAK OPERATOR VALVE
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 2:24 ON 2/7/02, KOCH'S PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER (PCC) IN WICHITA, KS DETECTED A PRESSURE DIFFERENTIAL IN ARKANSAS BETWEEN THE ELDORADO CHEMICAL DELIVERY UPSTREAM AND KOCH'S PINE BLUFF PUMP STATION DOWNSTREAM.  THE PCC NOTIFIED THE AREA REPRESENTATIVE TO INVESTIGATE A POSSIBLE VALVE CLOSURE.  THE PCC BEGAN SHUTTING DOWN INJECTIONS UPSTREAM TO REDUCE LINE PRESSURE AT THE RELEASE SITE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 13:25 THE KOCH REPRESENTATIVE CONFIRMED VALVE 3-5, AN ABOVE GROUND LINE BREAK OPERATOR VALVE, WAS CLOSED BY APPARENT VANDALISM.  A VAPOR CLOUD WAS PRESENT.  THE AREA IS VERY RURAL WITH NO HOMES OR BUILDINGS IN THE VICINITY.  THE KOCH REPRESENTATIVE NOTIFIED THE DIVISION OFFICE IN HERMANN, MO OF THE SITUATION.  DIVISION OFFICE PERSONNEL MADE APPROPRIATE FEDERAL AND STATE TELEPHONE NOTIFICATIONS AND BEGAN ORGANIZING AND MOBILIZING RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT TO THE SITE.  THE PCC COMPLETED LINE SHUT DOWN.  THE 2" MANUAL VALVE BETWEEN THE PIPELINE AND THE SMALL SENSING LINE WAS CLOSED AT APPROXIMATELY 16:30.  THIS STOPPED THE RELEASE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT VANDALS HAD CUT THROUGH THE STEEL PROTECTIVE BOX WITH TORCHES AND ATTEMPTED TO TAP INTO THE SMALL SENSING LINE TO STEAL AMMONIA.  A BRAIDED HOSE ATTACHED TO A PROPANE BOTTLE WAS FOUND AT THE RELEASE POINT AND WAS TAKEN BY THE LOCAL SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT AS EVIDENCE.  THE LINE WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 17:42.

column245: ON FEBRUARY 26, 2002, A BUCKEYE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED PRODUCT SPRAYING FROM A ONE INCH BALANCE LINE LOCATED ON A PUMP AT BUCKEYE PIPE LINE'S KOUTS STATION.  THE EMPLOYEE IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER, AND THE PUMP AND PIPELINE WERE SHUT DOWN AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES WERE IMPLEMENTED.  THE PUMP WAS BYPASSED AND THE LINE WAS RESTARTED.  UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE BALANCE LINE NIPPLE CRACKED AND FAILED, THUS CREATING A RELEASE OF PRODUCT, WHICH WAS CONTAINED ON STATION PROPERTY.  NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE APPROPRIATE AGENCIES AND CLEAN UP WAS PERFORMED BY BUCKEYE PIPE LINE PERSONNEL.

column238: INITIALLY WOLVERINE WAS NOT CERTAIN AS TO THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK THAT WAS DISCOVERED IN ITS GRAVITOMETER VAULT NEAR LOCKPORT, IL ON SEPTEMBER 11, 2001.  THE LEAK OBSERVED ON THAT DATE WAS BELOW THE REPORTING THRESHOLD.  A POST DISCOVERY INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT THE GRAVITOMETER, WHICH HAD NOT BEEN USED SINCE THE EARLY 1970'S, WAS THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK.  MECHANICAL STRESSES OVER A LONG PERIOD OF TIME CAUSED THE BOLTS INSIDE THE GRAVITOMETER TO COME LOOSE RESULTING IN THE GRAVITOMETER SAMPLE PROBE BASE TO TILT TO THE SIDE.  THIS TILTING ALLOWED REFINED PRODUCTS TO BYPASS THE GRAVITOMETER INTERNAL O-RING AND ENTER THE GRAVITOMETER ELECTRICAL ENCLOSURE THAT WAS NOT DESIGNED TO HOLD PIPELINE PRESSURES.  REFINED PRODUCT LEAKED FROM THE THREADED CONNECTIONS ON THE ELECTRICAL PORTION OF THE GRAVITOMETER INTO THE VAULT.  WOLVERINE HAS REMOVED THE GRAVITOMETER AND INSTALLED A BLIND FLANGE.
column245: AS A FOLLOW-UP TO WOLVERINE'S DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK SEPTEMBER 11, 2001, WOLVERINE HIRED A CONTRACTOR TO DIG SOIL SAMPLES AND PERFORM SOIL BORINGS TO DETERMINE IF THE LEAK OR ANY PREVIOUS UNDETECTED LEAKS THERE CAUSED CONTAMINATION AROUND THE GRAVITOMETER VAULT.  THIS ASSESSMENT WORK WAS DONE WITH THE APPROVAL OF THE ILLINOIS EPA.  ALTHOUGH THE VEGETATION IN THE AREA GAVE NO INDICATION OF ANY PROBLEMS AT THE SURFACE, THE SOIL BORINGS DETECTED REFINED PRODUCTS 10 TO 12 FEET BELOW THE SOIL SURFACE.  THE EXTENSIVE BORINGS PERFORMED IN THE AREA GAVE A PRELIMINARY INDICATION OF THE PLUME SIZE AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION THAT THE PLUME WAS NEAR BIG RUN CREEK (PREVIOUSLY REPORTED AS MINK CREEK).  FURTHER, THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE OF A SHEEN ON BIG RUN CREEK.  APPROXIMATELY 6 MONTHS AFTER THE INITIAL DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK AND DURING WOLVERINE'S ACTIVE FOLLOW-UP PLUME DEFINITION AND PRELIMINARY REMEDIATION WORK, THE AREA EXPERIENCED EXTREMELY STRONG RAINS AND A SHEEN WAS SUBSEQUENTLY DISCOVERED ON BIG RUN CREEK ON MARCH 5, 2002.  ALL APPROPRIATE REGULATORY REPORTS WERE MADE AT THAT TIME.  BIG RUN CREEK WAS PROMPTLY BOOMED WITH ABSORBENT PADS AND BOOMS DEPLOYED WHICH MET THE ILLINOIS EPA'S APPROVAL.  NO SHHEN HAS BEEN OBSERVED ON BIG RUN CREEK AT ANY TIME AFTER THE MARCH 5, 2002 REPORT.  WOLVERINE AND ITS CONTRACTORS ARE CURRENTLY CONDUCTING FURTHER SOIL BORINGS THAT WILL BETTER DEFINE THE PLUME SIZE AND FACILITATE THE PREPARATION OF A REMEDIATION PLAN.       UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: LANDOWNER HAD SMELLED GASOLINE AND CALLED THE JEFFERSON CITY TERMINAL ABOUT THE ODOR.  FIELD PERSONNEL NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER WHO BLOCKED IN THE LINE TO VERIFY LINE PRESSURES.  FIELD PERSONNEL WENT TO THE SITE AND CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF THE ODOR.  FIRE DEPARTMENT AND POLICE WERE NOTIFIED OF THE SITUATION. A NEARBY HIGHWAY WAS CLOSED. column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column238: REPAIR CLAMP HAD SOME NUTS THAT WERE NOT COMPLETELY TIGHT.
column245: OYSTER FISHERMAN REPORTED A SHEEN ON A PIPELINE CANAL IN BAYOU COOK.  FIRST INVESTIGATION, AT NIGHT, FOUND AN ODOR BUT NO OIL.  SYSTEM WAS LEFT DOWN OVERNIGHT AND A FIRST LIGHT THE INVESTIGATION WAS STARTED AGAIN.  A FEW DROPLETS OF OIL WERE SPOTTED BREAKING THE SURFACE OF THE WATER AND BECOMING A SHEEN.  THE AREA WAS BOOMED OFF AND A DIVER WAS SENT DOWN TO CHECK THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE IS IN ABOUT 5-6 FT OF WATER AND IS BURIED ABOUT 8 IN MUD.  THE DIVER JETTED OFF THE MUD AND FOUND A REPAIR CLAMP THAT HAD SOME NUTS THAT WERE NOT COMPLETELY TIGHT.  THE CLAMP WAS REPLACED WITH A NEW CLAMP.  DROPLETS OF OIL WERE STILL OCCASIONALLY BREAKING THE SURFACE SO THE DIVER WAS SENT DOWN AGAIN TO JET THE MUD ON EITHER SIDE OF THE REPAIR CLAMP.  NO OTHER LEAKS WERE FOUND.  THE DIVER PUT AN ABSORBENT PAD AROUND THE REPAIR CLAMP AND IT CAME BACK CLEAN.  OIL STOPPED BUBBLING AFTER THE MUD HAD BEEN JETTED FROM AROUND THE PIPELINE.  TOTAL SPILL WAS LESS THAN A GALLON.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ANALYSIS BY FMC ENERGY SYSTEMS INDICATED THAT DAMAGE TO THE METER BODY APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY HYDRAULIC SHOCK, AND WAS EXTENUATED BY IMPROPER LENGTH (ENGAGEMENT) OF MOUNTING BOLTS THAT SECURED THE INNERMECH TO THE METER BODY.  INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT IDENTIFIED THAT A SUDDEN SURGE OF FLOW TO THE METER (HYDRAULIC SHOCK), DURING A DELIVERY ROOM FROM TANKAGE, MAY HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY STARTING THE BOOSTER PUMPS AFTER THE VALVE WAS FULLY OPEN.  REVISED DELIVERY PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED THAT ENSURE BOOSTER PUMPS ARE STARTED WITH PARTIALLY OPEN VALVES, THUS PREVENTING THIS SITUATION FROM REOCURRING.  IT REMAINS INCONCLUSIVE AS TO WHY 5" RATHER THAN 6" BOLTS WERE INSTALLED IN THE METER.  SMITH METER HAS AGREED TO ASSUME THE COSTS FOR REPAIR OF THE INNEMECH BODY, SINCE THE SMITH METER REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE PARTS LISTS WERE UNCLEAR FOR THIS PARTICULAR METER.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: COMPANY MAINTENANCE CREWS WERE EXCAVATING A 30" PUMP STATION SUCTION LINE (LINE 4) AS PART OF THE TERRACE III EXPANSION PROJECT.  DURING THIS EXCAVATION, A FAILURE OCCURRED IN A 3/4" PIPING NIPPLE THAT WAS CONNECTED TO THE SUCTION LINE VIA A SOCK-O-LET FITTING.  APPROXIMATELY 50 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WAS RELEASED AND CONTAINED WITHIN AN 80'X50' BERMED AREA ON STATION PROPERTY.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY ISOLATED AND REPAIRED.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT REVEALED THAT MECHANICAL EXCAVATING EQUIPMENT MAY HAVE BEEN OPERATING IN CLOSER PROXIMITY TO THE STATION PIPING THAN ALLOWED BY COMPANY PROCEDURES.  HOWEVER, IT IS UNCLEAR WHETHER THE 3/4" PIPE WAS DIRECTLY IMPACTED, OR IF SOIL STRESS RESULTING FROM GROUND FROST CAUSED THE FAILURE, AS THE FITTING IN QUESTION WAS NEVER RECOVERED.  AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE, COMPANY POLICY REGARDING EXCAVATION OF EXISTING LINES WAS REVIEWED WITH THE OPERATOR AND HIS IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR AFTER THE INCIDENT.  IN ADDITION, INCIDENT SAFETY BULLETINS WERE ISSUED COMPANY-WIDE TO REINFORCE COMPANY POLICY ON EXCAVATION.

column245: ON MARCH 13, 2002, BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S LIMA STATION RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE VAN WERT COUNTY SHERIFF DEPARTMENT REPORTING A GASOLINE ODOR IN THE AREA OF BUCKEYE'S 402 PIPELINE.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION GASOLINE WAS DISCOVERED IN TWENTYSEVEN MILE CREEK.  CONTAINMENT DEVICES WERE DEPLOYED AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES WERE PERFORMED IN COLLABORATION WITH ON-SITE PUBLIC RESPONSE AND REGULATORY PERSONNEL.  THE RELEASE AREA WAS MADE SAFE AND THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED.  A PINHOLE FAILURE WAS DISCOVERED.  THE PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH STOCK CERTIFIED PIPE.  THE FAILED PIPE WAS SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT METALLURGIST FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL METALLURGICAL REPORT HAD NOT BEEN RECEIVED AS OF THE DATE OF THIS REPORT; HOWEVER, INITIAL FINDINGS INDICATE INTERNAL CORROSION.  THIS SECTION OF PIPE WAS PREVIOUSLY USED IN A MARATHON CRUDE OIL SERVICE.  BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY PURCHASED, RECONDITIONED, INSTALLED, AND PLACED THIS SECTION OF PIPE IN PETROLEUM PRODUCTS SERVICE IN 1955.  ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE OHIO ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, FEDERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT, EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT OF VAN WERT COUNTY, AND THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE & GAME COMMISSION.    THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT IS AS MARKED ABOVE.  WE HAVE RECEIVED THE FINAL LAB ANALYSIS OF THE PIPE AND THE REPORT STATES THAT THEY BELIEVE THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS INTERNAL MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION.  THE INTERNAL CORROSION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE STARTED MANY YEARS AGO WHEN THE PIPE WAS IN CRUDE OIL SERVICE.  THE SMYS OF THIS PIPE IS UNKNOWN, I TRIED ENTERING THIS IN THE FIELD PROVIDED HOWEVER THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT ACCEPT IT SO I ENTERED "0" SINCE THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME MARK THIS REPORT FINAL WITHOUT SOMETHING IN THIS FIELD.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: THIS IS A LEASED LINE OPERATED BY WILLIAMS PIPELINE COMPANY LLC (WPL).  THE COMPANY FROM WHOM THE LINE IS LEASED INFORMED WPL OF ITS INTENTION TO REPLACE A VALVE.  THE COMPANY'S JOB PLAN REQUIRED USING NITROGEN IN CONJUNCTION WITH PIGS TO PURGE SEVERAL MILES OF THE LINE SEGMENT INSTEAD OF DRAINING UP THE LINE IN ORDER TO REPLACE THE VALVE, AS WPL RECOMMENDED.  CONCERNED THAT NITROGEN WOULD DAMAGE A TANK ROOF AT THE WPL EL DORADO FACILITY, WPL PERSONNEL TRACKED THE PROGRESS OF THE NITROGEN BY TRACKING THE PIGS.  WHILE WAITING FOR THE PASSAGE OF THE PIGS AND NITROGEN THROUGH THE EQUILON PIPELINE COMPANY BOYER, KANSAS STATION, WPL PERSONNEL DISCOVERED THE LEAK.  WPL OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED AND EMERGENCY PROCEDURES INITIATED TO SHUT DOWN THE LINE.  EQUILON WAS NOTIFIED AND ITS ADJACENT LINE WAS PROMPTLY SHUT DOWN AND REPAIR CREWS CALLED.  THE SITE OF THE RELEASE WAS EXCAVATED AND A SECTION OF LINE APPROXIMATELY 6 FOOT LONG WAS DISCOVERED WITH SEVERAL DENTS AND GOUGES FROM THIRD PARTY DAMAGE, INCLUDING A FISH MOUTH SHAPED RUPTURE IN ONE OF THE GOUGES.  THE THIRD PARTY DAMAGE WAS DONE LAST YEAR BY THE PREVIOUS OPERATOR WPL BEGAN OPERATING THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS PROMPTLY REPAIRED USING PRETESTED NEW PIPE AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  THE 6 FOOT LONG SPECIMAN OF DAMAGED PIPE WAS SENT TO A METALLURGICAL COMPANY FOR ANALYSIS.  10-22-03 - THE PIPE FAILED SOLELY AS A RESULT OF GOUGING AND DENTING OF THE PIPE WALL FROM MULTIPLE EXTERNAL DAMAGE.

column245: SPILL WAS FROM AN ISOLATED, IDLED TANK WHICH HAD A 3'-6" OF CRUDE OIL IN IT AT TIME OF LEAK.  WATER IN AN ABOVE GROUND CIRCULATION LINE FROZE AND SPLIT THE LINE.  LEAK WAS SPOTTED BY A ROCKY MOUNTAIN PIPELINE SYSTEM (RMPL)  TRUCK DRIVER WHO REPORTED IT TO RMPL TEAM LEADER.  RESPONDERS UTILIZED VACUUM TRUCK TO RECOVER 40 OF THE 60 BBLS SPILLED. column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A 1/3" DIAMETER X 2" LONG EXTRA HEAVY PIPE NIPPLE CONNECTING AN AIR BLEEDER VALVE TO PUMP UNIT #6 AT THE RED BUTTE PIPE LINE CHATHAM, WY STATION FAILED.  APPROXIMATELY 595 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WERE RELEASED, (THE ORIGINAL RELEASE ESTIMATE WAS 500 BARRELS).  THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY A PASSING MOTORIST WHO REPORTED IT TO THE WASHAKIE CO SHERIFF.  THE WASHAKIE CO SHERIFF CONTACTED MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE PERSONNEL WHO IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE STATION.  CONTAINMENT FACILITIES KEPT THE CRUDE CONTAINED ON RED BUTTE PROPERTY.  FREE STANDING OIL WAS RECOVERED ON MARCH 14-16, 2002 AND HAS BEEN RETURNED TO STORAGE.  IMPACTED SOIL HAS BEEN ASSESSED AND IS BEING STOCKPILED FOR PROPER DISPOSAL.  THE FAILED PIPE NIPPLE AND ASSOCIATED VALVE AND FITTINGS WERE REPLACED ON MARCH 14 AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE ON MARCH 15.  THE FAILED NIPPLE IS BEING ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE NIPPLE FAILURE WAS PRIMARILY DUE TO OVER-TIGHTENING OF THE NIPPLE INTO THE VALVE BODY.  THE OVER-TIGHTENING LED TO A HIGHER STRESS FIELD AT THE FIRST ENGAGED THREAD OF THE NIPPLE IN THE VALVE BODY, PROMOTING FATIGUE FRACTURE OF THE NIPPLE.

column245: KMEP ENCOUNTERED A SEAL FAILURE ON OUR LINE 107 PUMP, LOCATED AT OUR MORRIS PUMP STATION, IN GRUNDY COUNTY, ILLNOIS.  AT 12:30 PM, OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A SEAL LEAK ALARM.  THE ACTIVATION OF THIS ALARM AUTOMATICALLY SHUTS DOWN AND ISOLATES THE PUMP.  THE ISOLATED PUMP WAS AUTOMATICALLY BY-PASSED AND THE LINE CONTINUED TO OPERATE.  THE INBOARD AND OUTBOARD PUMP SEALS WERE REPLACED AND THE UNIT WAS RESTARTED WITH NO FURTHER PROBLEMS.

column245: THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY AERIAL PATROL.  INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT THE ESTIMATED COST WAS LESS THAN $50,000. column238: ARC BURN FROM DOWNED ACTIVE POWER LINE.
column245: A POWER POLE GUY WIRE ANCHOR HAD BEEN ABANDONED IN PLACE ADJACENT TO THE BURIED 6" PIPELINE.  AN ACTIVE POWER LINE FAILED CAUSING AN ARC FROM THE ABANDONED GUY ANCHOR TO THE BURIED 6" PIPELINE.  THE ARC BURNED A PIN HOLE INTO THE PIPE RESULTING IN A RELEASE TO THE ENVIRONMENT.  KNOWLEDGE OF THE DOWNED POWER LINE WAS OBTAINED AFTER NOTIFICATION AND CONFIRMATION OF THE RELEASE.  RELEASE WAS CONFIRMED AT 11:00AM, ON MARCH 15, 2002.  THE DOWNED POWER LINE WAS REPORTED TO HAVE OCCURRED ON FEBRUARY 26, 2002.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON APRIL 16, 2002 AT 11:23 PM, THE OPERATOR ON DUTY AT NAVAJO REFINING COMPANY'S PIPELINE CONTROL ROOM OPENED A VALVE ON THE SCRAPER TRAP AT NAVAJO REFINING COMPANY'S LOVINGTON PUMP STATION.  WHEN THE VALVE CYCLED OPEN, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED A DROP IN THE STATION DISCHARGE PRESSURE, A DROP IN THE RECEIVING FLOW RATE, FOLLOWED BY A SCRAPER TRAP SUMP ALARM. THE OPERATOR SHUT DOWN THE LINE AT 11:25 PM.  THE OPERATOR THEN CALLED THE ON-CALL LOVINGTON TERMINAL TECHNICIAN AND THE ARTESIA CONTROL ROOM SUPERVISOR.  THE ON-CALL TERMINAL TECHNICIAN FOUND A SCRAPER TRAP BLEEDER VALVE IN THE OPEN POSITION.  THIS VALVE WAS INADVERTENTLY NOT LOCKED AND TAGGED OUT.  SUBSEQUENT TO THIS INCIDENT, NAVAJO'S PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN AMENDED TO REFLECT MORE SPECIFIC LOCKOUT/TAGOUT POLICIES AND CHANGES HAVE BEEN COMMUNICATED TO EMPLOYEES IN A SAFETY MEETING.

column245: RELEASE OCCURRED DUE TO AN IMPROPERLY FUNCTIONING PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE (PCV) AT PLANT 2 AIRPORT WHICH TRANSMITTED A PRESSURE SURGE (SPIKE) BACK TO THE PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE (PRV) ON MICRONIC FILTER #2 (MF2) AT SAND ISLAND. THIS CAUSED THE PRV ON MFT TO MONENTARILY OPEN TO RELEASE THE PRESSURE SURGE.  ONCE THE PRESSURE HAD DISSIPATED, THE VALVE ATTEMPTED TO CLOSE.  AT THIS POINT, IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT EITHER A SPECK OF DIRT OR RUST (DEBRIS) HAD LODGED ITSELF ON THE PRV VALVE SEAT PREVENTING POSITIVE VALVE CLOSURE THUS ALLOWING FUEL TO LEAK PAST THE PARTIALLY OPEN PRV INTO THE ONE INCH DRAIN LINE AND THEN INTO THE THREE INCH DRAIN PIPE LEADING TO AN AFL OIL WATER SEPARATOR APPROXIMATELY 50 TO 100 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE DRAIN.  THE ESCAPING FUEL OVERPOWERED THE THREE INCH DRAIN'S CABABILTY TO KEEP PACE WITH THE FLOW RATE THUS SPILLING OVER INTO THE SURROUNDING CONCRETE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT PAD, EVENTUALLY FILLING THE PAD TO CAPACITY AND THE PAD THEN OVERFLOWING ONTO THE SURROUNDING GROUND SURFACE WHICH IS ALSO WITHIN A SECONDARY CONTAINMENT. AREA.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE THREE INCH DRAIN LINE WAS PARTIALLY CLOGGED.  INVESTIGATIVE TEST RUNS FAILED TO DUPLICATE THE ORIGINAL RELEASE CONDITIONS.  THE PRV HAD BEEN REPLACED AS A PRECAUTION.  THE THREE INCH DRAIN HAS BEEN CLEARED OF ALL DEBRIS.  AS FOR THE PCV, AT PLANT 2, A PROCEDURE HAS BEEN PUTT INTO PLACE TO OVERCOME THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANY FUTURE PRESSURE SURGES BEING GENERATED FROM THE PCV.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: THE MAINLINE PUMP UNIT AT CENTENNIAL'S TUTWILER, MS PUMP STATION UNDERWENT INITIAL START-UP DURING THE MORNING OF MARCH 26, 2002. SUBSEQUENT TO INITIAL START-UP, THE PUMP UNIT WAS MONITORED BY COMPANY MAINTENANCE TECHNICIANS FOR APPROXIMATELY 3-4 HOURS. DURING THIS PERIOD, THE PUMP OPERATION WAS NORMAL. APPROXIMATELY NINE HOURS AFTER INITIAL START-UP, THE STATION OPERATOR VISUALLY NOTED PRODUCT LEAKAGE FROM THE PUMP UNIT. AT THIS TIME, THE PUMP UNIT WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED. IT WAS LATER DETERMINED THAT A TUBING FITTING, ASSOCIATED WITH THE PUMP INBOARD BEARING COOLING SYSTEM, HAD LEAKED RESULTING IN THE PRODUCT RELEASE. AFTER THOROUGH INVESTIGATION OF THE TUBING COMPONENT DESIGN AND INSTALLATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE TUBING FITTING HAD BEEN INSUFFICIENTLY TIGHTENED IN THE CONSTRUCTION PHASE. THE TUBE FITTING WAS REPAIRED, AND THE UNIT WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE. THE FITTING WAS TESTED DURING THE PUMP MANUFACTURER'S HYDROSTATIC TEST OF THE PUMP, AND WAS AGAIN SUBJECTED TO A 1 HOUR PNEUMATIC "PROOF TEST" UPON FINAL INSTALLATION. THE FACILITY IS OWNED BY CENTENNIAL PIPELINE LLC. 4/13/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. CAUSE WAS UPDATED FROM MISCELLANEOUS - TUBING FITTING INSUFFICIENTLY TIGHTENED DURING CONSTRUCTION PHASE AND INSTALLATION TO COMPONENT-FITTING WITH THE REMAINDER OF SECTION H5 FILLED OUT ACCORDINGLY.

column66: NIPPLE ON A VALVE CONNECTED TO PIPE
column245: WILLIAMS PIPE LINE COMPANY ENGAGED A CONTRACTOR TO DIG OUT A BURIED VALVE AND REPLACE IT WITH A GATE VALVE BOX.  THE BACKHOE OPERATOR USED THE BOTTOM OF THE BUCKET TO BRUSH LOOSE DIRT FROM THE TOP OF THE LINE INTO A DITCH HE HAD DUG ADJACENT TO THE BURIED VALVE.  WHILE BRUSHING AWAY LOOSE DIRT, THE HOE STRUCK A 3/4" NIPPLE CONNECTED TO A 3/4 BALL VALVE THAT PROTRUDED 8" FROM THE TOP OF THE LINE, RELEASING UNLEADED GASOLINE.  THE NIPPLE WAS INSTALLED BY THE PREVIOUS OWNED OF THE LINE DURING ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION IN 1957 AND WAS NOT IDENTIFIED ON AS-BUILT DRAWINGS.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LINE.  SORBENT BOOMS WERE PLACED ACROSS A NEARBY DRAINAGE DITCH AND A VACUUM TRUCK USED TO RECOVER LOST PRODUCT. THE DAMAGED NIPPLE WAS REMOVED AND A BULL PLUG WAS INSERTED INTO THE THREADED FITTING AND A TOR WELDED OVER IT FOR PROTECTION AND THE GATE VALVE BOX INSTALLED. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS, AND FRESH SOIL USED TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT.  THE REPAIRED LINE WAS HELD AT PRESSURE FOR SERVERAL HOURS TO CONFIRM ITS INTEGRITY AND THEN RETURNED TO SERVICE.

column176: OTHER LIQUID OR GAS TRANSMISSION PIPELINE OPERATOR OR THEIR CONTRACTOR
column245: ON MARCH 22, 2002 AT APPROXIMATELY 0816 HRS, SFPP LP'S PIPELINE WAS STRUCK BY A BACKHOE, PUNCTURING THE PIPELINE.  ON MARCH 1, 2002, KINDER MORGAN WAS CONTACTED VIA ARIZONA BLUE STAKE OF B & H CONSTRUCTION COMPANY - THE THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR WHO HIT OUR LINE - OF THEIR INTENTION TO EXCAVATE IN THE AREA CLOSE TO OUR PIPELINE ON PRICE ROAD.  KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL MET WITH B & H PERSONNEL AT THE SITE TO DISCUSS THE PROJECT AND THE PIPELINE WAS MARKED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE ROAD.  KINDER MORGAN WITNESSED THE CONTRACTOR EXCAVATING ON THE EAST SIDE OF ROAD AND INSTRUCTED THE CONTRACTOR TO NOTIFY US WHEN HE BEGAN EXCAVATING ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  AGAIN, ON MARCH 16, 2002, CONTRACTOR WAS INFORMED OF THE NECESSITY OF CONTACTING KINDER MORGAN PRIOR TO EXCAVATING ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE ROAD.  HOWEVER, NOTIFICATION WAS NEVER MADE.  NO ATTEMPTS WERE MADE BY THE CONTRACTOR TO ASCERTAIN THE PHYSICAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE BY "POT HOLING" OR OTHER MEANS PRIOR TO EXCAVATING IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF THE PIPELINE.  THE CONTRACTOR'S BACKHOE STRUCK THE PIPELINE.  B & H HAS ASSUMED FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE REMEDIATION EFFORTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE. 8-27-02 AS MENTIONED IN ORIGINAL REPOR OF THIS ACCIDENT, THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR WHO DAMAGED KINDER MORGAN PIPELINE ASSUMED RESPONSIBILITY FOR SITE REMEDIATION.  WHEN CONTRACTOR (B&H CONSTRUCTIONS) WAS APPROACHED BY KINDER MORGAN REGARDING COSTS EXPENDED ON REMEDIATION EFFORTS KINDER MORGAN WAS TOLD COSTS "APPROACHED 1,000,000" ALTHOUGH THESE COSTS WERE NOT BORN BY THE PIPELINE OPERATOR, THEY ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THE RELEASE.

column245: ENTERPRISE PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTORS WERE PERFORMING A CLOSE INTERVAL SURVEY THAT BEGAN ON TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 2002 THAT THE LEAK WAS FROM THE ENTERPRISE LOU-TEX 12" NGL PIPELINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND THE SECTION ISOLATED.  THE LINE SECTION IS TOTALLY CONTAINED WITHIN THE MARSH.  THE LINE WAS CLEARED OF PRODUCT AND PURGED WITH NITROGEN.  EXCAVATORS UNCOVERED THE LINE AND THE LEAKING PORTION WAS REMOVED AND A NEW PIECE WAS WELDED IN.  THE REMOVED PIECE OF PIPE WAS SENT OFF FOR ANALYSIS WITH THE RESULT BEING EXTERNAL CORROSION.

column238: HIGH PRESSURE HOSE CONNECTING PRESSURE TRANSMITTER TO LINE
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 21:00 HRS ON APRIL 11,2002, PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER NOTICED PRESSURE DROP AT GLEBURN STATION. ALL PUMPS ON LINE WERE SHUT DOWN AND AREA SUPERVISOR NOTIFIED. RESPONDING PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT 21:50 HRS AND CLOSED 3/4" VALVE TO ISOLATE LEAK. SPILL WAS FROM HIGH-PRESSURE HOSE THAT CONNECTED PRESSURE TRANSMITTER TO PIPELINE. HOSE HAD RUPTURED SPILLING APPROXIMATELY 25 BARRELS WITHIN DIKED AREA OF MANIFOLD. SOME OF CONTAINED FLUID WAS WATER FROM SNOWMELT AND RAIN SHOWERS. ESTIMATE OF AMOUNT CONTAINED ARRIVED AT BY LENGTH, WIDTH AND DEPTH MEASUREMENTS. HOSE REPLACED AND CRUDE OIL AND WATER RE-INJECTED INTO SYSTEM ON APRIL 12,2002. BY ALL OUTWARD APPEARANCE HOSE SEEMED SOUND.

column30: OTHER
column245: ON APRIL 24, 2002, BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY WAS PERFORMING AN INVESTIGATION OF A SUSPECTED ANOMALY IDENTIFIED DURING A SMART PIG RUN ON THE 701 PIPELINE NEAR MAINE, NEW YORK.  A BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY MAINTENANCE CREW HIT WHAT WAS DETERMINED TO BE AN UNAUTHORIZED TAP EXTENSION ON THE PIPELINE WHILE EXCAVATING THE SITE.  THE 701 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY AND BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED.  THE TIOGA COUNTY SHERIFF DEPARTMENT AND THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION WERE NOTIFIED OF THE UNAUTHORIZED TAP EXTENSION.  THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION HAS INITIATED A CRIMINAL INVESTIGATION INTO THE UNAUTHORIZED TAP EXTENSION.  THE UNAUTHORIZED TAP EXTENSION WAS REMOVED AND THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED AND RESTARTED ON APRIL 25, 2002.  CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION.

column245: ON MARCH 31,2002,THE OPERATOR ON DUTY AT KINDER MORGAN'S RICHMOND TERMINAL, CHANGED FLOW PATHS FROM ONE PIPELINE SYSTEM TO ANOTHER AT APPROXIMATELY 10:18 A.M. PST. AFTER THE "SWITCH", STATION PERSONNEL OBSERVED THE MANIFOLD AREA AND DID NOT OBSERVE ANY PROBLEMS. AT APPROXIMATELY, 11:24 A.M. THE OPERATOR ON DUTY OBSERVED PRODUCT BEING RELEASED IN OUR MANIFOLD AREA VIA A VIDEO MONITORING CAMERA. EMERGENCY ACTIONS, INCLUDING SHUTTING DOWN THE PIPELINE BEGAN IMMEDIATELY. CLEAN UP AND REMEDIATION BEGAN AS SOON AS THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS TERMINATED. UPON INSPECTION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN ASBESTOS GASKET IN 8" FLANGES WAS LEAKING PRODUCT. ORIGINALLY THE DAMAGE WAS BELIEVED TO BE LIMITED TO THE IMMEDIATE ON-SITE FACILITIES. HOWEVER, ONE APRIL 3, THE CALIFORNIA FISH AND GAME NOTIFIED KINDER MORGAN THAT SHEEN WAS OBSERVED ON A NEARBY SLOUGH. IT WAS SUBSEQUENTLY DETERMINED THAT APPROXIMATELY 1 BARREL OF DIESEL ENTERED A STORM DRAIN THAT OPENED INTO THE SLOUGH. RESPONSE AND CLEAN UP THE SLOUGH CAUSE THE ESTIMATED DAMAGES TO EXCEED $50,000.

column245: A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR FOR ALABAMA POWER COMPANY DAMAGED THE PIPELINE WHILE USING HEAVY EQUIPMENT TO INSTALL HIGH VOLTAGE POWERLINES.  IT WAS DISCOVERED, THAT THE CONTRACTORS TRACKHOE WAS STUCK IN THE RIGHT-OF-WAY MUCK AND USED THE BUCKET TO FREE ITSELF FROM THE MUCK.    COMMENT H-3(F): THE LINE LOCATION COULD NOT BE PHYSICALLY MARKED DUE TO SEVERAL FEET OF STANDING WATER WAS PRESENT ALONG THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY. INSTEAD, THE CONTRACTOR SUPERVISOR WAS VISUALLY SHOWN THE APPROXIMATE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE IN ASSOCIATION TO THE POWERLINE ACTIVITIES.

column245: AT 1000 HRS, 4/17/02 CITGO PRODUCTS PIPELINE WAS NOTIFIED OF A LEAK CAUSED BY A THIRD PARTY, ON OUR 10" EAGLE LINE SECTION, JUST NORTH OF WACO, TX.  PERMANENT MARKERS VISIBLE FROM EXCAVATION SITE, UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM.  THE PIPELINE WAS DOWN AT THE TIME OF THE DAMAGE AND THE DAMAGED SECTION WAS ISOLATED BY CLOSING MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES AT WACO STATION ON SOUTH AND ROSS STATION ON THE NORTH.  THIS ISOLATED A 13 MILE SECTION.  CITGO PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO THE SITE AND NOTIFIED OUR SUPPORT CONTRACTORS OF OUR REQUIRED SUPPORT NEEDS.  AFTER SECURING THE SITE AND MAKING THE EXCAVATION SAFE FOR MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES, THE LEAK WAS CLAMPED AND THE PRODUCT FLOW WAS STOPPED AT 14OO HRS.  AT 1430 HRS, AFTER A FULL EVALUATION, WE DETERMINED THAT THE DAMAGE WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  AT 1503 HRS, WE REPORTED THE INCIDENT TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER.  REPORT #599939

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL SAFETY & REGULATORY COMPLI
column245: ON APRIL 29, 2002, THE PUMPS AT ROXANA STATION WERE SHUT DOWN AT 11:09 AM BY LOCAL PRESSURE SWITCHES THAT DETECTED LOW SUCTION PRESSURE.  COMPUTATIONAL PIPELINE MONITORING (CPM)ALARMS ALSO IDENTIFIED THE RELEASE AT THE MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE LLC (MAPL) CONTROL CENTER AND THE OZARK CONTROL CENTER.  THE OPERATOR AT OZARK REACTED TO THE CPM ALARMS HE RECEIVED AND SHUT THE OZARK SYSTEM DOWN WITHIN 15 MINUTES.      AERIAL PATROL WAS USED TO LOCATE THE RELEASE.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS INITIATED IN LESS THAN ONE HOUR FROM THE SHUTDOWN, AND APPROPRIATE AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  MAPL AND CONTRACT PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT WERE DISPATCHED TO THE RELEASE SITE TO INITIATE OIL CONTAINMENT AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS.  AN INTEGRATED INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM WAS SET-UP ON SITE.     DURING THE APRIL 2002 EVENT, OIL FLOWED THROUGH AN UNDERGROUND FIELD TILE AND ENTERED INTO INDIAN CREEK.  CONTAINMENT BOOMS WERE DEPLOYED AND EARTHEN CONTAINMENT STRUCTURES WERE INSTALLED TO CONTAIN THE OIL.  THERE WERE NO IMPACTS TO WILDLIFE OR THE GENERAL PUBLIC.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS COLLECTED AND TRANSPORTED TO A LANDFILL FOR PROPER DISPOSAL PER ILLINOIS EPA WASTE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS.      THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  PER ANALYSIS BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, IN A REPORT TITLED "INVESTIGATION OF CAUSE OF FAILURE THE FAILURE OF WOODPAT CRUDE OIL PIPELINE" DATED JULY 22, 2002, THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY HYDROGEN CRACK INITIATION AND PROPAGATION THROUGH THE HEAT AFFECTED ZONE OF THE ELECTRIC-RESISTANCE-WELDED (ERW) LONGITUDINAL SEAM OF THE PIPE.  THE HYDROGEN CRACK WAS NOT PRESENT AT THE TIME OF ORIGINAL MANUFACTURE BUT APPEARS TO HAVE DEVELOPED WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF ATOMIC HYDROGEN INTO THE PIPELINE STEEL OVER TIME.  THE LABORATORY REPORT WAS SENT UNDER SEPARATE COVER TO MR. IVAN HUNTOON, DIRECTOR, CENTRAL REGION, OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY AUGUST 7, 2002.  OPS OVERSIGHT OF THE EVENT CONTINUES PER CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER CPF 3-2002-5007H.      THE REGULATORY REMEDIATION HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND A NO FURTHER ACTION (NFA) LETTER DATED APRIL 2004 FROM THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY.   IN DECEMBER 2005,MPL COMPLETED ITS ADDITIONAL REMEDIATION/RESTORATION BEYOND WHAT IS REGULATORY REQUIRED AT THE REQUEST OF LANDOWNERS.        4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. NAME OF HCA/HPA WAS SPELLED INCORRECTLY.  WAS ROXANNE INSTEAD OF ROXANNA.

column245: AERIAL PATROL SERVICE REPORTED SEEING DEAD VEGETATION ON RIGHT OF WAY DURING REGULARLY SCHEDULED AERIAL PATROL INSPECTION.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION AND EXCAVATION DISCOVERED LEAK FROM THE PIPELINE SEAM JOINT.  THE LINE HAD BEEN IDLE SINCE THE PREVIOUS DELIVERY AND HAD MINIMAL PRESSURE AT THE TIME.  THE SECTION OF LINE WITH THE DEFECT WAS REMOVED FROM THE LINE AND REPLACED WITH NEW, PRE-TESTED PIPE, ALL IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL PIPELINE REGULATIONS.  CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS.  NEW, CLEAN SOIL WAS USED IN ITS PLACE.  METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS DETERMINED THE CAUSE WAS MOST LIKELY FROM A MANUFACTURING DEFECT IN THE PIPE SEAM DURING MANUFACTURE OF THE PIPE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AN ELECTRICAL STORM IN THE AREA OF OUR KMEP WICHITA PUMP STATION CAUSED A POWER OUTAGE THAT IN TURNED SHUTDOWN OUR PUMP.  DURING THIS PROCESS, OUR UPSTREAM DELIVERY CUSTOMER CONTINUED TO PUMP INTO OUR STATION.  THEIR STATION IS SEVERAL MILES REMOTE TO OURS.  A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE ACTIVATED AND MOMENTARILY VENTED PRODUCT TO A FOUR HUNDRED AND SIXTY GALLON UNDERGROUND ACCUMULATOR.  THE PRODUCT RESIDING WITHIN THE ACCUMULATOR VAPORIZED AND VENTED THROUGH THE SYSTEM'S VENT STACK.  A SUBSEQUENT LIGHTING STRIKE IN THE VICINITY OF OUR VENT STACK IGNITED THE VAPORS.  ONCE ALL VAPORS WERE BURNED OFF THE FLASH FIRE WAS SELF EXTINGUISHED SINCE THE RELIEF VALVE HAD ALREADY RESEATED AND WAS NO LONGER VENTING PRODUCT.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 7:25 A.M.(CST) AN EMPLOYEE NOTICED A PATCHY COVERING OF FOG-LIKE SUBSTANCE ON THE GROUND JUST OUTSIDE THE COMPANY'S CONWAY PUMP STATION, WHERE THIS LATERAL LINE BEGINS.  SUBSEQUENT EXCAVATION DISCOVERED A LEAK.  STOPPIES WERE SET AND APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET OF NEW PIPE WAS INSTALLED AND THE LINE RETURNED TO SERVICE. THE DAMAGED SPECIMEN WAS SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  PRELIMINARY FAILURE ANALYSIS RESULTS INDICATE THERE WAS INADEQUATE WELD MATERIAL BETWEEN THE PIPE ENDS AROUND THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION OF THE GIRTH WELD, WHEREBY THE POOR QUALITY OF THE GIRTH WELD RESULTED IN A FABRICATED GAP WHICH FACILITATED CIRCUMFERENTIAL CREVICE CORROSION ON THE PIPE INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR SURFACES.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF FATIGUE OR OVERLOADING IN THE GIRTH WELD.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: FNF CONSTRUCTION, CONTRACTOR DOING WORK ON STATE HWY 54 WAS IN PROCESS OF REPLACING A CATTLE GUARD.  IN THE PROCESS OF DIGGING OUT OLD CATTLE GUARD, THE EQUIPMENT OPERATOR STRUCK THE PIPELINE, CAUSING TWO PUNCTURES OF APPROXIMATELY 2 1/2 INCHES IN DIAMETER EACH, AND PUTTING A BEND IN THE PIPE.  THIS INCIDENT TOOK PLACE IN THE RAILROAD ROW, NOT THE HIGHWAY ROW.  THE PRODUCT SPILLED WAS JP-8 JET FUEL, QUANTITY SPILLED IS UNDETERMINED (3,800 GALLONS RECOVERED IN VAC TRUCK), PRODUCT POOLED IN GENERAL VICINITY OF DAMAGE.  (GENERAL ESTIMATE BY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, TO INCLUDE RECOVERED PORTION ON VAC TRUCK, OF APPROXIMATELY 250 TO 300 BARRELS). LELAND BAIN, TERMINAL MANAGER, NOTIFIED OUR SPILL CONTRACTOR, THREW A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE IN HIS TRUCK, AND STARTED DRIVING TOWARD BLOCK VALVES.  HE CALLED SAM HERRERA (DESC-QSR) AND LARRY ELLIS (GM-CONTRACTS) IN TRANSIT TO NOTIFY.  LARRY ELLIS BEGAN NOTIFYING THE REGULATORY AGENCIES.  LELAND CLOSED THE NEAREST BLOCK VALVES TO THE NORTH AND SOUTH OF THE INCIDENT LOCATION, ASSESSED THE SITE, THERE WAS NO IMMINENT DANGER TO PERSONS OR PROPERTY.  WHEN THE RESPONSE CONTRACTOR ARRIVED THEY BEGAN RECOVERING LIQUID WITH VAC TRUCK AND DUG OUT AROUND THE DAMAGED PIPE.  THEY DETERMINED THAT THE PIPE WAS TOO SEVERELY DAMAGED FOR THE PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE TO WORK.  THEY OBTAINED A CLAMP REFERRED TO AS A FULL AROUND, AND CLAMPED THE DAMAGED AREA AS A TEMPORARY FIX TO STOP THE LEAK ONLY, NOT TO OPERATE THE PIPELINE.  APPROXIMATELY 11 FEET OF DAMAGED PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPELINE.

column245: WELD ON MOUNTING BRACKET FOR CYCLONE SEPARATOR MOUNTED ON PUMP BROKE, CAUSING ADDED WEIGHT AND VIBRATION ON TUBING FITTING GOING TO SEAL FLUSH.  TUBING PULLED LOOSE IN FITTING CAUSING LEAK.  LEAK RAN FOR A PERIOD OF TIME.  IT WAS FOUND BY BP OIL REFINERY PERSONNEL MAKING DAILY ROUNDS.  REPORTED TO PIPELINE AT 1410. THE STATION IS LOCATED WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF TEXAS CITY, TO QUALIFY FOR AN HCA, BUT THE PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED ON THE COMPANY PROPERTY.

column245: EL REAL PUMP STATION WAS PUMPING DISPLACEMENT OIL (AKA GAS OIL) TO FLUSH A SECTION OF PIPELINE.  PRIMARY PUMP #3 WAS ONE OF THE PUMPS USED FOR THIS OPERATION.  THE STATION OPERATOR SHUT THE STATION DOWN UPON COMPLETION OF THE OPERATION AND NOTICED OIL LEAKING FROM THE DISCHARGE OF PRIMARY PUMP #3. THE OPERATOR MANUALLY CLOSED SUCTION AND DISCHARGE BLOCK VALVES TO ISOLATE THE LEAK.  THE OIL WAS CONTAINED TO THE CONCRETE PUMP PAD THAT IS GRADED TO DRAIN TO CONCRETE RAINWATER SUMP.  INSPECTION REVEALED A BROKEN 3/4" NIPPLE USED TO CONNECT A 3/4" X 1" PRESSURE SAFETY VALVE TO A WELDOLET LOCATED ON THE DISCHARGE SIDE OF PRIMARY PUMP #3.  INITIAL ESTIMATE OF QUANTITY OF DISPLACEMENT OIL SPILLED WAS 20 BARRELS.  A CONTRACTOR WAS CALLED OUT FOR CLEANUP.  PIPING AND PAD WERE WASHED TO THE RAINWATER SUMP THEN THE SUMP WAS DRAINED AND WASHED.  DECANTING RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 20 BARRELS OIL WHICH WAS PUMPED INTO THE DISPLACEMENT OIL TANK AT EL REAL.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: THE KCPL 8" LINE EXPERIENCED A FAILURE ON 5/22/02 AT 0750 HOURS.  AT THAT TIME A PRESSURE LOSS WAS INDICATED IN CPL'S HOUSTONS CONTROL CENTER.  PER EMERGENCY REPSONSE PROCEDURES, THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND OPERATING PERSONNEL DISPATCHED TO RESPOND TO A POSSIBLE RELEASE.  ADDITIONAL, THE LOCAL AREA SUPERVISOR ENGAGED AREA EMERGENCY REPSONSE AGENCIES TO AID IN THE LOCATING THE RELEASE SITE. AT 0936 HOURS, THE FAILURE LOCATION WAS IDENTIFIED BY THE LOCAL RESPONDERS.  THE LINE SEGMENT WAS FURTHER ISOLATED AT THIS TIME BY CLOSING THE CLOSEST MANUAL BLOCK VALVES.  CONTAINMENT AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS BEGAN AT THAT POINT.        PRELIMINARY FINDING FROM THE METALLURGICAL REPORT INDICATE THE CAUSE TO BE SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION.  FURTHER ANALYSIS IS BEING CONDUCTED AND A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT UPON COMPLETION OF METALLURGICAL REPORT WILL BE FILED. ALONG WITH THE SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT FINAL LOSSES (A-5) WILL BE COMPLETED.     FAILURE ANAYLSIS REPORT WAS RECEIVED ON 7/24/02 FROM SHERRY LABORATORIES.  FINAL CONCLUSION OF FAILURE:  THE FAILURE OF THE SEAM WELD WAS DUE TO LACK OF FUSION OF THE WELD DURING THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS.

column238: 3RD PARTY TUG BOAT OPERATING IN AREA HIT AND DAMAGED PIPELINE.
column245: LEAK DISCOVERED AND VERIFIED IN THE ROW CONTAINING TWO CTPC 6" PIPELINES & ONE CTPC 10" PIPELINE. 10" PIPELINE ISOLATED & THE TWO 6" P/LS REMAINED FLOWING. CRUDE OIL STOPPED COMING TO THE SURFACE. CREWS THEN ISOLATED THE TWO 6" LINES & RETURNED 10" LINE TO SERVICE. CRUDE OIL BEGAN LEAKING TO SURFACE AGAIN. 10" LINE WAS SUSPECTED TO BE LEAKING. FROM 6/4 THRU 6/6, 10" LINE REMAINED ISOLATED AT NIGHT & ALL FLOW WAS DIVERTED INTO THE TWO 6" PIPELINES. AERIAL SURVEILLANCE EACH MORNING REPORTED NO SHEEN TO WATER. ON 6/7/02, DIVERS DISCOVERED TWO DENT/GOUGES ON ONE OF THE 6" LINES BETWEEN DIXON BAY JUNCTION & WEST BAY STATION. ONE DENT MEASURING 1" IN LENGTH AND 1/2" DEEP RESULTED IN THE EVENTUAL RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL. SPILL WAS CONFIRMED TO BE FROM THE 6" LINE AT COORD 29 06.49 & 89 21.67. TOTAL SPILL VOLUME ESTIMATED AT 0.84 GALLONS (LESS THAN 1 BARREL). DISIPATED QUICKLY, NONE RECOVERED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT, THE SUBJECT METER STATION WAS SHUT-IN.  THE 1-INCH X 1-INCH THERMAL RELIEF VALVE PROTECTING THE FILTER VESSEL RELIEVED A LOW VOLUME OF ETHYLENE PRODUCT TO THE FACILITY VENT SYSTEM.  THE FACILITY VENT SYSTEM EMPTIES TO THE ATMOSPHERE VIA THE VENT STACK WHICH IS LOCATED NEAR THE FACILITY FENCE LINE AND IS ELEVATED ABOVE THE METER STATION APPROXIMATELY 20-FEET.  THE RELIEF VALVE CONTINUED TO SEEP A SMALL VOLUME OF PRODUCT TO THE VENT STACK UNTIL OPERATIONS PERSONNEL ISOLATED THE RELIEF VALVE.  SOMETIME AFTER THE RELEASE BEGAN THE PRODUCT WAS IGNITED AT THE TOP OF THE VENT BY AN UNKNOWN IGNITION SOURCE.

column235: INCORRECT GASKET INSTALLED DURING ORIGINAL DELIVER
column245: THE SUBJECT RELEASE OCCURRED ON A PIPELINE TERMINAL DELIVERY LINE.  THE SPECIFIC LOCATION WAS AT AN ABOVE GROUND VALVE AT THE END OF THE DELIVERY LINE ON THE SHIPPER CUSTOMERS PROPERTY WHERE THE PIPELINE EXITS THE GROUND.  THE UPSTREAM FLANGE OF THE VALVE WAS LEAKING GASOLINE WHEN DISCOVERED.  THE DELIVERY LINE INCLUDING THE END OF PIPELINE VALVE IS OWNED AND OPERATED BY PLANTATION PIPE LINE CO.  THE FLANGE BOLTS WERE TIGHTENED WHICH STOPPED THE LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY COMPANY PERSONNEL WHILE PERFORMING ROUTINE MAINTENANCE.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY THE DELIVERY LINE WAS NOT OPERATING.  THE LAST DELIVERY ON THIS PIPELINE ENDED AT 05:00 THE MORNING OF JUNE 11, 2002 THAT IS WAS A SMALL SURFACE SPILL THAT HAD NOT IMPACTED ANY STREAM, RIVER, LAKE RESERVOIR, OR OTHER SIMILAR BODY OF WATER.  BASED UPON THE VISUAL OBSERVATION OF THE LEAK SITE, THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OR EXPECTATIONS THE PROPERTY DAMAGE FROM THE LEAK WOULD GENERATE COSTS THAT WOULD COME CLOSE TO OR EXCEED $50,000.  AFTER SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION WOULD BE NEEDED.  BECAUSE OF THE NEED FOR A SUB-SURFACE INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THE PROPERTY DAMAGE COSTS FROM THE LEAK HAD THE POTENTIAL TO APPROACH OR EXCEED $50,000. THIS DETERMINATION WAS MADE THE MORNING OF JUNE 14TH, TO WHICH PLANTATION PIPE LINE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER.  THE AMOUNT AND DURATION OF THE LEAK IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME.

column245: AT 0835 THE P-52 LINE WAS STARTED UP IN JET-A SERVICE.  AT 0930, THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN DUE TO AN OVER/SHORT DISCREPANCY OF 190 BBLS.  AT 0955 THE HOUSTON FIRE DEPARTMENT REPORTED A POSSIBLE OIL LEAK AND A FIRE AT CHARPOIT LANE.  BAYTOWN PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND SHUT THE APPROPRIATE MLV'S AND UPON ARRIVAL AT THE LOCATION, A FIRE WAS BURNING AS A RESULT OF A THIRD PARTY BURNING BRUSH ON TOP OF THE PIPELINE.  ONCE HFD HAD PUT OUT THE FIRE, TEPPCO PERSONNEL BEGAN EXCAVATING THE AREA AND LOCATED THE LEAK, WHICH WAS DETERMINED TO BE FROM THIRD PARTY DAMAGE.  EXCAVATION AND EARTH MOVING EQUIPMENT WERE ON THE CONSTRUCTING A HOUSE PAD.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL WAS DISCOVERED ON THE COMMON DISCHARGE PIPING FROM PUMP UNITS 8 AND 9 AT THE RED BUTTE PIPE LINE BYRON, WY STATION.  ON THE DISCHARGE HEADER TO THE SILVERTIP SCRAPER TRAP, A CRACK DEVELOPED IN A 6" 600# FLANGE, ACROSS A WELD, AND INTO A 6" X 12" REDUCER.  AN ESTIMATED 13.5 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED, OF WHICH 10 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED ON THE RED BUTTE STATION PROPERTY.  THE FAILED COMPONENTS - THE 6" FLANGE AND 6" X 12" REDUCER  WERE CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A NEW FLANGE AND REDUCER.  THE FAILED FLANGE/REDUCER WILL BE ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  11-18-02 THE FAILED FLANGE/REDUCER WAS ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.  THE PRINCIPAL CAUSE WAS FATIGUE IN SERVICE.  A CRACK INITIATED AT AN IMPERFECTION (WELDER'S BURN-THROUGH IN THE ROOT PASS) IN THE GIRTH WELD JOINING THE FLANGE AND REDUCER.  THE INITIATION AND PROPAGATION OF THE CRACK WAS A RESULT OF CYCLICAL SERVICE LOADINGS SUCH AS WHAT COULD OCCUR WITH MECHANICAL VIBRATION OR PRESSURE PULSATION EFFECTS FROM PUMP OPERATIONS.  POST FAILURE EXAMINATIONS OF THE GIRTH WELD IMPERFECTION DID NOT REVEAL THAT THE BURN-THROUGH WOULD HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED REJECTIONABLE BY THE CRITERIA IN API 1104.  THE FATIGUE LOADING OF THE MANIFOLD WAS REDUCED BY REMOVING A SPOOL PIECE CONTAINING A 6" BLOCK  VALVE AND A 6" CHECK VALVE.      04-07-2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  -LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE UPDATED TO DECIMAL DEGREES. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE PREVIOUSLY REPORTED WERE CORRECT, JUST NOT IN THE PREFERRED FORMAT  -SOMETIME FOLLOWING THE RELEASE, THE STATION PIPING WAS REPLACED.  CURRENT RECORDS DO NOT INDICATE IF THE PREVIOUS PIPING WHERE THE RELEASE OCCURRED WAS PREVIOUSLY HYDROTESTED OR NOT, SO "NO" WAS INDICATED IN H5-C DUE TO LACK OF INFORMATION TO SHOW OTHERWISE.  -HIGHLIGHTED ENTRIES ARE WHAT CHANGED FROM THE PREVIOUS SUBMISSION.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: ON JULY 4, 2002 AT APPROXIMATELY 00:12 MST, LINE 4 AT MP 1002.7 EXPERIENCED A FAILURE IN A REMOTE OPEN WETLAND AREA.  THE AREA OF THE RELEASE WAS AT A LOCATION WEST OF THE CITY OF COHASSET, MN.  APPROXIMATELY 6,000 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELASED AS A RESULT OF THE RUPTURE.  IN AN EFFORT TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACT TO THE SURROUNDING ENVIRONMENT, A CONTROLLED BURN OF THE CRUDE OIL WAS EXECUTED IN COORDINATION WITH COMPANY, LOCAL AND STATE OFFICIALS.  ON JULY 4, 2002 AT APPROXIMATELY 1445 MST IGNITION OF THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL TOOK PLACE.  RESIDENTS FROM APPROXIMATELY 10 HOMES WERE EVACUATED FROM THE SURROUNDING AREA AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE.  THERE WERE NO INJURIES AS A RESULT OF THE RELEASE OR FROM THE CONTROLLED BURN.  NO WATERWAYS WERE IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON JUNE 29, 2002 AT 6:00 HRS, CENTRAL CONTROL RECEIVED NOTIFICATION FROM AN OFF DUTY FIREMAN, WHO WAS DRIVING BY THE COMPANY'S OUTSTATION ON THE COLORADO SPRINGS TO DENVER PRODUCTS PIPELINE, THAT THERE WAS PRODUCT SPRAYING INSIDE THE FENCE TO THE FACILITY.  CENTRAL CONTROL, WHICH WAS OBSERVING FLOW DISCREPANCY ON THIS LINE SEGMENT, IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED THE TERMINAL MGR, TO THE SITE.  IN THE MEANTIME, CENTRAL CONTROL BEGAN CLOSING REMOTE BLOCK VALVES ON THIS LINE SEGMENT.  ON ARRIVAL AT THE SITE, THE TERMINAL MGR. ASSESSED THE RELEASE AND DETERMINED THAT IT WAS SPRAYING FROM THE 3/8" STAINLESS TUBING CONNECTING THE PIPELINE TO THE OUTSTATION.  FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL, WHO WERE STANDING BY WITH LOCAL POLICE DEPARTMENT OFFICERS, WERE INSTRUCTED TO CLOSE THE 1" BALL VALVE ON THE PIPELINE AND UPSTREAM OF THE BROKEN TUBING LEADING TO THE OUTSTATION, WHICH ISOLATED THE FACILITY AND STOPPED THE FLOW.  THERE WAS NO EVACUATION BU THE DIRT ROAD ADJACENT TO THE OUTSTATION WAS BLOCKED OFF FROM THE PUBLIC.  IN THE MEANTIME INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE, INCLUDING THE CALL TO THE NRC.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT 157 BARRELS OF JET TURBINE FUEL HAD ESCAPED FROM THE PIPELINE THROUGH THE BROKEN 3/8" SEGMENT OF STAINLESS STEEL TUBING CONNECTING THE PIPELINE TO THE OUTSTATION.  NO PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND SOIL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.  AT THIS DATE, JULY 29, 2002, REMEDIATION HAS BEEN ACCOMPLISHED AND CLOSURE WITH THE EPA IS IMMINENT (VERBAL HAS BEEN GRANTED).     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW PROJECT SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: THE LANDOWNER/FARMER WAS SURVEYING HIS CROPS AND OBSERVED A STAIN ON THE GROUND. HE THEN NOTIFIED THE KANEB PIPE LINE (KANEB) CONTROL CENTER AT WHICH TIME THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND AN INVESTIGATION WAS UNDERTAKEN IMMEDIATELY.  KANEB PERSONNEL WERE ABLE TO EXCAVATE THE AREA AND DETERMINE THERE WAS AN APPARENT LEAK.  SUBSEQUENT TO THE RESPONSE AND REPAIR OPERATIONS, THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO METALLURGICAL CONSULTANTS, INC. (MCI) IN HOUSTON, TEXAS FOR EXAMINATION AND TESTING.  MCI HAS INDICATED THAT LIGHTENING WAS THE CAUSE OF THE PINHOLE LEAK.  SPECIFIC AND/OR ESTIMATED INFORMATION REGARDING THE RELEASE QUANTITY, DURATION OF THE RELEASE, ANTICIPATED ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION EXPENSES ARE NOT AVAILABLE AT THIS TIME.  ADDITIONAL PERTINENT INFORMATION WILL BE PROVIDED IN FUTURE SUPPLEMENTAL REPORTS.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: THE ACCIDENT OCCURRED AT THE ¿600¿ MANIFOLD OF MONTELLO PUMP STATION AND BREAKOUT TANK FARM.  THIS MANIFOLD CONTAINS SEVERAL LOW-PRESSURE BOOSTER PUMPS THAT ARE USED TO PUMP PRODUCT FROM BREAKOUT TANKS TO HIGH-PRESSURE MAIN LINE PUMPS LOCATED IN ANOTHER SECTION OF THE PUMP STATION.  THE VALVE BODY OF A DARLING GATE VALVE (VALVE NO. 696), LOCATED ON THE BOOSTER PUMP DISCHARGE MANIFOLD, FAILED DUE TO OVERPRESSURE FROM HIGH-PRESSURE BLEEDING OFF THE MAIN LINE PUMP DISCHARGE MANIFOLD.  THE DARLING GATE VALVE, RATED AT 200 PSI WORKING PRESSURE, WAS SUBJECT TO A PRESSURE OF 1,080 PSI THAT WAS BLEEDING ACROSS A BLOCK VALVE AND 2 CHECK VALVES.     THE IMMEDIATE CAUSE IS THE OVERPRESSURE OF THE DARLING GATE VALVE NO. 696.  A SECOND IMMEDIATE CAUSE IS THE INTERNAL SEALING FAILURE OF BLOCK VALVE NO. 138 AND 2 CHECK VALVES ON THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE OF NO. 2 MAIN LINE PUMP.    THE FAILED VALVE HAS BEEN REPLACED AND THE INTERNALLY LEAKING GATE AND CHECK VALVES ARE BEING REMOVED, EXAMINED AND REPAIRED OR REPLACED PRIOR TO THE SECTION OF THE MANIFOLD WHERE THE OVERPRESSURE OCCURRED GOING BACK INTO SERVICE.

column245: ACCIDENT OCCURRED WHILE EQUIPMENT OPERATOR WAS GRADING RIGHT-OF-WAY DURING PIPELINE REPLACEMENT PROJECT.  OPERATOR HIT A 4" RISER ON PIPELINE THAT WAS PREVIOUSLY UNKNOWN AND WAS NOT IDENTIFIED ON ATLAS SHEET. EQUIPMENT OPERATOR IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED PACIFIC PIPELINE PERSONNEL OF INCIDENT.  OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE.  LINE WAS OPERATING AT APPROXIMATELY 300 BARRELS PER HOUR AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON JUNE 13, 2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 HOURS, A GASOLINE SPILL WAS DISCOVERED BY A COMPANY PIPELINE TECHNICIAN AT WYNNEWOOD TERMINAL, THE TERMINATION POINT OF THE ARDMORE TO WYNNEWOOD 12" PRODUCTS PIPELINE.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, AND PIPELINE SAFETY, THEN THE NRC WAS CALLED AT 15:10HRS.  THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 1 HOUR EARLIER WHEN A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE SET AT 720 PSI POPPED AT 550 PSI, FLOWING TO THE SUMP THEN OVERFLOWING TO A LOW SPOT ON SITE AND POOLING.  THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING A SECONDARY VALVE.  LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND RECOVERED 25 BARRELS OF THE 30 THAT WAS RELEASED FROM THE SUMP.  A SITE ASSESSMENT HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND THE COMPANY IS AWAITING RESULTS TO THEN DIRECT SOIL REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES.  COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $3000.  NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY ELIMINATING THE REDUNDANT VALVE AND REPIPING THE DRAIN LINE INTO TANKAGE.

column245: AT 13:01 THE HIGH-HIGH ALARM ON THE SUMP FOR THE COALESCERS ACTIVATED.  THE CONTROL CENTER SHUT DOWN THE ORION LINE AT 13:03.  EAST HOUSTON PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A MIS-ALIGNED VALVE ALLOWING THE COALESCERS TO DRAIN TO SUMP RATHER THAN TANK 300, WHICH RESULTED IN AN APPROXIMATE 10 BBL RELEASE OF GASOLINE TO THE GROUND SURROUNDING THE SUMP. THE SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED AND THE SUMP WAS FILLED WITH WATER TO HELP ELIMINATE VAPORS.   NO WATERS WERE AFFECTED. IMPACTED SOIL WILL BE DISPOSED OF.   UPSET REPORT WILL BE FAXED TO TNRCC REGION 12 WITHIN 24 HOURS OF RELEASE.   NO OTHER AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.    NOTE:  ACTUAL DURATION OF LEAK WAS 15 MINUTES--SYSTEM WOULD NOT ALLOW INPUT OF HOURS IN FRACTIONS.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 20:00 ON 6/1/02, LANDOWNER GARLAND WADE NOTIFIED THE KOCH PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER (PCC) IN WICHITA, KS OF AN AMMONIA ODOR ON HIS PROPERTY.  THE PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS REDUCED BY THE PCC AND A KOCH REPRESENTATIVE WAS DISPATHCED TO THE SITE.  THE KOCH REPRESENTATIVE FOUND AN AMMONIA ODOR AND SOME DISTRESSED VEGETATION AT THE SITE.  NO VISIBLE VAPORS WERE PRESENT.  THE PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED BY CLOSING THE NEAREST UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES FROM THE AFFECTED AREA.  DUE TO NO VISIBLE VAPORS OR IMMEDIATE THREAT TO KOCH OR LOCAL PERSONNEL, THE DECISION WAS MADE TO MONITOR THE SITE OVERNIGHT AND MOBILIZE AN EXVACATION AND STOPPLE CREW TO BEGIN WORK IN THE DAYLIGHT HOURS OF 6/3/02.  ON 6/3/02 AFTER SUCCESSFUL STOPPLING AND REMOVAL ANHYDROUS AMMONIA FROM THE AFFECTED SEGMENT, A SMALL HOLE WAS FOUND IN THE PIPE.  THE .0004" IS THE APPRENET RESULT OF AN LIGHTNING STRIKE THAT TRAVELED THROUGH TREE ROOTS AND JUMPED TO THE PIPELINE.  THE AFFECTED SECTION OF PIPE WAS OUT AND REPLACED.  THE CUT OUT WILL BE SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS.

column245: ON JULY 25, 2002, A BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY EMPLOYEE WAS TRANSFERRING JP8 THROUGH A 1" NEEDLE VALVE TO A TANK USED TO MIX ADDITIVE.  THE TRANSFER OPERATION WAS LEFT UNATTENDED WHILE THE EMPLOYEE CONDUCTED OTHER WORK.  WHEN THE EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO THE TRANSFER OPERATION, THE TANK HAD OVERFLOWED AND PRODUCT HAD ESCAPED FROM THE CONCRETE TANK DIKE THROUGH A PARITIALLY OPEN TANK DIKE VALVE.  THE STATION WAS SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY AND THE TANK DIKE VALVE WAS CLOSED.  THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WERE NOTIFIED.  CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF A MASSACHUSETTS LICENSED SITE PROFESSIONAL AND THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMANTAL RESOURCES.    I ENTERED "0" INTO THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT POINT OF AND TIME OF ACCIDENT AND ALSO IN THE MOP AT TIME OF ACCIDENT FIELDS.  THIS SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME FINILIZE THIS REPORT WITHOUT THESE 2 FIELDS BEING COMPLETED AND WOULD NOT ACCEPT "N/A" IN THE FIELDS.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: THE PIPELINE WAS SHIPPING PRODUCT FROM A REFINERY AT COFFEYVILLE, KANSAS, TO WILLIAMS PIPE LINE COMPANY FACILITY IN KANSAS CITY. PUMPING UNITS WERE BEING STARTED IN SEQUENCE ALONG THE LINE WHEN THE UNIT AT PAOLA, KANSAS ABRUPTLY SHUT DOWN. PIPELINE CONTROLLER WAS INVESTIGATING OPERATING PARAMETERS WHEN SCADA ALARMS INDICATED A DECRESE IN LINE PRESSURE BETWEEN HUMBOLDT AND PAOLA, KANSAS. HE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN ALL PUMPING UNITS AND NOTIFIED FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE. INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT A RELEASE HAD OCCURRED AND REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE FAILED PIPE WITH NEW, PRETESTED PIPE IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGULATIONS AND COMPAY PROCEDURE, AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. THE DEFECTIVE PIPE WAS SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS. 10-22-03 - THE FAILURE WAS EXTERNAL CORROSION THAT REDUCED WALL THICKNESS.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: AT 8:05 A.M. EDT A FARMER CONTACTED THE MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE (MAPL) OPERATIONS CENTER (OC) AND REPORTED A "SPRAY" SHOOTING UP IN THE AIR AT MAPL'S STATE LINE STATION. THE IN/OH STATE LINE- LIMA METERING LINE SEGMENT WAS SHUT DOWN AND SECURED BY THE MAPL OC WHO ALSO CONTACTED LIMA AREA PERSONNEL AND INFORMED THEM OF A PROBLEM AT STATE LINE STATION. LIMA AREA PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED MAPL'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES. UPON ARRIVING AT STATE LINE STATION, LIMA PERSONNEL OBSERVED AN OILY/GAS FILM ON THE GROUND IMMEDIATELY AROUND THE MAINLINE PUMP. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS QUICKLY DETERMINED TO BE THE INBOARD SEAL FLUSH LINE. FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE 3/8" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING HAD FAILED. THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE HAS NOT YET BEEN DETERMINED, BUT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION. A 40'X 50' AREA AROUND THE PUMP HAD AREAS OF POOLED LOW SULFUR DIESEL FUEL. SMALLER AREAS OUTSIDE THE FENCE ON MAPL PROPERTY ALSO SHOWED SIGNS OF DIESEL FUEL CONTAMINATION. IMPACTED SURFACE GRAVEL AND SOIL WERE COLLECTED IN ROLL-OFF CONTAINERS, AND WILL BE DISPOSED OF PURSUANT TO APPLICABLE STATE AND FEDERAL WASTE REGULATIONS. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS QUICKLY DETERMINED TO BE THE INBOARD SEAL FLUSH LINE.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE 3/8" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING HAD FAILED.  A MATERIALS FAILURE ANALYSIS CONDUCTED BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES INC, CONCLUDED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE TUBING FAILURE WAS FATIGUE CAUSED BY EXCESSIVE VIBRATION OF THE TUBING LINE INDUCED BY THE PUMP.  NO EVIDENCE OF IMPROPER INSTALLATION OR PRIOR DAMAGE TO THE TUBING WAS NOTED (FROM EXAMINING THE TUBE SPECIMEN).  FRACTOGRAPHIC AND METALLOGRAPHIC EXAMINATION OF THE FRACTURE DID NOT DISCLOSE ANY INDICATIONS OF CORROSION-FATIGUE CRACKING (CFC), STRESS-CORROSION CRACKING (SCC), OR HYDROGEN EMBRITTLEMENT.  MAPL'S INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT INSUFFICIENT TUBING SUPPORT WAS PROVIDED.  THE TUBING MANUFACTURER SPECIFICES 3' SPACING OF TUBING SUPPORTS WHILE 5' SPACING WAS USED IN THIS INSTALLATION.      4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE ORIGINALLY REVERSED, SO THEY HAVE BEEN CORRECTED.  ALSO, AMOUNT SPILL AND RECOVERED WERE UPDATED TO FROM 15 AND 13 TO 18 AND 16, RESPECTIVELY. CAUSE WAS UPDATED FROM 24-MISCELLANEOUS TO 15-COMPONENT - 3/8" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING PER NARRATIVE AND A REVIEW OF THE PROJECT. SEE NARRATIVE ABOVE FOR A DESCRIPTION OF THE ACCIDENT. POOR WORKMANSHIP WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE CONSTRUCTION DEFECT. H5 B AND C WERE ALSO UPDATED. SINCE THIS TUBING IS A COMPONENT AND NOT PIPE, LEAK PRESSURE TEST INFORMATION IS NOT APPLICABLE.

column245: AIRPORT CONTRACTOR WAS IN THE PROCESS OF CROSSING OUR 4" JET FUEL LINE WITH A 4'X 6' CONCRETE DRAINAGE SYSTEM, CROSSING WAS BEING WITNESSED BY CONOCO PERSONNEL.  WORK HAD STOPPED FOR THE DAY AT 3:00 P.M., WITH CONOCO PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTOR LEAVING THE SITE.  CONTRACTOR CALLED TRACKHOE RENTAL COMPANY ABOUT A PROBLEM WITH THE TRACKHOE, MECHANIC FROM RENTAL COMPANY WORKED ON TRACKHOE AND DECIDED TO PERFORM A TEST DIG.  IN DOING SO, HIT THE 4" JET FUEL LINE CAUSING THE RELEASE OF JET FUEL.  LINE WAS NOT IN OPERATION AT THE TIME OF THIS INCIDENT. THIS IS A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT. FINAL REPORT DID NOT INCLUDE LOSSES.

column245: AT 0930 HOURS AUGUST 8, 2002 EXPLORER'S TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT HUNTSVILLE STATION AND MADE A ROUTING INSPECTION OF THE GROUNDS.  HE DISCOVERED FUEL OIL IN THE OPEN PIT CONTAING THE 28" MAINLINE CHECK VALVE.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDEDIATELY SHUT DOWN TO STOP FUEL SEEPING FROM THE CHECK VALVE.  FUEL OIL WAS PUMPED FROM THE PIT AND IT WAS DETERMINED A VITON SEAL ON THE CHECK VALVE CLAPPER SHAFT WAS LEAKING WHERE THE SHAFT EXTENDS THROUGH THE BODY OF THE CHECK VALVE. THE SEAL WAS REPLACED AND THE PIPELINE RESTARTED.  THE SEAL IS BEING ANALYIZED FOR CAUSE OF FAILURE.  APPROXIMATELY 1 CUBIC YARD OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PLACED IN DRUMS FOR DISPOSAL.

column238: SPILLED DURING TANK MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: SPILL OCCURRED DURING AN API-653 TANK MAINTENANCE CLEANING ACTIVITY ON THIS OUT OF SERVICE BREAK-OUT TANK. THE CLEANING CREW WAS USING PARAFIN TO DAM FLUIDS INSIDE THE TANK WHEN IT GAVE WAY AND CRUDE OIL SPILLED OUT OF MANWAY INTO THE TANK DIKE AREA. IMMEDIATELY, NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE INTERNALLY TO SUPERVISORY PERSONNEL AND EXTERNALLY TOTHE NRC AT 10:30 A.M. PIPELINE PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND CONTAINED THE FLUID FOR PICK-UP BY VAACUM TRUCK THAT RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 5 BARRELS. THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RECOVERED WAS CLOSE TO THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT SPILLED DUE TO RECENT RAINS THAT HELD MOISTURE IN THE GROUND PREVENTING ABSORPTION. SOIL REMEDIATION IS OCCURRING NEARBY ON SITE. MEASURES WERE PUT IN PLACE TO PREVENT REOCCURRENCE BY FURTHER CLEANING ACTIVITIES.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON AUGUST 2,2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 100 HOURS, A CRUDE OIL SPILL WAS DISCOVERED BY A COMPAY PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT WASSON STATION, AN INTERMEDIATE PUMP STATION ON THE RINGGOLD, TX TO ARDMORE, OK CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM. INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT,PIPELINE CONTROL, AND PIPELINE SAFETY, THEN THE NRC WAS CALLED AT 12:47 HRS. THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 1.5 HOURS EARLIER ON THE SUCTION LINE SEGMENT RUNNING FROM THE BREAKOUT TANK TO THE CHARGE PUMP. THIS WAS DETERMINED BY A VISIT BY PIPELINE PERSONNEL TO THE STATION 1.5 HOURS EARLIER THAT MORNING, DURING WHICH OPERATION CONDITIONS WERE OBSERVED TO BE NORMAL. THE LEAK OCCURRED ON THE BOTTOM OF THE 10" SUCTION LINE APPROXIMATELY 6' FROM THE CHARGE PUMP. CRUDE OIL MIGRATED INTO A NEARBY VALVE BOX THEN OVERFLOWED TO A LOW SPOT NEARBY ON SITE AND POOLED. THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING THE VALVE ON THE TANK. LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND RECOVERED 8 BARRELS OF THE 25 THAT WAS RELEASED. THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY REPAIRED AND THE PUMP RESTARTED. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED TO A NEARBY SITE ON COMPANY PROPERTY FOR REMEDIATION.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON TUE. AUG.13TH, AROUND 1330, SUE GUIDRY, RECIVED A PHONE CALL FROM VAN SONNIER WITH COOPER T. SMITH, INC, HE HAD A MARSH HOE WORKING SOUTH OF SWEET LAKE , LA (HWY27), APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES EAST OF THE GIBBSTOWN BRIDGE ON THE INTRACOASTAL WATERWAY. THE WORK WAS BEING DONE APPROXIMATELY 150 YARDS NORTH OF THE INTRACOASTAL, AND 200 YARDS WEST OF THE BELL CITY DRAINAGE DITCH (WORK DONE BY WILCO MARSH BUGGY). MR SONNIER INDICATED THAT THE MARSH HOE OPERATOR HAD STRUCK A PIPELINE, BUT THAT THERE WAS NO DAMAGE. MS. GUIDRY ASKED IF A LOCATE HAD BEEN CALLED IN FOR THIS WORK. MR SONNIER SAID HE HAD NOT CALLED IN A LOCATE. MS. GUIDRY REQUESTED HE CALL IN A LOCATE (#236497) FOR THE MARSH WORK. STATE DATE FOR THE WORK WAS LISTED AS 8/15/02. WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 14TH, 2002, AT 0740, BILL STANSIFER RECIVED A PHONE CALL FROM DYNEGY'S HACKBERRY STORAGE FACILITY. HACKBERRY HAD RECIVED A CALL FROM VAN SONNIER,INDICATING THAT HIS MARSH HOE OPERATOR HAD STRUCK DYNEGY'S PIPELINE AND PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED.DYNEGY PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED, AND HACKBERRY BEGAN SHUTTING DOWN THE PLANTS FEEDING INTO THE PIPELINE. BAD WEATHER AND HEAVY TRAFFIC HAMPERED EFFORTS TO GE TO THE INCIDENT SITE. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE GRAND CHENIER-SOUTH EXTENSION HAD BEEN HIT. AFTER THIS LINE SEGMENT HAD BEEN ISOLATED , ALL OF THE PLANTS, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE BP-AMOCO GRAND CHENIER PLANT WRER ALLOWED TO COME BACK ON LINE. BLOCK VALVE ON BOTH SIDES OF THE INCIDENT SITE WERE BLOCKED IN. PIPELINE TECHNICIANS ON THE SCENE REPORTED A VAPOR CLOUD WHILE THE PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED. THERE DID NOT APPEAR T BE A SHEEN ON THE WATER. THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS DEPRESSURED BY 1430 ON WED 08/14/02 (7HOURS) (4,559 BBLS VENTED TO ATMOSPHERE). WEATHER CONDITIONS AT THE TIME PIPELINE PERSONNEL ARRIVED ON THE SCENE: FLOATING TURF, 20' RADIUS OF DAMAGE AREA- NO APPARENT SHEEN ON WATER. TEMPERATURE 78, CLOUDY, FREQUENT, HEAVY THUNDERSTOMS, WINDS OUT OF THE SOUTHEAST, 10-15 MPH. INVESTIGATION INDICATED THE MARSH HOE HAD NEARLY SPLIT THE PIPELINE IN TWO PIECE. ALL OF THE PRODUCT IN THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS RELEASED TO ATMOSPHERE. THERE WAS NO RECOVERY OF PRODUCT.

column245: RECENT PIPING MODIFICATIONS AT BRACKEN JUCTION HAD BEEN COMPLETED ON AUGUST 1, 2002 TO ACCOMMODATE OPERATIONAL CHANGES. NEW RELIEF VALVES HAD BEEN INSTALLED AS PART OF THIS NEW CONSTRUCTION. WHEN NEW PIPING WAS HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED RELIEF VALVES WERE CLOSED AND ISOLATED. WHEN PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN ON AUGUST 5 NEWLY INSTALLED RELIEF VALVE LEAKED AT SETTING LOWER THAN INDICTED FACTORY SETTINGS. LEAKAGE OVERFLOWED CONTAINMENT TANKAGE AND CAUSED RELEASE. VALVES WERE REMOVED, AND TESTED BY CALNEY TECHNICIANS AND FOUND TO BE INCORRECTLY SET AT MUCH LOWER THAN INDICATED SETTING STAMPED ON THE VALVE BODY. WHEN REPLACEMENT RELEIF VALVES WERE RECEIVED THEY WERE TESTED BY COMPANY TECHNICIANS PRIOR TO INSTALLATION.

column245: LINE WAS HIT BY A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR. OF THE 3210 BBLS RELEASED, 2500 BBLS WERE INTENTIONALLY RELEASED BETWEEN VALVES AS INDICATED ABOVE, IN ORDER TO EXCAVATE THE LINE SEGMENT PREPARATORY TO REPAIRING IT. LINE WAS PREPARED BY INSTALLING NEW PRE-TESTED PIPE AND X-RAYING ALL WELDS, IN ACCORDANCE WITH PIPELINE REGULATIONS AND COMPANY POLICY. 10-22-03 LINE WAS HIT BY A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR WHO GAVE THE STATE ONE-CALL AGENCY THE WRONG PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION OF THE TRACT OF LAND IT INTENDED TO EXCAVATE.  THE TRACT EVALUATED BY THE ONE-CALL CENTER DID NOT INCLUDE THE TRACT CONTAINING THE WPL LINE.  CONSEQUENTLY, THE PROCESS DID NOT CORRECTLY IDENTIFY THE LINE AND MAGELLAN PIPELINE COMPANY WAS NOT CONTACTED, WITH RESULT THAT THE LINE WAS NOT MARKED PRIOR TO EXCAVATION.

column245: A SECTION OF PIPE AT THE STATION (8") CONNECTING TO THE PIG LAUNCHER WAS FOUND TO HAVE A CLAMP ON IT.  APPARENTLY, YEARS AGO, BEFORE WE OWNED THE LINE, SOMEONE INSTALLED A CLAMP ON THE STATION PIPE UNDERGROUND, IT STARTED TO LEAK.  DUE TO ONGOING REPAIRS IN THE AREA, THE LEAK WAS CONTAINED IN THE TRENCH WE DUG FOR REPAIRS.  LIVE WAS SHUTDOWN AND SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.  LESS THAN 5 BBL LEAKED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: WHILE CLOSING STATION TANK FIREWALL DRAIN VALVES, A STATION TANK VALVE WAS MISTAKENLY CLOSED CAUSING AN OVERPRESSURE EVENT AT THE STATION THAT RESULTED IN 3 LEAKS RELEASING A TOTAL OF 7 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL.  THE TANK VALVE ALLOWS THE TANK TO FLOAT ON THE MAINLINE AND PROVIDES NECESSARY FLOW TO THE STATION PUMPS, DEPENDING ON THE INCOMING LINE CONDITIONS.  THE PIPELINE/STATION RELIEF VALVE IS TIED TO THE UPSTREAM OF THE STATION TANK VALVE TO RELIEVE INTO THE TANK.  OPERATIONAL CONDITIONS CAUSED THE STATION TO SHUT DOWN WHICH CAUSED THE PRESSURE IN THE STATION PIPING TO RISE ABOVE MOP BECAUSE BOTH THE NORMAL OUTLET TO THE TANK AND THE RELIEF SYSTEM WERE BLOCKED DUE TO THE CLOSURE OF THE STATION TANK VALVE.  AS A RESULT OF THIS INCIDENT, A TOTAL OF 7 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL LEAKED FROM A FLANGE GASKET, A PUMP SEAL, AND A VALVE RELIEF PORT.

column245: ON SEPTEMBER 9, 2002 WHILE PERFORMING A ROUTINE FILTER CHANGE AT BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S LINDEN STATION, EMPLOYEES FAILED TO CLOSE AN INLET VALVE TO ONE OF THE FILTER VESSELS.  DURING THE RE-FILL PROCEDURE A GATE VALVE WAS OPENED SLIGHTLY TO SUPPLY LINE PRESSURE TO THE 2" FILL LINES.  THE INLET VALVE THAT WAS NOT CLOSED ALLOWED PRODUCT TO FLOW INTO THE FILTER VESSELS, WHICH STARTED TO OVERFLOW BEFORE THE GATE VALVE COULD BE CLOSED.  APPROXIMATELY 15 BARRELS OF JET FUEL WAS RELEASED INTO THE CEMENT CONTAINMENT PAD AND CATCH BASIN.  A VAC TRUCK WAS CALLED AND ALL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 6,2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 1003 HOURS, A CRUDE OIL SPILL WAS DISCOVERED BY COMPANY PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT WICHITA FALLS PUMP STATION, THE BOL OF THE WICHITA FALLS TO MCKEE 14" CRUDE OIL PIPELINE. INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, AND PIPELINE SAFETY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE,AND THE NRC. THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 12 HOURS EARLIER WHEN THE UNDERGROUND 2"SUMP PIPING PERFORATED POOLING AROUND THE SUMP. THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING A SECONDARY VALVE. LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED, EXCAVATED CONTAMINATED SOIL AND REMOVED IT NEARBY FOR REMEDIATION. SOIL SAMPLING WAS COMPLETED AND THE AREA CLEANED. DISBONDED COATING THAT LEAD TO EXTERNAL CORROSION WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE CAUSE OF THE APPROXIMATE 5-BARREL RELEASE. COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $1635.00. NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY REPLACING THE AFFECTED PIPING.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. ROOT CAUSE DETERMINED TO NOT BE EXTERNAL CORROSION.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED IN TANK VALVE VALULT ON AUGUST 25,2002 DURING PREPARATION FOR SCHEDULED API 653 TANK INSPECTION OF TANK T-8. THE LOCATION OF RELEASE WAS UNDETERMINED. ORIGINALLY, THIS RELEASE DID NOT APPEAR TO BE TELEPHONICALLY REPORTABLE UNDER 49 CFR 195.52- THERE WERE NO DEATHS, INJURIES REQUIRING HOSPITALIZATION, FIRES OR EXPLOSIONS, OR POLLUTION TO WATERS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE AND WE DID NOT ANTICIPATE THAT THE DAMAGES WOULD EXCEED 50,000. HOWEVER, ON SEPTEMBER 6TH WE DETERMINED THAT THE COST ASSOCIATED WITH FINDING THE LEAK,REPAIRING THE LEAK AND REMEDIATION WOULD EXCEED $50,000. THESE COST INCLUDE HYDROSTATICALLY TESTING THE TANK FILL LINE, ADDITIONAL PREPARATION AND TESTING BEYOND THE API 653 STANDARDS TO FIND THE LEAK, E.G., THE REMOVAL OF EPOXY COATING, HELIUM, VACUUM BOX, MAGNETIC PARTICLE, AND DYE PENETRANT TESTING AND REPAIR OF THE CRACK DISCOVERED IN THE TANK PLATE. KINDER MORGAN NOTIFIED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AS SOON AS WE DISCOVERED THAT THIS MET THE TELEPHONIC NOTICE CRITERIA.

column245: CONTRACTORS AND KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEES WERE INVOLVED IN CONSTRUCTION PROJECT INVOLVING PIPING CHANGES TO THE 10,000 MANIFOLD IN CARSON TERMINAL. ONLY THE DIESEL AND JET FUEL SYSTEMS HAD BEEN INVOLVED AT THIS STAGE OF THE PROJECT AND WERE PROPERLY SECURED AND LOCKED OUT. THE FIELD CONSTRUCTION WORK ON AUGUST 27TH INCLUDED THE REMOVAL OF A BLIND FLANGE TO INSTALL A VALVE ON A GASOLINE HEADER IN THE MANIFOLD. THIS INFORMATION WAS NOT PROPERLY CONVEYED TO ALL CONCERNED IN THE FACILITY, RESULTING IN THE RELEASE WHEN TERMINAL PERSONNEL BEGAN PUMPING FROM THE TANK AFTER THE BLIND FLANGE HAD BEEN REMOVED. PERSONNEL WERE CLEARED FROM THE SITE, LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENTS RESPONDED AND FOAMED THE RELEASE, AND THE PRODUCT WAS DRAINED FROM THE MAINFOLD AREA AND RETURNED TO TANKAGE. THE RELEASE WAS COMPLETELY CONTAINED IN A CONCRETE LINED PIT BELOW THE MANIFOLD AREA AND RETURNED TO TANKAGE. THE RELEASE WAS COMPLETELY CONTAINED IN A CONCRETE LINED PIT BELOW THE MANIFOLD AND ALL PRODUCT RELEASED WAS RECOVERED.

THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND CLEANUP AND MAINTENANCE CONTRACTORS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  THE BROKEN NIPPLE WAS REPLACED AND THE PIPELINE RESTARTED NORMAL OPERATIONS.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column238: OUTLET SUMP DRAIN VALVE AT FACILITY WAS OPEN, LIKELY ACCIDENTLY KICKED OPEN BY METER TECHNICIAN WHILE PREPARING TO PROVE DELIVERY METER. THIS CAUSED THE SUMP TANK TO OVERFLOW ONTO THE SURROUNDING GROUND.
column245: A METER TECHNICIAN SET UP PORTABLE PROVER AT THIS DELIVERY TERMINAL MANIFOLD TO PROVE THE TURBIN METER.  AFTER PLACING PROVER ON LINE THE TECHNICIAN CHECKED FOR LEAKS AND FINDING NONE WENT BACK TO HIS TRUCK TO ENTER METER TEMPERATURE, PRESSURE AND PRODUCT GRAVITY INTO FLOW COMPUTER TO BEGIN THE METER PROVING PROCESS.  DURING THIS TIME THE TECHNICIAN WAS OUT OF SITE FROM DELIVERY  MANIFOLD AND SUMP TANK.  AFTER TEN MINUTES, THE TECHNICIAN RETURNED TO THE METER MANIFOLD AND DISCOVERED THE SUMP TANK OVERFLOWING.  THE TECHNICIAN IMMEDIATELY  DISCOVERED THE OPEN OUTLET SUMP DRAIN VALVE AND CLOSED IT STOPPING OVERFLOW.    THE ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION 'CAUSE ANALYSIS' DETERMINED THE FOLLOWING:  - DRAIN VALVE TO THE SUMP WAS OPEN / THIS 1/4 TURN BALL VALVE COULD BE EASILY OPENED INADVERTANTLY / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS TO INSTALL A LOCKING DEVICE ON THIS VALVE IN THE NORMALLY CLOSED POSITION  - SUMP TANK LEVEL INDICATOR DID NOT RISE AND THUS THE HIGH ALARM DID NOT FUNCTION / LIKELY CAUSED BY STUCK FLOAT OR CAM MECHANISM GETTING JAMMED / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS TO REPLACE THE MACHANICAL GAUGE WITH A ROOF TOP ALARM TYPE DEVICE  - VALVE WAS KICKED OPEN / TECHNICIAN REQUIRED TO STEP ACROSS PIPING AND VALVE NUMEROUS TIMES DURING METER PROVING / CORRECTIVE ACTION IS 'NONE' AS THIS CROSSING OVER PIPING CANNOT BE AVOIDED.  THE ADDITION OF A LOCKING DEVICE WILL EFFECTIVELY ELIMINATE THE ACCIDENTAL OPENING OF THIS VALVE

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: WILLIAMS PIPE LINE COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IN TULSA OKLAHOMA RECEIVED TWO ALARMS APPROXIMATELY TWO MINUTES APART FROM TWO LOCATIONS ON THE #3-8" BARNSDALL, OK. TO KANSAS CITY LINE. CONTROLLERS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE LINE AND CALLED OUT FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE. FIELD DETERMINED THAT A CONTRACTOR INSTALLING UTILITY SERVICES HAD PUNCTURED THE LINE WITH EXCAVATION EQUIPMENT.CONTRACTOR HAD CALLED KANSAS ONE-CALL CENTER, AND WPL HAD MARKED ITS THREE PIPELINES IN THE EASEMENT. WILLIAMS PERSONNEL INSTRUCTED EXCAVATOR TO WAIL UNTIL WPL PERSONNEL PROBED DEPTH OF THE LINES WHERE EXCAVATION WOULD CROSS THEM BECAUSE WPL PROCEDURES PERMIT ONLY EXCAVATION USING HAND TOOLS DIRECTLY ON TOP OF THE LINE. EXCAVATOR AGREED, BUT DIDN'T WAIT UNTIL THE APPOINTED TIME AND STARTED EXCAVATION USING HEAVY MECHANICAL EXCAVATION EQUIPMENT BEFORE WPL PERSONNEL ARRIVED. THE LINE WAS PUNCTURED AND PRODUCT RELEASED. WPL PERSONNEL REPAIRED THE PIPE WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH WPL PROCEDURES AND UNDER OVERSIGHT OF KDHE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2002 A BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY EMPLOYEE WAS VERIFYING THE PRODUCT LEVEL IN TANK 212 AT BUCKEYE'S MACUNGIE TANK FARM AFTER THE TANK WAS FILLED.  THE EMPLOYEE NOTICED PRODUCT COMING OUT OF THE CATHODIC PROTECTION TUBES, WHICH RUN BETWEEN THE DOUBLE-BOTTOM FLOORS OF TANK 212.  PRODUCT IN TANK 212 WAS TRANSFERED TO ANOTHER TANK AND ALSO PUMPED INTO THE PIPELINE TO DRAIN THE TANK.  BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY AND ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  THE TANK WILL REMAIN OUT-OF-SERVICE UNTILL THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT IS DETERMINED AND REPAIRS ARE MADE.   SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT UPDATE:  THE CAUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE A CRACK IN THE TANK FLOOR TO SHELL WELD.  THE AMOUNT SPILLED AND RECOVERED ALONG WITH THE COST OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN REVISED.  THE TANK IS BACK IN SERVICE.  I PLACED "0" IN THE MOP FIELDS SINCE THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET BE PUT IN N/A.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 29, 2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 0800 HOURS, A CRUDE OIL SPILL WAS DISCOVERED BY COMPANY PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT WICHITA FALLS PUMP STATION, THE BOL OF THE WICHITA FALLS TO MCKEE 14" CRUDE OIL PIPELINE.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY, ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE, AND THE NRC.  THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS EARLIER WHEN THE 1/4" CHECK VALVE COMING FROM THE CHEMICAL INJECTION PUMP RUPTURED, ALLOWING CRUDE OIL IN THE SUCTION LINE TO THE DISCHARGE PUMPS TO MIGRATE OUT OF THE BREAK AND INTO A CONCRETE CONTAINMENT AREA, OVERFLOWING AROUND THE CONTAINMENT.  THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY CLOSING A 1/4" VALVE GOING INTO THE SUCTION LINE.  LOCAL PERSONNEL RESPONDED, EXCAVATED 6 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL AND REMOVED IT TO AN AREA INSIDE THE STATION FOR REMEDIATION.  SOIL SAMPLING WAS COMPLETED AND THE AREA CLEANED.  COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $656.00.  INITIALLY, THIS RELEASE WAS REPORTED AS A 10 BARREL RELEASE, BUT DURING THE CLEAN-UP PHASE OF THE RESPONSE PERIOD, THE CONCRETE CONTAINMENT WAS DISCOVERED BENEATH THE OVERSPRAY OF CRUDE OIL.  THE ACCURATED FIGURES ARE 5 BARRELS RELEASED AND 3 BARRELS RECOVERED FROM THE CONTAINMENT.  NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY REPLACING THE 3/8" STAINLESS STEEL TUBING COMING FROM THE CORROSION CHEMICAL INJECTION AND THE 1/4" CHECK VALVE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM #21 (STILL EQUIPMENT RELATED).
