column238: DAMAGE CAUSED BY A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR PERFORMING RIGHT OF WAY MAINTENANCE WORK. PLEASE SEE NARRATIVE.
column245: ON THE 16TH OF OCTOBER, WHILE CLEARING BRUSH AND GRASS ON A COMPANY RIGHT OF WAY, A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR STRUCK THE MPL-110 (12") LINE WITH A HYDRAULICALLY DRIVEN, BOOM MOUNTED ROTARY MOWER CREATING A 3"X1" HOLE IN THE LINE. THE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED COMPANY PERSONNEL. THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND THE DAMAGED SECTION ISOLATED. THE SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED AND PICKED UP USING VACUUM TRUCKS. TEMPORARY REPAIR TO THE LINE WAS MADE USING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT CLAMP. PERMANENT REPAIR WILL BE MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A REPORT OF PETROLEUM VAPORS IN THE SEWER SYSTEM WAS RECEIVED BY SUNOCO PIPELINE LP (SPLP) FROM THE LOCAL SANITARY SEWER AUTHORITY ON FRIDAY, OCTOBER 25TH.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND SPLP PERSONNEL RESPONDED ALONG WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM PA DEPT. OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION (PADEP).  SPLP, PADEP AND SEWER AUTHORITY REPRESENTATIVES WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE ANY SOURCE FOR THE PETROLEUM VAPORS IN THE SEWER SYSTEM AND THE VAPORS ABATED.  THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED AND RAN FOR SEVERAL DAYS UNTIL VAPORS AGAIN WERE AGAIN DETECTED IN THE SEWER SYSTEM ON THE MORNING OF MONDAY, OCTOBER 28TH.  REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE SAME THREE ENTITIES AGAIN SEARCHED FOR A SOURCE.  THIS TIME A LEAKING FLANGE WAS FOUND AFTER EXCAVATION OF AN 8-INCH DELIVERY SPUR-LINE TAKE-OFF VALVE.      MIXED PRODUCT WAS FOUND IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE TAKE-OFF MANIFOLD AND HAD ENTERED THE SEWER SYSTEM VIA A NEARBY SEWER LATERAL.  THE LEAK WAS ISOLATED, THE SECTION OF PIPELINE AND MANIFOLD DRAINED, AND A REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE GASKET.      INITIAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE INCLUDED THE EXCAVATION OF SURFACE RECOVERY SUMPS AND USE OF VACUUM TRUCKS TO RECOVER PRODUCT AND CONTAMINATED GROUNDWATER FROM THESE SUMPS.  VENTING OF THE SEWER SYSTEM WAS ALSO DONE.  TO DATE, 600 GALLONS OF MIXED PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED.  ADDITIONALLY, TEN MONITORING WELLS HAVE BEEN INSTALLED AND THOSE, ALONG WITH SEVERAL NEARBY POTABLE WATER WELLS, HAVE BEEN UTILIZED TO CHARACTERIZE THE EXTENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT.  NO TRACE OF PRODUCT IS EVIDENT IN ANY OF THE POTABLE WATER WELLS, WHICH ARE LOCATED HYDRAULICALLY UP GRADIENT.  A LONG TERM IMPACT ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION PLAN IS BEING DEVELOPED.

column245: AT 1100 HOURS ON THURSDAY, OCTOBER 24 A PIPELINE RUPTURE, EXPLOSION AND FIRE OCCURRED ON THE 14" WT LPG PARTNERSHIP PIPELINE IN A REMOTE AREA AT MP 32.8. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN BY THE CONTROLLER AND A 7.5 MILE SECTION OF LINE WAS BLOCKED IN (BLOCK VALVES AT MP 31.9 & MP 39.4). THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS REPLACED AND THE SYSTEM WAS BROUGHT BACK ON LINE AT APPROXIMATELY 1200 HOURS ON SATURDAY OCTOBER 26.

column245: AT 12:15  A.M. THE MID-AMERICA PIPELINE COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IN TULSA RECEIVED TELEPHONIC NOTICE FROM A LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT VALVE ADJACENT TO 66TH STREET NORTH AND US HIGHWAY 75 WAS LEAKING AND THAT HIGHWAY 75 WAS BEING CLOSED AS A PRECAUTION. THE PIPELINE WAS NOT ACTIVELY PUMPING PRODUCT AT THE TIME. PIPELINE CONTROL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED FIELD PERSONNEL WHO RESPONDED. THE VALVE SITE WAS ENCLOSED WITH A CHAIN LINK FENCE TOPPED WITH RAZAR WIRE AND THE VALVE WAS ENCLOSED INSIDE A PROTECTIVE METAL ENCLOSURE. A SECTION OF THE FENCE HAD BEEN KNOCKED DOWN TO GAIN ENTRY, AND HINGES HAD BEEN CUT OFF THE ENCLOSURE TO GAIN ACCESS TO THE EXTERNAL RELIEVE DEVICE. A 1/2"  VALVE ON THE EXTERNAL RELIEF DEVICE ON A MAINLINE VALVE HAD BEEN BROKEN IN AN APPARENT ATTEMPT BY THIEVES TO STEAL AMMONIA FROM THE LINE. AMMONIA WAS LEAKING FROM THE 1/2" VALVE. COMPANY TECHNICIANS MADE REPAIRS TO THE VALVE. AS THE RELEASED PRODUCT DISSIPATED FROM THE HIGHWAY, US 75 WAS REOPENED AND THE PIPELINE RETURNED TO SERVICE. AN INVESTIGATION BY LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT IS UDERWAY. THE FENCE AND METAL ENCLOSURE WERE PROMPTLY REPAIRED.

column245: AT 04:35 MST, AN ENBRIDGE EMPLOYEE NOTICED CRUDE OIL IN AN EXCAVATION AND ON THE GROUND IN FLOODWOOD STATION.  THE CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED, AND ALL LINES WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED.  CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A CRACKED FILLET WELD ON THE UPSTREAM END OF A STOPPLE TEE.  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT IS MINIMAL, AS ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE STATION.  APPROXIMATELY 15 YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED.    THE LEAKING TEE WAS BETWEEN A MAIN LINE BLOCK VALVE AND ANOTHER STOPPLE TEE.  USING THE VALVE AND TEE FOR ISOLATION, THE LEAKING TEE WAS CUT OUT OF THE PIPELINE AND SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS.  THE INITIATING FEATURE WAS A WELD DEFECT WHICH GREW THROUGH OPERATING PRESSURE CYCLES, RESULTING IN THE GROWTH OF A FATIGUE CRACK THROUGH THE FILLET WELD.

column245: COATING ON RISER WAS APPARENTLY DAMAGED AT SOME POINT, WHICH CAUSED GENERAL CORROSION TO DEVELOP IN THE SPLASH ZONE.  THE GENERAL CORROSION WAS PREVIOUSLY ADDRESSED WITH THE APPLICATION OF ARMOR PLATE.  THE LEAK OCCURRED UNDER THE ARMOR PLATE APPLICATION.  THE TIMING OF THE LEAK WAS SHORTLY AFTER HURRICANES ISIDORE AND LILI.  MOVEMENT OF THE RISER DURING THE STORMS MAY HAVE IMPACTED THE TIMING OF THE CORRODED AREA BECOMING A LEAK.

column245: A PARTIALLY OPEN 1" DRAIN VALVE DISCHARGED CRUDE INTO AN UNDERGROUND SUMP WHICH OVERFLOWED. THE HIGH LEVEL ALARM SYSTEM FAILED. AS A RESULT, CRUDE RELEASED UNDETECTED INTO SECONDARY CONTAINMENT. THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT WAS SIZED TO HANDLE APPROXIMATELY 80 BBLS BUT THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DRAIN VALVE HAD NOT BEEN RECLOSED FOLLOWING MAINTENANCE IN THE PRECEDING WEEK ALLOWING CRUDE TO BE DISCHARGED OFF SITE. THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY THE OPERATOR WHILE WALKING TO VEHICLE AT THE END OF WORK SHIFT. THE HIGH LEVEL SWITCH WAS OF A MECHANICAL FLOAT TYPE WITH TWO LEVELS OF ALARM AND HAD BEEN INSTALLED NEW 3 MONTHS PRIOR. IT WAS SUCCESSFULLY TESTED AT INSTALLATION AND IT WORKED AFTER THE SOURCE OF CRUDE FLOW WAS STOPPED. NO REPORT OR RECORD COULD BE FOUND THAT INDICATED A CAUSE FOR THE OPEN DRAIN VALVE. IT WAS OBSERVED THAT THE VALVE DID NOT HAVE A LATCHING OR LOCKING MECHANISM TO MAINTAIN IT IN THE PROPER CLOSED POSITION WITHOUT DELIBERATE OPERATOR ACTION. INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT FAILURE OF THE LEVEL ALARM SYSTEM ALLOWED THE RELEASE OUT OF CONTAINMENT. THE HIGH LEVEL SYSTEM WILL BE UPGRADED WITH THE ADDITION OF AN ULTRASONIC LEVEL DETECTOR. SIMILAR FIRST VALVES OFF THE PIPELINE HAVE BEEN SURVEYED AND ARE BEING SECURED IN THE PROPER OPERATING POSITION.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 13, 2002, BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY WAS NOTIFIED BY THE SPRINGFIELD FIRE DEPARTMENT OF A POSSIBLE RELEASE ALONG ALBANY STREET IN SPRINGFIELD, MASSACHUSETTS.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY, BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED, AND ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A PINHOLE WAS DISCOVERED.  THE CAUSE OF THE PINHOLE WAS DETERMINED TO BE GENERAL CORROSION.  APPROXIMATELY 9 FEET OF PIPELINE HAS BEEN REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE AND THE ENTIRE SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS HYDROTESTED BEFORE BEING PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.     CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION AND TOTAL COST HAS BEEN INCREASED.

THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND A TECHNICIAN DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  IT WAS DETERMINED A 1/2 INCH THREADED NIPPLE CRACKED AT THE ELBOW ALLOWING GASOLINE TO ESCAPE.  THE NIPPLE WAS REPLACED AND PIPELINE RESTARTED.  AN INVESTIGATION IS BEING CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE POSSSIBLE CAUSES OF THE NIPPLE FAILURE.

column245: THE LINE APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN SNAGGED BY AN ANCHOR.  A 7000#  ANCHOR WAS FOUND APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET TO THE NORTH OF THE DAMAGED AREA.    THE DENT IS APPROXIMATELY 40% OF THE PIPE DIAMETER. ITS DIMENSIONS ARE  8"LONGETUDINAL X 6" CIRCUMFERENTAL. A 0.5" LONG X 1/16" WIDE CRACK PROPEGATED AT THE EDGE OF THE DEFORMATION 1.25" AWAY FROM A JOINT WELD..  SINCE THE LEAK HAD OCURRED SHORTLY AFTER HURRICANES ISIDORE AND LILI, MOVEMENT OF THE PIPE DURING THE STORMS PROBABLY CAUSED THE STRESSED AREA OF THE DENT TO FATIGUE AND OPEN, RESULTING IN  THE LEAK.    5-25-2006 SPOKE WITH OPS BLAINE KEINER.  DISCUSSED CAUSE CHOICE FOR REPORT OTHER MISC. #24 UNCHECKED AND CHECK H4 ITEM 11 FOR CAR, TRUCK OR OTHER VEHICLE NOT RELATING TO EXCAVATION ACTIVITY DAMAGING PIPE.  IN THIS CASE PROBABLY A BOAT/SHIP DUE TO ANCHOR FOUND NEXT TO PIPELINE.  AGREED TO CHANGE RICHARD KLASEN

column245: PRIOR TO THE LEAK AT PUENTE STREET, PIPELINE HOT OILING OPERATIONS WERE BEING CONDUCTED IN AN ATTEMPT TO DE-WAX THE PIPELINE IN PREPARATION FOR A HYDROTEST.  DURING THE HOT-OIL PROCEDURE PRESSURES WERE HIGHER THANK NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURES, BUT WITHIN MOP. THE GATHERING SYSTEM HAD BEEN SUCCESSFULLY HYDROTESTED IN JULY OF 1996 TO 755 PSIG WITH WHICH WE ESTABLISHED AN MOP OF 604 PSIG.  THE GATHERING SYSTEM FAILED AT A PRESSURE OF 600 PSIG, WHICH WAS BELOW THE MOP. THE LAB TEST RESULTS OF THE COUPON SPECIMEN OF THE PIPE SEGMENT THAT FAILED REVEALED OXIDES ALONG 73% OF THE SEAM BOND LINE.  THE FAILURE IS THUS ATTRIBUTED TO THE POOR MANUFACTURING OF THIS PIPE SEGMENT.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: COMPLAINT OF ODORS BY PROPERTY OWNER LED TO INTEGRITY TESTING AND EXCAVATION ALONG A PARALLEL SECTION OF 8-INCH AND 12-INCH PETROLEUM PRODUCT LINES.  THIS INVESTIGATION RESULTED IN DETERMINATION THAT 12-INCH LINE WAS LEAKING ADJACENT TO COMMERCIAL BUSINESS (HOTEL).  NO EVACUATIONS WERE NECESSARY.    RESPONSE WAS LIMITED TO LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT AND TOWNSHIP OFFICIALS.  PA DEP, US COAST GUARD, US FISH & WILDLIFE AND OPS HAVE MADE ON-SITE INSPECTIONS OF THE LEAK LOCATION.  NO IMPACT TO DARBY CREEK IS EVIDENT.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS FAILURE CAN NOT CONCLUSIVELY BE DETERMINED SINCE THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPELINE CAN NOT BE RETRIEVED BECAUSE OF THE RISK OF DAMAGING AN ADJACENT BUILDING DUE TO ITS CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE SECTION AT THE LEAK IS APPROXIMATELY 12 FEET DEEP FOR A CROSSING OF DARBY CREEK.  THE PIPELINE HAD ILI BY A HIGH-RESOLUTION ULTRASONIC PIG DEVICE IN OCTOBER 2001 WITH REPORT BEING RECEIVED IN JANUARY 2002.  THE SECTION OF LINE THAT LEAKED HAD A REPORTED FEATURE AND WAS SCHEDULED TO BE FIELD INVESTIGATED AFTER THE DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK. IN ORDER TO GATHER ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ABOUT THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE, A VIDEO CAMERA WAS RUN INSIDE THE FAILED PIPE SECTION TO LOCATE AND EXAMINE THE FAILURE LOCATION.  THIS INTERNAL VIDEO INSPECTION CONFIRMED THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK AS BEING THE SAME LOCATION AS THAT REPORT BY THE ILI.  BASED ON THE AVAILABLE INFORMATION, THE LEAK APPEARS TO BE CORROSION RELATED, EXACT CAUSE UNKNOWN.

column245: RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL AT WILDHORSE STATION WAS CAUSED BY CRUDE OIL ESCAPING CONTAINMENT THROUGH A PINHOLE THAT OPENED IN A SECTION OF IDLE PIPING.  LOCALIZED INTERNAL CORROSION PITTING CREATED THE PINHOLE.  THE CORROSION WAS CAUSED BY THE LACK OF FLOW THROUGH THE PIPING; ALLOWING WATER AND OTHER MICROBIOLOGICAL CONTAMINANTS TO SETTLE AND ATTACK THE INTERNAL SURFACES.

column241: ANN-MARIE KAYSER, MAPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY & REGULATORY CO
column245: ON JANUARY 8, 2002, A MARATHON ASHLAND PIPELINE LLC CORROSION TECHNICIAN VISTING THE SITE TO TAKE BIMONTHLY CATHODIC PROTECTION RECTIFIER READINGS DETECTED A HYDROCARBON ODOR AT THE SORRENTO, LA BLOCK VALVE SITE.  THE LINE WAS ALREADY IN A SCHEDULED SHUTDOWN PERIOD.  EMERGENCY PROCEDURES WERE ACTIVATED, AND STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT.  CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT WAS MOBILIZED TO THE SCENE TO EXCAVATE TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE HYDROCARBON.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PLACED ON PLASTIC SHEETING, AND SOIL CHARACTERIZATION SAMPLES WERE TAKEN TO DETERMINE PROPER DISPOSAL METHODS PER LADEQ REQUIREMENTS.  SOIL BORINGS WERE MADE TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF IMPACT.  THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE ORIGINATING FROM THE VALVE BONNET ASSEMBLY.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND A REPLACEMENT VALVE INSTALLED.  THE LEAKING VALVE ASSEMBLY WAS SHIPPED TO THE VALVE MANUFACTURER FOR EVALUATION.  THE CAUSE OF THE BONNET ASSEMBLY FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME BUT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION.  UPDATED COMMENTS 7/3/02.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAS WAS A VALVE BONNET ASSEMBLY O-RING.  THE MOSE LIKELY CAUSE OF THE LEAKAGE  WAS EXCESSIVE GREASE IN THE WRONG AREA DURING ASSEMBLY (BY THE MANUFACTURER/REPAIR CONTRACTOR).  PRESSURE AND TEMPERATURE CHANGES PROBABLY CAUSED FURTHER MOVEMENT OF THE O-RING, EVENTUALLY CAUSING THE LEAK.  THE REPAIR O-RINGS FURNISHED BY THE MANUFACTURER WERE DEFECTIVE IN INSIE DIAMETER SIZE AND CONTRIBUTED TO THE FAILURE.  THE INVESTIGATION IS ESSENTIALLY COMPLETE, HOWEVER ADDITIONAL CONTRIBUTING FACTORS MAY BE IDENTIFIED AT A LATER DATE.  11-8-04  THE RELEASE VOLUME, IMPACTED SOIL VOLUME, AND PROPERTY DAMAGE ESTIMATES WERE REVISED 04-04-2003. MAPL HAS NOT HAD A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN PROPERTY DAMAGE AS OF THE 04-04-2003 UPDATE AND THEREFORE IS PROVIDING THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY WITH A FINAL 7000-1 REPORT REGARDING THE 1-08-2002 EVENT AT THE SORRENTO, LA BLOCK VALVE SITE.

column238: SHEEN INVESTIGATION FOUND NO LEAKS.
column245: DURING A HEAVY RAINSTORM A SHEEN WAS FOUND ON LOW SPOTS ON COMPANY PROPERTY.  DUE TO THE HEAVY RAINS, THE SHEEN DID GET INTO A DITCH THAT LEADS TO THE 20 ARPENT CANAL.  THE SHEEN DID NOT GET INTO THE CANAL ITSELF.  THE DITCH WAS BOOMED AND THE SHEEN WAS CLEANED UP.  A HOLE WAS DUG ON COMPANY PROPERTY AND THE SHEEN AREA WAS FLOODED WITH FIRE HOSES TO CLEAN UP ANY RESIDUAL SHEEN IN THE GROUND.  LESS THAN A GALLON OF PRODUCT CAUSED THE SHEEN.

column238: 6" 150 ANSI FLANGE GASKET FAILURE.  FAILURE ANALYSIS INVESTIGATION DID NOT DETERMINE CAUSE OF FAILURE.
column245: THE GASKET THAT FAILED, DID SO BECAUSE A PORTION OF THE MATERIAL TORE AND BLEW OUT FROM BETWEEN THE FLANGE FACES.  THE FAILED GASKET WAS ON A 6" ANSI 150 BALL VALVE USED TO RECIRCULATED BACK TO TANKAGE DURING LOW FLOW RATE DELIVERIES.  IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO KNOW WHETHER PIPE STRAIN, VIBRATION FROM SERVICE, TEMPERATURE CHANGES, LESS THAN OPTIMUM BOLT STRESS, OR A COMBINATION OF THESE EFFECTS CAUSED THE FAILURE.  WE HAVE NOT HAD ROUTINE FAILURES OF THIS TYPE GASKET.  EMPLOYEES HAVE BEEN ADVISED OF THE POTENTIAL FOR FLANGE GASKET FAILURE AND TO REPLACE ANY "GARLOCK" TYPE GASKET THAT SHOWS STAINING OR ANY OTHER SIGN OF SEEPAGE.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: LEAK WAS INITIALLY REPORTED AS A STAIN ON THE GROUND BY AN AIR PATROL PILOT. INVESTIGATION REVEALED THE LEAK TO BE A PINHOLE IN A WELD, WITH NO MORE THAN 2 GALLONS OF OIL RELEASED. A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AT THE POINT OF THE LEAK. THIS REPORT WAS DELAYED BECAUSE THE COST, WHICH EVENTUALLY SURPASSED THE $50,000.00 REPORTING CRITERIA, WAS NOT ANTICIPATED. THE COSTS WERE INCURRED BECAUSE OF THE GREAT EXPENSE TO GET EQUIPMENT INTO THE AREA. DIFFICULTY IN REPORTING WAS EXPERIENCED IN PREVIOUS TRIES AT SUBMITTING. SOME OF THE DATA / INFORMATION DID NOT "FIT" NEATLY INTO SOME OF THE REPORTING FIELDS. I CONTACTED STEVE KERR TO REPORT THE REPORTING DIFFICULTY AND TO DISCUSS THE CHANGE IN REPORTING STATUS OF THIS LEAK DUE TO MONETARY CHANGES, AND RECEIVED INSTRUCTIONS ON HOW TO GET THE SYSTEM TO ACCEPT THE DATA WHICH APPLY TO THIS LEAK. THE CHANGE IN STATUS DUE TO THE EXPENSES INCURRED AND THE REPORTING DIFFICULTIES, COMBINED, ACCOUNT FOR THE TIMING OF THIS SUBMITAL. STEVE STATED THAT HE UNDERSTOOD THE REASONS BEHIND THE TIMING OF THIS REPORT. AN UPDATE TO THIS REPORT WILL BE FILED AS SOON AS ADDITIONAL INFORMATION BECOMES AVAILABLE. PLEASE CONTACT ME IF FURTHER INFORMATION IS NEEDED BEFORE THE ANTICIPATED UPDATE. THANK YOU.      DAVID B. STERLING.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT A 3RD PARTY OPERATION FEEDING CRUDE OIL TO THE PACIFIC MARKETING AND TRANSPORATION LLC (PMT) PALOMA PUMP STATION HAD A MALFUNCTION OF EQUIPMENT USED IN BLENDING CRUDE OIL AND NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS.  IT APPEARS THAT THE CRUDE OIL STREAM WAS REDUCED RESULTING IN AN INCREASE IN THE NGLS BEING RECEIVED AT THE PMT STATION.  THE NGLS WERE DISCHARGED AS A VAPOR FROM THE PUMPING EQUIPMENT.  THE MECHANISM FOR THIS IS STILL BEING INVESTIGATED.  THE CONCENTRATION OF NGL VAPORS ULTIMATELY CAME IN CONTACT WITH AN IGNITION SOURCE RESULTING IN AN EXPLOSION AND SUBSEQUENT FIRE.  THE INCIDENT WAS REPORT TO PMT BY TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION FROM AN OUTSIDE PARTY.  COMPANY PERSONNEL AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO THE INCIDENT.  THE EQUIPMENT WAS ISOLATED FROM THE PIPELINES BY CLOSING VALVES.  FIRE DEPARTMENT COMMAND MADE A DECISION TO ALLOW THE FIRE TO BURN ITSELF OUT.  ONLY A SMALL AMOUNT (LESS THAT 10 GALLONS) OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED FROM THE PUMP AREA.  ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE PUMP CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE COMPANY IS INVESTIGATING THE ACCIDENT.  A DECISION HAS NOT BEEN MADE AS TO WHEN OR IF THE FACILITY MAY BE PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.  THE FACILITY WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE INDEFINITELY.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 30, 2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 1330 HOURS, COMPANY PIPELINE PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED BY A FARMER OF A CRUDE OIL SPILL AT FOLLETT PUMP STATION, A TRUCK HAUL UNLOADING AND CUSTODY EXCHANGE POINT.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY, ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE, AND THE RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS.  THIS PUMP STATION IS PART OF A NON REGULATED CRUDE OIL GATHERING SYSTEM  IN THE TEXAS PANHANDLE.  THE LEAK OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS EARLIER WHEN A WELD ON THE INLET 3" SCRAPER TRAP CRACKED DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION.  THE SPILL WAS HALTED BY SHUTTING DOWN THE PUMP AND CLOSING THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES ON THE TRAP.  DUE TO FREEZING CONDITIONS AND ICING ON THE TERRAIN, THE ESTIMATED 30 BARRELS OF SPILLED CRUDE OIL DEVELOPED A WIDE DISPERSION AREA PENETRATING THE GROUND APPROXIMATELY 2" DEEP.  A DECISION WAS MADE TO CONTAIN THE SPILL AND REMEDIATE IT IN PLACE.  SOIL SAMPLING WAS COMPLETED AND REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  TOTAL COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $2398.00.  INTERNAL CORROSION WAS CONFIRMED AS THE CAUSE DURING REPLACEMENT OF THE TRAP BARREL.  WATER FALLING OUT OF THE CRUDE OIL HAD CORRODED THE WELD UNTIL IT GAVE AWAY.  NEW PREVENTATIVE MEASURES WERE ACCOMPLISHED BY REPLACING THE INLET SCRAPER TRAP BARREL.

column245: ON TUESDAY, DECEMBER 17TH, AT 1:50 PM SUNOCO PIPELINE, L.P.'S SOUR LAKE DISTRICT OFFICE RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM LANDOWNER DON CRYER REPORTING OIL ON HIS POND. THE 8" COLMESNEIL LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND EMPLOYEES DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  BY 6:00 PM THAT EVENING THE LINE HAD BEEN EXCAVATED, A SMALL PIN HOLE LEAK LOCATED AND A LEAK CLAMP INSTALLED;  CLEAN UP WAS COMPLETED BY DECEMBER 20TH, THE LINE WAS REPAIRED BY DECEMBER 21 AND PUT BACK INTO SERVICE ON DECEMBER 23.  THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDLIFE GAME WARDEN INFORMED SUNOCO PIPELINE, L.P. THAT THE LEAK HAD BEEN TURNED INTO THEIR DISPATCHER APPROXIMATELY TWO WEEKS PRIOR TO THE NOTIFICATION BY THE LANDOWNER.  ACCORDING TO THE GAME WARDEN, THE MAN WHO TURNED IN THE LEAK LEFT AN INCORRECT PHONE NUMBER WHICH PREVENTED PARKS AND WILDLIFE PERSONNEL FROM VERIFYING THE LOCATION OF THE SPILL.  THE PARKS AND WILDLIFE DISPATCHER WAS NOTIFIED AGAIN ON 12/15/02 AND THEIR FIELD PERSONNEL VERIFIED THE SPILL THE SAME DAY THE LANDOWNER LOCATED IT AND CONTACTED SUNOCO.  THE LEAK SEAPED FROM THE SMALL PIN HOLE IN THE PIPELINE, THROUGH A SMALL GULLY AND THROUGH A HEAVILY WOODED AREA APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET FROM THE PIPELINE TO THE POND.  THE TREES FORMED A CANOPY OVER THE POND, OBSTRUCTING THE VISION OF THE AIR PATROL PILOT.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: SITE IS A COMMERICAL SOD FARM.  EMPLOYEE PUNCTURED LINE WHILE BREAKING UP SOIL WITH A CHISEL PLOW.  THE LINE WAS NOT PUMPING PRODUCT AT THE TIME.  FARMER IMMEDIATELY CALLED WILLIAMS PIPE LINE COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL, WHO IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED FIELD PERSONNEL TO THE SITE.  LINE WAS ISOLATED BY CLOSING VALVES ON EITHER SIDE, PRODUCT WAS DRAINED FROM LINE AND DEFECTIVE PIECE WAS CUT OUT OF THE LINE AND REPLACED BY A NEW PIECE OF PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  LINE WAS RESTORED TO SERVICE.  REMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WILL BE DONE UNDER THE AUSPICE OF THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH & ENVIRONMENT. 8-7-03 METALURGICAL EXAMINATION INDICATED THE SOLE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE PUNCTURE BY THE PLOW BLADE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON DECEMBER 9, 2002, AT APPROXIMATELY 10:30 AM, KINDER MORGAN ENERGY PARTNERS LP WAS NOTIFIED THAT OUR 101 PIPELINE MAY HAVE BEEN HIT.  OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER THEN SHUT DOWN OUR 101 PIPELINE AND IMPLEMENTED OUR EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO BLOCK VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE REPORTED LINE HIT. THESE VALVES WERE ISOLATED WITHIN THIRTY MINUTES AFTER RECEIVING THE INITIAL CALL.  UPON OUR INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO THIRD PARTY DAMAGE.  A LANDOWNER OPERATING A BULLDOZER EQUIPPED WITH THREE 24 INCH LONG CHSEL PLOWS PUNCTURED OUR 101 PIPELINE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AT THE TIME OUR LINE WAS PUNCTURED, THE LANDOWNER HAD REMOVED TWO FEET OF COVER ABOVE OUR PIPELINE AND TWO FEET OF COVER REMAINED.  IN ADDITION, WE DETERMINED THAT THE LANDOWNER DID NOT SUBMIT A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION.

column238: POSSIBLE BOAT ANCHOR.
column245: ON THE MORNING OF 1/30/03, THE PIPELINE WAS STRUCK BY AN OUTSIDE FORCE THAT IMMEDIATELY CREATED A GASH IN THE PIPELINE.  OIL BEGAN TO LEAK FROM THIS GASH.  A CHEVRON/TEXACO FIELD SUPPLY BOAT NOTICED OIL ON THE WATER AND NOT KNOWING THE SOURCE CALLED OUT A SPILL RESPONSE CREW.  THE SUPPLY BOAT THEN FOLLOWED THE OIL TO ITS SOURCE.  NOTICING THAT IT WAS COMING FROM OUR PIPELINE, THEY NOTIFIED US.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN BY OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER, AND WE IMMEDIATELY CRETED A SPILL RESPONSE TEAM.

column245: A LANDOWNER REPORTED A POSSIBLE SPILL DUE TO A STAIN ON THE GROUND NEAR BELTWAY 8 AND NORTH GREENS ROAD IN ALDINE, TX.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN BY OPERATIONS CONTROL AND MAINTENANCE CREWS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.  IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT A LEAK DID EXIST AND CONTAINMENT PROCEDURES INITIATED.  THE PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 12' DEEP ALL PRODUCT (DIESEL FUEL) WAS CONTAINED IN PRE-DUG BELLHOLE.  TEMPORARY REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING A CLAMP AND PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE LATER BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE.  THE CAUSE OF THE SPILL WAS DUE TO EXTERNAL CORROSION.  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE LIMITED TO SOIL CONTAMINATION ON AN UNDEVELOPED COMMERCIAL PROPERTY, AND HYDROCARBON CONSTITUENTS IN GROUND WATER.  ALL CONTAMIATED SOIL WILL BE REMOVED AND HAULED TO A PROPER DISPOSAL SITE AND BE REPLACED BY NEW FRESH SOIL.  THERE WERE NO SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS TO PUBLIC SAFETY.  ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.

column245: ON TUESDAY FEBRUARY 4TH, 2003, THIS CRUDE OIL RELEASE WAS A RESULT OF A CRANE BOOM ( WORKING ON FACILITY PROPERTY JANUARY 23, 2003)TOUCHING A 69K VOLT POWER LINE AND CAUSING AN ELECTRICAL SURGE INTO THE GROUND.  THE ELECTRICAL SURGE CAUSED A BURN-THROUGH ON A SECTION OF THE 4" VACUUM PUMP DISCHARGE LINE WHERE A 1.5" ABANDONED CONDUIT LINE WAS TOUCHING IT BELOW GROUND.  THE 4" VACUUM PUMP DISCHARGE LINE TIES INTO THE 10" RELIEF HEADER TO TANK 1360 AT ERATH STATION.  THE RELIEF LINE WAS BEING USED TO BYPASS THE TIGER SHOALS METER RUNS WHILE VALVE MAINTENANCE WAS BEING PERFORMED.      NOTE:  LINE WAS NOT PRESSURIZED ON 1/23/03.

column238: CRACK IN BOTTOM PLATE OF ATMOSPHERIC ABOVE GROUND TANK
column245: AT 08:15 PST 1-2-03 KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED STAIN ADJACENT TO INLET VALVE ON BREAKOUT TANK C-27.  INTIAL INVESTIGATION FOCUSED ON SUSPECTED RELEASE SOURCE FROM TANK INLET VALVE AND ADJACENT PIPING.  SUBSEQUENT EXCAVATION RULED OUT THESE ITEMS AND IT WAS THEREFORE SUSPECTED RELEASE COULD BE ORIGINATING FROM THE TANK BOTTOM AND PROBABLE PROJECTED THAT THE COSTS WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  THIS WAS DETERMINED AT 11:15 PST 1-3-03 AND NRC WAS NOTIFIED TELEPHONICALLY AT 12:04 PST 1-3-03.  THE FOLLOWING WEEK DURING OUR CONTINUING INVESTIGATION CRACKS IN THE TANK BOTTOM PLATES WERE FOUND NEAR THE SUMP AREA OF THE BREAKOUT TANK.

column245: THE #2-8 INCH KEYSTONE TO GOLDSMITH PIPELINE RELEASED CRUDE OIL FROM A PINHOLE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION ON THE BARE PIPE SEGMENT IS CONTROLLED BY SACRIFICIAL ANODES. EXTREMELY HIGH SOIL RESISIVITY (DROUGHT CONDITIONS) AND PREMATURE ANODE DETERIORATION CONTRIBUTED TO THIS LOCALIZED CORROSION EVENT.  218.40' OF NEW PIPE WAS INSTALLED IN THIS AREA, ALONG WITH NEW ANODES ON BOTH ENDS OF THE SEGMENT.  CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED TO GOLDSMITH STATION FOR FIREWALL REPAIR.  THE AFFECTED AREA OF THE ROW AND THE IMPACTED ADJACENT SOIL HAVE BEEN REMEDIATED SATISFACTORILY TO RAILROAD COMMISSION STATEWIDE RULE 91 CRITERIA.

column245: DURING THE TESTING OF THE REPAIR FROM THE LEAK ON 1-30-03 (REPORT NO. 20030044), THE PIPELINE WAS PRESSURED TO 750PSI TO CONFIRM THAT THE CLAMP DID NOT LEAK.  THIS IS WELL BELOW THE MOP FOR THE PIPELINE.  HOWEVER, THE LINE BEGAN TO LEAK VERY CLOSE TO CAILLOU ISLAND STATION #5.  AFTER FURTHER INSPECTION, IT WAS DETERNIMED THAT THE PIPELINE HAD EXPERIENCED OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE AT THIS POINT.  THE AREA OF DAMAGE FAILED WHEN THE LINE WAS LEAK TESTED.  THIS LEAK WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTICED BY ONE OF OUR CREWS STATIONED ALONG THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY, AND THE TEST WAS ABANDONED.    NOTE:    F.2E - ENVIRONMENTAL-WATER CONTAMINATION AMOUNT:  ACTUAL 5 GALS.  G.3--DURATION OF LEAK:  ACTUAL 1/2 HOUR

column235: 0.75" NEEDLE VALVE FAILED DUE TO EXCESS VELOCITY T
column241: JENNIFER RADER, ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY & REGULATORY COM
column245: DURING A ROUTINE CHECK OF THE CENTENNIAL KILBOURNE PUMP STATION, A MARATHON ASHLAND PIPE LINE TECHNICIAN IDENTIFIED A PRODUCT RELEASE ORIGINATING FROM THE VICINITY OF THE PUMPING UNIT.  THE STATION AND MAINLINE WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN, AND THE STATION AND PUMPING UNIT WERE ISOLATED BY CLOSING VALVES. ALL PRODUCT RELEASED REMAINED ON COMPANY PROPERTY.  THE RELEASE ORIGINATED FROM A 3/4" NEEDLE VALVE WHICH WAS A COMPONENT OF THE PUMP BEARING COOLING SYSTEM.  A TAPROOT ANALYSIS HAS BEEN INITIATED TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE NEEDLE VALVE FAILURE.  AS A SHORT-TERM SOLUTION, THIS NEEDLE VALVE, AND OTHERS WITH SIMILAR APPLICATION, HAVE BEEN REPLACED.  ADDITIONAL MODIFICATIONS MAY BE INDICATED ONCE THE TAPROOT ANALYSIS IS COMPLETE. 8-6-03 THE RELEASE ORIGINATED FROM A 3/4" NEEDLE VALVE WHICH WAS COMPONENT OF THE PUMP BEARING COOLING SYSTEM.  A TAPROOT INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTED AND DETERMINED THAT THE NEEDLE VALVE FAILED DUE TO EXCESS VELOCITY AT THE PUMP BEARING COOLING LINE LEADING TO CAVITATION AND EVENTUALLY A HOSE THROUGH THE WALL OF THE NEEDLE VALVE AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE.  THIS SUPPLEMENT REPORT IS THE FINAL REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT.       4/20/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA REVIEW. CAUSE UPDATED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO INCORRECT OPERATION.  DESCRIPTION OF EVENT REMAINS UNCHANGED- CAUSE SIMPLY RECATEGORIZED FOLLOWING REEVALUATION.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THE RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF AN UNANTICIPATED VALVE FAILURE DURING NORMAL MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY. THE MAINTENANCE PROJECT WAS TO INSTALL A TEST PORT ON THE STATION DISCHARGE RELIEF VALVE, #33, TO ENABLE THE VALVE TO BE FUNCTIONALLY TESTED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED THAT THE RELIEF VALVE WAS TO BE TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE TO INSTALL THE TEST PORT. THE UPSTREAM BLOCK VALVE, #56, WAS CLOSED AS WELL AS THE DOWNSTREAM VALVE, #36. THE DISTANCE BETWEEN THE BLOCK VALVES IS APPROXIMATELY SIX FEET. THE PLUG IN THE UPSTREAM PORTION OF THE RELIEF VALVE WAS LOOSENED AND UNSCREWED SLOWLY. ONCE REMOVED, OIL BEGAN TO FLOW OUT OF THE VALVE BODY, THE MACHINIST ON SITE PUSHED THE STATION EMERGENCY STOP AND BEGAN CLOSING PUMP SUCTION VALVES, THINKING THE PRESSURE WAS HEAD PRESSURE FROM TANKAGE. AT THAT TIME, A GAUGER ARRIVED AND CLOSED THE STATION DISCHARGE VALVE, #45, AND THE FLOW CEASED. THE BLOCK VALVE UPSTREAM OF THE RELIEF VALVE DID NOT HOLD ALLOWING CRUDE OIL TO ESCAPE FROM THE 1/2" THREADED OPENING IN THE RELIEF VALVE BODY. ONCE THE STATION DISCHARGE VALVE WAS CLOSED AND OIL FLOW STOPPED, A 1/2" VALVE WAS INSTALLED IN PLACE OF THE PLUG, TO ALLOW FOR TESTING OF THE RELIEF VALVE IN THE FUTURE.

column245: LOCAL OPERATOR NOTICED A SHEEN ON A RAINWATER PUDDLE IN A TANK DIKE ON 1/30/03. HE IMMEDIATELY CLOSED THE DIKE DRAIN AND MADE APPROPRIATE NOTIFICATIONS. PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED FROM A TANKLINE VENT ACESS WELL ADJACDENT TO THE TANK ISOLATION VALVE. THE SOURCE WAS DETERMINED TO BE A NIPPLE ON THE VENT VALVE. ON 1/30/03 THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR INSPECTION. INSPECTION OF THE TANK FLOOR REVEALED A CRACK IN TOP ANGLE OF SUMP. THE TANK FLOOR HAS BEEN REPLACED.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: THE TANK HAS BEEN PHYSICALLY ISOLATED FROM ITS SERVICE LINE SINCE 10/20/02.  THAT INCLUDED THE REMOVAL OF THE TANK SHELL VALVE WITH BLINDED FLANGES INSTALLED IN ITS PLACE. A ONE-INCH PLUG ON THE TANK LINE HAD BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A 1/2" BALL VALVE AND FOUR-FOOT VENT RISER TO FACILITATE PRODUCT EVACUATION OF THE TANK LINE. THE VALVE WOULD NORMALLY BE IN THE CLOSED POSTION UNLESS AN EVACUATION WAS NECESSARY. THE BLINDED FLANGES AND THE VENT ARE LOCATED IN AN EXCAVATED AREA APPROXIMATELY 12 FT. WIDE X 12 FT LONG X 5 FT DEEP. THIS VOID HAD BEEN FILLED WITH WATER AND SNOW IN THE TIME PERIOD SINCE 10/20/02 THAT COVERED THE FLANGES AND VENTS UNDER A 10 INCH WATER LEVEL.  IN THE RECENT WEEKS, AN EXTENDED PERIOD OF SUBFREEZING TEMPERATURES TURNED THE WATER INTO ICE APPROXIMATELY 6 INCHES THICK.    AS TEPERATURES BEGAN TO MODERATE IN THE DAYS LEADING UP TO THE INCIDENT, THE WATER TABLE RECEDED AND THE ICE CAP BEGAN TO SINK.  IT HAS SINCE BECOME APPARENT THAT AS THE ICE SANK, IT PHYSICALLY JARRED THE 1/2" VENT VALVE INTO A PRACTICALLY OPEN POSITION.  OVER TIME THE TANK LINE HAD BECOME FILLED WTIH GASOLINE THAT MIGRATED OUT OF THE VENT RISER WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPENED. IT IS COMMON PRACTICE FOR OPERATIONS TO CHECK AN OUT OF SERVICE STINGER FOR THE EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT THAT MAY HAVE MIGRATED INTO AN EVACUATED TANK-LINE.  THIS STINGER HAD BEEN CHECKED ON THIS DAY AND THE DAY BEFORE BUT DID NOT SHOW EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT.  IT IS THEORIZED THAT THE STINGER HAD ALSO FROZEN AND DID NOT ALLOW FOR PRODUCT TO BE SEEN.

column235: INADEQUATE PROCEDURES COUPLED WITH WINTER WEATHER
column245: THE PROCEDURES FOR TANK ROOF DRAINING WERE INADEQUATE COUPLED WITH THE WEATHER CONDITIONS CONTRIBUTING TO A FAILURE OF THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM ALLOWED THE PRODUCT TO ENTER THE DRAIN LINE. WINTER WEATHER WITH EXTREME TEMPERATURE ALLOWED WATER TO FREEZE IN THE DRAIN LINE CAUSING A FAILURE IN THE DRAIN SYSTEM.

column70: PACKING GLAND FAILURE ON CHECK VALVE
column245: ON 1/07/03 AT APPROXIMATELY 1005 HOURS THE PACKING GLAND ON THE CHECK VALVE AT THE +12 ELEVATION ON THE EB 160 RISER BLEW OUT AND LEAKED CRUDE OIL INTO THE WATER. THE PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE LEAK WAS 1477 PSIG. THE MAOP FOR THE LINE AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT IS 2160 PSIG. THERE HAD BEEN A PLATFORM SHUTIN ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE PIPELINE PRIOR TO THE LEAK OCCURRING, BUT THE TRENDING SHOWS THE HIGHEST PRESSURE EXPERIENCED ON THIS PART OF THE SYSTEM WAS 1477 PSIG. THE CHECK VALVE WAS ISOLATED AND THE CRUDE OIL PUSHED DOWN THE SEGMENT WITH A POLY PIG AND WATER. THE WATER WAS THEN PUMPED OUT AND CHECK VALVE REPARIED.   THIS IS THE FINAL REPORT

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: CRUDE OIL WAS DISCOVERED IN THE TANK #7 CONTAINMENT AREA.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION SHOWED A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRUDE OIL LEAKING FROM THE AREA OF THE CHIME OF THE TANK.  THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND THE OIL WAS TRANSFERRED TO ANOTHER TANK TO STOP FURTHER LEAKAGE.  AFTER CLEANING AND SAFE-UP, THE TANK WAS INTERNALLY INSPECTED IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK.  A SILVER DOLLAR SIZED CORROSION HOLE THAT DEVELOPED FROM THE TOP SIDE OF THE TANK FLOOR WAS FOUND.  THERE WERE NUMEROUS AREAS OF TOP SIDE CORROSION BUT ONLY ONE HOLE.  THE CAUSE OF THE CORROSION WAS A LACK OF TANK BOTTOM COATING AS WAS THE PRACTICE OF THE PREVIOUS TANK OWNER.  THE TANK BOTTOM AND LOWER TANK SHELL WILL BE REPAIRED AND WILL RECIEVE A 20 MIL EPOXY COATING PRIOR TO BEING PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.

column245: CONTRACT TANK MAINTENANCE CREW TURNED TANK 6045 OVER TO LOCATION OPERATIONS AFTER COMPLETING MAINTENANCE WORK.  AT APPROXIMATELY 12:30 PM AN OPERATIONS EMPLOYEE OPENED TANKS 452 AND 453 TO TRANSFER PRODUCT INTO TANK 6045.  AT 15:00, THE EMPLOYEE INSPECTED TANK PRIOR TO LEAVING FACILITY, EVERYTHING APPEARED TO BE OKAY.  THE NEXT MORNING AT 09:15 THE SAME EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO THE TANK FARM FOR THE DAILY INSPECTION.  AT THAT TIME, HE NOTICED A PRODUCT LEAK AT TANK 6045.  A BALL VALVE ON THE RELIEF LINE WAS LEFT OPEN.  THE RELIEF LINE TUBING WAS NOT PUT BACK INTO PLACE PRIOR TO RECEIVING PRODUCT INTO TANK.  THE EMPLOYEE CLOSED THE VALVE AND BEGAN THE NECESSARY STEPS TO REPORT AND CLEAN UP THE RELEASE AND HOOK UP THE RELIEF LINE.

column43: ICE REMOVAL FROM THE NEMADJI RIVER
column47: TANK FEEDER LINE REPAIR AND HYDRO TESTING
column64: END CAP OF DELIVERY LINE FAILED
column245: ON JANUARY 24, 2003, AN INCIDENT OCCURRED AT OUR SUPERIOR, WISCONSIN TERMINAL FACILITIES DURING A SWING FROM TANK 19 TO TANK 23 OFF LINE 4. WHILE OUR INVESTIGATION IS ONGOING, INITIAL INDICATIONS ARE THAT AN END CAP OFF OF A 24" DELIVERY LINE FAILED DURING A RELATIVELY MINOR PRESSURE SURGE CAUSED BY AN OPERATOR MOMENTARILY SWINGING AGAINST A CLOSED TERMINAL VALVE DURING A DELIVERY. THIS RESULTED IN THE RELEASE OF APPROXIMATELY 4500 BARRELS CRUDE OIL, A PORTION OF WHICH MIGRATED OFF SITE TO THE NEARBY FROZEN NEMADJI RIVER. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT APPROXIMATELY 450 BARRELS OF OIL REACHED THE RIVER; HOWEVER, INFORMATION GATHERED FROM NUMEROUS MONITORING WELLS INDICATED THAT THE PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED ABOVE THE ICE AND THAT IT DID NOT REACH THE ACTUAL WATERS OF THE RIVER. CLEANUP OF THE ICE HAS BEEN COMPLETED.    THE ENBRIDGE ENVIRONMENT DEPARTMENT HAS RECEIVED A SITE CLOSURE LETTER FROM THE WI DNR.

column245: A 2" DRAIN LINE CONNECTED TO THE DISCHARGE OF THE 8RK BOOSTER PUMP IN THE FUEL MANIFOLD HAD COLLECTED WATER UPSTREAM OF THE 2" DRAIN VALVE.  THE LINE HAD FROZEN DURING A PERIOD OF COLD WEATHER WHILE THE MANIFOLD HAD BEEN INACTIVE.  PUMPING FROM THE FUEL MANIFOLD ON THE 8RK LINE BEGAN AT 22:04 ON SUNDAY, JANUARY 25, 2003.  THE EXACT TIME THE RELEASE BEGAN IS UNKNOWN.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED AND THE AFFECTED LINE SEGMENT SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED AT 00:48 ON MONDAY, 1/27/03.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: OPERATOR FOR ENERGY OPPORTUNITY & GROWTH (EOG) DISCOVERED THE LEAK AND CALL IT INTO WYOMING ONE CALL WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED ALL OPERATORS IN THE AREA.  AFTER INITIAL INSPECTION IT WAS DETERMINED TO BE ROCKY MOUNTAIN PIPELINE SYSTEMS (RMPS) LEAK.  THE OPERATOR FOR EOG HAD SHUT IN ALLL LACT'S UPON DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK.  RMPS EXCAVATED THE LEAK AND PLACED A TEMPORARY PIPE CLAMP FOR THE NIGHT.  PERMANENT REPAIRS WAS MADE THE NEXT DAY.  ALL FREE LIQUIDS WERE RECOVERED FROM THE SITE AND PROCESSED BACK INTO EOG'S PRODUCTION SYSTEM OR INTO RMPS PIPELINE SYSTEM DOWN STREAM OF THE LEAK.  ALL CLEAN UP PROCEDURES WERE APPROVED BY THE STATE OF WYOMING.  CLEAN UP IS COMPLETE AS OF THE DATE OF THIS REPORT.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: MIRAMAR JUNCTION IS AN UNMANNED METERING STATION AND PIPING MANIFOLD ON KINDER MORGAN'S INTRASTATE PIPELINE SYSTEM.  ON FEBRUARY 3, 2003, MAINTENANCE WAS PERFORMED ON A CONTROL VALVE AT THIS SITE.  THE STATION WAS DRAINED DOWN THROUGH A 2" DRAIN VALVE UNDER THE STRAINER.  THE STATION WAS REPRESSURED TO 90 PSI FROM FPRODUCT IN THE SUMP AND THE PRESSURE REMAINED STATIC.  THIS FACILITY IS ONLY SUBJECT TO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE WHEN DELIVERING TO MILITARY STORAGE.  AT 17:11 ON FEBRUARY 8, 2003 A KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE SWITCHED TO MILITARY STORAGE AND PRESSURE A MIRAMAR INCREASED TO 500 PSI.  THE EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO COMPLETE THE MILITARY DELIVERY AT 08:00 ON FEBRUARY 9, 2003 AND OBSERVED PRODUCT RELEASING FROM TOP OF SUMP.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND SECURED AND EMERGENCY  RESPONSE WAS INITIATED.  THE APPARENT CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE DEBRIS IN SEAT OF A 2" STRAINER DRAIN VALVE, CAUSING INABILITY TO SEAT PROPERLY.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY, & REGULATORY COM
column245: TUBING FOR INSTRUMENTATION WAS REROUTED TO SEPARATE SHUTDOWN SWITCHES FOR MULTIPLE PUMP UNITS.  THE REVISED ROUTING UTILIZED EXISTING TUBING THAT WAS CONNECTED TO ANOTHER SECTION OF TUBING WITH A TEE.  THE OTHER SECTION OF TUBING HAD BEEN CAPPED, BUT IT HAD BEEN DAMAGED AND BROKEN INTO TWO PIECES.  THE NEW INSTALLATION WAS PRESSURE TESTED, BUT THE SECTION THAT HAD BEEN BROKEN WAS LIKELY PLUGGED WITH ICE SO THAT IT PASSED THE PRESSURE TEST.  THE ICE PLUG SUBSEQUENTLY FAILED, RELEASING PRODUCT.  IT WAS DISCOVERED BY AN OPERATOR PASSING BY THE LOCATION.  A TAPROOT ANALYSIS IS CURRENTLY BEING CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE ACTUAL ROOT CAUSE AND TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE.  A TAPROOT INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE ACTUAL ROOT CAUSE AND TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS TO PREVENT A RECURRENCE.  THE INVESTIGATION HAS REVEALE THAT THE CAUSE OF THIS EVENT WAS DUE TO INADEQUATE TRAINING MAPL IS IN THE PROCESS OF ENSURING APPROPRIATE TRAINING IS GIVEN.      4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. PLOTTED THE ORIGINALLY REPORTED COORDINATES AND THEY WERE NOT AT THE POINT OF RELEASE. UPDATED COORDINATES TO THE ROBINSON RIO STATION ACCORDINGLY.  LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE ORIGINALLY REPORTED AS 39.0458N AND - 87.71826W, RESPECTIVELY. UPDATED HCA INFORMATION. ORIGINALLY WAS NOT IDENTIFIED AS BEING AN HCA, BUT IT WAS IN A POPULATED AREA.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A 1-INCH DIAMETER DRAIN VALVE WAS ATTACHED HORIZONTALLY (WITH AN L-PIPE EXTENSION) TO THE BOTTOM OF THE PROVER PIPE SYSTEM AT SAMARIA, MI.  THIS L-PIPE ARRANGEMENT CREATED AN AREA FOR WATER TO COLLECT AND DID NOT ALLOW FOR THE EXPANSION OF ICE.  THE VALVE RUPTURED AS A RESULT OF WATER THAT HAD SETTLED OUT FROM THE CRUDE AND FROZE.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS DETERMINED TO BE NATURAL FORCES; SPECIFICALLY, TEMPERATURE WITH SUBCAUSE BEING FROZEN COMPONENT.    THE L-PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND THE 1-INCH VALVE HAS BEEN PLACED IN THE VERTICAL POSITION ALLOWING ANY FUTURE ICE EXPANSION TO ESCAPE INTO THE LARGER 12-INCH PROVER PIPE RUN.  ALL SIMILAR VALVE INSTALLATIONS AT SAMARIA, MI AND OREGON, OH HAVE BEEN UPGRADED TO PREVENT A SIMILAR OCCURRENCE.

column245: THE RELEASE OCCURRED ON EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY'S (EMPCO) EMPIRE CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM AT A PRODUCTION PLATFORM KNOWN TO EMPCO AS THE LAKE WASHINGTON PLATFORM.  THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS A LINE BREAK WHICH OCCURRED IN A 4" PIPE WHICH CONNECTS TO EMPCO'S 12" MAINLINE.  BASED ON A REVIEW OF THE OPERATIONAL DATA ON THE EMPIRE PIPELINE SYSTEM, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE LINE BREAK OCCURRED AT 0304 HRS. ON MARCH 2, 2003.  EMPCO'S OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER SHUTDOWN AND ISOLATED THE EMPIRE SYSTEM PUMPING UNITS AND THE INJECTION POINTS ALONG THE EMPIRE SYSTEM MAINLINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE.  THE EXISTENCE AND PHYSICAL LOCATION OF THE LEAK WAS CONFIRMED AT 0500 HRS., MARCH 2, 2003. THE 4" AND 12" ISOLATION VALVES LOCATED ON THE PLATFORM WERE BOTH CLOSED BY 0525 HRS.  EMPCO MOBILIZED OIL SPILL RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT.  ALL AGENCIES NOTIFIED.  CLEAN-UP IS COMPLETE.  A COPY OF THE FINAL INVESTIGATION REPORT WAS SUBMITTED TO THE HOUSTON OPS REGIONAL OFFICE.

column245: ON SUNDAY MORNING, MARCH 16 AT 0800 HRS., THE STATION OPERATOR WAS MAKING HIS ROUTINE DAILY STATION CHECKS WHEN HE ARRIVED AT GRAPEVINE PUMP STATION TO FIND THE #2 MAINLINE CENTRIFUGAL PUMP LEAKING CRUDE OIL FROM THE INBOARD SEAL.  HE IMMEDIATELY SWITCHED PUMPS AND ISOLATED THE #2 PUMP.  THE STATION OPERTOR THEN NOTIFIED THE AREA SUPERVISOR WHO CONTACTED RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND NOTIFIED THE APPROPRIATE COMPANY PERSONNEL AND STATE AGENCIES.  CLEANUP OF THE GROUND SURFACE WAS BEGUN WITHIN AN HOUR AND THE SEAL THAT FAILED WAS REPLACED BY 1200 HRS., 3/16/03.  THE SEAL LEAK DETECTOR WAS TESTED AND FOUND TO GE FUNCTIONING PROPERLY.

column245: CONTRACTOR WAS CLEARING ROW FOR OPERATOR AT A REMOTE LOCATION. WHILE PULLING OUT OF LOW AREA ONTO A LEVY, CONTACT WAS MADE WITH PIPE AND PIPE WAS PUNCTURED. OPERATOR RESPONDED BY MAKING AREA SAFE AND NOTIFYING APPROPRIATE STATE AND NATIONAL REGULATORY PARTIES. THE RELEASE OF HVL PROPANE QUICKLY FLASHED OFF AND NO RESIDUAL CONTAMINATION WAS EVIDENT. THE RELEASE TO THE ATMOSPHERE WAS MONITORED AND THE AREA WAS KEPT SAFE. THE MLBV WERE CLOSED ISOLATING THE SEGMENT OF PIPELINE AND TO EXPEDITE THE BLOW DOWN, IT HAS BEEN ESTIMATED THAT 90% OF THE PROPANE THAT WAS RELEASED WAS DONE SO VIA A CONTROLLED BURN AT A REMOTELY LOCATED BLOW DOWN VALVE SITE ON THE PIPELINE. APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET OF THE LINE WAS REPLACED AND THE LINE WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE AS THE SEGMENT WHERE THE DAMAGE OCCURRED IS NOT REQUIRED FOR OPERATIONS AT THE PRESENT TIME. NRC CASE NUMBER 634189 LA STATE POLICE CASE NUMBER 03000294.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: CAUSE OF LEAK IS THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN A PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE ON THE PUMP DISCHARGE.  WHEN THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN, OIL LEAKING INTO SUMP STOPPED.  THERE WAS NO HIGH PRESSURE INDICATING THAT THE RELIEF VALVE FAILED, BUT NO OTHER SOURCE FOUND TO BE LEAKING.  A RETEST WAS DONE ON THE VALVE AND SHOWED IT TO BE OK.  TO PREVENT THIS FROM HAPPENING AGAIN, THE RELIEF VALVES ON ALL PUMPS WERE REPLACED AND TESTED.  ALSO, THE PIPING FROM THE RELIEF VALVES WAS PIPED SO THEY WOULD DISCHARGE INTO A TANK RECEIVING LINE INSTEAD OF THE SUMP.  A HIGH SUMP ALARM HAD FAILED DUE TO POWER FAILURE ON THE SUMP, SO THE HIGH SUMP ALARM WAS CONNECTED TO ITS OWN POWER SOURCE.  THEN THE ALARM AND SUMP CONTROL WAS CONNECTED TO THE SCADA CONTROL.

column245: ON MARCH 16, 2003, A MOTORIST NOTICED STAINING AND DEAD VEGETATION ON COLONIAL'S RIGHT OF WAY JUST DOWNSTREAM OF WHERE LINE 3 AND 4 CROSS RT. 28 IN NOKESVILLE, VA.  HE CALLED COLONIAL'S FAIRFAX DELIVERY FACILITY AT 16:15 TO REPORT HIS FINDING. THE FAIRFAX OPERATOR INITIATED THE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE PROCEDURES.    THE LEAK WAS FOUND ON THE 32 IN. LINE 4 ON MARCH 19, 2003. A CRACK HAD DEVELOPED IN A BOTTOM SIDE DENT. A PIPELINE REPAIR SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED.  ADEQUATE SEDIMENT AND STORMWATER RUNOFF CONTROLS WERE PUT IN PLACE. RAIN WATER REMOVED DURING EXCAVATION WAS TREATED ON-SITE THROUGH CARBON VESSELS.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON MARCH 2, 2003 AT APPROXIMATELY 0900 HOURS, CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL NOTICED AN ACCUMULATING LOSS IN VOLUME OF CRUDE BEING PUMPED.  PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE ALERTED TO INVESTIGATE AND SUBSEQUENTLY, DISCOVERED A SPILL AT 1215 HOURS LOCATED 15 MILES AWAY AT THE STEWART PUMP STATION.  THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN, A SITE ASSESSMENT MADE, THEN INTERNAL NOTIFICATION TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, PIPELINE SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE WERE MADE FOLLOWED BY EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. THE SPILL WAS IN PART CONTAINED INSIDE THE PUMPHOUSE ON THE CONCRETE FLOOR AND THE REMAINDER CONFINED TO COMPANY PROPERTY.  FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VACUUM TRUCK AND PUMP REPAIRS WERE MADE.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED AND REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  THE LEAK RESULTED FROM FAILURE OF THREADS ON THE PACKING GLAND BODY, WHICH WAS REPLACED.  THE OTHER PACKING GLAND WAS INSPECTED FOR SIMILAR CONDITIONS, BUT NONE WERE FOUND.  TOTAL COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $9500.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. SEAL FAILURE SUB-CAUSE CHANGED FROM "OTHER."

column245: LAND OWNER DISCOVERED THE LEAK AND CALLED ROCKY MOUNTAIN PIPELINE SYSTEM'S (RMPS) OPERATION CONTROL CENTER. UPON NOTIFICATION THE CONTROL CENTER SHUT DOWN THE LINE AND NOTIFIED FIELD OPERATION PERSONNEL. UPON DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK LOCATION THE BLOCK VALVE UPSTREAM WAS SHUT IN, THE BLOCK VALVE DOWN STREAM WAS LEFT OPEN TO ALLOW THE LINE TO DRAIN BACK INTO THE FT LARAMIE STATION. THE SITE WAS EXCAVATED AND A TEMPORARY CLAMP WAS INSTALLED. PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE ON THE 23RD. RMPS HAS VOLUNTARILY REDUCED THE MOP 20% OF THIS LINE SEGMENT UNTIL AN INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT IS CONDUCTED.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column238: DURING NITROGEN PURGING ACTIVITIES FOR LINE REPAIR, NITROGEN APPEARED TO BLOW THROUGH FRAC TANK.
column245: BP PIPELINE WAS PREPARING TO PERFORM PERMANENT LINE REPAIR 2-3 MILES EAST OF THIS SITE. DURING PURGE ACTIVITIES, PIG MOVED BY NITROGEN ARRIVED AT THE RECEIVER SITE, WITH NITROGEN BLOWING THROUGH FRAC TANK. BEFORE LOCAL PERSONNEL COULD SWITCH NITROGEN TO SECOND FRAC TANK, H2S EVOLVED FROM THE CRUDE DUE TO TURBULENCE OR N2 PRESSURE, IMPAIRING ABILITY TO ACROSS VALVES TO SWITCH OVER AND CLOSE OUT NITROGEN. AT THIS TIME, CRUDE WAS BLOWN WITH NITROGEN TO SIDE OF FRAC TANK, ENDING UP IN EXCAVATION OF RECEIVING TRAP. PERSONNEL WERE FINALLY ABLE TO ISOLATE VALVE AFTER DONNING FRESH AIR EQUIPMENT, HOWEVER ENOUGH TIME HAD PASSED TO ALLOW 15BBLS TO ESCAPE FRAC TANK. MOST OF THE OIL WAS RECOVERED IN THE EXCAVATION OR RECEIVER TRAP, WHICH HAD PREVIOUS CONCRETE FLOOR POURED TO ALLOW SAFER WORK SURFACE AND TO MINIMIZE POTENTIAL ANY DAMAGE TO ENVIRONMENT SHOULD PROBLEM ARISE.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 3:55 P.M., APRIL 1, 2003, THE OIL MOVEMENTS COORDINATOR RECEIVED A PUMP #1 UNAUTHORIZED CHANGE FROM THE PONCA CITY PUMP STATION.  THE LOCAL OPERATOR AT THE PUMP STATION NOTIFIED THE OIL MOVEMENTS COORDINATOR THAT THE #1 UNIT HAD WENT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION.  THE LINE WAS ISOLATED WITH THE REMOTELY OPERATED VALVES AND LOCAL FIEL OPERATION WERE NOTIFIED.  LOCAL FIELD OPERATIONS WERE ORGANIZED AND MOBILIZED TO BEGIN LOOKING FOR A POSSIBLE FAILURE OF THE LINE PIPE.  CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO MP 0, MP 18.  DISCOVERY OF THE RELEASE SITE WAS AT 9:48 P.M..  CAUSE OF INCIDENT IS SEAM FAILURE. PIPE IN THE AREA OF THE RELEASE WAS REPLACED AND THE LINE RESTARTED ON 4/4/2003.    PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LAB FOR A FULL METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  MORE TO FOLLOW.   LAB RESULTS INDICATED THAT THE FAILURE INITIATED AT A GROOVE-LIKE AREA OF EXTERNAL CORROSION CENTERED ON THE ERW BONDLINE.  THE DEEPEST CORROSION WAS CENTERED ON THE BONDLINE.  HENCE, IT IS CONCLUDED THAT THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION.  THE ANALYSIS OF CAUSE OF FAILUR REPORT WAS SENT TO THE SOUTHWEST REGIONAL OFFICE.

column66: GASKET FOR ON LINE FLASHER SYSTEM
column245: AT 0710 ON APRIL 15, 2003, A CONTRACTOR WAS SENT TO INSPECT A SIGHT GLASS THAT WAS RECENTLY INSTALLED ON THE LINE 2 ON-LINE FLASHER.  THE CONTRACTOR FOUND A SMALL PUDDLE OF PRODUCT UNDER THE ON-LINE FLASHER AND SAW THAT THE DIAPERS IN THE AREA HAD ABSORBED SOME PRODUCT. UPON INVESTIGATION LOCAL PERSONNEL DETERMINED THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT WAS A FILTER FOR THE ON-LINE FLASHER SYSTEM. LINE # 2 WAS SHUT DOWN AT 0719 THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS ISOLATED FROM THE MAINLINE AND THE LINE WAS RESTARTED AT 0819.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: WORK WAS BEING CONDUCTED TO PREPARE FOR THE LOWEREING OF THE 12" ALDING TO HEARNE PRODUCTS PIPELINE WHERE IT INTERSECTS WITH SPRING CYPRESS ROAD, MP 93.5 IN SPRING, TX. TWO 12" STOPPLE FITTINGS AND FOUR 2" TOR FITTINGS WERE PLANNED TO BE INSTALLED.  THE INSTALLATION OF THE 2" TOR FITTINGS INVOLVES HOT TAPPING THE LINE TO MAKE THE FITTING FUNCTIONAL.  THIS ENABLES THE EXISTING LINE TO BE DRAINED THROUGH THE TOR FITTING AND A 2" VALVE THAT IS ATACHED TO IT.  WHILE PERFORMING THE HOT TAP ASSOCIATED WITH THE THIRD 2" TOR FITTING, THE 2" VALVE THAT IS CONNECTED TO THE 2" TOR FITTING FAILED TO HOLD PRESSURE.  THIS LED TO A RELEASE OF GASOLINE WHEN THE TAPPING TOOL WAS REMOVED FROM THE 2" VALVE.  THE RELEASE IMMEDIATELY REACHED A HEIGHT OF ~60' FOR A FEW MINUTES.  THE STREAM HAD DECREASED TO ~3' BY 0945 HRS AND TO A 1' BY ~1130 HRS.  THREE CONTRACT EMPLOYEES WERE INVOLVED IN THIS HOT TAPPING PROCESS BUT THEY WERE NOT INJURED. DURING THIS RELEASE AND A FIRE DID NOT ENSUE.  APPROPRIATED ACTIONS WERE TAKEN IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE RELEASE TO PREVENT A FIRE AND TO NOTIFY THE PROPER ENTITIES.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE IMMEDIATE WORK AREA WITH NO SIGNIFICATE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS.  AS A PRECAUTIOARY MEASURE, PERSONNEL WERE EVACUATED FROM A NEARBY ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING.

column245: AFTER COMPLETION OF A VALVE SWITCH FROM TANK CC-14 TO THE SURGE, PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED BY A KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE ABOVE THE SUSPECT BURIED VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS EXCAVATED AND FOUND TO HAVE SEPARATED ON THE FLANGE ATTACHING THE VALVE BODY TO THE VALVE EXTENSION DUE TO MECHANICAL FAILURE OF THE CAP SCREWS SECURING THE FLANGE.  THE VALVE WAS REPAIRED AND PRESSURE TESTED.  SUBSEQUENT ACTIVITIES HAVE FOCUSED ON PRODUCT RECOVERY AS WELL AS SOIL AND GROUNDWATER REMEDIATION.  COSTS CONTINUE TO ACCRUE AND A SUPPLEMENTAL 7000-1 WILL BE SENT WHEN COSTS ARE FINALIZED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: OBSERVATION OF THE FAILURE SHOWED A CIRCUMFORENTIAL CRACK AROUND THE WELDED JOINT CONNECTING THE 2-INCH DRAIN PIPE AND THE 2-INCH DRAIN ISOLATION VALVE.  A 3/8 INCH DIAMETER HOLE WAS OBSERVED AT THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION LOCATED UNDER THE POSITION WHERE THE WELD HAD BEEN.  THE FOLLOWING WAS ALSO OBSERVED.  MARKING CONSISTENT WITH EROSION ON THE SHOULDER OF THE 2-INCH DRAIN PIPING AND THE STATION DISCHARGE DRAIN PIPING WAS WELDED WITH AN APPROXIMATE 30 DEGREE MISALIGNMENT WITH THE 2-INCH ISOLATION VALVE.  THE 10-INCH STATION DISCHARGE PIPING IN THIS AREA WAS REPLACED TO ASSURE NO FURTHER MATERIAL DEFECTS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE.  THE 2-INCH DRAIN SYSTEM WAS RE-DESIGNED TO REMOVE THE MISALIGNMENT.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN BECAUSE IN-LINE INSPECTION DATA HAD BEEN RECEIVED THAT  DAY THAT INDICATED AN ANOMALY WITH METAL LOSS GREATER THE 80% OF WALL THICKNESS.  WHILE LOCATING THE ANOMALY, A TECHNICIAN NOTED DRIED OIL NEAR THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED TO INVESTIGATE FURTHER.  A PINHOLE LEAK WAS FOUND IN A CORROSION PIT.  THE HOLE WAS SO SMALL THAT WHEN FOUND IT WAS NOT LEAKING.  APPARENTLY, THE HOLE WOULD PLUG UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS, WHICH EXPLAINS THE SMALL AMOUNT (APPROXIMATELY 5 GALLONS) RELEASED.  THE PITTED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.     4/23/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  A TYPOGRAPHICAL ERROR ASSOCIATED WITH THE LONGITUDE WAS CORRECTED.  ALSO, THE AMOUNT OF OIL RECOVERED WAS UPDATED FROM 0 TO 5 GALLONS. IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND DISPOSED ACCORDINGLY.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON APRIL 2, 2003, AT APPROXIMATELY 2055 HOURS, CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL SWITCHED DELIVERIES.  AT 2155 HOURS, OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE ALERTED TO INVESTIGATE A LOSS OF PRESSURE ON THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND THE APPROPRIATE SEGMENT ISOLATED.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS 23:44 HOURS AND 24:01 HOURS RESPECTIVELY.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL SEARCHED THE ROW UNTIL FIRST LIGHT WHEN THE LEAK SITE WAS DISCOVERED BY HELICOPTER.  A SITE ASSESSMENT MADE FOLLOWED BY RESPONSE EQUIPMENT AND PERSONNEL ARRIVING AT THE SITE TO EFFECT CONTAINMENT AND CLEAN-UP OPERATIONS.  FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VACUUM TRUCK, CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED, AND REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  ONE JOINT OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.  THE CAUSE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION. 6-25-2003 THE CAUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE CORROSION CAUSED BY ELECTRICAL DISCHARGE.  THERE WAS A CLOSED VALVE AT THE DELIVERY SITE THAT CREATED A PRESSURE SURGE WHEN THE PRODUCT FLOW WAS DIVERTED TO A SECOND DELIVERY POINT.  ALTHOUGH NOT EXCEEDING THE MOP, THE SURGE ON THE PIPELINE EXPLOITED THE AREA WEAKENED BY CORROSION.  NO HIGH PRESSURE SHUTDOWNS WERE TRIGGERED.  REPAIRS HAVE BEEN MADE, THE ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETE, SUBSEQUENT I-L-I RUNS HAVE BEEN COMPARED TO PROVE THE INTEGRITY OF THE LINE, AND BIOREMEDIATION OF THE AREA IS ONGOING.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: CANADIAN PACIFIC RAILROAD EMPLOYEES WERE WORKING IN THE AREA OF MP 894 WHEN THEY SPOTTED A CONTRACT INSPECTOR WORKING WITH A SLEEVING CREW. THEY REPORTED THAT THEY SAW CRUDE OIL ON THE GROUND AND TOOK THE INSPECTOR TO THE LOCATION. THE INSPECTOR SAW THE SPILL AND IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WHO, IN TURN, CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER.  THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATORS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN ALL LINES IN THE AREA AND BEGAIN EMERGENCY NOTIFICATIONS.    THE OIL WAS CONTAINED IN A MARSHY AREA, AND BERMS WERE CONSTRUCTED TO PREVENT EXFILTRATION OFF-SITE.  FREE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS, AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS HAULED TO A STORAGE FACILITY FOR FUTURE LANDFARMING AND LANDFILLING.    A PLIDCO SPLIT+SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED INITIALLY AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR UNTIL A CUT-OUT COULD BE PERFORMED. THE CUT-OUT WAS COMPLETED ON APRIL 22, 2003.  IN ADDITION TO THE STOPPLE TEES, TWO PLIDCO WELD+END COUPLINGS WERE USED TO TIE IN THE NEW PIPE.

column245: THIS INCIDENT WAS DUE TO THE APPARENT FAILURE OF A WELD IN THE SUMP AREA OF A RECENTLY CONSTRUCTED TANK.  THE TANK HAD BEEN IN OPERATION FOR ONLY FOUR MONTHS, AND THERE IS NO ACCURATE METHOD TO DETERMINE HOW LONG THE FAILED AREA HAD BEEN LEAKING.  IT APPEARS THAT ADVANCE TANK AND CONSTRUCTION COMPANY'S WELDER FAILED TO FOLLOW ESTABLISHED CONSTRUCTION AND MANUFACTURING PROCEDURES, WHICH LIKELY RESULTED IN THE APPARENT FAILURE OF THE WELD.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: THIS INCIDENT OCCURRED DURING INITIAL FILLING FROM THE 28¿ MAINLINE OF NEWLY CONSTRUCTED COLGATE PUMP STATION.  PRIOR TO FILLING THE STATION ABOVE GROUND PIPING, A LOCKOUT/TAGOUT OPERATION WAS PERFORMED ON ALL VALVES CONNECTED THE NEW 28¿ PIPING.  LATER A 4¿ VALVE CONNECTING THE STATION PIPING TO THE DRAIN SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED AND WAS NOT INCLUDED IN THE FINAL LOCKOUT/TAGOUT INSPECTION CONDUCTED PREVIOUSLY.  THIS VALVE WAS NOT FULLY CLOSED AND ALLOWED FLOW INTO THE SUMP TANK DURING INITIAL FILLING OF THE STATION PIPING CAUSING OVERFLOW THE SUMP.  THE OVERFLOW WAS QUICKLY DETECTED BY ON-SITE PERSONNEL AND FLOW INTO THE SUMP STOPPED.      A SMALL AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RAN OFF EXPLORER¿S PROPERTY INTO A COUNTY ROAD DITCH, THROUGH A CULVERT AND ONTO THE ADJACENT LANDOWNERS PASTURE.  IT DID NOT REACH SURFACE WATER.  CONTAMINATED SOIL ON THE LANDOWNER¿S AND EXPLORER¿S PROPERTY HAS BEEN REMOVED.

column70: CRACK FROM EXTERNAL FORCES-TOP PIPE DAMAGE
column245: IN RESPONSE TO AN ADJACENT LANDOWNER PHONE CALL TO EXPLORER¿S CONTROL CENTER IN TULSA, OKLAHOMA A COMPANY EMPLOYEE RESPONDED TO MP 404.8. HE DISCOVERED GASOLINE ON WATER IN A SHALLOW MAN-MADE POND.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE POND.  TWENTY-TWO BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FORM THE POND WATER.  THE REMAINDER WAS ENTRAINED IN THE SOIL ALONG THE SIDES AND BOTTOM OF THE POND.  THAT SEGMENT OF 28¿ PIPELINE WAS NOT OPERATING AT THE TIME DUE TO SCHEDULED DELIVERIES INTO THE UPSTREAM GREENVILLE, TEXAS TANK FARM.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS AND ADDITIONAL COMPANY PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE FOR CLEANUP AND REPAIRS.  ADJACENT HWO VALVES WERE CLOSED.   A PLIDCO CLAMP-ON SPLIT SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED TO ALLOW RETURN TO OPERATION TO DISPLACE GASOLINE AND GET FUEL OIL AT THE SITE FOR A SAFE REPAIR WORK ENVIRONMENT.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED ON MAY 9, 2003 AND TRANSPORTED TO OUR GREENVILLE OFFICE FOR REMOVAL OF THE PLIDCO SLEEVE AND SHIPMENT TO A METALLURGICAL LAB FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.      INITIAL ON-SITE VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE PIPE DAMAGE WAS LIMITED DUE TO GASOLINE LEAKING FROM THE FAILURE.  IT APPEARS THE FAILURE WAS THE RESULT OF TOPSIDE MECHANICAL DAMAGE THAT OCCURRED WHEN THE POND WAS BUILT OR POSSIBLY DURING SUBSEQUENT MAINTENANCE.  PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED FROM TWO IN-LINE CRACKS, EACH APPROXIMATELY ½ INCH LONG AND SEPARATED BY ½ INCH.  REPORTS FROM VARIOUS INTERNAL LINE INSPECTIONS DID NOT CALL OUT THIS DAMAGE.    AFTER REVIEW OF COMPANY HISTORICAL AERIAL REPORTS AND ONE-CALL EXCAVATION NOTICES, WE HAVE FOUND NO RECORD OF THIS POND BEING BUILT.  IT WAS DONE WITHOUT OUR KNOWLEDGE OR PERMISSION SOMETIME PRIOR TO 1990 BASED ON AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS REVIEWED AT THE LOCAL USDA SERVICE CENTER.  LOCAL LANDOWNERS ARE BEING CONTACTED FOR ADDITIONAL INFORMATION.    NOTES  PART C 5A  - PRESSURE AT TIME OF DISCOVERY.  PART G 3   - TEN DAYS DURATION IS BASED ON THE LANDOWNERS COMMENT AT TIME OF   INITIAL REPORT THAT HE HAD SMELLED PETROLEUM ODOR ABOUT TEN DAYS EARLIER.

column245: ON APRIL 21, 2003, A SPILL OF SOUR CRUDE OIL OCCURRED AT MIDLAND STATION IN MIDLAND, TEXAS.  APPROXIMATELY 200 BARRELS RELEASED, WITH 180 BARRELS RECOVERED.  THE SPILL OCCURRED IN STATION PIPING, THE CAUSE WAS INTERNAL CORROSION.  ONE RESIDENCE NORTH OF THE STATION WAS EVACUATED DUE TO ODORS.  THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED INSIDE MIDLAND STATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE MINIMAL.  TEMPORARY REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING A CLAMP, PERMANENT REPAIRS WILL CONSIST OF REPLACING PIPE.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON APRIL 17, 2003, AT APPROXIMATELY 1100 HOURS, A CRUDE OIL STAIN AT RINGLING JUNCTION WAS DISCOVERED BY THE COMPANY'S AERIAL PATROL PILOT WHILE PATROLLING THE RINGGOLD TO ARDMORE CRUDE PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE PILOT IMMEDIATELY CALLED HIS OBSERVATION TO PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT THE ARDMORE PIPELINE OFFICE WHO THEN DISPATCHED A RESPONSE CREW TO INVESTIGATE.  EXCAVATION BEGAN AT 11:45 HOURS AND CONTINUED UNTIL APPROXIMATELY 16:00 HOURS WHEN THE EXACT POINT OF THE RELEASE WAS FOUND ON AN OLD OUT-OF-SERVICE 12" BYPASS.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, AND PIPELINE SAFETY, THEN THE NRC WAS CALLED AT 16:30 HOURS.  CLEAN UP OF CONTAMINATED SOIL AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN IMMEDIATELY.  REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED IN TWO STAGES; FIRST, A FULL WRAP-AROUND CLAMP WAS APPLIED TO THE AFFECTED PIPE, AND SECOND, THE OLD BYPASS LINE WAS UNFLANGED AND REPLACED WITH A BLIND FLANGE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON APRIL 12, 2003, AT APPROXIMATELY 02:30 HOURS, CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL RECEIVED AN ALARM INDICATING A DISCHARGE PUMP LOCKOUT AT ELMENDORPH PUMP STATION.  AT 06:00 HOURS, CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL CALLED OPERATIONS PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE PUMP FAILURE.  THE PIPELINE TECHNICIAN RESPONDED AT 07:00, SUBSEQUENTLY DISCOVERING THE PRODUCT SPILLED AT THE PUMP, AND CALLED OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT TO RESPOND, REPAIR, AND CLEAUP.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS WERE MADE AT 08:30 HOURS AND 08:38 HOURS, RESPECTIVELY. A SITE ASSESSMENT WAS MADE, FOLLOWED BY RESPONSE EQUIPMENT AND PERSONNEL ARRIVING AT THE SITE TO EFFECT CONTAINMENT AND CLEAN-UP OPERATIONS.  FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VAACUM TRUCK, CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED, AND REMOVED NEARBY FOR ONSITE REMEDIATION. THE CAUSE WAS SEAL FAILURE THAT ALLOWED PRODUCT TO WASH LUBRICATION OUT OF THE PUMP INBOARDS AND OUTBOARD BEARINGS RESULTING IN BEARING FAILURE, AND IN TURN LED TO PUMP FAILURE.  PRODUCT OVERFLOWED THE SUMP AND POOLED AROUND THE PUMP AREA.  THE PUMP HAD TO BE OVERHAULED IN ORDER TO RETURN IT TO SERVICE.  IN ORDER TO ALLEVIATE FURTHER OCCURANCES OF THIS TYPE, THE PUMP HAS BEEN EQUIPPED WITH TANDEM SEALS AND A LEVEL/SHUTDOWN SWITCH WAS INSTALLED ON THE SUMP.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON APRIL 9, 2003, AT APPROXIMATELY 1600 HOURS, OPERATION PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED BY EL PASO FIELD PERSONNEL WHO WERE EXCAVATING THEIR PIPELINE IN A COMMON ROW, THAT FREE PRODUCT (GASOLINE/DIESEL) WAS OBSERVED IN THE EXCAVATION.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY RESPONDED TO THE LOCATION AND BEGAIN SEARCHING FOR THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE.  AT 19:15 HOURS, THE LEAK, A 1" LONGITUDINAL CRACK WAS DISCOVERED BY RESTARTING THE LINE.  THE LINE WAS AGAIN SHUT DOWN AND TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A HIGH PRESSURE CLAMP.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATION TO THE NRC AND RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS WERE MADE AT 18:10 HOURS AND 18:14 HOURS, RESPECTIVELY. A SITE ASSESSMENT WAS MADE FOLLOWED BY RESPONSE EQUIPMENT AND PERSONNEL ARRIVING AT THE SITE TO EFFECT CONTAINMENT AND CLEAN-UP OPERATIONS.  FREE PRODUCT WAS PICKED UP BY VAACUM TRUCK, CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS SAMPLED, AND REMOVAL BEGAN THE FOLLOWING DAY.  ON APRIL 29, 2003, ONE JOINT OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.  THE CASE REMAINS UNKNOWN PENDING INVESTIGATION RESULTS BY A THIRD PARTY LABORATORY. 7-28-03 EFFECTIVE JUNE 20, 2003, THE ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION WAS COMPLETED BY THIRD PARTY INVESTIGATION SERVICE.  IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT "SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION" DUE TO DAMAGED COATING WAS THE CAUSE.  PLEASE NOTE: 1. THE MOP OF THE PIPELINE IS 1050 PSIG; THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT THE POINT AND TIME OF THE ACCIDENT WAS 600 PSIG.  2.  THE AMOUNT OF TOTAL COST HAS BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT THE COMPLETION OF REPAIRS AND ACCIDENT INVESTIGATION.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: SINCLAIR'S RESPONSE TO PART F.2.E INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING: LESS THAN ONE BARREL OF PRODUCT REACHED AN OFF-STREAM STOCKPOND. NO HYDROLOGIC CONNECTION EXISTS BETWEEN THAT STOCKPOND AND WATERS OF THE U.S. THIS SPILL DID NOT RESULT IN WATER POLLUTION AS DESCRIBED UNDER 49 CFR 195.52(A)(4).  ON MARCH 26, 2003 OPERATION COORDINATOR TANE HARTMAN RECEIVED LOW PRESSURE ALARMS ON SCADA AT ELK MOUNTAIN STATION (16:56:38) AND SINCLAIR STATION (16:57:10), AND A SINCLAIR HIGH RATE ALARM (16:57:17).  TANE INITIATED SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES ON THE LINE AT 16:57:30, BY SHUTTING DOWN THE PUMPING UNITS AT SINCLAIR AND CLOSING BLOCK VALVES AT SINCLAIR, LARAMIE STATION, LOVELAND STATION AND DENVER PRODUCTS TERMINAL.  AT THE TIME, THE LINEFILL CONSISTED ON 32,215 BBLS OF #2 FUEL OIL AND 10,124 BBLS OF GASOLINE.  AT 60,000 BBL GASOLINE BATCH HAD BEEN STARTED AT 04:30.  LOGS INDICATE THAT LINE PRESSURE AT SINCLAIR WAS 1721 PSI AND 1360 PSI AT ELK MOUNTAIN PRIOR TO THE RUPTURE.  SINCLAIR WAS RUNNING THREE UNITS IN SERIES, CONTROLLING ON DISCHARGE, WITH A SETPOINT OF 1730 PSI.  NO INTERMEDIATE PUMP STATIONS WERE IN OPERATION.  DRAG REDUCER WAS BEING INJECTED AT SINCLAIR AND THE RATE ON THE LINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 810 BPH.  THIS WAS THE NORMAL OPERATION FOR THIS PIPELINE.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND BLOCKED IN.  OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR CHRIS FLACK AND OIL MOVEMENTS SUPERVISOR PAT WILSON WERE THE FIRST CALLED.  CHRIS WAS AT THE CONTROL CENTER WITHIN 20 MINUTES AND HAD STARTED MAKING FURTHER INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WHILE ON ROUTE, INCLUDING NOTIFICATION TO MARK PETERSEN, SINCLAIR¿S MANAGER OF PIPELINES AND TERMINALS IN SALT LAKE CITY.  SINCLAIR PIPELINE (SPL) EMPLOYEES WERE DISPATCHED TO SECTIONALIZE THE LINE BETWEEN LARAMIE STATION AND SINCLAIR.  PRESSURE WAS HOLDING AT LARAMIE AND PRESSURE CONTINUED TO DROP AT ELK MOUNTAIN.  BOTH THE CARBON COUNTY AND ALBANY COUNTY SHERIFFS WERE CALLED TO NOTIFY OF A POSSIBLE LEAK AND TO REPORT TO US ANY REPORTS OF GASOLINE ODORS ETC.  DISTRICT MANAGER BARRY BLUTH, WHO WAS WESTBOUND ON I-80 BETWEEN LARAMIE AND CHEYENNE AT THE TIME OF NOTIFICATION, WAS THE FIRST TO REPORT AN ODOR WHEN HE CROSSED THE MEDICINE BOW RIVER IN ELK MOUNTAIN.  HE PROCEEDED TO CLOSE THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY BLOCK VALVE (18:48) AND JON BROWN CLOSED THE BARTLETT BLOCK VALVE (18:52) THEREBY ISOLATING THE MEDICINE BOW RIVER CROSSING.  BARRY ALSO REPORTED MORE GASOLINE ODORS AT THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY BLOCK VALVE.  A STRONG WEST WIND WAS BLOWING AND IT WAS CONCLUDED THAT THE RELEASE HAD TO BE WEST OF THE VALVE.  BY 18:00 THE MAINTENANCE DEPARTMENT HAD BEGUN MOBILIZING A VAC TRUCK, SPILL TRAILERS, A DOZER AND SPL¿S BACK HOE TO ELK MOUNTAIN.  MORE PERSONNEL WERE ON HAND AND FOOT PATROLS AND A 4-WHEELER HEADED WEST FROM THE ELK MOUNTAIN HIGHWAY VALVE.  WINDS WERE BLOWING @ 30 TO 40 MPH WITH SNOW FALLING.  THE WEATHER IMPAIRED EFFORTS FOR OFF ROAD TRAVEL, SO TRAVERSING THE ROW WAS DIFFICULT.  ALSO ATTEMPTS TO REACH ELK MOUNTAIN MANAGER, DAVID SPAUGH WAS CONTACTED AND HE ASSISTED BREAKING THROUGH THE DRIFTS AND HIS TRACTOR, ENABLING AREA OPERATOR JIM WILLCOX AND PAT WILSON TO REACH ELK MOUNTAIN STATION (21:21).  PAT AND JIM IMMEDIATELY LOCATED THE LEAK APPROXIMATELY 100' UP STREAM OF ELK MOUNTAIN STATION.  ONCE CONFIRMED, ALL RESPONDING PERSONNEL REPORTED TO ELK MT. STATION.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY NO FLOW WAS APPARENT OUT OF THE LEAK SITE.  ASSESSMENT OF SPILL SIZE AND SPREAD BEGAN, WITH THE PONDS LOCATED TO THE NORTH OF THE STATION AS THE HIGHEST CONCERN.  ONCE CONFIRMED, ALL RESPONDING PERSONNEL REPORTED TO ELK MT. STATION.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY NO FLOW WAS APPARENT OUT OF THE LEAK SITE.  ASSESSMENT OF SPILL SIZE AND SPREAD BEGAN, WITH THE PONDS LOCATED TO THE NORTH OF THE STATION AS THE HIGHEST CONCERN.  AN INCIDENT COMMAND POST AND STAGING AREA WAS ESTABLISHED AT THE ELK MOUNTAIN I-80 INTERCHANGE.  THE SOUTHEAST WYOMING OIL SPILL ASSOCIATION (SWOONS) SPILL TRAILER FROM CASPER ARRIVED AT 21:00.  BECAUSE OF THE INCLEMENT WEATHER AND THE CLOSURE OF I-80, THE DOZER DID NOT REACH THE SITE, HOWEVER HYLAND TRUCKING WAS ABLE TO GET SPL¿S BACKHOE TO THE STAGING AREA BY 23:00.  THE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED THE HIGHWAY PATROL AND OBTAINED A WAIVER TO THE ROAD CLOSURE FOR RESPONDING PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT.  A TRAILER VACUUM TRUCK FROM HYLAND ALSO MADE IT TO THE STAGING AREA.  THE CONDITION OF THE ROAD FROM THE STAGING AREA INTO THE STATION DID NOT PERMIT EITHER OF THE VAC TRUCK¿S ACCESS.  CHRIS FLACK MADE NOTIFICATION TO THE NRC AND WYOMING DE AT 22:15 AND 22:26 RESPECTIVELY.  MATERIAL FROM SPL¿S SPILL TRAILER WAS BROUGHT FROM THE STAGING AREA TO THE LEAK SITE TO CONTAIN THE EXTENT OF THE SPILL.  A GENERATOR AND PORTABLE LIGHTS WERE DEPLOYED.  ABSORBENT BOOMS AND PADS WERE INSTALLED AT THE EDGE OF THE SPILL SITE.  CONTAINMENT WAS ACHIEVED AND PERSONNEL LEFT THE SITE AT 01:00. 2-24-04 METALURIGICAL INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT A DENT WITH GOUGE WAS THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column110: WELDED STOPPLE W FLANGES IN BODY
column245: ON MAY 7, 2003, A SUNOCO PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS PERFORMING A LINE LOCATE IN RESPONSE TO A ONE-CALL TICKET FOR THIRD PARTY WORK PLANNED NEAR THE 8-INCH INKSTER TO SARNIA PIPELINE.  WHILE IN THE AREA, THE EMPLOYEE NOTICED AN AREA OF DEAD VEGETATION APPROXIMATELY 15 FEET IN DIAMETER ON THE PIPELINE R/W AND A LIGHT SHEEN LEACHING OUT OF THE SOUTH BANK OF THE NEAR-BY MIDDLE BRANCH ROUGE RIVER.  THE SHEEN DISSIPATED TO THE ATMOSPHERE WITHIN A FEW FEET OF THE SHORE.  DUE TO SCHEDULE, THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN SHUTDOWN FOR SEVERAL DAYS AND WAS UNDER 470 PSI STATIC PRESSURE.  THE LINE CONTAINED BUTANE.  MLV¿S WERE CLOSED ON EITHER SIDE OF THE LEAK LOCATION.      PIPELINE EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND MAINTENANCE CREWS RESPONDED.  AN ADSORBENT BOOM WAS PLACED AROUND THE SHEEN TO PREVENT ANY MIGRATION DOWN RIVER.  THE AREA OF THE DEAD VEGETATION WAS EXCAVATED EXPOSING THE PIPELINE AND A LARGE HALF-BARREL CONTAINER OF PITCH LOCATED ON TOP OF THE PIPELINE.  DUE TO AN EXTREMELY SLOW LEAK RATE, IT WAS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE THE EXACT LEAK LOCATION.  A REVIEW OF LINE DRAWINGS INDICATED THAT A STOPPLE FITTING HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THIS LOCATION IN 1961.  ILI RECORDS FROM A 1998 MFL PIG RUN INDICATED NO REMARKABLE FEATURES AT THIS LOCATION.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE HALF-BARREL CONTAINER THAT CONTAINED THE STOPPLE FITTING.  BUTANE WAS BLED OFF AND PUMPED INTO AN ADJACENT FACILITY TO REDUCE PRESSURE.  THE LINE WAS NITROGEN PURGED OF BUTANE ON MAY 9.      THE LEAKING STOPPLE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A SECTION OF NEW PRE-PRESSURE TESTED PIPE ON MAY 12.  AN IDENTICAL STOPPLE FITTING LOCATED ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE RIVER WAS ALSO REMOVED AND REPLACED.  THE LINE WAS REFILLED AND PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE ON MAY 16.    A FORENSIC FAILURE INVESTIGATION OF THE STOPPLE FITTING WAS CONDUCTED BY THE STAFF OF THE SUNOCO PIPELINE INKSTER OFFICE.  THIS INCLUDED WELDING END CAPS ON THE SECTION OF LINE, PRESSURE TESTING THE STOPPLE FITTING AND LATER DISASSEMBLY OF THE STOPPLE DEVICE.  THIS STUDY INDICATED THAT THE RTJ STYLE FLANGE ASSEMBLY ON THE TOP OF THE STOPPLE FITTING HAD A VERY SMALL LEAK MIGRATING BETWEEN THE FLANGE FACES AND THE RTJ GASKET.     WILL POTENTIALLY BE REQUIRED TO PERFORM LIMITED SOIL REMEDIATION BY MIDEQ.

column245: A CONTRACTOR WORKING INSIDE THE SPARTANBURG FACILITY VISUALLY IDENTIFIED PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AND NOTIFIED A COLONIAL TECHNICIAN WHO INSPECTED THE AREA. THE INSPECTION REVEALED THE SOURCE OF PRODUCT WAS A PHASE SEPARATION TANK HOWEVER THE OVERFLOW HAD STOPPED. THE PRODUCT FLOWED INTO THE FACILITY RETENTION POND AND WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE FACILITY PROPERTY. THE CLEAN UP OF CONTAINED PRODUCT WAS INITIATED AND COMPLETED.  AN INVESTIGATION TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE OVERFLOW WAS INITIATED BUT HAS NOT BEEN COMPLETED. A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE ENTERED UPON COMPLETION.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY & REGULATORY COMPL
column245: WHILE LAUNCHING A PIG, PRODUCT SPRAYED FROM A PLUG ON A 16-INCH WKM KICKER VALVE. THE RELEASE OCCURRED DURING THE BEGINNING OF A PLANNED PIG LAUNCH, DURING WHICH THE FIELD OPERATORS WERE ON A CONFERENCE CALL WITH OUR COMMAND CENTER. COMMUNICATION REGARDING THE RELEASE WAS INSTANTAEOUS AND THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN. CLEAN-UP BEGAN WITHIN MINUTES, AND THE LINE WAS RE-STARTED APPROXIMATELY 13 HOURS LATER. NO INJURIES OR HEALTH HAZARDS OCCURRED. THE RELEASE CAME FROM A 1/2 INCH PLUG OPENING IN THE VALVE BODY. A DETAILED INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT TWO EMPLOYEES DID NOT FOLLOW THE INTENDED PROCEDURES FOR VALVE MAINTENANCE WORK PERFORMED ON MAY 4, 2003 7-29-03 THIS SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT IS THE FINAL REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT.     4/23/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING A QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES (BV1 AND BV2) WERE IDENTIFIED AS AUTOMATIC WITH THE LENGTH OF THE SEGMENT ISOLATED AND DISTANCE BETWEEN VALVES BEING IDENTIFIED AS 150 FEET.

column245: ON MAY 22, 2003 EXPLORER WAS REPLACING THE UNIT 1 MAINLINE PUMP, WHICH REQUIRED THAT THE SUCTIONS AND DISCHARGE GATE VALVES FROM THE UNIT TO BE REMOVED.  THE UNIT SUCTION ADN DISCHARGE LINES FROM THE PUMP WERE DISCONNECTED AT THE PUMP'S 20" FLANGES.  AT NIGHT, BLIND FLANGES WERE INSTALLED ON THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE LINES TO SECURE THEM UNTIL WORK COULD RESUME THE NEXT MORNING.  THE BOLTS WERE NOT PROPERLY TIGHTENED ALLOWING PRODUCT TO LEAK FROM THE BLIND FLANGE JOINT.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON MAY 23, 2003 WHEN THE CREW ARRIVED AT THE STATION TO RESUME WORK ON THE PUMP.

column245: OIL WAS DISCOVERED ON THE RIGHT-OF-WAY BY A LANDOWNER RIDING AN ATV.  HE NOTIFIED THE PPLC CONTROLLER AT 11:15 HOURS, MAY 17.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AT 11:17 HOURS.  FIELD SURVEYS REVEALED A SMALL CRACK IN THE PIPE WHERE THE PIPELINE CAME TO REST ON A BOULDER.  THE CRACK OCCURRED IN AN AREA HAVING SUBSTANDARD BACKFILL.  MOVEMENTS OF THE BOULDER, DUE TO GROUND FROST, SHIFTED THE BOULDER TO POINT WHERE THE PIPELINE BECAME DENTED AND CRACKED.  THE LEAK WAS STOPPED BY INSTALLING A MECHANICAL REPAIR CLAMP AROUND THE PIPE AT APPROXIMATELY 1900 HOURS, MAY 18.  THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO OPERATING SERVICE AFTER THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED.  SUBSTANDARD BACKFILL WAS REMOVED FROM THE AREA.  ADEQUATE SAND PADDING WAS INSTALLED AROUND THE PIPE AND AREA WAS BACKFILLED, REGARDED AND SEEDED.

column245: CRACKED WELD. THERMO-COUPLING MANUFACTURED OF STAINLESS STEEL, WELDED INTO A THERMO-WELL MANUFACTURED OF HIGH-CARBON STEEL. THE WELD WAS CRACKED AROUND ITS ENTIRE CIRCUMFERENCE. THE THERMO-COUPLING IS ~20 INCHES LONG. IT WAS POSITIONED NEAR THE MIXER BLADES INSIDE THE TANK. SUSPECT CAUSE OF FAILURE IS THE TURBULENCE CREATED BY THE MIXER AND THE LEVERAGE EFFECT OF THE THERMOCOUPLING AT THE TANK, WHERE THE WELD WAS LOCATED.

column245: ON JUNE 10, 2003 A COLONIAL OPERATION EMPLOYEE AT PENNSAUKEN JUNCTION AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 HOURS OBSERVED A SMALL AMOUNT OF DEAD VEGETATION AT THE BASE OF THE TNK FARM DIKE WALL.  A COLONIAL ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNICIAN ARRIVED TO PROCEED WITH AN INVESTIGATION AROUND 1410.  A SOIL/GAS SURVEY WAS INITIATED IN THE DIKE AREA. A TEST PIT WAS DUG NEAR TANK 1330 AND PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED AT APPROXIMATELY 1741 HOURS.  THE INVESTIGATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF 37 MONITORING POINTS INSTALLED WITH 14 POINTS USED AS RECOVERY POINTS.  IT WAS DETERMINED ON JUNE 25, 2003 THAT THE RECOVERY OPERATION EXCEEDED THE $50,000 THRESHOLD FOR TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION AND THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED.  PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS ARE CONTINUING.     THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND INTERNALLY INSPECTED.  THE TANK FAILED IN THE AREA WHERE THE FLOOR PLATES ARE WELDED TO THE TOP OF THE SUMP.  THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE FATIGUE IN THE WELD AT THE POINT WHERE THE FLOOR PLATE IS WELDED TO THE SUMP.     THE TANK WAS REPAIRED PER API 653 STDS. AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON NOVEMBER 15, 2005.  COMPLETION OF THE PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS DETERMINED 236 BARRELS SPILLED.

column245: A HIGH RESOLUTION CALIPER INTERNAL INSPECTION TOOL IDENTIFIED THE DENT.  OIL WAS DISCOVERED ON THE RIGHT-OF-WAY, BY A PPLC EMPLOYEE, WHILE PERFORMING THE DIG SAFE LAYOUT TO EXCAVATE THE DENT THAT WAS FOUND TO BE LEAKING.  THE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER AT 15:18 HOUR ON JUNE 23RD.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY.  PUMPS LOCATED IN THE DOWN STREAM STATIONS WERE RUN UNTIL 15:48 HOUR TO REDUCE SYSTEM PRESSURE AT THE LEAK LOCATION.  FIELD INVESTIGATION REVEALED A SMALL CRACK IN THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE WHERE THE PIPELINE CAME TO REST ON A BOULDER.  MOVEMENT OF THE BOULDER, DUE TO GROUND FROST, SHIFTED THE BOULDER TO THE POINT WHERE THE PIPELINE HAD BECOME DENTED AND CRACKED.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY INSTALLING A MECHANICAL REPAIR CLAMP AROUND THE PIPE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK ON SERVICE AT 04:17 HOUR ON JUNE 24TH.  SUBSTANDARD BACKFILL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE, AN ADEQUATE SAND PAD WAS INSTALLED AROUND THE PIPE, AND THE AREA WAS BACKFILLED AND REGRADED.

column241: QUINTIN H FRAZIER, MANAGER PIPELINE SAFETY
column245: ON WEDNESDAY JUNE 4TH, A CHILTON COUNTY ALABAMA EMPLOYEE OPERATING A ROAD GRADING MACHINE, STRUCK PLANTATION PIPE LINE'S 8MG PIPELINE.  THE PUMPING STATION DOWNSTREAM OF THE RELEASE SITE SHUT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION AT 09:04AM (C.D.T) AFTER WHICH PLANTATION'S OPERATION CONTROL CENTER INITIATED SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES FOR THE ENTIRE PIPELINE.  EMPLOYEES AND CONTRACTORS WERE DISPATCHED FROM PLANTATION'S HELENA, ALABAMA TANK FARM TO BEGIN LOOKING FOR A POSSIBLE RELEASE.  PLANTATION WAS CONTACTED AT APPROXIMATELY 10:20 AM (C.D.T.) BY THE CHILTON COUNTY ROAD DEPARTMENT.  THE ROAD DEPARTMENT INFORMED PLANTATION THAT ONE OF THEIR ROAD GRADERS HAD STRUCK PLANTATION'S 8MG PIPELINE.  THE CHILTON COUNTY ROAD DEPARTMENT DID NOT SUBMIT A ONE-CALL LOCATE REQUEST FOR THE ROAD GRADING THEY WERE PERFORMING.  COUNTIES IN ALABAMA ARE EXEMPT FROM ONE-CALL REQUIREMENTS WHEN CONDUCTING ROUTINE MAINTENANCE.

column245: ON JUNE 28, 2002, CONTRACT LABORERS WERE BOLTING PIPE SEGMENT TO AN EXISTING MANIFORLD AT TEPPCO'S TODHUNTER TERMINAL.  DURING THIS ACTIVITY, A VAPOR CLOUD COLLECTED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DITCH THEY WERE WORKING IN.  THE CONTRACTOR'S ON-SITE SUPERVISOR AND ONE LABORER ATTEMPTED TO STOP THE VAPOR RELEASE BY TIGHTENING THE BOLTS ON A SET OF FLANGES LOCATED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DITCH.  THE CONTRACT LABORER WAS OVERCOME BY THE VAPOR RESULTING IN HIS DEATH.  TEPPCO EMPLOYEES IMMEDIATELY INITIATED THE EMERGENCY PLAN AND CALLED ON LOCAL MEDICAL ASSISTANCE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A RELEASE OF AN ESTIMATED 900 BARRELS OF PROPANE TO THE ATMOSPHERE FROM THE 12" PIPELINE AT THE SOUR LAKE OCCURRED ON 7/9/03 WHEN ESD VALVE 3 OPENED WHILE CONTRACTOR COMPANY PERSONNEL WERE IN THE PROCESS OF INSTALLING A SKILLET BLIND ON THE VALVE.  ESD VALVE 3 IS AN AIR-ACTUATED VALVE THAT OPENS WHEN INSTRUMENT AIR IS SUPPLIED TO THE VALVE ACTUATOR.  ON TUESDAY, 7/08/03, A DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH WENT TO THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO PREPARE IT FOR THE BLIND INSTALLATION TO BE COMPLETE ON WED. 7/9/03.  HE CLOSED ESD VALVE 3 AND  DE-PRESSURED THE DOWNSTREAM PIPING.  HE NEXT FLAGGED THE VALVE ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE SOLENOID AND THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WITH PINK FLAGGING TO SIGNIFY THAT THESE VALVES WERE TO BE CLOSED TO PREVENT ESD VALVE 3 FROM BEING OPENED.  A CONTRACT I&E TECHNICIAN HAD COMPLETED HIS TESTS.  HE ALSO GAVE THE TECHNICIAN INSTRUCTIONS TO CLOSE THE MAIN AIRLINE VALVE TO ESD 3.  THE I&E TECHNICIAN CLOSED THE BYPASS AND SOLENOID VALVES, BUT DID NOT CLOSE THE MAIN AIRLINE VALVE TO ESD 3.  NO LOCKS OR TAGS WERE APPLIED TO THE VALVES.  ON WEDNESDAY, 7/9/03 BENTON CONSTRUCTION WAS ASSIGNED THE JOB OF INSTALLING THE BLIND ON ESD VALVE 3.  THAT MORNING, A DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH WENT TO THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO VERIFY THAT THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED AND IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED.  HE VERIFIED THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED, AND HE FLAGGED THE LOCATION OF WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED WITH GREEN FLAGGING.  HE DID NOT CHECK THE POSITION OF THE ESD VALVE OR THE POSITION OF THE VALVES ON THE AIR SUPPLY LINES.  HE THEN CALLED THE BENTON CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN, WHO WAS IN ROUTE (WITH HIS CREW) TO THE STATION, AND INFORMED HIM THE STATION WAS DE-PRESSURED AND GREEN FLAGGING HAD BEEN PLACED ON THE FLANGE WHERE THE BLIND WAS TO BE INSTALLED.  THE DYNEGY PIPELINE TECH THEN LEFT THE SOUR LAKE PUMP STATION TO ATTEND TO OTHER TASKS BEING COMPLETED THAT DAY.  BEFORE STARTING WORK, THE BENTON CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN VERIFIED THE PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED AND THE VENT VALVES WERE OPEN.  HE ALSO VERIFIED THAT ESD VALVE 3 WAS CLOSED.  HE DID NOT CHECK THE POSITION OF ESD 3 AIR SUPPLY VALVES.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT, BENTON CONSTRUCTION PERSONNEL HAD INSTALLED THE BLIND AND ALL THE FLANGE BOLTS HAD BEEN HAND TIGHTENED.  AS THE CREW WAS PREPARING TO COMPLETELY TIGHTEN THE FLANGE BOLTS, THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WAS INADVERTENTLY OPENED, AND AIR WAS SUPPLIED TO THE VALVE ACTUATOR.  ESD VALVE 3 OPENED AND PROPANE WAS RELEASED FROM THE SPACE BETWEEN THE VALVE AND THE SKILLET BLIND.  EVEN THOUGH THE STATION'S INSTRUMENT AIR COMPRESSOR WAS SHUT DOWN, THE BACKUP NITROGEN BOTTLES KEPT INSTRUMENT AIR SUPPLIED TO THE ESD VALVE 3.  BECAUSE THE SOLENOID BYPASS VALVE WAS OPEN, THE HACKBERRY OPERATOR WAS NOT ABLE TO CLOSE THE ESD VALVE.  THE LEAK CONTINUED UNTIL IT WAS POSSIBLE TO SHUT OFF THE INSTRUMENT AIR SUPPLIED FROM THE NITROGEN BOTTLES TO ESD VALVE 3.

THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE 0400 JULY 16, 2003.
