column245: THE VISUAL INSPECTION AND PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATE THE PRESENCE OF A SMOOTH DENT ON THE TOP OF THE PIPE WHICH CONTAINED A THROUGH-WALL HAIRLINE CRACK IN THE BODY OF THE PIPE.  NO GOUGES OR SCRATCHES TO THE PIPE COATING WERE DETECTED AND THERE WERE NO REPORTS OF ANY RECENT EXCAVATION ACTIVITY IN THE VICINITY.  THE INVESTIGATION IS ON GOING AND CAUSE OF FAILURE HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED.  A DEAD DUCK AND TURTLE WERE FOUND IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK BUT NO DETERMINATION HAS BEEN MADE TO THE CAUSE OF DEATH.  THE AIR PATROL NOTICED BROWN VEGETATION IN THE LEAK AREA ON THE EVENING OF THE 9TH.  HIS MESSAGE WAS RECEIVED ON THE MORNING OF THE 10TH.  ON THE SAME MORNING (THE 10TH), A CONTRACTOR WAS IN THE SAME AREA AND SMELLED GASOLINE AND REPORTED IT.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON JULY 9, 2003, AN EXCAVATOR INSTALLING A WATER LINE HIT BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S PIPELINE AND CAUSED A RELEASE.  BUCKEYE WAS NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND A CREW SENT TO THE SITE IMMEDIATELY.      A LEHEY CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGE SECTION OF PIPELINE WITH PRE-CERTIFIED PIPE BEFORE THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED.      THE EXCAVATOR HAD NOTIFIED BUCKEYE THROUGH THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM ON MAY 15,2003, OF HIS INTENT TO INSTALL A WATER LINE.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE AND DETERMINED THAT BUCKEYE WAS IN THE AREA.  THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE LOCATED BUCKEYE'S PIPELINE USING A LINE LOCATOR AND PLACED FLAGS OVER THE PIPELINE.  THE EMPLOYEE ALSO DISCUSSED WITH THE EXCAVATOR BUCKEYE'S REQUIREMENTS.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS SENT TO THE SITE ROUTINELY TO INSPECT THE PROGRESS OF THE WORK BY THE EXCAVATOR.      WHEN THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE MARKED THE PIPELINE HE DID NOT ACTUALLY MARK THE PIPELINE BUT INADVERTENTLY MARKED A RECTIFIER CABLE THAT WAS ATTACHED TO THE PIPELINE.  AT THE LOCATION WHERE THE EXCAVATOR HIT BUCKEYE'S PIPELINE THE CABLE WHICH WAS MARKED AS THE PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 30 FEET FROM THE ACTUAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE.      THE EXCAVATOR CONTACTED THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM FOR THIS WORK ON MAY 15, 2003.  UNDER CT LAW THE EXCAVATION NOTICE EXPIRES AT THE END OF 30 DAYS.  IF THE EXCAVATOR HAS NOT COMPLETED WITH THE WORK IN 30 DAYS A RENEWAL NOTICE IS REQUIRED.  THE EXCAVATOR DID NOT SUBMIT A RENEWAL NOTICE TO THE CT ONE CALL SYSTEM.  HOWEVER, THE EXCAVATOR WAS WORKING IN THE AREA FOLLOWING BUCKEYE'S MARKINGS.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT WAS CHANGED TO EXCAVATOR DAMAGE FROM INCORRECT OPERATION AT THE REQUEST BY MR. ALEX DANKANICH FROM THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT THE POINT OF FAILURE WAS FOUND TO BE 1396 PSI.  THAT PRESSURE HAD BEEN HELD FOR APPROXIMATELY 6 HOURS PRIOR TO THE SUDDEN FAILURE.  METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE SITE INDICATED THE PRESENCE OF LIGHT "NON-AGGRESSIVE" CORROSION IN THE AREA OF THE FAILURE.  THE FAILURE LOCATION WAS NOTED AS BEING IN THE EXTRADOSE OF THE 45 DEGREE FIELD BEND (3 O'CLOCK).  THE ORIGNIAL WAS THICKNESS WAS FOUND TO BE 0.220.  THE CORRODED WALL THICKNESS AT THE POINT OF FAILURE WAS 0.200.  METALLURGICAL CONCLUSION WAS THE FAILURE WAS DUE TO STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.  THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT TO BE DISBONDED COATING WHICH ALLOWED THE PROPOGATION OF THE EVENTUAL SCC FAILURE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON 6/4/03 GOLDEN WEST REFINERY/THIFTY OIL COMPANY, (GWR/TOC) WAS PLANNING TO DRILL A MONITORING WELL NEAR THE LOCATION OF TWO OF KINDER MORGAN'S PIPELINES LOCATED AT 12930 S SHOEMAKER AVE IN THE CITY OF SANTA FE SPRINGS, CA.  AN UNDERGROUND SERVICE ALERT, (USA) NO. A6491542 WAS ISSUED AT 1659 ON 05/29/03 AND AN UPDATED USA NO. A6491542-01A WAS ISSUED AT 0905  ON 05/30/03 INFORMING KINDER MORGAN OF THE PLANNED WORK.  WE ACKNOWLEDGED RECEIPT OF THE USA'S AND WERE AWARE OF THE UPCOMING WORK.  ON TUESDAY MORNING, 06/03/03, WE WENT TO THE JOB SITE TO LOCATE GWR/TOC'S DELINEATION FOR THEIR PROPOSED MONITORING WELL, WHICH WAS AT THE SOUTH WEST CORNER OF THEIR PROPERTY, AND DETERMINED IT'S PROXIMITY TO OUR TWO PIPELINES.  WE CALLED GWR/TOC AND SPOKE WITH THEIR REPRESENTATIVES.  WE INFORMED HIM THAT THE LOCATION GWR/TOC REPRESENTATIVE STATED THAT THE WELL HAD TO BE PLACED IN THE DIRT AREA.  WE THEN TOLD THE GWRT/TOC REPRESENTATIVE THAT THE WELL MUST BE PLACED AS FAR AWAY FROM THE MOST EASTERLY MARK AS POSSIBLE AND THAT WE WANTED TO BE PRESENT WHEN THEY DID THE WORK.  WE WERE TOLD THAT THEY WOULD DO THE JOB MID-AFTERNOON ON 6/04/03 AND THAT WE WOULD BE CALLED BEFORE BEGINNING WORK.  THE MORNING OF 06/04/03 KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL DROVE BY THE WORK SITE ON THE WAY TO ANOTHER PROJECT AND FOUND NO ACTIVITY. AT APPROXIMATELY 0945 ON 06/04/03 WE CONTACTED GWR/TOC TO GET AN UPDATE ON THEIR START TIME AND WAS INFORMED THAT THE WORK HAD BEEN COMPLETED.  A KINDER MORGAN REPRESENTATIVE IMMEDIATELY PROCEEDED TO THE AREA AND FOUND THE WELL IN PLACE APPROXIMATELY FOUR (4) FEET EAST OF OUR MARKS AND ASSUMED IT TO BE CLEAR OF OUR LINES.  HE ASKED THE CREW IF THEY HAD RUN INTO ANY UNDERGROUND OBSTRUCTIONS AND THEY TOLD US "NO, IT WAS A CLEAN HOLE".  AT THAT POINT WE CONSIDERED THE JOB COMPLETE AND NO FURTHER ACTION WAS TAKEN.  ON 07/11/03 KINDER MORGAN WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE BY THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT.  THEY HAD BEEN CALLED TO THE SCENE DUE TO THE ODOR.     ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS (SOIL AND GROUNDWATER REMEDIATION) NOT LISTED BECAUSE THE THIRD PARTY THAT HIT THE LINE HAS TAKEN OVER THE REMEDIATION AND WILL NOT GIVE US THE DATA.

column47: EMER. RESPONSE LABOR, EQUIP. FLARING, REPAIRS
column245: LEAK WAS REPORTED BY A NUECES COUNTY DEPUTY CONSTABLE.  THE DEPUTY WAS TRAVELLING ON STATE HWY 77, 3 MILES SOUTH OF DRISCOLL, TEXAS WHEN HE NOTICED AN ICE BALL FORMING AT A CASING VENT.  HE IMMEDIATELY CALLED THE EMERGENCY 24 HOUR NUMBER AS STATED ON THE PIPELINE MARKER.  HOUSTON OPERATIONS CONTROLL CENTER PERSONNEL, AFTER CONFIRMING LINE SHUT DOWN, IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, AND EMERGENCY PROCEDURES/RESPONSE WERE IMPLEMENTED. MAINTENANCE CREWS ARRIVED AT THE SITE WITHIN 30 MINUTES, AND REPAIR PLANNING AND STEPS WERE TAKEN.  DUE TO A VAPOR CLOUD PLUME EMANATING FROM THE CASING VENT, ALL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS WERE TAKEN.  THE WIND DIRECTION DID NOT WARRANT CLOSING STATE HIGHWAY 77, BUT THE EVENT DID WARRANT CLOSING A SECTION OF A RAILROAD  NEXT TO THE INCIDENT.  DUE TO THE LENGTH OF THE FLARING OPERATIONS, PULLING THE PIPE OUT OF THE CASING, PERMANENT REPAIR WAS NOT COMPLETED UNTIL AUGUST 7, 2003.  DURING THIS TIME ALL PRECAUTIONS WERE TAKEN TO PROTECT THE PUBLIC.  ALL APPROPRIATE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE SITE WAS VISITED BY THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION'S GAS SERVICES DIVISION FOR PIPELINE SAFETY.  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE MINIMAL AND THERE WERE NO SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC DISRUPTION.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: DURING DEHYDRATION PLANT UPGRADE, VALVES WERE INSTALLED FOR SMART PIGGING OPERATION.  THE METER STATION WAS PRESSURED UP ON AUGUST 1 @ 4:00 PM.  THE O-RING SEALS (VALVE STEM) BLEW OUT AT APPROXIMATELY 6:00 PM ON AUGUST 6.  THE LINE WAS NOT SHUTDOWN BECAUSE IT OCCURRED ON DRI PROPERTY, THERE WAS NO HAZARD TO THE PUBLIC OR ENVIRONMENT.  ONLY AUTHORIZED EMPLOYEES WERE ALLOWED IN THE AREA.  ADDITIONAL PPE WAS NOT REQUIRED.  THE VALVE WAS REMANUFACTURED AND THE VENDOR CHECKED SHOP RECORDS THAT INDICATE THE OPENINGS USED WERE NOT COMPATIBLE FOR CO2 SERVICE.  A SPOOL PIECE WAS BUILT SO THE VALVE COULD BE REMOVED AND REPAIRED.  THIS REQUIRED A LINE SHUT DOWN FOR APPROXIMATELY 5 HOURS.  THIS DOWNSTREAM METER VALVES AND THE FIRST MAINTAIN BLOCK VALVE (C-010) LOCATED INSIDE THE METER STATION.  SHUTDOWN OF PRODUCTION WELDS STARTED @ 0300 ON AUGUST 9, 2003.  INSTALLATION OF THE SPOOL PIECE WAS COMPLETED AT 11:30 AM. PRODUCTION WALLS WERE BROUGHT BACK ON WITH FULL FLOW RESTORED BY 1:30 PM.

column245: AT 02:30 PDST JULY 24, 2003 KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE AT RENO TERMINAL RECEIVED SCADA ALARM OF INVOLUNTARY OPENING OF INCOMING MOV AT KINDER MORGAN METERING STATION ON FALLON NAVAL AIR STATION.  THIS CAUSED STATIC PRESSURE IN PIPELINE TO FORCE RELIEF VALVE PROTECTING MANIFOLD PIPING TO RELIEVE INTO STATION PUMP.  SUMP OVERFLOWED ONTO SURFACE GRAVEL.  RENO EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED AREA MANAGER WHO ADVISED EMERGENCY CALL TO BASE FIRE DEPARTMENT.  FIRE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED AND UTILIZED BASE FUELS PERSONNEL TO MANUALLY CLOSE FACILITY VALVES AND STOP FLOW OF PRODUCT.  THIS WAS ACCOMPLISHED AT 03:05 PDST.  INITIAL ASSESSMENT DID NOT INDICATE THAT RELEASE WOULD MEET TELEPHONIC NOTICE REQUIREMENTS OF PART 195.52.  HOWEVER, ON AUGUST 15, 2003, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT DAMAGES WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 12:21 HOURS, MAY 9, 2003, ONE OF THE COMPANY'S MAINTENANCE CREWS WAS EXCAVATING THE ROW FOR A FUTURE REPLACEMENT AND DISCOVERED A SMALL AMOUNT OF "FREE" PRODUCT (GASOLINE) IN THE DITCH. THE CREW ATTEMPTED TO DETERMINE WHICH LINE WAS RELEASING THE PRODUCT (THIS IS A COMMON ROW) AND CONFIRMED THE CORPUS CHRISTI TO HOUSTON 12" REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE HAD A SMALL PINHOLE AT A SPOT OF CORROSION ON THE PIPE.  INTERNAL (COMPANY RESPONSE) AND EXTERNAL (NRC AND RRC) NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE, THEN A TEMPORARY FULL ENCIRCLEMENT CLAMP WAS POSITIONED ON THE LINE.  REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AND IS ONGOING.  THE LINE WAS SCHEDULED FOR PERMANENT REPAIR SET TO OCCUR JUNE 16, 2003.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: ON JULY 30, 2003, AT APPROXIMATELY 13:07 MST, SFPP, L.P. EXPERIENCED A LINE RUPTURE ON OUR 8" LINE SECTION 6 (LS-6).  OUR OPERATOR IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN OUR TUCSON TO PHOENIX 8" LINE AND INITIATED OUR EMERGENCY RESPONSE.  SUBSEQUENTLY, WE ALSO RECEIVED A CALL FROM A BUILDING CONTRACTOR THAT WAS WORKING IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE LINE FAILURE.  THE CONTRACTOR REPORTED THAT A PIPELINE WAS LEAKING GASOLINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO CLOSE THE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES TO ISOLATE THE AREA.  OUR CONSULTANT'S METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS DETERMINED THAT THE FAILURE WAS A RESULT OF STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.  2-2-2010 ADDITION COST WILL BE INCURRED IN FUTURE FOR DISSOLVED GW CLEANUP. TOTAL COST THROUGH 12/31/09 $12,030,440.YA

column245: ON AUGUST 12, 2003 BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY STARTED TO REFILL THE NORCO PIPELINE AFTER MAINTENANCE WORK WAS CONDUCTED ON THE PIPELINE.  ON AUGUST 13, 2003 AT 0326 HOURS A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE CALLED THE BUCKEYE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER TO REQUEST THAT THE REFILL OPERATION BE STOPPED AND THE PIPELINE SHUTDOWN DUE TO A SUSPECTED RELEASE, THE CONTROL CENTER SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE AT 0327 HOURS.      BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A FAILED ACETYLENE WELD WAS DISCOVERED, ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.      RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY, U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, AND THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY.      BY AUGUST 16, 2003 APPROXIMATELY 717 FEET OF PIPE HAD BEEN REPLACED AND HYDROTESTED WITH ALL WELDS BEING RADIOGRAPHICALLY EXAMINED.  ON AUGUST 21, 2003 THE PIPELINE WAS REFILLED AND A ONE HOUR INTEGRITY PRESSURE TEST WAS PERFORMED ON THIS PIPELINE SECTION ON AUGUST 25, 2003.  THE PIPELINE RESTARTED OPERATIONS ON AUGUST 29, 2003 AT A REDUCED MOP OF 380 PSI.      THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.       KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FINAL ANALYSIS REPORT STATES: "WE BELIEVE THAT STRESSES INDUCED BY THE RECENT REHABILITATION WORK THAT WAS PERFORMED WITHIN 20 FEET OF THIS LOCATION IN COMBINATION WITH THE PASSAGE OF THE IN-LINE INSPECTION TOOL MAY HAVE CAUSED MOVEMENT AND THUS OVER STRESS OF THE GIRTH WELD DUE TO POSSIBLE MISALIGNMENT OF THE JOINT THEREBY CAUSING IT TO FAIL."       TO FINALIZE THIS REPORT I HAD TO PUT A "0" IN THE SMYS FIELD UNDER MATERIAL SPECIFICATION SINCE IT WOULD NOT TAKE UNKNOWN.

column199: 2 INCH STAINLESS STEEL BRAIDED FLEX HOSE
column245: THE SOURCE OF THIS RELEASE WAS THE FAILURE OF A 2-INCH STAINLESS STEEL BRAIDED FLEX HOSE BEING UTILIZED DURING TEMPORARY VENTING OPERATIONS DURING REFILLING OF THE PIPELINE AFTER A SHUTDOWN.  METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS SHOWED THAT FLEX HOSE FAILED DUE TO FATIGUE.  PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE IN THAT SEGMENT AT THE TIME OF FAILURE WAS 700 PSI.  NO VISUAL SIGNS OF FATIGUE WERE NOTED ON THE HOSE PRIOR TO INSTALLATION.  THE FLEX HOSE BURST PRESSURE RATED BY THE MANUFACTURER WAS 2,000 PSI AND ITS MANUFACTURER RATED WORKING PRESSURE WAS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN 500 PSI.  ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE HAS RESULTED IN SEVERAL CORRECTIVE MEASURES TO PREVENT FUTURE SIMILAR RELEASES.  THESE MEASURES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF POLICIES, STANDARDS AND PROCEDURES FOR A TEMPORARY VENTING SYSTEM FOR THE COCHIN PIPELINE, AND INCORPORATION OF TEMPORARY USE MATERIALS, SUCH AS FLEX HOSES, INTO THE OPERATOR'S MATERIAL INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  NEW HOSES WITH WORKING PRESSURES RATED FOR FULL PIPELINE PRESSURE HAVE BEEN PUT IN PLACE AND THE OLD HOSES TAKEN OUT OF SERVIS.

column245: ON AUGUST 7, 2003, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT BUBBLES WERE COMING UP IN THE STANDING WATER SITUATED OVER THE SUNOCO TO CATLETTSBURG 3" PROPANE LINE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  UPON EXCAVATION, A RATHER LARGE SIZED "ICE BALL" WAS ENCOUNTERED SURROUNDING THE THREE INCH PIPELINE.  AFTER REMOVING THE "ICE BALL" FROM THE THREE INCH PROPANE LINE, A PINHOLE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED.  FACTORS INCLUDING ACTIVE EXTERNAL CORROSION, DISBONDED COAL TAR COATING AND LOW CATHODIC PROTECTION POTENTIALS CONTRIBUTED TO THE PINHOLE LEAK.

column245: BP PERSONNEL DISCOVERED LEAK ON AN ABOVE GROUND SECTION OF STATION HEADER IN MANIFOLD.  STATION WAS SHUTDOWN, AND BP PERSONNEL CALLED TO RESPOND TO INCIDENT.  A PIPE CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AND SEGMENT ISOLATED.  PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION POINTS TO INTERNAL CORROSION ON A "DEAD-LEG" SECTION OF PIPE.  IT APPEARS THAT A CLOSED VALVE CONNECTING AN ACTIVE PORTION OF STATION MANIFOLD PIPING TO THE INACTIVE SEGMENT IN QUESTION WAS NO LONGER COMPLETELY SEALING AND ALLOWED THE INACTIVE SECTION BE PRESSURED.

column245: LANDOWNER/DEVELOPER WAS INSTALLING 8' BOX STORM SEWER LINES ACROSS THE LOCAL SAND/GRAVEL PIT.  THE DEVELOPER WAS TOLD BY GENESIS ENGINEERING AND ROW DEPT THEY COULD NOT DIG UNTIL WE HAD A ENCROACHMENT AGREEMENT SIGNED AND IN PLACE AND ONLY AFTER LINES WERE FLAGGED AND PERMISSION GRANTED.  THEY DUG ANYWAY.  THE CONTRACTOR FOR THE DEVELOPER THOUGHT HE HAD PERMISSION AND INDEED THEY DID NOT.  THE DEVELOPER HAD AGREED TO PAY THE COSTS OF THE CLEAN UP AND REPAIR OF THE INCIDENT.  AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE INCIDENT IS STILL ON-GOING HOWEVER 7.5 FEET OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH A POLY TAPE COATING.

PIPELINE) TO COMPLETE CONCRETE CUTTING AT SITE AND HAD USED THEM THE PREVIOUS DAY AT SOUTH END OF BRIDGE TO LOCATE THREE PIPELINES OPERATOR HAS IN THIS ROW. SUBCONTRACTOR ARRIVED AND WAS GIVEN INSTRUCTIONS TO CUT SIDEWALK AND NOT GO DOWN LOWER THAN 8" AND TO SCORE CURB DOWN TO FLOW LINE. CONTRACTOR BEGAN TO CUT AT A DEPTH OF 8" IN THE STREET AS HE APPROACHED CURB. HE STRUCK THE #3-8" (HUNTINGTON BEACH PRODUCTS LINE) WHICH WAS AT A DEPTH OF 7.75" DEPTH OF COVER,  JUST CUTTING THE DEPTH OF THE PIPE'S WALL THICKNESS. ALL PRODUCT RECOVERED.

column245: A CONOCOPHILLIPS GAUGER WAS CHECKING TORREY STATION DURING HIS NORMAL WORK DUTIES.  UPON ARRIVING FOR CHECK, HE DISCOVERED A LEAK ON THE STATION DISCHARGE LINE.  HE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN ALL OPERATIONS AT THE FACILITY AND DID A QUICK ASSESSMENT OF THE RELEASE.  THE LEAK HAD SPRAYED THE STATION MANIFOLD, WEST SIDE OF THE PUMP HOUSE AND GROUND AREA.  THE GAUGER NOTIFIED THE OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR WHO THEN NOTIFIED COMPANY PERSONNEL FOR RESPONSE TO THE INCIDENT.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED TO THE COMPANY FACILITY WITH NO CRUDE OIL RELEASED OFF SITE.  THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE 12" STATION DISCHARGE LINE AT A WELD WITH 520 PSIG LINE PRESSURE.  IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT INTERNAL MICROBIOLOGICAL CORROSION TOOK PLACE ALONG THE GIRTH WELD.

column245: THE MOTOR CONTROL CENTER BREAKER WAS TRIPPED AND WOULD NOT RESET DUE TO LIGHTNING DAMAGE ON THE FLOOD LIGHT SYSTEM. WITH THE BREAKER TRIPPED IN THE MOTOR CONTROL CENTER,THE ELECTRIC MOTOR ON THE SUMP COULD NOT COME ON TO PUMP THE SUMP WHEN IT REACHED "HIGH LEVEL." DUE TO THE HIGH RATE OF RAIN, AND THE LIGHTNING DAMAGE, THE SUMP OVERFILLED CAUSING A 6 BARREL CRUDE OIL RELEASE ON TO THE GROUND IN THE SUMP AREA.  THE LOCALIZED FLOODING ALLOWED THE CRUDE TO BE RECOVERED WITHOUT CONTACTING THE GROUND.

column245: A POWER SURGE DUE TO LIGHTNING AT MAIN PASS 69 CONTROL PANEL CAUSED AN EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN UPSTREAM FROM MP 69.  WHEN THE VALVES CLOSED, PRESSURE INCREASED WHILE UPSTREAM PRODUCERS WERE SHUTTING DOWN.  A LOOSE BLIND FLANGE ON A HEADER AT MAIN PASS 225 BEGAN TO LEAK.  THE UPSTREAM VALVE TO THE BLIND FLANGE WAS CLOSED TO PREVENT FLOW TO THE HEADER.  THE HEADER ASSEMBLE IS LOCATED OVER SECONDARY CONTAINMENT.  HOWEVER, APPROXIMATELY 10 GALLONS OVERFLOWED THE CONTAINMENT AND WAS RELEASED INTO THE GULF.

column245: AT 0611 ON SEPT. 26, 2003, LIGHTNING STRUCK NEAR THE BERTHA PUMP MANIFOLD AREA AT THE EAST ST. LOUIS TERMINAL RESULTING IN A PRESSURE TRANSMITTER FIRE OWNED BY LACLEDE PIPELINE.  THE FIRE QUICKLY SPREAD TO NEARBY PIPING SEGMENTS RESULTING IN MULTIPLE PIPING FAILURES AND ASSOCIATED FIRES.  THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED AND THE SITUATION WAS CONTROLLED AT 1308.  THERE WERE NO INJURIES.    THE INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM WAS ESTABLISHED EARLY IN THE EVENT ON A LOCAL AND COPORATE LEVE.  THE UNIFIED COMMAND INCLUDED FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL AND RESPONSIBLE PARTY PERSONNEL (COP & LACLEDE).  WOOD RIVER REFINERY EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL RESPONDED ALONG WITH 6 FIRE DEPARTMENTS.  SOLUTIA EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL ALSO RESPONDED.

column245: AT 0611 ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2003, LIGHTNING STRUCK NEAR THE LACLEDE/CONOCOPHILLIPS INTERCONNECT, PUMP, AND PIGGING FACILITY LOCATED IN EAST ST. LOUIS, ILLINOIS.  THE LIGHTNING STRIKE RESULTED IN A FIRE AT A PRESSURE TRANSMITTER WHICH LED TO MULTIPLE PIPING FAILURES AND ASSOCIATED FIRES.  ALL FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED AND THE SITUATION WAS CONTROLLED AT 1308 ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2003.  NO PIPING FACILITIES IMPACTED BY THE FIRE WERE OPERATING AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  THERE WERE NO FATALITIES OR INJURIES; HOWEVER, THERE WAS SIGNIFICANT PROPERTY DAMAGE AND PRODUCT LOSS AS A RESULT OF THE ACCIDENT.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY & REGULATORY COMPL
column245: DURING THE PROCESS OF LOADING A PIG AND FILLING A LAUNCHER, THE OPERATOR NOTICED CRUDE OIL SPRAYING FROM A BLEEDER PLUG ON THE CLOSURE (PRESSURE SAFETY INTERLOCK).  THE LAUNCHER WAS ISOLATED/DRAINED.  UPON INVESTIGATION, IT WAS NOTED THAT A METALLIC DISK SEAL ON THE BLEEDER PLUG WAS DAMAGED.  THIS ITEM WAS REPLACED.     4/22/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE ADDED FROM INFORMATION IN THE NRC REPORT. AMOUNT RELEASED WAS 0.29 GALLONS.  PREVIOUSLY, THIS AMOUNT WAS REPORTED AS "0" BECAUSE 0.29 GALLONS DOES NOT ROUND UP TO 1 GALLON.  THIS SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT CHANGES THE AMOUNT RELEASED FROM "0" TO "1" SO THE FORM SEEMS CONSISTENT WITH THE OTHER INFORMATION REPORTED ( I.E., A RELEASE OCCURRED, SO A VOLUME RELEASED IS ALSO REPORTED).  AMOUNT RELEASED WAS MUCH LESS THAN 1 GALLON, BUT 1 GALLON WAS REPORTED DUE TO THE CONSTRAINTS OF THE FORM.    PART F, QUESTION 2E -AMOUNT IN WATER IS STILL BEING REPORTED AS "0" BECAUSE AMOUNT IN WATER EQUATES TO APPROXIMATELY 0.007 BBLS, WHICH IS MUCH CLOSER TO "0" BARRELS THAN TO "1' BARREL.

column245: THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS FROM A BELOW GRADE VAULT OR PIT ON THE STATION DISCHARGE PIPING.  THE CAUSE WAS DUE TO THE AGING AND RESULTANT WEAKENING OF A 2000 PSI RATED 1/2-INCH DIAMETER HYDRAULIC HOSE USED FOR CALIBRATION, WHICH WAS ATTACHED TO A FLOW METER LOCATED IN AN UNDERGROUND VAULT OR PIT.  THE PIT CONTAINED WATER AND, AS CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED, IT FLOATED TO THE TOP, FILLING AND OVERFLOWING THE VAULT, AND FURTHER TRAVELING SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET TO THE CONTAINMENT POND.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED ON STATION PROPERTY, BETWEEN THE CONTAINMENT POND AND THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE.  THE FAULTY HOSE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED.

column245: THERE IS A WELDED THREAD 0 LAT FITTING ON THE BOTTOM PART OF THIS BLOCK VALVE WHICH IS USED TO DRAIN THE BODY CAVITY OF THE VALVE.  DURING AN EXCAVATION TO INSPECT THE COATING, AN APPURTENANCE WITHIN THE THREAD 0 LAT WAS DAMAGED AND OIL FROM THE BLOCK VALVE CAVITY AND PIPELINE WAS RELEASED AND CONTAINED WITHIN THE EXCAVATION.  THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO THE PIPE, BLOCK VALVE, OR SITE FACILITIES.  THE THREADS OF THE WELDED THREAD 0 LAT WERE CHASED AND A ONE INCH PLUG WAS INSTALLED.  THE FILLET WELD OF THE THREAD 0 LAT WAS PARTICLE INSPECTED PRIOR TO RETURNING THE PIPELINE/VALVE TO SERVICE.  CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND DISPOSED OF.

column245: THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY AERIAL PATROL.  INITIAL INVESTIGATION ON 10/9/03 INDICATED A TWO BARREL LEAK AND THE ESTIMATED COST WAS LESS THAN $50,000. column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AN ESTIMATE 800 BBLS OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED FROM THE LA BASIN DISTRICTS NUMBER 82 LINE, INTO A BP PIPELINE OWNED BELOW GROUND VALVE VAULT WHERE THE SPILL HAS BEEN CONTAINED.  THE LA BASIN VAULT IS LOCATED ON THE PROPERTY OF PACIFIC PIPELINE COMPANY, WHICH IS A FENCED SITE SITUATED IN A LARGE INDUSTRIAL AREA REMOTE FROM RESIDENTIAL AREAS. BP PIPELINES OPERATIONS PERSONNEL AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS RESPONDED TO THE SPILL SITE, AND BEGAN PUMPING CRUDE OIL FROM THE VAULT.  NO INJURIES OR FIRE RESULTED FROM THIS SPILL.  SEVERAL AGENCIES INCLUDING THE US COAST GUARD AND CALIFORNIA FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ARRIVED ON SITE, BUT LEFT AFTER REVIEWING THE IMPACT OF THE SPILL AND THE BP PIPELINES RESPONSE.

column61: HIGH POPULATION, DRINKING WATER & ECOLOGICAL AREA
column245: PIPELINE OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER DETECTED A LINE IMBALANCE ON THE AFFECTED LINE SEGMENT.  ANALYSIS AND INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED A PIPELINE BREACH, RESULTING IN THE EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN OF THE PIPELINE VIA SCADA, INCLUDING CLOSING REMOTELY CONTROLLED VALVES TO ISOLATE THE PIPELINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED  BY ESTABLISHING AN INCIDENT COMMAND CENTER.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTITIVIES AND COMMUNICATIONS WITH PUBLIC OFFICIALS AND IMPACTED PUBLIC WERE CONDUCTED.  THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED, AND THE FAILED SECTION WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW, PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE FAILED SECTION WAS SENT TO THIRD PARTY COMPANY FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS DETERMINATION.  THE REPAIRED PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT A REDUCED OPERATING PRESSURE PENDING FAILURE ANALYSIS DETERMINATION AND POTENTIAL MITIGATIVE MEASURES.  SITE REMEDIATION, INCLUDING FREE PRODUCT RECOVERY, CONTAMINATED SOIL REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT, AND SURFACE RESTORATION IS ONGOING. 12-15-04 METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT THE FAILURE WAS PROBABLY CAUSED BY STAGED GROWTH OF AN INTIAL LACK OF FUSION GIRTH WELD DEFECT.  SETTLEMENT OR CONSOLIDATION FOLLOWING MASS SOIL REPLACEMENT ASSOCIATED WITH ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION OF A PRIOR RELEASE COULD HAVE CAUSED CONTINUED FLAW EXTENSION WITH A FINAL FAILURE BEING CAUSED BY MORE RECENT SOIL MOVEMENT AND SETTLEMENT OF THE PIPELINE DUE TO CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 6, 2003, AN OPERATIONS TECHNICIAN OBSERVED A RELEASE OF DRA AT THE MAPL TEXAS CITY STATION.  THE DRA INJECTION SKID, AS WELL AS THE ASSOCIATED PIPELINE SYSTEM, WERE SHUTDOWN AT THE TIME.  UPON THE COMPLETION OF AIR MONITORING, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN EMERGENCY DID NOT EXIST.  THE FAILURE OCCURRED ON A BANDED HOSE FITTING WHICH IS UTILIZED BETWEEN THE DRA STORAGE TANK AND THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE INJECTION SKID.   THIS FITTING IS UTILIZED TO TRANSITION FROM HOSE TO THREADED CONNECTIONS.  THE HOSE HAS A COMPRESSION FIT OVER A RIBBED STEEL NIPPLE, AND IS ALSO RETAINED IN PLACE WITH METAL BANDING.  IN THIS INSTANCE, THE HOSE PULLED AWAY FROM THE STEEL PIPE NIPPLE.  THIS RESULTED IN A 12 BBL RELEASE, 7 BBLS OF WHICH WAS RETAINED IN A DESIGNATED CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE DRA RELEASE WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CLEANED UP FOR PROPER DISPOSAL.

column245: DURING NORMAL OPERATIONS, OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A HIGH SUMP ALARM AND THE ENGINEERING SYSTEMS THEN SHUT IN THE MILTONVALE MAINLINE PUMPS.  A FIELD PERSON WAS CONTACTED AND DISPATCHED.  UPON HIS ARRIVAL AT THE MILTONVALE PUMP STATION, HE OBSERVED THE VENT LINE FOR OUR #3 THERMAL RELIEF VALVE ON THE DISCHARGE SIDE OF OUR 101 PIPELINE HAD A LIGHT FROST BUILD UP.  THE RELIEF VALVE WAS ISOLATED AND REPLACED WITH A NEW ONE.  THE SEAT OF THE FAILED RELIEF VALVE WAS NOT SEATED CORRECTLY THEREFORE ALLOWING THE RELEASE OF PRODUCT.

column245: PIPELINE WAS OUT OF SERVICE IN PREPARATION OF HYDROSTATIC TESTING FOR TRANSMONTAIGNE'S INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  CONTRACTOR WAS CLEARING THE LINE OF LIQUID IN PREPARATION OF INSTALLING THE PIGGING BARREL USING NITROGEN TO MINIMIZE IGNITION DANGER.  CONTRACTOR LOOSENED BONNET ON CHECK VALVE TO CHECK FOR PRESSURE.  THE PRESSURE RELEASE DISPLACED THE O-RING ON THE BONNET ASSEMBLY ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE INTO THE EXCAVATION.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED TO THE EXCAVATION AND WAS REMOVED BY VACUUM TRUCK.  CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED FOR AUTHORIZED DISPOSAL.  CONTRACTORS QUALIFICATIONS HAVE BEEN SUSPENDED FOLLOWING AN INTERNAL INVESTIGATION. 2-13-04 CONTRACTOR'S SUSPENSION WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT UNTIL THE CONTRACTOR IS REQUALIFIED.  THE SPILL SITE WAS CLOSED  WITH THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY.

column245: A BULLDOZER, WITH RIPPER BLADE ATTACHED STRUCK KANEB'S SIX-INCH PIPELINE, RESULTING IN A BREACH OF THE PIPE WALL.  THIS, NON-KANEB, EXCAVATING CONTRACTOR WAS BREAKING UP COMPACTED SOIL AT THE TIME OF THE PIPELINE STRIKE.  FORTUNATELY, THE PIPELINE WAS NOT UNDER ACTIVE PUMPING OPERATIONS, WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR THE RELATIVELY SMALL RELEASE VOLUME AND MINIMAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT.    NOTE: THE ANSWER TO QUESTION 9.F. PART H WAS CHECKED AS NO IN ORDER TO GET THE FORM TO SUBMIT, BUT THE NO ANSWER IS NOT A TRULY ACCURATE RESPONSE.  KANEB WAS NOT NOTIFIED PRIOR TO THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITY, THEREFORE, THE LINE WAS NOT MARKED BECAUSE KANEB WAS NOT MADE AWARE OF THE IMPENDING EXCAVATION ACTIVITY.  THIS ISSUE WAS DISCUSSED ON NOVEMBER 26, 2003 WITH MR. FERNANDO LOPEZ AT THE RESEARCH AND SPECIAL PROGRAMS ADMINISTRATION FOR THE PURPOSE OF SUBMITTING AN  ACCURATE REPORT.  AN EMAIL WILL BE SENT TO MR. LOPEZ PERTINENT TO THIS PROBLEM.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: SHORTLY AFTER P-73 PUMP WAS STARTED UP, KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE WAS MAKING NORMAL INSPECTION ROUNDS AND OBSERVED CRUDE OIL SEEPING FROM GROUND AROUND LOCATION OF PUMP DISCHARGE.  PUMP WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN, LINE WAS ISOLATED, AND EXCAVATION WAS STARTED.  UPON COMPLETION OF EXCAVATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT RELEASE HAD ORIGINATED FROM 2" DRAIN CONNECTION ON BOTTOM OF PUMP DISCHARGE PIPING.  CONNECTION WAS REMOVED, PIPING WAS REPAIRED AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.  EXAMINATION OF REMOVED 2" DRAIN PIPING REVEALED INTERNAL CORROSION PRESENT PROBABLY CAUSED BY ENTRAPPED WATER.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 2003 AT 1434 HOURS THE MAZON SHERIFF¿S DEPARTMENT CONTACTED BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY¿S EAST CHICAGO STATION TO REPORT A POSSIBLE RELEASE ON THE NORCO PIPE LINE COMPANY¿S PIPELINE NEAR MAZON, ILLINOIS.  AT 1440 HOURS THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY.  AT 2255 HOURS A CORROSION PIT WAS DISCOVERED, ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  A CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  THE DEFECTIVE SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 300 FEET OF NEW CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  AFTER REPLACEMENT WORK WAS COMPLETED A HYDROTESTED PER PART 195, SUBPART E AND A 4 HOUR LEAK TEST WERE PERFORMED.  ALL REPAIRS AND RESTART ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED UNDER CLOSE CONSULTATION WITH THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE GRUNDY COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL REPORT STATES THAT - PITTING CORROSION OF THE OD SURFACE THAT PRODUCED AREAS OF INTERCONNECTED AND OVERLAPPING PITS CAUSED THIS LEAK.  THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OF FATIGUE, MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC), OR ENVIRONMENTAL CRACKING - JUST PITTING CORROSION.  IN THE SMYS FIELD I HAD TO ENTER "0" SINCE IT WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE IT BLANK AND WOULD NOT ACCEPT UNKNOWN.

column238: FAILURE OF NITRILE BAG USED FOR ISOLATION OF VAPORS DURING BEVELING OPERATION.
column245: CONTRACTOR FOR CALNEV PIPELINE LLC WAS MAKING TIE-IN OF 20" GASOLINE LINE ON PUMP STATION PROPERTY.  PIPE WAS EVACUATED AND DRAINED OF LIQUID PRODUCT.  NITRILE BAG WAS INSERTED INTO THE LINE TO ISOLATE VAPORS FROM HOT WORK.  DURING BEVELING OPERATION NITRILE BAG FAILED AND VAPORS IGNITED, BURNING CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEE ON ABDOMEN AND ARMS.  CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEE WAS TREATED AT LOCAL HOSPITAL AND RELEASED (NOT ADMITTED).  VAPOR FIRE WAS IMMEDIATELY SUPPRESSED AND TIE-IN COMPLETED WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.      UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: OPERATOR PERSONNEL WERE EXCAVATING A BURIED MLV WITH AN EXCAVATOR IN PREPARATION FOR A MAINTENANCE PROJECT TO REPLACE THE MLV WITH A NEW VALVE IN AN ABOVE GROUND SETTING.  IN THE COURSE OF PERFORMING THE EXCAVATION ALONG SIDE OF THE PIPELINE AND MLV, A ROCK THAT APPARENTLY WAS INCLUDED IN THE BACKFILL DURING THE ORIGINAL LINE CONSTRUCTION WAS PUSHED UNDERGROUND INTO THE SIDE OF THE BURIED MLV BY THE BUCKET. THIS RESULTED IN THE BREAKING OFF OF 2 SMALL BLEEDER VALVES FROM THE MLV BODY.  PRODUCT WAS RELEASED AND MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED CONTROL CENTER TO HAVE THE PIPELINE SYSTEM PRESSURE DRAINED OFF (THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS NOT OPERATIONAL AT THE TIME OF THE ACCIDENT AND WAS UNDER STATIC PRESSURE).  MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL USED A PATCH HELD IN PLACE BY THE EXCAVATOR BUCKET TO REDUCE THE LEAK RATE.  LINE PRESSURE WAS REDUCED AND ADJACENT MLVS WERE CLOSED.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 14, 2003 WHILE PATROLLING THE RIGHT-OF-WAY A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE DETECTED A PETROLEUM ODOR AT A CASING VENT LOCATED AT GRAND RIDGE ROAD NEAR MAZON, ILLINOIS.   BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED IMMEDIATELY, THE PIPELINE WAS ALREADY SHUTDOWN.  THE DEFECTIVE SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 230 FEET OF NEW CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  AFTER REPLACEMENT WORK WAS COMPLETED A HYDROTEST WAS CONDUCTED ON THIS PIPELINE SECTION.   ALL REPAIRS AND RESTART ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER CLOSE CONSULTATION WITH THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE GRUNDY COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY.   THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATED FOR ANALYSIS.   FOR THE FIELD ON THIS REPORT ¿YEAR PROTECTION STARTED¿ WE ENTERED 1957.  THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE THIS FIELD BLANK AND WE ARE NOT SURE WHEN CATHODIC PROTECTION STARTED ON THIS PIPELINE SO WE ENTERED IN THE DATE OF THE OLDEST RECTIFIER.     THE FINAL REPORT STATES THAT - PITTING CORROSION OF THE OD SURFACE THAT PRODUCED AREAS OF INTERCONNECTED AND OVERLAPPING PITS CAUSED THIS LEAK.  THERE WERE NO INDICATIONS OF FATIGUE, MICROBIOLOGICALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC), OR ENVIRONMENTAL CRACKING - JUST PITTING CORROSION.     I HAD TO ENTER A "0" INTO THE SMYS FIELD SINCE IT WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE IT BLANK AND WOULD NOT ACCEPT UNKNOWN.

column245: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONAL SHUT THE SYSTEM DOWN DUE TO A SUSPECTED LEAK. AN AERIAL OVERFLIGHT CONFIRMED OIL ON THE WATER. SPILL RESPONCE WAS IMMEDIATELY INITIATED. OIL WAS CONTAINED WITH BOOMS AND RECOVERED UTILIZING SKIMMERS AND SORBENT PADDING.    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS ONGOING AND A REPORT IS PENDING.     INCIDENT INVESTIGATION COMPLETE APRIL 30, 2004 ANS WAS SHARED WITH A.T. RALLIS, C. MCLAREN, AND R. LOPEZ WITH THE OPS. INVESTIGTION SHOWED THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE TO BE THE RESULT OF FLAWS IN THE PIPE MANUFACTURING PROCESS COMBINED WITH EXTERNAL CORROSION.

column245: DRAIN VALVE ON PIPELINE STRAINER EQUIPMENT LEAKED THROUGH AND INTO STATION DRAIN SYSTEM PIPING. WORK PERFORMED 20 YEARS PRIOR ON STATION DRAIN AND SUMP SYSTEM RESULTED IN THE STRAINER DRAIN PIPING BEGING TIED INTO ABANDONED-IN-PLACE DRAIN SYSTEM PIPING.  USE OF THE DRAIN VALVE TO DRAIN THE STRAINER HAD NOT OCCURRED.  STRAINER WAS OPENED ONLY TWICE IN PAST 20 YEARS FOR SERVICE AND A VACUUM TRUK WAS USED TO REMOVE RESIDUAL PRODUCT FROM THE STRAINER BODY FROM THE TOP OF THE STRAINER AFTER IT WAS OPENED.  ABANDONED IN PLACE PIPING HAS BEEN REMOVED AND THE STRAINER DRAIN PIPING HAS ALSO BEEN REMOVED.  A NEW PLUG VALVE WAS INSTALLED ON THE STRAINER.

column245: A PRODUCTION COMPANY HAD A TRACKHOE OPERATOR WORKING IN THE AREA EXCAVATING TO RELOCATE AND BURY AN OLD PUMP PAD AND COLLAR WHEN THE TRACKHOE OPERATOR HIT EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY'S 6" INACTIVE TORCH TO IATAN NGL LINE WITH THE TRACKHOE BUCKET.  THE LINE HAS BEEN INACTIVE THE PAST YEAR AND ONLY HAD ~250 PSI.  THE ESCAPING NGL VAPORS WERE MINIMAL AND DUE TO THE LOCATION OF THE PUNCTURE, THE VAPORS ESCAPED AND DISIPATED INTO THE HOLE PREVIOUSLY DUG BY THE TRACKHOE OPERATOR.  ALL SAFETY AND CONTAINMENT MEASURES WERE TAKEN AND PUBLIC SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE MINIMAL.   THE LINE DEPRESSURIZED FOR ~3 DAYS INTO THE CONTAINMENT HOLE.  PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WITH NEW TESTED PIPE.  THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION PIPELINE SAFETY DIVISION WAS NOTIFIED IN ACCORDANCE WITH TAC AND PART 195 REGULATIONS AND COMPANY PROCEDURES.  THE TRRC ASSIGNED REPORT #04-HC-017.

column245: AN EXTERNAL CORROSION LEAK WAS ENCOUNTERED DURING AN INSPECTION PROJECT OF OUR PROPANE DEHYDRATOR PIPING LOCATED UNDER THERMAL INSULATION.  THE FACILITY WAS SUBSEQUENTLY SHUT IN BY LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL WHEN THEY INITIATED AN ESD. THE DEHYDRATOR PIPING WAS FURTHER ISOLATED AND BLOWN DOWN.  THE PIPING CONTAINING THE EXTERNAL CORROSION LEAK WAS REPLACED AND THE SYSTEM WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.

column245: ENBRIDGE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR RECEIVED A GAS ALARM AT CLEARBROOK AND DISPATCHED FIELD GAUGER TO CHECK IT OUT.  GAUGER FOUND CRUDE OIL ON GROUND WITHIN BUILDING THAT HOUSES CONTROL VALVES FOR 36" AND 26" DELIVERY LINES TO MINNESOTA PIPELINE.  ALL LINES WERE SHUT DOWN AND AREA WAS ISOLATED.  BEMIDJI PLM WAS DISPATCHED.  EXCAVATION REVEALED A 1/8" HOLE IN THE 16" BYPASS LINE AROUND THE 26" CONTROL VALVE 151-PCV-211.  FREE OIL WAS RECOVERED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS AND REINJECTED AT CLEARBROOK.  CONTAMINATED SOIL HAS BEEN HAULED TO AN APPROVED LAND FARM FACILITY (MARK II OF FOSSTON).  AN 18" LONG PLIDCO SPLIT+SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED.

GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AT THE CONCLUSION OF A FUEL OIL TRANSFER THE OPERATOR DISCOVERED A POOL OF OIL ABOVE THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS ISOLATED AND SURFACE CLEAN-UP STARTED.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS EXCAVATED AND A SPOT OF LOCALIZED CORROSION WAS FOUND TOP DEAD CENTER OF THE PIPE. THIS CORROSION AND RESULTING HOLE APPEARED TO BE AT THE LOCATION OF A CAD WELD FOR A POLARIZATION CELL LEAD.  THE COATING AT THIS LOCATION HAD BEEN REMOVED TO MAKE THE CAD WELD.  THE LINE WAS REPAIRED AND THE FAILED PORTION IS BEING SENT TO OUR LAB FOR FURTHER METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS. THE CONCLUSIONS OF OUR CORROSION PERSONNEL AND METALURGISTS IS AS FOLLOWS:THE FAILED SECTION OF THE 30" OIL LINE WAS SHOWN TO OUR METALLURGIST AT THE LAB AND HE SAID THAT UNFORTUNATELY THE NATURE OF THE CORROSION OF THE PIPE PRECLUDES A DEFINITIVE ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE MODE, DUE TO THE COMBINATION OF DIFFERENT TYPES OF CORROSION PRESENT.  THE PRESENCE OF GENERAL CORROSION ON THE PIPE AND GROSS MATERIAL LOSS ESSENTIALLY PRECLUDES EXAMINING THE STEEL FOR CORROSION CAUSED BY A SPECIFIC EVENT, SUCH AS AC CURRENT ARCING AT THE FAILURE POINT (WHERE THE STUD FOR THE GROUNDING CABLE WAS LOCATED).      THUS WE ARE LEFT WITH PIECING THE FAILURE MODE TOGETHER BASED ON THE HISTORY.  OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE HISTORY IS:    ¿H THE 30" LINE WAS INSTALLED ABOUT 1976, WITH THE BURIED ISOLATION JOINT AT THE PORT OF PALM BEACH UTILIZING THREADED STEEL STUDS WELDED TO BOTH SIDES OF THE ISOLATION JOINT.  A ZINC / COPPER GROUNDING CELL WAS WIRED TO THE JOINT VIA THE STUDS.  CATHODIC PROTECTION (CP) WAS NOT PROVIDED FOR THE SHORT, ISOLATED SECTION OF THE LINE (EAST SIDE OF THE JOINT).    ¿H IN 1980, A POLARIZATION CELL WAS INSTALLED ACROSS THE ISOLATION JOINT.  4/0 POLARIZATION CELL CABLES WERE CONNECTED TO THE LINE USING THE EXISTING STUDS AT THE ISOLATION JOINT.  COPPER COMPRESSION RING TERMINALS WERE USED FOR THESE CABLE CONNECTIONS.  NOTE THAT THE THERMAL INSULATION HAD TO BE REMOVED TO RETROFIT THESE CABLES; PROPER SEALING OF THE INSULATION AND JACKET MAY NOT HAVE OCCURRED ONCE THESE CABLES WERE RETROFITTED TO THE PIPES.    ¿H WITH THE INSTALLATION OF THE RIVIERA PLANT FUEL OIL STORAGE TANK CP SYSTEM IN 1997, THE ISOLATED SECTION OF THE 30" LINE AT THE PORT OF PALM BEACH BEGAN RECEIVING CP, SINCE THIS SECTION OF THE LINE IS GROUNDED COMMON TO THE PLANT TANKS.    ¿H IN DECEMBER 2003, THE 30" LINE LEAKED ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE ISOLATION JOINT.  UPON VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE LEAK, THE STEEL STUD HAD CORRODED AWAY, AND THE COMPRESSION RING TERMINAL OF THE 4/0 CABLE APPEARED TO HAVE EXPERIENCED ARCING (THE RING PART OF THE TERMINAL NO LONGER EXIST; ONLY THE CRIMP PORTION WAS REMAINING).  THE STUD & 4/0 CABLE CONNECTION ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE JOINT WAS FOUND INTACT AND IN GOOD CONDITION.    GIVEN THE TIMELINE OF THE EVENTS, IT IS LIKELY THAT GENERAL CORROSION OF THE SHORT, ISOLATED SECTION OF THE LINE (EAST SIDE OF THE JOINT) PROCEEDED FOR ABOUT 21 YEARS (1976 TO 1997).  GENERAL CORROSION IS EVIDENT ON THE ISOLATED PART OF THE REMOVED SECTION OF PIPE.    SINCE THE ISOLATED SECTION OF LINE WAS NOT PROTECTED WITH CP DURING THIS TIME, A BIMETALLIC CORROSION CELL EXISTED BETWEEN THE STEEL STUD AND SURROUNDING PIPE, AND THE COPPER CABLE AND COPPER RING CONNECTOR, WITH THE STUD AND SURROUNDING STEEL PIPE BEING ANODIC (CORRODING) TO THE COPPER COMPONENTS.  VISUAL INSPECTION INDICATES THAT THE COATING AND THERMAL INSULATION AT THE LEAK LOCATION WAS NOT IN GOOD CONDITION, WHICH ALLOWED GROUNDWATER TO BE PRESENT AT THE STUD CONNECTION, AND ALLOWED THE BIMETALLIC CORROSION TO PROCEED.  THE 30" POLARIZATION CELL AT THE PORT PASSES AC CURRENT BACK TO THE RIVIERA PLANT GROUND; AC EXISTS ON THE 30" BECAUSE IT IS LOCATED IN THE TRANSMISSION RIGHT-OF-WAY, AND VOLTAGE IS INDUCED ON THE LINE FROM THE TRANSMISSION LINES.    IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE BIMETALLIC CORROSION CELL AT THE STEEL STUD EVENTUALLY DEGRADED THE ELECTRICAL CONNECTION AT THE STUD, RESULTING IN A HIGH RESISTANCE CONTACT.  CONSEQUENTLY THE AC CURRENT PA SSING THROUGH THIS CONNECTION EVENTUALLY BECAME AN ARCING CONDITION; THIS WAS EVIDENT FROM THE DAMAGE SEEN ON THE RING CONNECTOR.  THE ONGOING ARCING AC MAY HAVE BEEN A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR TO THE PIPE CORROSION, BUT UNFORTUNATELY THIS CANNOT BE MEASURED DIRECTLY.  THE FACT THAT THE LINE LEAKED SOME SIX YEARS AFTER CP WAS APPLIED TO THE ISOLATED SECTION OF LINE FURTHER SUPPORTS THE POSSIBILITY THAT ARCING AC CURRENT AT THE STUD CONTRIBUTED TO THE CORROSION.    AS COUNTERMEASURES TO THIS EVENT, THESE INSULATORS THAT STILL EXIST WITHIN OUR SYSTEM ARE GIVEN SPECIAL ATTENTION WHEN IN-LINE INSPECTIONS ARE CONDUCTED FOR SIGNS OF METAL LOSS.  AN ILI WAS CONDUCTED ON THIS PIPELINE AFTER THE EVENT TO INSURE INTEGRITY GOING FORWARD.  ADDITIONALLY, THIS INSULATING FLANGE WAS MOVED ABOVE GROUND AND THE POLARIZATION CELL LEADS WERE CONNECTED WHERE THEY WERE EASILY INSPECTED VISUALLY.

column245: 1" XXH (SCHEDULE 140) NIPPLE SHEARED AT ROOT OF THREADS IN PIPING TO HIGH DISCHARGE PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE MOUNTED ON 2651 GASO PUMP. 1" NIPPLE WAS THREADED INTO WELD-O-LET ON 4" DISCHARGE PIPING ON PD PUMP. column245: A MISCOMMUNICATION RESULTED IN PERSONNEL DIRECTING THE FLOW OF GASOLINE FROM THE PIPELINE INTO A TANK AGAINST A CLOSED VALVE.  AS AS RESULT, PRESSURE IMMEDIATELY BUILT UP ON THE PIPELINE AND ALL ITS COMPONENTS UNTIL A PUMP CASING CRACKED.  IF THE COMPONENT HAD HELD PRESSURE AS IT WAS RATED, IT WOULD HAVE ALLOWED THE EMERGENCY PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE TO OPEN THEREBY RELIEVING THE PRESSURE AND NOTIFYING THE CONTROL CENTER OF A PROBLEM.

column245: EDMONTON CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR RECEIVED A GAS ALARM AT MINONG STATION AND DISPATCHED STATION TECHNICIAN TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL, TECHNICIAN FOUND OIL SPRAYING INSIDE THE PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE (PCV) BUILDING. HIGH LOWER EXPLOSIVE LIMIT (LEL) LEVELS AND SPRAYING OIL PREVENTED ENTRY. STATION SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES WERE CLOSED AND THE SPRAY DISSIPATED. CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS BROKEN STAINLESS STEEL TUBING CONNECTING THE 2" PIPE TO THE STATION DISCHARGE PRESSURE TRANSMITTER. OIL WAS PRIMARILY CONFINED TO PCV BUILDING,WITH A SMALL AMOUNT JUST OUTSIDE THE BUILDING PERIMETER. NO SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT IS EXPECTED.

column241: LEWIS D RICHEY, SENIOR RELIABILITY INSPECTOR
column245: ON DECEMBER 13, 2003 BETWEEN 2:45AM AND 3:30AM THE 7+25 ANCHOR POINT ON THE #6 DOCKLINE FAILED.  THE ANCHOR POINT WAS RIPPED OUT OF THE PIPE CREATING A 3" X 3.5" HOLE IN THE PIPE.  THE PIPE SHIFTED BECAUSE OF THE FAILED ANCHOR AND A 2" STUBOUT ABOUT 450' DOWNSTREAM OF THE FAILED ANCHOR POINT CRACKED.  APPROXIMATELY 1000 BARRELS OF HEAVY COKER GAS OIL SPILLED TO THE GROUND.  THE FAILURE MECHANISM IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  WE FEEL EITHER A LINE HAMMER OR THERMAL EXPANSION EFFECT OR COMBINATION OF BOTH CAUSED THE ANCHOR POINT TO FAIL. WE HAVE TAKEN STEPS TO PREVENT FUTURE ISSUES WITH THIS AND OUR OTHER DOCKLINES.  WE WILL SUBMIT A COMPLETE FOLLOW-UP REPORT ONCE THE INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN COMPLETED.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column238: HUMAN ERROR-CONTRACT EMPLOYEE FAILED TO FULLY CLOSE A BUTTERFLY ISOLATION VALVE.
column245: CONTRACT COMPANY WAS WORKING ON CLEANING TANK 1957.  AT END OF THE WORK DAY AT (17:00 HRS) ON FRIDAY, JANUARY 16, 2004, A CONTRACT EMPLOYEE FAILED TO FULLY CLOSE A BUTTERFLY ISOLATION VALVE THAT WENT TO A CENTRIFUGE TANK.  THE VALVE LEAKED OIL INTO THE CENTRIFUGE TANK WHICH OVERFLOWED.  ONCE THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY PREMOR OPERATORS, THE LEAK WAS TRACED BACK TO THE LEAKING VALVE WHICH WAS THEN FULLY CLOSED.  CONTAINMENT BOOMS WERE THEN PLACED AT STRATEGIC LOCATIONS TO MINIMIZE THE SPILL AREA.

column245: THE INCIDENT OCCURRED ON A LOW PRESSURE TANK LINE LOCATED WITHIN THE CASPER FACILITY PROPERTY BOUNDARY.  THE PROJECT INVOLVED A SCHEDULED CRUDE OIL TANK LINE ALTERCATION.  THE ROUTINE PROCEDURE INCLUDED LINE DRAIN DOWN, FLANGE REMOVAL, MUD PLUG THE LINE AND WELD A 6" TAP INTO THE TANK LINE.  SAFETY PROCEDURES WERE REVIEWED AND IN PLACE FOR THE PROCEDURE.  DURING THE WELDING PROCEDURE, THERE WAS A FLASH FIRE (APPROXIMATE DURATION = 2 SECONDS) WHICH RESULTED IN INJURIES TO 4 CONTRACTOR PERSONNEL.  TWO OF THE INJURIES REQUIRED SHORT TERM HOSPITALIZATION AND THE PATIENTS WERE RELEASED WITHIN 2 DAYS.  THERE WAS NOT A RELEASE OF PRODUCT OR EQUIPMENT DAMAGE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS INCIDENT.       UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: THE FIELD OPERATING PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED BY THE CENTRAL PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER ON JANUARY 7, 2004 THAT A HIGH SUMP ALARM INDICATION AT ALLENTOWN STATION (UNMANNED)WAS OCCURRING.  THE CONTROLLER SHUTDOWN THE MAINLINE AT THIS FACILITY AT 0457 AT THE REQUEST OF THE FIELD OPERATOR WHO HAD ARRIVED AT THE FACILITY TO INVESTIGATE THE ALARM. THE FIELD OPERATOR OBSERVED APPROXIMATELY 1" OF KEROSENE FLOATING ON TOP OF WATER CONTAINED IN THE ACCESS WELL FOR THE CHECK VALVE. A CREW ARRIVED AND REMOVED THE FUEL/WATER MIXTURE AND CONTAMINATED SOIL AROUND THE CHECK VALVE.  AN INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE SEALS AND GLANDS FOR THE CHECK VALVE HAD FAILED.  THE VALVE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED AT 2400 AND THE LINE PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.

column245: WATER SEEPED IN TO THE DRAIN LINE OF AN EXTERNAL FLOATING ROOF THAT IS INSTALLED ON AN ABOVEGROUND STORAGE TANK THAT IS IN BREAKOUT TANK SERVICE.  APPARENTLY, THE WATER FROZE CAUSING THE THREADS TO CRACK ON A PIPE NIPPLE COMPONENT OF THE DRAIN LINE ASSEMBLY.  THE DRAIN LINE IS MADE UP OF SEVERAL SECTIONS OF PIPE AND SWIVEL JOINTS, THE ENDS OF WHICH ARE CONNECTED TO THE EXTERNAL FLOATING ROOF AND THE NIPPLE AND VALVE ASSEMBLY THAT IS INSTALLED ON THE EXTERNAL TANK WALL.  APPARENTLY, A LEAK DEVELOPED IN ONE OR MORE OF THE SWIVEL JOINTS, ALLOWING THE GASOLINE WITHIN THE TANK TO BE RELEASED TO THE OUTSIDE VIA THE CRACKED THREADS ON THE DRAIN LINE.

column245: ON JANUARY 19, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 11:30 HOURS, AN EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE IDENTIFIED NUMBER TWO FUEL OIL AROUND THE BASE OF THE PUMP FOUNDATION AND RUN-OFF TOWARDS THE CONTROL BUILDING AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION. ON JANUARY 16, 2004, THE NUMBER TWO MAINLINE UNIT AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION WAS REMOVED FOR REPAIRS, AND THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE GATE VALVES INTO THE UNIT WERE SHUT, LOCKED-OUT AND TAGGED-OUT, AND THE DISCHARGE LINES INTO THE MAINLINE UNIT, THAT WAS REMOVED, WERE PROPERLY SEALED WITH BLIND FLANGES.  HOWEVER, A UNION ON THE .500-INCH DISCHARGE PRESSURE TUBING OFF THE DISCHARGE LINE FILLED WITH PRODUCT OVER THE WEEKEND AND PRODUCT LEAKED FROM THE UNION THAT WAS LOOSENED, AND NOT TIGHTENED.  THE FREE-PHASED PRODUCT WAS VACUUMED-UP, AND THE IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PLACED IN ROLL-OFF BOXES FOR PROPER MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL.  SOIL SAMPLING AND SUBSURFACE GEOPROBE TESTING HAS INDICATED THAT ALL THE IMPACTED SOIL HAS BEEN REMOVED.

column126: REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL
column245: EL PASO ENERGY INSTALLING A 24" PIPLINE (CAMERON HIGHWAY) ALONG PREMCOR PIPELINE COMPANY RIGHT-OF-WAY. EL PASO CONTRACTORS HAD DUG A 20-YARD LONG X 10' WIDE 10' DEEP TRENCH TO MAKE A CONNECTION. EL PASO CONTRACTOR WHILE DIGGING THE TRENCH MOVED THE EXCAVATED DIRT TO THE EASTSIDE OF THE TRENCH. EL PASO CONTRACTOR INSTALL METAL SHEETING ALONG EAST WALL OF TRENCH. AREA HAD BEEN EXPERIENCING RAIN OVER THE LAST COUPLE OF DAYS. WITH THE WEIGHT OF THE EXCAVATED DIRT AND THE SATURATED SOIL, THE EAST TRENCH WALL MOVED CAUSING PREMCOR'S 10" CRUDE OIL PIPELINE TO MOVE APPROXIMATELY 1 FOOT. THIS MOVEMENT OF SOIL AGAINST THE EXPOSED PIPELINE CAUSE AND ACETALYNE WELD TO CRACK CIRCUMFERENTIALLY APPROX. 17" CAUSING THE SPILL. DURING THE ENTIRE TIME, THE OIL SPILL WAS CONTAINED INSIDE THE TRENCH.

column245: BECAUSE THE CONTRACTOR WAS GOING TO BE DRILLING NEAR OUR PIPELINE AND WANTED TO CONFIRM THE PIPELINES DEPTH, ARRANGEMENTS WERE MADE TO POT HOLE THE PIPELINE AT 100' INTERVALS. THIS WORK WAS DONE IN THE PRESENCE OF A HELCO REP. PIPELINE EXPOSURE REPORTS WERE COMPLETED AND THE LINE FLAGED. AT THE HUALANI INTERSECTION THE DRILLING OPERATOR ASSUMED THAT THE PIPELINE MARKER WAS OVER THE PIPELINE AND USED THAT AS A GUIDE INSTEAD OF THE EXPOSED PIPELINE MARKERS. SEE THE ATTACHED REPORT FOR A SUMMARY OF THE RESPONSE.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AT 0645 ON 1/2/04, WHILE MAKING THE MORNING ROUNDS, THE OPERATOR ON DUTY NOTICED A SHEEN ON THE SURFACE OF THE WATER.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION INDICATED THE SHEEN WAS A RESULT OF A MINOR LEAK ON THE RISER OF SS 266 TO 22 208 F PUMP (MMS SEG #450) AT THE PLUS 10 LEVEL.  THE LINE WAS SHUT IN, A TEMPORARY CLAMP INSTALLED AND THE AGENCY/INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  PLANS WERE IMMEDIATELY INITIATED TO AFFECT PERMANENT REPAIRS.  THESE REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON 1/4/04.  FOLLOW-UP INVESTIGATION SHOWED THAT THE AREA OF CORROSION LEADING TO THE LEAK HAD BEEN REPORTED ON PREVIOUS THIRD PARTY TOP SIDE INSPECTIONS IN-HAND AS MODERATE.  THE RESULTS OF THE MOST CURRENT INSPECTION COMPLETED IN AUGUST '03 HAD NOT YET MADE IT INTO OUR HANDS.  SUBSEQUENT TO THE INCIDENT, WE TRACKED DOWN THE REPORT AND UPON EXAMINATION OF SAME FOUND THAT THE AREA OF THE LEAK HAD BEEN DESCRIBED ON THIS REPORT AS SERIOUS.  CONCLUSIONS DRAWN FROM THE ANALYSIS OF THE FACTS INDICATE THAT THE INSPECTION COMPANY HAS NOT BEEN INCONSISTENT IN THE APPLICATION OF A STANDARDIZED PROTOCOL IN THE CONDUCT OF INSPECTIONS AND COMPILATION OF REPORTS.  WE HAVE ALSO CONCLUDED THAT WE THE OPERATOR COULD HAVE BEEN MORE DILIGENT AND PROACTIVE IN WORKING WITH THE SERVICE PROVIDER IN ESTABLISHING A MORE RELIABLE PROCESS.  WE WILL BE WORKING WTIH THE THIRD PARTY INSPECTION COMPANY TO REMEDY THE SITUATION.

column245: A HIGH PRESSURE GREASE FITTING ON A 6 INCH ANSI 600 BALL VALVE FAILED AND STARTED TO DRIP.  THE VALVE WAS LOCATED ON A SCRAPER TRAP BYPASS. WHEN THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED THE LEAK WAS SECURED. EMPCO PERSONNEL AND A VALVE TECH FLEW BY HELECOPTOR TO THE PLATFORM AND MADE REPAIRS TO THE FITTING. THE VALVE IS SCHEDULED TO BE REPLACED DURING THE NEXT SCHEDULED SHUT DOWN.

column47: REPAIR OF BREAKOUT TANK FLOATING ROOF
column66: SEAL OF FLOATING ROOF OF 150,000 BARREL
column245: OIL WAS DISCOVERED ON TOP OF THE FLOATING ROOF OF ONE 150,000 BARREL TANK LOCATED AT THE LEWISTON STATION TANK FARM FACILITY. THE TANK WAS IMMEDIATELY ISOLATED AND TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE. STEPS WERE IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENTED TO TRANSFER THE OIL TO ANOTHER "ON-SITE" TANK IN ORDER TO READY THE TANK FOR FURTHER INSPECTION AND REPAIR EFFORTS. NO OIL WAS RELEASED TO THE ATMOSPHERE OR ONTO THE GROUND. THE TANK IS LOCATED INSIDE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT AS WELL WHICH, RENDERS NO THREAT TO THE ENVIRONMENT OR TO PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY.

column245: AFTER AN EARLY OPERATIONAL SCENARIO WHICH REQUIRED ROUTINE DELIVERIES, THE PIPELINE EVENTUALLY MIGRATED INTO A SITUATION WHERE IT WAS RARELY USED.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT THESE PERIODS OF LONG STAGNATION ENABLED WATER TO SETTLE OUT OF THE LINE FILL AND CAUSE THE SUBJECT AREA OF INTERNAL CORROSION.  THIS CORROSION IN TURN CAUSED THE PIPE TO BE WEAKENED AND TO CRACK AND FAIL FROM NORMAL HOOP STRESS.

column245: JAYHAWK'S BOOSTER PUMP AT IT'S HOLDREDGE PUMP STATION WAS THE FAILURE.  THE BEARING ON THE PUMP WENT OUT CAUSING THE PUMP TO GET HOT AND IN TURN THE PUMP SEAL FAILED, SPRAYING OIL ONTO THE HOT BEARING CAUSING THE BOOSTER TO IGNITE.  THE FIREBURNED ALL OF THE OIL SPRAYING OUT OF THE PUMP.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: ON SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2004, A PROPERTY OWNER CALLED BUCKEYE¿S 800 NUMBER TO REPORT A POSSIBLE RELEASE.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS DISPATCHED IMMEDIATELY TO THE AREA WHERE PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED.  BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED IMMEDIATELY.  THE PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE AT THE TIME THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED WAS 0 DUE TO THE PIPELINE ALREADY BEING SHUTDOWN DUE TO NORMAL SCHEDULING.    AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PRODUCT CAME FROM A MAINLINE VALVE THAT HAD A CRACK IN THE BODY.  IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE CRACK IN THE MAINLINE VALVE BODY WAS CAUSED DUE TO THE COLD WEATHER AND WATER SETTLING IN THE BODY OF THE VALVE.    THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, AND LOCAL KNOX COUNTY SHERIFF¿S OFFICE WERE NOTIFIED.  THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AFTER A PLAN WAS SUBMITTED AND APPROVED BY THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.    ENTERING THIS SUPPLEMENTAL DATA REPORT DUE TO THE SYSTEM DID NOT RECORD THE AMOUNT SPILLED AND RECOVERED AND SOME OTHER DATA THE FIRST TIME.    I HAD TO ENTER "0" INTO THE WALL THICKNESS AND SMYS FIELDS, THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT LET ME LEAVE THEM BLANK.

column245: UPON ARRIVAL FOR SHIFT CHANGE AT HOUSTON STATION, AN OPERATOR SMELLED GASOLINE VAPORS IN THE STATION MANIFOLD AREA.  SHE NOTIFIED THE NIGHT SHIFT AND CONTROL CENTER.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER ARRIVED AND DETERMINED THAT CONTRACT HELP WAS NEEDED TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF PRODUCT RELEASE. UPON ARRIVAL OF EQUIPMENT AND MANPOWER, EXCAVATION BEGAN AND THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS FOUD TO BE A CRACK NEAR THE TOE OF THE WELD WHERE A 36" SHIPPER LINE CONNECTED INTO THE MAIN 40" GASOLINE HEADER WITHIN HOUSTON STATION. THE AREA WAS ISOLATED AND DRAINED UP TO INITIATE THE REPAIR PLAN.  A TEE-LIKE REPAIR SLEEVE WAS FABRICATED OUT OF 36" & 40" SLEEVE MATERIAL AND WELDED TO THE HEADER.

CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A CONTRACT CREW UNDER DIRECTION OF AN ENBRIDGE PROJECT COORDINATOR WAS BEGINNING TO DIG AN INDICATION (DENT WITH METAL LOSS) AT MP 1007.33 NEAR THE TOWN OF GRAND RAPIDS, MN. ALTHOUGH NO OIL WAS SEEN ON THE TOP OF THE GROUND,FRESHLY CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS ENCOUNTERED ONCE DIGGING COMMENCED. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A SLOW, WEEPING CRACK ON OUR 26" LINE 2 PIPE. UPON EXCAVATION, A ROCK WAS REMOVED FROM THE DENT AND WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK. A ONE-FOT TIGHT-FITTING SLEEVE, PLACED OVER A RUBBER PATCH, WAS WELDED OVER THE DENT. DISOCVERY, EVALUATION AND REPAIR OF CRACK WAS ALL COMPLETED WITHIN 12 HOURS.   UPDATE 8/11/2004 - AN ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT HAS DETERMINED THAT THE GROUNDWATER DIRECTLY BELOW THE AREA OF THE LEAK WAS AFFECTED.  ADDITIONAL MONITORING WELLS MUST BE INSTALLED TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF THE GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION.  ONCE THE WELLS ARE INSTALLED AND MONITORED, A BETTER ESTIMATE OF VOLUME AND COST OF ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION CAN BE ESTABLISHED.    FOLLOWING THE INSTALLATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF A MONITORING WELL, APPROXIMATELY 1 FOOT OF OIL WAS OBSERVED IN EARLY AUGUST 2004.  THE MINNESOTA POLLUTION CONTROL AGENCY WAS NOTIFIED OF THIS FINDING AT THAT TIME.  ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATION WAS NECESSARY TO DEFINE THE OIL LOST AND THE ASSOCIATED IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER, WHICH TOOK SOME TIME DUE TO DIFFICULT SITE ACCESS, REQUIRED PERMITS, CHANGE IN LAND OWNERSHIP AND DIFFICULT DRILLING CONDITIONS (LARGE BOULDERS).  DRILLING BEGAN IN EARLY SEPTEMBER AND CONTINUED THROUGH NOVEMBER UNTIL SNOWFALL RESTRICTED ACCESS.  ALL MONITORING WELLS WERE SUBSEQUENTLY DEVELOPED AND SURVEYED.  THE INITIAL MONITORING EVENT WAS COMPLETED IN MID-DECEMBER AND A CONFIRMATORY SAMPLING EVENT WAS CONDUCTED IN LATE JANUARY TO DETERMINE WHETHER THE INITIAL OBSERVATIONS WERE VALID AND THE OIL THICKNESSES OBSERVED IN THE WELLS HAD STABILIZED.  FOLLOWING THE COLLECTION OF THE DATA FROM THE LATE JANUARY SAMPLING EVENT, THE OIL LOST VOLUME WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CALCULATED BASED ON THE OBSERVED OIL THICKNESSES IN THE MONITORING WELLS AND REPORTED TO THE APPLICABLE AGENCIES INVOLVED.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: DELAWARE TERMINAL COMPANY ("DTC") WAS INFORMED BY CEREZA ENGERGY INC. ("CEREZA") THAT CEREZA PLANNED TO INSTALL A 12 INCH PIPELINE TO TRANSPORT METHANE GAS FROM A WILMINGTON, DELAWRE DUMP SITE TO A POWER PLANT OWNED AND OPERATED BY CONECTIV ENERGY SUPPLY ("CONECTIV") IN EDGEMOOR, DE ALONG A ROUTE THAT WOULD OVER A CONSIDERABLE DISTANCE, BE TEN FEET FROM DTC'S 10 INCH OIL PIPELINE TO THE SAME CONECTIV POWER PLANT.  DTC CAUTIONED CEREZA, QUAD 3 GROUP, INC., THE ENGINEERING FIRM RETAINED BY CEREZA AND CONECTIV CONCERNING THE CLOSENESS OF THE PROPOSED GAS PIPELINE TO DTC'S OIL PIPELINE.  DTC SUGGESTED CEREZA CONSIDER OTHER ROUTES, INCLUDING ONE PARALLELING ANOTHER CEREZA PIPELINE FROM THE SAME DUMP TO THE SAME POWER PLANT, WHICH WOULD NOT ENDANGER DTC'S PIPELINE.  DTC ALSO CAUTIONED CEREZA CONCERNING THE EXTREMELY WET CONDITIONS THAT EXISTED AT THE TIME IN THE AREA OF THE WORK.  NOTWITHSTANDING DTC'S CAUTIONS, CEREZA PROCEEDED AS IT HAD ORIGINALLY PLANNED.  ALTHOUGH THE PIPELINE WAS TO BE INSTALLED BY TRENCHING, CEREZA, OR ITS CONTRACTOR, GEORGE & LYNCH, INC. ("GEORGE & LYNCH") DECIDED TO TRENCH ONLY A PORTION OF THE ROUTE AND DECIDED TO UTILIZE UNDERGROUND BORING FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE ROUTE.  THE UNDERGROUND BORING APPARENTLY WAS PERFORMED IN A GROSSLY NEGLIGENT MANNER WHICH RESULTED IN THE GAS PIPELINE BEING INSTALLED ALONG A WINDING PATH WHICH CAME CLOSER THAN THE MINIMUM 10 FOOT SEPARATION, GUARANTEED BY CEREZA, ALONG MUCH OF THE ROUTE, AND CROSSING OVER, OR THROUGH, DTC'S PIPELINE IN AT LEAST TWO LOCATIONS IN ERROR.  IN AT LEAST ONE OF THOSE LOCATIONS, THE BORING EQUIPMENT PUNCTURED DTC'S PIPELINE.  GEORGE & LYNCH REPORTED AN OIL SPILL IN THE AREA OF DTC'S PIPELINE AT COMMENCEMENT OF BUSINESS ON FEBRUARY 9, 2004.

TANK 414 AT BOYER HAS TWO SETS OF VENTS, P&CD ARE BASED OFF UPPER VENTS. RELEASE OCCURRED AT FILL HEIGHT OF 47¿ 7¿ WELL BELOW ANY PROTECTIVE DEVICES THAT WERE IN PLACE. column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 12:23 HOURS, JANUARY 9,2004, ONE OF THE COMPANY'S CONTRACTORS UNINTENTIONALLY DRILLED INTO A COMPANY PRODUCT PIPELINE WHILE BORING A NEW COMPANY PIPELINE ROAD CROSSING.  THE CONTROL ROOM WAS CALLED AND THE LINE SHUT DOWN AT 12:30 HOURS.  COMPANY AND CONTRACTOR PERSONNEL RESPONDED IMMEDIATELY TO CONTAIN THE SPILL AND SET UP RECOVERY OPERATIONS.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NRC AND THE RRC. PERSONNEL RECOVERD 70 BARRELS OF 183 BARRELS SPILLED AND BEGAN REMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL THAT AFTERNOON.  THE FOLLOWING DAY THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS RECOVERED AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE IN THE CROSSING.  THE LINE WAS RESTORED TO SERVICE WITHOUT INCIDENT. 7-21-04 IN THIS FINAL REPORT APPROXIMATE COSTS FOR RESPONSE, REPAIR AND REMEDIATION HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AS LISTED IN PART A5.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 9:30PM ON 3/3/04, THE TULSA CONTROL CENTER NOTICED A SMALL SHORTAGE ON THE ORANGE LINE FOR THE HOUR.  THE DISPATCHER IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE LINE AND CONTACTED FIELD PERSONNEL.  FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND CLOSED THE MAIN LINE VAVLES EFFECTIVELY BLOCKING OFF THE LINE.  THEY INSPECTED ALL ACCESSIBLE LOCATIONS AND DID NOT FIND ANY INDICATION OF A LEAK.  THE LINE REMAINED SHUT DOWN.  THE NEXT MORNING THE AIR PATROL WAS CALLED THE FLY THE LINE AND INSPECT IT FOR ANY SIGNS OF A LEAK.  A SHEEN WAS NOTICED ON THE BESSIE HEIGHTS MARSH.  THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A TUGBOAT HITTING THE LINE.  A CONTRACTOR WAS BROUGHT IN TO REPAIR AND LOWER THE LINE.

column245: A MIXED PETROLEUM PRODUCT RELEASE WAS CONFIRMED ON MARCH 19, 2004 FROM THE 110-MILE LONG 14 INCH TWIN OAKS TO NEWARK PIPELINE IN MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP (LIMA POST OFFICE), DELAWARE COUNTY, PA.  THE MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP SEWER AUTHORITY INITIALLY DETECTED PETROLEUM ODORS IN A SANITARY SEWER AT THIS INTERSECTION.  SUNOCO PIPELINE INVESTIGATED THEIR PIPELINE AS THE SOURCE WHILE SEWER AUTHORITY AND LOCAL FIRE OFFICIALS ALSO INVESTIGATED OTHER POTENTIAL SOURCES IN THE VICINITY.  UPON EXCAVATION OF THE PIPELINE AND CASING IT WAS CONFIRMED THAT THERE WAS A RELEASE FROM THE PIPELINE.    APPARENTLY PRODUCT WAS LOST AT A LOW RATE OVER AN UNKNOWN PERIOD OF TIME BUT AT LEAST 1 DAY AND 19 HOURS IN DURATION BASED ON THE SEWER AUTHORITY NOTIFICATION OF ODORS UNTIL CONFIRMATION OF THE LEAK.  NO EVACUATIONS WERE NECESSARY AND A SMALL AREA AROUND THE CASING END WAS SECURED WITH TRAFFIC BARRIERS WHILE PIPELINE CREWS INVESTIGATED THE LEAK, MADE REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE AND BEGAN CLEANING UP THE PRODUCT.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACING THE FAILED SECTION WITH A 6-FOOT SECTION OF PRE-TESTED API 5LX 14-INCH X 0.375¿ WT X-52 LINE PIPE.  EXCAVATED SOILS WERE REMOVED FROM THE SITE FOR REMEDIATION AND DISPOSAL.  A REMEDIATION SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED IN THE REPAIR TRENCH PRIOR TO BACKFILLING THE REPAIRED PIPELINE AND CASING.  REMEDIATION IS ONGOING    THE FAILURE OCCURRED ON THE PIPE BODY BETWEEN THE 2:00 AND 3:00 O¿CLOCK ORIENTATION 10-INCHES IN FROM THE DOWNSTREAM END OF A 20-INCH DIAMETER CASING ACROSS ROUTE 1.  CC TECHNOLOGIES EXAMINED THE FAILED PIPE AND DETERMINED THE FAILURE WAS DUE TO A CRACK LOCATED AT THE BOTTOM OF A LONGITUDINALLY ORIENTED, EXTERNAL METAL LOSS FEATURE APPROXIMATELY 3-INCHES LONG, 1-INCH WIDE WITH A DEPTH OF 89% OF PIPE WT.  A FAILURE ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THE CRACK WAS MOST LIKELY PROPAGATED BY A FATIGUE MECHANISM, DRIVEN BY PRESSURE FLUCTUATIONS ON THE PIPELINE.

column245: MESA TANK FARM OPERATOR DISCOVERED A CRUDE OIL RELEASE WHILE MAKING ROUTINE TANK FARM INSPECTION. THE  SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS THE PUMP BYPASS LINE OF THE TANK DISCHARGE LINE TO TANK # 1586. THE BYPASS LINE WAS PART OF THE ORIGINAL DESIGN (INSTALLED BELOW GRADE IN ITS ENTIRETY, EXCLUDING THE HANDWHEEL OF THE VALVE)  ALLOWING TANK MOVEMENT IN BOTH DIRECTIONS THROUGH A COMMON LINE.  A DEDICATED FILL LINE WAS INSTALLED SOMETIME PRIOR TO 1973. UPON ITS INSTALLATION, THE PUMP BYPASS A DEAD LEG WITHIN THE ACTIVE PIPELINE SEGMENT. THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE WAS IDENTIFIED AS  INTERNAL CORROSION.

column89: NOT POSSIBLE DUE TO PHYSICAL CONSTRAINTS IN THE SYSTEM
column245: DURING HYDROTEST PREPARATORY WORK ON 26" PIPING WITHIN THE SUPERIOR TERMINAL, A VAPOR PLUG APPARENTLY FAILED DURING WELDING OPERATIONS, RESULTING IN A FLASH, SIGNIFICANT SMOKE, AND THE RELEASE OF ABOUT 2 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL INTO THE EXCAVATION.  THERE WERE NO INJURIES. THE SECTION OF PIPELINE BEING WORKED ON WAS ISOLATED FROM ALL LIVE SYSTEMS AND HAD BEEN DRAINED UP. OPERATIONS AT THE TERMINAL WERE NOT IMPACTED.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT REMAINS UNDER INVESTIGATION. A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRUDE OIL DRAINED INTO THE TERMINAL DITCH ADJACENT TO THE EXCAVATION, BUT THIS WAS CONTAINED WITH BERMING AND BOOM TO ABOUT FIFTY FEET OF DITCH.  CLEAN UP SHOULD BE RELATIVELY EASY AND THE OVERALL RELEASE IMPACT IS MINOR.  ALTHOUGH, UNDER THE 5 BARREL DOT REPORTING THRESHOLD FOR LEAKS OCCURRING DURING MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES, THE FLASH DOES TRIGGER DOT AND NRC REPORTING.  THIS INCIDENT WILL BE THOROUGHLY INVESTIGATED AS TO CAUSE AND LEARNINGS COMMUNICATED AS SOON AS POSSIBLE VIA CLOSE CALL BULLETIN.

column245: THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO EXTERNAL CORROSION.  DURING THE INTEGRITY DIG, THE CREW OBSERVED THE PIPELINE LEAKING FOLLOWING THE REMOVAL OF SCALE FROM THE CORRODED AREA. AFTER THE DISCOVERY, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND THE LEAK CLOSED IN, THE WORK CREW PLACED A CLAMP ON THE PIPELINE AND REPAIRED IT WITH A TYPE "B" SLEEVE.  SUBSEQUENT ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATIONS WERE PERFORMED BEGINNING ON APRIL 20, 2004.  ON APRIL 22, 2004 IT WAS DETERMINED THE COST OF THE INVESTIGATIONS COULD EXCEED $50,000.  AFTER THIS DETERMINATION WAS MADE, PLANTATION IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER (NRC) AT 11:38 AM (EDT).

A 10 MILE SEGMENT OF LINE WAS ISOLATED AND FLARES WERE BROUGHT IN TO FLARE DOWN THE LINE. C.3.A - DIAMETER IS ACTUALLY 1/2 INCH INSTEAD OF 1 INCH AS INDICATED IN THIS REPORT.     10/19/2005 - AMENDED FINAL REPORT WITH CORRECTION OF MOP DATA AND INSTALLATION DATE. column157: INACTIVE PIPE AFFECTED BY SEDIMENT & WATER
column245: CRUDE OIL WAS DISCOVERED COMING FROM GROUND ON THE NORTH SIDE OF TEXACO ROAD (CONOCO PHILLIPS PROPERTY). SIX SEPARATE COMPANY'S LINES CROSS ONE ANOTHER IN A 200' DIAMETER AREA.  THE OIL RESULTED FROM A LEAK IN AN 8" INACTIVE LATERAL LINE ATTACHED TO A TRANSFER LINE BETWEEN TEPPCO AND ENBRIDGE. PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN A SHALLOW DITCH AND TWO VACUUM TRUCKS RETRIEVED STANDING FREE PRODUCT.  VISUAL INSPECTION INDICATED THE LEAK WAS DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSSION.  A TEMPORARY GASSO CLAMP REPAIR WAS MADE, AND THE LINE RETURNED TO SERVICE.  PERMANENT CORRECTIVE ACTION TAKEN INCLUDED DOSCONNECTING THIS INACTIVE LATERAL. IT WAS THEN CAPPED AND NITROGEN PURGED. THE TEE CONNECTION WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND A PRETESTED CYLINDER WAS INSTALLED IN ITS PLACE.

column238: FLANGE ON UNDERGROUND SPOOL PIECE WAS NOT PROPERLY SEQUENCED WHEN TORQUED. SMALL WEEP DEVELOPED BETWEEN GASKET AND FLANGE.
column245: DURING STATION WALK-AROUND ON MAY 3, 2004 AT APPROXIMATELY 00:01 HOURS, A SMALL AMOUNT OF PRODUCT WAS IDENTIFIED NEAR THE UNDERGROUND PIPING FROM THE DISCHARGE OF MAINLINE UNITS TO THE GREENVILLE, TEXAS STATION.  EXCAVATION OF AREA IDENTIFIED WEEPING OF PRODUCT AT THE BOTTOM OF THE FLANGE AND GASKET. THE SPOOL PIECE THAT WAS EXCAVATED WAS ASSOCIATED WITH THE ORIGINAL 1971 CONSTRUCTION. THE CAUSE OF WEEPING WAS FROM FLANGES NOT BEING PROPERLY SEQUENCED, AND TORQUED, WHICH CAUSED A SMALL GAP BETWEEN THE FLANGE AND GASKET.  DEPTH OF COVER WAS APPROXIMATELY 72 INCHES TO THE TOP OF THE SPOOL, AND 96 INCHES TO THE BOTTOM OF THE SPOOL. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN FOR 12 HOURS FOR REPAIRS, WHICH INCLUDED RESURFACING ALL FOUR FLANGES, BEFORE THE SPOOL PIECE WAS REINSTALLED. THE ACTUAL DURATION OF THE RELEASE IS PRESENTLY NOW KNOWN, AS THERE WAS ONLY A WEEP.  APPROXIMATELY 130 CUBIC YARDS OF PETROLEUM IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED, AND TESTING INDICATED APPROXIMATELY 12.9 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE SOIL.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: DURING A NORMAL SHUTDOWN OF LINE SECTION 25 AT 18:32 PDST ON APRIL 27, 2004 SCADA INFORMATION RECEIVED IN OUR CONTROL CENTERS IN ORANGE AND CONCORD, CALIFORNIA INDICATED THAT WE HAD AN ABNORMAL OPERATING CONDITION - THE DATA INDICATED A DROP IN PRESSURE AND AN INCREASE IN FLOW.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND WE IMMEDIATELY BEGAN INVESTIGATING THE CAUSE OF THE ABNORMAL OPERATING CONDITION.  WE DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO BEGIN SURVEILLANCE OF THE PIPELINE BY DRIVING THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY LOOKING FOR EVIDENCE OF A SPILL.  BY DARK, ON TUESDAY, APRIL 27, WE HAD NOT FOUND EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE.  THE DECISION WAS MADE TO POSTPONE SURVEILLANCE UNTIL DAYLIGHT THE NEXT DAY DUE TO THE PRACTICAL LIMITATIONS OF SPOTTING INDICATIONS OF A RELEASE AFTER DARK, CONCERNS FOR OUR EMPLOYEE'S SAFETY, AND THE FACT THAT THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN, THEREBY MINIMIZING ANY POTENTIAL FOR CONTINUING TO RELEASE PRODUCT FROM THE PIPELINE EVEN IF WE HAD A RELEASE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 0600, ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 2004 KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL RESUMED PATROLLING THE PIPELINE FOR EVIDENCE OF A SPILL; ADDITIONALLY, WE BEGAN AERIAL SURVEILLANCE AT APPROXIMATELY 0745.  (DUE TO FLIGHT RESTRICTION, THE PLANE WAS NOT CLEARED TO TAKE OFF UNTIL THEN.) THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY WAS FLOWN TWICE AND PERSONNEL DROVE THE RIGHT-OF-WAY; THERE WAS STILL NO SIGN OF A RELEASE.  BY APPROXIMATELY 10:00 AM, IT APPEARED LESS AND LESS AS IF THE ABNORMAL OPERATING CONDITION WAS DUE TO A RELEASE.  HOWEVER, TO BE SURE, IN ACCORDANCE WITH STANDARD PROCEDURES, THE DECISION WAS MADE TO APPLY MINIMAL PRESSURE TO THE PIPELINE TO ENSURE ITS INTEGRITY.  THIS WAS DONE BY USING SMALLER PUMPS THAN ARE NORMALLY USED FOR PIPELINE OPERATION. PRIOR TO CONDUCTING THE TEST, WE NOTIFIED THE CALIFORNIA STATE FIRE MARSHALS OFFICE TO INFORM THEM OF OUR PLANS.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1240 PST, DURING THE ATTEMPTED RE-PRESSURING OF THE PIPELINE, KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL REALIZED THAT THE PRESSURE WAS NOT INCREASING AS EXPECTED, AND THE PUMPS WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN.  AT APPROXIMATELY THE SAME TIME, THE PILOT INFORMED GROUND PERSONNEL THAT HE SPOTTED A DISCOLORED AREA BETWEEN MILE POST 13 AND 15.  GROUND CREWS WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE SUSPECTED SITE.  AT 1406 PST, KM FIELD EMPLOYEES NOTIFIED THE ORANGE CONTROL CENTER OF CONFIRMATION OF DISCOLORATION AND DETECTION OF DIESEL ODOR AT MILE POST 15.1.  NOTIFICATION TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AND OFFICE OF EMERGENCY SERVICES WERE MADE IMMEDIATELY - WITHIN 30 MINUTES OF CONFIRMATION THAT WE HAD A SPILL (1418 & 1435 RESPECTIVELY)  SUBSEQUENTLY WE MADE CALLS TO THE CSFM LAKEWOOD OFFICE (APPROXIMATELY 14:36 PM) AND WESTERN REGION OF THE OPS (APPROXIMATELY 1450 PM).       NOTE REMEDIATION COMPLETE HOWEVER SOME MINOR RESTORATION COSTS MAYBE INCURRED IN THE FUTURE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column47: OIL COLLECTION, SOIL REMOVAL AND REPAIR WORK
column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: PREPARATIONS WERE BEING MADE TO HYDROTEST THE LINE 3 TO LINE 5 CROSSOVER PIPING WITHIN SUPERIOR TERMINAL.  THERE WAS A NEED TO WELD FITTINGS ON THIS 16" CROSSOVER LINE (THIS LINE IS RARELY USED IN OPERATIONS).  TO ENSURE THE LINE WAS FULL AND ENSURE SAFE WELDING, IT WAS PRESSURIZED BY OPENING THE VALVE TO LINE 3 PRESSURE.  THE CROSSOVER PIPE BEGAN LEAKING AND SPILLED APPROXIMATELY 20 BARRELS INTO NEARBY DITCHING.  VALVES WERE CLOSED, THE PIPELINE ISOLATED AND THE OIL MIGRATION WAS STOPPED. THE AFFECTED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE.     THIS LEAK SHOULD NOT HAVE ANY IMPACT ON THE MAINLINE OR NORMAL SUPERIOR TERMINAL OPERATIONS. CLEAN-UP WILL REQUIRE EXCAVATION OF OILY SOIL FROM THE SURROUNDING AREA AND DITCHES. NO SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT IS EXPECTED; HOWEVER, THERE WILL BE A FAIR AMOUNT OF EXCAVATION AND CLEAN UP TO DO. COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT $100,000.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column61: HAGERTY CREEK. TRIB, TO CADDO LAKE
column241: ALLEN D RICHEY, DISTRICT MANAGER, KILGORE DISTRICT
column245: ON 02/27/04 AT 1400 HRS THE KILGORE DISTRICT P/L OFFICE RECEIVED A CALL FROM ONE OF OUR PIPELINE OPERATORS INFORMING US THAT OUR PATROL PILOT HAD SPOTTED A LEAK ON THE ARKLATEX MAINLINE NE OF MARSHALL, TX.  THE OPERATOR CONTACTED OUR PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER TO HAVE THE LINE SHUT DOWN, THEN CONTACTED OUR DISTRICT OFFICE TO EFFECT A CLEANUP.  UPON ARRIVAL AT THE LEAK SITE, THE LEAK WAS FOUND TO BE THE RESULT OF EXTERNAL CORROSION IN A 20-FEET EXPOSURE WHERE THE PIPELINE SPANNED ACROSS A SMALL CREEK WHICH SERVES AS THE RUN-OFF FROM A FOUR ACRE STOCK TANK THAT HAD BEEN BUILT IMMEDIATELY SOUTH OF THE PIPELINE ROW.  IT IS SUSPECTED THAT OVER THE YEARS THE CONTINUED RUN-OFF FROM THE STOCK TANK HAS CAUSED THE SOIL TO ERODE ACROSS THE ROW WHICH EXPOSED THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE.  THERE WAS LOCALIZED PITTING WHERE THE PIPE COATING HAD BEEN DAMAGED.  THE LEAK OCCURRED AT THE TWO O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE PIPELINE AND WAS SPRAYING OIL UP INTO THE TREES ALONG THE ROW AND THEN RUNNING INTO THE CREEK.  PLAINS IS ESTIMATING THAT 45 BBLS WERE RELEASED, 30 RECOVERED AND RE-INTRODUCED INTO OUR SYSTEM, 10 WERE RECOVERED VIA SORBENT MATERIAL, AND 5 WERE LOST OR TRAPPED ON RECOVERED DEBRIS.

column241: WAYNE E ROBERTS, MANAGER OF ENVIRONMENTAL & REGULATORY COMPL
column245: THE #2-8 INCH KEYSTONE TO GOLDSMITH PIPELINE RELEASED CRUDE OIL FROM A PINHOLE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.  EXTERNAL CORROSION ON THIS BARE PIPE SEGMENT IS CONTROLLED BY SACRIFICIAL ANODES.  EXTREMELY HIGH SOIL RESISIVITY (DROUGHT CONDITIONS) AND PREMATURE ANODE DETERIORIATION CONTRIBUTED TO THIS LOCALIZED CORROSION EVENT.  NEW PIPE WILL BE INSTALLED IN THIS AREA, ALONG WITH NEW ADOES ON BOTH ENDS OF THE SEGMENT.  CONTAMINATED SOIL IS BE REMOVED TO GOLDSMITH STATION FOR FIREWALL REPAIR.  THE AFFECTED AREA OF THE ROW AND THE IMPACTED ADJACENT SOIL WILL BE REMEDIATED SATISFACTORILY TO RAILROAD COMMISSION STATEWIDE RULE 91 CRITERIA.

column245: ON THE MORNING OF APRIL 13, 2004 PLAINS PIPELINE PREPARED TO TAKE A CONDENSATE RECEIPT FROM SUN PIPELINE.  THE AMOUNT WAS TO BE ONLY ENOUGH TO CONDUCT A METER PROVING ON THE SUN 10" METER.  PIPELINE OPERATOR, ERIC DAHLEN CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER TO INFORM THEM THAT HE SHOULD OPEN VALVE 98 TO RECEIVE THE BBLS. INTO TANK 412, MR. DAHLEN DID NOT SPECIFICALLY TELL THE CONTROL CENTER TO OPEN VALVE 51 AND BECAUSE OF AN INCORRECT DIAGRAM ON THE CONTROLLER'S SCREEN AT THE CONTROL CENTER, THE CONTROLLER DID NOT SEE THAT VALVE 51 HAD TO BE OPENED.  THE DELIVERY WAS STARTED AND DUE TO THE FACT THAT VALVE 51 WAS CLOSED, PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS APPLIED TO THE FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTORS CONNECTING THE IN STATION PIPING MANIFOLD TO THE TANKS. THE FLEXIBLE METAL CONNECTOR ON TANK 414 FAILED AND ALLOWED 600 BBLS OF CONDENSATE TO BE PUMPED INTO THE FIREWALL CONTAINMENT AREA OF THAT TANK.    AFTER REVIEW, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THIS PIPELINE (TEXOMA TO WHITE OAK STATION)IS EXCLUDED FROM REGULATION UNDER 49 CFR 195 BECAUSE IT MEETS THE DEFINITION OF A LOW-STRESS PIPELINE AND OPERATES IN A RURAL AREA (INCLUDED IN RESPONSE TO INFORMATION REQUESTS FROM OPS, SOUTHWEST REGION, ON APRIL 14, 2004, AND APRIL 20, 2004.

column238: A 2-INCH GATE VALVE USED TO BLOW-DOWN THE PIG RECEIVER TO THE PUMP STATION FLARE / VENT HAD TRASH LODGED IN THE SEAT CAUSING THE VALVE TO LEAK A SMALL AMOUNT OF PRODUCT TO THE FLARE / VENT STACK.  THERE WAS INCLEMENT WEATHER IN THE AREA AT THE TIME AND IT IS SUSPECTED THAT EITHER STATIC ELECTRICITY CAUSED BY THE STORM OR A NEAR-BY LIGHTNING STRIKE IGNITED THE FLARE / VENT STACK.  THE SMALL WEAK FLAME (APPROXIMATELY 6 TO 8-INCHES HIGH) WAS EXTINGUISHED IMMEDIATELY AFTER DISCOVERY BY COMPANY PERSONNEL WITH A PORTABLE HAND-HELD DRY POWDER FIRE EXTINGUISHER.  THE 2-INCH GATE VALVE WAS SUBSEQUENTLY REPLACED WITH A 2-INCH PLUG VALVE IN ORDER TO AVOID A RE-OCCURRENCE OF A SIMILAR EVENT IN THE FUTURE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT 08:03 ON SUNDAY MAY 23, 2004 A .5" OUTSIDE DIAMETER STAINLESS STEEL PRODUCT SAMPLING LINE AT OLYMPIC'S RENTON STATION FAILED.  PRELIMINARY METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS SUGGESTS THAT THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE WAS LIKELY AN ELECTRICAL ARCING CONDITION RESULTING FROM WHAT IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN A SIGNIFICANT GROUND FAULT, I.E. TRANSMISSION OF POWER LINE VOLTAGE TO THE GROUND.  THE GROUND FAULT CREATED A SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCE IN VOLTAGE BETWEEN THE PRODUCT SAMPLING LINE AND AN ADJACENT CONDUIT FITTING.  THE TRANSFER OF ELECTRICAL CURRENT VIA ARCING QUICKLY CAUSED A "BURN-THROUGH" CONDITION THAT RESULTED IN METAL LOSS TO THE SAMPLING LINE AND THE CREATION OF A SMALL PINHOLE.  GASOLINE SPRAYED FROM THE PINHOLE AND WAS MOST PROBABLY IGNITED IMMEDIATELY AS A RESULT OF THE HEAT GENERATED BY THE ARCING CONDITION.    THE SUSPECT GROUND FAULT OCCURRED WITHIN, OR VERY NEAR, THE POWER COMPANY'S ELECTRCAL SUBSTATION WHICH SUPPLIES POWER TO RENTON STATION AND IS PHYSICALLY SITUATED IN THE RENTON STATION YARD.  THIS ELECTRICAL "EVENT" IMMEDIATELY ENERGIZED THE ENTIRE GROUNDING SYSTEM AND RAPIDLY DISSIPATED THROUGH A NUMBER OF METAL STRUCTURES, DAMAGING ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS AT THE RENTON STATION AND CAUSING THE RENTON STATION TO LOSE POWER.  PIPELINE OPERATIONS PRIOR TO THE ELECTRICAL EVENT WERE NORMAL IN ALL RESPECTS.    THERE WERE NO INJURIES OR FATALITIES CAUSED BY EITHER THE RELEASE OR ENSUING FIRE, ALTHOUGH THREE FIRE FIGHTERS WERE CONTAMINATED BY GASOLINE, TAKEN TO HARBORVIEW MEDICAL CENTER AND RELEASED.  NO OFF-SITE ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE HAS BEEN DETECTED.  APPROXIMATELY 45 BARRELS OF GASOLINE WERE RELEASED FROM THE SAMPLING LINE, INCLUDING AN ESTIMATED 7 BARRELS THAT WERE BURNED OFF DURING THE FIRE, RESULTING IN ROUGHLY 38 BARRELS (LESS THAN 1600 GALLONS) OF GASOLINE RELEASED TO THE AIR OR TO THE GROUND.  APPROXIMATELY 20 BARRELS (840 GALLONS) HAVE BEEN RECOVERED, AND APPROXIMATELY 18 BARRELS (746 GALLONS) EITHER EVAPORATED OR REMAIN ON-SITE AND ARE IN THE PROCESS OF BEING RECOVERED.

column245: CONTROL ROOM OPERATOR IDENTIFIED A POSSIBLE UPSET CONDITION AND SHUT DOWN THE VALLEY PIPELINE (CORPUS CHRISITI TO EDINBURG REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE) AT APPROXIMATELY 03:30 HOURS. SATURDAY MORNING, MAY 1, 2004. AT 07:00 HOURS OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE MOBILIZED IN ADDITION TO THE AERIAL PATROL PILOT TO SEARCH THE LINE SEGMENT. AT APPROXIMATELY 09:40 HOURS, THE LEAK SITE WAS IDENTIFIED 1500 FT S OF HWY 141 ON THE KING RANCH. EXCAVATION REVEALED A GOUGE ON THE SIDE OF THE PIPE ADJACENT TO AN 8" LONG SPLIT WHICH WAS CAUSED BY UNKNOWN THIRD PARTY DAMAGE. REPAIR CREWS INSTALLED A 6" PLIDCO REPAIR CLAMP AND PLACED THE LINE BACK IN SERVICE AT 18:30 HOURS THE SAME DAY. AN ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT HAS BEEN PERFORMED AND REMEDIATION IS ONGOING. THIS 6" LINE IS NOW OUT OF SERVICE HAVING BEEN REPLACED BY A NEW ORIGIN TO EDINBURG 10" PRODUCTS REPLACEMENT PIPELINE COMPLETE THROUGH THIS AREA AS OF MAY 7, 2004.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: ON FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 2004 AT 22:15 (EST) A SENIOR OPERATOR AT SOUTH BALTIMORE CONTACTED THE OPERATIONS MANAGER TO REPORT A SUMP OVERFLOW CONDITION. SOUTH BALTIMORE DELIVERY IS A REMOTE FACILITY SERVED VIA LINE 31 FROM DORSEY JUNCTION CONTROLLED BY THE ATLANTA CONTROL CENTER. DURING THE EVENING OF JUNE 11, 2004 THUNDERSTORMS PASSED THROUGH THE AREA AND CAUSED A TEMMPORARY POWER FAILURE.  THE POWER FAILURE CAUSED SEVERAL ALARMS, INCLUDING SHIPPER MAX TANK FILL WHICH INITIATED AN AUTOMATIC SHUT DOWN ON LINE 31 - DORSEY UNITS SHUT DOWN, SOUTH BALTIMORE TAKE-OFF VALVE CLOSED.  CONTROLLER CALLED OUT A LOCAL SENIOR OPERATOR TO INSPECT THE STATION PRIOR TO RESUMING OPERATIONS.  PRIOR TO SENIOR OPERATOR REACHING THE FACILITY, POWER WAS RESTORED AND THE CONTROLLER CLOSED THE SHIPPER DELIVERY VALVE.    UPON ARRIVAL AT THE FACILITY, THE SENIOR OPERATOR FOUND THE MANIFOLD THERMAL RELIEF SYSTEM RELIVING INTO THE SUMP, CAUSING THE SUMP TO OVERFLOW.  THE SENIOR OPERATOR OPENED THE SHIPPER VALVE TO RELIEVE MANIFOLD PRESSURE AND STOP THE FLOW INTO THE SUMP.  THE OVERFLOW WAS CAPTURED BY THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM AND ENTERED THE FACILITY OIL/WATER SEPARATOR WHICH CONTAINED 16" OF PRODUCT ON THE INLET SIDE.  NO PRODUCT WAS DISCHARGED FROM THE SEPARATOR.  DURING CLEAN UP EFFORTS, IT WAS DISCOVERED THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM WAS NOT FLOWING PROPERLY INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATORS AND ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ACCUMULATE THROUGHOUT THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM.  THE ENTIRE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM WAS EXCAVATED AND CONTAMINATED SOIL REMOVED AND PROPERLY STORED AND SEALED IN PLASTIC UNTIL APPROPRIATE DISPOSAL METHOD IS DETERMINED.    INVESTIGATION FOUND THE STATION TAKE-OFF VALVE HAD NOT FULLY CLOSED AND ALLOWED STATIC LINE PRESSURE TO ENTER THE MANIFOLD PIPING.  THE VOULUME WAS LOW AND DID NOT ACTIVATE THE MANIFOLD RELIEF SYSTEM, BUT DID CAUSE A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE TO RELIEVE INTO THE SUMP AT THE 145 PSI SETTING.  THE TAKE-OFF VALVE WAS CYCLED AND SEATED PROPERLY. AFTER TESTING THE VALVE AND INSPECTING ALL COMPONENTS THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS.

THE BUILDING WAS REMOVED AND THE SITE WAS EXCAVATED.  THE LEAK WAS FOUND ON A 16"  PCV BYPASS LINE TO THE LINE 3 DELIVERY LINE.  INTERNAL CORROSION WAS FOUND AND A SECTON OF THE LINE WAS REPLACED.
