column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: AT 17:00 EST ON DECEMBER 16, 2003, A WOODBURY OPERATOR RECEIVED A CALL FROM A NEIGHBOR LIVING ON HILL SIDE RD. THE NEIGHBOR INDICATED THAT HE SMELLED PRODUCT AROUND AN AREA ADJACENT TO THE WOODBURY TANK FARM. AN OPERATOR AND AN ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNICIAN INVESTIGATED THE AREA IN QUESTION. THEY NOTICED ODORS COMING FROM A DRAINAGE LINE THAT RUNS FROM THE REAR OF THE TANK FARM TOWARDS HILL SIDE ROAD. AN ODOR WAS PRESENT BUT THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF A SHEEN ON THE WATER. THE TANK FARM AREA AROUND THIS ODOR WAS INVESTIGATED AND NO VISIBLE SIGNS OF A PROBLEM WERE FOUND.  BETWEEN DECEMBER AND MARCH, GROUND WATER SAMPLES WERE TAKEN FROM EXISTING COLONIAL MONITORING WELLS AND SEVERAL ROUNDS OF GEO-PROBE TEST WERE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE CONTAMINATION. THE RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION INDICATED SOME LEVELS OF CONTAMINATION ABOVE THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT GROUNDWATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND THAT TANK 1234 COULD BE A POSSIBLE SOURCE. ON APRIL 15,2004 TANK 1234 WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND PREPARED FOR CLEANING. ON APRIL 29TH, HMT CONDUCTED A HELIUM TEST ON THE TANK¿S FLOOR AND FOUND A POSSIBLE INDICATION IN A WELD ON A FLOOR PLATE. A MAGNETIC PARTICLE INSPECTION OF THE INDICATION DID NOT CONFIRM AN ANOMALY. THE SECTION OF THE FLOOR CONTAINING THE INDICATION WAS REMOVED AND THE SOIL DIRECTLY BENEATH THE INDICATION SHOWED NO CHARACTERISTICS OF PRODUCT LOSS. ADDITIONAL GEO-PROBE BORINGS CONDUCTED INSIDE OF THE TANK INDICATED CONTAMINATION NEAR THE TANK¿S SUMP. TEST RESULTS POINT TO TANK 1234 AS THE PROBABLE SOURCE OF CONTAMINATION, BUT THE ACTUAL SOURCE WAS NOT IDENTIFIED. COLONIAL RECEIVED CONFIRMATORY SURFACE WATER SAMPLING RESULTS ON THE EVENING OF FRIDAY, JUNE 11, 2004.  THE LAB DATA WAS EVALUATED ON MONDAY, JUNE 14, 2004 AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE REPORTED RESULTS FROM TWO SAMPLING LOCATIONS EXCEEDED NEW JERSEY INSTREAM WATER QUALITY STANDARDS, PROMPTING A NOTIFICATION TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER.     AN API STANDARD 653 OUT OF SERVICE INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED JANUARY 11 TO 13, 2005 BUT NO THROUGH FLOOR DEFECTS WERE FOUND. REPAIRS AND ADDITIONAL TESTING OF THE BOTTOM SUMP WERE PERFORMED IN JANUARY 2005.  ON JANUARY 29,2005 THE FINAL INSPECTION DETERMINED THE TANK WAS SUITABLE FOR SERVICE.  ON APRIL 11, 2005 A MONITORING WELL WAS PLACED DOWNGRADIENT OF THE TANK FOR MONITORING.  ON AUGUST 26, 2005 THE TANK WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.

column238: BOLTS ON A STOPPLE TEE WERE LOOSE ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE BY THE BLIND GASKET.
column245: ON FRIDAY, JULY 9, 2004, A WEST SHORE PRESONNEL WAS INFORMED BY AN ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING COMPANY THAT A MONITORING WELL FOR A SPEEDWAY GAS STATION HAD FREE PRODUCT IN IT.  WHEN THE WEST SHORE PERSONNEL ARRIVED, HE NOTICED A SMALL AREA OF DISCOLORED VEGETATION OVER A STOPPLE TEE THAT WAS 56 FEET FROM THE MONITORING WELL.  AT 9:40 A.M. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  BY EARLY AFTERNOON IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE BOLTS ON THE BLIND OF THE STOPPLE TEE WERE LOOSE AND PRODUCT WAS ESCAPING AROUND THE BLIND GASKET.  A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED AND THE BLIND WAS BOLTED DOWN.  A PHONE CALL WAS MADE TO THE DOT THAT THE SITUATION HAD BEEN RESOLVED.  PERMISSION WAS GRANTED BY DOT TO START THE PIPELINE UP WHICH WAS DONE AT 5:00 P.M. ON THE SAME DAY.

column245: AROUND 1830 HOURS, JUNE 25, 2004 BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY WAS NOTIFIED BY THE NICHOLSON FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT THEY WERE RESPONDING TO A FIRE AT THE BUCKEYE NICHOLSON PUMP STATION.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS ALREADY SHUTDOWN DUE TO SCHEDULING.  ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  A ¼¿ PRESSURE TRANSMITTER SENSE LINE WAS PUNCTURED WHERE IT COMES THROUGH THE TOP OF A MAINLINE VALVE PIT COVER.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION BY BUCKEYE AND THE LOCAL FIRE MARSHALL THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE LIGHTENING.  CLEANUP ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN COORDINATED WITH THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.

column245: AT 2310 HOURS ON JUNE 26, 2004 THE CLAY VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT REPORTED TO BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY PRODUCT COMING OUT OF A PIPELINE VENT PIPE ALONG RT-31 IN CLAY, NEW YORK.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN, EMPLOYEES AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY CONTRACTOR WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS ALREADY SHUTDOWN DUE TO SCHEDULING.  ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED INSIDE A CASING UNDER RT-31.  THE PIPELINE HAS BEEN PULLED FROM THE CASING AND WAS REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.  NO FINAL REPORT HAS BEEN RECEIVED HOWEVER THE PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION HAS LEAD US TO BELIEVE THAT THE CAUSE WAS LIGHTENING.   CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING COORDINATED WITH THE STATE OF NEW YORK PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION.      THE REPORT FROM KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES STATES "THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A LIGHTING HIT." "NO OTHER CONTRIBUTING CAUSE OF THE FAILURE WAS IDENTIFIED."

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON JUNE 18, 2004 AT APPROXIMATELY 2012 HOURS, THE FACILITY OPERATOR AT WOODBURY PUMP STATION DISCOVERED GASOLINE SPRAYING FROM THE ABOVE GROUND PUMP MANIFOLD AREA AND IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE STATION ISOLATING THE LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS FROM A FAILED GASKET FOR THE BOLTED COVER OF A 12-INCH WHEATLEY SWING-CHECK VALVE LOCATED BETWEEN THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE LINES OF PUMP UNIT THREE.  THE FACILITY OPERATOR THEN NOTIFIED THE REGION 1 OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR WHO RESPONDED TO THE SCENE ALONG WITH OTHER PIPELINE MAINTENANCE AND HES PERSONNEL PLUS A DESIGNATED OSRO FOR THIS FACILITY.      INITIALLY THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CONFINED ON THE PUMP STATION PROPERTY WITH ANY AND ALL FREE PRODUCT BEING COLLECTED VIA VAC TRUCK IN PUDDLES, ON THE STONES AND IN A SUBSURFACE FRENCH DRAIN SYSTEM LOCATED BENEATH THE PIPING MANIFOLD.  THIS DRAIN SYSTEM EMPTIES INTO THE FACILITY OIL/WATER SEPARATOR AND HAD COLLECTED THE LEAKED PRODUCT.  SEVERAL HOURS AFTER THE LEAK OCCURRED, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR HAD A DAMAGED BAFFLE THAT ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ENTER A STORM WATER SEWER, AN UNNAMED TRIBUTARY AND COLLECT IN A MAN-MADE STORM WATER RETENTION POND LOCATED IN A NEARBY RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT.  POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL WERE ON-SCENE AND WENT DOOR TO DOOR OF THE NEARBY RESIDENCES.  NO EVACUATIONS WERE MADE.  ADDITIONAL OSRO PERSONNEL WERE CALLED TO THE SCENE TO COLLECT THE PRODUCT AND CLEAN THE STORM SEWERS, UNNAMED TRIBUTARY AND POND.  THE PRODUCT IN THE RETENTION POND RESULTED IN A FISH KILL.  AGENCY OFFICIALS INVOLVED INCLUDED LOCAL POLICE AND FIRE PERSONNEL, GLOUCESTER COUNTY AND NJ DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.    RESULTS OF THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THE ACCIDENT WAS MOST LIKELY DUE TO THE IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF THE FLANGE ASSEMBLY RESULTING IN OVER-COMPRESSION OF A PAPER/FIBER GASKET.  THE FLANGE ASSEMBLY THAT FAILED HAD BEEN REASSEMBLED ABOUT 3 MONTHS PRIOR TO THE FAILURE WITHOUT SPECIFIC ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE AVAILABLE TO THE OPERATOR¿S MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL.  AS A RESULT OF THE INVESTIGATION, SUNOCO PIPELINE WILL ISSUE A BOLTED FLANGE ASSEMBLY PROCEDURE INCLUDING BASIC PRACTICES, MATERIAL REFERENCES AND TORQUE VALUES.  THE PROCEDURE WILL ALSO ADDRESS PROPER CALIBRATION OF TORQUE WRENCHES.

column245: THE LOWER RETAINER CLIP ON THE TOP MOUNTING PIN OF THE JENSEN MODEL 650 VA MIXER BROKE.  THIS ALLOWED THE TOP MOUNTING PIN TO VIBRATE UP TO THE POINT THAT THE MIXER WAS LONGER SUPPORTED.  THE WEIGHT OF THE MIXER MOTOR CAUSED THE MIXER SHAFT TO SHIFT DOWNWARD, WHICH CAUSED THE PACKING  AROUND THE SHAFT OPENING.  CONTACT WITH JENSEN REVALS THIS IS A KNOWN DEFECT.  A "FIX" WAS SENT OUT IN THE 1990'S WHICH REQUIRES THE INSTALLATION OF A RETAINER WASHER.  THIS "FIX" IS BEING INSTALLED ON ALL MODEL 650 VA MIXERS THOUGHOUR OUR SYSTEM WHICH DID NO ALREDY HAVE THEM.

column241: EVELYN WOOTTEN, DOT COMPLIANCE SUPERVISOR WESTERN AREA
column245: THE CRACK WAS 2.75" LONG.  THE CRACK WAS NOT IN THE PIPE BODY.  THE CRACK DID RUN LENGTHWISE BUT IT WAS IN THE JOINT WHERE THEY HAD WELDED TWO HALF SOLES TOGETHER.  THE REASON THE CRACK DEVELOPED WAS POOR WELDING PRACTICES.  THEY DID NOT BEVEL THE HALF SOLES, THEY WERE JUST BUTTED UP AND A WELD PUT ON TOP OF THE SEAM.  THE RELEASE WAS ACTUALLY IN A CORROSION PIT UNDER THE HALF SOLES THAT FOUND ITS WAY OUT THROUGH THE CRACK.  THE CRACK WAS NOT IN THE LONG SEAM OF THE PIPE.  THE CRACK FORMED DUE TO POOR WELDING PRACTICE AND DID NOT ACTUALLY PROPAGATE, IT JUST CRACKED.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON JULY 5, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 1830 HOURS AN EMPLOYEE NOTICED A PETROLEUM PRODUCT ODOR COMING FROM THE AREA OF TANK 353.  TANK 353 IS A 322,500 BARREL, 48 FOOT TALL BY 220 FOOT DIAMETER FIXED ROOF JET FUEL TANK THAT WAS LAST INTERNALLY INSPECTED IN JANUARY OF 2003. UPON INVESTIGATION OF THE AREA AROUND TANK 353 ON JULY 5, 2004, THE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED THE SOURCE OF THE ODOR WAS FROM JET FUEL SEEPING FROM BENEATH THE TANK FLOOR AND THE RING WALL OF TANK 353, AND WAS ACCUMULATING IN THE TANK DIKE. ON JULY 2, 2004, STATION GAUGES INDICATED 7 INCHES OF RAINFALL WITHIN A 24-HOUR PERIOD IN GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA. DURING THE HEAVIEST RAINFALL, THE DIKE OUTFALL VALVE FOR TANK DIKE 353 COULD NOT BE OPENED TO DISCHARGE WATER FROM THE TANK DIKE SINCE THE OUTFALL POINT IS A LOCAL CREEK, AND CREEK LEVELS WERE AT FLOOD STAGE AND WERE ABOVE THE DIKE DISCHARGE POINT. WHEN THE CREEK LEVELS SUBSIDED TO ALLOW FOR THE DISCHARGE, THE WATER INSIDE THE TANK DIKE WAS DISCHARGED. HOWEVER, BEFORE THE WATER COULD BE DISCHARGED, APPROXIMATELY 15 INCHES OF WATER ACCUMULATED INSIDE THE TANK DIKE AND AROUND TANK 353, WHICH WAS EMPTY. THE EMPTY TANK RECEIVED A 103,049 BARREL BATCH OF JET FUEL ON JULY 4, 2004, AT 20:10 HOURS.  THE TANK FLOOR OF THE EMPTY JET FUEL TANK FLOATED ENOUGH DUE TO THE WATER LEVELS TO CAUSE A 3 INCHES CRACK IN THE TANK FLOOR WHERE THE VERTICAL SUPPORT BRACKET FOR THE VORTEX BREAKER IS WELDED TO THE FLOOR AROUND THE SINGLE SUCTION AND FILL LINE ON THE BOTTOM OF THE TANK. THE TANK WAS IMMEDIATELY TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR INSPECTION, AND REPAIRS. THE PETROLEUM IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED, AND SOIL TESTING HAS INDICATED THAT IMPACTED SOIL IN THE DIKE AREA HAS BEEN REMOVED.      PART C ORIGIN OF THE ACCIDENT - 5. MAXIMUM OPERATING PRESSURE A. AND B: TANK 353 IS AN ATMOSPHERIC STORAGE TANK AND NOT A PRESSURE CONTAINING VESSEL.  THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE FOR PART C.5.A. WAS BASED ON HEAD PRESSURE OF PRODUCT IN THE TANK AT TIME OF ACCIDENT, AS WELL AS THE MOP FOR PART C.5.B WAS BASED ON A FULL TANK.

column238: BARGE LOADING ARM DID NOT DRAIN PROPERLY.
column245: DOCK PERSONNEL HAD JUST COMPLETED A BARGE UNLOADING AT DOCK #1.  WHEN THE LOADING ARM WAS DISCONNECTED FROM THE BARGE MANIFOLD IT APPEARS THAT A QUANITY OF CRUDE OIL WAS STILL IN THE ARM ASSEMBLY CAUSING THE ARM TO DIP AND FALL ON TO THE DECK OF THE BARGE AND RELEASE TRAPPED CRUDE OIL ON TO THE DECK OF THE BARGE. THE OIL RAN OFF THE DECK OF THE BARGE AND IN TO THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER.   BARGE CREW AND SHELL OPERATOR DEPLOYED BOOM TO CONTAIN RELESED CRUDE.  THE RELEASED CRUDE WAS DISPERSED BY RIVER CURRENTS REDUCING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BOOMING ACTIONS.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON SUNDAY, JULY 11, 2004 PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED COMING FROM A DRAIN PIPE WHICH GOES INTO THE QUINNIPIAC RIVER IN NEW HAVEN, CONNECTICUT.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ENACTED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND STRIPPING SECTIONS OF PIPELINE THE RELEASE LOCATION WAS DISCOVERED ON MONDAY, JULY 12, 2004.  A TEMPORARY REPAIR SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON TUESDAY, JULY 13, 2004.  A PERMANENT REPAIR WILL BE MADE LATER THIS MONTH BY CUTTING OUT THIS SECTION OF PIPE AND REPLACING IT WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED TO BE EXTERNAL CORROSION CAUSED BY DISCARDED CONSTRUCTION MATERIAL LEFT IN THE DITCH AT THE TIME OF CONSTRUCTION.  ALL RECOVERY AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE CONNECTICUT DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, U.S. COAST GUARD, AND THE NEW HAVEN FIRE DEPARTMENT.

column245: EXXONMOBIL HAMMOND TERMINAL WAS NOTIFIED AT 1557 HRS ON 6/15/04 THAT A ROUTINE THIRD PARTY FLYOVER SITED A SHEEN ON SITTING RAINWATER IN A COMMON PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY(ROW).  THE ROW IS OCCUPIED BY EXXONMOBIL HAMMOND TERMINAL PIPELINES AND MULTIPLE OTHER OPERATOR PIPELINES.  EXXONMOBIL HAMMOND TERMINAL PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO SCENE, ALONG WITH SEVERAL OTHER OPERATORS.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE SHEEN WAS GASOLINE, BUT IT WAS UNKNOWN WHICH OPERATOR'S PIPELINE WAS THE CAUSE. THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE OF FURTHER SPILLAGE, NO IMPACTS TO PUBLIC SAFETY, AND THE AREA WAS SECURED.  EXCAVATION OF THE ROW WAS UNDERTAKEN.  EXXONMOBIL CONTACTED AND MADE REPORT TO NRC ON 6/16/04, ATTRIBUTING SHEEN TO 'UNKNOWN' OPERATOR.  EXXONMOBIL SPOKE WITH DAVID BARRETT, CENTRAL REGION OPS ON 6/17/04.  ON 6/18/04, IT WAS DETERMINED THE PRODUCT CAME FROM EXXONMOBIL HAMMOND TERMINAL'S 12" GASOLINE PIPELINE TO NORCO BUCKEYE LAKE GEORGE STATION #1, WHEN A PINHOLE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED ON THE LINE.  ON THAT SAME DATE, EXXONMOBIL ATTEMPTED TO REPORT TO NRC, BUT NRC ADVISED EITHER A NEW REPORT MUST BE FILED OR EXXONMOBIL COULD COMMUNICATE DIRECTLY TO DOT.  EXXONMOBIL ADVISED CARL GRIFFIS, OPS CENTRAL REGION THAT THE LEAK WAS FROM ITS PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUTDOWN SINCE EXXONMOBIL RECEIVED NOTIFICAITON OF THE SHEEN, AND WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL REPAIR PLANS ARE COMPLETED.

column238: 1/4" PLUG ON PUMP CAUSING VIBRATED LOOSE END WAS FORCED OUT OF THE CASING BY PUMP/PRODUCT PRESSURE.
column245: TIOGA INITIATED A PIPELINE DELIVERY TO THE GREATER PITTSBURGH INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT AT APPROXIMATELY 11:30 AM ON FRIDAY, JULY 9TH.  TIOGA PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE DURING THE STARTUP PHASE OF THE OPERATION TO VERIFY THAT THERE WERE NO PROBLEMS.  TIOGA PERSONNEL WITNESSED THE STARTUP OF THE PUMP INVOLVED IN THE INCIDENT AND OBSERVED NO LEAKS OR OTHER PROBLEMS.  A THIRD PARTY NOTIFIED TIOGA PERSONNEL OF THE INCIDENT AROUND 7:00 AM ON SATURDAY JULY 10TH.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS OBVIOUS - 1/4" THREADED PLUG HAD BLOWN OUT OF THE TOP OF THE PUMP CASING.  AN INSPECTION OF THE SURROUNDING PIPING REVEALED A SCRATCH MARK ON THE UNDERSIDE OF AN OVERHEAD BYPASS VALVE.  THIS SCRATCH/INDENTATION APPEARS TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY THE PLUG WHEN IT WAS FORCED BY PRESSURE FROM THE PUMP CASING.  THE PLUG WAS NEVER FOUND.  THE THREADS ON THE PUMP CASING WERE INSPECTED, AND APPEARED TO BE IN SATISFACTORY CONDITION.  IT IS OUR BELIEF THAT THE PLUB VIBRATED LOOSE OVER TIME AND WAS FINALLY EXPELLED, RESULTING IN A PRODUCT LEAK OUT THE THREADED HOLE IN THE PUMP CASING.

column245: ON THURSDAY, JULY 22, 2004 A BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY MAINTENANCE CREW WAS EXCAVATING AROUND A MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE TO PERFORM MAINTENANCE WORK.  AT 0835 THE BACKHOE OPERATOR STRUCK A 2¿ TAP VALVE THAT WAS LOCATED ON THE TOP SIDE OF THE 702 PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE BUCKEYE MAINTENANCE CREW NOTIFIED THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR AND THE BUCKEYE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.     THE 2¿ TAP CONNECTION WAS REPAIRED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO OPERATION AROUND 1650 HOURS.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES.

column245: ON MONDAY, AUGUST 2, 2004 A CONTRACTOR WORKING FOR BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY WAS REMOVING CONCRETE ON THE 702 PIPELINE SYSTEM.  DURING THE PROCESS OF REMOVING THE CONCRETE AROUND THE 702 PIPELINE THE 701 PIPELINE WAS STRUCK.  BOTH THE 702 AND 701 PIPELINES WERE ENCASED IN ONE CONCRETE POUR AT THIS LOCATION.  THE BUCKEYE INSPECTOR AT THE WORK SITE NOTIFIED THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR AND THE BUCKEYE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE 701 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.     A TEMPORARY SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN OPERATION AROUND 1630 HOURS AT A REDUCED PRESSURE.  A PERMANENT REPAIR WILL BE MADE LATER THIS MONTH BY CUTTING OUT THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE AND REPLACING IT WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE PERMANENT REPAIR HAS BEEN MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED PIPE WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES.     I PLACED "0" IN THE "PUNCTURE, DIAMETER (INCHES)" FIELD SINCE THE FIELD WOULD NOT ACCEPT 0.5 OR 1/2, WAS NOT SURE WHAT ELSE TO TRY FOR 1/2".

column245: THE 20 INCH WINK TO EL PASO PIPELINE LEAKED 10.1 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL DUE TO A PINHOLE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND ISOLATED FOR APPROX. 6 HOURS. THE LEAK WAS REPAIRED. A THIRD PARTY DETECTED THE LEAK, IT WAS VERIFIED BY KM PERSONNEL. REMIDIATION ON THE SOIL HAS BEGUN, APPROX. 14 CUBIC FEET OF EARTH WILL BE REMIDIATED. THE LEAK OCCURED AT 1500 HOURS, BROUGHT BACK INTO SERVICE AT 2100 HOURS THAT SAME DAY.

column245: THIS IS AN INTRASTATE PIPELINE. LEAK WAS NOT ORIGINALLY THOUGHT TO BE TELEPHONICALLY REPORTABLE TO THE NRC. FINAL TOTALS FOR RESPONSE AND CLEANUP WERE HIGHER THAN ORIGINALLY ESTIMATED.    A HORIZONTAL WELD FAILED ON A STOPPLE FITTING. PINHOLE LEAK OCCURRED. STOPPLE FITTING REPLACED WITH LINE PIPE.      2/15/2010: CHANGED RECOVERED AMOUNT FROM 0 BARRELS TO 5 BARRELS.

column245: ON MONDAY, JULY 26, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 0700 HOURS, A CONTRACT EMPLOYEE IDENTIFIED PETROLEUM PRODUCT IN AN EXCAVATION HOLE THAT WAS DUG TO REMOVE THE TANK SHELL VALVE FOR THE INSTALLATION OF BLINDS TO CONDUCT REPAIRS ON TANK 353 AT THE GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA TANK FARM.  ON FRIDAY, JULY 23, 2004, SHELL VALVE BOLTS WERE BEING LOOSENED, AT WHICH TIME PRODUCT STARTED TO SEEP FROM THE FLANGE.  THE FLANGES WERE TIGHTENED BACK UNTIL CONFIRMATION OF THE PRODUCT SOURCE COULD BE CONFIRMED.   THE REMOVAL OF THE VALVE WAS POSTPONED UNTIL MONDAY, JULY 26, 2004.  OVER THE WEEKEND, THE TANK SHELL VALVE WAS OBSERVED PERIODICALLY FOR LEAKAGE THROUGH 12:00 HOURS ON SATURDAY, JULY 24, 2004. THERE WERE NO VISIBLE SIGN OF LEAKAGE.  ON MONDAY, JULY 26, 2004, AT 0700 AN EMPLOYEE IDENTIFIED PETROLEUM PRODUCT IN THE EXCAVATION HOLE. THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT WAS IDENTIFIED AS LEAKAGE FROM THE FLANGE.  THE ISSUE WAS RESOLVED, AND THE VALVE WAS REMOVED FOR THE INSTALLATION OF THE BLINDS. THE IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED FOR PROPER MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL.

REMEDIATION OF IMPACTED SOIL WAS CONDUCTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE REGULATIONS.

column245: ETHYLENE WAS DETECTED TO BE LEAKING FROM A PIG TRAP AT THE CHOCOLATE BAYOU ETHYLENE SKID LOCATED AT THE EQUISTAR CHEMICALS, LP.  CHOCOLATE BAYOU CHEMICAL COMPLEX AT 0239 HRS ON 14 JUL 2004.  THE PIG TRAP WAS ISOLATED AND DEINVENTORIED BY EQUISTAR PIPELINE OPERATIONS PERSONNEL BY 0400 HRS ON 14 JUL 2004.  APPROXIMATELY 30.8 BBL OF ETHYLENE WAS RELEASED.  A PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATED O-RING FAILURE CAUSED THE INCIDENT.  A FORMAL INVESTIGATION TEAM HAS BEEN FORMED AND IS WORKING ON IDENTIFYING THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT.

column245: TESORO'S AERIAL PATROL PILOT SPOTTED AND REPORTED THE LEAK, LOCATED IN A MARSHY ENVIRONMENT.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND EXCAVATION WAS BEGUN AT THE SITE.  ABOUT 200 FT OF PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED; THIS SEGMENT CONTAINED NUMEROUS SLEEVES AND WAS LYING ON TOP OF A COAL SEAM.  UPON INITIAL EXAMINATION, THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.  IN ORDER TO LOCATE THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK, THE PIPELINE WAS STARTED UP AT 80% OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  AFTER THE LEAK WAS PINPOINTED, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN, AND THE ENTIRE 200 FOOT SECTION (CONTAINING THE SLEEVES) WAS REPLACED.  THE CUTOT SECTION HAS BEEN SENT TO A METALLURGICAL LAB FOR TESTING.  THE PIPELINE CONTINUES TO OPERATE AT 80% OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT UNTIL AFTER PRELIMINARY RESULTS FROM THE TOOL RUN (EXPLAINED BELOW) HAVE BEEN RECEIVED AND/OR IMMEDIATE REPAIRS HAVE BEEN MADE.  TESORO WAS IN THE PROCESS OF CONDUCTING AN IN-LINE INSPECTION OF THIS PIPE SEGMENT PER ITS INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. AN IN-LINE INSPECTION GEOMETRY TOOL WAS RUN THE WEEK OF JUNE 1, 2004.  AND, A METAL LOSS TOOL WAS RUN THE WEEK OF JUNE 21, 2004 (AFTER THE LEAK WAS REPAIRED).

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON MONDAY, JUNE 28, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 2:00PM, THERE WAS A MAJOR RELEASE OF SOUR CO2 FROM THE BRAVO PIPELINE SYSTEMS, ANTON PIPELINE.  THE INCIDENT TOOK PLACE AT THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF FROM THE ANTON PIPELINE.  THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF IS A STUB OUT ON THE MAINLINE WHICH UNTIL  RECENTLY CONSISTED OF A RISER TAKING IT ABOVE GROUND AND A MANUAL BLOCK VALVE WHICH WAS BLIND FLANGED ON THE DOWN STREAM SIDE.  PRESENTLY THERE IS A PROJECT UNDERWAY, WHICH WILL CREATE A NEW CO2 FLOOD IN THE LEVELLAND AREA.   THE PROJECT IS DESIGNATED AS THE LEVELLAND UNIT PHASE I CO2 PROJECT.  AS PART OF THIS PROJECT, THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF HAS BECOME THE SITE OF CO2 DELIVERY FROM THE ANTON PIPELINE TO THE LEVELLAND UNIT PHASE I CO2 PROJECT.  THE FLOOD PROJECT INCLUDES THE INSTALLATION OF A METER RUN AT THE LEVELLAND DELIVERY SITE. SOMETIME PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, THE PROJECT TEAM HAD TEMPORARILY INSTALLED A PIPING SPOOL APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET IN LENGTH TYING THE LEVELLAND TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE TO THE METER RUN.  THE INSTALLATION WAS TEMPORARY AND THE FLANGE BOLT NUTS WERE ONLY STARTED ON THE STUDS.  TO ALLOW THIS TEMPORARY INSTALLATION, IT WAS NECESSARY THAT THE BLIND FLANGE BE REMOVED FROM THE TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE.  DURING THE DESIGN PHASE OF THE PROJECT, IT WAS DECIDED THAT THE TAKE-OFF BLOCK VALVE WOULD BE AUTOMATED AND THAT AN ADDITIONAL BLOCK WOULD NOT BE INSTALLED. IN ORDER TO AUTOMATE THIS BLOCK VALVE, A MOTORIZED CONTROLLER HAD TO BE INSTALLED ON THE BLOCK VALVE, ELECTRICAL POWER HAD TO BE MADE AVAILABLE AT THE VALVE, AND CONTROL WIRING AND A SATELLITE LINK  HAD TO BE INSTALLED.  SOMETIME PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT A SUNLAND RMT AUTOMATION TECHNICIAN HAD RAN WIRING FROM THE ELECTRICAL POWER SOURCE TO A BREAKER BOX AT THE VALVE LOCATION AND THEN FROM THE BREAKER BOX TO THE VALVE.  PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, A BRAVO PIPELINE OPERATOR RAN CONDUIT AND CONTROL WIRING FROM THE METERING BUILDING TO THE VALVE.  THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT THE BRAVO PIPELINE OPERATOR WENT TO THE LOCATION TO CONNECT THE CONTROL WIRING TO THE VALVE AND TO MAKE THE VALVE CONTROL FUNCTIONAL.  ONCE THE CONTROL WIRING WAS CONNECTED, IN ORDER TO CHECK VALVE ROTATION, THE PIPELINE OPERATOR TURNED ON THE POWER TO THE BLOCK VALVE AND PUSHED THE BUTTON TO OPEN THE VALVE.  THE VALVE PARTIALLY OPENED AND 9.5 MILLION CUBIC FEET OF CO2 WAS RELEASED AND VENTED.  PRESSURE ON THE ANTON CO2 PIPELINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 1800 PSIG.  THE PIPELINE OPERATOR PUSHED THE STOP BUTTON ON THE VALVE AND EVACUATED.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED AND PROPER NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  THE ANTON CO2 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  PUBLIC ROADS WERE BLOCKED FOR APPROXIMATELY AN HOUR.  THERE IS NO EVIDENCE INDICATING THE PUBLIC WAS EVER PLACED IN DANGER.  LAW ENFORCEMENT REOPENED THE ROADS AT APPROXIMATELY 3:00PM.  PIPELINE PRESSURE DROPPED TO APPROXIMATELY 300 PSIG BY 5:30 PM AND THE TAKE-OFF VALVE WAS CLOSED.

column238: VACUUM BREAKER ON TANK ROOF
column245: A VACUUM BREAKER HAD RECENTLY BEEN INSTALLED ON THE EXTERNAL FLOATING ROOF TANK DURING AN OUT OF SERVICE INSPECTION.  THE DESIGN OF THE RISER ON THE VACUUM BREAKER WAS NOT SUFFICIENT TO FULLY ACCOUNT FOR STATIC FLUID LEVELS WHEN THE ROOF BECAME LOADED WITH STORM WATER.  ALL OF THE OIL WAS RELEASED ONTO THE ROOF OF THE TANK AND WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE CONFINES OF THE TANK SHELL.  ALL OF THE OIL WAS RECOVERED.  THE RISER ON THE VACUUM BREAKER WAS EXTENDED AND THE TANK WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON AUGUST 5, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 1000 HOURS, JET TURBINE FUEL WAS OBSERVED LEAKING FROM A SUMP AT TUCUMCARI PUMP STATION BY COMPANY PERSONNEL.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO MANAGEMENT, PIPELINE CONTROL, AND PIPELINE SAFETY, THEN THE NRC WAS CALLED AT 11:23 HOURS.  FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND CLEAN UP OF CONTAMINATED SOIL AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN IMMEDIATELY.  THERE ARE NO LONG TERM ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT ISSUES TO BE CONSIDERED.  UPON INVESTIGATION, IT WAS LEARNED THAT THE THERMAL RELIEF VALVE FAILED, AND IN TURN, THE HIGH LEVEL ALARM ON THE SUMP ALSO FAILED LEADING TO AN OVERFLOW.  AFTER REVIEW BY ENGINEERING, THE THERMAL RELIEF VALVE WAS REMOVED FROM THE SYSTEM PIPING AND A NEW TYPE SUMP LEVEL ALARM WAS INSTALLED AND TESTED.  THE SYSTEM HAS RUN SATISFACTORILY TO DATE WITH NO PROBLEMS.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON OCT. 13, 2004 AT APPROX. 2030 HOURS A LEAK WAS VERIFIED ON THE CRC PIPELINE MAINLINE BLOCK 17. THE AREA WAS SECURED AND MONITORED ALL NIGHT, PERSONNEL MONITORED FOR H2S IN THE SURRONDING AREA WITH MULTIGAS DETECTORS AND FOUND NO TRACE OF H2S. MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES 18 AND 15 WERE CLOSED AND 33.87 MILES OF MAINLINE WAS ISOLATED AND DEPRESSURED. WHEN THE LINE PRESSURE WAS DOWN TO 300 PSI USING THE MULTIGAS DETECTOR 3 PPM OF H2S WAS MONITORED. AT 1100 HOURS ON OCT. 14 ,2004 THE LINE WAS DEPRESSURED AND MADE SAFE FOR MAINTENANCE. MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE 17 WAS EXCAVATED (MADE EMERGENCY ONE CALL TO DIGGTESS) AND NIPPLE ON THE BODY BLEED BROKE. REPAIRED NIPPLE AND PUT LINE BACK IN SERVICE AT APPROX. 1830 HOURS.

column245: CONTRACT METER PROVER HAD ATTACHED HIS HOSES TO COMPANY'S METER PROVER CONNECTIONS. CONTRACTOR MADE NECESSARY ALIGNMENTS TO BEGIN THE PROVING PROCESS. AT THIS POINT, ONE OF THE HOSE CONNECTIONS FAILED AND THE HOSE BECAME DETACHED FROM THE METER PROVER CONNECTION. CRUDE OIL ESCAPED FROM THE HOSE AND SPILLED ONTO THE GROUND. THE CONTRACTOR ATTEMPTED TO ADJUST THE VALVE ALIGNMENTS TO BLOCK THE SOURCE OF THE SPILL. THE VAPORS FROM THE SPILL IGNITED AND FLASHED. A FIRE ENSUED, WHICH INVOLVED THE REAR OF THE PROVER TRAILER AND THE PROVER CONNECTIONS ON THE METER SKID. THE CONTRACTOR ESCAPED FROM THE FIRE AND SUFFERED A 1ST DEGREE BURN TO HIS LEFT CHEEK. THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED BY THE COMPANY FIRE BRIGADE AND THE NEDERLAND AND PORT NECHES FIRE DEPARTMENTS.

column245: OPERATOR'S CONTRACTOR EXCAVATING LINE FOR 5100' PIPE REPLACEMENT FOLLOWING AN ILI (RUN IN 2003). CONTARATOR HAD EXPOSED SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET OF LINE. CONTRACTOR INADVERTANTLY GOUGED TOP OF LINE CREATING A SMALL (.250") HOLE. OPERATOR PERSONNEL WERE ON HAND AND IMMEDIATELY CALLED CONTROL CENTER TO SHUT DOWN LINE. DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES WERE LEFT OPEN AS THE THEY WERE DOWN GRADIENT. PUMP STATION ALIGNMENT WAS CHANGED SO THAT PRODUCT COULD DRAIN BACK INTO TANKAGE. A TEMPORARY REPAIR CLAMP WAS INSTALLED. THE DAMAGED SECTION OF LINE IS TO BE TIED IN WEEK OF NOVEMBER 1, 2004.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATOR
column245: DURING A NORMAL OPERATION AT WOOD RIVER STATION A TANK WAS BEING DRAINED OF DIESEL TO FACILITATE A NORMAL CHANGE OF PRODUCT. THE TANK WAS DRAINED USING THE MAINLINE BOOSTER PUMP UNTIL LOSS OF SUCTION WHICH CAUSED THE INTRODUCTION OF AIR INTO THE 150# ANSI CLASS HEADER WITHIN WOOD RIVER STATION.  THIS PORTION OF STATION PIPING WAS IDLE OVERNIGHT.  THE NEXT MORNING UPON START UP AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION IGNITION EVENT OCCURRED CAUSING THREE GASKETS TO FAIL SIMULTANEOUSLY, RELEASING SIX BARRELS OF GASOLINE ONTO THE WOOD RIVER STATION PROPERTY.  MAPL PERFORMED A TAPROOT @ INCIDENT INVESTIGATION UTILITIZING MAPL PERSONNEL AND A THIRD PARTY CONSULTANT.  THE INSPECTION RESULTS FORM THE THIRD PARTY CONSULTANT STATES THAT AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION OCCURRED CAUSING THE DIESEL AND AIR MIXTURE WITHIN THE LINE TO IGNITE AND SUBSEQUENTLY CAUSING THE PRESSURE WITHIN THE HEADER TO INCREASE RAPIDLY UNTIL THE GASKETS FAILED AND THE PRESSURE WAS ALLEVIATED.  WITH INPUT FROM THE GASKET MANUFACTURER THE INVESTIGATION TEAM ESTIMATED THAT THE PRESSURE COULD HAVE RISEN TO 1,200 PSI PRIOR TO THE GASKETS FAILING THUS ALLEVIATING THE PRESSURE.  THIS EVENT HAPPENED EVEN THOUGH WOOD RIVER HAD A PROPERLY SIZED RELIEF VALVE IN PLACE AND OPERATIONAL.  IN RESPONSE TO THE RELEASE MAPL CONTROLLED AND CLEANED UP THE RELEASED PRODUCT.  MAPL ALSO CONDUCTED AN INSPECTION OF THE HEADER THAT RESULTED IN A TOTAL OF SIX GASKETS BEING REPLACED.  A ONE HOUR, 100% MOP (275PSI) PROOF TEST WAS THEN CONDUCTED ON THE HEADER PRIOR TO RECOMMISSIONING.  THE PRELIMINARY INDICATIONS FROM THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION PROMPTED MAPL TO ISSUE A COMPANY WIDE OPERATIONAL SAFETY ALERT ON OCTOBER 5, 2004 TO ENSURE THAT THIS TYPE OF EVENT DOES NOT OCCUR IN THE FUTURE.  MAPL HAS IMPLEMENTED NEW PROCEDURES THAT DO NOT ALLOW PULLING TANKS DOWN TO LOSS OF SUCTION, POSSIBLY INTRODUCING AIR INTO STATION PIPING WITHOUT A PRIOR APPROVED PLAN TO REMOVE THE AIR BEFORE START UP.  THE ALERT ALSO REQUIRES THAT USE OF MAPL COMMISSIONING, DECOMMISSIONING AND RECOMMISSIONING (CDR) PROCESS FOR ALL MAINTENANCE OR OPERATIONS THAT MAY INTRODUCE AIR INTO THE SYSTEM.  THESE NEW PROCEDURES ENSURE THE ELIMINATION OF AIR IN STATION PIPING TO AVOID RAPID COMPRESSION UPON START UP.      4/20/2010 UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  HCA INFORMATION UPDATED RELEASE WAS NOT ORIGINALLY IDENTIFIED AS BEING IN AN HCA WHEN, IN FACT, IT OCCURRED IN A POPULATED AREA.  ALSO THE NARRATIVE HAS BEEN UPDATED A BIT TO ALLEVIATE ANY CONFUSTION.  THE CONFUSION MAY ARISE AS A RESULT OF THE NARRATIVE  DISCUSSING THE IGNITION OF THE PRODUCT WHEN THE CHECK BOX FOR "PRODUCT IGNITED" IS NOT CHECKED.  THE INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT AN ADIBATIC COMPRESSION OCCURRED CAUSING THE PRESSURE WITHIN THE HEADER TO INCREASE RAPIDLY UNTIL THE GASKET FAILED AND THE PRESSURE ALLEVIATED.  THE INVESTIGATION REPORT DID SAY THAT THE ADIABATIC COMPRESSION CAUSED THE DIESEL AND AIR MIXTURE WITHIN THE LINE TO IGNITE.  HOWEVER, WITH AN ADIABATIC COMPRESSION, THERE IS NO TRANSFER OF HEAT.  THE DOT/PHMSA DEFINITION OF IGNITE IS THAT THE COMMODITY CAUGHT FIRE.  THERE WAS NOT A FIRE AND THERE WAS NO TRANSFER OF HEAT AS A RESULT OF THIS EVENT.  IT WAS ALSO CONSIDERED WHETHER THIS FIT THE DEFINITION OF AN EXPLOSION, AND THE DETERMINATION WAS THAT THIS DID NOT MEET THAT DEFINITION EITHER.  EXPLODE MEANS THE RELEASE OF TRANSPORTED COMMODITY RESULTED IN A SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY, WHETHER ACCOMPANIED BY A FIRE INVOLVING THE RELEASED COMMODITY OR NOT.  THE RELEASE OF THE TRANSPORTED PRODUCT DID NOT RESULT IN AN SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY.  RATHER THE SUDDEN AND VIOLENT RELEASE OF ENERGY RESULTED IN THE RELEASE OF A TRANSPORTED PRODUCT.

column245: DURING A ROUTINE MONTHLY TANK INSPECTION, A VERY SMALL AREA OF OILY SOIL WAS NOTICED AT THE BASE OF TANK 3357.  UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THERE APPEARED TO BE A LEAK IN THE FLOOR OF THE TANK. IT HAS BEEN TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND LOCKED OUT. CONTRACTORS HAVE BEEN SCHEDULED TO GAS-FREE AND CLEAN THE TANK. ONCE THIS HAS BEEN COMPLETED, REPAIR ASSESSMENTS WILL BE MADE.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: DURING POST-STORM IMPACT FROM HURRICANE IVAN VISIBLE OIL SHEENS WERE OBSERVED AND REPORTED NEAR BP'S MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE IN THE VICINITY OF MAIN PASS BLOCK 69.  THE OIL SHEENS REPORTED ON 10-1-04 WERE FINGERPRINTED AND LATER CONFIRMED AS PRODUCT TRANSPORTED IN SHELL'S 18" PIPELINE.  DURING BP'S POST-STORM ASSESSMENTS FOR THE MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE IT WAS ALSO CONFIRMED THAT REQUIRED SEPARATION WAS LOST BETWEEN THE MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE AND SHELL'S 18" PIPELINE IN THE VICINITY OF MAIN PASS BLOCK 69.  IT WAS DURING THE OPERATION OF SEPARATING THESE TWO PIPELINES THAT THE RELEASE FROM THE MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE OCCURRED. THE 10-26-04 LEAK WAS CONFIRMED DURING A LIFTING OF SHELL'S EQUILON 18" PIPELINE WHICH WAS WAS LOCATED ABOVE AND PHYSICALLY CONTACTING THE MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE.  JUST PRIOR TO THE LIFTING OF THE SHELL PIPELINE, DIVERS HAD REMOVED THE SHELL PIPELINE CONCRETE COATING WITH WATERBLASTING EQUIPMENT.  THE BARE PORTION OF THE LOWER MAIN PASS OIL GATHERING PIPELINE WAS THEN EXAMINED AND IDENTIFIED AS HAVING SMALL PINHOLES IN THE VICINITY OF THE CONTACT POINT BETWEEN THE TWO PIPELINES, THUS ALLOWING CRUDE OIL TO BE RELEASED TO RECEIVING WATERS.  DURING THIS OPERATION RECOVERY EQUIPMENT WAS IN PLACE AND COLLECTING ALL CRUDE OIL BEING RELEASED FROM THE PIPELINE.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 28, 2004, AT APPROXIMATELY 11:54 HOURS AN EXPLORER PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN WAS TO BEGIN A DELIVERY FROM EXPLORER PIPELINE¿S GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA, FACILITY TO ITS WEST TULSA, OKLAHOMA, METER STATION.  AT 11:51:59 THE EXPLORER PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN TOOK MAINLINE UNIT 2 OFF AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, WHILE MAINLINE UNIT 3 WAS STILL OPERATING AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION.  A  100 PSI MAINLINE UNIT SUCTION SET POINT WAS THEN ESTABLISHED AT THE OKMULGEE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, WHICH IS THE NEXT DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION FROM THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, AT 11:53:18, TO SLOW THE LINE RATE DOWN FOR THE DELIVERY FROM GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA, TO THE WEST TULSA, OKLAHOMA METER STATION.  WHEN FLOW WAS ESTABLISHED AT THE WEST TULSA, OKLAHOMA, METER STATION, THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN SENT A COMMAND TO START MAINLINE UNIT 1 AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION AT 11:54:33, BUT MAINLINE UNIT 1 FAILED TO START.  THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN THEN INITIATED A COMMAND TO START MAINLINE UNIT 2 AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION AT 11:54:54.  AS THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN WAS MONITORING THE MAINLINE UNIT 2 START AT THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION, A LOW SUCTION PRESSURE ALARMED THE SCADA AT 11:56:14, THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN NOTICED A SUDDEN DROP IN PRESSURE, THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION¿S MAINLINE UNIT 3 WENT DOWN AT 11:56:19 AND THE STATIONS MAINLINE UNIT 2 WENT DOWN 11:56:29.  THE CONTROL CENTER TECHNICIAN REVIEWED THE INFORMATION, INITIATED THE ABNORMAL OPERATING PROCEDURES, THEN THE EMERGENCY OPERATING PROCEDURES, AND INITIATED THE SHUT DOWN OF THE ENTIRE 28 INCH PIPELINE SYSTEM AT 11:57:36. THE REMOTELY OPERATED STATION PIPELINE BLOCK VALVES WERE THEN INITIATED TO BE SHUT.  THE OKMULGEE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION REMOTELY OPERATED STATION BLOCK VALVE WAS INITIATED TO SHUT AT 12:01:28, AND INDICATED SHUT BY SCADA AT 12:01:51.  THE HOLDENVILLE, OKLAHOMA, PUMP STATION REMOTELY OPERATED STATION PIPELINE BLOCK VALVE WAS INITIATED TO SHUT AT 12:05:35, AND INDICATED SHUT BY SCADA AT 12:05:54. LOCAL CREWS WERE CONTACTED TO CHECK THE AREA, AS WELL AS A HELICOPTER SURVEY CREW WAS REQUESTED. LOCAL CREWS WERE ADDITIONALLY DISPATCHED TO SHUT MANUAL DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES.  THE LEAK LOCATION WAS LOCATED AT 14:03, AND RECOVERY OPERATIONS BEGAN WITH THE DISPATCHING OF VACUUM TRUCKS AND HEAVY EQUIPMENT.     THE LEAK DURATION (INITIAL LEAK INDICATION UNTIL PRODUCT CEASED DRAINING FROM THE PIPELINE) OF 30 MINUTES, OR 0.50 HOURS, WAS CALCULATED BASED ON SCADA INFORMATION, AND HYDRAULIC MODELING.    A 26 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND TRANSPORTED TO CC TECHNOLOGIES IN DUBLIN, OHIO FOR A FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE ANALYSIS WAS PERFORMED OCTOBER 11, 2004, THROUGH OCTOBER 14, 2004, IN THE PRESENCE OF A DOT OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY REPRESENTATIVE, AND EXPLORER PIPELINE REPRESENTATIVES.  A FINAL REPORT IS EXPECTED FROM CC TECHNOLOGIES BY EARLY DECEMBER, 2004. THEREFORE, PART H ¿ APPARENT CAUSE, BOX H8 ¿ UNKNOWN STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN MARKED, UNTIL SUCH TIME AS THE FINAL REPORT CAN BE COMPLETED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES.  ONCE THE FINAL REPORT IS COMPLETED, A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE FILED FOR SECTION H ¿ APPARENT CAUSE.      PART C.3.A. THE CURRENT REPORTED RUPTURE LENGTH IN INCHES IS THE LENGTH OF THE ENTIRE TEAR AFTER THE RUPTURE.     PART D.2. THE WALL THICKNESS IS .312.  ON-LINE SYSTEM WILL NOT ACCEPT THE FULL WALL THICKNESS OF .312.     PART H.1.B. THE MP 459 RELEASE HAS BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO NEAR-NEUTRAL PH SCC IN THE BOTTOM SIDE DENT THAT WAS ESTIMATED BY A CALIPER ILI SURVEY TO BE LESS THAN 1% OF THE PIPE DIAMETER.

column245: AT 1350 10/07/04 RUNNING HORSE PIPELINE (RHP) RECEIVED NOTIFICATION OF A LINE HIT ON NAPI (NAVAJO AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS INDUSTRY).  TRACTOR OPERATOR FOR NAPI WAS PLOWING FIELD AND HIT PIPELINE.  COMMAND TO SCADA SYSTEM TO SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE WAS GIVEN AT 1350.  BLOCK VALVE AT BISTI STATION CLOSED AT 1350 ON LOW SUCTION.  RHP PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT LEAK SITE 1400.  SPILL CONTAINMENT COMMENCED.  NOTIFICATION TO NRC WAS MADE AT 1525, NOTIFICATION TO NAVAJO EPA MADE AT 1531 AND NEW MEXICO OIL CONSERVATION DIVISION AT 1545.  AT 1530, IMI, INC. SPILL CONTRACTOR ARRIVED WITH BACKHOE, LEAK UNCOVERED, VACUUM TRUCK ARRIVE AND 35 BBLS, WERE RECOVERED.  AT 1900 TEMPORARY REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED WITH HALF-SOLE CLAMP INSTALLED.  EXCAVATED DIRT IS BEING STOCK PILED ON PLASTIC FOR TEST MONITORING.  RECOVERY IS ONGOING BY ON SITE TECHNOLOGIES, FARMINGTON UNDER THE DIRECTION OF NAVAJO EPA, ARLENE LUTHER.  NAPI CONTENDS ONE CALL WAS MADE.  ONE CALL TICKET IN QUESTION WAS OBTAINED FROM THE NEW MEXICO ONE CALL CENTER AND INFORMATION IS DOCUMENTED THAT RHP WAS NOT NOTIFIED OF THIS EXCAVATION ACTIVITY DUE TO LEGAL DESCRIPTION SUBMITTED ON TICKET DOES NOT INCLUDE RHP FACILITIES.

column47: LABOR, SERVICES & MATERIALS FOR EMERG RESPONSE
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 1355 HRS, ON SEPTEMBER 25, AN EMPLOYEE OF PRIDE FEEDERS WAS CONSTRUCTING A DRAINAGE DITCH IN WHICH TO DRAIN A RUN-OFF HOLDING POND WHEN HE STRUCK OUR PIPELINE WITH THE FRONT END LOADER HE WAS OPERATING.  NEITHER OKLAHOMA ONE CALL OR VALERO WAS CALLED PRIOR TO THE EXCAVATION ACROSS THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  THE PIPELINE WAS MARKED BY PIPELINE MARKERS VISIBLE 300' UPSTREAM AND 450' DOWNSTREAM OF THE RELEASE LOCATION, AND 25" OF COVER.  THE PIPELINE, WHICH WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  WAS PUNCTURED IN THE LONGITUDNAL SEAM CREATING AN OPENING 5/8" BY 5 1/4" LONG.  PRIDE FEEDERS FOREMAN IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER AND OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SCENE.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL RESPONDED, CLOSED THE BLOCK VALVES, AND BEGAN RECOVERING FREE PRODUCT FROM THE RELEASE.  AN EMERGENCY LOCATE WAS PHONED TO OKLAHOMA ONE CALL, THEN THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND REPLACED BY 12' OF NEW 6" 5LX-42, .188 W.T. PIPE.  THE INSTALLATION WAS COMPLETED AT 2020 HRS AND RECOVERY EFFORTS CEASED AT 2100 HRS.  BIOREMEDIATION OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL IS ONGOING TO DATE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: VINTAGE PETROLEUM OPERATES A 6" GAS AND OIL GATHERING SYSTEM IN SAN ANTONIO BAY, CALHOUN COUNTY, TEXAS.  THE 6" PIPELINE DEVELOPED A PINHOLE LEAK ON THE BOTTOM OF THE LINE ALLOWING OIL AND GAS TO ESCAPE INTO THE BAY WATERS.  AT APPROXIMATELY 10:20 AM A SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED BY OPERATING PERSONNEL AND REPORTED TO VINTAGE PETROLEUM'S DISTRICT FOREMAN.  OPERATING  PERSONNEL SHUT IN ALL WELLS CONTRIBUTING TO THE GATHERING SYSTEM AND ISOLATE THE LEAKING SECTION OF LINE.  AT 11:10 AM THE DISTRICT FOREMAN NOTIIFIED THE NRC (RESPONSE NO. 703032) OF THE INCIDENT AT 11:15 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE (RESPONSE NO. 20032877) AT 11:30 NOTIFIED THE US COAST GUARD, AT 11:33 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS PARKS AND WILDFIRE, AT 11:35 NOTIFIED THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY, AND AT 11:45 AM NOTIFIED THE TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION DOT/PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICE OF THE INCIDENT.  WHILE THE NOTIFICATIONS WERE BEING MADE THE OPERATING PERSONNEL ISOLATED THE LEAKING SECTION OF LINE AND BLEW DOWN TO A HOLDING TANK.  THE SHEEN FROM THE LEAK QUICKLY EVAPORATED (CRUDE OIL - API GRAVITY 58") IH THE MORNING SUN, THUS REDUCING WATER CONTAMINATION.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED AND PRESSURE TESTED, THEN LATER PLACED INTO SERVICE.  CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE INTERNAL MICROBIOLOGICAL CORROSSION.  THE CHEMICAL CORROSION PROGRAM WAS EVALUATED THEN CHANGED TO INSURE BETTER PROTECTION.

column245: A JAYHAWK EMPLOYEE WAS CLEARING THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY OF HEAVY BRUSH WHEN THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED.  JAYHAWK'S 24HR PIPELINE OPERATOR WAS NOTIFIED AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  JAYHAWK'S MAINTENANCE CREW ARRIVED AT THE LEAK SITE WITHIN THE HOUR AND UNCOVERED THE PIPELINE AND INSTALLED A CLAMP ON THE LEAK.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION FOUND THE PIPELINE TO HAVE EXTERNAL CORROSION IN THIS AREA.  JAYHAWK DRAIN THE LINE DOWN AND INSTALLED 78 FEET OF NEW TESTED 8-INCH AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED WITH REDUCED PRESSURE.

column70: TORN IN TWO BY MUD-SLIDE CAUSED BY HURICANE
column245: THE SUBJECT PIPELINE WAS UNINTENTIONALLY MOVED BY A UNDERWATER MUD-SLIDE THAT WAS GENERATED BY WAVE ACTION BY HURRICANE IVAN.  THE PIPELINE WAS TORN IN TWO BY THE FORCES OF THE MUD-SLIDE.  THE SEPERATION TOOK PLACE IN SOUTH PASS 38.  THE PIPELINE WAS EVENTUALLY LOCATED ON OCTOBER 18, 2004.    THE LEAK DURATION IN PART G, ITEM 3 IS LISTED AS 0-DAYS AND 0-HOURS BECAUSE WHEN THE PIPE WAS SEPERATED IT WAS SHUT-IN FOR HURRICANE IVAN AND THE SPILL WAS INSTANTANEOUS.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON NOVEMBER 9, 2004 A 5 BARREL REGULATORY REPORTABLE CRUDE OIL SPILL OCCURRED ON THE HAWKINS GATHERING SYSTEM SITE 11 F.G. 4" FIBERGLASS PIPELINE.  THE SPILL WAS CAUSED BY THIRD PARTY DAMAGE.  A TRACKHOE OPERATOR WAS VOLUNTARILY WORKING FOR THE VETERAN'S ADMINISTRATION WITHIN THE CITY OF HAWKINS, TEXAS AND WAS MOVING HIS TRACKHOE AND SUNK THE BUCKET IN THE GROUND TO HELP PULL HIMSELF ALONG AND HIT THE FIBERGLASS PIPELINE.  THE WORK IN THE AREA WAS ONGOING AND THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN MARKED.  THE SITE HAD BEEN VISITED BY EXXONMOBIL PERSONNEL THE DAY OF THE EVENT AND THERE WAS NO SCHEDULED WORK TO BE DONE NEAR THE PIPELINE.  4-1/2 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED.  THE LINE HAS BEEN REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  THERE WERE NO IMPACTS TO PUBLIC SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS WERE LIMITED TO SHALLOW SOILS IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA.  ALL APPLICABLE AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.

column245: ON 9/28/04 STATION PERSONNEL CHECKING MANIFOLD AREA DISCOVERED CRUDE OIL POOLED UP IN THE MANIFOLD AREA.  A SPILL CLEANUP TEAM WAS DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION ALONG WITH AN EXCAVATION CREW TO EXCAVATE THE POINT OF RELEASE.  AFTER SOME EXCAVATION A SMALL HOLE THE SIZE OF A PENCIL WAS DISCOVERED IN A SECTION OF 4" PIPE WHICH IS TIED IN TO TWO PRESSURE RELIEF VALVES. THIS LINE CAN BE LINED UP TO THREE DIFFERENT TANK HEADERS TO PROVIDE RELEIF FROM THERMAL EXPANTION ON THE MANIFOLD.  THIS LINE CAN REMAIN STAGNANT FOR PROLONG PERIODS OF TIME MAKING IT MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO INTERNAL CORROSION.  THIS SECTION OF 4" PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A SECTION OF 2" WITH A CHECK VALVE TO ELIMINATE THE POSSIBILITY OF TANK OIL FROM LEAKING BACK THROUGH THE RELEIF PIPING.

column245: THIS INCIDENT IS BEING INVESTIGATED BY THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPT AS CRIMINAL MISCHIEF AND IS CASE # 04A020727.  TWO SUSPECTS HAVE BEEN ARRESTED.  SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT PHONE # IS 936-760-5876.  INVESTIGATORS SAID THE TWO MEN USED A STOLEN PIECE OF HEAVY EQUIPMENT (TRACKHOE)AND DUE A HOLE THAT PUNCTURED THE PIPELINE.  GREGG JOHNSON OF THE HOUSTON REGION, PIPELINE SAFETY, RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS ALSO RESPONDED AND REPORTED ON THIS INCIDENT (PHONE 713-869-8425). column245: A PARTIALLY BURIED STRAINER, ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF A CUSHING TERMINAL BOOSTER PUMP, DEVELOPED A LEAK BELOW GRADE. column241: QUINTIN H  FRAZIER, MANAGER PIPELINE SAFETY
column245: ON THURSDAY OCTOBER 21ST, MAINTENANCE CREWS WERE REBUILDING THE SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES ON PUMP UNIT 302 AT OUR HELENA, AL TANK FARM.  THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN SHUT DOWN FOR PIPELINE MAINTENANCE REASONS AND THE MAINTENANCE CREWS WERE USING THIS OPPORTUNITY TO REBUILD PUMP UNIT 302'S VALVES.  WHILE RE-SETTING THE RIGGING FROM THE CRANE TO MOVE FROM THE SUCTION VALVE TO THE DISCHARGE VALVE, A FLASH FIRE OCCURRED INSIDE UNIT 302'S SUCTION VALVE CAVITY.  IT IS BELIVED THAT STATIC ELECTRICITY WAS THE IGNITION SOURCE.  INITIALLY, THIS INCIDENT WAS NOT DEEMED DOT REPORTABLE BY FIELD PERSONNEL BECAUSE THERE WAS NO RELEASE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS.  AS STATED IN DOT REGULATION 195.50 REPORTING ACCIDENTS, "AN ACCIDENT REPORT IS REQUIRED FOR EACH FAILURE IN A PIPELINE SYSTEM SUBJECT TO THIS PART IN WHICH THERE IS A RELEASE OF THE HAZARDOUS LIQUID OR CARBON DIOXIDE TRANSPORTED RESULTING IN ANY OF THE FOLLOWING..." A SUBSEQUENT SAFETY REVIEW OF THIS INCIDENT BY PLANTATION PIPE LINE (PPL) PROMPTED THE QUESTION OF DOT REPORTABILITY.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A DOT 7000-1 REPORT SHOULD BE SUBMITTED FOR THIS INCIDENT WHILE ALSO SEEKING CLARIFICATION FROM OPS AS TO WHETHER THIS INCIDENT IS ONE THAT SHOULD BE REPORTED UNDER DOT REGULATION 195.50(A).  PLANTATION PIPE LINE RESPECTFULLY ASKS THE OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY TO CLARIFY IF THIS INCIDENT INVOLVING A FLASH FIRE AND NO RELEASE OF PETROLEUM PRODUCTS IS REPORTABLE PER DOT REGULATION 195.50(A).    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: MARKWEST EMPLOYEES PERFORMING MAINTENANCE ON FLOW STATION #4, DOWNSTREAM OF THE FAILURE SITE.  FLOW STATION #4 VALVE FAILED IN THE CLOSED POSITION CAUSING AN INCREASE (SPIKE) IN PRESSURE.  THE FAILURE RESULTED WHEN THE PRESSURE IN THE LINE EXCEEDED THE STRENGTH OF THE REMAINING LIGAMENT OF THE PIPE CAUSING DUCTILE TEARING.  THE EVIDENCE COLLECTED IN THE INVESTIGATION SUGGESTS THAT THE INTERFERENCE CORROSION WAS A PRIMARY CONTRIBUTING CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  THE PRESSURE AT WHICH THE PIPELINE FAILED (1404) WAS NOT GREATER THAN THE LINE MOP.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON 11-10-04 @ 2039, PERSONNEL FROM THE WORTHAM TEAM ARRIVED AT MP 36.2   (NEAR MILFORD, TX.) TO INVESTIGATE A LANDOWNERS REPORT OF A PETROLEUM SMELL IN THE VACINITY OF OUR LPG ROW. HE FOUND A PATCH OF FROZEN GROUND ABOVE CPL'S 14" LPG LINE AND NOTIFIED OUR CONTROL CENTER TO SHUT DOWN AND BLOCK IN THE SYSTEM. WITH WET CONDITIONS AND THE FROZEN SOIL, WE DECIDED TO SET STOPPLE FITTINGS ON EITHER SIDE OF THE LEAK AREA AND LAY 950' OF NEW 14" LINE AROUND THE PROBLEM AREA. WHEN WEATHER PERMITS, WE WILL EXCAVATE THE AREA AND DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK. OUR RECORDS SHOW AN OLD STOPPLE FITTING AT THIS LOCATION AND WE SUSPECT THAT IT MAY BE THE SOURCE OF THIS SMALL LEAK.      ON 12-20-04, THE LEAK SITE WAS EXCAVATED AND AN OLD STOPPLE FITTING REMOVED FOR FURTHER EXAMINATION. WE FOUND THAT THE "O" RING ON THE COMPLETION PLUG HAD DETERIORATED ALLOWING PRODUCT TO LEAK BY AND THAT THE GASKET ON THE BLIND FLANGE WAS ALSO LEAKING.

column245: ON 11/1/04 AT APPROXIMATELY 14:45 OUR MORRIS MAINTENANCE STAFF DISCOVERED A LEAK NEAR THE INLET PIPING AT THE BELLY OF THE #2 PROPYLENE TANK LOCATED AT OUR MORRIS, IL STORAGE FACILITY.  IN PREPARATION FOR SOME MAINTENANCE WORK ON TANK COMPONENTS, THIS TANK WAS PREVIOUSLY ISOLATED AND PURGED OF PRODUCT.  THE ISOLATION VALVES FOR THIS TANK APPEARED TO HAVE ALLOWED SOME PRODUCT TO SEEP INTO THE ISOLATED TANK.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT ONLY 3.5 GALLONS OF PROPYLENE WAS RELEASE FROM THE LEAK LOCATION.  THE CAUSE FOR THE RELEASE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION AND WE WILL SUBMIT A SUPPLEMENTAL AND FINAL REPORT WHEN THE INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETE.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 7:45 PM CENTRAL TIME ON NOVEMBER 22, 2004, A PRESSURE DROP WAS OBSERVED AT THE PONCA CITY OK, CONTROL CENTER ON THE BORGER - DENVER PIPELINE SYSTEM. PRESSURE DROP WAS BETWEEN LAJUNTA CO AND THE ORDWAY PUMP STATION.  THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND CREWS DISPATCHED. A SEAM FAILURE WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY FIVE MILES DOWNSTREAM (MP 209.5) OF LA JUNTA CO.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE, NO VISIBLE PRODUCT OBSERVED.  THE RELEASE DID NOT IMPACT ANY SURFACE WATER AND DUE TO SOIL CONDITION, PERCOLATED INTO THE SOIL NEAR THE PIPELINE.  SOIL REMEDIATION AT THE SITE IS ONGOING. ALL CORRECTIVE ACTIONS ARE BEING SENT TO THE WESTERN REGION OFFICE FOR REVIEW.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column238: BURIED FLANGE CONNECTION ON DOWNSTREAN SIDE OF CHECK VALVE LOOSENED DUE TO VIBRATION OVER 16 YEAR PERIOD OF OPERATION.
column245: THE LEAK OCCURRED FROM A BURIED, FLANGE END CHECK VALVE.  WHEN THE VALVE WAS EXPOSED, SEVERAL STUD BOLTS ON THE BOTTOM PORTION OF THE FLANGE WERE FOUND LOOSE, THE APPARENT REASON WHY THE FLANGE CONNECTION BEGAN TO LEAK.  VIBRATION FROM PUMP OPERATION, PUMP START AND STOPPING AND SEASONAL THERMAL EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION OVER TIME IS BELIEVED TO BE THE REASON THE FLANGE CONNECTION BECAME LOOSE.   THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY A STATION OPERATOR DOING A ROUTINE INSPECTION OF THE STATION.  THE STATION HAS AN ASPHALT COVERING AND THE OPERATOR OBSERVED CRUDE OIL SEEPING TO THE TOP OF THE ASPHALT.  THE STATION IS EQUIPPED WITH MONITORING WELLS DESIGNED TO MONITOR ANY LEAKAGE FROM THE BURIED FLANGES WITHIN THE STATION.  THE MONITORING WELL ADJACENT TO THE FLANGE THAT WAS FOUND LEAKING WAS CHECKED ON NOVEMBER 12, 2004 AND THE HYDROCARBON VAPOR READING IN THE WELL INDICATED NO FLANGE LEAKAGE.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE FLANGE BEGAN LEAKING SOME TIME BETWEEN THE STATION INSPECTION ON NOVEMBER 12 AND THE STATION INSPECTION ON NOVEMBER 15.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: BETWEEN 18:30 PM AND 24:00 PST, 400 BBLS OF CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED FROM TEMPORARY STORAGE TANKS DUE TO TANK OVERFILL.  TANK 907, 30,000 BBL TANK IS OUT OF SERVICE FOR API 653 INSPECTION.  5 2500 BBL FRAC TANKS WERE INSTALLED TEMPORARILY TO FLOW CRUDE THROUGH DURING SURGES OR OTHER OPERATIONAL ISSUES ON THE MAILINE.   REVIEW OF SCADA TRENDS INDICATE THAT THE RELIEF VALVE OPENED   BELOW THE SET PRESSURE LIMIT (70 PSI) AND FAILED TO CLOSE AFTER RELIEVING.  THERE WAS NO APPARENT REASON TO SUSPECT FLOW DUE TO THE MAINLINE OPERATION AT THE TIME, LINE PRESSURE WAS 50 PSI AND THE RELIF VALVE WAS SET TO OPEN AT 70 PSI.  ALSO, THE HI-HI LEVEL APPEARED TO NOT FUNCITION PROPERLY.  CRUDE OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE CONTAINMENT AREA WITHIN THE TANK DIKE.  CREWS WERE DISPATCHED AND RECOVERY AND CLEAN UP COMMENCED.  RECOVERED 390 BBLS OF CRUDE AND PUT BACK INTO TANKAGE.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column241: JENNIFER  RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY CO
column245: ON NOVEMBER 10, 2004, OIL WAS DISCOVERED SEEPING FROM UNDER TANK 657 NEAR THE NOZZLE DURING ROUTINE (EVERY EIGHT HOURS) VISUAL INSPECTION.  IMMEDIATE ACTION WAS TAKEN TO INSTALL CONTAINMENT AROUND THE SPILL ALLOWING ONLY TWO BARRELS TO REACH THE SOIL SURROUNDING THE TANK. EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIONS WERE ALSO IMMEDIATE IN REMOVING THE CONTAMINATED SOIL FROM THE FACILITY AND SHIPPING IF OFFSITE PER ALL APPLICABLE REGULATIONS.  THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE IS FROM AN ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION WELD.  UPON CLEANING THE TANK, A 3/8" FATIGUE CRACK ON THE BASE OF THE BRACKET WELD WAS FOUND ON THE FLOOR PLATE ALLOWING THE RELEASE TO OCCUR.  THE TANK HAS BEEN PUMPED DOWN, REMOVED FROM SERVICE, CLEANED AND IS IN THE PROCESS OF BEING REPAIRED.  AN INTERNAL INVESTIGATION IS BEING CONDUCTED ON THIS EVENT. 5-18-05 THE RELEASE OCCURRED DUE TO INADEQUATE SAND PACK UNDER THE TANK FLOOR RESULTING IN 3/8" FATIGUE CRACK ON THE BASE OF BRACKET WELD ON THE FLOOR PLATE.  THE OPERATOR LOSSES IN PART A 5 INCLUDE THE VALUE OF PRODUCT LOST, THE ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION, THE COST OF CLEANING THE TANK AND THE REPAIR OF THE BRACKET WELD.     4/19/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  A NEGATIVE SIGN WAS ADDED TO THE LONGITUDE. "OTHER" FOR #18 UNDER WELD WAS REMOVED AS WAS THE MISCELLANEOUS DESCRIPTION OF "WELD/CONSTRUCTION FATIGUE FAILURE FAILURE AT THE BASE OF THE BRACKET WELD".  THOUGH ALL THIS INFORMATION IS TRUE, IT IS APPROPRIATE TO ONLY FILL OUT ONE CAUSE.  THE REMAINDER OF THE INFORMATION IS INCLUDED IN THIS NARRATIVE.

column245: EAST BAY MUNICIPAL UTILITY DISTRICT (EBMUD) CONTRACTOR MOUNTAIN CASCADE WAS INSTALLING WATER PIPELINE ADJACENT TO KINDER MORGAN PIPELINE.  PIPELINE HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY POTHOLE AND MARKED FOR EBMUD CONTRACTORS.  MOUNTAIN CASCADE ONE CALL TICKET FOR WORK IN THIS AREA WAS FILED SEPTEMBER 13, 2004.  KINDER MORGAN REPRESENTATIVE MET WITH MOUNTAIN CASCADE REPRESENTATIVES AT JOB SITE ON SEPTEMBER 22, 2004 TO POINT OUT PIPELINE LOCATION.  SUBSEQUENT EXTENSIONS OF ONE CALL TICKET WERE RECEIVED ON SEPTEMBER 22, OCTOBER 6, OCTOBER 20 & NOVEMBER 3, 2004.  ON THE SECTION OF THE ONE CALL TICKET REQUESTING "REMARK YES OR NO" MOUNTAIN CASCADE SELECTED "NO" ON EACH EXTENSION.  CAUSE OF INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY CALIFORNIA STATE FIRE MARSHALL AND CAL-OSHA.  3/1/2010 NO FREE PRODUCT REMAINS SO WE ARE CLOSING THE REMEDIATION. ADDITIONAL COST SPENT FOR ENVIRNMENTAL INVESTIGATION $153,425 THROUGH 3-31-09.YA

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: CONTRACTOR PERFORMING BORING ACROSS BARNES FERRY RD WITHOUT PROPERLY NOTIFYING THE UPC.   HIT OUR LINE AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 HOURS WITH 3/4" BIT.  THEN REALIZING THEY HIT SOMETHING DID NOT REMOVE BIT WHICH KEPT THE PIPELINE FROM LOSING EXCESSIVE PRODUCT.  A RESIDENT OF BARNES FERRY RD NOTIFIED THE CONTRACTOR THAT THERE WAS A PIPELINE RUNNING UNDER THE ROAD.  THEY FOUND OUR CONTACT NUMBER ON A PIPELINE MARKER APPROXIMATELY 1000 FT AWAY.  I RECEIVED A PHONE CALL AT APPROXIMATELY 14:00 FROM SOUTHERN STATE ENTERPRISE STATING THEY HAD HIT A FUEL LINE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 14:02 WE SHUT DOWN ROBINS LINE PUMP AND CLOSED ALL VALVES.  WE CALLED ROBINS AFB AT APPROX 14:05 AND TOLD THEM TO CLOSE OFF.  WE WENT TO SITE, VERIFIED HIT, AND NOTED DAMP DIRT AT BOTTOM OF PIT AT APPROX 14:20.  WENT 1000 YARDS AND CLOSED OFF BLOCK VALVE AT APPROX 14:30.  CALLED SOUTH EASG MANAGER APPROX 14:45 TO NOTIFY.  THEN CALLED FLORIDA ROCK TANK LINES TO EXCAVATE FUEL OUT OF PIPELINE AT APPROX 15:30.  I THEN CALLED EH&S MANAGER AT 16:00.  HE CALLED GAEPD AND NRC WHO WILL COPY OPS ON REPORT.  CHECKED WEATHER - CLEAN FOR 24 - 48 HRS.  I CALLED CITY MACON EMERGENCY MGMT AND THEY ASKED ME TO PAGE THE FIRE DEPT AT 16:30.  FIRE DEPT WAS CONTACTED BY PAGER BUT DID NOT RESPOND OR RETURN MESSAGE.  FLORIDA ROCK CAME IN AT APPROX 16:30 TO EXCAVATE PRODUCT OUT OF LINE.  AT APPROX 16:55 WES/KANEB ASKED THE FOREMAN OF SOUTHERN STATE IF HE HAD A LOCATE TICKET OR NUMBER AND HE COULD NOT COME UP WITH ONE.  THE TERMINAL OPERATOR INFORMED ME THAT QSR GOVERNMENT REPRESENTATIVE, HAD SHOWN UP AT SITE AND INDICATED THE RELEASE LOOKED TO BE 25 GALLONS OF FUEL OR LESS.  I CALLED INDUSTRIAL HYDRO BLAST TO SET UP VAC-TRUCK IF NEEDED.  WILL BE ON STAND BY WAS NOT REQUIRED.  MOVED OUT APPROX 1600 GALLONS JP8 INTO TRUCK OUT OF LINE AT MACON TERMINAL WHICH EQUALS .826 GALLONS PER FOOT.. SHOUL CLEAN 1,937 FEET OF PIPE.  THE HIT IN THE LINE WAS APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FT NORTH FROM BLOCKED VALVE.  AT APPROX 15:00 UNCOVERED PIPE 3/4" BIT IN THE SIDE, 9 TO 10 O'CLOCK POSITION OF OUR PIPE.  REMOVED BIT, BUT LOST NO FUEL, BECAUSE PIPE WAS FREE OF FUEL AT THIS POINT DUE TO PULLING FUEL BACK TO THE TERMINAL WITH TANKER AND PUMP.  CLEANED OFF PIPE AND PUT ON A FULL SEAL TEMPORARY CLAMP AT APPROX 19:15.  COVERED UP PIPE MARK SITE WITH FLAGS AND MARKING TAPE.  WENT BACK TO TERMINAL TO DOUBLE CHECK ALL VALVES AND CLOSED UP FOR THE DAY AT APPROX 23:00.  AT 6:00AM ON 12/2/04 REMOVED PRODUCT FROM FLORIDA ROCK TANK TRUCK, WITH QSR APPROVAL, BACK INTO TANK 550FT.  AFTER THIS, CALLED UTILITY PROTECTION CENTER TO SEE IFF A TICKET WAS CALLED IN.  TALKED WITH OCTAVIA AND SHE SEARCHED FROM NOV 4 TO DEC 2 2004 AND COULD NOT FIND A LOCATE TICKET FROM SOUTHERN STATE.  SHE INFORMED ME TO CALL PSC.  AT THIS TIME I CONTACTED THEM, RECEIVING VOICE MAIL, AND LEFT A MESSAGE FOR THEM TO CALL ME BACK DUE TO AN UNAUTHORIZED HIT BY A UTILITY CONTRACTOR WITHOUT A LOCATE TICKET.  AT 07:00 I CALLED BIBB COUNTY ENGINEERS AND TALKED WITH KEITH BRASWELL ON HOW TO HANDLE PUTTING GRIFFIN RD BACK INTO SERVICE ONCE REPAIRS WERE MADE.  SOUTHERN STATE ENTERPRISES, THE COMPANY THAT BORED INTO OUR 4" PIPE, IS A SUB-CONTRACTOR OF ANSCO & ASSOC WHICH FROM WHAT WE UNDERSTAND IS A SUBCONTRACTOR FOR BELL SOUTH CO.  THE COST TO REPAIR THIS SECTION OF LINE AND CLEAN UP AND REMEDIATE AT THIS TIME IS ESTIMATED AT $27,000 (AS OF 12/5/04).  AS OF TODAY, 12/5/04 19:00 PIPE REPAIR IS COMPLETE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON DECEMBER 06, 2004 I KEVIN BENNETT RECEIVED A CALL FROM A PLAINS PIPELINE GAUGER NOTIFYING THE PLAINS DISTRICT MANAGER OF A LEAK AT THE WHITE OAK STATION.  THE STATION WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME,  BUT THE GAUGER CALLED THE CONTROL CENTER TO NOTIFY THEM OF THE PROBLEM AND FLAG THE STATION SO THAT NO PRODUCT COULD MOVE IN OR OUT.  UPON ARRIVAL I NOTICED THE PRODUCT HAD RUN APPROXIMATELY 600 FEET.  A CLEAN UP WAS INITIATED AND WE STARTED DIGGING TO FIND OUT WHAT WAS LEAKING.  IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT AN OLD DEAD 6"   THAT CAME OFF THE TANK HEADER HAD A SMALL HOLE DUE TO BEING BLINDED OFF AND LETTING IT STAND FULL OF WATER, CAUSING INTERNAL CORROSION.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A THIRD PARTY GAS COMPANY EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED A LEAK FROM LINE 80 AND CALLED THE CONTROL CENTER.  CONTROL IMMEDIATELY SHUT LINE DOWN AND DISPATCHED EMPLOYEES FOR A RESPONSE.  THE LEAK WAS FOUND IN A COTTON FIELD AND CONTAINED.  150 BARRELS RELEASED AND 60 BARRELS RECOVERD.    CAUSE OF LEAK IS STILL TO BE DETERMINED AS PIPE IN BEING ANALYSED BY AN OUTSIDE LABORATORY.  INITIAL INVESTIGATION SEEMS TO INDICATE EXTERNAL CORROSION, DUE TO INADEQUATE COATING APPLICATION.     METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUSION:  THE LEAK IN THE PIPLINE OCCURRED AT A REGION OF EXTERNAL CORROSION THAT WAS LOCATED AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION ON ONE SIDE OF THE STOPPLE FITTING.  THE AREAS SURROUNDING THE WALL PENETRATION EXHIBITED A UNIFORM, GENERAL ATTACK THAT PRODUCED SEVERE WALL THINNING.  THE LOCATION OF THE CORROSION SITE AND KNOWN HISTORY OF THE INSTALLATION SUGGESTED THAT THE CORROSION HAD MOST LIKELY RESULTED FROM LOCALIZED FAILURE OF THE PROTECTIVE COATING THAT HAD BEEN RE-APPLIED AFTER INSTALLATION FO THE STOPPLE FITTING.

column238: THE INTERNAL ONE HALF INCH TUBING OF A HEAT/COOLING EXCHANGER FAILED AT A BEND WITHIN THE EXCHANGER IT SELF.
column241: JAMIE A HERNANDEZ, MANAGER OF PIPELINE SAFETY
column245: THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO A FAILURE AT A BEND OF AN INTERNAL ONE-HALF INCH TUBING OF THE INBOARD OF A HEAT/COOLING EXCHANGER ON OUR NUMBER ONE PUMP FOR OUR LINE 105.  THE RELEASED QUANTITY IS AN OVER CONSERVATIVE ESTIMATE THAT WAS CALCULATED AFTER REVIEWING SCADA OPERATING RECORDS. KMEP BELIEVES THAT THE ACTUAL AMOUNT RELEASE WAS CONSIDERABLY LESS THAN THE FIFTY TWO BARRELS REPORTED AS THE TEMPERATURE THAT DAY WAS NEAR THE BOILING POINT OF THE BUTANE, 31.1 DEGREES FARENHEIT, THEREFORE KEEPING THE PRODUCT IN A NEAR LIQUID PHASE.  THE PUDDLE OF PRODUCT WAS VISUALLY LESS THAN THE AMOUNT CALCULATED.  BY THE TIME THE REPAIRS WERE MADE, THE PRODUCT HAD VAPORIZED OFF AND NO PRODUCT REMAINED ON THE GROUND.

column245: ON MAINTENANCE CALL OUT TO REMOTE BOOSTER SITE APPROX 22:30 PST NOVEMBER 21, 2004.  KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE OBSERVED GASOLINE ODOR ON INTERSTATE IN VICINITY OF CALNEV PIPELINE.  KINDER MORGAN CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED AND PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AS PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE UNTIL DAYLIGHT.  AT 05:50 NOVEMBER 22, 2004 EMPLOYEE REPORTED SIGHTING SPRAY COMING FROM PIPELINE ROW.  NRC WAS NOTIFIED OF CONFIRMED RELEASE AT 07:27 NOVEMBER 22, 2004.  OUR INVESTIGATION SUGGESTS THAT THIS RELEASE RESULTED FROM OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE TO THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE, WHEN UNCOVERED, REVEALED DENTS, WHICH COULD HAVE BEEN THE RESULT OF MECHANICAL EQUIPMENT AND/OR LARGE BOULDERS AND ROCKS, PUSHED ON TO THE PIPELINE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: PIPELINE NO 24 RUNS FROM FREEPORT TERMINAL TO THE SWEENY COMPLEX AT OLD OCEAN.  THE LINE IS OPERATED WITH THE SEGMENT FORM FREEPORT TERMINAL TO JONES CREEK TERMINAL IN INTERMITTENT SERVICES AND THE SEGMENT FROM JONES CREEK TERMINAL TO SWEENY COMPLEX IN FULL-TIME SERVICE.  THE LEAK OCCURRED ON THE 5.8 MILE SEGMENT OF THIS LINE BETWEEN FREEPORT AND JONES CREEK TERMINAL.  THIS PART OF PIPELINE 24 WAS IDLED ON NOVEMBER 10TH.  THE AIR PATROL FLEW THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY ON NOVEMBER 9TH OR 6 DAYS BEFORE THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED AND DID NOT OBSERVE ANY EVIDENCE OF OIL.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL AT CONOCOPHILLIPS JONES CREEK TERMINAL DISCOVERED THE LEAK AT 5:00 PM NOVEMBER 15, 2004.  EMERGENCY PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED FROM CONOCOPHILLIPS SWEENY COMPLEX.  THERE ARE TWO CRUDE OIL PIPELINES IN THE AREA WHERE THE LEAK OCCURRED - 12" PL#4 AND 24" PL#24. PIPELINE NO 4 WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY IN ADDITION TO PIPELINE NO 24 WHICH WAS ALREADY IDLED.  PIPELINE #4 AND PIPELINE #24 WERE MANUALLY ISOLATED UTILIZING THE MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES CLOSEST TO THE LEAK POINT TO MINIMIZE ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL WORKED THROUGH THE NIGHT TO RECOVER OIL.  OIL DID NOT REACH THE JONES CREEK.  OIL WAS DETECTED AT IS CLOSEST POINT APPROXIMATELY 100 YARDS FROM THE CREEK.  THE SOURCE OF THE CRUDE OIL LEAK WAS LOCATED THE FOLLOWING DAY THROUGH A PLANNED METHODOLOGY.  THE 12" PIPELINE #4 WAS PRESSURED TO 150PSIG AND BLOCKED IN.  THE PRESSURE WAS MAINTAINED FOR 2 HOURS VERIFYING THAT #4 PIPELINE WAS NOT LEAKING.  PIPELINE NO 4 WAS THEN PUT BACK IN SERVICE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1:00 PM A LOCATION ON THE 24" (PIPELINE NO. 24) WAS EXCAVATED WHERE SOME GRASS APPEARED TO BE BROWNER THAN IN THE SURROUNDING AREA.  OIL WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING FROM THE 24" AT THIS LOCATION.  THE LEAK LOCATION WAS IMMEDIATELY PLUGGED.  A SCAB CLAMP WAS INSTALLED ON THE LINE AT APPROXIMATELY 10:00 PM THAT EVENING.  THE LEAK WAS NEAR A WELD AND POSSIBLY IN THE HEAT AFFECTED ZONE.  THERE WAS INDICATION OF CORROSION UNDER THE COATING POSSIBLY DUE TO WATER ENTERING THROUGH DISBONDED COATING.  THE CP ON THIS LINE WAS MEASURED AT -1.3659 MV.  THE POSSIBLITY OF INTERNAL CORROSION AS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR HAS NOT BEEN ELIMINATED.  A FINAL REPORT IS ANTICIPATED IN EARLY JANUARY OF 2005.  THE PIPELINE WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE AND CLAMPED UNTIL THE REPAIR IS MADE.  A SECTION OF PIPE WILL BE REMOVED FOR INSPECTION AND ANALYSIS AT THAT TIME.

THE TANK HAS BEEN TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND WILL BE INSPECTED AND REPAIRED.     UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION OF THIS LEAK, INCLUDING SEVERAL HISTORICAL RECORDS, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE OIL RESIDUE IN THE SOIL WAS A RESULT OF AN EARLIER LEAK, RATHER THAN A RECENT OCCURRENCE. THE TANK WILL NOT NEED TO BE TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND INSPECTED AS ORIGINALLY THOUGHT.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: ON WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 2004 AT 1105 BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY¿S LOCAL SUPERVISOR RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM AN EMPLOYEE REPORTING A GASOLINE RELEASE ON OUR 10" SHIPPER LINE.  THE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER WAS IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED IMMEDIATELY AND COMPANY EMPLOYEES WERE SENT TO THE SITE.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A 1½¿ PUNCTURE WAS DISCOVERED IN THE PIPELINE.  IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT AN EXCAVATOR DIGGING IN THE AREA HIT THE PIPELINE A COUPLE OF DAYS BEFORE THE INCIDENT WAS DISCOVERED BY OUR EMPLOYEE AND DID NOT NOTIFY BUCKEYE OF THE DAMAGE.  BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY DID NOT RECEIVE ANY ONE CALL NOTIFICATION FOR THIS WORK.  THERE WERE PERMANENT PIPELINE MARKERS IN THE AREA.     THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  RECOVERY AND CLEANUP OPERATIONS WERE PERFORMED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE NEW YORK PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION, U. S. COAST GUARD, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION, AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A BOOSTER PUMP DISCHARGE FLANGE CRACKED BECAUSE OF THE STRESSES ASSOCIATED PIPING HAD PLACED ON THE PUMP FLANGE.  THE PUMP WAS AN EARLY 1950¿S CAST IRON PUMP IN A LOW-PRESSURE SERVICE BETWEEN A BREAKOUT TANK AND A MAINLINE PUMP.  AS A RESULT, A RELEASE OF TRANSMIX OCCURRED AT APPROXIMATELY 09:36 HOURS AND LASTED FOR APPROXIMATELY 9 MINUTES.  THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED BY LOCAL MARKETING TERMINAL OPERATORS AT APPROXIMATELY 09:45 HOURS.  THEY NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER AND THE PUMP WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN WHICH ISOLATED THE LEAKING PUMP BY CLOSING MOVS.      PRODUCT FLOWED AROUND THE TANK DIKE, UNDER THE FACILITY FENCE AND THEN ALONG A PUBLIC ROAD UNTIL IT ENTERED A TRIBUTARY OF THE ALLEGHENY RIVER THAT RUNS THROUGH THE TERMINAL.  PRODUCT NEVER REACHED THE ALLEGHENY RIVER.  CONTAINMENT AND RECOVERY EFFORTS BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  A BOOM WAS PLACED AT THE RIVER END OF THE TRIBUTARY.  A CALL WAS PLACED TO 911 TO FACILITATE RESTRICTION OF TRAFFIC NEAR THE AREA OF THE RELEASE.  A CLEANUP CONTRACTOR WAS CALLED TO PROVIDE VACUUM TRUCKS, ROLL OFF BOXES AND TANK TRUCKS.  EXCAVATION OF SOIL WAS COMPLETED ON DECEMBER 16 AND 17 ALONG BOTH SIDES OF THE FENCE LINE AND UP TO THE PUMP PAD.    THE SOURCE OF THE STRESS ON THE PUMP WAS THE RESULT OF ONE OR MORE OF THE FOLLOWING REASONS: THE REPLACEMENT OF NEARBY PIPE SUPPORTS, MODIFICATION OF CONCRETE WALLS THAT MAY HAVE BEEN SUPPORTING THE PUMP SUCTION AND DISCHARGE PIPING, GROUND HEAVE AS A RESULT OF THE RECORD RAINFALL THIS YEAR AND THE SUDDEN BELOW FREEZING TEMPERATURES ON THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT.  THE PIPE SUPPORT REPLACEMENT AND THE MODIFICATION OF THE CONCRETE WALLS WERE PERFORMED IN MID-2004 TO MEET THE NEW DOT 195 REQUIREMENTS OF ATMOSPHERIC CORROSION INSPECTION UNDER PIPE SUPPORTS AND THROUGH WALL PENETRATIONS.    AS A RESULT OF THE INVESTIGATION INTO THIS INCIDENT, THE COMPANY WILL DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR IDENTIFYING AND WORKING WITH CAST IRON COMPONENTS AND PROVIDE TRAINING FOR FIELD PERSONNEL.  THE EXISTING MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE PROCESS WILL ALSO BE REVIEWED FOR INCLUSION OF WORK ACTIVITIES RESULTING FROM ROLL OUT OF NEW REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A LAMONS BRAND 12 INCH FLEX CG 600 # SPIRAL WOUND GRAFOIL FILLER 304 SS GASKET STAMPED ASME B16.20 WAS INSTALLED BETWEEN THE SPLIT TEE AND SANDWICH VALVE AND CUTTING MACHINE.  THE SPLIT TEE, SANDWICH VALVE, AND STOPPLE CUTTER WERE PRESSURE TESTED WITH NITROGEN AT 650 PSI, 30 PSI OVER PIPELINE PRESSURE FOR 15 MINUTES.  AFTER A SUCCESSFUL PRESSURE TEST, THE CUTTER WAS ENGAGED AND BEGAN DRILLING.  AS THE PILOT BIT BROKE THROUGH THE PIPELINE WALL, NITROGEN FOLLOWED BY PROPANE ESCAPED FROM THE GASKET AREA BETWEEN THE SANDWICH VALVE AND CUTTER HEAD.  ALL PERSONNEL EVACUATED, IGNITION SOURCES ELIMINATED AND PERSONNEL ACCOUNTED FOR.  PERSONNEL WERE THEN ASSIGNED TO BLOCK THE ROAD NORTH AND SOUTH DOWNWIND OF THE FAILURE.  THE RESIDENTS IN THE HOUSE NORTH OF THE FAILURE WERE EVACUATED BY THE OPERATOR.  THE COMMUNITY EMERGENCY RESPONSE SET UP A VOLUNTARY EVACUATION.  INVESTIGATION OF THE GASKET FAILURE SHOWED THE TAIL OF THE SPIRAL WOUND PORTION OF THE GASKET SPRUNG LOOSE AND CAUGHT IN THE CUTTER HEAD.  AFTER THE SUCCESSFUL PRESSURE TEST, THE CUTTER HEAD WAS BROUGHT DOWN IN CONTACT WITH THE PIPELINE AND BEGAN ROTATION.  THE CONTENTS OF THE SPIRAL WOUND GASKET WAS FOUND LEADING FROM THE CUTTER TOOTH, AROUND THE CUTTER HEAD AND WRAPPED AROUND THE BOARING BAR ABOVE THE CUTTER HEAD.  PORTIONS OF THE SPIRAL WOUND GASKET WAS RECOVERED AND SENT FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  RESULTS OF THAT ANALYSIS WILL BE FORTHCOMING.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: AT APPROXIMATLY 1030 , 12/24/04, A LOCAL BUSINESS OWENER NOTIFIED CONOCO PIPE LINE CO, THAT CRUDE OIL WAS LEAKING FROM A NEARBY BLOCK VALVE SITE.  THE LINE SEGMENT WAS NOT IN OPERATION AT THE TIME.  COMPANY PERSONELL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE VALVE.  VALVE WAS CLOSED AND LEAKAGE STOPPED.  CAUSE OF LEAKAGE WAS A CRACK IN A 1/2" X 3/4" WATER DRAIN VALVE ON THE MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE.  ROOT CAUSE IS WATER HAD BEEN ENTRAPPED IN THE DRAIN VALVE, COLD TEMPERATURES CAUSED WATER TO FREEZE, THEREFORE CRACKING SIDE OF VALVE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: THE BOLTS HOLDING THE RELIEF VALVE ACTUATOR IN PLACE BECAME RUSTED BY NATURAL ELEMENTS. ONE BOLT BROKE CAUSING A LEAK, THE RELEASING OF CO2 CAUSED A CHILLING EFFECT WHICH IN TURN CAUSED THE OPERATOR TO SEPARATE FROM THE BODY OF THE VALVE. THIS CAUSED THE REAMINING BOLTS TO BREAK UNDER THE EXTREME STRESS. THE LEAK WAS ISOLATED TO THREE 1/2 PORTS ON THE VALVE BODY. THE LEAK EAS CONTROLLED AND SHUT IN BY 12:25 P.M. THE REPAIRS WERE MADE AND THE RELIEF VALVE PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 05:29 ON 12/25/2004, AN OPERATOR PERFORMING A STATION CHECK DISCOVERED PRODUCT FLOWING FROM THE NORTHSIDE METERING SUMP.  THE SUMP GAUGE INDICATED A LEVEL OF 1' 11".  THE OPERATOR IMMEDIATELY STARTED THE METERING SUMP PUMP AND MANUALLY TURNED THE GAUGE RESET KNOB.  THIS ACTION DISLODGED THE GAUGE AND THE LEVEL INCREASED TO OVER 9' AND A HIGH SUMP ALARM WAS THEN RECEIVED IN THE CONTROL ROOM.  THE OPERATOR THEN NOTIFIED ADDITIONAL OPERATORS TO HELP DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE SOURCE WAS A THERMAL RELIEF VALVE THAT HAD NOT RE-SEATED AFTER ACTIVATING.  THE THERMAL RELIEF VALVE WAS RESET AND THE PRODUCT STOPPED FLOWING INTO THE SUMP.  CONTAINMENT EFFORTS WERE INITIATED AND CONTAINMENT WAS ACHIEVED BY EXISTING EXCAVATIONS IN PROXIMITY TO THE SUMP.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 9:10 AM ON AUGUST 19TH, THE TULSA CONTROL CENTER NOTICED A SUDDEN DROP IN PRESSURE AND CONTACTED THE FIELD TO REPORT A POSSIBLE LEAK ON THE TRUSCOTT TO CHILDRESS LINE.  THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND THE FIELD DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO CLOSE ALL MANUAL BLOCK VALVES.  THE CONTROL CENTER SHUT ALL REMOTE OPERATED STATION MAIN LINE VALVES.  THE PIECE OF FAILED PIPE WAS SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, INC, A METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS COMPANY WHERE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY "..PRESSURE-CYCLE INDUCED ENLARGEMENT OF A PIPE MANUFACTURING DEFECT REFERRED TO AS BURNED METAL CRACKING."

column245: FISHERMAN DISCOVERED BUBBLES IN PIPELINE CANAL.  CALLED THE SORRENTO CONTROL ROOM AND PERSONNEL WAS DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON DISCOVERY, IMMEDIATE MEASURES WERE TAKEN TO ISOLATE THE LINE AND REDUCE PRESSURE.  THE LINE WAS DISPLACE WITH NITROGEN THE NEXT DAY AND REPAIRS COMMENCED.     REPAIRS WERE MADE AND FLOW COMMENCED ON PIPELINE IN JANUARY, 2005.      THE SEGMENT IDENTIFIED AS POSSIBLY LEAKING WAS REMOVED AND TESTED IN THE SHOP WITH NO LEAK BEING DUPLICATED. THE CAUSAL RESULTS ARE INCONCLUSIVE.

column19: IN EXCAVATED BELL HOLE WHERE IMPACT TO THE PIPELIN
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AT 11:45 AM ON JANUARY 11, 2005, PLAINS PIPELINE AND CONTRACT PERSONNEL WERE MAKING MODIFICATIONS AT THE "LONGWOOD JUNCTION" IN PREPARATION FOR SMART TOOL RUN.  WHILE IN THE PROCESS OF MAKING THESE MODIFICATIONS, THE TRACKHOE SLIGHTLY BUMPED A 6 INCH THREADED VALVE.  AS A RESULT, APPROXIMATELY 700 BARRELS OF VIRGIN CRUDE OIL DRAINED FROM THE LINE INTO A 200 FT BY 4 FT DITCH.  PLAINS PERSONNEL THEN INSTRUCTED THE TRACKHOE OPERATOR TO EXCAVATE TWO BELL HOLES AS TO CONTAIN ALL DRAIN DOWN.  THE DRAIN DOWN TIME WAS APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS.  RECOVERED CRUDE OIL WAS 695 BARRELS.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: AT 13:34 ON 12/28/2004, KANEB'S CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR ("CC OPERATOR") LOCATED IN WICHITA, KS NOTICED A DROP IN PRESSURE AND FLOWRATE ON THE WOONSOCKET TO WOLSEY SEGMENT LOCATED IN SOUTH DAKOTA.  THE CC OPERATOR SHUT DOWN THE SEGMENT AND ISOLATED IT BY CLOSING REMOTE OPERATED BLOCK VALVES AT WOONSOCKET STATION AND WOLSEY TERMINAL.  KANEB THEN DISPATCHED FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE EQUIPMENT AT WOONSOCKET STATION AND TO PATROL THE RIGHT OF WAY FOR EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE.  IN ADDITION, KANEB DISPATCHED A PLANE TO CONDUCT AN AERIAL PATROL OF THE RIGHT OF WAY BETWEEN WOONSOCKET STATION AND WOLSEY TERMINAL.  NO EVIDENCE OF A RELEASE WAS FOUND AND THE SEARCH WAS HALTED AT DUSK DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS.  KANEB PERSONNEL NOTIFIED SEVERAL RESIDENCES ALONG THE RIGHT OF WAY OF A POSSIBLE RELEASE, AND PROVIDED CONTACT INFORMATION TO THEM.  THE GROUND PATROL RESUMEDD AT 7:30 ON 12/29/04 USING FOUR-WHEEL ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES.  AN AREA WITH GASOLINE ODOR WAS DISCOVERED AT 8:55 AND EXCAVATION CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  AN EMERGENCY ONE-CALL WAS CALLED IN AT 9:30 AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS NOTIFIED AT 10:05.  THE ACTUAL RELEASE LOCATION WAS EXPOSED AT 13:00, AND DRAIN UP AND TEMPORARY CAPPING OF THE LINE WAS PERFORMED. ON 12/30/2004, AN APPROXIMATE 40 FT SECTION OF LINE PIPE WAS REPLACED.  EXCAVATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL CONTINUED UNTIL 1/1/2005.  BASED ON KANEB'S INVESTIGATION, A POLE BARN WAS INSTALLED NEAR THE PIPELINE IN 1997.  THE POLE BARN EXCAVATION WAS NOTICED DURING KANEB'S ROUTINE AERIAL PATROL AND KANEB PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.  AT THE TIME, IT DID NOT APPEAR THAT ANY BORING WAS SUFFICIENTLY CLOSE TO THE PIPELINE TO CAUSE DAMAGE, AND THE LINE WAS NOT EXCAVATED FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  KANEB REQUESTED THE LANDOWNER REMOVE SEVERAL POLES THAT WERE NEAR THE PIPELINE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: ON SATURDAY, JANUARY 15, 2005 AROUND 0820 A CONTRACTOR WORKING FOR BUCKEYE PIPE LINE COMPANY NOTICED PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AT BUCKEYE¿S SINKING SPRING TERMINAL.  THE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE.   THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER AND THE MAINLINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED AND THE MACUNGIE MAINTENANCE CREW WAS SENT TO THE INCIDENT SITE.  ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.   AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A ¾" CHECK VALVE WAS DISCOVERED WITH A CRACK IN ITS BODY.  THE CHECK VALVE WAS REMOVED AND A PLUG INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  LATER A NEW CHECK VALVE WAS INSTALLED AS THE PERMANENT REPAIR.  THE CHECK VALVE THAT CRACKED WAS SHIPPED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS.

column238: THE TANK FLOOR HAD A MATERIAL DEFECT.
column245: AT 15:02 ON 1-18-05 AN A OPERATOR CHECKING TANKS IN THE PELHAM TANK FARM DISCOVERED PRODUCT FLOWING FROM AROUND THE BOTTOM OF TANK 211 ALONG THE CONCRETE TANK RING. HE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE OPERATIONS MANAGER, ALABAMA. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER,SHIFT SUPERVISOR ATLANTA CONTROL CENTER, WHO ORDERED THE TERMINATION OF THE ONGOING DELIVERY OF M GRADE GASOLINE INTO THE TANK. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER ALSO NOTIFIED THE GULF COAST DISTRICT LEADER AND THE GULF COAST DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL LEADER. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER HAD THE TANK FARM DUTY OPERATOR CONTINUE PUMPING PRODUCT FROM TANK 211 OUT ON LINE 12 TO BIRMINGHAM.   THE TANK TO TANK TRANSFERR SYSTEM WAS STARTED TO MOVE THE 211 PRODUCT TO TANK 212 AND ALSO TANK 213 WAS OPENED TO FACILITATE A GRAVITY FEED FROM TANK 211 TO 213. TANK 211 HAD APPROXIMATELY 46700 BBLS OF PRODUCT IN THE TANK AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED. THE PELHAM FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS CONTACTED AND ASKED TO RESPOND TO APPLY FOAM OVER THE SPILLED PRODUCT AS PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE SO EQUIPMENT COULD BE MOVED INTO THE DIKE AREA TO PICK UP THE SPILLED PRODUCT. TANK 211 WAS EMPTY AT 17:51. THE FREE FLOWING SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE TANK DYKE AND RECOVERY OF THIS PRODUCT WAS COMPLETED AT 20:00.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: WOODBURY STATION IS THE ORIGIN PUMP STATION FOR THE 16-INCH HARBOR PIPELINE SYSTEM.  IT CAN SOURCE PRODUCT FROM THE SUNOCO EAGLE POINT AND GIRARD POINT REFINERIES ALONG WITH CONOCO PHILLIPS REFINERY. ON JANUARY 28, AT APPROXIMATELY 0515 HOURS, THE ON-DUTY STATION OPERATOR AT WOODBURY RECEIVED A HIGH TANK ALARM FOR PRESSURE RELIEF TANK NUMBER 4590, WHICH SERVES AS A SURGE RELIEF TANK FOR ALL INCOMING PIPELINES.  AT THE TIME OF THIS ALARM, THE INCOMING 16-INCH PIPELINE FROM EAGLE POINT REFINERY WAS DELIVERING GASOLINE.  THE GAUGE LEVEL FOR THIS TANK INDICATED ONLY 6 BARRELS IN THE TANK (CAPACITY IS 1600 BARRELS), THE INCOMING OPERATING PRESSURE WAS LOWER THAN THE PRESSURE RELIEF SETTING AND THE SURGE RELIEF VALVE INDICATED CLOSED.  THE OPERATOR WENT TO THE TANK TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE THE REASON FOR THE ALARM BECAUSE ALL OPERATING DATA SHOWED NO PRODUCT SHOULD HAVE BEEN ENTERING THE TANK.  WHEN THE TANK SIDE GAUGE DEVICE WAS BUMPED, THE GAUGE SPUN PROVIDING A GAUGE READING FOR A FULL TANK.  BEFORE THE OPERATOR COULD START TO TRANSFER PRODUCT FROM THE RELIEF TANK, PRODUCT STARTED OVERFLOWING FROM THE TANK VENT.  AT THIS POINT, ALL INCOMING PIPELINES INTO WOODBURY WERE SHUT DOWN QUICKLY THEREBY STOPPING THE TANK OVERFLOW.  THE MAIN OUTGOING PIPELINE WAS ALSO SHUT DOWN JUST TO BE SAFE.    APPROXIMATELY 250 GALLONS OF GASOLINE OVERFLOWED FROM THE TANK.  ALL SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CAPTURED IN THE TANK DIKE.  PRODUCT AND CONTAMINATED ICE AND SNOW WERE CLEANED UP UTILIZING A VACUUM TRUCK AND DRUMS.  CONTAMINATED SOILS WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE SURFACE AND REMEDIATED.    AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT INDICATED 3 SEPARATE EQUIPMENT FAILURES.  THE PILOT CONTROLLED RELIEF VALVE OPENED DURING AN OPERATIONAL BACK-PRESSURE EVENT SEVERAL HOURS PRIOR TO THE TANK OVERFLOW AND APPARENTLY DID NOT FULLY RESEAT.  THIS ALLOWED PRODUCT TO CONTINUE TO DELIVER INTO THE RELIEF TANK.  A SECOND EQUIPMENT FAILURE INVOLVED THE RELIEF VALVE ACTIVATION ALARM MICRO SWITCH.  THIS DEVICE WAS FROZEN OPEN AND DID NOT ALERT THE OPERATOR TO THE FACT THAT THE RELIEF VALVE HAD OPENED.  THE THIRD DEVICE TO NOT FUNCTION PROPERLY WAS THE TANK SIDE-GAUGER THAT HAD THE STEEL TAPE FROZEN, THEREBY NOT INDICATING ANY CHANGE IN TANK VOLUME.  A FOURTH DEVICE, AN INDEPENDENT ROOF TOP ALARM PROVIDED THE ONLY ALARM TO THE OPERATOR.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: FAILURE OCCURRED IN WELD LOCATED 50 FT FROM THE BANK OF THE KENTUCKY RIVER.  THE FAILURE IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY SOIL SUBSIDENCE WHICH WAS CAUSED BY HIGH WATER.  THE SOIL SUBSIDENCE EXERTED FORCE ON THE WELD, CAUSING IT TO CRACK.  FAILED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGIES FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE OPS FAILURE ANALYSIS PROTOCOL IS BEING USED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES.  LEAK VOLUMES ARE STILL ESTIMATES SUBJECT TO UPWARD REVISION.   5-11-05 THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS TAKEN BY CC TECHNOLOGIES (CCT) TO THEIR FACILITY FOR A FAILURE ANALYSIS.  THE RESULT OF THE FAILURE ANALYSIS CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF A THROUGH-WALL CRACK IN THE 22" GIRTH WELD.  THE CRACK EXTENDED FOR 2:30 TO THE 8:00 ORIENTATION, LOOKING DOWNSTREAM, ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE.  CCT CONCLUDED THAT THERE WERE THREE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE PIPELINE FAILURE AS FOLLOWS: "IN CONCLUSION, THE THREE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS IN THE PIPELINE FAILURE WERE A BENDING STRESS ON THE PIPE CAUSED BY SEVERE FLOODING OF THE NEARBY KENTUCKY RIVER, A POOR QUALITY GIRTH WELD EXHIBITED BY POROSITY AND OR INCLUSIONS IN THE WELD AS WELL AS SECONDARY CRACKS AT THE WELD BASE, AND AN OFFSET BETWEEN THE TWO SECTIONS JOINED BY THE FAILED GIRTH WELD." CCT ALSO POINTS OUT THAT "THE WELD QUALITY IS TYPICAL FOR THIS PIPE VINTAGE AND WOULD NOT HAVE POSED A PROBLEM IN THE ABSENCE OF OUTSIDE BENDING FORCES."
