column245: AT 9:00 P.M. FEBRUARY 3 2005, A RELEASE WAS FOUND AT THE SANTA PAULA STATION.  IT WAS FIRST THOUGHT AND REPORTED TO BE A SEAL FAILURE ON A PUMP.  WHEN THE AREA WAS SECURED AND CHECKED WITH THE PROPER EQUIPMENT AND ACCESS INTO THE STATION WAS PERMITTED, IT WAS FOUND THAT THERE WAS NOT A SEAL FAILURE BUT THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE STATION DRAIN SYSTEM.  IT WAS FOUND THAT A FOREIGN OBJECT HAD LODGED UNDER THE SEAT OF A 1 1/2 INCH CHECK VALVE.  THIS ALLOWED THE SUMP TO FILL AND FLUID TO BACK IN THE DRAINS AND GROUND FOR THE STORAGE TANK THAT THE SUMP WAS LINED UP TO.

column241: ROY BRIDGE, MANAGER PIPELINE SAFETY - PACIFIC
column245: ON FEBRUARY 7, 2005 THE USCG NOTIFIED KINDER MORGAN THAT A SHEEN IN THE OAKLAND ESTUARY HAD BEEN IDENTIFIED AS JET FUEL AND THAT IT WAS COMING FROM A STORM DRAIN OUTFALL.  KINDER MORGAN'S PIPELINE CROSSES THE STORM DRAIN IN SEVERAL PLACES UPSTREAM OF THE OUTFALL.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN AND THE KINDER MORGAN EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  THE KM EMERGENCY RESPONDERS PARTICIPATED IN THE UNIFIED COMMAND WITH COAST GUARD AND OTHER AGENCIES TO INVESTIGATE AND SEARCH FOR THE PIPELINE LEAK.  KINDER MORGAN NOTIFIED THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER (NRC) OF THE SUSPECTED RELEASE AT 20:39 HOURS ON 2/7/05 (NRC CASE NUMBER 749476).  AFTER NUMEROUS EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES FAILED TO IDENTIFY THE LEAK SOURCE, THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED WITH NITROGEN AND TRACER GAS USED TO LOCATE THE POINT OF THE JET FUEL; AT APPROXIMATELY 03:30 HOURS ON 2/11/05 THE RELEASE SITE WAS LOCATED.  THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE SITE IDENTIFICATION AT 03:41 HOURS ON 2/11/05.  THE ON-SITE PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATES THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO FAILURE OF PREVIOUSLY DAMAGED PIPE; NUMEROUS SCRATCHES AND LONGITUDINAL CREASES WERE FOUND INDICATING PREVIOUS MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  THE DAMAGED PORTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND WILL UNDERGO METALLURGICAL EXAMINATION.

column30: OTHER
column245: ON DECEMBER 22, 2004 A CONTRACT EMPLOYEE WORKING AT THE MOTIVA PORT ARTHUR REFINERY DISCOVERED AN UNDERGROUND PIPELINE LEAK AT THE INTERSECTION OF TERMINAL ROAD AND MLK IN PORT ARTHUR, TEXAS.  THE PORT ARTHUR POLICE DEPARTMENT WAS NOTIFIED TO BLOCK OFF THE ROAD AND EXCAVATION OF THE PIPELINE BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  A PINHOLE IN THE 16" DOCK LINE WAS FOUND TO BE LEAKING FUEL OIL.  THE LINE WAS MANUALLY BLOCKED IN BY PRODUCTION PERSONNEL AND TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL THE REPAIRS COULD BE COMPLETED.  ALL LIQUIDS WERE PICKED UP BY VACUUM TRUCKS AND TRANSPORTED TO THE REFINERY.  AREAS OF LOCALIZED PITTING WERE DISCOVERED DURING VISUAL EXAMINATION OF THE LINE OVER A DISTANCE OF APPROXIMATELY 500 FEET.  THIS LINE IS UNDER CATHODIC PROTECTION, BUT THE DEPTH OF COVER IS LESS THAN 12 INCHES WHICH MAY HAVE ALLOWED ATMOSPHERIC CORROSION.  A TOTAL OF 500 FEET OF PIPELINE WERE REPLACED BEFORE THE LINE WAS PUT BACK IN SERVICE ON JANUARY 18, 2005.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM CAUSED A PURCHASE POWER INTERRUPTION ON THE SYSTEM.  THE SYSTEM RESPONDED APPROPRIATELY UNTIL A HI LIQUID LEVEL SWITCH THAT WOULD HAVE SHUT IN THE FLOW OF CRUDE OIL TO THE TANK FAILED.  THE TANK OVERFILLED AND APPROXIMATLEY 5 BBLS OF CRUDE SPILLED ONTO THE GROUND.  INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT THE PRIMARY HIGH LEVEL TRANSMITTER FOR THE TANK DID NOT FUNCTION AS INTENDED ALLOWING THE FLOW TO CONTINUE INTO THE TANK.  WE FOUND FIELD WIRING WRAPPED AROUND THE MECHANICAL LINKAGE INSIDE THE INSTRUMENT'S ENCLOSURE THUS JAMMING THE TRANSMITTER.  THE SECONDARY TANK HIGH LIQUID LEVEL DEVISE ALSO DID NOT PROVIDE THE INTENDED SHUTDOWN DUE TO A BLOWN FUSE.  PRESENTLY, ALL ASSOCIATED MECHANICAL, ELECTRICAL AND LOGIC ISSUES WHICH CONTRIBUTED TO THE FAILURE OF THESE LEVEL DEVICES HAVE BEEN CORRECTED. THE SYSTEM HAS BEEN TESTED AND PLACED BACK INTO OPERATIONS.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULTORY COMP
column245: THE RELEASE OCCURRED IN THE STATION MANIFOLD.  SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS FROM THE TOP OF A 6" CHECK VALVE, JUST DOWNSTREAM OF A METER.  THE METER HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY ISOLATED BY CLOSING A VALVE, APPROXIMATELY 4' DOWNSTREAM OF THE CHECK VALVE.  IT IS THEORIZED THAT CLOSURE OF THIS DOWNSTREAM VALVE, SUBJECTED THE CHECK VALVE, AND 4' SEGMENT OF PIPE TO THERMAL PRESSURE BUILD-UP.  THIS THERMAL PRESSURE CAUSED THE O-RING IN THE CHECK VALVE TO FAIL, AND THE RELEASE WAS THEN FUELED BY THE DISCHARGE OF THE STATION BOOSTER PUMP.  NOTE: ON PART C, NUMBER 5(A) "ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT POINT AND TIME OF ACCIDENT" IS BEING REPORTED AS 1400 PSI.  THIS PRESSURE WAS NOT RECORDED BUT IS DERIVED FROM A CALCULATION BASED ON WHAT COULD HAVE HAPPENED, GIVEN THAT CLOSURE OF THE VALVE COULD HAVE BLOCKED IN AN APPROXIMATE 4-FOOT SECTION OF PIPE, ALONG WITH THE CHECK VALVE, IF, THE VALVE AND CHECK PROPERLY SEALED.  THE 1400 PSI ESTIMATE WAS BASED ON A 19 DEGREE RISE IN TEMPERATURE OF MEDIUM BLOCKED IN THE CHECK VALVE AND SEGMENT OF PIPE.     4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW.  FAILURE OCCURRED IN A VALVE, WHICH IS A COMPONENT.  SMYS IS NOT APPLICABLE IN THIS SITUATION; THEREFORE, "O" WAS CHANGED TO A BLANK FIELD.  SEAL FAILURE TYPE WAS CHANGED FROM GASKET TO O-RING BASED ON A RE-EVALUATION OF THE INFORMATION PREVIOUSLY PRESENTED IN THE NARRATIVE.

column245: THE OUTSTATION PREVIEW GRAVITOMER ASSOCIATED WITH EXPLORER PIPELINE¿S 24 INCH LINE IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM OF THE WOOD RIVER (HARTFORD), ILLINOIS TANK FARM EXPERIENCED A 30 BARREL RELEASE OF DIESEL FUEL ON MARCH 2, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 13:00 HOURS.  THE MICROPUMP GRAVITOMETER MALFUNCTIONED CAUSING THE SHAFT TO WEAR A HOLE AT THE END OF THE GRAVITOMER PUMP HOUSING.  IT WAS DETERMINED DURING THE INVESTIGATION THAT THE MALFUNCTION OF THE GRAVITOMETER WAS CAUSED FROM A REBUILT PUMP THAT WAS MISSING A SHAFT SPRING.        NOTE:   PART D - MATERIAL SPECIFICATION 2. WALL THICKNESS IS .281.  REPORTING SYSTEM WILL NOT ALLOW THE FULL WALL THICKNESS OF .281 TO BE SAVED.

column245: THE PLAINS CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM THE LONGVIEW FIRE DEPARTMENT STATING THAT THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL IN A STORM DRAIN AND THE SMELL OF GAS WAS PRESENT.  THE PLAINS CONTROL CENTER CALLED THE GAUGER WHO WENT TO THE SITE AND CALLED THE PLAINS CONTROL CENTER TO SHUT DOWN THE ARKLATEX MAIN LINE.  AT FIRST IT DID NOT APPEAR THAT THE LEAK WAS FROM THE PLAINS PIPELINE. AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THE LEAK WAS PROBABLY DUE FROM OUR PIPELINE.  THEN A DECISION WAS MADE TO PURGE A 700 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE AND INSTALL NEW PIPE BY BORING UNDER THE ROAD.  THE SITUATION WAS DISCUSSED WITH THE LONGVIEW FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THEY WERE NOT CONCERNED DUE TO THE SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL DISCHARGED. THE SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL WAS CLEANED UP AND THE STORM DRAINS WERE MONITORED.

column238: FAILURE OF AN OLD REPAIR CLAMP OVER A GIRTH WELD.    LOCAL PERSONEL BELIEVE THE REPAIR WAS MADE WHEN THE REFINERY OWNED AND OPERATED THE LINE.  UNKNOWN WHEN THE CLAMP REPAIR WAS MADE. column241: KENNETH L LYBARGER, SR COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR
column245: TENANT FARMING THE PROPERTY DISCOVERED DEAD VEGETATION IN VICINITY OF THE LINE AND NOTIFIED MAGELLAN PIPELINE COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER, WHICH CONTACTED LOCAL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE.  SIMULTANEOUSLY, OPERATIONS CONTROL BEGAN CLOSELY MONITORING THE PRESSURE ON THIS AND THE TWO ADJACENT MAGELLAN PIPELINES.  FIELD PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE STAIN AND BEGAN EXCAVATING THE LINE TO MAKE A PHYSICAL EXAMINATION.  A PHYSICAL INSPECTION INDICATED A SEEPER IN THE VICINITY OF THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM.  A TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS MADE BY WELDING ON A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE, AND LATER THE SECTION OF THE PIPE WAS REMOVED AND SENT TO A METALLURGICAL COMPANY FOR ANALYSIS.  PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY INSTALLING A PIECE OF PRE-TESTED PIPE; ALL WELDS WERE NON-DESTRUCTIVELY INSPECTED.  CONTAMINATED SOIL IS BEING MITIGATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE ENVIRONMENTAL INSTRUCTIONS AND PROCEDURES. METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT TWO MANUFACTORING DEFECTS IN THE ERW SEAM LINKED UP TO FORM THE DEFECT CAUSING THE RELEASE, WHICH WAS CLASSIFIED AS A RARE COINCIDENCE.

column245: AT 11:15 AM ON MARCH 7, 2005 WORKERS IN A PECAN ORCHARD REPORTED AN ICE UPHEAVAL ALONG A SHORT SECTION OF OUR R/W. A LEAK WAS CONFIRMED & M/L GATE VALVES WERE CLOSED BOTH UP AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE LEAK SITE. THE AREA WAS CHECKED WITH GAS DETECTORS AND CORDONED OF ACCORDINGLY. A NITROGEN DISPLACEMENT SERVICE COMPANY WAS USED TO DISPLACE THE PROPANE IN THE VALVE SECTION CONTAINING THE LEAK. THE VALVE SECTION WAS THEN BLOWN DOWN OF NITROGEN PRESSURE AND THE ENTIRE JOINT OF PIPE CONTAINING THE DEFECT WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED. THE LEAKING ANOMALY APPEARED TO BE A MILL DEFECT THAT DID NOT AFFECT THE SEAM. IT HAS BEEN SENT TO A METALLURGICAL LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS. 7-13-05 WITH INFORMATION DISCOVERED AFTER ORIGINAL SUBMITTAL, KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, INC. DETERMINED THE LEAK TO HAVE BEEN CAUGHT BY THE CATHODIC PROTECTION RECTIFIER INFLUENCING THIS AREA HAVING ITS POLARITY REVERSED FROM NORMAL. THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT OF PRODUCT LOST WAS BASED UPON CONSIDERATION OF THE SQUARE AREA OF THE PIPE WALL PENETRATION.

column47: RESPONSE COST, RECOVERY, CLEANUP, CONTRACT LABOR
column245: ON MARCH 30, 2005 AT 8:00 P.M. LIGHTNING STRUCK CRUDE OIL STORAGE TANK # 2734 AT MPLCO'S PATOKA, ILLINOIS  TANK FARM, CAUSING A FIRE THAT DESTROYED/CONSUMED 486 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL AND SEVERELY DAMAGED THE TANK SHELL AND ROOF.  THERE WERE NO INJURIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS INCIDENT.  DURING THE NIGHT OF THE INCIDENT, LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENTS APPLIED WATER TO THE EXTERIOR OF THE TANK IN AN ATTEMPT TO KEEP IT COOL.  CONTRACTORS FROM WILLIAMS FIRE AND HAZARD FLEW TO THE SITE THE MORNING OF MARCH 31, 2005.  FOAM WAS APPLIED TO EXTINGUISH THE FLAMES AND THE FIRE WAS SUCCESSFULLY PUT OUT AT 2:00 P.M. ON MARCH 31, 2005 AFTER BURNING FOR EIGHTEEN HOURS.   NO FIRE-FIGHTING WATER/FOAM WAS SPRAYED OUTSIDE #2734; OR THAT NO FOAM / OIL WAS ALLOWED OUTSIDE OF THE TANK AFTERWARDS. THE STORMWATER (FIRE-FIGHTING WATER SPRAYED ON THE EXTERIOR OF #2734) RESULTS REVEAL NO LEAD, NO OIL & GREASE; THIS STORMWATER WAS ALLOWED TO GRAVITY DRAIN BACK TO THE ON-SITE PONDS.    ALL APPROPRIATED FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES WERE PROMPTLY NOTIFIED.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 12:30 PM CST WHILE EXCAVATING A DENT ANOMALY FOR THE PIPELINE INTEGRITY GROUP AT MP 379.1562 ON LINE 6A, AN OIL SHEEN BECAME VISIBLE ON TOP OF GROUND WATER WITHIN THE BELL HOLE. GARY HEIKKINEN (ENBRIDGE SITE INSPECTOR) IMMEDIATELY CALLED THE CONTROL CENTER AND HAD THE PIPELINE SHUT DOWN. ROBERTS PIPELINE WAS THE CONTRACTOR EXCAVATING AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. TOTAL VOLUME OUT OF PIPE WAS ESTIMATED AT 5 BARRELS.    AN INDEPENDENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANT WAS HIRED TO TAKE AND ANALYZE PERIODIC SOIL SAMPLES. RESULTS WERE USED TO DETERMINE SOIL REMOVAL. FINAL SAMPLES SHOWED NO SOIL CONTAMINATION REMAINED AT THE SITE. ALL OIL CONTAMINATED MATERIAL WAS TRANSPORTED TO A WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY.    THE CAUSE FOR THIS LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO HAVE RESULTED FROM A DENT IN THE PIPE THAT SUSTAINED ROCK DAMAGE AFTER IT WAS PLACED INTO SERVICE. A PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED OVER THE DEFECT AND WAS WELDED INTO PLACE FOR A PERMANENT REPAIR.

column245: AIR PATROL CALLED POSSIBLE LEAK IN TO DON CULBERTSON ON MARCH 17, 2005.  PLAINS PIPELINE AND CONTRACT PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE INCIDENT SITE TO EFFECT CLEAN UP EFFORTS.  CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED OF INCIDENT AND ALL PUMPING ACTIVITY CEASED AT APPROX 1:35PM.  WE ARRIVED AT INCIDENT TO FIND APPRX 1 BBLS OF CRUDE ON A NO NAME CREEK.  THE LINE WAS EXPOSED AND A TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS MADE.  EARTH DAMS AND BOOMS WERE USED TO CONTAIN SPILL.  USING ABSORBENT MATERIAL AND SPAHG CRUDE WAS REMOVED FROM CREEK AND BAGGED FOR DISPOSAL.    REFERENCE PART C.3.G (PAGE 2 OF 4), HIGH RESOLUTION TOOL WAS RUN ON 2/21/05.  THE RESULTS WERE RECEIVED ON 4/4/05 WHICH WAS AFTER THE LEAK ON 3/17/05

column241: KENNETH DAVID BORN, DIRECTOR REGULATORY COMPLIANCE
column245: TWO INDIVIDUALS DRIVING FOUR WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLES BECAME STUCK WHILE DRIVING DOWN A LOW POINT ON A DIRT ROAD PARALLELING LDPL'S PIPELINE ROW.  A RUBBER TIRE FRONT END LOADER WAS BROUGHT TO THE SITE TO PULL OUT THE STUCK VEHICLES.  IT WAS SUCCESSFUL IN PULLING OUT OF THE FIRST VEHICLE.  WHILE REPOSITIONING TO PULL OUT THE SECOND VEHICLE THE LOADER DROVE OUT ON THE PIPELINE ROW AND GOT STUCK.  THE OPERATOR PUT THE BUCKET DOWN TO TRY AND PULL ITS SELF OUT.  WHILE DOING THIS THE BUCKET REPEATEDLY CAME INTO CONTACT WITH THE 4" LDPL PIPELINE CAUSING SEVERAL SCRAPES AND GOUGES.  EVENTUALLY ONE OF THESE CONTACTS CAUSED THE PIPE TO FAIL RESULTING IN THE RELEASE AND IGNITION OF NGL PRODUCT.  THE LOADER WAS A TOTAL LOSS.

column245: THE CONSTRUCTION DEFECT (ARC BURN) CRACKED AND BEGAN TO LEAK CAUSING A FROST PATCH VISABLE AT THE SURFACE.  REPAIR WAS DONE BY STOPPLE AND CUT OUT OF THE ENTIRE 56 FT OF PIPE.  THE SAMPLE SPECIMEN WAS SUBMITTED BY EPOLP TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR TESTING AND ANALYSIS.  THE FINAL REPORT CONCLUDED THAT AN ARC STRIKE CAUSED AXIAL CRACKS TO OCCUR IN THE FUSED METAL. ONE CRACK WAS ENLARGED BY FATIGUE UNTIL THE PIPE WALL WAS BREACHED AND THE PIPE LEAKED.

column245: TENANT FARMING LAND PUNCTURED LINE WHILE INSTALLING DRAIN TILE.  TENANT DID NOT MAKE A ONE-CALL LINE LOCATE REQUEST.  MAGELLAN OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IN TULSA DETECTED THE PRESSURE DROP, IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE LINE, AND CALLED OUT FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE.  FIELD PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENTED EMERGENCY PROCEDURES.  THE LINE WAS PROMPTLY REPAIRED AND THE SOIL WAS REMEDIATED UNDER THE AUSPICES OF, AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH, DIRECTIONS FROM THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 09:00 HOURS, MARCH 7, 2005, COMPANY OPERATIONS WAS NOTIFIED BY ENTERPRISE FIELD PERSONNEL THAT THERE WAS POSSIBLY A LEAK IN THE AREA OF THE HOUSTON 12" REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE ROW.  COMPANY FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND LOCATED THE LEAK.  THE CONTROL ROOM SHUT THE LINE DOWN AT 10:00 HRS AND FIELD PERSONNEL CALLED OUT RESPONSE EQUIPMENT.  THE LEAK WAS BLOCKED IN WHILE CONTAINMENT AND EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN.  THE LEAKSITE IS LOCATED IN A PLOWED FIELD THAT WAS WET AND MUDDY FROM THE PREVIOUS DAY'S RAIN.  THE LINE WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A PIPELINE CLAMP AND RESTARTED AT 17:00 HRS.  EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NRC AND THE RRC AT 10:45 HRS AND 11:07 HRS RESPECTIVELY.  ON MARCH 23, 2005, PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE WITH REPLACEMENT OF 51' OF NEW 5L X-42, 0.250 WT PIPE PREVIOUSLY HYDROTESTED TO 1440 PSIG.  THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO FULL OPERATION.  ENVIRONMENT ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION AS WELL AS LAND DAMAGE SETTLEMENT IS UNDERWAY. THE SEGMENT OF PIPE CONTAINING THE DEFECT WAS SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LAB FOR ANALYSIS ON MARCH 29, 2005.  THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE REMAINS UNKNOWN.      UPDATE AS TO CAUSE 8/21/06 LAB ANALYSIS BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, INC. CONCLUDES THAT A WELD DEFECT IN THE ERW WELD FROM THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS FAILED DUE TO DETERIORATION BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM BODY OF PIPE TO PIPE SEAM, PER KIEFNER REPORT.

column238: LEAK IN ROOF DRAIN LINE
column241: RICHARD S PETERSEN, MANAGER OF OPERATIONS
column245: THE STATION OPERATOR DISCOVERED THE OIL IN THE TANK DIKE OF TANK 344 DURING HIS MORNING ROUNDS.  DURING THE PREVIOUS NIGHT, A LEAK HAD DEVELOPED IN THE ROOF DRAIN LINE IN TANK #344 ALLOWING OIL IN THE TANK TO DRAIN OUT INTO THE TANK DIKE THRU THE ROOF DRAIN LINE.  UPON DISCOVERY, THE ROOF DRAIN VALVE WAS CLOSED AND THE TANK WAS PUMPED OUT.  TO DATE, THE TANK HAS NOT BEEN CLEANED; THEREFORE, WE HAVE NOT ENTERED THE TANK TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE DRAIN LINE FAILURE.     10/28/2005 - THE TANK HAS BEEN TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND IS NO LONGER IN USE.  NO FURTHER INFORMATION ON WHAT MAY HAVE CAUSED THE ROOF DRAIN TO LEAK.

column241: STEVE MAROSITZ, MANAGER PIPELINE SAFETY - PACIFIC REGION
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 11:15 HOURS PST ON 04/01/05, A SKIER NOTIFIED KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL AT ROCKLIN STATION THAT HE SMELLED A GASOLINE ODOR ON DONNER SUMMIT. THE ROCKLIN OPERATOR CONTACTED KINDER MORGAN'S CONTROL CENTER.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND KINDER MORGAN'S LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  THE OES AND NRC WERE NOTIFIED. SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS A CRACK ASSOCIATED WITH MECHANICAL DAMAGE CONSISTENT WITH AN INTENTIONAL ATTEMPT TO BEND THE PIPE.  THE EXACT TIME AND VOLUME OF THE RELEASE IS UNKNOWN.  THE EXACT TIME OF THE FAILURE IS UNKNOWN, THEREFORE, THE ACTUAL OPERATING PRESSURE AT TIME OF FAILURE IS UNKNOWN.  THE 1997 GEOMETRY TOOL RUN WAS TO ENSURE PASSAGE OF THE MFL TOOL ONLY.  CRACK ASSOCIATED WITH MECHANICAL DAMAGE DURING CONSTRUCTION.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A LINE FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE VICINITY OF MENDICANT ISLAND IN SOUTH LOUISIANA AT APPROXIMATELY 2:29 PM ON APRIL 19, 2005 ON EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY'S ("EMPCO'S") GRAND ISLE TO LITTLE LAKE 12" CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE GRAND ISLE OPERATOR ON DUTY AND HIS FIELD SUPERVISOR, BOTH PRESENT AT THE TIME, IMMEDIATELY DECIDED TO SHUTDOWN WHEN INDICATIONS OF FLOWRATE INCREASE AND CORRESPONDING PRESSURE DECREASE ON THE LINE WERE NOTED. STEPS WERE IMMEDIATELY TAKEN TO INVESTIGATE A POTENTIAL RELEASE AND OIL SPILL RESPONDERS WERE NOTIFIED TO BE ON STANDBY. A HELICOPTER WAS MOBILIZED TO THE AREA, AND A BOAT WAS DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE.  OIL ON THE WATER WAS CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY 3:00 PM.  OIL SPILL RESPONSE EQUIPMENT WAS IMMEDIATELY MOBILIZED AND APPROPRIATE REGULATORY REPORTING WAS DONE.    THIS INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION.    NOTES:   1.)ITEM 19A OF THIS FORM IS UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME.  THE FAILED SECTION WILL UNDERGO METALLURGICAL TESTING TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  THE ANSWER "MATERIAL DEFECT" IS A GUESS.  THIS IS A REQUIRED FIELD.  2.)THE PIPELINE IS STILL SHUT DOWN AT THE TIME OF THIS FILING.  IT IS UNCLEAR WHEN THE LINE WILL BE RETURNED TO SERVICE.

column238: BOLTS ON STOPPLE TEE WERE LOOSE ALLOWING PRODUCT TO SEEP OUT.
column245: ON MAY 19, 2005, AN EMPLOYEE OF THE OAK BROOK FIRE DEPARTMENT NOTICED A SHEEN ON SURFACE WATER NEXT TO THE ROADWAY WHERE HE WAS BICYCLING.  THE OAK BROOK FIRE DEPARTMENT CALLED THE WEST SHORE PIPE LINE EMERGENCY PHONE NUMBER WHO THEN IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 ON THE 19TH.  LOCAL WEST SHORE PERSONNEL WERE THEN NOTIFIED AND PROCEEDED TO THE SITE.  EMERGENCY RESPONDERS WERE CALLED OUT.  ON MAY 20, 2005, THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE AT A STOPPLE TEE.  BOLTS ON THE BLIND OF THE STOPPLE WERE LOOSE AND PRODUCT WAS SEEPING AROUND THE BLIND GASKET.  A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED AND THE BLIND WAS BOLTED DOWN.  A PRESSURE TEST WAS CONDUCTED.  A DOT REPRESENTATIVE ON SITE ACCEPTED THE RESULTS OF THE PRESSURE TEST AND AUTHORIZED THE RESTARTING OF THE PIPELINE AT 1605 ON THE 20TH.

column245: ON THURSDAY, MAY 5, 2005 AT 1710 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS OVERFILLED TANK 133 WHICH IS LOCATED AT BUCKEYE¿S EAST CHICAGO TERMINAL.  EXPLORER PIPE LINE WAS CALLED TO SHUTDOWN ITS PIPELINE WHICH WAS DELIVERING TO THE TANK AND PRODUCT WAS TRANSFERRED FROM TANK 133 TO TANK 134.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.   THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE INCORRECT OPERATION.  DURING THE DELIVERY OF PRODUCT INTO TANK 133 THE SCADA HIGH LEVEL ALARM ACTIVATED AT 1611 HOURS AND THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED THE STATION OPERATOR TO CONFIRM THE ALARM.  AT THAT TIME THE STATION OPERATOR INFORMED THE CONTROL CENTER THAT THE ALARM WAS NOT ACCURATE.  THE STATION OPERATOR DETERMINED THAT THE HIGH LEVEL ALARM WAS INCORRECT BASED ON THE OPENING ELECTRONIC AND HAND GAUGING THAT WAS PERFORMED PRIOR TO THE START OF THE DELIVERY.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE AGENCY WAS NOT NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY.  BUCKEYE¿S FIELD PERSONNEL THOUGHT THE TANK WAS UNDER EPA JURISDICTION (STORAGE TANK) AND NOT UNDER DOT JURISDICTION (BREAKOUT TANK).  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE AGENCY WAS NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY AFTER BUCKEYE¿S FIELD PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED THAT TANK 133 WAS UNDER DOT JURISDICTION.

column245: APPROXIMATELY 0645 ON 05/02/05 A THIRD PARTY OC NURSERY EMPLOYEE REPORTED THE RELEASE.  AT 0650 WATSON PERSONNEL CONTACTED ORCC REGARDING THE LA RIVER WEST BLOCK VALVE LEAKING FROM A VALVE BOX LOCATED WITHIN THE OC NURSERY.  OES WAS ADVISED AT 0658, CASE NUMBER 05-2619 WAS ASSIGNED.  NRC WAS ADVISED AT 0825, CASE NUMBER 757427 WAS GIVEN.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND KINDER MORGAN'S LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS A CRACK AT THE THREADS OF THE 1" NIPPLE OF THE SENSING LINE OF THE LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM.  THE EXACT TIME AND VOLUME OF THE RELEASE IS UNKNOWN.  THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT THE POINT AND TIME OF THE ACCIDENT IS UNKNOWN BECAUSE THE TIME OF THE ACCIDENT IS UNKNOWN.  **PART C 3 (E&F) AN INTERNAL INSPECTION (ILI) WAS RUN ON THE MAINLINE PIPE IN 1999 AND AGAIN IN 2004.  THE 1" PRESSURE SENSING LINE THAT FAILED WAS NOT INCLUDED IN THOSE INSPECTIONS.

column241: DONALD E HANKEY, REGULATORY COMPLIANCE ADMINISTRATOR
column245: ON FRIDAY, APRIL 29, 2005 AT 0900 HOURS, A BUCKEYE GULF COAST EMPLOYEE WAS DRIVING BY THE LNVA CANAL AND NOTICED A WATER SPRAY IN THE AREA OF WHERE THE 406 PIPELINE CROSSED THE CANAL.  THE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER AND THEY CONFIRMED THAT A PRESSURE DROP HAD JUST OCCURRED ON THE 406 PIPELINE.  HUNTSMAN'S AND BUCKEYE'S SUPERVISORS WERE NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY AND THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  THE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES WERE CLOSED AND THE PIPELINE WAS FLARED.  AT 1400 HOURS, NITROGEN WAS INJECTED INTO THE PIPELINE AND AT 1645 HOURS, THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS INERTED.  SKILLETS WERE PLACED AT BOTH VALVE SITES TO ISOLATE THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE.  AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE PORT ARTHUR FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENTS RESPONDED AND CLOSED HIGHWAY 73, WHICH RUNS PARALLEL TO THE CANAL.  AT 1645 HOURS, THE HIGHWAY WAS REOPENED.  ALL PRODUCT THAT WAS RELEASED EVAPORATED AND NO ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE OCCURRED.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS RECOVERED ON WEDNESDAY, MAY 4, 2005 AND THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE BY THE OUTSIDE FORCE.  BUCKEYE HAD NO WAY OF DETERMINING WHO OR HOW THE PIPELINE WAS DAMAGED.  THE CANAL WAS RE-BORED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO THE OPERATION ON FRIDAY, MAY 6, 2005.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: THIS LEAK WAS DISCOVERED IN A GIRTH WELD.  REPAIR MADE USING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT BOLT-ON SLEEVE.  THE VOLUME REPORTED INCLUDES THE BLOW DOWN VOLUME FOR REMOVING A SEGMENT OF PIPE PURSUANT TO AN INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT ASSESSMENT THAT WAS SCHEDULED SOON AFTER THE REPAIR OF THE LEAK.  DETAILS: ON MAY 22, 2005, A LAND OWNER (TOM MARTIN) CALLED IN A DEAD SPOT IN HIS FIELD AT 19:00.  THE AREA FIELD TECH DARIN SHULISTA CALLED DAVE ANDERSON, AREA COM, AT 19:30 TO DISCUSS THE LEAK ISSUE WITH THE AREA SUPERVISOR, TIM SCHUTT. DAVE WENT TO LEAK SITE WITH TIM AND DARIN AND HAND DUG TO WITHIN 12" OF LINE AND TESTED WITH A LEL METER AND PICKED UP LESS THAN 10% LEL.  OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS NOTIFIED AND THEY BLOCKED IN THE LINE SECTION.  ON MAY 23, 2005, A CONTRACTOR EXCAVATED THE SITE AND DISCOVERED A LEAKING GIRTH WELD AT STATION # 27798+75.  THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED USING A 6" BOLT-ON PLIDCO SLEEVE.  OPERATIONS CONTROL THEN PLACED THE LINE BACK IN NORMAL OPERATIONS.  MAY 26, 2005, 100' OF LINE SECTION WAS EXCAVATED TO CUTOUT THE REPAIRED SECTION.  A STOPPLE SITE WAS EXCAVATED AT STATION # 27800+82.  MAY 31, 2005, THE CONTRACTOR RECEIVED THE PIPE MATERIALS, WELDED UP AND HYDROTESTED THE REPLACEMENT SECTION, AND INSTALLED A 6" 900 ANSI STOPPLE FITTING WITH 2" TOR FITTING.  JUNE 1, 2005, THE CONTRACTOR TAPPED AND SET STOPPLE.  OPERATIONS EVACUATED 2348' OF 6" LINE WITH A VOLUME OF 81 BARRELS.  JUNE 2, 2005, OPERATIONS COMPLETED EVACUATION OF LINE WITH NITROGEN, REMOVED REPAIRED SECTION OF PIPE, INSTALLED NEW REPLACEMENT SECTION.  SYSTEM WAS PURGED AND STOPPLE REMOVED COMPLETING ALL PIPING WORK.  JUNE 3, 2005, CONTRACTOR COATED ALL PIPE AND FITTINGS, BACK FILLED AND CLEANED SITE.  JUNE 13, 2005, THE CUTOUT PIPE WAS SUBMITTED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC. FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS.      THE FINAL KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE LEAK WAS THE RESULT OF AN ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION GIRTH WELD DEFECT KNOWN AS "BURNTHROUGH".

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON MONDAY, MAY 23, 2005 AT 1540 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS WAS NOTIFIED BY A PROPERTY OWNER OF A POSSIBLE RELEASE.  THE PROPERTY OWNER REPORTED A WET SPOT OVER OUR PIPELINE ALONG WITH A SMELL OF GASOLINE.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  BUCKEYE¿S CONTROL CENTER SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE AT 1544 HOURS AND MONITORED PRESSURE.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE POSSIBLE RELEASE.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED TO BE IN THE AREA OF THE PIPE SEAM.  A PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR AND THE SITE WAS MANNED 24 HOURS A DAY UNTIL THE FINAL REPAIR WAS MADE.  THE MOP OF THIS PIPELINE SECTION WAS LOWERED TO 1,000 PSI FROM THE 1,440 PSI MOP.  THE FINAL REPAIR CONSISTED OF PURGING THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE AND REPLACING THE ENTIRE PIPE JOINT WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.     AT THIS TIME IT LOOKS LIKE THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE IS A MATERIAL DEFECT IN THE PIPE SEAM.  NO CORROSION WAS FOUND IN THE AREA OF THE RELEASE.  THE ENTIRE PIPE JOINT WAS SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR FURTHER DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE.  ONCE BUCKEYE RECEIVES KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FINAL REPORT THIS 7000-1 REPORT WILL BE UPDATED TO REFLECT ITS FINDINGS.  THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE A MANUFACTURES MATERIAL DEFECT IN THE PIPE SEAM.

column245: A LANDOWNER REPORTED THE LEAK.  THE EPOLP OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS NOTIFIED FROM THE NUMBER ON THE LINE MARKER.  THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN BY OPERATIONS CONTROL.  FIELD PERSONNEL INVESTIGATED AND ISOLATED THE MANUAL UPSTREAM VALVE.  THE REMOTE DOWNSTREAM VALVE WAS OPERATED AND SHUT BY OPERATIONS CONTROL.  THE NEXT DAY THE LEAK WAS EXCAVATED, LOCATED AND A TEMPORARY SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE.  SUBSEQUENTLY THE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR ANALYSIS. THE FINAL KIEFNER REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS MECHANICAL DAMAGE CONSISTING OF A LONGITUDINALLY ORIENTED GOUGE WIHIN A DENT.  INCIDENTAL STRESS-CORROSION CRACKING WAS OBSERVED IN THE GOUGE THAT WOULD NOT HAVE OCCURRED WITHOUT DAMAGE TO THE COATING.    EXPLANATION:  G.3  ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION - ACTUALLY UNKNOWN.                C.5.A  ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT POINT AND TIME - THE LINE WAS DOWN  WITH ONLY MINIMAL PRESSURE.

column241: EDWARD "BUZZ" FANT, DIRECTOR - COMPLIANCE CODE AND STANDARDS
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 0652 OUR DEMING STATION SHUT DOWN AS A RESULT OF A POWER DISRUPTION.  THIS EVENT CAUSED A SLACK LINE CONDITION BETWEEN OUR EL PASO AND DEMING STATIONS.  OUR OPERATOR AT OUR EL PASO STATION ATTEMPTED TO REPACK THE LINE BY STARTING OUR UPSTREAM EL PASO STATION.  AT APPROXIMATELY 0741 FIELD PERSONNEL DECIDED TO SHUT DOWN EL PASO STATION BECAUSE THE LINE PACK OPERATION WAS NOT RESULTING IN A SIGNFICANT RISE IN LINE PRESSURE.  WE SUBSEQUENTLY ACTIVATED OUR EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES, DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO START PATROLLING THE PIPELINE, AND NOTIFIED FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES.  AT 1117 THE LINE RIDER REPORTED VAPORS AND CONFIRMED LEAK LOCATION.  ALL AGENCIES WERE THEN UPDATED.  *ESTIMATED TIME UNTIL AREA WAS MADE SAFE IS THE TIME FROM DISCOVERY UNTIL THE ALAMAGARDO BLOCK VALVE WAS CLOSED.  **ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS THE TIME FROM THE INITIAL PRESSURE DROP UNTIL THE ALMAGORDO BLOCK VALVE WAS CLOSED.

column245: 10/15/2008    THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A SMALL HOLE IN THE PIPE AT AN UNEXPOSED SECTION SUBJECT TO CORROSION.  THE PIPE SECTION WAS REPAIRED. OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT, THE MAJORITY WAS SUCCESSFULLY CONTAINED AND REMOVED FROM THE WATER. ADDITIONALLY, AND STAINED SOIL FROM THE WATER'S EDGE WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF PROPERLY.    THE SPILL AND RESULTING CLEANUP WERE HANDLED IN ACCORDANCE WITH NJ DEP OVERSIGHT (SPILL #05-05-31-1500-21).    THE BANK AREA AROUND THE PIPE SECTION WAS MONITORED FOR A PERIOD OF SEVERAL MONTHS TO VERIFY THAT NO ADDITIONAL OILS WERE BEING RELEASED.    THE SPILL IS CONSIDERED CLOSED AND NO FURTHER ACTION IS REQUIRED.

THE LEAK WAS DETERMINDED TO BE MINOR AND NOT DETRIMENTAL TO PUBLIC OR EMPLOYEE SAFETY.  THE SANTA FE COUNTY LEPC WAS NOTIFIED OF THE LEAK AND WAS MADE AWARE OF THE LOUD NOISE AND THAT THERE WAS NO THREAT TO THE PUBLIC. THE LEPC WAS AGAIN NOTIFIED WHEN OUR PERSONNEL WAS ABLE TO REPACK THE VALVE BU AND STOP THE LEAK.

column245: ON TUESDAY, JUNE 21, 2005, A BUCKEYE PARTNERS EMPLOYEE NOTICED A TRANSMIX/WATER MIXTURE OF PRODUCT WAS LEAKING FROM A MANHOLE COVER IN THE AREA OF THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR.  THE EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED IMMEDIATELY.   AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A SMALL PINHOLE WAS DISCOVERED ON A 2¿ LINE THAT IS USED TO DRAIN WATER FROM THE TANKS TO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR.  IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE PINHOLE WAS EXTERNAL CORROSION.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF THE PIPE WAS CUTOUT AND REPLACED.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  CLEANUP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.

column245: DURING THE 3-YEAR ATMOSPHERIC CORROSION INSPECTION ACTIVITIES OF A MAIN LINE VALVE SITE THAT IS PARTIALLY ABOVE GROUND AND PARTIALLY BURIED, THE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL IDENTIFIED PETROLEUM SOIL CONTAMINATION AT THE VALVE SETTING LOCATED AT QUINN ROAD NEAR THE VILLAGE OF SAVONA IN STEUBEN COUNTY, NY. THE CREW BEGAN TO EXCAVATE THE SITE AND FOUND A WEEPING BURIED FLANGE, DRIPPING 5 TIMES PER MINUTE. THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN, DEPRESSURIZED AND THE FLANGE WAS TIGHTENED AND THE LEAK STOPPED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NYDEC PER THE NY STATE REGULATIONS. AN IMPACT ASSESSMENT WAS DONE INCLUDING A SERIES OF TEST PITS TO IDENTIFY THE EXTENT OF THE CONTAMINATION.  IMPACTED SOILS WERE IDENTIFIED AND DELINEATED. PREDOMINANT IMPACT WAS SOUTH OF THE VALVE SETTING, APPROXIMATELY 46 FEET FROM THE VALVE.  REMEDIATION INCLUDED SOIL EXCAVATION TO REMOVE CONTAMINATED SOIL MATERIALS.  AFTER COMPLETION OF THE REMEDIATION WORK, THE SITE WAS GRADED TO PLACE ALL PIPELINE FLANGE CONNECTIONS AND THE MAIN LINE VALVE ABOVE GROUND.  THE SITE FENCE WAS REINSTALLED AND BOLLARDS INSTALLED TO PROTECT THE PIPING FROM VEHICLE TRAFFIC.

column245: THE RELEASE OCCURRED WHEN AN INTERNAL THERMOWELL BROKE ON THE PUMP#3 ALLOWING VGO TO LEAK THROUGH ELECTRICAL CONDUITS TO AN ELECTICAL PANEL.  KPL OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISCOVERED THE RELEASE AND ACTIVATED KPL'S EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION SYSTEM ON 6/19/05.  KPL OPERATIONS PERSONNEL INITIALLY APPLIED ABSORBANT PADS TO THE SPILL AREA.  MILLER WAS CONTACTED AND RESPONDED WITH A VACUUM TRUCK AND RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 1 TO 1.5 BARRELS OF VGO.  MILLER THEN USED A BACKHOE TO EXCAVATE VGO IMPACTED SOIL.  ON 6/20/05 ARCADIS ARRIVED ON SITE (REMEDIATION CONTRACTOR) AND DIRECTED FURTHER EXCAVATION BY MILLER USING A BACKHOE AND HAND DIGGING.  THIRTEEN SAMPLES WERE TAKEN AND THE RESULTS INDICATED THAT FOUR GENERAL AREAS WOULD REQUIRE ADDITIONAL EXCAVATION.  THE FOUR AREAS ARE SCHEDULED TO BEGIN ON JULY 15, 2005.  AFTER EXCAVATION A SECOND ROUND OF SAMPLES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE IF FURTHER ACTIONS ARE NECESSARY.

column245: ON JUNE 27TH, 2005 AT APPROXIMATELY 9:15 AM THE CUSHING POLICE DEPARTMENT CONTACTED THE DRUMRIGHT DISTRICT AND INDICATED THEY HAD RECEIVED ODOR COMPLAINTS FROM AREA BUSINESSES LOCATED ADJACENT TO OUR LITTLE FARM STATION.  DARREN CLOUD AND DAVID YEAGER WERE SENT TO LITTLE FARM STATION TO INVESTIGATE.  AT 9:45 AM DARREN CLOUD VERIFIED A CRUDE OIL RELEASE.  ALL RELEASED CRUDE OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE DIKE OF TANK 70.  DARREN VERIFIED THAT THE TANK DIKE DRAIN WAS CLOSED THEN CONTACTED SEVERAL LOCAL VACUUM TRUCK COMPANIES FOR ASSISTANCE.    THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS INTERNAL CORROSIAN ON OUR 30" RECEIPT LINE.  TOTAL VOLUM RELEASED - 550 BBLS, TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED 535 BBLS.  RECOVERED FREE OIL WAS RETURNED TO THE SYSTEM AND IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED (~400 YDS).  IMPACTED SOIL TO BE REMEDIATED PER OCC RULES AND REGULATIONS.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A STOPPLE WAS INSTALLED ON OUR 6 INCH PIPELINE BY A CONTRACTOR TO ALLOW FOR THE REPLACEMENT OF FOUR VALVES ASSOCIATED WITH A PIG LAUNCHER.  HYDROCARBONS IN THE PIPING SEGMENT FROM THE STOPPLE TO THE PIG LAUNCHER WERE THEN EVACUATED.   THE CONTRACTOR CONFIRMED THAT THERE WAS NO PRESSURE REMAINING IN THE PIPELINE SEGMENT THAT WAS EVACUATED.  THE CONTRACTOR OPENED THE END CAP OF THE PIG LAUNCHER.  A SHORT TIME LATER, HYDROCARBON MATERIAL EXITED THE LAUNCHER.      A CONTRACTOR HAD PLACED AN AIR COMPRESSOR IN THE VICINITY OF THE PIG LAUNCHER TO ASSIST WITH THE VALVE REPLACEMENT.  AFTER THE HYDROCARBON MATERIAL EXITED THE LAUNCHER, AN EMPLOYEE ATTEMPTED TO SHUT DOWN THE AIR COMPRESSOR.  THE HYDROCARBONS WERE IGNITED BY THE COMPRESSOR AND THE EMPLOYEE WAS BURNED AND SUBSEQUENTLY DIED.     FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE EVENT WERE:  A LEAKING STOPPLE, PLACEMENT AND OPERATION OF AN AIR COMPRESSOR, AN INSUFFICIENT JOB PLAN, AND RESPONSE TO A VAPOR CLOUD.

column245: ON WEDNESDAY, JULY 13, 2005 WHILE DIGGING A GROUND WATER MONITOR WELL AT BUCKEYE PARTNERS MACUNGIE TANK FARM AN ENVIRONMENTAL CONTRACTOR HIT BUCKEYE¿S TANK 206 LINE.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTRACTOR WAS CONDUCTING THE WORK FOR BUCKEYE.  MACUNGIE OPERATIONS WERE NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY OF THE INCIDENT AND THE 701 PIPELINE PUMPING FROM THE TANK WAS SHUTDOWN.  BUCKEYE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE SENT TO THE INCIDENT SITE.   THE TANK 206 SHELL GATE VALVE WAS CLOSED WHICH STOPPED THE RELEASE OF PRODUCT.  THE 701 PIPELINE WAS SWITCH TO A DIFFERENT TANK AND RESUMED PUMPING ON JULY 13, 2005.  THE LINE WAS EXPOSED AND A TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS MADE ON WEDNESDAY, JULY 13 WITH THE PERMANENT REPAIR MADE ON JULY 18, 2005.   THE EMPLOYEE WHO CONDUCTED THE LOCATING AND MARKING ACTIVITY WAS IMMEDIATELY SUSPENDED FROM THESE OPERATOR QUALIFICATION TASKS.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE LINES IN THE AREA WERE NOT LOCATED AND MARKED CORRECTLY.  THE EMPLOYEE IN QUESTION WAS DISQUALIFIED FROM PERFORMING THESE TASKS UNTIL RETRAINING AND RE-QUALIFICATION CAN BE CONDUCTED.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT ON JULY 13, 2005.  CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES.

column245: THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR WAS WORKING FOR LANDOWNER TO CLEAR PROPERTY OF BRUSH & TREES.  SUNOCO PIPELINE L. P.'S EAST TEXAS 10 INCH CRUDE OIL PIPELINE RUNS THROUGH THE PROPERTY.  THERE WAS NOT A TEXAS ONE CALL NOTIFICATION MADE BY THE LANDOWNER OR THE CONSTRUCTION COMPANY.  THE LINE HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY FLAGGED AND A DEPTH OF 16 INCHES REPORTED TO THE DOZER OPERATOR.  THE LINE WAS CLEARLY MARKED ON THE NORTH AND SOUTH FENCE ROWS AS WELL. THE FAILURE OCCURRED WHEN THE RIPPER BAR TOOTH THAT HAD BEEN WELDED TO THE DOZER BLADE GOUGED THE PIPELINE RESULTING IN A CRUDE OIL RELEASE AND FIRE.  THE REPPER BAR TEETH MEASURED 2 INCHES WIDE BY 16 INCHES LONG.

column245: OPERATOR MADE A VALVE LINE-UP ON THE MANIFOLD AND FAILED TO ENSURE THAT THE REMOTE ACTUATED TANK VALVE HAD ACTUALLY OPENED AT THE TANK.  WITHOUT THE PROPER VALVE ALIGNMENT, THE OIL DID NOT HAVE AN OPENING AND THE THERMAL RELIEF VALVE ON THE HEADER OPENED (AS DESIGNED) TO RELIEVE THE LINE PRESSURE.    THE FLOW FROM THE THERMAL RELIEF GOES INTO THE SUMP AND THE SUMP OVERFLOWED WHEN IT'S CAPACITY WAS EXCEEDED.  THE OIL FROM THE SUMP WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE IMMEDIATE AREA, ADJACENT TO THE SUMP AND MANIFOLD.

column245: RANCHER THAT LEASES LAND WAS GRADING A DIRT ACCESS ROAD ALONG A HILLSIDE WITH A ROTO-GRADER. WORK OCCURRED WITHOUT A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION. CHEVRON'S BAY AREA PRODUCTS LINE (BAPL) - SAN JOSE LEG CROSSES UNDER THIS DIRT ROAD. GRADER STRUCK THE PIPELINE WITH GRADING BLADE AND PUNCTURED THE PIPELINE.     THERE ARE EXISTING LINE MARKERS DIRECTLY ABOVE THIS DAMAGE LOCATION ON TOP OF THE HILL AND DIRECTLY BELOW THIS LOCATION AT THE BOTTOM OF THE HILL. BOTH ADJACENT LINE MARKERS ARE VISIBLE FROM THE DIRT ROAD. THERE ARE ADDITIONAL PIPELINE MARKERS PLACED BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THIS LOCATION WITHIN LINE SIGHT OF EACH OTHER.    AIR PATROL FLIES THIS LEG OF THE BAPL TWICE A WEEK ACCORDING TO THE EXISTING LEASE REQUIREMENTS THAT CHEVRON HAS WITH THE LAND OWNER. INCIDENT OCCURRED ON A SUNDAY EVENING.

column245: THE INBOARD PUMP SEAL FAILED ON MAINLINE UNIT#1 AT WILLOW STATION.  THE RELEASE WAS ALARMED AND RECEIVED AT PIPELINE CONTROL BY THE STATION HAZ-GAS DETECTOR AND UNIT SEAL FAIL PROBE.  AFTER A LOCAL EMPLOYEE VERIFIED A VAPOR CLOUD, THE STATION WAS ISOLATED BY PIPELINE CONTROL.  ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO REDUCE THE PRESSURE AT THE STATION AND THE PUMP WAS THEN ISOLATED BY LOCAL EMPLOYEES.    AS A PRECAUTION, LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS WERE NOTIFIED BY THE OPERATOR, AND THE FIRE DEPARTMENT ASSISTED IN CLOSING TWO ROADS NEAR THE STATION AND EVACUATING ONE RESIDENT.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: AN EMPLOYEE WAS TRANSFERRING OIL INTO STORAGE TANK, #495, FROM TANK # 313 AT BURNS TERMINAL AND WAS DISPATCHED TO THE BURNS DOCK TO CHECK A SUMP DUE TO HEAVY RAINS.  AFTER CHECKING ON THE SUMP, HE LEFT THE DOCK AND WENT HOME.  HE AWOKE THE NEXT MORNING AND REALIZED THAT HE HAD LEFT THE BURNS TERMINAL WHILE IN THE PROCESS OF TRANSFERRING FROM TANK TO TANK AND DID NOT SHUT DOWN THE PUMP.  HE IMMEDIATELY WENT TO THE TERMINAL AND STOPPED THE FLOW OF OIL INTO TANK #495.  THE CONTROL CENTER DID NOT SEE THE OVERFILL OF THE TANK DUE TO AN ALARM FAILURE.  ALL OF THE SPILLED CRUDE OIL WAS RETAINED WITHIN THE DIKE.  CORRECTIVE ACTIONS WERE INITIATED AND THE OIL WAS RETURNED TO THE TANK.

column245: A PIN HOLE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON BURIED PIPE.  PRODUCT WAS EVACUATED TO ANOTHER FACILITY.  THE PIPE WAS EXCAVATED AND ABOUT 26' OF PIPE WAS SANDBLASTED AND INSPECTED. TWO SIGNIFICANT EXTERNAL CORROSION PITS WERE REPAIRED WITH A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT PIPE SLEEVE.  CORROSION PITTING OCCURRED OVER A LENGTH OF ABOUT 8' WHERE POLY TAPE WAS LOOSE IN A LONG FIELD BEND.  THE SANDBLASTED PIPE WAS COATED WITH A LIQUID EPOXY COATING (SPC2888).       CONTAMINATED SOIL VOLUME FROM THIS PIPELINE RELEASE CAN NOT BE SEGREGATED FROM CONTAMINATION BEING REMEDIATED FROM A SEPARATE UNASSOCIATED LARGER ADJACENT PLANT INCIDENT THAT PRECEDED THE PIPELINE RELEASE.    THE FILING ON MARCH 10, 2008 WAS MADE AS A SUPPLEMENTAL FILING BECAUSE ONGOING ENVIRONMETAL REMEDIATION WAS NOT ADEQUATELY DELINEATED.      UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column238: FAILURE OCCURRED DUE TO FAULTY O-RING ON RECEIVING 16" SCRAPER TRAP CLOSURE DOOR.
column245: OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IN HOUSTON EXPERIENCED AN OVER/SHORT ISSUE ON THE BAYTOWN TO IRVING PRODUCTS INTRASTATE PIPELINE SYSTEM AT MIDNIGHT ON 9/7/05.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN UNTIL DAYLIGHT SO THAT A PATROL PLANE COULD FLY THE LINE.  AERIAL PATROL SPOTTED A SMALL GASOLINE SPRAY FROM THE SCRAPER TRAP CLOSURE DOOR AT THE MAYPEARL TRAP, NEAR MAYPEARL, TEXAS.  RESPONSE CREWS WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE AREA TO INVESTIGATE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN O-RING HAD FAILED ON THE RECEIVING SCRAPER TRAP DOOR CLOSURE.  SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED AND REPAIRS MADE BY INSTALLING A NEW O-RING. AN ESTIMATE OF THE QUANTITY RELEASED IS 400 BARRELS ( 200 BARRELS TO THE SOIL AND 200 BARRELS TO EVAPORATION).  THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON 9/7/05.  THE IMPACTED SOIL IS BEING EXCAVATED, TESTED, AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WILL BE TRANSPORTATED TO AN APPROVED LANDFILL. ALL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGULATIONS. THERE WAS NO SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC SAFETY IMPACTS AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS IS LIMITED TO SOIL CONTAMINATION.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: CHALMETTE REFINERY OPERATOR, IN AN ATTEMPT TO REDIRECT THE INCOMING CRUDE STREAM, CLOSED MOEM PIPELINE IN CAUSING HIGH PRESSURE ON THE MOEM PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE PIPELINE RELIEF VALVE TO TANK #303 FAILED TO OPERATE ALLOWING PRESSURE TO CONTINUE TO BUILD.  AT 140 PSI, THE TWO 1" PRESSURE RELIEF VALVES ON THE METER RUN RELIEVED TO THE SUMP.  THE SUMP PUMP DISCHARGE IS PIPED BACK TO THE PIPELINE SO, THE SUMP HAD NO WHERE TO PUMP.  THIS RESULTED IN LESS THAN 8 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL SPILLING OVER FROM THE SUMP.  ALL APPROPRIATE STATE NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE WITHIN REQUIRED TIMELINES.  THERE WERE NO SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC SAFETY IMPACTS OR  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS. LOSS INVESTIGATION TEAM ANALYSIS DEVELOPED SOLUTIONS ON HOW TO PREVENT THIS SITUATION FROM RECURRING.

column245: DURING A HYDROSTATIC TEST OF THE CCPS TRANSPORTATION, LLC (SPEARHEAD) PIPELINE SYSTEM, A RUPTURE OCCURED IN A CORN FIELD APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES NORTHEAST OF RUSH STATION NEAR RUSHVILLE, ILLINOIS. AN ESTIMATED 1500 BBLS OF TEST WATER WAS OUT WITH THE AMOUNT OF CRUDE OIL ENTRAINED IN THE WATER ESTIMATED TO BE 107 BARRELS. WATER MADE ITS WAY TO A DRAIN TILE AND ENTERED NEARBY SUGAR CREEK WHICH WAS REPORTED TO BE STAGNANT AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE. ABSORBANT BOOM WAS PLACED DOWNSTREAM OF THE AREA. THE WATER COMING FROM THE TILE APPEARED TO BE CLEAN. SWAMP MATS WERE PLACED IN THE FIELD TO ENABLE CREWS TO GET TO THE SITE. ALL NECESSARY RESOURCES RESPONDED TO THE SITE TO ASSIST WITH CLEANUP AND REPAIR. REPAIR CONSISTED OF REPLACING 44.7 FEET OF PIPE ON AUGUST 25, 2005. TOM MCMASTER OF THE CENTRAL REGION OPS WAS ON SITE THE DAY OF THE RELEASE.

column245: AROUND 0015 HOURS ON MONDAY, AUGUST 29, 2005, A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE WAS STARTING A BATCH CHANGE AT BUCKEYE¿S LIVERPOOL TERMINAL WHEN HE DISCOVERED A CHECK VALVE LEAKING PRODUCT.  THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN, THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR WAS CONTACTED, AND MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  ALL CONTACTS WERE MADE TO THE APPROPRIATE AGENCIES.   AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE O-RING ON THE CHECK VALVE HAD FAILED.  THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION WAS ON SITE AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES WERE CONDUCTED UNDER THEIR SUPERVISION.

column245: HURRICANE KATRINA - TANK 1506 WAS RELEASING OIL TO THE TANK DIKE THROUGH UNKNOWN PATHWAY.  CRUDE OIL WAS PUMPED TO BARGE FROM DIKED AREA.  9-14-2006 FLOOR OF ABOVE GROUND STORAGE TANK WAS DAMAGED DURING HURRICANE, RELEASING TANK VOLUME TO DIKED AREA.   8/20/2007 DAMAGE AS A DIRECT RESULT OF HURRICANE KATRINA DUE TO BOTH CAUSES FLOODING AND WIND.  WINDS EXCEEDED 100MPH, TIDAL SURGE IN EXCESS OF 25FEET HIGH.  THE FACILITY LAY DIRECTLY IN THE PATH OF THE HURRICANE.  SEVERAL PHASES OF RESPONSE TOOK PLACE TO COMPLETE THE CLEANUP OF THE FACILITY.  THE INITIAL RESPONSE OF REMOVING OIL FRO THE TANK DIKE, TRANSFERRING OIL FROM TANKAGE, CLANING TANKS, DEMOLITION OF TANKS AND PIPING, AND FINAL CLEAN UP.

column245: CHEVRON PIPE LINE COMPANY'S (CPL) FOURCHON TERMINAL WHICH IS LOCATED IN THE VERY SOUTHEASTERN PART OF LOUISIANA SOUTH OF GOLDEN MEADOW IN LAFOURCHE PARISH WAS DAMAGED BY HUIRRICANE KATRINA.  DURING HURRICANE KATRINA'S TIDAL SURGE, A CHEVRON PRODUCTION POTABLE WATER TANK FLOATED AND RAN OVER THE CPL MAINLINE PUMP DISCHARGE PIPING, BREAKING OFF A 3/4" NIPPLE FITTING ON THE PIPING.  THIS RESULTED IN A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL FROM CPL'S CRUDE OIL SALES TANK TO SURFACE WATERS. HELICOPTER OVER-FLIGHT DISCOVERED THE SHEEN OF OIL ½ MILE LONG BY 50 YARDS WIDE ORIGINATING AT FOURCHON TERMINAL, EXTENDING NORTHEAST INTO (OR NEAR) BAYOU LAFOURCHE. (NOTE: BAYOU LAFOURCHE IS A COMMERCIALLY NAVIGABLE WATEREWAY HCA).

column245: LANDOWNER NOTIFIED CONOCOPHILLIPS SUPERVISOR OF A POSSIBLE LEAK AT THE WEST CABIN BLOCK VALVE A 0430 9/19/05.  LINE WAS DOWN DUE TO LEAK DETECTION ALARM RECEIVED AT CONTROL CENTER.  UPON ARRIVAL TO THE SITE, SUPERVISOR IDENTIFIED THE LEAK TO BE COMING FROM THE INSULATING GASKET ON THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF THE BLOCK VALVE.  GASOLINE WAS LEAKING FROM THE GASKET AREA.    PRELIMINARY CAUSE: FAILURE OF INSULATING GASKET.  THE GASKET HAS BEEN SENT TO THE VENDOR FOR FURTHER TESTING.  VITON MATERIAL APPEARED TO BE DISBONDED FROM THE FIBER MATERIALTHAT MAKES UP THE INSULATING GASKET.

column245: A THIRD PARTY PIPELINE CONTRACTOR WAS IN THE PROCESS OF INSTALLING A PIPELINE FOR ANOTHER OPERATOR.  THIS CONTRACTOR PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTED A ONE CALL TICKET AS REQUIRED.  KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL MARKED THE LINE IN THE AREA OF THE PROPOSED EXCAVATION AS REQUESTED BY THE CONTRACTOR.  THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOTIFIED THAT KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL HAD TO BE PRESENT AT THE TIME THEY CROSSED OUR PIPELINE.  ON SEPTEMBER 12, 2005 KINDER MORGAN FIELD PERSONNEL RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE CONTRACTOR NOTIFYING US, AS PREVIOUSLY AGREED TO BY BOTH PARTIES, THAT THEY WERE NEARING THE LOCATION WHERE THEY WERE GOING TO BE EXCAVATING ACROSS KINDER MORGAN¿S PIPELINE.  FIELD PERSONNEL INFORMED THE CONTRACTOR THAT THEY WERE IN ROUTE TO WITNESS THE CROSSING OF OUR PIPELINE AND REITERATED THAT THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOT TO DIG ACROSS OUR PIPELINE UNTIL WE WERE PRESENT.  THE CONTRACTOR STOPPED DIGGING AT A POINT WHERE HE BELIEVED  WAS AWAY FROM OUR PIPELINE AND HE RELOCATED HIS TRENCHER TO A LOCATION WHERE HE THOUGHT HE WAS CLEAR OF OUR PIPELINE AND STARTED DIGGING AGAIN WITHOUT WAITING FOR KINDER MORGAN PERSONNEL TO ARRIVE.  THE PIPELINE CONTRACTOR STRUCK OUR PIPELINE SHORTLY THERE AFTER.  THE INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE CONTRACTOR UTILIZED A THIRD PARTY¿S SURVEY MARKERS AS THE INDICATION OF THE PIPELINE LOCATED INSTEAD OF KINDER MORGAN¿S FLAGGING, WHICH HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY MOWED OVER BY THE CONTRACTOR THAT WAS CONSTRUCTING THE PIPELINE.

column245: CFPL WAS TRANSPORTING LOW SULFUR DIESEL FUEL THROUGH THE PIPELINE WHEN THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER NOTICED A LOSS OF PRESSURE, LOW VOLUMETRIC FLOW INTO THE ORLANDO RECEIVING TERMINAL AND AN INCREASE IN FLOW THROUGH THE HEMLOCK ORIGIN PUMPING STATION IN TAMPA.    THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER INITIATED SHUT DOWN PROCEDURES FOR THE 10¿ PIPELINE. CFPL TAMPA MANAGEMENT WAS NOTIFIED IMMEDIATELY.    A PHONE CALL WAS RECEIVED SHORTLY AFTER THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN FROM THE DOVER FIRE DEPARTMENT WHICH PROVIDED THE LOCATION OF A DIESEL SPILL.  THE CALL WAS RECEIVED ON THE CFPL 800 EMERGENCY NUMBER.  CFPL STAFF INITIATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES BY SENDING PERSONNEL TO THE SPILL LOCATION.  THE CFPL 10¿ PIPELINE IS LOCATED IN THE CSX RAILROAD RAILWAY CORRIDOR RIGHT-OF-WAY IN THE DOVER/PLANT CITY AREA.  THE ACTUAL RUPTURE WAS LOCATED IN THE CSX/CFPL RIGHT-OF-WAY NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF MARTIN LUTHER KING BLVD (HIGHWAY 574) AND WILKINSON DRIVE.  CFPL PERSONNEL INITIATED ACTIONS TO CLOSE ADDITIONAL MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE RUPTURE AREA.    INITIAL INVESTIGATIONS INDICATE THE RUPTURE WAS DUE TO PREVIOUS THIRD PARTY DAMAGE.    REMAINING FOURTY-FIVE BARRELS TO BE RECOVERED IN LONG TERM REMEDIATION OF RELEASE SITE.

column245: THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO ENBRIDGE PIPELINES (NORTH DAKOTA) ON THE NPS 16 PIPELINE FROM MINOT TO CLEARBROOK BETWEEN MP 77 AND 78, AT 7:55 A.M., TUESDAY, SEPT. 27, 2005.  APPROXIMATELY 350 BARRELS OF SWT WAS RELEASED, CONTAMINATING AN AREA APPROXIMATELY 2700 SQUARE YARDS.  THE LINE WAS SHUT IN AND ALL FREE PRODUCT WAS HAULED BACK TO MINOT STATION.  THE LINE WAS BACK IN SERVICE WITH A PERMANENT REPAIR EARLY WEDNESDAY (09/28/05) MORNING.  THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC (REPORT #769975) AND THE NORTH DAKOTA DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT (REPORT #05-120).    THE LINE WAS STRUCK BY HEAVY EQUIPMENT DURING HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION ON U.S. HIGHWAY 2. ENBRIDGE HAD PROVIDED THE CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR WITH THE APPROXIMATE HORIZONTAL LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE IN RESPONSE TO THE CONTRACTOR'S ONE-CALL NOTIFICATION ON AUGUST 2, 2005.  THE CONTRACTOR INFORMED ENBRIDGE THAT EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES WOULD NOT OCCUR IN THE VICINITY OF THE PIPELINE.  THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES CONTINUED UNTIL THE STRIKE OCCURRED ON SEPTEMBER 27 WITHOUT FURTHER ONE-CALL NOTIFICATIONS BY THE CONTRACTOR.  MOST OF THE OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION BORROW PIT ESTABLISHED BY THE CONTRACTOR.

AS A RESULT OF THE MOVEMENT, THE PIPELINE WAS TORN IN-TWO A SHORT DISTANCE FROM THE SOUTH MARSH ISLAND BLOCK 239 PLATFORM WHERE IT ORIGINATES.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT, BECAUSE OF THE APPROACHING HURRICANE, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT-IN AND ISOLATED.  THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF CRUDE OIL RELEASED IS ESTIMATED AT 1/8-BARREL.

column245: EL DORADO FIELD STAFF ARRIVED ON SITE OCTOBER 21, 2005 AND DISCOVERED TANK 4152 HAD A LEAK ON THE MIXER. ALTHOUGH THE RELEASE WAS INITIALLY ESTIMATED AT 200 BARRELS, ACTUAL VOLUME OUT WAS DETERMINED TO BE 2350 BARRELS, ALL CONTAINED IN THE DIKE AREA. THIS TANK IS LEASED TO NCRA AND THEY WERE PULLING OUT OF IT AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE. JAYHAWK PIPELINE INCREASED THEIR RATE TO MAXIMUM IN AN EFFORT TO PULL DOWN THE LEVEL AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE. NCRA APPROVED THE GRAVITY FEED AS WELL TO THEIR LEASED TANK 4151. NCRA STAFF WERE ON SITE AND TWO VACUUM TRUCKS CLEANED UP THE FREE-STANDING OIL. FIRE AND POLICE WERE CONTACTED.    THE PIVOT PINS THAT HOLD THE MIXER TO THE TANK SHELL HAVE A POORLY DESIGNED KEEPER RING THAT ALLOWED THE KEEPER RING TO FALL OFF AND THE PIN TO VIBRATE OUT.  WE HAVE SINCE BEEN MADE AWARE THAT THE MIXER MANUFACTURER HAS A RETROFIT TO PREVENT THE KEEPER RING FROM FALLING OFF THE PIN, AND WE HAVE ORDERED THE RETROFIT AND WILL BE INSTALLING IT AS SOON AS POSSIBLE.

column245: ON OCTOBER 24, 2005, BUCKEYE PARTNERS MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER SUSPECTED THAT TANK 220 AT BUCKEYE¿S MACUNGIE STATION MAY HAVE A RELEASE DUE TO VOLUMETRIC SHORTAGE.  MACUNGIE STATION WAS NOTIFIED AND INSPECTED THE TANK AND DID NOT SPOT ANY PRODUCT IN THE AREA OF THE TANK.  THE TANK WAS EMPTY AND PREPARED FOR ENTRY.  ON NOVEMBER 1, 2005 THE INSIDE OF THE TANK WAS INSPECTED AND A CRACK WELD WAS DISCOVERED, HOWEVER THERE WERE STILL NO SIGNS OF PRODUCT OUTSIDE THE TANK.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.   THE CAUSE OF THE CRACK IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND DRILLING PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED IN THE AREA OF THE TANK DIKE.  ALL CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE US DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION.   AFTER REVIEWING THE TANK LOGS BUCKEYE HAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASE OF PRODUCT STARTED ON OCTOBER 17, 2005 AROUND 0300.          SUPLEMENTAL REPORT - CLICKED ON THE WRONG CAUSE, SHOULD HAVE BEEN WELD AND NOT MATERIAL.          THIS IS BEING UPDATED TO REFLECT THE CURRENT ESTIMATED COSTS OF THE INCIDENT.  THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE A CRACKED WELD IN THE AREA OF THE TANK SUMP.

column235: INCORRECT RELIEF SETTING, SET BELOW MOP.
column245: AT 7:20 AM THE OPERATOR NOTICED THAT THE 55 GALLON DRUM THAT PSV-104 WAS TEMPORARILY DIVERTED TO WAS RUNNING OVER AND DIESEL FUEL WAS RUNNING INTO THE STORM WATER SUMP VAULT FOR 8010 TANK DIKE AREA.  THE OPERATOR IMMEDIATELY CLOSED A 1" VALVE UNDER PSV-104 TO STOP THE FLOW OF PRODUCT.      PSV-104 WAS TEMPORARILY DIVERTED TO A DRUM DUE TO TANK 8010 BEING OUT OF SERVICE FOR AN API 653 INSPECTION.  PRESSURE SETTING FOR PSV-104 WAS SET TO 100 PSI INSTEAD OF THE 275 PSI THAT IT WAS TO BE SET AT.  ON A DELIVERY TO MAGELLAN, LINE PRESSURE WAS A 125 PSI, THEREFORE THE RELIEF VALVE OPENED AND DIVERTED TO THE DRUM.  IF THE PSV-104 WOULD HAVE BEEN SET TO ITS PROPER SET POINT 275 PSI, RELIEF WOULD HAVE NOT ACTIVATED.      NO PRODUCT CONTACTED WATER.  THE SUMP IS WITHIN THE DIKES AND IS UTILIZED FOR RAIN WATER COLLECTION AND TESTING BEFORE DISCHARGE.  THE DIKES AND SUMPS WERE EMPTY OF WATER PRIOR TO THIS INCIDENT.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON NOVEMBER 2, 2005 A RELEASE OF 2 BARRELS OF FUEL OIL WAS LOCATED AT MILE POST 403.3 ON THE 24 INCH PIPELINE DOWNSTREAM OF THE WOOD RIVER, IL TANK FARM.  A 10.67 FOOT LONG SECTION OF THE 24 INCH PIPE CONTAINING THE THROUGH WALL FLAW AND UPSTREAM REFERENCE GIRTH WELD WAS REMOVED, COVERED WITH PLASTIC WRAP AND SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGIES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE PURPOSE OF THE ANALYSIS WAS TO DETERMINE THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE AND DETERMINE WHETHER THERE WERE OTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTORS.  THE INVESTIGATION DETERMINED A LEAK EMANATED FROM A PRE-EXISTING THROUGH WALL DEFECT LOCATED AT THE FUSION LINE OF THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM WELD.  THE MORPHOLOGY OF THE DEFECT IS CONSISTENT WITH LACK OF FUSION AT THE BOND LINE OF THE ERW.  THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS LISTED AS 0 AS THE DURATION IS NOT KNOWN. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND REMEDIATION OF SUBSURFACE WATER IS ONGOING. ZERO BARRELS ARE NOTED ON AMOUNT IN WATER AS THE CONCENTRATIONS ARE IN THE PARTS PER MILLION RANGE.  THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY THAT HAS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT HAS YET TO PROVIDE CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, PHMSA HAS REQUESTED A CLOSURE REPORT.  THEREFORE, EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $80,000 FOR CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT WITH THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY.

column245: A CRUDE OIL PARAFFIN HEATER ON SHIP SHOAL 332 B PLATFORM WAS BEING USED TO CIRCULATE THE CEASER OIL PIG TRAP.  THE HEATER SHELL RUPTURED AND A SMALL FIRE IGNITED FROM THE CRUDE OIL SPRAY.  THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED AND LINE HEATER ISOLATED.  FURTHER EVALUATION STILL IN PROGRESS AT THIS TIME.     A NEW LINE HEATER HAS BEEN REDISIGNED AND IS READY FOR SERVICE.  CURRENTLY THE NEW LINE HEATER IS NOT INSTALLED DUE TO LOW PRODUCTION VOLUMES.

column245: WHILE TILLING HIS FIELD, THE LANDOWNER DISCOVERED ON 11/11/05 A FIVE FOOT DIAMETER AREA WITH DEAD VEGETATION AND NOTIFIED THE COMPANY.  THE COMPANY LOWERED THE OPERATING PRESSURE, EXCAVATED THE "DEAD" SPOT AND VERIFIED A PINHOLE LEAK ON THE OUTSIDE EDGE OF A GIRTH WELD AT ABOUT THE 2 O'CLOCK POSITION FACING EAST.  THE COATING WAS CLEANED OFF TO BARE PIPE, AND A PLIDCO "BOLT ON SLEEVE" WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAK ON 11/11/05 AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR.  THE REPAIR WAS THEN COATED, AND THE EXPOSED AREA WAS BACKFILLED.     THE PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS WELDED IN NOVEMBER 2006 AS A PERMANENT REPAIR.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON NOVEMBER 6, 2005 AT 0648 HOURS, THE EA SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. (SPLP) CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM THE SCIPIO-REPUBLIC FIRE DEPARTMENT THAT THERE WAS FIRE AT ONE OF OUR PIPELINE STATIONS NEAR REPUBLIC, OH.  THE PIPELINE IN THE AREA WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME BUT HAD A STATIC PRESSURE OF ABOUT 300 PSI.  THE CONTROL CENTER CONFIRMED THE REPORTED FIRE LOCATION AS BEING AT THE OUT-OF-SERVICE LOWELL PUMP STATION.  AT 0655 HOURS, THE AREA SUPERVISOR WAS NOTIFIED AT HOME AND BEGAN RESPONDING TO THE SCENE.  AT 0656 HOURS CONTROL CENTER OPENED INTO HUDSON TANK FARM TO DRAIN PRESSURE FROM THE PIPELINE AND AT 0658 HOURS, A DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION WAS STARTED TO PULL PRODUCT AWAY FROM THE LOCATION OF THE FIRE.  AT 0659 HOURS, THE DOWNSTREAM PUMP STATION WENT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION AND THE MAIN LINE VALVES AT LOWELL WERE CLOSED.    AT 0705 HOURS, THE RESPONDING SPLP SUPERVISOR, CALLED THE FIRE DEPARTMENT REPRESENTATIVE ON SCENE TO ESTABLISH CONTACT.  FROM THIS CONVERSATION, THE SPLP SUPERVISOR WAS ABLE TO DETERMINE THAT THE FUEL SOURCE OF THE FIRE WAS STAINLESS STEEL INSTRUMENT TUBING.  THE FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS THEN ADVISED OF THE LOCATION OF A 1/2" VALVE THAT COULD BE CLOSED TO SHUTOFF THE PRODUCT SUPPLYING THE FIRE.  THIS VALVE WAS SHUT BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THE FIRE BURNED OUT.  AT 0725 HOURS, THE SPLP SUPERVISOR ARRIVED ON-SITE, MET WITH THE FIRE DEPARTMENT, MONITORED THE ATMOSPHERE AND DETERMINED THE AREA TO BE SAFE.    UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THERE HAD BEEN A BAND OF SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS MOVING THROUGH THE AREA AT THE TIME THE FIRE OCCURRED AND THAT A BOLT OF LIGHTNING HAD STRUCK NEAR THE STATION BURNING A HOLE THROUGH ¼ INCH TUBING RELEASING AND IGNITING GASOLINE.  LOWELL PUMP STATION IS CURRENTLY IN A DECOMMISSIONED STATE WITH THE STATION PIPING PURGED AND ISOLATED FROM THE MAIN PIPELINE.  THE LOCATION IS STILL UTILIZED AS A MAIN LINE PRESSURE DATA POINT FOR THE CPM LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM.  INVESTIGATION OF SCADA DATA INDICATED THAT THE LINE STARTED LOSING PRESSURE AT 0633 HOURS.  EXAMINATION OF THE PIPELINE FOUND A LIGHTNING DIFFUSER ON AN INSULATING JOINT WITH A SHATTERED DISC ALLOWING CURRENT FROM THE LIGHTNING STRIKE TO TRAVEL DOWN THE ABOVE GROUND MAIN LINE PIPING AND ONTO THE TUBING WHERE IT GROUNDED TO A NEARBY PIPE SUPPORT. THE ENTIRE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONSUMED BY THE FIRE AND WAS CALCULATED AS BEING APPROXIMATELY 90 GALLONS.

column177: WORKING A GRAVEL PIT NEAR PIPELINE ROW
column245: THE INCIDENT OCCURRED AT THE ACE WEST DONNIE ROOKS GRAVEL PIT AREA LOCATED 0.2 MILES DOWNSTREAM OF THE PUMP STATION. ACE WEST EMPLOYEE WAS OPERATING A BULLDOZER UNDER THE DIRECTION OF DONNIE ROOKS, WHOM WAS AWARE OF THE PIPELINE, HOWEVER, THE BULLDOZER OPERATOR LOST TRACK OF THE PIPELINE IN RELATIONS TO HIS WORK AREA. FOR UNKNOWN REASONS THE BULLDOZER OPERATOR DROPPED THE RIPPER AND MADE CONTACT WITH THE PIPELINE CAUSING A 3 INCH WIDE HOLE INTO THE PIPELINE.CRUDE OIL WAS RELEASED IN A CIRCLE APPROXIMATELY 100FT IN DIAMETER. NO INJURIES.

column245: ON MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 2005, BUCKEYE PARTNERS LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL DISCOVERED PRODUCT NEAR TANK 4 AT BUCKEYE¿S HARTFORD TERMINAL.  THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND PREPARED FOR ENTRY.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION A BURN HOLE WAS DISCOVERED IN THE TANK FLOOR.   TANK 4 HAD JUST BEEN PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AFTER AN INTERNAL 653 INSPECTION WAS CONDUCTED BY AN OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR.  THE BURN HOLE IS IN AN AREA WHERE THE TANK FLOOR HAD BEEN REPAIRED BY THE CONTRACTOR.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.          THE BURN HOLE WAS CAUSED BY A CONTRACTORS WELDER CUTTING METAL PLATES INSIDE THE TANK WHILE THE TANK WAS BEING REPAIRED AFTER AN INTERNAL 653 INSPECTION.

column245: THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY HUMAN ERROR DURING A MAINTENANCE PROJECT. IMPROPER LABELING CAUSED CONTRACTORS TO IMPACT AN ACTIVE LINE DURING PROJECT WORK AND THE LINE WAS NOT BLIND FANGED.  THE ERROR WAS DISCOVERED BY OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DURING A ROUTINE CHECK AT START-UP.  THE QUANTITY OF JET A FUEL THAT WAS SPILLED WAS 126 BARRELS.  89 BARRELS OF THIS PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED AND SOIL REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY.  THERE WERE NO FIRES, EXPLOSIONS, INJURIES OR FATALITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE.  COST OF THIS RELEASE EXCEEDED $50,000.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 22, 2005, KMEP PERSONNEL RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS IN PROXIMITY TO OUR MILTONVALE KANSAS PUMP STATION.  THESE OFFICIALS REPORTED THE POSSIBILITY OF A RELEASE AT OUR MILTONVALE STATION.  KMEP PERSONNEL CONTACTED AND INFORMED OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER OF THE INFORMATION RECEIVED.  OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER PERSONNEL ININITIATED A SHUT OF OUR 102 AND 101 PIPELINE SYSTEMS UNTIL PERSONNEL ARRIVED TO INVESTIGATE.  WHEN PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT OUR MILTONVALE STATION THEY CONFIRMED THE RELEASE TO OUR HOUSTON CONTROL CENTER.  THE INITIAL KMEP FIELD PERSONNEL THAT ARRIVED AT THE STATION, INITIATED OUR EMERGENCY PROCEDURES AND MADE THE AREA SAFE BY 07:00.  OUR INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT A SECTION OF ONE HALF INCH STAINLESS STEAL TUBING USED IN OUR PUMP SEAL FLUSH SYSTEM HAD SLIPPED OUT OF ITS FERRULE FITTING.  THE TUBING WAS ASSOCIATED WITH OUR NUMBER ONE UNIT ON OUR 102 PIPELINE.  THE PRODUCT RELEASE WAS NORMAL BUTANE WHICH COLLECTED AS FROST ON THE SURROUNDING STATION GRAVEL BEFORE VAPORING OFF AS THE DAY WARMED UP.  THE RELEASE CAUSED NO SOIL OR WATER CONTAMINATION.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: DARBY CREEK TANK FARM (DCTF) IS OPERATED AS A BREAKOUT TANK FARM FOR STORAGE OF CRUDE OIL RECEIVED FROM SHIPS UNLOADING AT TWO SUNOCO LOGISTICS DEEP WATER BERTHS VIA TWO 24-INCH PIPELINES.  THE DCTF ALSO SUPPLIES CRUDE OIL DIRECTLY TO THE SUNOCO GIRARD POINT REFINERY 137 PROCESSING UNIT VIA A SINGLE 16-INCH PIPELINE.  DCTF CURRENTLY HAS 25 TANKS IN SERVICE WITH APPROXIMATELY HALF TIED INTO THE ¿S SHIP LINE¿ MANIFOLD (SSL) AND HALF INTO THE ¿N SHIP LINE¿ MANIFOLD (NSL).  DCTF IS A MANNED FACILITY WITH TWO OPERATORS ON DUTY WORKING 12 HOUR SHIFTS, 24/7.  ON NOV. 22, TANK NUMBER 24 (#24) WAS BEING FILLED FROM THE SSL AND WAS FILLED TO SAFE FILL CAPACITY AT 1000HOURS.  AT THAT TIME THE DAY SHIFT OPERATORS SWITCHED THE DELIVERY TO #35 ON THE NSL.  FLOW TO #24 WAS STOPPED BY CLOSING THE CENTRAL MANIFOLD BLOCK VALVE ON THE SSL.  THE ¿STREET VALVE¿ LOCATED BETWEEN THE SSL AND #24 SHOULD ALSO HAVE BEEN CLOSED BY THE OPERATOR BUT WAS NOT.  DCTF OPERATORS CHANGED SHIFT AT 1700 HOURS WITH #35 STILL IN THE PROCESS OF BEING FILLED.  AT 2225 HOURS, THE CRUDE DELIVERY WAS SWITCHED FROM #35 ON THE NSL TO #3 ON THE SSL.  SINCE THE ¿STREET VALVE¿ TO #24 WAS LEFT OPEN EARLIER IN THE DAY, THE SSL NOW HAD BOTH #3 AND #24 TANKS ON LINE.  SEVERAL ALARMS FOR TANK HIGH LEVEL IN TANK #24 WERE RECEIVED BY THE NIGHT SHIFT OPERATORS BUT NOT ACTED ON BECAUSE THE OPERATOR BELIEVED THAT THE TANK WAS OFF LINE.  AT 0205 HOURS ON NOV. 23 THE OPERATORS RECEIVED A SEPARATE OPERATIONAL ALARM ON THE SAME ALARM PANEL WHERE THE DC24 HI-HI LEVEL ALARM IS LOCATED.  THE OPERATORS ACKNOWLEDGED THIS SEPARATE ALARM AND THEN DISCOVERED CRUDE OIL OVERFILLING #24 AND INTO THE TANK DIKE.  THE OPERATORS IMMEDIATELY TOOK APPROPRIATE ACTIONS TO STOP FLOW INTO #24 BY CLOSING THE ¿STREET VALVE¿.  THE SHIP UNLOADING WAS STOPPED A SHORT TIME LATER.  ALL OF THE SPILLED CRUDE OIL WAS CONTAINED BY THE TANK DIKE SYSTEM AND 99% WAS PUMPED BACK INTO ANOTHER TANK FOR NORMAL REFINERY PROCESSING.  DAMAGE TO #24 WAS LIMITED TO A MAN PLATFORM, SECONDARY SEAL, TANK GAUGING AND HIGH ALARM EQUIPMENT.  THE TANK HAS BEEN EMPTIED OF CRUDE OIL BUT HAS NOT YET BEEN RETURNED TO SERVICE PENDING COMPLETION OF REPAIR WORK.   A TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO OPS ON NOV. 23 AT 0800 HOURS.

column238: PACKING FAILURE
column245: EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO STANLEY STATION TO DISCOVER OIL HAD LEAKED FROM THE PISTON GLAND, FILLED THE DRAIN SUMP AND RAN ONTO THE GROUND.  ALL FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED WITH FURTHUR REMEDIATION WORK UNDER WAY.  ALL PRODUCT REMAINED ON SITE.  THE PACKING GLAND ON THE 1755 GASO PUMP WAS FOUND TO BE WASHED OUT.  CRUDE OIL WOULD LEAK OUT WHEN LINE PRESSURE WAS MINIMAL; AS IN THOSE INSTANCES WHEN THE LINE WAS DOWN AND THE GASO OFF.  THE SOURCE FOR THE LEAK PROVED TO BE THE SOURCE TANK AND TANK HEAD THE ONLY OTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTOR.  IT WAS CUSTOMARY FOR LOCAL PERSONNEL TO CHECK THE PACKING ON THE PUMP WHEN IT WAS RUNNING, BUT NOT NECESSARILY WHEN IT WAS IDLE.  LOCAL PERSONNEL HAD CHECKED IN EARLY AT THE STATION AND THEN WENT ON THEIR ASSIGNED ROUTES FOR THE DAY.

column238: CRACK IN TANK FLOOR.  NO CORROSION FOUND. UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION GOUGE WAS FOUND ON THE UNDERNEATH SIDE OF FLOOR. GOUGE APPEARED TO BE CAUSED BY WELDING TORCH.
column245: TANK 1081 HAD RECENTLY BEEN PUT BACK INTO SERVICE AFTER RECENT COMPLETION OF AN API 653 INTERNAL INSPECTION.  AFTER FILLING OF THE TANK, A STAIN WAS DISCOVERD NEXT TO THE CHIME OF THE TANK.  UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THE PRODUCT WAS COMING FROM UNDER THE TANK.  THE TANK WAS EMPTIED OF PRODUCT AND ALL PRODUCT WAS REMOVED.  UPON INVESTIGATION, A SMALL CRACK WAS DISCOVERED IN THE PARENT MATERIAL OF ONE OF THE FLOOR SHEETS.  COUPON WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO LABORATORY FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS.

column235: MORE OIL BEHIND DISPLACEMENT SQUEEGE THAN ANTISIPA
column245: EMPCO OPERATIONS WAS REMOVING A DISPLACEMENT SQUEEGE FROM THE PIPELINE.  A LARGE PAN WAS IN PLACE TO CATCH THE OIL.  THE PAN OVERFLOWED WHEN APPROXIMATELY 150 BARRELS OF CRUDE WAS RELEASED INTO THE BELL HOLE.  MORE OIL HAD ACCUMULATED BEHIND THE SQUEEGE THAN WAS ANTICIPATED.   ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE BELL HOLE AND WAS PROMPTLY REMOVED WITH A VACUUM TRUCK.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS PLACED IN A LINED ROLL-OFF CONTAINER AND WILL BE PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.

column245: THIS PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUTDOWN PRIOR TO HURRICANE KATRINA. THE LINE IS STILL SHUT DOWN AWAITING INSPECTION AND REPAIR.  UNKNOWN FAILURE COMPONENT.  BELEIVE THIS AREA OF THE PIPELINE IS APPROXIMATELY 15 FEET DEEP IN BOTTOM OF SEA FLOOR.  A SHEEN WAS FIRST IDENTIFIED IN THE AREA OF THIS SHEEN ON 9/17/05 DURING A PRESSURE UP TO VERIFY INTEGRITY, NRC REPORT #772834.  THIS PIPELINE REMAINS SHUT DOWN SINCE THIS EVENT. HOPE TO HAVE EQUIPMENT AVAILABLE BY MARCH 2006 FOR REPAIR.   PIPELINE WAS REROUTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE MARCH 30, 2006.  14.9 MILES OF PIPELINE WERE ABANDONED.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: HURRICANE KATRINA - PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUT DOWN SINCE BEFORE THE HURRICANE.  THE PIPELINE WAS INSPECTED AND FOUND SETTLEMENT.  A CRACK WAS FOUND ON THE PIPE IN THE SETTLED PIPE SEGMENT CLOSE TO AN ANODE ATTACHED TO THE PIPE. NO OIL WAS FOUND AT TIME OF INSPECTION.    THE PIPELINE WAS BEING DISPLACED WITH WATER IN PREPARATION OF REPAIR.  A POLLUTION DOME WAS LOCATED OVER THE CRACK TO CAPTURE ESCAPING OIL DURING DISPLACEMENT.  THE SUCTION LINE FROM THE POLLUTION DOME DEVELOPED A LEAK.  THE DISPLACEMENT WAS SHUT DOWN AND CLOSED OFF POLLUTION DOME.  ESTIMATED 10 BBLS OF OIL WAS RELEASED BEFORE VALVE COULD BE CLOSED.  PIPELINE IS 2,750 FEET DEEP.

column30: OTHER
column245: ON NOVEMBER 8M, 2005 AT APPROX. 9:30 A.M. CENTRAL STANDARD TIME, MPL¿S WABASH 16¿ PRODUCTS PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AFTER WE RECEIVED A CALL FROM A LANDOWNER REPORTING THE SMELL OF PRODUCT AROUND THE CREEK BANK NEAR THE WABASH LINE IN ST. ANNE, ILLINOIS.  MPL IMMEDIATELY INITIATED LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES.  MPL RESPONSE PERSONNEL ON-SITE CONFIRMED A SLIGHT SHEEN ON THE SURFACE OF SPRING CREEK MOVING DOWNSTREAM (WEST) FOR APPROXIMATELY 1 TO 1.5 MILES.  ON NOV 9, 2005, PIPELINE EXCAVATION BEGAN AND ON NOV 10, 2005 THE SOURCE OD THE RELEASE WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE WABASH 16¿ PRODUCTS PIPELINE WITH THE CHAMPAIGN TO GRIFFITH SEGMENT. THE PRODUCT HAD MIGRATED TO UNDERGROUND FROM THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE APPROX. 150 FT  INTO SPRING CREEK FROM THE BASE OF THE CREEK BANK.  THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS REPAIRED WITH A TUPE ¿B¿ SLEEVE ON NOV 10, 2005.  ON NOV 18, 2005 KIEFNER & ASSOC ADVISED THAT THEIR PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS INDICATED THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY COLD WELD OR LACK OF FUSION WITH NO SIGNS OF FATIGUE.  THE JOINT OF PIPE THAT WAS REMOVED IS CURRENTLY UNDERGOING TESTING BY KOEFNER & ASSOC AND ANOTHER OUTSIDE COMPANU. MPL IS CURRENTLY OPERATING THE PIPELINE  AT REDUCED RATES, WHICH WILL CONTINUE UNTIL THE FAILURE MECHANISM IS KNOWN AND THE REMEDIATION PLAN HAS BEE APPROVED BY THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PIEPL;INE SAFETY.  AS OF JAN 3, 2006, MPL HAS RECEIVED AND REVIEWD REPORTS FROM OUTSIDE BENDORS STATING THE AUSE OF THE RELEASE TO THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS DUE TO LACK OF FUSION OR A "COLE WELD".  RELEASE ESTIMATE OF 52 BBLS WAS CALCULATED BY EFI GLOBAL AND WAS BASED ON THE TOTAL PETRO HYDOCARB ANALYSIS AND ASSOCIATED MASS BALANCE CONVERSION CALCULATION.  KIEFNER & ASSOC CALCULATED THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION BY GRAPHING THE PIPELINES PRESSURE CYCLES, THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RELEASED AND THE LENGTH OF THE CRACK.      JULY 8, 2013 - UPDATED H5 WITH SEAM TYPE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON DECEMBER 17TH, 2005 AT 19:00, A THIRD PARTY CALLED THE ALPHARETTA CONTROL CENTER TO REPORT THE SMELL OF FUEL COMING FROM OUR STAFFORD PUMPING STATION. THE PUMPING STATION AND THE PIPELINE WERE SHUT DOWN, INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE INITIATED AND A COMPANY EMPLOYEE WAS DISPATCHED TO THE STATION.  THE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED A RELEASE OF TURBINE FUEL UPON ARRIVAL AT THE SITE.  ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED ON SITE IN A LINED CONTAINMENT BASIN.    A&A ENVIRONMENTAL WAS DISPATCHED TO CLEAN-UP THE RELEASE.  FREE LIQUIDS WERE PICKED UP AND IMPACTED SOILS AND GRAVEL WERE REMOVED FOR OFF SITE DISPOSAL.  DURING CLEAN-UP IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CONTAINMENT BASIN LINER HAD BEEN BREACHED WHERE IT ATTACHED TO THE BASIN DISCHARGE PIPE, THUS CAUSING SOIL CONTAMINATION.      THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A CRACK IN A NIPPLE THAT CONNECTS THE PUMP DISCHARGE PRESSURE CELL TO A NEEDLE VALVE AND QUICK CONNECT.  THE CAUSE OF THE NIPPLE FAILURE HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED AT THIS TIME.  THE ENTIRE PRESSURE CELL ASSEMBLY WAS REPLACED.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: THE LANDOWNER NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER OF THE RELEASE. THE CONTROL CENTER  SHUT DOWN THE LINE SEGMENT AND NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT SUPERVISOR WHO SUMMONED OPERATION/MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL. MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE WITHIN ONE HOUR TO MANUALLY SHUT DOWN AN INJECTION PUMP AND CLOSE BLOCK VALVES TO ISOLATE THE SYSTEM. VACUUM TRUCKS AND FRAC TANKS WERE USED FOR RECOVERY AND STORAGE OF FREE OIL. THE TEXAS RRC INSPECTOR AND THE FEDERAL ON SCENE COORDINATOR FOR REGION 6 EPA ARRIVED ON SITE BY 1540.  ALL FREE OIL (1030 BBLS.)WERE RECOVERED WITHIN 24 HOURS. THE REMOVAL OF CONTAMINATED SOIL BEGAN ON 12/27/2005 AND THE LINE WAS CLAMPED. THE LINE SEGMENT REMAINS SHUT DOWN UNTIL REPAIRS WILL ALLOW A SMART PIG TOOL TO BE RUN PRIOR TO STARTUP OF THE SYSTEM.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON DEC. 10, 2005 AM AT 08:30 HRS, COMPANY PERSONNEL RUNNING ONE OF THE BI-DAILY PATROLS SET IN PLACE TO MONITOR THE LEAKSITE OF DEC. 2, 2005, THAT WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED BY A PIPELINE CLAMP IN NUECES BAY, DISCOVERED AN OIL SHEEN OVER THE HOUSTON 12" PRODUCT PIPELINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY AND AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE (TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE, NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, TEXAS CHEMTEL, AND TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION).    COMPANY PERSONNEL BLOCKED IN THE LEAKING SEGMENT AND BOOMED THE AREA OF THE SHEEN.  NITROGEN WAS INJECTED WITH A PIG TO REPLACE THE LEAKING PRODUCT.  DIVERS WER CALLED AND THE "FLOW SERVE" PIPELINE CLAMP WAS REPLACED BY A PLIDCO PIPELINE CLAMP WITH A MORE SUITABLE SEAL OF MARINE APPLICATION.  THE LINE WAS CHECKED FOR LEAKS THEN RESTARTED WITH PRODUCT.  A SUBSEQUENT INSPECTION REVEALED NO LEAKS.    THE PIPELINE, FROM THE DEC. 2, 2005 RELEASE AND TEMPORARY CLAMP REPAIR TO DEC. 6, HAD BEEN OPERATING AT PRESSURES OF 500 PSIG REDUCED FROM TYPICAL LEVELS WITHIN THE 100O PSIG MOP.  ON DEC. 6, 2005, THE OPERATING PRESSURE WAS INCREASED TO 800 PSIG.  ON DEC. 10, AT 0832 HRS, THE CLAMP WAS DISCOVERED TO BE LEAKING AND SUBSEQUENTLY, THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  THE FLOWSERVE CLAMP WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH PLIDCO CLAMP. ON DEC. 11, AT 0745 HRS, THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE OPERATING AT REDUCED PRESSURE OF 500 PSIG UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE.  THE DAMAGED SEGMENT WAS OR REPLACED WITH 42' OF NEW PIPE ON DEC. 20, 2005.  AFTER INSPECTING FOR LEAKS, THE LINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AT NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE AND SURFACE PATROLS OF THE LEAK AREA CONDUCTED DAILY SINCE DEC. 4, 2005 WERE DISCONTINUED.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO COMPONENT FAILURE.

column7: HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: OTHER
column70: PIPE LEAK AT TYPE B SLEEVE
column245: LANDOWNER DISCOVERED A VAPOR CLOUD IN REMOTE FIELD ON 12/27/2005 AND NOTIFIED EPOLP. EPOLP PROMPTLY SHUTDOWN THE LINE, NOTIFIED LOCAL FIRE AND POLICE, AND BEGAN VENTING PRODUCT FOR EXCAVATION & REPAIR. ONE RAILROAD AND SEVERAL LOCAL GRAVEL ROADS WERE BLOCKED UNTIL AREA MADE SAFE. AN ESTIMATED 3113 BBLS WAS SPILLED PRIOR TO ISOLATING THE LINE. AN ADDITIONAL 6550 BBLS WERE BLOWN DOWN UNDER CONTROLLED MAINTENANCE VENTING. THE PIPE HAD A CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK ALONG THE FILLET WELD ON A TYPE B SLEEVE INSTALLED IN 1995. THE SLEEVE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE. OPS REP DAVID BARRETT WAS ON SITE DURING BLOWDOWN AND EXCAVATION. THE FAILED PIPE WAS SUBMITTED TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS. THE LINE WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE UNDER A REDUCED CONTROL SET POINT OF 959 PSIG AT THE UPSTREAM KEARNEY PUMP STATION. THE PRESSURE AT THE NEAREST UPSTREAM CONTROL POINT, AT KEARNEY STATION, WAS 1066 PSIG AT THE TIME OF THE LEAK. TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION PIPELINE FLOW AND ELEVATION, THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT THE POINT AND TIME OF THE LEAK WAS 610 PSIG.    THE KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY STRESS CORROSION CRACKING AND FURTHER CONCLUDED THAT THE DEVELOPMENT AND GROWTH OF THE CIRCUMFERENTIALLY-ORIENTED CRACK WAS INFLUENCED BY EXTERNAL FORCES ON THE PIPELINE AND HAD LITTLE, IF ANYTHING, TO DO WITH THE LEVEL OF INTERNAL PRESSURE IN THE PIPELINE.  WITH THIS INFORMATION, THE PRESSURE CONTROL AT THE KEARNEY STATION WAS RESET TO THE PRE-LEAK SET POINT.    PAGE 1 - SECTION 5 (LOSSES): OPERATOR PROPERTY DAMAGE IS REPAIR COSTS - LABOR & MATERIALS; VOLUME LOST AS RESULTS OF LEAK = 3113 BBLS AT A VALUE OF $104,366; VOLUME LOST AS RESULTS OF CONTROLLED BLOWDOWN = 6550 AT A VALUE OF $219,595.

column245: THE CISCO FIRE DEPARTMENT NOTIFIED PERSONNEL ON SITE AT CISCO STATION THAT THEY HAD RECEIVED CALLS FROM CITIZENS STATING THAT THEY SMELLED CRUDE OIL WHILE TRAVELING ON STATE HWY 206 JUST SOUTH OF THE TOWN OF CISCO, TEXAS.  THE LINE SEGMENT WAS SHUT DOWN AND LOCAL PERSONNEL BEGAN WALKING THE PIPELINE.  THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY 1/2 MILE WEST OF STATE HWY 206.  OPERATION/MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE ONSITE BY 0230.  THE RELEASE SITE WAS EXCAVATED AND A CLAMP INSTALLED BY 0530.  ALL FREE OIL WAS RECOVERED VIA VACUUM TRUCK WITHIN 24 HOURS.  EXCAVATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL BEGAN ON 11/12/2005.  REMEDIATION CELLS ARE IN PLACE AND THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WILL BE REMEDIATED ONSITE.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: THIRD PARTY LABORATORY ANALYSIS REVEALED THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  COMPANY OPINION IS THAT THE DAMAGE OCCURRED DURING THE MANUFACTURING OR COATING PROCESSES OF THE PIPE DUE TO LOCALIZED COATING DAMAGE IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK AND NOT THE ADJACENT GOUGED AREA.    ON DEC.2ND, 2005, AT 9:30 HOURS, THE CORPUS CHRISTI OIL SPILL ASSOCIATION NOTIFIED COMPANY PERSONNEL THAT AN OIL SHEEN HAD BEEN SPOTTED ON THE NORTH SIDE OF NUECES BAY OVER THE HOUSTON 12" PRODUCT PIPELINE. BY 10:30 HRS.COMPANY OPERATIONS PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE SHEEN AND DETERMINED IT WAS COMING FROM THE HOUSTON PIPELINE.THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY AND AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE MADE ( TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE, NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, TEXAS CHEMTEL, AND TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISSION).    COMPANY PERSONNEL BLOCKED IN THE LEAKING SEGMENT AND BOOMED THE AREA OF THE SHEEN.NITROGEN WAS INJECTED WITH A PIG TO REPLACE THE LEAKING PRODUCT. DIVERS WERE OQ QUALIFIED, THE LINE WAS COVERED BY JETTING , AND A "FLOW SERVE" PIPELINE CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAK AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR. THE LINE WAS CHECKED FOR LEAKS THEN RESTARTED WITH PRODUCT. A SUBSEQUENT INSPECTION REVEALED NO LEAKS. THE DAMAGED SEGMENT WAS THEN SCHEDULED FOR REPLACEMENT AS SOON AS PRACTICAL.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO BODY OF PIPE/CONSTRUCTION DEFECT.

column245: AT 1450 HOURS ON 01/07/06, OUR CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM THE WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP DISPATCHER THAT THERE WAS A POSSIBLE LEAK FROM ONE OF OUR PIPELINES ALONG OMAR ROAD IN WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, LUCAS COUNTY, OHIO.  SUNOCO PIPELINE OPERATES 2 PIPELINES AND ANOTHER LIQUID PIPELINE OPERATOR ALSO OPERATES SEVERAL PIPELINES ALONG OMAR ROAD.  ALL PIPELINES IN THIS AREA WERE SHUT DOWN WITH SUNOCO PIPELINE CREWS PERFORMING EXCAVATION OF THEIR 6-INCH PRODUCTS PIPELINE DUE TO THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE RELEASED LIQUID.  AT 0200 HOURS ON 01/08/06, A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAKING 6-INCH SUNOCO PRODUCTS PIPELINE.  THE REMAINING PIPELINES IN THE AREA WERE RESTARTED DURING THIS TIME PERIOD.    FROM 01/10/06 TO 01/13/06, THE PIPELINE WAS DISPLACED WITH NITROGEN AND A SECTION OF THE PIPELINE ALONG WITH THE REPAIR CLAMP WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW COATED AND PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE LINE WAS REFILLED AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATION ON 01/14/06.  THE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS DELIVERED TO CC TECHNOLOGY FOR A FORENSIC INVESTIGATION WHERE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CORROSION WAS MICROBIAL IN NATURE.  THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE WAS UNDER CATHODIC PROTECTION AND COATED WITH HYDROLENE FILLED WOOD BOXING.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: UPDATE AS TO CAUSE:  PER 3RD PARTY ANALYSIS, THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS STRESS CORROSION CRACKING CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.    AS TO WHAT CAUSED THE EXTERNAL CORROSION, THAT IS YET UNDETERMINED. STRAY CURRENT CORROSION WAS SUSPECTED BUT WAS NOT VERIFIED BY A CLOSE INTERVAL SURVEY.    ON THE AFTERNOON OF OCTOBER 25, 2005, THE VALERO L.P. WAS NOTIFIED BY KOCH PIPELINE PERSONNEL THAT THERE WAS POSSIBLY A LEAK DETECTED EARLIER BY EXXON-MOBIL PERSONNEL IN THE AREA OF THE HOUSTON 12" REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE ROW NEAR THE VALERO REFINERY TANK FARM, OUTSIDE OF REFINERY PROPERTY.  COMPANY FIELD PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND BEGAN A SEARCH FOR THE LEAK.  IMMEDIATELY, THE CONTROL ROOM WAS CALLED FOR ANY ALARMS OR UNDERAGE IN THROUGHPUT, AND ALL QUERYS WERE NEGATIVE.  VALERO THEN SAMPLED THE POOLED PRODUCT AND DETERMINED THAT IT CONTAINED SMALL AMOUNTS GASOLINE.  VALERO CONTINUED WITH KOCH PERSONNEL IN SEARCHING THE PIPELINE CORRIDOR FOR THE SOURCE THROUGHOUT THE DAYS OF OCTOBER 26 AND 27.  DURING THIS TIME THE INITIAL RESPONSE AND CONTAINMENT MEASURES WERE IN PLACE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS PERFORMING RECOVERY OPERATIONS.  IN FURTHER EFFORTS TO RULE OUT CUSTODY OF THIS RELEASE, THE COMPANY BEGAN A HYDROTEST ON THE LINE AT 18:35 ON OCTOBER 29TH.  AT 18:45 THE PINHOLE IN THE PIPE WAS DISCOVERED AND THE LINE WAS SHUT THE LINE DOWN FOR REPAIRS.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE AND CALLS ERE PLACED TO THE NRC, THE RRC, AND CHEMTREC.    THE SEGMENT OF PIPE CONTAINING THE DEFECT WAS SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LAB FOR ANALYSIS ON NOVEMBER 1, 2005.  THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE REMAINS UNKNOWN.       4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE OF CORROSION CHANGED FROM STRESS CORROSSION CRAKING TO ROOT CAUSE OF STRAY CURRENT.

column245: HURRICANE RITA DAMAGED PIPELINE.  REPAIRS TO THE LINE WERE BEING CONDUCTED.  DIVERS WERE PERFORMING A CUT ON THE 8" PIPELINE TO REMOVE A PIECE OF DAMAGED PIPE FROM THE LINE.
