column30: OTHER
column245: HURRICANE RITA DAMAGED PIPELINE - REPAIR ACTIVITY.   DIVERS WERE CUTTING A PIPELINE SUBSEA.  WHEN THE PIPE PIECES SEPARATED, THE PIPELINE END MOVED A DISTANCE OF 4FT.  WHEN THE PIPE MOVED, APPROX. 5 GALLONS OF OIL ESCAPED OUT THE END OF THE PIPE.  THE DIVER IMMEDIATELY STUCK A PIG IN THE END OF THE PIPE TO PREVENT ANY MORE OIL FROM ESCAPING.    DIVERS HAD INSTALLED A HUMP TO CREATE A LOCAL HIGH POINT TO KEEP OIL AWAY FROM THE CUT.  A TEMP. HOT-TAP AT THE CUT POINT TO CHECK FOR OIL, NONE FOUND.  A POLLUTION DOME WAS IN PLACE OVER THE CUT, IT BECAME INEFFECTIVE ONCE THE LINE HAD MOVED.  A 2.5 TON DEAD-MAN ANCHOR WAS ALSO ATTACHED TO THE PIPELINE AS IT WAS BEING CUT.  IT DID NOT PREVENT MOVEMENT.

column245: OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE - THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR FOR FARMER.  CONTRACTOR MADE ONE CALL.  COMPANY CONTACT WAS MADE NEXT DAY WITH CONTRACTOR CONTACT ON SITE.  DISCUSSED ACTIVITY AND MARKINGS.  CONTRACTOR STATED THAT HE WOULD STAY AWAY FROM AREA.  PIPELINE ROAD MARKER WAS 134 FEET FROM RELEASE LOCATION.  CONTRACTOR WAS DEEP RIPPING THE FIELD WITH A CAT D-11, PULLING A SIX FOOT LONG RIPPER TOOTH BURIED FULL DEPTH.  CAT OPERATOR WAS NOT CONTACT PERSON.  THE RIPPER TOOTH SEVERED THE 10" PIPELINE.  OIL DRAINED FROM THE PIPELINE AND WAS CONTAINED IN THE TRENCH CUT BY THE RIPPER TOOTH.

column241: JENNIFER RADER, MPL ENVIRONMENTAL, SAFETY AND REGULATORY COM
column245: ON JANUARY 13, 2006, MARATHON PIPE LINE LLC (MPL) RECEIVED A CALL FROM A LOCAL LANDOWNER NOTING A SHEEN AND SMELL OF PRODUCT ON A CREEK IN PARKE COUNTY NEAR RACCOON LAKE, IN. MPL SHUT DOWN THE WOOD RIVER - CLERMONT 10" PRODUCTS SYSTEM TO DEPLOY EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES AND INVESTIGATE THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE. DURING THE EXCAVATION NEAR THE PIPE, AN AREA OF WET PRODUCT WAS NOTED ALONG WITH A SMALL AREA OF COATING FALLING FROM THE PIPELINE. THE RELEASE WAS DEFINED AS A PINHOLE IN THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION ON SEAMLESS PIPE. ULTRASONIC THICKNESS (UT) TESTING WAS PERFORMED ON THE AREA OF PIPELINE WHERE THE PINHOLE WAS LOCATED. A ONE- INCH DIAMETER AREA OF LAMINATION WAS IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE PIPE WALL. MPL CONDUCTED UT ON ADDITIONAL AREAS OF THE PIPELINE IN THE LOCATION OF THE RELEASE AND ALL READINGS WERE WITHIN TOLERANCE OF THE NOMINAL PIPE WALL THICKNESS AND THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF EXTERNAL CORROSION. AFTER COMPLETING THE NON-DESTRUCTIVE TESTING, MPL REPAIRED THE DEFECT BY INSTALLING A TYPE "B" SLEEVE ON THE PIPELINE ON JANUARY 14, 2006 AND RESTARTING THE PIPELINE ON JANUARY 15, 2006. THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS BASED ON INFORMATION BY THE THIRD PARTY WHO CALLED IN THE RELEASE ON JANUARY 13, 2006. 4/20/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. PLOTTED COORDINATES AND NOTICED THEY WERE INACCURATE. UPDATED ACCORDINGLY. PREVIOUSLY, LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE WERE REPORTED AS 39.4532N AND 87.042410W, RESPECTIVELY.

column245: ON FRIDAY, JANUARY 20, 2006 A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE REPORTED A POSSIBLE RELEASE AT BUCKEYE¿S DETROIT STATION.  HE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR WHO ACTIVATED BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  THE STATION WAS SHUTDOWN AND A CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.      AFTER EXTENSIVE EXCAVATION OF THE STATION GROUNDS AND PRESSURE TESTING OF STATION PIPING A CRACKED 1/2¿ BURIED DRAIN CONNECTION WAS DISCOVERED ON SATURDAY, JANUARY 28, 2006.  THIS CONNECTION WAS REMOVED AND CAPPED.      ALL EXCAVATION AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES WERE DONE WITH CONSULTATION WITH THE UNITED STATES ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY.      THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.      INVESTIGATION FINDING - EQUIPMENT USED DURING SCRAPER TRAP REMOVAL WORK MAY HAVE CAUSED DAMAGED DRAIN CONNECTION.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THE INCIDENT REVIEW OF THE RELEASE OF 45 BARRELS OF OIL AT SUNSET STATION ON FEBRUARY 9, 2006 WAS DUE TO A PACKING FAILURE THROUGH THE RECIPROCATING PUMP G-2.  THIS WAS A TOTAL FAILURE OF THE PACKING WHICH CAUSED A SEGMENT OF THE PACKING TO SEPARATE AND BLOW OUT PAST THE PACKING GLAND THAT HOLDS THE PACKING IN PLACE.  THE SEPARATED PIECE FOUND ITS WAY INTO THE DRAIN PIPING AND WEDGED ITSELF INTO THE DRAIN, THUS PLUGGING THE DRAIN AND RENDERING THE SEAL FAILURE SWITCH INEFFECTIVE.  THE OIL WITHIN THE PUMP CONTINUED TO PUMP OUT OF THE GLAND (WHICH NOW ACTED AS AN ORIFICE) AND THE SPRAY AROUND THE PUMP INDICATES THAT THE RELEASE WAS DISPERSED OUT OF THE PUMP COVER ONTO THE BELT/MOTOR DRIVE GUARD AND SURROUNDING FAILURE.

NO VAPOR CLOUD OR VISIBLE SIGN OF NH3 LEAKAGE.  11:52-PCC NOTIFIED VALERO EMPLOYEE TO INVESTIGATE, THEN STOPPED PRODUCT FLOW TO AREA BY REMOTELY CLOSING UPSTREAM BLOCK VALVE AT HERMANN, MO.  ALSO REMOTELY CLOSED UPSTREAM MAINLINE VALVE AT CANTON, MO PUMP STATION.  11:53-INCREASED DELIVERIES AT MARSHALLTOWN AND WASHINGTON DOWNSTREAM FACILITIES TO REDUCE PRESSURE.  11:55-NOTIFIED APPROPRIATE VALERO MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL.  12:10-REMOTELY CLOSED DOWNSTREAM VALVE AT ELDORA, IA PUMP STATION.  12:39-VALERO EMPLOYEE MANUALLY CLOSED VALVE 6-1 UPSTREAM OF AREA.  13:02-VALERO EMPLOYEE ON SITE AND CONFIRMED AMMONIA ODOR AT VALVE. BACK FILLED AND COVERED WITH PLASTIC.  NOTIFIED T.D. WILLIAMSON TO SEND A STOPPLE CREW TO REPLACE VALVE. column245: THE CRUDE OIL WAS DETECTED BY THE LINE FLYER ON FEBRUARY 1, 2006 AT APPROX 0950. PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE SITE AND UPON VERIFICATION OF A SMALL POOL OF CRUDE OIL ON THE SURFACE THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN. AT 10:15, EXCAVATION OF THE PIPE REVEALED A SMALL, APPROX 5 INCH CRACK IN THE LONG SEAM OF THE PIPE ADJACENT TO THE UPSTREAM GIRTHWELD. THE CRACK IS ATTRIBUTED TO A MATERIAL DEFECT WITH THE MANUFACTURE OF THE PIPE. THE CRACK WAS REPAIRED BY INSTALLING A TYPE B SLEEVE.    IT IS ESTIMATED THAT APPROX 50 BARRELS OF OIL WAS RELEASED. ALL OIL AND CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS RECOVERED. NO IMPACTS TO WILDLIFE, GROUNDWATER, OR THE PUBLIC OCCURRED. SOIL WILL BE TREATED/DISPOSED AT A LICENSED FACILITY.

column245: 02/21/06  08:00(APPROX.) - PIPELINE EMPLOYEE INVESTIGATED DISCOLORED STANDING RAIN AND DISTRESSED VEGETATION AT SITE. DISCOVERED SMELL OF AMMONIA AND SOME BUBBLES OF AMMONIA SEEPING THROUGH STANDING RAIN WATER ON TOP OF RIGHT OF WAY. NOTIFIED AREA MANAGER. NOTIFIED APPROPRIATE VALERO MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL.    08:15 (APPROX.)- REDUCED PIPELINE PRESSURE AT SITE FROM APPROX. 1,200 PSI TO 500 PSI VIA PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER. BEGAN PROCESS OF MOBILIZING APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL AND REPAIR EQUIPMENT.     08:50(APPROX.) BEGAN TO TELEPHONE NOTIFICATION TO APPROPRIATE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. NRC # 788691.    11:55 -- TRACKHOE ON SITE TO INSTALL BERMS, PER LA-DEQ,AROUND LEAK SITE TO PREVENT STANDING RAIN WATER FROM MIGRATING. MONITORED SITE OVERNIGHT.     02/22/2006- DUG BELL HOLES FOR ANTICIPATED DOUBLE STOPPLE TO REMOVE AFFECTED SECTION OF PIPE. CONTAMINATED WATER AND SOIL WAS DISPOSED OF AT A CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES WITH OVERSIGHT FROM LA-DEQ.CLOSED APPROPRIATE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES. ISOLATION OF RELEASE SITE ACCOMPLISHED AT APPROX. 2207. BEGAN OVERNIGHT PROCESS OF BURNING OFF AMMONIA VAPORS VIA PORTABLE FLARE. LA-DEQ WAS INVOLVED IN THE PERMITTINGFOR THE PRODUCT FLARING.    02/23/2006--  EXCAVATED DOWN TO PIPE AND FOUND LEAK ORIGINATING FROM REPAIR SLEEVE. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS DISPOSED OF AT A CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES WITH OVERSIGHT FROM LA-DEQ. NO ADDITIONAL WATER OR SOIL REMEDIATION IS NECESSARY. CUT OUT THE AFFECTED SECTION OF PIPE AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE.  LINE RETURNED TO SERVICE AT APPROX. 23:30.    03/08/2006--  THE REMOVED REPAIR SLEEVE AND PIPE WERE CAPPED AND HYDRO TESTED TO VALIDATE CAUSE AND VOLUME OF RELEASE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE WAS A PRE-EXISTING LACK OF FUSION ON THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM OF THE 6¿ PIPE.  THE MOST PROBABLE CAUSE TO TRIGGER THE FAILURE WAS AGING WITH CYCLICAL OPERATION OF THE SYSTEM.  THERE WAS NO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE SPIKE, INADVERTENT VALVE CLOSURE OR PRESSURE SURGE FOUND IMMEDIATELY PRIOR TO THE FAILURE EVENT.  THE SECTION OF THE FAILED SEAMED PIPE WAS NOT RECORDED WITHIN THE PIPELINE DATABASE.  THE DATABASE IDENTIFIED THE SECTION OF PIPE AS SEAMLESS CONSTRUCTED PER API 5L X-42.  THE FAILED PIPE WAS TESTED AND IDENTIFIED AS BUTT WELD WROUGHT IRON PIPE, WHICH IS AN ACCEPTABLE PIPELINE MATERIAL PER 20TH EDITION OF API 5L.

column245: WE WERE PRESSURE TESTING OUR 4 INCH OIL LINE AFTER RITA. AFTER ALL TESTS WERE DONE WE WAITED UNTIL MORNING TO BRING PIPELINE ONLINE. I TALKED WITH PLAINS AND WAS TOLD PIPELINE WOULD BE OPENED UP BY 9 AM. WE BROUGHT HI S/T ON-LINE. PHONES WERE DOWN DUE TO RITA. OUR PUMPS CAME ONLINE AROUND 11:30 AM. WE GOT A PSH ON THE PIPELINE DUE TO THE PLAINS NOT OPENING THE VALVE. A LEAK WAS FOUND LATER DUE TO OUR 4 IN PIPELINE SETTING DOWN ON A 16 INCH PIPELINE CAUSING THEM TO RUB. THE LINES WERE IN THE SURFAT HIGH TIDE. THE PIPE WAS WORN THIN. THE LINES WASHED WASHED OUT DUE TO RITA CAUSING THE RUPTURE.

column245: AT 10:44 A.M. THE PUMP AT PRI STATION ON THE POWDER RIVER PIPELINE SYSTEM WAS STOPPED.  AT 10:48 A.M. PLC SHOWED A LOW SUCTION PRESSURE ALARM WHICH WAS THE START OF THE RELEASE.  LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY.  COMPANY PERSONNEL WAS DISPATCHED TO PRI STATION. AFTER ARRIVAL IT DTERMINDED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS FROM A FAILURE OF THE 3/8" FITTING ON THE SUCTION PRESSURE TRANSMITTER.  BROKEN FITTING WAS REPLACED.

column245: ON SATURDAY, APRIL 1, 2006 THE SEAL ON THE MAINLINE PUMP AT BUCKEYE'S DIAMOND PUMP STATION FAILED.  LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL DISCOVERED THE FAILURE AND REPORTED IT TO THEIR LOCAL SUPERVISOR AND THE MACUNGIE CONTROL CENTER.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND BUCKEYE'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.     AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION THE CAUSE OF THE SEAL FAILURE WAS DETERMINED TO BE ABRASIVE SOLIDS IN THE SEAL FLUSH FLUIDS.     ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND CLEAN-UP ACTIVITIES WERE COMPLETED.

column245: A PINHOLE LEAK ON A BURIED GIRTH WELD WAS DISCOVERED FROM DEAD VEGETATION.  THE LEAK WAS AT THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION.    A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED TO REPAIR THE LEAK.  THE PIPELINE WAS NOT SHUTDOWN FOR REPAIR, AND MINOR PITTING IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK WAS INCIDENTAL TO THE LEAK.     ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND REMEDIATION HAS BEEN COMPLETED.

column245: DURING A ROUTINE FACILITY DRIVE THROUGH, THE ON DUTY OPERATOR NOTICED A SMALL STREAM OF GASOLINE FLOWING FROM UNDER THE NORTH SIDE OF TANK 1505.  THE TERMINAL SUPERVISOR WAS NOTIFIED AND RESPONSE TO THE INCIDENT COMMENCED. TANK 1505 AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK, HAD APPROXIMATELY 122,000 BBLS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE IN THE TANK.  A TRANSFER FROM TANK 1505 TO OTHER LOCAL TANKAGE ON SITE WAS STARTED TO EMPTY TANK 1505.  ADDITIONAL A DELIVERY OF 30,000 BBLS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE WAS MADE TO MAGELLAN.  MORE INFORMATION TO FOLLOW AS INVESTIGATION OF INCIDENT HAS NOT BEEN COMPLETED.     11/26/07  THE TANK BOTTOM WAS SANDBLASTED AND THE PIT WITHIN THE PIT MORPHOLOGY ASSOCIATED WITH MICROBIAL (MIC) ATTACK WAS OBVIOUS.  THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF THE MIC WAS DUE TO SULFATE REDUCING BACTERIA (SRB)AND OTHER ACID PRODUCTIN BACTERIA (APB).

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A WOMAN OF THE PUBLIC CALLED THE CONTROL CENTRE INFORMING THEM OF A LEAK AT OUR BRITTON PUMP STATION. NOTIFICATION PROCEDURES WERE FOLLOWED, AND A LOCAL TECHNICIAN TRAVELED TO THE SITE. APPROXIMATELY 25 BBLS. OF OIL HAD LEAKED FROM NEARBY THE PUMP (WHICH IS NOT LOCATED INSIDE A BUILDING) AND WAS POOLED IN A COUPLE LOCATIONS AT THE STATION, AND HAD SPRAYED OVER THE PUMP AND OTHER PARTS OF THE STATION AND NEARBY PUBLIC ROAD. THE LINE HAD BEEN SHUT DOWN UPON RECEIVING THE CALL FROM THE WOMAN. UPON FURTHER EXAMINATION, IT WAS FOUND THAT A NIPPLE ON A PRESSURE TRANSMITTER NEAR THE PUMP HAD CRACKED. THE NIPPLE WAS ISOLATED WITH A 2" VALVE, THE STATION SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVES WERE CONFIRMED CLOSED, AND THE AUTHORITY WAS GIVEN TO START THE LINE ON STATION BYPASS. CREWS WERE MOBILIZED TO CLEAN THE SPILL AND REPAIR THE CRACKED NIPPLE. THE ROAD AND THE DITCH WERE ONLY IMPACTED BY A MIST OF OIL. THERE WAS NO FREE OIL IN THESE AREAS, AND THE ROAD WAS NOT SLIPPERY.

column245: OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISCOVERED THE LEAK.  AN 0-RING ON A BURIED STOPPLE FITTING LEAKED.  THE LEAK COULD NOT BE STOPPED BY TIGHTENING.  THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN. ANHYDROUS AMMONIA PRODUCT WAS DISPLACED WITH NITROGEN AND THEN THE FITTING WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH PRE-TESTED 8.625", 0.219" WALL THICKNESS, API 5L X-52 PIPE.    SOIL AT THE LEAK LOCATION WAS CONTAMINATED AND IS BEING REMEDIATED.  FURTHER SITE WORK WILL DETERMINE THE FINAL AMOUNT OF SOIL CONTAMINATION AND DETERMINE WHETHER ANY GROUND WATER WAS ALSO CONTAMINATED.        UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: AT 0700 HRS ON APRIL 29, 2006, SUNOCO PIPELINE LP RESPONDED TO A CRUDE OIL RELEASE AT THE SINCLAIR REFINERY IN TULSA. 63BBLS OF CRUDE HAD BEEN RELEASED INSIDE THE TANK DYKE AT TANK 1 DELIVERY. THE ACCUMULATED OIL WAS RECOVERED VIA VACUUM TRUCK AND DELIVERED TO THE REFINERY OIL/WATER SLOP TANK. APPROX. 60 BBLS WERE RECOVERED. SOIL REMEDIATION WITHIN THE TANK DYKE AREA ARE BEING DONE TO OCC/ODEQ RULES AND REGS.  THE RELEASE WAS DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION ON A DEAD LEG OF PIPE.  FOUR GEESE WERE OBSERVED WALKING IN THE CONTAMINATED AREA SO A LOCAL WILDLIFE RECOVERY SPECIALIST (RECOMMENDED BY THE TULSA ZOO) WAS CONTACTED TO OBSERVE THE GEESE AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS. THE GEESE WERE OBSERVED FOR 2.5 HRS AFTER CAPTURE ATTEMPTS WERE UNSUCCESSFUL. THE GEESE WERE OBSERVED FEEDING AND GROOMING THEMSELVES AND EXHIBITED NO ILL EFFECTS.  THE WERE OBSERVED FLYING AWAY FROM THE AREA.  THIS SEGMENT OF PIPELINE IS SCHEDULED FOR AN INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT IN JUNE 2006.

column245: OPERATOR CONNECTED 2" SUCTION HOSE TO THE TRANSMIX BLEND PUMP, BLED AIR OFF OF THE PUMP AND OPENED APPROPRIATE VALVING TO COMPLETED TRANSFER.  OPERATOR WENT TO LOCAL CONTROL CNETER AND STARTED PUMP.  THE TANK GAUGING SYSTEM WAS NOT SHOWING ANY MOVEMENT OUT OF THE TANK.  OPERATOR WENT BACK TO THE PUMP THINKING PUMP WAS ON AIR AND BLED AIR OFF OF PUMP.  NORMAL FLOW RATE (42 BPH)FROM THE TANK WAS OCCURING WHEN THE OPERATOR ARRIVED BACK TO THE CONTROL CENTER.  AS OPERATOR WAS WATCHING TANK GAUGE OPERATOR NOTICED THAT THE FLOW RATE HAD JUMPED TO 128 BPH, OPERATOR WENT TO CHECK THE PUMP.  UPON ARRIVING IT WAS FOUND THAT THE CAMLOCK FITTING HAD COME LOOSE AND TRANSMIX WAS FLOWING INTO THE CONCRETE CONTAINMENT CATCH BASIN. TRANSFER WAS SHUT DOWN AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES COMMENCED. DESIGN CHANGES ARE BEING MADE TO HARD PIPE THIS OPERATION TO ELIMINATE THE USE OF A HOSE.

column245: OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A PINHOLE LEAK ON A BURIED GIRTH WELD.    THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN ON MAY 23, 2006 FOR REPAIR AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON MAY 25, 2006.    A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON MAY 25, 2006 TO REPAIR THE LEAK.  THE WELD AREA AROUND THE INSTALLED SLEEVE WAS INSPECTED BY MAG PARTICLE, AND NO CRACKS WERE FOUND.    THE PINHOLE WAS IN A GIRTH WELD THAT WAS MADE IN 1997 FOR THE INSTALLATION OF A PIPE PUP.     THE FILING ON MARCH 19,2008 WAS MADE AS A SUPPLEMENTAL FILING BECAUSE ONGOING ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS NOT ADEQUATELY DELINEATED AT THAT TIME.     UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column245: A SEVERE THUNDERSTORM PASSED THROUGH THE AREA ACCOMPANIED BY LIGHTNING STRIKES.  LIGHTNING STRUCK THE GROUND A SHORT DISTANCE FROM THE UNDERGROUND PIPELINE, TRAVELING THROUGH THE GROUND TO OUR PIPELINE.  A 1/4" HOLE WAS FORMED WHERE THE LIGHTNING LEFT THE UNDERGROUND PIPELINE ALLOWING PRODUCT TO BE RELEASED FROM THE PIPELINE.  THIS PRODUCT IGNITED AND BURNED UNTIL THE PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED AND BLED DOWN.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED AND PUT BACK IN SERVICE.  THE SECTION OF REMOVED PIPELINE WAS SUBMITTED FOR ANALYSIS WITH RESULTS PENDING.      NOTE: PART C-3-A PUNCTURE DIAMETER IS ACTUALLY 1/4" IN LIEU OF 1" INDICATED ON REPORT.     JULY 11, 2007: UPON RECEIPT AND REVIEW OF THE FINAL METALLURGY REPORT FROM KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, IT WAS CONCLUDED THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT WAS FROM A LIGHTNING STRIKE.

column238: INTERNAL ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE.
column245: ON THURSDAY, 5/18/06, AT APPROXIMATELY 12:54 WE HAD AN EVENT AT OUR MORRIS STORAGE FACILITY THAT INVOLVED OUR 25,000 BARREL NATURAL GASOLINE SPHERE.  THE EVENT WAS DETERMINED TO BE DOT NRC REPORTABLE AT APPROXIMATELY 16:15, AND THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED BY 18:23 CST.  REPORTS AND CONFIRMATION OF FIRE MADE THE EVENT REPORTABLE.  NO PRODUCT WAS RELEASED TO THE GROUND.    OUR PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THERE WAS AN INTERNAL DEFLAGRATION WHILE THE TANKS WAS BEING FILLED.  VISIBLE DAMAGE TO THE TANK INCLUDES:  ¿ THE SHEARING OF STAIRWELL BASE SUPPORTS AT THE TOP QUARTER OF THE TANK   ¿ SHEARING OF THE TOP GUARD RAIL AT ITS BASE CONNECTS TO THE TANK,   ¿ THE SCORCHING OF THE EXTERIOR PAINT ON THE FLARE VENT LINE,   ¿ THE POSSIBLE MAXIMUM EXPANSION OF THE INSTALLED EXPANSION JOINT AND  ¿ THE DISINTEGRATION OF THE TWO ALUMINUM RELIEF VALVE BODIES.    KINDER MORGAN'S INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT AN INTERNAL ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE INGNITED THE VAPOR SPACE AT THE TOP OF THE TANK.

column245: DURING THE INSTALLATION OF A RETRACTABLE CORROSION COUPON HOUSING, THE TEMPORARY ¼¿ PLASTIC PLUG INSTALLED BY THE MANUFACTURER WASN¿T REPLACED WITH A PERMANENT ¼¿ STEEL PLUG. THE RELEASE OCCURRED WHEN THE PLASTIC PLUG WAS PUSHED OUT BY LINE PRESSURE WHEN THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE, CAUSING THE RELEASED GASOLINE TO MIST INTO THE AIR. A VAPOR MONITOR DETECTED THE RELEASE WITHIN MINUTES & THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN. THE INVOLVED EMPLOYEES HAD AN APPROVED WRITTEN WORK PROCEDURE WHICH REQUIRED PRESSURE TESTING THE INSTALLATION PRIOR TO RETURNING TO SERVICE.  THE EMPLOYEES FAILED TO FOLLOW THE PROCEDURE, WHICH WOULD HAVE PREVENTED THIS OCCURRENCE.  THE EMPLOYEES WERE COUNSELED REGARDING THEIR NON-CONFORMANCE WITH COMPANY POLICIES AND GUIDELINES. THE EMPLOYEES WERE TESTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH DOT AND WOLVERINE PIPE LINE CO. DRUG AND ALCOHOL POLICIES.  BOTH EMPLOYEE¿S TEST RESULTS WERE NEGATIVE.  SIX GALLONS WAS RECOVERED BUT ONE BARREL WAS REPORTED, BECAUSE THE ON-LINE SYSTEM WOULDN¿T ACCEPT GALLONS OR A DECIMAL NUMBER.

column245: APPROXIMATELY 1925 ON 05/21/06 ROCKLIN PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A SPRAY COMING OUT OF A PUMP FITTING. ORCC WAS CONTACTED AT 1951 AS WELL AS THE OES, NRC, CUPA AND US BOR. THE INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT THE ½ INCH STAINLESS STEEL TUBING BENEATH THE COMPRESSION FITTING ON THE ROCKLIN TO RENO UNIT #8 PUMP OUTBOARD BEARING COOLING LINE HAD FAILED. A LIGHT RAIN CARRIED THE PRODUCT BENEATH THE GRAVEL EXACERBATING THE FUEL SPREAD.

column245: WHILE ARRIVING AT PUMP STATION TO RECEIVE A PIG, LEAK WAS NOTICED COMING FROM THE O-RING WITHIN THE CLOSURE ON THE PIPELINE PIG TRAP.  CATCH BASIN WAS FULL OF GASOLINE AND 4'X 30' AREA OF SOIL WAS IMPACTED.    PIPELINE TRAP WAS ISOLATED, GASOLINE IN CATCH BASIN WAS PICKED UP.  NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.  OSRO WAS CALLED AND IMPACTED SOIL WAS CLEANED UP.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 12:45 P.M., 6-1-2006, A PRESSURE DROP WAS NOTICED ON THE 4/6 INCH PBC LINE BETWEEN MEDFORD, OK TO PONCA CITY, OK BY THE LOGISTICS CONTROLLERS. THE LINE WAS NOT ACTIVE AT THE TIME OF THIS INCIDENT. THE LOGISTICS CENTER NOTICED THE PRESSURE DROP, RECEIVED A CALL FROM A LOCAL RESIDENT AND CONFIRMED THE LEAK AT MP #2 WITH LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL.  THE NEAREST BLOCK VALVES WERE CLOSED ISOLATING THE AFFECTED SEGMENT AND ARRANGEMENTS WERE MADE TO DRAIN THE LINE INTO MEDFORD AND FLARE THE PRODUCT AT THE PONCA CITY REFINERY IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE THE RELEASE.  ONCE LINE WAS DEPRESSURED THE SEGMENT WAS REPAIRED AND PUT BACK INTO SERVICE.   THE LEAK WAS LOCATED AT A SPAN CROSSING OF A LOCAL CREEK.  UPON VISUAL EXAMINATION OF THE PIPE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE LINE HAD BEEN SHOT WITH A HIGH POWERED RIFLE, PUNCTURING THE LINE.  A HOLE 3/8 OF AN INCH BY 1/2 INCH WAS DETECTED.  LOCAL AUTHORITIES AND THE FBI WERE NOTIFIED AND ARE CONTINUING THE INVESTIGATION

column245: A LEAK OCCURRED ON THE ABOVE GROUND PIPING IN THE MARYSVILLE UPSTREAM DENSITOMETER BUILDING ON LINE 5, SPILLING CRUDE OIL OUT OF THE BUILDING AND INTO THE NEARBY DITCH. PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THE DENSITOMETER PUMP FAILED, CAUSING THE CRUDE OIL TO BE RELEASED. IT ALSO APPEARS THAT THE CHECK VALVE ON THE DISCHARGE SIDE OF THE DENSITOMETER PIPING FAILED, CAUSING CRUDE TO FLOW BACK INTO THE DENSITOMETER PUMP FROM THE MAIN LINE. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE. SAMPLES WERE TAKEN TO VERIFY CLEAN SOIL. THE PUMP AND CHECK VALVE WERE REPLACED, AND THE UNIT WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE ON 6/14/06.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT 2010 HOURS ON JUNE 6, 2006, MID-VALLEY PIPELINE CLOSED OUT A DELIVERY INTO THE SUN MID-AMERICA TANK FARM. AT APPROXIMATELY 2300 HOURS THE OREGON PD RECEIVED A CALL VIA THE 911 SYSTEM REGARDING AN ODOR OF FUEL/PETROLEUM. OREGON PD RESPONSE TO THE NOTICE RESULTED NOTICE OF A POSSIBLE SPILL NEAR MID-VALLEY'S SAMPLING SYSTEM AT SUN MID-AMERICA TANK FARM. LOCAL MID-VALLEY PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND CONFIRMED THE LEAK.  COMPANY AND CONTRACTOR PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED AND BEGAN CLEANUP ACTIVITIES. UPON EXCAVATION, A PINHOLE LEAK WAS FOUND IN THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE 16" MAINLINE RELIEF SYSTEM PIPING.  A PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AND THE LINE RETURNED TO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 1530 HOURS ON JUNE 7, 2006.  THE ORIGINAL LEAK WAS APPROXIMATELY 1 BBL WITH APPROXIMATELY 19 BBLS DRAINING OUT OF THE PINHOLE AFTER THE SECTION WAS BLOCKED IN.  THE DRAIN DOWN WAS CAUGHT IN A PAN AND REMOVED BY VACUUM TRUCK.  AFFECTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND PLACED IN ROLL OFFS FOR DISPOSAL.  ON JUNE 21, 2006, A RAIN EVENT OCCURRED AT THE MID-AMERICA TANK FARM. REFINERY PERSONNEL NOTICED A SLIGHT SHEEN NEAR THE AREA OF THE LEAK AND REPORTED THIS TO THE NRC.  MID-VALLEY PERSONNEL INVESTIGATED AND FOUND NO LEAKAGE.  THE SHEEN WAS CHARACTERIZED AS EXTREMELY LIGHT AND LOOKED LIKE SOMETHING ONE WOULD SEE ON A PAVED ROAD AFTER A LIGHT RAIN.

column245: ON SUNDAY, JUNE 11, 2006, BUCKEYE¿S LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL WAS RECEIVING PRODUCT FROM A SHIPPER AT BUCKEYE¿S HARTSDALE STATION.  THE SHIPPER WAS DELIVERING NAPHTHA AND THEN SWITCHING TO RAFFINATE WITH A SPOT OF DIESEL FUEL BETWEEN THE TWO.  DURING THE SWITCH BUCKEYE¿S LOCAL OPERATOR OPENED AND CLOSED VALVES TO SWITCH BETWEEN TANKS, DURING THIS SWITCH THE LOCAL OPERATOR FAILED TO OPEN ONE OF THE VALVES LOCATED ON THE TANK MANIFOLD CAUSING A GASKET ON THE VALVE TO FAIL WHEN PRESSURE BUILT AGAINST THE CLOSE VALVE.   THE LOCAL OPERATOR SHUTDOWN THE DELIVERY AND CONTACTED THE SHIPPER AND THE HARTSDALE SUPERVISOR AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.  BUCKEYE¿S MAINTENANCE CREW ALONG WITH A LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONTRACTOR RESPONDED TO THE INCIDENT.   ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ALONG WITH SCHERERVILLE HAZMAT TEAM RESPONDED.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON JUNE 12, 2006, THE CONTENTS OF TANK 373 A 121,000 BBL GASOLINE TANK WERE IGNITED BY LIGHTNING STRIKE. THE LIGHTING STRIKE WAS WITNESSED BY EXPLORER PERSONNEL AND OTHER AREA WITNESSES.    ACCORDING TO PRELIMINARY ESTIMATES, THE TANK CONTAINED APPROXIMATELY 118,000 BARRELS OF REGULAR GASOLINE (87 OCTANE) WHEN THE FIRE BEGAN. THE FIRE WAS MINIMIZED BY DRAINING THE TANK CONTENTS AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE, FACTORING IN FIREFIGHTING CONSIDERATIONS AS WELL AS PUMPING CAPACITY AND GRAVITY FEED RATES.     THE STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY OF THE SIDEWALLS OF THE TANK WERE MAINTAINED SUCH THAT THERE WAS NO RELEASE OF GASOLINE TO BE ABSORBED INTO THE GROUND. THIS IS CONFIRMED BY THE FACT THAT WATER AND FIRE FIGHTING LIQUIDS RECOVERED HAVE NO PETROLEUM SHEEN.     A TOTAL OF APPROXIMATELY 24,319 BARRELS OF GASOLINE WERE BURNED IN THE FIRE OVER A PERIOD OF APPROXIMATELY 10.5 HOURS.    TANK 373 WAS AN INTERNAL FLOATING ROOF TANK WITH DUAL VAPOR WIPER SEALS.  THE TANK WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1971 TO API STANDARD 650 BY CBI.  THE TANK WAS A 48 FEET BY 140 FEET CONE ROOF TANK OPERATED AS A BREAKOUT TANK.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: DUE TO SEVERE DAMAGE FROM HURRICANE KATRINA TO THE BOA OSTRICA PIPELINE STATION A TEMPORARY CONNECTION, METERING SKID AND BOOSTER PUMPS WERE INSTALLED TO PROVIDE CRUDE OIL FLOW TO CONOCO PHILLIPS ALLIANCE REFINERY.  DURING THE INSTALLATION OF THE TEMPORARY PIPING A FLANGE WITH A 2-INCH VALVE WAS INSTALLED TO ASSIST IN THE EVACUATION OF THE LINE DURING THE INSTALLATION.  THE VALVE WAS COVERED WITH A WOODEN BOX TO PROTECT THE 2-INCH VALVE AND THEN THE EXCAVATION PIT WAS COVERED WITH SOIL.  FOLLOWING COMPLETION OF REPAIRS AT THE STATION, CONTRACTORS WERE EXCAVATING DOWN TO THE WOODEN BOX COVERING THE 2-INCH VALVE AND INADVERTENTLY STRUCK THE VALVE, CAUSING IT TO FAIL AND RELEASE THE CRUDE OIL.  THE TEMPORARY STATION WAS IMMEDIATELY BLOCKED IN AND THE RELEASED HYDROCARBONS CONTAINED WITHIN A 20'X20'X4' DEEP PIT.  THE RELEASED HYDROCARBONS WERE IMMEDIATELY VACUUMED OUT.  NO OIL MIGRATED OFFSITE.  EXCAVATION OF THE HYDROCARBON-CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS INITIATED THE FOLLOWING DAY.

THE LEAK WAS SUBSEQUENTIALLY IGNITED AND BURNED FOR APPROXIMATELY TWO HOURS BEFORE IT WAS EXTINGUISHED. column245: A PIN HOLE LEAK OCCURRED ON THE PIPING BETWEEN THE TYE TANK (#991), AND THE BOOSTER PUMP WHICH FEEDS THE MAINLINE PUMP ON THE HAWLEY TO TYE 6", 8" PIPELINE.  THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE DYKE AROUND THE TANK. THE LEAK CLEANUP COST WAS ORIGINALLY THOUGHT TO BE WELL BELOW THE 50K REPORTING THRESHOLD, SINCE IT WAS CONTAINED BY THE TANK'S SECONDARY CONTAINMENT.  EXCAVATION AROUND THE TANK TO REMOVE THE CONTAMINATED SOIL PROVED TO BE MORE EXTENSIVE AND SLOW TO COMPLETE, THUS THE HIGHER THAN EXPECTED CLEANUP COST.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: THIS LINE WAS IDLE AND FILLED WITH PROPANE AND WAS BEING PRESSURED UP UNDER A MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY TO PLACE IT INTO SERVICE WHEN THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED.  A WIRELINE SERVICE DRIVER OBSERVED A VAPOR CLOUD AND CALLED 911 AT ABOUT 6:30 AM (MOUNTAIN TIME) ON 06/23/06.  THE EUNICE FIRE CHIEF AND A NEW MEXICO STATE POLICE OFFICER WERE ON SITE BUT LEFT THE SCENE BEFORE 10:00 AM (MOUNTAIN TIME).  ENTERPRISE, UNDER CONTROLLED MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES, LOWERED THE LINE PRESSURE TO ZERO GUAGE PRESSURE BY FLARING PROPANE AT THE HOBBS STATION FLARE AND FLARING ADDITIONAL PRODUCT THROUGH A PORTABLE FLARE SET AT THE FIRST BLOCK VALVE NORTH OF THE LEAK SITE.  INITIALLY, THE PLAN WAS TO ISOLATE THE LEAK SEGMENT AT THE NEAREST BLOCK VALVE BUT THEN IT WAS DECIDED TO TAKE THE COMPLETE LINE OUT OF SERVICE BY PURGING THE LINE WITH NITROGEN.  SEPARATE NRC TELEPHONIC REPORTS WERE MADE TO REPORT THE PRODUCT FLARED AT THE SEPARATE  FLARE SITES.  CASE NUMBER 801759 REPORTED THE PRODUCT FLARED THROUGH THE PORTABLE FLARE NEAREST THE LEAK SITE, AND CASE NUMBER 801836 REPORTED THE ADDITIONAL PRODUCT FLARED AT HOBBS STATION NEAR SEMINOLE, TEXAS FOR TAKING THE LINE OUT OF SERVICE.  DURING THE FLARING PROCESS, FOUR ADDITIONAL MUCH SMALLER LEAKS WERE ALSO DISCOVERED ON THIS LINE.      ALL LEAKS HAVE BEEN REPAIRED AND THE LINE HAS BEEN HYDROTESTED.  THE LINE WILL BE RETURNED TO SERVICE AT A LATER DATE PENDING COMMERCIAL NEED FOR PRODUCT DELIVERIES TO CUSTOMERS.      EXCAVATION OF THE PRIMARY LEAK SITE REVEALED THAT THE LEAK WAS IN THE BODY OF THE PIPE AT THE 1:00 POSITION AT A HOLE OF ABOUT 3/8¿ DIAMETER INSIDE A CORROSION PIT.   IT APPEARS THAT THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A SHIELDED MOISTURE CELL UNDER DISBONDED TAPE WRAP.     THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AT BOTH FLARE SITES WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6 A. UNDER PART A IS THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE AS A RESULT OF THE LEAK.  THE TOTAL ESTIMATED REPAIR COST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT DOES NOT INCLUDE THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH PIPELINE INTEGRITY ASSESSMENT WORK REQUIRED TO MAKE THE LINE READY FOR SERVICE.

column245: APPROXIMATELY 0145 ON 06/22/06 FIELD PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A METAL SEPARATION WITHIN DENT ON OUTER SURFACE OF PIPE ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE THE LINE AND MIGRATE TO A STORM DRAIN. ORCC WAS CONTACTED AT 0226 AS WELL AS OES, NRC, CUPA AND THE US BOR. EVENT IS ASSOCIATED WITH TWO OTHER THREATENED RELEASES CALLED INTO THE AGENCIES AT 2130 ON 06/15/06 AND 1352 ON 06/16/06. THE CAUSE OF THE EVENT IS BELIEVED TO BE OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE. THE PIPE WAS SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS.   NOTE: PART A6C AMOUNT SPILLED IS ACTUAL 16.07BBLS AMOUNT RECOVERED IS ACTUAL 1.9BBLS. ALL FREE PRODUCT HAS BEEN REMOVED. WE CONSIDER THIS FINAL HOWEVER SOME FUTURE COSTS MAYBE INCURRED FOR GROUNWATER INVESTIGATION/CLEANUP.

column245: ON JUNE 22, 2006 AT 19:49 HOURS, TANK 325 AT EXPLORER PIPELINE¿S GLENPOOL, TULSA COUNTY, OKLAHOMA TANK FARM WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE FOLLOWING API 653 REPAIRS TO THE TANK, AND MAINTENANCE TO THE TANK¿S SHELL VALVE. WHEN THE SHELL VALVE WAS RE-INSTALLED, THE PROPER TORQUE ON THE VALVE BOLTS WAS NOT OBTAINED AND A RELEASE WAS EXPERIENCED AROUND THE FLANGE WHEN THE TANK WAS BEING RE-FILLED. THE TANK SHELL VALVE BOLTS WERE ADEQUATELY TORQUED, AND ALL IMPACTED SOIL HAS BEEN REMOVED.

column245: COMPANY MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A DEAD SPOT IN THE VEGETATION. EXCAVATION REVEALED A SMALL LEAK IN A FILLET WELD ON A STOPPLE SPLIT TEE FITTING AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION.  ON JULY 29, A NEW STOPPLE SPLIT TEE AND TOR FITTING WERE WELDED ONTO THE LINE PIPE.  THE NEW FILLET WELDS WERE INSPECTED WITH MAG PARTICLE ON JULY 30.  ON JULY 31, MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL SET THE STOPPLE, BLEW DOWN PRODUCT INTO A NURSE TANK, CUT OUT THE OLD SPLIT TEE AND TOR FITTING AND REPLACED THE CUT OUT WITH 5 FEET OF NEW 6.625" OD, 0.156" WT, X-46 ERW PIPE.  THE 2 TIE-IN WELDS WERE THEN X-RAYED; THE PIPE WAS SAND BLASTED AND TAPED WITH RD-6; THE SPLIT TEE WAS COATED WITH MASTIC.  LASTLY, THE LINE WAS FILLED WITH PRODUCT, THE STOPPLE PLUG WAS PULLED, THE EXCAVATED SITE WAS BACKFILLED, AND OPERATION OF THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO OPERATION CONTROL.    THE LEAK OCCURRED AT A WELD HIGH/LOW AREA WHERE THE INITIAL STOPPLE FILLET WELD WAS OF POOR QUALITY AND SUBJECTED TO EXTERNAL CORROSION. THE MATERIAL COVERING THE FAILED AREA WAS SENT TO HOUSTON FOR FURTHER EVALUATION.  THE EVALUATION CONFIRMED THAT THE CAUSE WAS A POOR WELD.    THE COST OF THE PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT IS FOR THE VOLUME OF ALL UNRECOVERED PRODUCT LOSSES ASSOCIATED WITH THE LEAK AND LEAK REPAIR WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6A UNDER PART A IS THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT IS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED DIRECTLY THROUGH THE WELD LEAK.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON JULY 25, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 0500 THE TECHNICIAN RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE CONTROL CENTER INFORMING HIM THEY RECEIVED A HIGH SUMP ALARM AT SOUTH MACON DELIVERY. THE TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT THE DELIVERY APPROXIMATELY 0521 AND PROCEEDED TO CHECK THE YARD. HE FOUND PRODUCT SPRAY ON THE GROUND IN THE MANIFOLD FROM THE SUMP. PRODUCT (GASOLINE) ALSO DISCHARGED FROM THE O/W SEPARATOR INTO A DITCH ADJACENT TO THE MANIFOLD AREA.  THE PRODUCT POOLED IN THE DITCH WITHIN AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 100' BY 3'.  THE TECHNICIAN NOTIFIED THE OM OF THE PROBEM AND SUBSEQUENTLY THE OM NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AND THE SOUTHEAST ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE INCIDENT. THE OM AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER DISPATCHED PROJECTS AND THE CONTRACTOR TO ASSIST IN THE RECOVERY.   THE TECHNICIANS RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 65 GALLONS OF PRODUCT FROM POOLED AREAS AND SUMP HOLES IN THE DITCH USING BUCKETS.  THE PRODUCT RELEASED TO THE DITCH MIGRATED APPROXIMATELY 15 BEYOND COLONIAL'S FENCE ONTO MAGELLAN'S PROPERTY.  THE TECHNICIANS NOTIFIED MAGELLAN OF A RELEASE OF PRODUCT ON THEIR PROPERTY. PRODUCT DID NOT REACH A SMALL CREEK LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 200' DOWNGRADIENT OF THE STATION.  APPROXIMATELY 65 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE MANUALLY RECOVERED FROM THE DITCH.  APPROXIMATELY 1600 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED FROM THE DITCH AREA AND MAGELLAN PROPERTY AND STOCKPILED ON SITE FOR FUTURE DISPOSAL.  AN ESTIMATED 25 GALLONS OF PRODUCT (BASED ON LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF COMPOSITE SAMPLES) WERE CONTAINED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL.   AN ESTIMATED 42 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS LOST TO EVAPORATION FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT WITHIN THE DITCH.  THE GEORGIA EPD WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE ON 7/25/06 AT 9:30 DUE TO POTENTIAL GROUNDWATER IMPACTS. RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS RELEASE HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT WAS THE SHIPPER INADVERTENTLY CLOSED THE SHIPPER TERMINAL VALVE AND CAUSED A BLOCKED LINE.   PHMSA ACCIDENT INVESTIGATOR NORTIFIED COLONIAL ON MAY 18, 2011 THAT THE APPARENT CAUSE FOR THIS ACCIDENT SHOULD BE INCORRECT OPERATION RATHER THAN OTHER SINCE THE SHIPPER INADVERTENTLY CLOSED A VALVE CAUSING A BLOCKED LINE.  THE INCIDENT ANALYSIS PERFORMED BY COLONIAL DID NOT DETERMINE THAT AN INCORRECT OPERATION TOOK PLACE BY COLONIAL.

column241: HENRY L. LEGER - DOT PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST
column245: AN ETHYLENE GAS RELEASE OCCURRED ON MONDAY, AUGUST 7, 2006, AT CHEVRON PIPE LINE'S (CPL) 16¿ ETHYLENE SYSTEM'S PLACIDE ROAD VALVE SITE. A CPL MAINTENANCE CREW ARRIVED AT THE SITE TO PERFORM WORK, SUPPORTING THE ETHYLENE SYSTEM PIM PROJECT. THE SYSTEM WAS ACTIVE, OPERATING AT A NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE OF 1200 PSIG. THE SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDED THE REMOVAL OF A 16¿ BLIND FLANGE, AND INSTALLATION OF A 16¿ GATE VALVE. THE GATE VALVE INSTALLATION WAS REQUIRED FOR THE REMOVAL OF A T. D. WILLIAMSON LOCK-O-RING PLUG THAT HAD BEEN INSTALLED IN OCTOBER, 2001. AFTER OPENING THE 1¿ BLEEDER VALVE ON THE 16¿ BLIND FLANGE AND VERIFYING 0 PSIG, THE CPL MAINTENANCE CREW BEGAN REMOVING THE 16¿ BLIND FLANGE. WHILE REMOVING THE BOLTS, ETHYLENE GAS BEGAN ESCAPING BETWEEN THE FLANGES.    IT IS SUSPECTED THAT WHILE VENTING THE PRESSURE DOWNSTREAM OF THE LOCK-O-RING PLUG, A 1200 PSI DELTA ACROSS THE PLUG FORCED THE PLUG AGAINST THE BLIND FLANGE. THE POSITION OF THE PLUG LIKELY SEALED THE BLEEDER PORT, FALSELY INDICATING NO PRESSURE BEHIND THE BLIND. ALSO, IT IS SUSPECTED THAT WHILE THE PLUG WAS FORCED AGAINST THE BLIND FLANGE, THE PLUG¿S O-RING ENTERED THE RING SEGMENT GROOVE. ENTERING THE RING SEGMENT GROOVE LIKELY CAUSED DAMAGED TO THE O-RING, ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE WHEN THE BOLTS TO THE BLIND FLANGE WERE LOOSENED.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A THIRD PARTY DISCOVERED THIS LEAK ON AUGUST 16, 2006.    AFTER DISCOVERY, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN ON AUGUST 16, 2006 FOR REPAIR.  A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE RATED FOR 1500 PSIG WAS INSTALLED ON AUGUST 17 AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR, AND THE LINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE ON AUGUST 17, 2006.    AFTER VISUAL EXAMINATION AND FROM PAST STUDIES ON THIS LINE, THE PINHOLE LEAK IN THIS PARTICULAR LONGITUDINAL SEAM WAS CONCLUDED TO BE MOST LIKELY CAUSED BY A PIPE MANUFACTURING DEFECT.      THE PLIDCO SLEEVE WAS WELDED IN AS THE PERMANENT REPAIR.     THE FILING ON MARCH 19, 2008 WAS MADE AS A SUPPLEMENTAL FILING BECAUSE ONGOING ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS NOT ADEQUATELY DELINEATED AT THAT TIME.      UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column245: A RELEASE OF APPROXIMATLY 140 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WAS DISCOVERED AS A TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT THE EL DORADO TERMINAL ON 8/13/06. THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS BURIED TERMINAL PIPING NEAR TANK 4160. THE PRODUCT MIGRATED DOWN THE SITE DRAINAGE DITCH AND INTO A POND. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT THE OIL ON THE POND COVERED AN AREA 150' X 60'. ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE TERMINAL PROPERTY. THE PIPING WAS ISOLATED AND THERE WAS NO OPERATIONAL IMPACT TO THE INTERCONNECTING PIPELINES OR REFINERY. THE NRC AND KDHE WERE NOTIFIED. VACUUM TRUCKS PICKED UP FREE PRODUCT AND CONTRACTORS WERE DISPATCHED TO EXCAVATE AND REPAIR THE PIPING.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON 8/13/2006 AT 13:44 A HIGH SUMP ALARM FROM ST. IVES STATION (LINE 2) WAS RECEIVED IN THE CONTROL CENTER.  THE CONTROLLER CALLED OUT A TECHNICIAN TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL AT APPROXIMATELY 14:30, THE TECHNICIAN DISCOVERED PRODUCT OVERFLOWING FROM THE SUMP.  THE TECHNICIAN STARTED THE SUMP PUMP TO LOWER THE PRODUCT LEVEL.  DURING PUMPING OF THE SUMP, A STUCK FLOAT SWITCH IN THE SUMP DISLODGED, TRIGGERED THE MAX FILL ALARM, AND LOCKED OUT THE STATION AS DESIGNED.   PRODUCT RELEASED FROM THE SUMP MIGRATED THROUGH THE SUBSURFACE ALONG UNDERGROUND PIPING IN THE VICINITY OF THE SUMP AND THE LINE 2 STATION YARD DRAIN SYSTEM. THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONFINED TO THE LINE 2 PORTION OF THE STATION AND OIL/WATER SEPARATOR.  SURFACE WATER WAS NOT IMPACTED.  THE TECHNICIAN NOTIFIED THE OM OF THE INCIDENT AND SUBSEQUENTLY THE OM NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AND THE SOUTHEAST ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE INCIDENT. THE STATE OF ALABAMA WAS NOTIFIED BY TELEPHONE ON 8-13-2006 AT 20:50.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES FOR THIS RELEASE HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column47: COMPANY & CONTRACTOR LABOR, EQUIP RENTAL, REPAIRS
column245: THE EIGHT INCH KINDER MORGA ENERGY PARTNERS 106W LINE LEAKED THROUGH THE BODY OF A FORTY FIVE DEGREE BEND ALIGNING THE PIPELINE WITH A PRIVATE BRIDGE CROSSING ABOVE THE DES PLAINES RIVER IN WILL COUNTY, ILLINOIS APPROXIMATELY FIFTY FEET EAST OF MAINLINE VLOCK VALVE #4.  THE LEAK WAS DUE TO EXTERNAL CORROSION ALONG THE EDGE OF A TACK-WELDED WEAR PAD.  THE CORROSIVE AGENT WAS ROAD SALT, WHICH ACCUMULATED IN HIGH CONCENTRATION IN THE GAP BETWEEN THE BEND AND THE TACK-WELDED WEAR PAD.     DURING THE RESPONSE PHASE OF THE EMERGENCY, KINDER MORGAN ESTIMATED THE RELEASE VOLUME TO BE, AT A MINIMUM, 400 BARRELS BASED ON THE LINE FILL OF THE ISOLATED SECTION OF PIPELINE BETWEEN THE UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES.   THE VOLUME OF 1419 BARRELS DENOTED IN PART A, 6 C OF THIS REPORT IS BASED ON THE VOLUME REQUIRED TO REFILL THE LINE AT START UP.  GIVEN THE NATURE OF HIGHLY VOLATILE LIQUIDS, SUCH AS REFINERY GRADE BUTANE, WE CAN NOT DETERMINE THE ACTUAL VOLUME RELEASED DURING THE EMERGENCY PHASE OF THE ACCIDENT PRIOR TO ISOLATION OF THE SECTION, AND   WHAT MAY HAVE VENTED DURING THE REPAIR PHASE.    FRACTIONAL ENTRIES NOT ALLOWED BY DOT'S ONLINE DATA ENTRY SYSTEM SO THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION WAS ROUNDED UP:  RUPTURED LEGTH IS 19 INCHES OR 1.583 FEET NOT 2 FEET AS NOT IN REPORT; ESTIMATED NUMDER OF CUBIC YARDS IS 0.5 INCLUDING VEGITATION NOT 1; ESTIMATED LEAK TIME IS 23.75 HOURS NOT 1 DAY AS NOTED.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A BICYCLIST DISCOVERED SMALL GAS BUBBLES ON THE ILLNOIS AND MICHIGAN CANAL ON 8/22/06 AND CALLED THE LEAK INTO THE COMPANY LIQUID CONTROL CENTER.  UPON ARRIVAL AT THE SITE, OPERATIONS PERSONNEL MEASURED 32% LEL NEAR THE WATER SURFACE.    THE LINE WAS BLOCKED IN AND THE CONTENTS EVACUATED. THE LOCAL FIRE MARSHAL AND COUNTY DEPUTY SHERIFF WERE ON SITE INITIALLY, AND THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TEMPORARILY CLOSED A NEARBY BICYCLE PATH WHILE THE PIPE CONTENTS WERE BEING EVACUATED.  UNDER CASE NUMBER 809136, A SEPARATE NRC TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS MADE ON AUGUST 25 TO REPORT THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS FLARED AND VENTED UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS TO EVACUATE THE LINE.  APPROXIMATELY 1400 BARRELS OF PROPANE WERE FLARED AND THE REMAINING 1740 BARRELS WERE VENTED.    THE ORIGINAL PIPE UNDER THE CANAL WAS ABANDONED IN PLACE AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE. THE 2005 ILI RUN DID INDICATE A METAL LOSS FEATURE (36% WALL LOSS)WITHIN THE CANAL CROSSING (ENGINEERING STATION 114+78); HOWEVER, THE FEATURE DID NOT MEET REPAIR CRITERIA AND THEREFORE WAS NOT INVESTIGATED FURTHER.    AN IRIS ULTRASONIC C-SCAN WAS RUN MARCH 5-9, 2007 ON THE ABANDONED SEGMENT THAT LEAKED. A CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELD WAS IDENTIFIED AS HAVING AN INCOMPLETE ROOT PASS AND INCOMPLETE CAP PASS OVER 30% OF THE PIPE CIRCUMFERENCE.  THE IRIS TOOL DID NOT INDICATE WELD DEFECTS ON ANY OTHER CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELDS WITHIN THE CANAL CROSSING AND THE MFL DID NOT IDENTIFY ANY FEATURES AT ANY OTHER CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELDS IN THIS PIPELINE SEGMENT.    THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AND VENTED WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6A UNDER PART A IS THE PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE AS A RESULT OF THE LEAK.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON AUGUST 17, 2006, AT 08:45 CDT THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM A CONTRACTOR IN NASHVILLE SAYING HE HAD HIT THE PIPELINE WITH A BULLDOZER NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF THE LINE AND NASHBORO BLVD IN METRO NASHVILLE.  THE CONTRACTOR REPORTED THAT THE LINE WAS LEAKING DIESEL FUEL.  BOTH LINES 19 AND 20 WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND AS MUCH PRESSURE AS POSSIBLE WAS REMOVED FROM LINES INTO NASHVILLE DELIVERY. AT 08:50, THE CONTROL CENTER LEADER INFORMED THE DISTRICT LEADER WHO SUBSEQUENTLY NOTIFIED THE OPERATIONS MANAGER.  AT  09:03, OPERATIONS MANAGER SENT OUT 2 NASHVILLE SENIOR OPERATORS AND 2 TECHNICIANS TO INVESTIGATE.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER MADE NOTIFICATION TO NASHVILLE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND DISPATCHED LOCAL OSROS TO THE SITE TO ASSIST IN RESPONSE AND CLEAN UP ACTIVITIES.    AT 09:26,  SENIOR OPERATOR ARRIVED ON SITE AND CONFIRMED THAT DIESEL FUEL WAS LEAKING FROM LINE 20.  THE BULLDOZER OPERATOR THAT HAD STRUCK THE LINE WAS BUILDING A DIRT BERM TO CONTAIN THE PRODUCT.  THE SENIOR OPERATOR DIRECTED THE OPERATOR TO BUILD AN ADDITIONAL BERM TO PREVENT THE PRODUCT FROM ENTERING A STORM DRAIN THAT WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET DOWNGRADIENT OF THE RELEASE POINT.  THE UPSTREAM LINE 20 BLOCK VALVE AT LAKE ROAD WAS CLOSED TO MINIMIZE THE DRAIN-UP AT THE POINT OF RELEASE.  TDEC AND NASHVILLE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT ARRIVED AT THE LEAK SITE AROUND 09:30.     AT 10:30, EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS ARRIVED AND BEGAN TO RECOVER PRODUCT THAT HAD POOLED BEHIND THE CONTAINMENT BERMS WITH VACUUM TRUCKS.  LINE 20 WAS EXCAVATED AND FUEL OIL WAS OBSERVED TO BE DRAINING OUT OF A 1-INCH BY 4-INCH HOLE IN THE PIPELINE.  A VACUUM TRUCK WAS UTILIZED TO CONTAIN AND RECOVER THE REMAINING DRAIN-UP FROM THE LEAK, WHICH CONTINUED UNTIL APPROXIMATELY 12:30.  RECONNAISANCE WAS CONDUCTED IN THE LEAK SITE VICINITY TO IDENTIFIY ALL POTENTIAL PRODUCT RESURGENCE POINTS IN THE EVENT OF PRODUCT MIGRATION THROUGH THE SUBSURFACE.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS DEPLOYED BOOM AT SIX LOCATIONS WITHIN A NEARBY CREEK AND PLUGGED THE STORM SEWER AS A PRECAUTION.  TO DATE, NO PRODUCT HAS MIGRATED TO THE CREEK, STORM DRAIN, OR SANITARY SEWER.  A PRODUCT RECOVERY TRENCH WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY AT THE BASE OF THE HILL ADJACENT TO NASHBORO BLVD.  APPROXIMATELY 1,500 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT LOCATIONS BEHIND THE CONTAINMENT BERMS AND FROM THE RECOVERY TRENCH. THE INITIAL ESTIMATED RELEASE VOLUME OF 200 BARRELS IS BASED UPON LINE FILL CALCULATIONS AND DRAIN-UP ESTIMATES.    BASED UPON A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED AT THE LEAK SITE, IT APPEARS THAT IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE ARE CONFINED TO AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 200 FEET BY 200 FEET ALONG THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY SOUTH OF NASHBORO BLVD.  EXCAVATION EFFORTS ARE UNDERWAY TO REMOVE AN ESTMATED 10,000 TO 12,000 TONS OF SOILS IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE.  EXCAVATION OF THE IMPACTED SOILS IS EXPECTED TO MINIMIZE GROUNDWATER IMPACTS AND SHOULD ALLOW FOR SITE CLOSURE FROM THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION.  THE MAJORITY OF PRODUT RECOVERED FROM THE ENVIRONMENT WILL BE FROM THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOILS.  THE FINAL VOLUME OF RECOVERED PRODUCT WILL BE DETERMINED UPON COMPLETION OF SOIL EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES.     SITE REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.  APPROXIMATELY 9,916 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED AND TRANSPORTED TO A LOCAL LANDFILL FOR DISPOSAL.  CLEAN-UP GOALS WERE MET AND A CLOSURE REQUEST WILL BE SUBMITTED TO TDEC IN JANUARY 2007.  NO ADDITIONAL ACTIONS ARE EXPECTED AT THE SITE. AN UPDATED SPILL VOLUME ESTIMATE OF 113 BARRELS HAS BEEN CALCULATED BASED UPON THE COMBINED TOTAL OF THE AMOUNT OF LIQUID PRODUCT RECOVERED AT THE SITE (35 BARRELS) AND THE ESTIMATED VOLUME OF PRODUCT ABSORBED WITHIN IMPACTED SOILS (78 BARRELS) AT THE SITE. THE SPILL VOLUME ESTIMATE ASSUMES THAT ALL OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED EITHER IN LIQUID PHASE BY VACUUM TRUCK OR IN THE ABSORBED PHASE THROUGH SOIL EXCAVATION AND THAT ONLY NEGLIGIBLE AMOUNTS OF PRODUCT WERE LOST TO EVAPORATION, DISSOLVED IN GROUNDWATER, OR REMAIN WITHIN SITE SOILS.  THIS ASSUMPTION IS BASED UPON THE LOW VOLATILITY AND SOLUBILITY OF FUEL OIL AND THE RESULTS OF SITE INVESTIGATION ACTIVITIES.

column245: NEWARK TANK NO. 26 IS A SMALL DUAL USE AND DUAL JURISDICTIONAL TANK LOCATED AT A PIPELINE CUSTOMER¿S TRUCK TERMINAL FACILITY.  IN ADDITION TO USE AS A TRANSMIX DELIVERY TANK, IT ALSO SERVES AS A PIPELINE SURGE RELIEF TANK.  ON AUGUST 29, 2006 AT 0730 HOURS LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL FOR THE TRUCK TERMINAL NOTICED A POOL OF TRANSMIX ON TOP OF WATER THAT HAD ACCUMULATED IN A SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE FROM AN OVERNIGHT RAINSTORM.  AN OSRO WAS CONTACTED TO REMOVE THE 800 GALLONS OF TRANSMIX AND 1800 GALLONS OF WATER FROM THE CONTAINMENT DIKE.  THIS SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE IS CONSTRUCTED WITH CONCRETE WALLS AND FLOOR.  DUE TO THIS UNIQUE CONSTRUCTION METHOD OF THE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIKE, NONE OF THE RELEASED TRANSMIX OR WATER IMPACTED THE ENVIRONMENT.    A CERTIFIED TANK INSPECTION CONTRACTOR INSPECTED THE TANK AND DETERMINED THAT THE TANK HAD A HOLE IN THE FLOOR AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL AREAS OF UNDERSIDE PITTING.  DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF THE UNDERSIDE PITTING AREAS, A NEW SECOND BOTTOM WAS INSTALLED IN THIS TANK.  IN THIS DOUBLE BOTTOM SCENARIO, AN HDPE LINER AND CONCRETE PAD WAS INSTALLED.  THE HDPE LINER ELECTRICALLY DISCONNECTS AND REDUCES THE POSSIBLE CORROSIVE EFFECTS ON THE REPLACEMENT FLOOR AND WILL CHANNEL ANY FUTURE COMMODITY LEAKAGE TO TANK PERIMETER LEAK DETECTION PORTS.    A TEMPORARY RESTRICTION PROHIBITING THE USE OF A LOWER PRESSURE RATED METER PROVER LOOP, FOR WHICH THE SURGE RELIEF SYSTEM IS DESIGNED, WAS PUT INTO PLACE UNTIL THE TANK REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED.  THESE TEMPORARY MEASURES WERE LIFTED AND THE METER PROVER LOOP WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE AT THE COMPLETION OF THE TANK REPAIRS IN OCTOBER 2006.

column245: APPROXIMATELY 1209 ON 08/24/06 FIELD PERSONNEL DISCOVERED STAINED DIRT AND SMELLED VAPORS WHILE INSPECTING AREA. ORANGE CONTROL CENTER WAS CONTACTED AT 1314 AS WELL AS OES, NRC, CUPA AND THE US BOR. SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT INTERNAL CORROSION CAUSED A PINHOLE LEAK IN THE WELD OF THE 2-INCH CHECKVALVE BYPASS LINE. THE CORROSION MORPHOLOGY AND THE NEAR-STAGNANT CONDITIONS IN THE BYPASS LINE INDICATE THAT THE PITTING MAY HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY MICROBIAL-INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC). HOWEVER, A CONCLUSIVE DETERMINATION OF MIC CANNOT BE MADE UNLESS SPECIFIC INTERNAL DEBRIS SAMPLING PROCEDURES ARE FOLLOWED IMMEDIATELY UPON EXPOSURE TO THE OUTSIDE ATMOSPHERE.    A SMALL AMOUNT OF GROUNDWATER ENTERED THE EXCAVATION SUBSEQUENT TO THE RELEASE CAUSING MINOR IMPACT.    NOTE: THE 2-INCH BYPASS LINE IS NOT PIGGABLE BECAUSE OF PHYSICAL RESTRAINS, HOWEVER, THE MAINLINE IS PIGGABLE.    * THE EXACT TIME OF ACCIDENT IS UNKNOWN, THEREFORE, THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE AT POINT AND TIME OF ACCIDENT IS UNKNOWN. THE OPERATING PRESSURE AT TIME OF DISCOVERY WAS 722 PSIG.

column245: A PRODUCT STAIN WAS FOUND IN THE VICINITY OF THE LINE 2 ORIGINATION VALVES AT HEBERT STATION. A CONTRACT CREW WAS BROUGHT IN THE MORNING OF SEPTEMBER 11, 2006 TO EXCAVATE THE AREA IN QUESTION. WHILE PERFORMING THE EXPLORATORY EXCAVATION, THE CREW FOUND THAT THE SOIL AROUND THE PORT ARTHUR/MOBIL OIL TO OIL ORIGINATION VALVE WAS HEAVILY SATURATED WITH FUEL OIL. THE OPERATIONS MANAGER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE FINDINGS AND HE CONTACTED THE DISTRICT LEADER. THE ORIGINATION VALVE WAS FULLY EXCAVATED AND IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE GASKET ON THE DOWNSTREAM FLANGED CONNECTION WAS THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE. APPROXIMATELY 35 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND 1 BARREL OF FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS. LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE EXCAVATED SOIL INDICATED THAT ANOTHER 3.35 BARRELS OF FUEL OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE CONTAMINATED SOIL; BRINGING THE TOTAL RELEASED VOLUME TO 4.35 BARRELS.  A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED AND THE LINE WAS PRESSURE TESTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON THE AFTERNOON OF SEPTEMBER 12TH. THE EXCAVATION WAS BACKFILLED DURING THE WEEK OF DECEMBER 17TH.

column245: LEAK DEVELOPED ON FILLET WELD ON SADDLE FITTING AFTER LINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE (7 DAYS) THE WELD CRACKED AT APPROXIMATELY 3 O'CLOCK POSITION. THE CRACK WAS APPROXIMATELY 3" LONG. AT THE TIME OF THE FAILURE, PERSONNEL WERE APPLYING COATING TO THE PIPE WHEN THE H25 SENSORS INDICATED A POTENTIAL LEAKAGE ON THE PIPELINE.  THE EXCAVATION WAS EVACUATED AND APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL NOTIFIED.      THE FILLET WELD WHERE THE CRACK OCCURED WAS NON-DESTRUCTIVE TESTED USING THE MAGNETIC PARTICLE (MT) TESTING METHOD.

column238: BODY BLEED .5 INCH UNION LOOSE FITTING.
column245: FIRST NOTIFIED AT 0800 HRS CST THAT A PASSERBY NOTICED A LEAK ON OUR PIPELINE.  THE CONTROL CENTER GAVE ME THE CONTACT NAME AND PHONE NUMBER.  I NOTIFIED ALLEN AT 0807 AND HAD ALLEN TO CONTACT SID WITH HENRY PETROLEUM ABOUT THE PROPOSED LEAK. AN ERL WAS SENT OUT AT 0705 MT ABOUT A PROPOSED LEAK.  ALLEN CALLED ME AT 0910 HRS AND ADVISED THAT SID ADVISED THAT THE LEAK WAS EAST OF THE CITY OF CRANE.  THE ONLY PIPELINE THAT WE HAVE EAST OF CRANE IS THE COMANCHE CREEK LINE.  ALLEN ADVISED THAT AFTER TALKING WITH SID IT WAS DETERMINED THAT IT WAS AT THE EOG STATION.  ALLEN PROCEEDED OVER TO THE STATION AND FOUND THAT WE HAD CO2 COMING OUT OF THE GROUND AROUND THE MAINLINE VALVE SITE.  AT THIS TIME I CONTACTED THE CONTROL CENTER AND ADVISED THEM THAT WE DID IN FACT HAVE A LEAK AND THAT WE NEEDED TO SEND OUT AN ERL WHICH THEY DID.  A CONFERENCE CALL WAS SET UP AND IT WAS DETERMINED TO SHUT IN THE PIPELINE.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT IN AT 1140 HRS AND WE ALLOWED SACROC TO CONTINUE PULLING ON THE LINE TO REDUCE THE PRESSURE.  AT 1159 HRS BLOCK VALVE 11 WAS CLOSED, AT 1345 BLOCK VALVE 13 WAS CLOSED.  WE STARTED BLOWING DOWN THE PIPELINE AT 1349 HRS WHICH HAD A LINE PRESSURE OF 1301 PSI.  THE BLOCK VALVE AT PUMP 15 WAS CLOSE AT 1631 HRS.  THE LINE WAS BLOW DOWN BY 1920 HRS AND WE STARTED EXCAVATING THE VALVE.  AT 2100 HRS WE SHUT DOWN FOR THE NIGHT AND WOULD CONTINUE THE NEXT DAY.    10-11-06    0800 HRS WE CONTINUED EXCAVATING THE VALVE.  WE FOUND THAT THE LEAK WAS ON THE BODY BLEED LINE OF THE VALVE.  THERE WAS A UNION AND A NIPPLE THAT WAS ONLY HAND TIGHT AND IT IS SUSPECTED THAT THIS WAS THE POINT OF THE LEAK, BUT THIS WILL NOT BE TOTALLY DETERMINED UNTIL A LAB HAS EXAMINED THE PARTS.  THE REPAIRS WERE MADE TO THE VALVE THAT WERE NEEDED WHICH INCLUDED REPLACING THE BODY BLEED LINE AND ALL FOUR OF THE GREASE LINES.  WE STARTED FILLING THE LINE AT 1538 HRS, BLOCK VALVE 13 WAS FULLY OPENED AT 1643 HRS AND BLOCK VALVE 11 WAS FULLY OPEN AT 1700 HRS.  AT THAT TIME THE CONTROL VALVE FEEDING THE CRC PIPELINE WAS PLACED INTO THE AUTOMATIC MODE AND THE CONTROL CENTER THEN HAD CONTROL OF THE REST OF THE FILLING PROCESS.  THE LINE WAS FILLED DURING THE NIGHT AND BY 0600 HRS ON 10-11-06 ALL DELIVERIES WERE BACK DELIVERING PRODUCT TO OUR CUSTOMERS.

column245: KINDER MORGAN WAS NOTIFIED BY EPNG EMPLOYEES OF AN ODOR AND STAIN ON BOWEN RANCH AT APPROXIMATELY 1300. THE SEGMENT OF LS-4 WAS DOWN AT THE TIME OF NOTIFICATION; WE WERE DELIVERING PRODUCT TO ALAMOGORDO JUNCTION WHICH IS UPSTREAM OF THE LEAK SITE. LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE AREA TO INVESTIGATE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1535, KM CONFIRMED THE LEAK INVOLVED LS 4. WE ISOLATED THE DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVE AT RIO GRANDE VALLEY EAST AT APPROXIMATELY MP 31.5 AT 1558. THE SEGMENT WAS ALREADY ISOLATED UPSTREAM AT EL PASO BREAKOUT STATION. EXCAVATION AND INVESTIGATION BEGAN.  THE INVESTIGATION FOUND THE CAUSE OF THE CORROSION TO BE INTERFERENCE FROM ADJACENT PIPELINES.  NOTE: ESTIMATED AMOUNT RELEASED IS 1.5 BBLS, HOWEVER, THE PHMSA SOFTWARE WILL NOT ALLOW DECIMALS. THEREFROE, WE ROUNDED UP FOR AMOUNT SPILLED AND ROUNDED DOWN FOR THE AMOUNT RECOVERED (ACTUAL ESTIMATE AT TIME OF THIS SUBMITTAL 1.1 BBLS).    NOTE 2: ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS UNKNOWN.

column245: AT 1100 ON SEPTEMBER 26, A PIPELINE OPERATOR'S EMPLOYEE WAS MARKING OUT PIPELINE WHEN HE DISCOVERED A DEAD PATCH OF GRASS ABOVE THE TOLEDO TO SARNIA LINE AT MECHANIC STREET IN TOLEDO, OH. THE INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM WAS ACTIVATED AND THE SITE WAS TREATED AS AN ACTIVE LEAK. THE SARNIA LINE WAS RUNNING 83 OCTANE AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED. THE SARNIA LINE WAS SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY.    THE LINE WAS DUG UP AND UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THERE WAS A STOPPEL FITTING IN THE EXACT LOCATION OF THE LEAK. MONITORING AND PHYSICAL EVIDENCE SHOWED THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE STOPPLE FITTING. A PLAN WAS DEVELOPED TO CUT OUT AND REPLACE THE LEAKING STOPPLE FITTING, AS WELL AS ANOTHER ONE ABOUT 150 FEET TO THE NORTH.    BOTH STOPPLE FITTINGS WERE REPLACED WITH NEW LINE PIPE. WORK WAS COMPLETED ON THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 28 AT APPROXIMATELY 0900 WITH LINE START UP OCCURING THE NEXT DAY. THE LEAKING STOPPLE WILL BE SENT OUT TO A THIRD PARTY FIRM FOR ANALYSIS.    SOILS WERE EXCAVATED UNTIL THE EXCAVATION WAS CLEAN, 100% RECOVERY. POST EXCAVATION SAMPLES WERE COLLECTED. SOILS WERE TAKEN OFF-SITE FOR DISPOSAL.

column245: ON 9/26/2006 A CONTRACT CREW WORKING FOR HOLLY ENERGY PARTNERS UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF A CONTRACT INSPECTOR.  THE COMPANY HAD WORKED BOTH PIPELINES IN THE ROW USING A LINE LOCATOR.  THE EXCAVATOR HAD HAND LOCATED THE TRUST X-6 WHICH THEY WERE WORKING ON THE BACKHOE OPERATOR WAS TRENCHING ON EACH SIDE OF THE TRUST X-6 PIPELINE.  THE EXCAVATION CREW WAS UNAWARE THA THE TRUST 6-8 PIPELINE CROSSED UNDER THE TRUST X-6 PIPELINE IN THIS AREA.  THE TRUST X-6 ALLIGNMENT SHEETS HOLLY RECEIVED FOR ALON USA DID NOT SHOW THE LINE CROSSING.  BECAUSE THE CREW WAS WORKING ON THE TRUST X-6 PIPELINE THEY WERE USING THE TRUST X-6 ALLIGNMENT SHEETS & NOT THE TRUST 6-8 ALLIGNMENT SHEETS.  THE BACKHOEOPERATOR STRUCK THE TRUST 6-8 PIPELINE CAUSING A PUNCTURE APPROX 2" W X 3" L.  THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR ON DUTY RECOGNIZED A PROBLEM AND SHUT DOWN BEFORE THE AREA SUPERVISOR CONTACTED HIM.

column235: UNANTICIPATED INTERFERENCE OF A SAFETY CONTROL
column241: STEVE MAROSITZ, MANAGER CODES AND STANDARDS
column245: APPROXIMATELY 1415 ON 10/23/06 WHILE DRAINING A 1-INCH LINE INTO A FIVE GALLON BUCKET THROUGH A 1-INCH BALL VALVE, THE GASOLINE IN THE BUCKET IGNITED.    THE INITIAL DRAIN DOWN OF THE 1-INCH LINE WAS BEING DONE TO LOWER THE LEVEL IN THE 4-INCH PRODUCT LINE SO THAT THE VACUUM BREAKER BUTTERFLY VALVE COULD BE REMOVED FOR MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR. ALL LOCKOUT/TAGOUT PROCEDURES WERE PERFORMED AND A SAFE WORK PERMIT ISSUED. DRAIN DOWN BEGAN THROUGH THE 1-INCH BALL VALVE WHILE THE 5 GALLON METAL BUCKET WAS SUPPORTED BY THE METAL HANDLE BY ITS OWN WEIGHT. AS THE BUCKET WAS FILLED WITH APPROXIMATELY 1 GALLON OF GASOLINE, THE PLASTIC HANDLE INTERRUPTED THE BOND, WHEN, PRESUMABLY, A STATIC-GENERATED SPARK IGNITED THE GASOLINE IN THE BUCKET. THE 1-INCH VALVE WAS CLOSED AND THE FIRE WAS CONTAINED IN THE BUCKET AND PROMPTLY EXTINGUISHED.    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 2 PM ON OCTOBER 20, 2006, THE EDMONTON CONTROL CENTER ADVISED THAT A CRUDE OIL SMELL WAS REPORTED ON THE RIGHT OF WAY NEAR WILTON STATION. LINE 1 WAS SHUT DOWN AT THE TIME WITH NGL ACROSS WILTON. UPON RECEIVING THE REPORT, THE CONTROL CENTER SHUT DOWN LINES 2, 3 AND 4. BEMIDJI PLM WAS DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE THE REPORT. AT 3:20 PM LOCAL TIME, TIM POLLOCK ADVISED OF OIL STAINING ON THE GROUND AT MP927.5 JUST UPSTREAM OF WILTON. THE LEAK IS NOT IN AN HCA. ALL REGULATORY AGENCIES WERE CONTACTED. UPON EXCVATION, THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A CRACK IN THE SIDE SEAM WELD OF A PREVIOUSLY INSTALLED TIGHT FITTING LEAVE. THE DEFECT WAS REPAIRED BY INSTALLING AN OVERSLEEVE.

column245: A LEAKING 2¿ UNION FITTING ON THE PROVER LOOP PUMP BACK LINE WAS FOUND BY LOCAL OPERATIONS PERSONNEL PERFORMING A ROUTINE TERMINAL INSPECTION.  THE PIPELINE WAS QUICKLY SHUTDOWN AND CONTAINMENT AND CLEAN UP MEASURES WERE INITIATED. MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO DRAIN THE PROVER, ISOLATE THE SYSTEM, AND UNBOLT THE PIPING BETWEEN THE TWO, 2¿ DRAIN VALVES, AND PLUG BOTH VALVES.  THE LEAKING 2¿ UNION WAS REMOVED AND THE PROVER LOOP WAS ISOLATED FROM THE TERMINAL.   ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: CLAY COUNTY KANSAS SHERIFF DEPARTMENT CALLED ENTERPRISE PRODUCTS OPERATING LP AT 10:00 AM ON OCTOBER 25, 2006 REPORTING A VAPOR CLOUD RELEASE.  OPERATING PERSONNEL VERIFIED AT 10:25 AM THAT THE RELEASE WAS ON THE WEST LEG NH3 LINE.    AFTER DISCOVERY, THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND LINE SEGMENT BLOCKED IN.  THE PUBLIC WAS EVACUATED FROM THE RURAL SITE UNTIL ALLOWED TO RETURN AT 1400 HOUR ON OCTOBER 26, 2006. PHMSA PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE OCTOBER 26, 2006.    REPAIR BEGAN ON OCTOBER 26, 2006 AND WAS COMPLETED 28, 2006. THE RUPTURE SEGMENT WAS SENT FOR A METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS TO STRESS ENGINEERING IN HOUSTON, TX.    THE METALLURGICAL EVALUATION CONCLUDED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RUPTURE WAS METAL LOSS FROM EXTERNAL CORROSION.  ALSO, BASED ON METALLOGRAPHIC EXAMINATION AND MECHANICAL TESTING, THE LONG SEAM WELD WAS FOUND TO BE ACCEPTABLE.    THE REPAIRED LINE SEGMENT IS CURRENTLY OPERATING AT A 20% PRESSURE REDUCTION PURSUANT TO CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER CPF NO. 3-2006-5044H.     UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THE INBOARD PUMP SEAL FAILED ON PUMP UNIT NO 2 AT AULT STATION ON THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN PIPELINE OWNED AND OPERATED NY SUNCOR ENERGY (USA) PIPELINE CO. ON  OCT 19, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 1600MST. CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL SAW A HIGH SUMP ALARM, SHUT DOWN THE STATION BYPASSED THE CRUDIE OIL AROUND THE STATION , AND CALLED OUT A LOCAL OPERATOR WHO DISCOVERED THE SEAL FAILURE.  ALSO, THE OPERATOR DISCOVERED THE SUMP HAD OVERFLOWED AND APPROXIMATELY 15 BARREL OF CRUDE OIL WAS ON THE GROUND AROUND THE SUMP. NO OIL HAD GONE BEYOND THE CONFINES OF THE STATION.  THE LOCAL OPERATOR CLOSED THE STATION ISOLATION VALUES MANUALLY WHICH MADE THE STATION SAFE.  A VAC TRUCK WAS CALLED AND THE FREE OIL PICKED UP.  FURTHER ALL CONTAMINATED SOIL - APPROXIMATELY 30-35 C.Y. HAS BEEN REMOVED. NRC WAS NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.

column70: O-RING LEAK ON SWING CHECK VALVE
column245: 10-31-06 AT 0645 THIRD PARTY (PUBLIC) NOTIFIED THE LOUIS DREYFUS CONTROL ROOM TO REPORT SMELL AT VALVE SITE 5.    10-31-06 AT 0718 LOUIS DREYFUS REPRESENTATIVE ARRIVED ON SCENE ALONG WITH ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST FIRE DEPARTMENT AND VERIFIED SMALL LEAK ON CHECK VALVE SWING CHECK ARM AT VALVE SITE 5.  LEAK WAS MONITORED WITH HYDROCARBON DETECTOR, HYDROCARBONS WERE CONFIRMED TO FENCED IN AREA AT VALVE SITE 5. FIRE DEPARTMENT LEFT SCENE AT 0740    10-31-06 AT 0745 LOUIS DREYFUS CONTROL ROOM STARTED BRINGING PRESSURE DOWN ON LINE.  10-31-06 AT 0915 PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM WERE CLOSED.    10-31-06 AT 1015 CONTRACTED HAZMAT TEAM ARRIVE ON SCENCE AND DETERMINED LESS THAN 5 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS RELEASED.    10-31-06 AT 1345 HAZMAT TEAM RELEASED FROM SITE. CONTINUOUS MONITORING WAS CONDUCTED WITH HYDROCARBON DETECTORS EVERY 1/2 HOUR UNTIL REPAIR COULD BE MADE.  10-31-06 AT 1635 TELEPHONIC CALL WAS MADE TO OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY 7000-1 WITH REPORT # 816686    10-31-06 ESTABLISHED 24 HOUR MONITORING OF SITUATION UNTIL REPAIRS CAN BE MADE.    11-01-06 FAXED IN "SAFETY RELATED CONDITION REPORT" TO LOUISIANA DNR AND DOT OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.    11-04-06 AT 1450 INSTALLED CLAMP ON CHECK VALVE FOR REPAIR  11-04-06 AT 1450 OPENED DOWNSTREAM AND UPSTREAM VALVES AND STARTED UP PIPELINE.  11-05-06 MONITORED VALVE SITE 5 FOR ONE WEEK EVERYDAY AND WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR ON A WEEKLY SCHEDULE.  11-16-06 COMPLETED WRITTEN 700-1 "ACCIDENT REPORT" AND MAILED IN TO OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY.       THE INVESTIGATION RESULTS REPORTED THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT TO BE DUE TO A CHEMICALLY ATTACKED O-RING. ANALYSIS SHOWED THE O-RING IN THE CHECK VALVE TO BEMADE OF BUNA-N MATERIAL AND WAS CHEMICALLY ATTACKED BY THE TRANSPORTED PRODUCT.  VITON O-RING MATERIAL SHOULD HAVE BEEN USSED FOR THIS APPLICATION. SINCE THE INITIAL INCIDENT, AN INTERNAL AUDIT HAS BEEN PERFORMED ON THE LDH ENERGY OLEFINS LLC PIPELINE SYSTEM TO CONFIRM THAT ALL SEALS AND O-RINGS WERE OF VITON MATERIAL.

column245: THIS PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUT DOWN SINCE BEFORE HURRICANE KATRINA.  WE WERE CONDUCTING A STAND-UP TEST ON THE LINE TO INSURE INTEGRITY.  WE USED SEAWATER TO BEGIN STAND-UP TEST, REACHED 70 PSI AND PRESSURE DROPPED TO 0 PSI.  WE INVESTIGATED BY HELICOPTER TO LOCATE RELEASE SITE. SITE OIL SPOTTED  28 56 19N 89 16 82W IN THE GULF OF MEXICO, SOUTH PASS 38.  WE PULLED A VACUUM ON THE LINE TO REDUCE FURTHER RISK OF SHEENING.  WILL NEED VESSEL TO GET TO SITE AND INVESTIGATE POSSIBLE CAUSE AND REPAIRS REQUIRED.   REPLACED 2,000 FEET OF PIPELINE AROUND MUD SLIDE AREA. BELIEVE PIPE FAILED DUE TO EXTENAL NATURAL FORCES CAUSED BY MUD SLIDE ON SEA FLOOR.

column245: LOCAL PROPERTY OWNER HAD CALLED IN THAT THERE WAS OIL ON THE GROUND.  AN OIL PLUME OF 25¿ BY 15¿ WAS OBSERVED AND LOOKED TO BE COMING OUT FROM BENEATH A LARGE CONTAINER, WHICH WAS APPROXIMATELY 15¿ WEST OF THE WEST CASING VENT FOR THE 710 FWY.  TRASH, CONTAINERS, OLD BOATS CLUTTERED THE AREA.  AREA BETWEEN VAULT AND EXPOSED CASING WAS EXCAVATED.  THIS WAS DELAYED DUE TO 12,500 VAC CONDUIT CROSSING AND NOT WANTING TO EXPOSE.  COATING APPEARED TO BE SOMASTIC WHICH CAN CONTAIN 1-2% ASBESTOS.  PITTING WAS NOTED ON THE TOP OF PIPE AND SOME MORE MINOR PITTING ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE, BUT NO PENETRATION WAS VISIBLE.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: THE INCIDENT WAS DISCOVERED BY THE PLAINS PIPELINE MIDLAND CONTROL CENTER.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED INSIDE THE STATION FIREWALL AT THE MIDLAND BASIN TANK FARM.  INVESTIGATION HAS DETERMINED THAT THE ROOF DRAIN ON TANK 1332 FAILED ALLOWING OIL TO EXIT OUT OF THE ROOF DRAIN VALVE INTO THE STATION FIREWALL.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE ROOF DRAIN FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AND STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  THEREFORE, THE RELEASE IS CLASSIFIED AS OTHER UNTIL THE TANK IS CLEANED AND THE INVESTIGATION COMPLETED.    INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT THE ESTIMATED COST WOULD BE LESS THAN $50,000.  SUBSEQUENTLY, THE REMEDIATION COSTS HAVE EXCEEDED THE ORIGINAL ESTIMATES AND THE TOTAL COST NOW EXCEEDS $50,000.    PART H7. ITEM 23  DURING THE INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A SWIVEL JOINT IN THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM HAD SEIZED CAUSING THE PIPE TO PULL FROM THE SWIVEL JOINT.  THE SWIVEL JOINTS IN THE ROOF SYSTEM HAD BEEN RECENTLY EPLACED BY A CONTRACTOR ON AN API STANDARD 653 INSPECTION REQUIRED BY 49 CFR 195.432.  THE INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THE CONTRACTOR INSTALLED SWIVELS THAT WERE DIFFERENT IN LENGTH, ALTHOUGH THE CONTRACTOR WAS AWARE OF THE DIFFERENT LENGTH OF THE SWIVEL, ADJUSTMENTS WERE MADE TO THE DRAIN PIPING, BUT THIS ADJUSTMENT PROHIBITED FREE M0MENT OF THE DRAIN PIPING CAUSING SOME SEPARATION OF THE PIPING FROM THE SWIVEL.  THE SWIVEL JOINTS WERE REPLACED BY THE CONTRACTOR UNDER WARRANTY AND RETURNED TO THE ORIGINAL CONFIGURATION.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 16, 2006, AN EMPLOYEE WAS CHECKING PRODUCT HAZE AT A WOOD RIVER, ILLINOIS SAMPLE BUILDING AND INADVERTENTLY BUMPED A .250 INCH BALL VALVE SAMPLE VALVE THAT WAS ASSOCIATED WITH A LINE THAT WAS NOT OPERATING.  WHEN THE LINE WAS STARTED AT 03:01 HOURS A SINK IN THE SAMPLE BUILDING EVENTUALLY OVERFILLED AND RELEASED GASOLINE.  DURING STATION CHECKS A STRONG NORTH WIND PREVENTED THE OPERATOR FROM DETECTING ANY PETROLEUM SMELLS, UNTIL APPROXIMATELY 06:00 HOURS WHEN IT WAS DETECTED AND THE VALVE WAS SHUT.  THE FREE-PHASE PRODUCT WAS VACUUMED-UP, THE PETROLEUM IMPACTED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED, PLACED IN LINED ROLL-OFF BOXES FOR DISPOSAL. TO ELIMINATE ANY POTENTIAL FUTURE OCCURRENCE, THE BALL VALVE INVOLVED HAS BEEN REPLACED WITH A LOCKING COLLAR VALVE.

column238: TANK 1504 MIXER TOP HINGE FAILURE CAUSING MIXER TO LEAN AWAY FROM TANK.
column245: ON 12-03-2006, TANK 1504 AT CPPL¿S BORGER CRUDE TERMINAL HAD JUST BEEN TOPPED OFF.  OPERATOR ON DUTY IMMEDIATELY NOTICED THAT THE LEVEL IN T1504 WOULD NOT LEVEL OFF.  TANK GAUGING COMPUTER WAS SHOWING 800 BBLS TO 1200 BBLS AN HOUR LOSS.  AS EMPLOYEE DROVE AROUND T1504, IT WAS NOTICED THAT THE WEST MIXER HAD COME LOOSE AT THE TOP HINGE AND HAD FALLEN AWAY FROM THE TANK, ONLY SUPPORTED BY THE BOTTOM HINGE.  CRUDE OIL WAS LEAKING OUT OF THE KNUCKLE JOINT PACKING AREA AT THE TANK WALL CONNECTION.  NOTIFICATIONS WERE IMMEDIATELY MADE TO START LOWERING THE TANK LEVEL BY PUMPING CONTENTS TO REFINERY AND OTHER TANKS ON SITE.  ALL CRUDE WAS CONTAINED IN THE DIKE.

column245: THIS RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY THE PIPELINE PATROL PILOT ON 12/12/06.  DUE TO OTHER PIPELINES IN THE AREA, IT WAS NOT DETERMINED UNTIL 12/13/06 THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE PLAINS BARKER TO NETTLETON PIPELINE.    THIS RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF LEAKAGE FROM A SMALL CORROSION RELATED PINHOLE IN THE PIPE BODY.  A REVIEW AND ANALYSIS OF SCADA FLOW AND PRESSURE RECORDS INDICATED A DISCREPANCY BETWEEN FLOW INTO AND OUT OF THE PIPELINE ON DECEMBER 4, 2006.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND A THOROUGH ROW SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED FOR INDICATION OF LEAKAGE.  NONE WAS FOUND.  PIPELINE OPERATIONS RESUMED BUT SCADA FLOW DATA ON THE PIPELINE DID NOT CONCLUSIVELY INDICATE THE PRESENCE OF A LEAK.  THE OVER AND SHORT DATA PRIOR TO VISUAL DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK INDICATED BOTH SHORT AND OVER CONDITIONS.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT LEAKAGE FROM THE SMALL PINHOLE WAS NOT CONSTANT CAUSING THE OVER/SHORT INDICATIONS TO BE ERRATIC AND INCONCLUSIVE.  IT IS POSSIBLE THAT CORROSION PRODUCTS OR OTHER OBSTRUCTIONS WOULD SOMETIME PLUG THE HOLE CAUSING THE LEAKAGE TO STOP.    THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  ON 12/20/06 IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE COSTS WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  THIS WAS DUE TO THE CONTAMINATION AREA BEING LARGER THAN THE INITIAL EVALUATION AND THAT THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS NOT SUITABLE FOR PLANNED TREATMENT OPTIONS AND WOULD HAVE TO BE HAULED OFF SITE AND LAND FARMED.  SINCE THIS RELEASE OCCURRED ON AN INTRASTATE PIPELINE AND BEING WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF GLADEWATER, ON 12/20/06, A TELEPHONE CALL WAS MADE TO THE RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS KILGORE (REGION 3) PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICE AND THE RAILROAD COMMISSION'S EMERGENCY LINE, RRC REPORT NUMBER 07-HC-256.    REF: PART A, PAR. 5. "LOSSES" AND PART F, PAR. 2.B. "ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT":  THE SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN COST WAS PRIMARILY DUE TO THE REMOVAL AND TRANSPORT OF APPROXIMATELY 7000 CUBIC YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL TO AN OFFSITE FACILITY AND IMPORTING CLEAN FILL DIRT.

column245: ON THE MORNING CHECK OF THE FACILITY ON 12/16/06 BY THE PLAINS GAUGER THERE WAS NO INDICATION OF AN OIL RELEASE AT THE METER SITE.  WHEN THE PLAINS PIPELINE METER PROVER APPROACHED THE SITE AT 1300 HOURS TO PROVE THE METER, HE DISCOVERED THE OIL RELEASE.    THE SEGMENT OF PIPE EXPERIENCING THE LEAK IS A 6 INCH BYPASS LOOP AROUND THE METER, LEAVING THE 10 INCH MAINLINE AND REENTERING THE 10 INCH MAINLINE.  FLOW THROUGH THE 6 INCH BYPASS LINE IS CONTROLLED BY A FLEX FLOW RELIEF VALVE IN THE EVENT OF METER FAILURE (BLOCKAGE).  IT APPEARS THAT DUE TO THE BYPASS LOOP LINE INACTIVITY THAT INTERNAL CORROSION DEVELOPED WHICH WAS THE FACTOR CONTRIBUTING TO THE EVENT.

column245: THE HIGH ISLAND PIPELINE SYSTEM CONTROL CENTER DETECTED A PRESSURE LOSS AND IMMEDIATELY THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS REVEALED THAT THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN SEVERED BY AN UNKNOWN OUTSIDE FORCE APPROXIMATELY 30 MILES OFFSHORE SOUTHEAST OF GALVESTON AT A WATER DEPTH OF APPROXIMATELY 100 FEET.    PART F 1B.  REPAIRS HAVE NOT BEEN COMPLETED ON THE PIPELINE.  PRESENTLY, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT IT WILL TAKE APPROXIMATELY TWO MORE DAYS TO FINISH THE REPAIR OF THE PIPELINE WEATHER PERMITTING.    PART F 1B (REVISED).  REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AND PIPELINE PLACED BACK IN SERVICE AT 1700 HOURS ON JANUARY 29, 2007.    PART H4.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PIPELINE WAS SEVERED BY A SHIP'S ANCHOR WHICH WAS DRAGGED ACROSS THE PIPELINE.

column245: ON A FACILITY CHECK OF HEALDTON STATION, THE PLAINS PIPELINE OPERATOR DISCOVERED A RELEASE WITHIN THE STATION.  UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE SEGMENT OF PIPE EXPERIENCING THE LEAK WAS A SIX (6) INCH RELIEF PIPELINE (AFTER THE RELIEF VALVE THAT GOES TO A BREAKOUT TANK) WHICH IS CONNECTED TO THE EIGHT (8) INCH MAIN JURISDICTIONAL PIPELINE.  THE INACTIVITY OF THE PIPELINE CONTRIBUTED TO INTERNAL CORROSION, THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON DECEMBER 27, 2006 AT 1645 HOURS, CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A TELEPHONE CALL, FROM A PASSING MOTORIST, OF A 6-INCH HIGH FIRE AT SYLVANIA PUMP STATION, LOCATED ON THE OUTSIDE MAIN LINE PUMP.  THE PUMP WAS SHUTDOWN AND LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT NOTIFIED ALONG WITH AREA PIPELINE PERSONNEL.  THE FIRE WAS OUT PRIOR TO THE ARRIVAL OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL AT ABOUT 1700 HOURS.  IMMEDIATE OBSERVATIONS OF THE SCENE DETERMINED THAT THE FIRE WAS LIMITED TO THE AREA OF THE PUMP OUTBOARD SEAL AND BEARINGS WITH NO EVIDENCE OF LEAKING OR SPILLED GASOLINE ON THE PUMP EQUIPMENT OR GROUND SURROUNDING THE PUMP FOUNDATION.    INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT DETERMINED THAT THE PUMP SEAL AND BEARING FAILED.  THE FAILURE RESULTED IN THE AREA SURROUNDING THE OUTBOARD SEAL AND BEARING TO OVERHEAT, WHICH IGNITED RESIDUAL LUBRICANTS AND POSSIBLY GASOLINE MIST LEAKING FROM THE SEAL AREA.  THE FIRE BURNED ITSELF OUT AFTER RESIDUAL LUBRICANTS ON THE PUMP WERE CONSUMED AND ELIMINATION OF POSSIBLE PUMP SEAL MISTING ONCE THE PUMP WAS SHUT DOWN.  THE DAMAGE TO THE PUMP SEALS AND BEARING HOUSING REQUIRED THE PUMP TO BE SENT TO A REPAIR SHOP.  THE INVESTIGATION ALSO FOUND THAT THE PUMP DE-STAGING, COMPLETED SOME 15 YEARS AGO, RESULTED IN A THRUST IMBALANCE OF THE SHAFT AND LIKELY CONTRIBUTED TO THE BEARING FAILURE AND RESULTANT FIRE.  ADDITIONAL WORK WAS PREFORMED ON THE PUMP TO HYDRAULICALLY REBALANCE THE PUMP INTERNALS, ELIMINATE FOUND PUMP CASE WASH-OUTS AND TO REPAIR THE SHAFT.  THE LINE WAS RUN AT A REDUCED RATE WITHOUT SYLVANIA PUMP STATION DURING THE PUMP REPAIR PROCESS AND WAS RETURNED TO FULL SERVICE ON JANUARY 18, 2007 WHEN THE REPAIRED PUMP WAS REINSTALLED.    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/24/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 0830 MST, A CALL WAS RECEIVED FROM THE EDMONTON CONTROL CENTER THAT THERE WAS A PRESSURE LOSS AT OWEN STATION. THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND THE VESPER PLM CREW WAS NOTIFIED AND RESPONDED TO OWEN STATION. AT 1115 MST, THE LEAK WAS CONFIRMED BY VESPER PLM AND ADDITIONAL VESPER AND FORT ATKINSON PLM CREWS MOBILIZED MANPOWER AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE EQUIPMENT TO THE LEAK SITE. SUPERIOR AND BEMIDJI PLM CREWS WERE ALSO NOTIFIED AND BEGAN TO MOBILIZE MANPOWER AND EQUIPMENT. AN OPS INSPECTOR ARRIVED ON SITE JANUARY 2, 2007 AND WITNESSED THE REPAIR.

column245: THE 3/4IN PURGE LINE ON THE #2 PUMP AT THE CORTEZ PIPELINE STATION HAD BROKE WHERE CO2 WAS RELEASED INTO THE PUMP BUILDING. THE 3/4IN. PIPE WAS BUTTED UP TO THE 3/4IN. 90 DEGREE ELBOW FITTING AND WAS WELDED TOGETHER. APPEARS THAT THE WELD DID NOT GET THE PENATRATION NEEDED FOR THE TWO JOINTS TO MAKE A SOLID WELD. PIPING PARTS ARE BEING SENT OFF TO A LAB FOR ANALYSIS. THE 90 DEGREE ELBOW WAS NOT A SLIP JOINT TYPE FITTING. ALL FITTINGS ARE BEING LOOKED AT AND REPLACED AS NEEDED.  PUMP WAS ISOLATED BLOWN DOWN AND REPAIRS MADE.   PIPING HAD LEAKED FOR APPROXIMATELY 20 MINUTES.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 6:00 PM A COLONIAL OPERATOR DOING A STATION CHECK SMELLED GAS FUMES WHEN HE NEARED THE LINE 1 SAMPLE BUILDING.  AFTER NOTICING GASOLINE ON THE GROUND, HE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN RECEIPTS AND DELIVERIES AND NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER IN ALPHARETTA.  THE LINE 1 CONTROLLER SHUT DOWN THE MAINLINE AND THE BLOCK VALVES BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE AREA WERE CLOSED AND LOCKED.  UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION, THE PRODUCT WAS DETERMINED TO BE COMING FROM THE AREA SURROUNDING THE FACILITY'S TAKE-OFF VALVES.  ONCE THE AREA AROUND THE VALVE WAS EXCAVATED, A SMALL HOLE WAS FOUND ON THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF A DRAIN VALVE IN A THREE INCH LINE, JUST DOWN STREAM OF THE PRIMARY TAKE-OFF VALVE.     HEAVY RAINS KEPT THE PRODUCT ON TOP OF THE GROUND AND IN ACCESS WELLS AND JUNCTION BOXES.  PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE WELLS, BELL HOLES, EXCAVATION AREA AND JUNCTION BOXES USING A VACUMN TANKER AND TRUCK. SOIL WAS ALSO REMOVED FROM THE AFFECTED AREA. THE HAZMAT TEAM FROM THE CHARLOTTE FIRE DEPARTMENT ARRIVED ON SITE AT 22:30. FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL NOTIFIED  MECKLENBURG COUNTY LAND USE AND ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES AGENCY (MCLUESA) PERSONNEL WHO ARRIVED 1/22/07 AT 00:30.  A TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS GIVEN TO AMBER LINDON WITH THE NCDENR MOORESVILLE REGIONAL OFFICE ON 1/22/07.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: STANLEY STATION CONTAINS PIPING FROM A DIESEL UNIT THAT WAS REMOVED IN 2004.  THIS PIPING WAS USED FOR EXISTING PISTON PUMPS THAT INJECT PRODUCT FROM THE STANLEY TANKS UNTIL NOVEMBER OF 2006.  IN NOVEMBER OF 2006, DISCHARGE PIPING FROM THE INJECTION PUMPS WAS MODIFIED.  THIS MODIFICATION LEFT APPROXIMATELY 80 FEET OF 10¿ PIPE IDLED SUBJECT TO DISCHARGE PRESSURE.  OF THIS 80 FEET OF PIPE, 20 FEET WAS ISOLATED WITH A CHECK VALVE.  JANUARY 25TH WAS THE WARMEST DAY OF THE YEAR WITH LOCAL TEMPERATURES REACHING 43 DEGREES F.  THIS 20 FEET OF PIPING ISOLATED FROM THE REST WAS EXPOSED TO THERMAL EXPANSION.  THIS CREATED A PRESSURE LARGE ENOUGH TO RUPTURE THE PIPE ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE CHECK VALVE.  THE CHECK THEN ALLOWED OIL TO FLOW FROM THE MAINLINE THROUGH THE DISCHARGE PIPING, THROUGH THE CHECK AND OUT OF THE RUPTURED STATION PIPE.  PRESSURE WAS ESTIMATED USING CALCULATIONS BASED ON OBSERVED TEMPERATURE RISE.  THE RELEASE WAS ISOLATED, CONTAINED AND IMMEDIATELY CLEANED UP.  THE FLAPPER WAS REMOVED FROM THE CHECK VALVE TO ELIMINATE THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT.

column30: OTHER
column245: FRIDAY JANUARY 5, 2007    12:21PM - AOK CONSTRUCTION FOREMAN, TOM ROBERTSON, CALLED QRI INSPECTOR, JEFF KING, AND REPORTED THEIR DITCHING MACHINE HAD STRUCK A PIPELINE WHILE EXCAVATING TRENCH TO INSTALL FLOWLINES IN PREPARATION FOR TIE-IN TO 20" GAS GATHERING LINE.    12:25 -  PUMPS AT HOOD PROCESSING PLANT SHUTDOWN    12:35 - CLOSED MATLOCK 8" BLOCK VALVE LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 2.5 MILES SOUTH OF THE PUNCTURE IN ORDER TO ISOLATE THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE.    12:50 - CLOSED SAM MARSHALL BLOCK VALVE LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 2.5 MILES NORTH OF THE PUNCTURE.  AT THIS POINT, WITH THE LINE ISOLATED, THERE WAS NO WAY TO RECOVER THE LIQUIDS IN THE LINE.  THE WEATHER WAS 65 DEGREES F, CLEAR, AND A SLIGHT NORTHERLY WIND WAS HELPING TO DISPERSE THE VAPORS.  THERE WAS NO ACCUMULATION OR RUNOFF OF LIQUIDS ON THE GROUND.  DUE TO THE PROXIMITY OF THE MATLOCK VALVE SITE NEAR A RESIDENCE AND THE SAM MARSHALL LOCATED DIRECTLY UNDER HIGH VOLTAGE POWER LINES, WE CHOSE TO LET THE LINE BLOW DOWN TO BELOW 100PSI BEFORE OPENING THE BLOW-OFFS AT EACH VALVE SITE.  THE LINE WAS COMPLETELY EVACUATED AT 5:41P.M.    REPORTING:    TRRC:   512-463-6788   REPORT# 07-HC-287   ULIE PRESLEY                    FOLLOW UP CALL RECEIVED BY JAMES HUDDLESTON FROM JODY AT 972-240-5757          (OFFICE) OR 512-971-3074 (CELL).  SHE REQUESTED WE LET HER KNOW WHEN          THE LINE WA BLOWN DOWN TO ZERO PRESSURE.  THIS OCCURRED AT 5:41PM AND          JODY WAS NOTIFIED.    USDOT:  800-424-8802   REPORT#822-928    NAME NOT GIVEN    REPAIRS:    PRE-TESTED REPLACEMENT PIPE JOINTS WERE BROUGHT TOTHE LOCATION, WELDED, AND X-RAYED.    AN 84.5FOOT SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS REPLACED USING THE PRE-TESTED AND 100% X-RAYED PIPE.  TIE-IN WELDS WERE 100% X-RAYED.    THE PIPELINE OPERATIONS PERSONNEL PURGED THE LINE OF AIR.  THE BLOCK VALVES WERE THEN FULLY OPENED AND THE LNE WAS MADE READY FOR SERVICE AT 4:38AM.  THE HOOD PROCESSING PLANT HAD BEEN NOTIFITED OF OUR EXPECTED IN-SERVICE TIME AND WAS READY TO BE PLACED BACK ON-LINE.  THEY BROUGHT THE PLANT BACK ON-LINE AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS WITHIN A FEW HOURS.

column30: OTHER
column245: WHILE COMPLETING THE INSTALLATION OF A TRENCH BOX SYSTEM TO FACILITATE ROAD BORE OPERATIONS, AN ENBRIDGE CONTRACTOR PUNCTURED (1" X 4") THE ADJACENT LINE 14 WITH THE EDGE OF A STEEL ROAD PLATE. THE ADJACENT LINE WAS WELL MARKED PRIOR TO THIS INCIDENT. A THIRD PARTY HAS BEEN RETAINED TO PERFORM A COMPREHENSIVE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION WHICH IS CURRENTLY ONGOING. UNTIL THIS INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETE, INTERIM AWARENESS EDUCATION HAS BEEN PROVIDED TO ALL PERSONNEL WORKING ON THIS PROJECT. FURTHER MEASURES WILL BE TAKEN, IF NECESSARY, PENDING THE RESULTS OF THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION.     MITIGATIVE MEASURES AS OUTLINED IN CORRESPONDENCE SUBMITTED TO PHMSA DATED SEPT 8, 2009 WERE EMPLOYED AND INCORPORATED INTO CONSTRUCTION PRACTICES AND PROCEDURES.    INVESTIGATIVE ACTIVITIES HAVE DEFINED THE FULL NATURE AND EXTENT OF THE RELEASE.  CORRETIVE ACTIONS ARE ONGOING USING SOIL VAPOR EXTRACTION AND AIR SPARGING TO ABATE RESIDUAL OIL AND REMEDIATE IMPACTED SOIL AND GROUNDWATER.

column245: DURING ROUTINE ROUNDS OF THE CLEARBROOK TERMINAL, THE GAUGER FOUND APPROXIMATELY 7 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL AROUND THE DISCHARGE SIDE OF L-2 PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE. LINE 2 WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED AND ADDITIONAL OIL CAME TO THE SURFACE. ALL CRUDE WAS CONTAINED IN THE VICINITY OF THE PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE AND IMMEDIATELY OUTSIDE OF THE L-2 PUMP ROOM. THERE WAS NO IMMEDIATE THREAT OF CRUDE OIL MIGRATING OFF OF THE PROPERTY OR IMPACTING ENVIRONMENTAL AREAS OUTSIDE OF THE TERMINAL YARD. THE CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE A BLOCK AND BLEED FITTING ON THE VALVE BODY THAT HAD BEEN STRESSED BY GROUND MOVEMENT/FROST HEAVING. THIS INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO THE MINNESOTA DUTY OFFICER, REPORT #86979 TO MR. JOHN ELDER, BUT NOT TO THE NRC AS THE INCIDENT DOES NOT MEET REPORTING PARAMETERS.
