column238: WEATHER CONDITIONS CAUSED WATER THAT HAD COLLECTED TANK'S ROOF DRAIN PIPING TO FREEZE, FORCING AN ADJACENT FLANGE GASKET TO FAIL.
column245: TANK 103 WAS PUT BACK IN SERVICE IN OCT. 2006, AFTER BOTTOM REPAIRS, NEW ROOF DRAIN PIPING, ROOF SEALS & PAINTING WERE COMPLETED. THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM WAS LEFT IN ITS NORMALLY OPEN POSITION TO PREVENT AN ACCUMULATION OF WATER ON THE EXTERNAL FLOATING ROOF. WHEN OIL WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING FROM THE ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM, THE ROOF DRAIN VALVE WAS IMMEDIATELY CLOSED AND THE TANK WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE FOR INSPECTION. AFTER REMOVAL OF OIL REMAINING IN THE TANK & CLEAN UP OF OIL SPILLED IN THE TANK CONTAINMENT AREA, CREWS WERE ABLE TO SAFELY ENTER THE TANK ON 2-28-07. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT OIL HAD ENTERED THE ROOF DRAIN PIPING THROUGH THE FLANGE OF A FLANGED SWIVEL JOINT. THE ROOF DRAIN PIPING WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE TANK FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE COMPONENT FAILURE.     OUR INVESTIGATIONS INDICATED THAT WEATHER CONDITIONS CAUSED WATER THAT HAD COLLECTED IN THE TANK'S ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM TO FREEZE, FORCING AN ADJACENT FLANGE GASKET TO FAIL.

AN IGNITION SOURCE GOT BEHIND THE PLUG AND A SMALL FLASH FIRE OCCURRED.  THE FLASH FIRE WAS QUICKLY EXTINGUISHED WITH A SMALL FIST SIZE FLAME REMAINING WITHIN THE PIPE WHICH WAS IMMEDIATELY PUT OUT.

column245: AT 1109 HOURS ON 2/7/07, SUNOCO LOGISTICS RECEIVED CALL FROM THE TERMINAL MANAGER AT MARATHON TERMINAL IN ROMULUS WHICH IS A DELIVERY LOCATION ON THE SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. 8-INCH TOLEDO ¿ INKSTER LINE NAMED ROMULUS JUNCTION. GASOLINE WAS LEAKING OUT OF A VAULT WHERE TAKEOFF PIPING CONNECTS THE LINE TO A PREVIEW DENSITOMETER. THE LEAK SITE IS ENTIRELY CONTAINED IN THE MARATHON TERMINAL, LOCATED AT 28001 CITRON ROAD. THE LEAK ORIGINATED ON THE TAKEOFF PIPING AND WAS FROM A THREADED 2-INCH UNION.  IT APPEARS AS IF THE THREADED UNION LIKELY LOOSENED FROM FREEZE-THAW CYCLES ACTING ON THE UNION AND ATTACHED 2-INCH PIPING.    THE INITIAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS TO SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE. THE VAULT WAS PUMPED OUT WITH A VACUUM TRUCK. APPROXIMATELY 600 GALLONS OF GASOLINE WAS COLLECTED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE MI DEQ FOR POTENTIAL TO IMPACT GROUNDWATER, AS WELL AS 911 (ROMULUS FIRE DEPARTMENT). IN THE CASE OF THE 911 NOTIFICATION, THE DISPATCHER DEEMED THE NOTIFICATION AS NON-EMERGENCY AND MADE NO REPORT NOR RESPONDED ANY EMERGENCY SERVICES.  A REPORT TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS LATER MADE ON MARCH 13 WHEN A SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED ON NEARBY WATER.    FOR SAFETY OF THE WORK CREW, THE ENTIRE VAULT WAS REMOVED, AND AREA WAS EXCAVATED.  ABOUT 80 YARDS OF SPOILS WERE COLLECTED INTO ROLL-OFF BOXES FOR DISPOSAL.  MONITORING WELLS AND SAMPLING HAS BEEN PERFORMED ON THE IMPACTED AREA BY A GROUND WATER CONSULTANT FOR SITE ASSESSMENT.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE SITE WILL BE CLEARED FOR CLOSURE BY THE MI DEQ IN THE NEAR FUTURE.

column245: ON FEBRUARY 18, 2007, AT APPROXIMATELY 04:09 HOURS, AN INCORRECT VALVE ALIGNMENT OCCURRED, BLOCKING THE FLOW PATH INTO THE GREENVILLE (CADDO MILLS, TX) TANK FARM ACTIVATING THE MANIFOLD PRESSURE RELIEF SYSTEM, WHICH OPERATED AS DESIGNED FOR PRESSURE PROTECTION.      WHEN THE RELIEF SYSTEM ACTIVATED, A RELEASE OCCURRED IN AN AREA OF LOCALIZED INTERNAL CORROSION ON THE 20-INCH RELIEF LINE TO THE TRANSMIX TANK.        CONCURRENTLY, WHEN THE PRESSURE RELIEF ACTIVATED, A RELEASE ALSO OCCURRED FROM A CAST IRON GASO PD PUMP ALIGNED TO THE 20-INCH RELIEF LINE.  THE RELEASE OCCURRED AT A CRACK ON A PREVIOUS REPAIR WELD ON THE SUCTION PUMP CASE.  THE GASO PD PUMP HAS CLASS 300 SUCTION FLANGES, AND CLASS 600 DISCHARGE FLANGES.  THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE CRACK TO THE GASO PUMP IS NOT KNOWN, BUT FREEZING CONDITIONS AND WATER INSIDE THE PUMP CASE MAY HAVE BEEN CONTRIBUTING FACTORS.

column245: On February 22, 2007, the Dispatcher operating the SCADA system noticed that the level in Tank #10 at Santa Rita began dropping while no product was being removed from it. He dispatched local personnel to investigate the cause of the decrease in tank level. Local personnel confirmed  that there was a leak at the mixer housing  location.  Local personnel immediately  dispatched  a vac truck, cat and backhoe to the sight to collect the released product and the Dispatcher began transferring the crude from Tank #10 to the other tank at the facility. When the product was removed from the tank and the atmospheric sampling  showed  that  it was acceptable  to  access the tank,  local personnel confirmed that the tank roof sank, causing damage to the mixer, resulting in the release. Approximately 25 yards of soil were disposed of as a result of this release.  The cuase of the release was determined to be inadequate construction procedures. The tank installation contractor failed to provide adequate support to the upper portion of the tank, allowing for wind to damage the tank prior to it being placed into service. The indented section of the tank shell was remedied by installing external angle iron supports, to correct the out of round section.

column245: THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON 3/06/07 AS AN ICE BALL ON THE GROUND BY A THIRD PARTY OPERATING PERSON.  AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED, THE LINE WAS SHUT IN WHILE THE REFINERY THAT SUPPLIES THE ISOBUTANE WAS SHUTDOWN FOR MAINTENANCE.  THE LINE HAD ABOUT 22 PSIG PRESSURE, WHICH WAS THE VAPOR PRESSURE AT AMBIENT TEMPERATURE.    ON 3/07/07, THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE LEAK WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A PLIDCO CLAMP ON SLEEVE.    THE INTEGRITY OF THE LINE WAS ASSESSED BY ILI ON 5/02/07, AND A SEGMENT WHERE THE LEAK OCCURRED WILL BE REPLACED UNDER INTEGRITY REHAB WORK.

column245: DUE TO CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA, A ROCKY MOUNTAIN PIPELINE OPERATOR VISITED OUR INACTIVE DESERET PUMP STATION ON 3/14/07 AND DISCOVERED THE RELEASE.  THE SURFACE CONDITIONS ON OR ADJACENT TO THE PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY WAS CHECKED BY AERIAL FLIGHT ON 03/05/07 WITH NO EVIDENCE OF AN OIL RELEASE.    AN INVESTIGATION AT THE RELEASE SITE FOUND THAT THE THREADS ON A 1/4" ELBOW (ATTACHED TO THE MAIN PIPELINE) HAD CRACKED ON THE SIDE CONNECTED TO A 1/4" LINE GOING TO A NEEDLE VALVE ON AN ABOVE GROUND INSTRUMENT PANEL AT THE INACTIVE STATION.  THE RELEASED OIL STAYED ON THE FACILITY PROPERTY.

column245: A CONTRACTOR WHILE EXCAVATING AN ILI ANOMALY, SMELLED AMMONIA AND CALLED OPERATIONS.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL REDUCED THE LINE PRESSURE, EXCAVATED THE PIPE, REMOVED THE COATING, CLEANED THE EXTERNAL SURFACE AND PLACED A TYPE B CLAMP OVER THE LEAK.  THE PINHOLE STOPPED LEAKING WHEN THE PRESSURE WAS REDUCED.  AFTER THE CLAMP WAS INSTALLED, THE PRESSURE WAS RAISED BACK TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE WITH NO EVIDENCE OF LEAKAGE.  THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED, AND THE SEGMENT RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATION ON MARCH 20, 2007.     THE FILING ON FEBRUARY 27, 2008 WAS MADE AS A SUPPLEMENTAL FILING BECAUSE THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT WAS NOT YET ADEQUATELY DELINEATED.    UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column245: A GAUGER AT CLEARBROOK WAS CHECKING THE GONVICK DENSITOMETER SITE DUE TO ERRONEOUS READINGS RECEIVED ON LINE 2 UPSTREAM DENSITOMETER AT CLEARBROOK TERMINAL. AT THE DENSITOMETER SITE, HE DISCOVERED OIL SPRAYING OUT OF THREADS ON A 2" UNION LOCATED WITHIN A WHISTLE. THE GAUGER CALLED THE CONTROL CENTER AND ALL LINES WERE SHUT DOWN UNTIL VERIFICATION WAS MADE THAT THE PROBLEM EXISTED ONLY ON LINE 2. THE OTHER LINES WERE RE-STARTED. THE LINE 2 DENSITOMETER 2" TAKE-OFF LINE WAS ISOLATED BY BEMIDJI PLM CREWMEMBERS AND THE LEAK STOPPED. APPROXIMATELY 5 BARRELS OF OIL WAS RECOVERED. THE BEMIDJI PLM WAS AT THE DENSITOMETER SITE FOR LINE 2 START-UP TO VERIFY THAT NO OIL WAS ESCAPING AND TO MAKE NECESSARY REPAIRS TO THE 2" PIPING.

column70: LACK OF FUSION DEFECT IN LONG SEAM. SEE H5
column241: KENNETH L. LYBARGER, SR. COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR
column245: A MEMBER OF THE PUBLIC REPORTED SMELLING ODORS.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION LED TO EXCAVATING THE LINE WHERE A PINHOLE SIZE LEAK IN THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM WAS FOUND.  THE PIECE OF PIPE CONTAINING THE PINHOLE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW, PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE EFFECTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED IN ACCORDANCE WITH ENVIRONMENTAL GUIDELINES AND COMPANY PROCEDURES.   METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS OF THE FAILURE INDICATED A PIN HOLE LEAK AT AN ERW SEAM BOND LINE LACK-OF-FUSION DEFECT THAT ORIGINATED FROM A MANUFACTURING FLAW IN THE ERW SEAM. THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE OF FATIGUE CRACK GROWTH.

column245: EPOLLC PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER NOTICED AN ANOMALY IN THE LINE BALANCE FOR THE WEST LEG LOOP(RED)LINE AND IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN THIS SYSTEM.  FIELD PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO INVESTIGATE AND AT APPROXIMATELY 1:00 AM ON 3/30/07, FIELD PERSONNEL REPORTED THEY HAD DISCOVERED BUBBLING IN A DRAINAGE DITCH.  THE LIQUID RELEASED FROM THE LINE WAS NATURAL GASOLINE.    THE LEAK WAS EXCAVATED AND CLAMPED WITH A PLIDCO SPLIT SLEEVE.  STOPPLES WERE SET AND THEN THE LIQUID IN PIPE BETWEEN THE STOPPLES WAS PUMPED INTO A FRAC TANK.  AT THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK, TOOTH MARKS SUSPECTED FROM A BACKHOE WERE FOUND ALONG THE TOP OF THE PIPE.  THERE WAS ALSO RECENT EVIDENCE OF EXCAVATION WORK.  THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS  CUT OUT AND REPLACED.  PHMSA, EPA, AND NDEQ ALL HAD PERSONNEL AT THE SITE PRIOR TO BACKFILLING.  THE LINE WAS BACKFILLED AND PLACED BACK IN SERVICE ON APRIL 10, 2007.

column245: ON THURSDAY, APRIL 26, AT 10:00 A.M., PECOS METER STATION EXPERIENCED CO2 VENTING THROUGH THE METER¿S RELIEF VALVE. THE RELIEF VALVE VENTED FOR APPROXIMATELY 1 HOUR AND 55 MINUTES. THE CORTEZ SCADA CONTROL CENTER NOTIFIED THE FIELD SUPERVISOR OF THE EVENT. THE SUPERVISOR ARRIVED ON SCENE, INVESTIGATED THE INCIDENT AT THE METER STATION. THE STATIC PRESSURE AT THE STATION WAS 1392 PSI., NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE. THE RELIEF VALVE IS SET TO RELIEVE AT 2270 PSI. ALL PRESSURES AT THE PECOS METER STATION WERE NORMAL (1394 PSI); THE RELIEF VALVE WAS BLOCKED IN, MADE SAFE, REMOVED AND REPLACED. THE STATION WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE AT 1:55 A.M. APPROXIMATELY 190 MCF OR 73 BBLS EQUIVALENT WAS VENTED. THE RELIEF VALVE WAS SENT OFF TO BE TESTED. THE RELIEF VALVE TESTED GOOD. THE RELIEF VALVE DID HOWEVER LEAK THROUGH WORN SEATS; THIS WOULD NOT CAUSE THE VALVE TO PREMATURELY RELIEF DUE TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE.

column245: DISCOVERED BY AERIAL PATROL.  OIL WAS RELEASED INTO THE NECK OF A FARM POND AND WAS CONTAINED AT THIS POINT.  ALTHOUGH THE MFL TOOL IDENTIFIED THE ANOMALY THAT RESULTED IN THE LEAK, THE ANOMALY DID NOT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR REPAIR.  TOOL TOLERANCE AND CORROSION GROWTH FACTORS WERE USED AS A PART OF THE REPAIR CRITERIA.  THE ANOMALY WAS NOT LOCATED WITHIN AN AREA THAT COULD AFFECT A HCA.    THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  ON 7/3/07 IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE COST COULD EXCEED $50,000 AND THE NRC AND THE OKLAHOMA CORPORATION COMMISSION PIPELINE SAFETY DEPARTMENT WERE NOTIFIED.  THE LARGER THAN ORIGINALLY ESTIMATED COSTS WAS DUE TO ABOVE NORMAL RAINFALL IN THE AREA THAT CAUSED DELAYS IN PIPELINE REPAIRS.  ACCURATE COST DETERMINATION WAS NOT AVAILABLE UNTIL CONTRACTORS SUBMITTED THE INVOICE.    THIS RELEASE IMPACTED AN ISOLATED FARM POND WITH NO SIGNIFICANT NEXUS TO A WETLAND OR NAVIGABLE WATERWAY AS DEFINED BY "RAPANOS".  THIS WATER IMPACT IS NOT CONSIDERED REPORTABLE UNDER PHMSA FOR POLLUTION OF A WATER BODY OR UNDER "RAPANOS" FOR CONTAMINATION OF A WETLAND OR NAVIGABLE WATERWAY.

column245: LANDOWNER WAS USING A GRADING BLADE TO CLEAR GARBAGE, BRUSH, ETC. FROM HIS PROPERTY.  THE LANDOWNER HAD CALLED "ONE CALL" AND THE PIPELINE WAS MARKED.  THE LANDOWNER UNINTENTIONALLY PUNCTURED OUR PIPELINE AND IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED OUR CONTROL CENTER TO REPORT THE RELEASE.  THE PIPELINE AT THE RELEASE SITE WAS BURIED APPROXIMATELY 4 INCHES, MOST LIKELY BECAUSE THE GATHERING PIPELINE WAS INSTALLED WHEN THE AREA WAS RURAL.

column245: WHILE CONDUCTING A MANUAL TANK SWITCH, LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL DETECTED GASOLINE ODORS IN AREA OF 600 MANIFOLD.  AT THE TIME IT WAS RAINING AND GASOLINE WAS FOUND IN SURFACE PUDDLES.  THE PUMP STATION WAS SHUT DOWN SINCE MOST MOVEMENTS INTO AND OUT OF THIS LARGE PUMP STATION AND BREAKOUT TANK FARM GO THROUGH THIS MANIFOLD.  COMPANY CREWS WERE CALLED IN AS WELL AS AN OSRO WITH A VAC TRUCK.  EXCAVATION OF THIS AREA DENSE WITH BURRIED PIPING RESULTED IN THE DISCOVERY OF A GRAVITY DRAIN LINE WITH AN EXTERNAL PIN HOLE LEAK.  A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THIS PIN HOLE AND PERMANENT REPAIRS WILL BE MADE IN FUTURE.

column245: ON MONDAY MAY 7, 2007 EMPCO EXPERIENCED A REFINED PRODUCTS RELEASE ON THE BAYTOWN TO IRVING PIPELINE (BIPL).  THE LEAK SITE IS LOCATED IN HARRIS COUNTY, TEXAS NEAR EMPCO'S SATSUMA STATION.  THE INCIDENT OCCURRED AS A REPAIR CREW WAS USING A BACKHOE TO EXCAVATE AN 8 INCH VALVE THAT WAS SCHEDULED TO BE REPLACED.  DURING THE WORK A 2 INCH VALVE, THREADED TO THE END OF A 2 INCH STUB LINE THAT WAS WELDED TO THE MAINLINE IN THE 3 OCLOCK POSITION, BECAME DISLODGED.       ¿X AN ESTIMATED VOLUME OF 844 BARRELS OF GASOLINE WAS RELEASED  ¿X THE GASOLINE ENTERED A DITCH RUNNING ALONGSIDE JACKRABBIT ROAD   ¿X EMPCO HAS WORKED DILIGENTLY TO MINIMIZE ANY IMPACTS TO PUBLIC SAFETY   AND ADVERSE ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES REGARDING THE INCIDENT  ¿X EMPCO AND EXXONMOBIL GLOBAL REMEDIATION CONTINUE TO WORK TOGETHER TO ENSURE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND SITE REMEDIATION ARE DONE EFFECTIVELY  ¿X APPROPRIATE AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE  ¿X AN INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS UNDERWAY

THE ISOLATED SECTION, WHICH DID NOT SEE OIL MOVEMENT, WAS SLATED FOR REMOVAL AS PART OF A FACILITY INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. column245: AS PART OF A FACILITY INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROJECT, SEVERAL DEAD LEGS OF PIPE ON TANK TRANSFER LINES WERE REMOVED FROM THE FACILITY AND THE REMAINING PIPE SEALED WITH BLIND FLANGES.  THE CONSTRUCTION CREW PERFORMING THE OPERATION UTILIZED THE WRONG SIZED GASKET (20" INSTEAD OF 24") WHEN SEALING SOME OF THE BLIND FLANGES.  AS OIL WAS REINTRODUCED INTO THE LINES, IT DISCHARGED FROM AN IMPROPERLY SEALED BLIND FLANGE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON TUESDAY, MAY 15, 2007, BUCKEYE WAS RUNNING A SMART PIG IN AN ETHYLENE PIPELINE.  A TEMPORARY FILTER SKID WAS SETUP AT THE RECEIVING END OF THE PIG RUN.  AT 1230 AN O-RING FAILED IN THE HORIZONTAL HINGED ENCLOSURE DOOR OF THE FILTER VESSEL.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE ON SITE IMMEDIATELY CLOSED THE INLET VALVE TO THE VESSEL ISOLATING THE VESSEL FROM THE PIPELINE.  BUCKEYE EMPLOYEES ON SITE NOTIFIED THEIR LOCAL SUPERVISOR WHO IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE AGENCIES ARRIVED ON SITE AND ASSISTED WITH EMERGENCY PROCEDURES.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE ENCLOSURE DOOR WAS SLIGHTLY OUT OF ALIGNMENT, THIS ALLOWED FOR THE DOOR AND THE FILTER ASSEMBLY O-RING NOT TO SEAL PROPERLY.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON JUNE 5TH A LEAK OCCURRED ON THE 20-INCH WINK PIPELINE PIGGING BYPASS AT GUADALUPE PUMP STATION.  THE LEAK WAS INITIALLY FOUND BY THE LANDOWNER BETWEEN 12PM AND 1PM AND REPORTED IT TO PHMSA¿S SOUTHWEST REGIONAL OFFICE IN HOUSTON BY PHONE. PERSONNEL AT PHMSA RELAYED THE INFORMATION BY EMAIL TO KINDER MORGAN VP-ENGINEERING/OPS WHO THEN FORWARD IT ON TO THE CORRECT BUSINESS UNIT. THE LEAK OCCURRED FROM A PIN-HOLE INTERNAL CORROSION CELL ON THE BOTTOM OF THE ABOVEGROUND SECTION OF THE PIGGING BYPASS.  AFTER THE LEAK WAS VERIFIED THROUGH CONVERSATIONS WITH THE LANDOWNER, THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AT ABOUT 3:20 PM.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER WAS NOTIFIED AT 4:00 PM ¿ NRC# 837649RAWLS. THE TXRRC MIDLAND OFFICE WAS NOTIFIED AT 4:12, JOB NUMBER 70-5795 WAS ASSIGNED TO THE SPILL. KM PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT GUADALUPE STATION AT 5:00 PM AND ISOLATED THE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPE. OIL RAN OFFSITE DOWN THE DIRT ROAD TO A LOW SPOT CONTAINING RAINWATER WHERE IT POOLED AND THEN HAD SHEEN OF OIL FLOW OUT THROUGH THE BRUSH ON TOP OF RAINWATER IN NARROW PATHWAYS APPROXIMATELY 1¿-2¿ WIDE LEAVING ONLY A RESIDUAL AMOUNT OF OIL ON THE GRASS.  A OIL SPILL VOLUME WAS CALCULATED AT 74.4 BBLS, WITH 20 BBLS OF OIL BEING RECOVERED ALONG WITH 70 BBLS OF RAINWATER.  PHMSA AND EPA SENT PERSONNEL TO THE SITE ON 6/6 TO INVESTIGATE.  THE PHMSA REPRESENTATIVE WAS ALSO ON SITE 6/7.   BY THE END OF THE DAY ON 6/6, ALL OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL HAD BEEN SCRAPED UP INTO PILES AND WAS BEING MOVED VIA DUMP TRUCK TO A REMEDIATION SITE ON THE GUADALUPE STATION PROPERTY. ADDITIONALLY ON 6/6 THE ENTIRE 20¿ BYPASS LINE WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND BLIND FLANGES WERE INSTALLED ON THE 20¿ VALVES ADJACENT TO THE BYPASS PIPELINE. THE 20¿ PIPE WILL BE SENT OFF FOR ANALYSIS FOR INTERNAL CORROSION. ON 6/7 CREWS CONTINUED TO MOVE THE CONTAMINATED SOIL TO THE REMEDIATION SITE. SOIL STOCKPILED ON KINDER MORGAN PROPERTY, SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED ON 6/12 FOR HAZARD CHARACTERISTICS AND TPH.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column126: REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL
column245: A CATEPILLAR D9H DOZER STRUCK AND RIPPED OPEN THE TOP QUADRANT OF THE 14-INCH DIAMETER MONTELLO TO BALD EAGLE JUNCTION REFINED PETROLEUM PRODUCTS PIPELINE WHILE REPORTEDLY WIDENING AN EXISTING HAUL ROAD IN AN INACTIVE COAL STRIP MINE THAT WAS BEING PREPARED FOR FUTURE MINING OPERATIONS.  THE OWNER OF THE EQUIPMENT AND CONSTRUCTION COMPANY PERFORMING THE WORK ADMITTED THAT HE HAD INSTRUCTED HIS 70 YEAR OLD DOZER OPERATOR TO NOT WORK WITHIN 50 FEET OF THE PIPELINE.  NO ONE-CALL WAS PLACED BY THE CONTRACTOR WITH PA ONE-CALL FOR THIS WORK.    THE RELEASE WAS DETECTED BY THE PIPELINE CPM/SCADA-BASED LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN.  APPROXIMATELY 63,000 GALLONS OF GASOLINE (93 CF20) WAS RELEASED IN THE STRIP MINE AREA.  THE EQUIPMENT OPERATOR WHO STRUCK THE PIPELINE WAS HOSPITALIZED.  GASOLINE ODORS TRAVELED DOWN GRADIENT TO AN AREA OF HOMES AND THREE SCHOOL BUILDINGS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 1/3 OF A MILE FROM THE RELEASE.  LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS INITIATED A PRECAUTIONARY EVACUATION OF APPROXIMATELY 150 RESIDENTS FROM 45 HOMES AND 3,400 STUDENTS, FACULTY AND STAFF FROM THE SCHOOLS.  MONITORING COMPLETED BY SUNOCO PIPELINE PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTORS FOUND NO EVIDENCE OF ELEVATED LEVELS OF  HYDROCARBONS IN THE RESIDENTIAL AREA OR SCHOOLS BUT SOME THESE BUILDINGS WERE NOT REOCCUPIED FOR APPROXIMATELY 42 HOURS PENDING COMPLETION OF AIR SAMPLING.    PA STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AND MINING OFFICIALS AND FEDERAL MINE SAFETY AND DOT PHMSA PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICIALS RESPONDED TO THE ACCIDENT FOR INVESTIGATION.  LONG-TERM ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESSMENT INDICATES NO IMPACT TO SURFACE OR GROUND WATER.  RELEASED PRODUCT THAT DID NOT IMMEDIATELY VOLATILIZE OR THAT HAS NOT BEEN RECOVERED OR REMEDIATED IS PRINCIPALLY CONTAINED IN MADE LAND SOILS FROM HISTORIC COAL MINING ACTIVITIES.  A LEGAL SETTLEMENT HAS RESULTED IN ASSIGNMENT OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINAL REMEDIATION TO THE PROPERTY OWNER.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE REMEDIATION OF THE SOILS WILL BE DONE BY INCINERATION AT A LOCAL PLANT WITH THE APPROVAL OF PA DEP.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACEMENT OF THE DAMAGED PIPE WITH A NEW SECTION OF PIPE.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THE FILL LINE TO LONG BEACH TANK #3 WAS OUT OF SERVICE.  TO RECEIVE OIL FROM DOMINGUEZ HILLS INTO TANK #3, THE PROCEDURE CALLED FOR THE OIL TO FLOW THROUGH THE PUMP BY-PASS LINE AT LONG BEACH STATION AND TO USE THE PUMP SUCTION LINE FOR OIL TO ENTER TANK #3.  THE PROCEDURE DID NOT SPECIFY THAT THE FLOW RATE FROM DOMINGUEZ HILLS SHOULD BE DECREASED OR SPECIFY THAT THE PRESSURE ON THE LONG BEACH STATION SUCTION MANIFOLD HAD TO BE MAINTAINED LESS THAN THE RELIEF SET POINT.  WHEN THE PUMP WAS ACTIVATED AT DOMINGUEZ HILLS, EXCESS PRESSURE WAS CREATED WHICH CAUSED THE THERMAL RELIEF VALVE ON THE PUMP SUCTION MANIFOLD AT LONG BEACH STATION TO RELIEVE.

column241: KENNETH L. LYBARGER, SR. COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR
column245: A 2" THREADED FITTING IN THE EL DORADO EAST STATION ON A LINE CONNECTING A MAINLINE TO THE LOW PRESSURE MANIFOLD RELIEF SYSTEM PIPING SYSTEM ON THE #7 -16" SOUTH LINE LEAKED APPROXIMATELY 8 GALLONS OF DIESEL.  DUE TO HEAVY RAINES IN THE AREA AT THE TIME, THE DIESEL FUEL FLOWED INTO THE DITCH IMMEDIATELY NORTH OF MPC'S EL DORADO EAST STATION AND WAS CARRIED THROUGH THE DITCH INTO THE ENTRANCE OF NEARBY CONSTANCE CREEK.  TWO CONTAINMENT BOOMS WERE INSTALLED WHERE THE DITCH ENTERED CONSTANT CREEK TO PREVENT FURTHER MOVEMENT OF THE SHEEN.  A THIRD CONTAINMENT BOOM WAS ALSO INSTALLED FURTHER DOWNSTREAM ON THE CREEK AS A PRECAUTION.  UNDERFLOW DAMS WERE CONSTRUCTED ALONG THE DITCH IN CASE OF ADDITIONAL HEAVY RAINS.  THE 2" FITTING AND LINE WERE REMOVED AND PLUGS WERE INSTALLED.  THE RELEASED MATERIAL IS BEING RECOVERED AND DISPOSED IN ACCORDANCE WITH STATE ENVIRONMENTAL GUIDELINES AND MPC PROCEDURES.  THE STATE KDHE REVIEWED THE SITE AND WAS PLEASED WITH THE RESPONSE AND THE MEASURES IN PLACE.

column245: LANDOWNER NOTIFIED CONOCOPHILLIPS OF STAINED SOIL IN THE AREA OF MP 702. LINE FLYER HAD FLOWN THE SYSTEM JUST 36 HOURS PRIOR TO THE NOTIFICATION WITH A REPORT OF "ALL CLEAR". CONTROL CENTER WAS CALLED TO SHUT THE LINE DOWN AND CLOSE THE UPSTREAM BLOCK VALVE. COMPANY EMPLOYEE INVESTIGATED THE CALL AND FOUND STAINED AREA TO BE ON THE CONOCOPHILLIPS ROW. LOCAL OPERATIONS THEN CLOSED THE DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVE AND MADE PROPER NOTIFICATIONS. LINE WAS EXCAVATED, PINHOLE FOUND AND CLAMPED UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS COULD BE MADE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON 5/29/07 AT 07:30 HOURS, A LANDOWNER IN WINDER GA REPORTED  THE ODOR OF GASOLINE AND A SMALL SHEEN AT THE LINE 01 CROSSING OF WILLIAMSON CREEK NEAR WINDER GA IN BARROW COUNTY.    CPC AND CONTRACT ROW PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION TO INVESTIGATE AND CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF A SMALL SHEEN AT THE PIPELINE CROSSING OF WILLIAMSON CREEK.  THE AREA OF THE SHEEN MEASURED FROM 4 TO 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND APPEARED SPORADICALLY.  THE SHEEN EVAPORATED QUICKLY AND DID NOT MIGRATE OR ACCUMULATE DOWNSTREAM.  LINE 1 WAS SHUTDOWN AT 08:00 HOURS ON TUESDAY.   THE SED RESPONSE TEAM WAS MOBILIZED TO THE SITE AND THE INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE ESTABLISHED.   CONTRACT CREWS ARRIVED ON SCENE AND INITIATED RESPONSE ACTIONS WHICH INCLUDED THE INSTALLATION OF TWO UNDERFLOW DAMS, RIVER BOOM AND ABSORBENT BOOM  JUST DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROW CROSSING IN WILLIAMSON CREEK.  TWO ADDITIONAL BOOM CONTAINMENT SITES WHERE INSTALLED AT THE HIGHWAY 316 AND BEN JOHNSON ROAD CROSSINGS OF WILLIAMSON CREEK DOWNSTREAM OF THE ROW.  THE CREEK FLOW WAS DIVERTED AROUND THE ROW CROSSING  USING AN UPSTREAM DAM AND PUMP.  EXCAVATION AND INSPECTION OF THE LINE BEGAN ON 5/30/07 ONCE THE SITE WAS SECURE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTAINMENT MEASURES WERE IN PLACE. DRAIN-UP OPERATIONS OF THE AFFECTED SECTION OF LINE WERE ALSO INITIATED. INSPECTION OF THE LINE DID NOT IDENTIFY THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK DUE TO THE LOW RELEASE RATE AND REDUCED PRESSURE WITHIN THE PIPELINE.  DRAIN-UP OF THE AFFECTED SEGMENT OF LINE 1  WAS COMPLETED ON THE EVENING OF JUNE 2 AND AN 80-FOOT SECTION OF PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED.  THIRD-PARTY EVALUATION DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED THROUGH-WALL CRACK APPROXIMATELY 3.5 INCHES LONG LOCATED WITHIN THE SECTION OF PIPE REMOVED. THE THIRD-PARTY REPORT STATES THAT THE CRACK BEGAN AND GREW DUE TO STRESS CORROSION CRACKING, THEN GREW BY CORROSION FATIGUE, AND THEN FAILED DUE TO DUCTILE OVERSTRESS OF THE REMAINING LIGAMENT.     THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC AT 10:00 HOURS ON 5/29/07 AND TO THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURSES (GA DNR) ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION DIVISION (EPD) AT 10:00 HOURS ON 5/29/07 DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF A SHEEN IN THE CREEK AND POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER.    APPROXIMATELY 3046 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED IN THE VICINITY OF THE RELEASE AREA AND TRANSPORTED TO THE NEARBY REPUBLIC LANDFILL FOR DISPOSAL.  LABORATORY ANALYSES OF THE SOIL INDICATE THAT AN ESTIMATED 139 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RELEASED TO AND CONTAINED WITHIN THE IMPACTED SOIL.  A TOTAL OF 25 GALLONS OF FREE PHASE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED FROM THE EXCAVATION AREA.  AN ESTIMATED 38 GALLONS OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS LOST TO EVAPORATION.  BASED ON THESE ESTIMATES, THE TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME IS ESTIMATED TO BE APPROXIMATELY 200 GALLONS.    ENVIRONMENTAL CLEAN-UP OPERATIONS WERE COMPLETED ON 6/11/07.  A REPORT DOCUMENTING RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION ACTIONS WITH A REQUEST FOR SITE CLOSURE WAS SUBMITTED TO THE GA EPD IN DECEMBER 2007.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: OTHER
column245: ON 6/01/07 AT 10:38 HOURS, THE CONTROL CENTER, AT THE REQUEST OF INTEGRITY ENGINEER, SHUT DOWN LINE 19 BASED ON DATA RECEIVED FROM A TOOL RUN THAT INDICATED AN ANOMALY ON THAT LINE AT STATION NUMBER 1148+79.  A CONTRACTOR CREW WAS IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO EXCAVATE THE LINE AND INSPECT THE ANOMALY.   A COLONIAL INSPECTOR REACHED THE SITE AT 15:10 AND REPORTED A 3' X 3' AREA OF STAINED SOIL WITH AN ODOR OF GASOLINE ON THE GROUND SURFACE ABOVE LINE 19 AT THE LOCATION OF THE ANOMALY.  LINE 18 WAS ALSO SHUT DOWN AS A PRECAUTION UNTIL THE LEAK SOURCE COULD BE DISCOVERED.  LINE 19 WAS BLOCKED AT ROME AND AT CHATTANOOGA JCT.  ONCE THE SITE WAS SECURE AND SAFE CONDITIONS WERE ESTABLISHED AND VERIFIED, A CONTRACT CREW BEGAN EXCAVATION OF THE SITE AT 18:50.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON LINE 19 AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION AT 19:20.  LINE 18 RESTARTED AFTER DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK ON LINE 19.  THE LEAK WAS PLUGGED AND A TYPE B SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON LINE 19.  THE REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AND THE LINE RESTARTED AT 03:10 ON 06/02/07.    RECONNAISSANCE ACTITIVITIES WERE IMMEDIATELY INITIATED IN THE SURROUNDING AREA TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE.  EVIDENCE OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS LIMITED TO THE 3' X 3' SOIL STAIN ABOVE LINE 19 AT THE LOCATION OF THE ANOMALY.  A NUMBER OF SURFACE WATER FEATURES (SPRINGS AND CREEKS) WERE IDENTIFIED IN THE VICINITY OF THE RELEASE.   NO IMPACTS TO SURFACE WATER HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED THROUGH OBSERVATION AND WATER QUALITY SAMPLING OF THE IDENTIFED FEATURES.   ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDING SURFACE WATER SAMPLING AND THE INSTALLATION OF SOIL BORINGS WERE CONDUCTED IN 2007.   SITE INVESTIGATION ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED TO DATE INDICATE THAT THE RELEASE DID NOT  INPACT GROUNDWATER.  APPROXIMATELY 330 TONS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WERE EXCAVATED IN DECEMBER 2007.    A LIMITED AMOUNT OF SOIL IMMEDIATELY BELOW THE POINT OF RELEASE COULD NOT BE EXCAVTED DUE TO THE DEPTH OF THE SOIL AND THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE.  ADDITIONAL ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED THROUGH JULY 2008 CONFIRM THE LIMITED EXTENT OF THE REMAINING CONTAMINATED SOIL. CURRENTLY NEGOTIATING SITE CLOSURE WITH GA EPD. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT FUTURE ACTIVITIES WILL BE LIMITED TO SURFACE WATER SAMPLING AND MONITORING.  AN ESTIMATED 25 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED THROUGH SOIL EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES.  NO FREE PHASE PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED.  TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED TO DATE IS 25 GALLONS.  THE COSTS TO ADDRESS THE RELEASE HAVE BEEN UPDATED TO $129,600 AND INCLUDES FUTURE ANTICIPATED SITE MONITORING COSTS.

column245: ON JUNE 7, 2007 AT APPROXIMATELY 0425 A CONTROLLER FOR BUCKEYE PARTNER RECEIVED AN ALARM FROM WAYNE STATION THAT SHUTDOWN THE STATION.  THE CONTROLLER CALLED THE LOCAL DELEIVERY PERSON TO INVESTIGATE.  ON FURTHER INVESTIGATION THE LOCAL DELIVERY PERSON DISCOVERED THE RELEASE AND IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR.  THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENTED BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  THE RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE CAUSED BY A SEAL SHAFT O-RING FAILURE ON PUMP NUMBER 2.   ALL OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND ALL RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED ON BUCKEYE¿S PROPERTY AND RECOVERED.

column245: ON SUNDAY JUNE 24TH 2007, THE CANTON OHIO TERMINAL EXPERIENCED AN OVERLOADING OF THE TERMINAL¿S UNINTERRUPTIBLE POWER SUPPLY (UPS) RESULTING FROM THE FAILURE OF AN AUTOMATED VALVE DURING RECEIPT OF A PIPELINE DELIVERY OF GASOLINE.  AS PER DESIGN, THE INCOMING FLOW OF PRODUCT WAS STOPPED BY THE AUTOMATIC (UNINTENDED) CLOSURE OF THE DELIVERY LINE¿S POWER FAIL VALVE AND THE FLOW WAS THEN DIVERTED, VIA A PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE, TO AN INTERNAL FLOATING ROOF INTERFACE TANK.  THE TERMINAL¿S UPS WAS THE SINGULAR POWER SOURCE FOR PRIMARY PIPELINE AND TERMINAL MONITORING, WARNING, AND COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT WHICH IS UTILIZED BY THE TULSA CONTROL CENTER (TCC) TO REMOTELY MONITOR SYSTEM OPERATION.  DUE TO THE FAILURE OF THE UPS AND ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATION EQUIPMENT, THE TCC CONTROLLER WAS UNAWARE THAT PRODUCT WAS FLOWING INTO THE SMALLER CAPACITY INTERFACE TANK.  THE INTERFACE TANK WAS SUBSEQUENTLY OVER FILLED AND APPROXIMATELY 307 BBLS OF GASOLINE WAS RELEASED TO THE TANK DIKE CONTAINMENT BEFORE THE CONTROLLER SHUT DOWN THE SYSTEM.  BP PERSONNEL AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTORS RESPONDED.  MONITORING SHOWED NO OFF-SITE MIGRATION OR OTHER HAZARDS TO THE PUBLIC.  REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES COMMENCED LATER THE SAME DAY.

column245: MAINLINE PUMP UNITS ARE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE COOLANT TO THE BEARINGS OF THE UNIT.  THIS COOLANT IS THE PRODUCT THAT IS BEING PUMPED THRU IT AT THE THAT TIME.  THAT PRODUCT IS DIRECTED FOR THE CASE OF THE PUMP AND TUBED TO THE INBOARD AND OUTBOARD BEARINGS.   THE TUBING USED IS STAINLESS STEEL .035 WT WITH A PRESSURE RATING OF 2600 PSI.   THE TUBING FAILED IN THE AREA ADJACENT TO THE  FERRULE FITTING THAT IS ATTACHED TO THE OUTBOARD BEARING BOX.  THE FAILURE WAS VERY SMALL FRACTURE THAT DID NOT APPEAR TO BE CAUSED BY VIBRATIONS OR FAULTY INSTALLATION.  THE RELEASE WAS IN THE FORM A VERY FINE MIST, AND DID NOT CREATE ANY POOLED OR STANDING PRODUCT.

column245: ON 6/12/07 A THIRD PARTY OPERATOR IN THE AREA NOTICED BUBBLES IN THE ATCHAFALAYA RIVER NEAR EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY'S (EMPCO)8" GARDEN CITY RAWMAKE PIPELINE THAT WAS SHUT-IN.  HE CONTACTED EMPCO.  EMPCO IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO THE SITE. THERE WAS NO VISIBLE SPILL OR SHEEN ON WATER. PERSONNEL MOBILIZED VESSELS ON THE ATCHAFALAYA RIVER AND OBSERVED SMALL VOLUME OF BUBBLES IN THE VICINITY OF EMPCO'S RIGHT OF WAY.  DIVERS WERE MOBILIZED AND LOCATED SMALL LEAK SITE ON BOTTOM OF EMPCO'S PIPELINE ON 6/14/07.  THE SITE WAS SUCCESSFULLY CLAMPED.  THE NRC WAS CONTACTED UPON EMPCO'S DETERMINATION THAT THE $50,000 COSTS CRITERIA WAS IMMINENT (AT APPROXIMATELY 1800 HOURS).  AT THAT TIME THE LEAK VOLUME WAS BELIEVED TO BE MINIMAL/LESS THAN REPORTING CRITERIA.  BASED UPON SUBSEQUENT FACT GATHERING, EMPCO ESTIMATES THAT THE LEAK COULD HAVE OCCURRED AS EARLY AS MAY 2, 2007.  IT WAS SO SMALL AND SLOW THAT IT HAD NOT BEEN VISIBLE DURING REGULAR AERIAL PATROLS. FOR PURPOSES OF THIS REPORT, A REVIEW OF RECORDS WAS CONDUCTED AND BASED ON THAT DATA, EMPCO ESTIMATED WORST CASE VOLUME LPG RAWMAKE LOSS.  PART E, NO. 2 SUPPLEMENTAL EXPLANATION - THE PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK FOR APPROXIMATELY 250 FEET, AND ANOTHER EXPOSED SECTION WAS FOUND AT STA. # 465+03, LENGTH OF EXPOSURE 450 FEET.  THE LINE HAD BEEN SURVEYED AND FOUND APPROPRIATELY BURIED IN JUNE 2005, PRIOR TO HURRICANES KATRINA AND RITA.  SCOURING DUE TO RIVER CURRENTS EXPOSED THE PIPELINE AND ALLOWED A STUMP TO BECOME LODGED UNDER IT.    DIVERS REMOVED THE LARGE STUMP THAT WAS WEDGED ON THE UNDERSIDE OF THE PIPELINE AT THE LEAK SITE.  BASED ON PINHOLE IN THE MIDDLE OF SMALL INDENTATION AT CONTACT POINT OF STUMP, IT IS LIKELY THE STUMP CONTRIBUTED TO THE DAMAGE.  EMPCO OBTAINED THE USCG'S CONCURRENCE BEFORE SANDBAGGING BOTH SHALLOW SITES.  THUS, THE PIPELINE IS NOT A HAZARD TO NAVIGATION.  THE LINE SECTION WAS DISPLACED WITH NITROGEN, ISOLATED, DISCONNECTED AND IDLED.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: TENANT FARMER NOTICED THAT CORN PLANTS HAD RECENTLY DIED IN AN AREA DIRECTLY ABOVE THE PIPELINE AND NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER.      LOCAL KANEB PERSONEL INVESTIGATED REPORT AND VERIFIED THE SMELL OF AMMONIA IN THE SOIL.  THE PIPE WAS EXCAVATED ON 6.4.07 FOR INVESTIGATION.  A SMALL LEAK WAS FOUND AT APPROXIMATELY 12:40 ORIGINATING FROM AN UNKNOWN SOURCE.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AT APPROXIMATELY 12:45 AND CLOSEST UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES WERE CLOSED TO ISOLATE THE LEAK.    THE LEAK WAS CLAMPED AT APPROXIMATELY 13:00 STOPPING THE LEAK.  THE PIPE WAS EFFECTIVELY REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 20:30 ON 5.6.07.    TELEPHONIC REPORTING NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY MO LEPC, MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT TIME OF DISCOVERY.    THE AFFECTED JOINT OF PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR INDEDPENDENT ANALYSIS.     SUMMARY & CONCLUSION OF KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES ANALYSIS:  THE LEAK OCCURED IN THE ERW SEAM OF THE PIPE SPECIMEN AND WAS CAUSED BY A MANUFACTURING DEFECT. THE DEFECT IS CONSISTENT WITH A COLD WELD (LACK OF FUSION) CAUSED BY CONTAMINATION OF THE COIL EDGES DURING FORMATION OF THE ERW WELD.  THE WELD DEFECT WAS ORIGINALLY FILLED WITH BRASS (A COPPER ZINC ALLOY)   FROM THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS THAT BLOCKED LEAKAGE EARLY-ON IN THE LIFE OF THE PIPE.  WITH THE PASSAGE OF TIME, THE FOREIGN MATERIAL IS BELIEVED TO HAVE DETERIORATED BY DISSOLUTION OR FRACTURING, THEREBY PERMITTING LEAKAGE.        4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column241: STEPHEN M. PEYTON, MANAGER PIPELINE OPERATIONS
column245: A PINHOLE LEAK WAS FOUND IN THE PIPE.  THE OIL HAD MIGRATED TO A JOINT IN AN IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT STORMWATER LINE AND HAD FOLLOWED THE STORMWATER LINE ACROSS THE ROAD, THROUGH THE PARKING LOT AREA AND INTO THE OCEAN.  THE STORMWATER LINE HAD APPARENTLY BEEN INSTALLED AFTER THE PIPELINE; AND DURING THE EXCAVATION FOR THE STORMWATER LINE, THE PROTECTIVE COATING OF THE OIL PIPELINE WAS DAMAGED, ALLOWING EXTERNAL CORROSION TO WEAR AT THE PIPELINE UNTIL THE LEAK OCCURRED.TO PREVENT REOCCURENCE OF THIS TYPE OF RELEASE, PARAMOUNT RELOCATED APPROXIMATELY 400 FEET OF PIPE TO MOVE IT AWAY FROM THE STORMWATER LINE.  IN ADDITION, PARAMOUNT FOLLOWS NORMAL OPERATING PROCEDURES OF BIWEEKLY LINE RIDING TO ENSURE UNAUTHORIZED EXCAVATIONS ARE NOT TAKING PLACE ALONG THE PIPELINE, AND RESPONDING TO DIG ALERTS TO OVERSEE AUTHORIZED EXCAVATIONS.  PARAMOUNT WAS NOT THE OPERATOR OF THE OIL PIPELINE AT THE TIME OF THE STORMWATER LINE INSTALLATION, BUT ADHERES TO THESE PROCEDURES TO ENSURE THIS TYPE OF INCIDENT DOES NOT REOCCUR.

column245: BAYOU GOULA STATION IS CONNECTED TO 2 16" CRUDE PIPELINES.  ONE LINE COMPLETED A SHIPMENT APPROXIMATELY 1 HOUR PRIOR TO LEAK DISCOVERY, AND WAS DOWN.  UPON NOTIFICATION BY AIR PATROL, EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE PERSONNEL SHUT IN STATION, AND MOBILIZED TO SITE.  THEY DETERMINED LEAK CAME FROM EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE FACILITIES INSIDE STATION.  THEY FOUND A PINHOLE LEAK ON THE BOTTOM OF A 12" STATION RELIEF PIPELINE AND REPAIRED IT.  CLEAN-UP PROCEEDED AND THE  PIPELINES/STATION RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS.    THE NRC WAS CONTACTED ON 6/21/07 UPON DETERMINATION THAT ESTIMATED COSTS WOULD MEET REPORTING CRITERIA.    METALLURGICAL TESTING DETERMINED MICROBIOLOGICAL INDUCED CORROSION (MIC) TO BE THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF THE INTERNAL CORROSION.

column245: ON JUNE 28, 2007, AT APPROXIMATELY 10:11 HOURS, AN EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE ARRIVED AT THE HANKAMER, TEXAS PUMP STATION AND LOCATED AN ABOVE GROUND FLANGED CONNECTION DRIPPING JET FUEL.  THE JET FUEL THAT WAS RELEASED WAS COMPLETELY CONTAINED IN A DITCH AT THE HANKAMER, TEXAS PUMP STATION, WHICH IS LOCATED IN AN OIL PRODUCTION FIELD. THE DITCH AT THE OIL FIELD PRODUCTION FIELD IS DRY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR.  HOWEVER, DUE TO RECENT RAINS, THE DITCH CONTAINED SOME STANDING WATER.  THE WATER AND THE JET FUEL WAS VACUUMED AND PLACED IN A FRAC TANK.  THE WATER AND SOIL HAVE BEEN TESTED AND ARE AWAITING APPROPRIATE DISPOSAL.   THE ABOVE GROUND FLANGED CONNECTION EXPERIENCED A GASKET FAILURE. THE FLANGED CONNECTION WAS INSPECTED, A NEW GASKET WAS INSTALLED, AND THE FLANGED CONNECTION WAS RETORQUED.

column245: ON JULY 14, 2007 AT 14:35, EXPLORER PIPELINE¿S 28 INCH PIPELINE EXPERIENCED A RUPTURE IN A PASTURE AT MILE POST 151.76, WHICH IS 6.3 MILES NORTH EAST OF HUNTSVILLE, TEXAS.  6,568 BARRELS OF JET FUEL WAS RELEASED AND 4,675 BARRELS OF JET FUEL WAS RECOVERED. THE REMAINING 1,893 BARRELS OF JET FUEL WAS CONTAINED IN SOIL OR ABSORBENT MATERIAL THAT WAS PROPERLY MANAGED AND DISPOSED.        CC TECHNOLOGIES ISSUED THE FINAL REPORT TITLED METALLURGICAL REPORT; ANALYSIS OF RUPTURE ON EXPLORER PASADENA TO GREENVILLE 28 INCH DIAMETER PIPELINE AT M.P. 151.8, ON NOVEMBER 29, 2007.  THE FAILURE AT M.P. 151.76 HAS BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO FATIGUE CRACKING.  THE CRACK INITIATED AT THE TOE OF THE DSAW PIPE SEAM.  NO EVIDENCE OF CORROSION, STRESS CORROSION CRACKING, MECHANICAL DAMAGE OR MATERIAL DEFECTS WAS OBSERVED.    PART C - 3.G. HIGH RESOLUTION MAGNETIC FLUX TOOL - YEAR RUN IN 1999 AND 2004  PART D - 2. column245: EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE (EMPCO) WAS CONTACTED BY A CITIZEN AND ADVISED OF A POSSIBLE CRUDE RELEASE IN A DITCH NEAR ITS MELVILLE EAST SCRAPER TRAP STATION.  THE EMPCO OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN A PIPELINE CONNECTED TO THE FACILITY, AND PERSONNEL MOBILIZED TO THE SITE.  THEY DISCOVERED A RELEASE FROM THE SCRAPER TRAP AT THE FACILITY.  EMPCO NOTIFIED NRC, STATE, AND LOCAL OFFICIALS.     THE MAJORITY OF THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED IN A NEARBY DITCH.  A SMALL QUANTITY REACHED AN IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT FARMER'S FIELD.  VACUUM TRUCKS WERE USED TO RETRIEVE THE CRUDE OIL IN THE DITCH.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM FARMER'S PROPERTY AND DITCH.    EMPCO MADE A SECOND NRC REPORT, 843351, WHEN THE ACTUAL SPILL QUANTITY INCREASED.    EMPCO COMPLETED AN INVESTIGATION INCLUDING MEETING WITH MANUFACTURER.  EMPCO DETERMINED THE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT TO BE MANUFACTURER DEFECT; THE TRAP DOOR CLOSURE WAS DEFECTIVE AND CAUSED O-RING FAILURE.    2/16/2010...CORRECTED COMPENSATED LOSSES (ESTIMATED) BY REMOVING $460K FROM THE PUBLIC/COMMUNITY LOSSES REIMBURSED BY OPERATOR SECTION AND ADDED THE $460K TO THE OPERATOR LOSSES SECTION PLUS AN ADDITIONAL $65K, MAKING A NEW TOTAL COST OF $665,730.OO

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: OTHER
column61: FT. LUPTON DRINKING WATER AND HIGH POPULATION
column64: STATION SUMP. 5 TO 6 IN. RAIN STORM FLOODED STA.
column245: FIVE TO SIX INCHES OF RAIN IN 1 TO 2 HOURS IN THE EARLY MORNING HOURS OF AUGUST 3, 2007 CAUSED LOCALIZED FLOODING. WATER DEPTH IN FT. LUPTON STATION REACHED 2.0 TO 2.5 FEET. THE DEPTH OF WATER ALLOWED RAIN WATER TO FLOW INTO THE STATION OVERFLOW SUMP. WHEN THE SUMP WAS FULL OF WATER, THE CRUDE OIL IN THE SUMP WAS FORCED OUT THE GAUGING HATCH. THE HIGH SUMP ALARM CAUSED THE STATION TO SHUT DOWN AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED. DUE TO FLOODING, IT WAS DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE IF A PROBLEM EXISTED. WHEN OTHER PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT APPROXIMATELY 3:45 A.M., IT WAS DETERMINED THERE HAD BEEN A RELEASE AND IT WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT APPROXIMATELY 4:00 A.M.. THE RELEASE TOOK PLACE IN A SHORT PERIOD OF TIME ONCE THE SUMP TANK WAS FULL OF WATER. IT IS ESTIMATED THE RELEASE BEGAN AND ENDED WITHIN A 15 MINUTE PERIOD. THE SUMP TANK IS USED TO COLLECT ANY OIL ASSOCIATED WITH ABOVE GROUND EQUIPMENT SUCH AS PUMP SEAL FLUSHES AND MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES. THE SUMP LEVEL IS MAINTAINED AT 2 TO 3 BARRELS OF OIL. THE RELEASED CRIDE OIL FROM THE SUMP TANK FLOWED WITH THE FLOOD WATERS OVER WELD COUNTY ROAD 20 DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO THE PUMP STATION AND MOVED WITH THE FLOOD WATERS ALONG THE UNION PACIFIC RAILROAD BERM SEVERAL HUNDRED FEET TO THE WEST. OIL COLLECTED A VARIOUS POINTS UP TO COUNTY ROAD 22 WHERE THE FLOOD WATERS WERE CONTAINED. THERE IS NO EVIDENCE OF ANY CRUDE OIL IN SURFACE WATERS OF THE SOUTH PLATTE RIVER OR ITS TRIBUTARIES. ALL OIL WAS CONTAINED ADJACENT TO THE RAILROAD BERM AND THE FIELDS BELOW THE PUMP STATION. ALL CONTAMINATED SOILS AND VEGETATION HAVE BEEN CLEANED UP AND NO FURTHER REMEDIATION IS NECESSARY. AS A RESULT, NO IMPACT TO GROUND WATER IS EXPECTED.

column245: THIS IS AN OLD COLLARED LINE; A REMEDIATION SITE, FROM A PREVIOUS RELEASE AT THIS LOCATION, WHERE THE GROUND SETTLED DUE TO HEAVY RAINS AND FLOODING PULLED THE COLLAR APART AT THE THREADS WHICH RESULTED IN THIS RELEASE.  THIS LINE SEGMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND ALL PRODUCT REMOVED.    ALTHOUGH THE COST FOR THE RESPONSE TO THIS RELEASE EXCEEDS $50,000, A TELEPHONIC REPORT TO THE NRC WAS NOT MADE AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE BECAUSE IT WAS ANTICIPATED THAT THE HEAVY RAIN WOULD LIMIT PENETRATION OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT INTO WATER SATURATED SOIL.  THE RELEASE HOWEVER REACHED AND PENETRATED THE LOOSE SOIL OF A PREVIOUS EXCAVATION THAT RESULTED IN THE REMOVAL, REMEDIATION, AND REPLACEMENT OF A MUCH LARGER VOLUME OF SOIL THAN WAS ESTIMATED AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE, THUS INCREASING THE RESPONSE AND REMEDIATION COSTS ABOVE $50,000.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON SUNDAY, AUGUST 5, 2007, AT 12:51 PM ERIE TOWNSHIP FIRE DEPARTMENT CONTACTED THE SUNOCO LOGISTICS CONTROL CENTER TO REPORT A LEAK ON THE RAUCH ROAD MAIN LINE VALVE. THE FIRE DEPARTMENT HAD INITIALLY SHUT DOWN RAUCH ROAD, TELEGRAPH ROAD AND THE ADJOINING RAILROAD TRACKS. THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN, WHICH AT THE TIME WAS MOVING JET A. REGIONAL EMPLOYEES WERE NOTIFIED AT 13:00 TO RESPOND TO THE LEAK SITE.     WHEN SUNOCO LOGISTICS PERSONNEL ARRIVED ONSITE, THEY VERIFIED THAT THE LEAK HAD STOPPED AND THAT ALL PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE OPEN EXCAVATION AROUND THE VALVE SITE. AIR MONITORING WAS CONDUCTED TO VERIFY SAFE CONDITIONS, AND ALL ROADWAYS WERE REOPENED AT 14:00. MARINE POLLUTION CONTROL WAS CALLED IN TO PUMP OUT THE SPILLED PRODUCT, WHICH WAS APPROXIMATELY 5 BBLS OF JET A. ALL PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE BY 19:00. FURTHER SOIL REMEDIATION WILL BE CONDUCTED AS REQUIRED.    THE LEAK WAS ON A FLANGE ON THE NEWLY INSTALLED ABOVE GRADE MLV AT RAUCH ROAD, WHICH HAD REPLACED A BELOW GRADE VALVE LOCATED ONE MILE SOUTH. THE WORK ON THE MLV WAS COMPLETED FRIDAY EVENING. THE LINE HAD STARTED UP AT 05:30 ON SATURDAY, AUGUST 4 AFTER LINE FILLING AND PROOF TESTING OF THE ROUGE LINE. THE INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT THE FLANGE HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY TORQUED, NOR HAD THE SITE BEEN VISIBLY INSPECTED BEFORE START UP. WHEN RESPONDERS ARRIVED ONSITE, THEY FOUND SOME OF THE FLANGE BOLTS WERE ONLY HAND TIGHT. ANOTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTOR TO THE LOOSENED FLANGE IS THE FACT THAT THE CRIBBING SUPPORTING THE LINE HAD SUNK 2- 3 INCHES AFTER INSTALLATION.     THE RESPONDING CREW REPLACED THE GASKET AND PROPERLY TORQUED THE FLANGE. WORK WAS COMPLETED BY 20:30. PRESSURE TESTING WAS CONDUCTED AND COMPLETED AT 02:10 ON AUGUST 6, AT WHICH TIME THE LINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.  THE OPERATOR QUALIFICATIONS OF ALL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL INVOLVED WITH THE INSTALLATION OF THE MLV WERE SUSPENDED PENDING TRAINING AND RE-QUALIFICATION.

column245: ON FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 7, 2007 AT APPROXIMATELY 18:04 EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY (EMPCO) EXPERIENCED A REFINED PRODUCTS RELEASE ON THE BAYTOWN TO IRVING INTRASTATE PIPELINE (BIPL).  THE LEAK SITE IS LOCATED IN BRAZOS COUNTY, TEXAS SEVERAL MILES NORTH OF EMPCO'S NAVASOTA STATION.  THE INCIDENT OCCURRED AS A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR WORKING ON A STATE HIGHWAY PROJECT STRUCK THE 8 INCH PIPELINE WHILE ATTEMPTING TO REMOVE A TEMPORARY HAUL ROAD.  AN ESTIMATED VOLUME OF 1477 BARRELS OF UNLEADED GASOLINE WAS RELEASED.  THE GASOLINE IMPACTED THE SPILL SITE AND A CREEK IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY.  AGGRESSIVE SPILL RESPONSE EFFORTS WERE EMPLOYED TO MINIMIZE THE PUBLIC SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF THE INCIDENT.  TEXAS STATE HIGHWAY 6 WAS CLOSED FOR APPROXIMATELY 7 HOURS FRIDAY NIGHT AS A RESULT OF ELEVATED HYDROCARBON VAPORS.  EMPCO IS WORKING TO ENSURE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND SITE REMEDIATION ARE DONE FLAWLESSLY.    THE 3RD PARTY CONTRACTOR WAS WORKING ON A STATE PROJECT TO EXPAND HIGHWAY 6.  ONE CALL NOTIFICATION WAS MADE FOR THE ROAD WORK AS WELL AS EXCAVATION OF A NEARBY POND (DIRT FROM THE POND WAS BEING USED FOR ROAD CONSTRUCTION PROJECT).  THERE WAS NOT A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION MADE FOR THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITY (GRADING) THAT RESULTED IN EMPCO¿S PIPELINE BEING STRUCK.    AFTER THE INCIDENT THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN REMOTELY AND REMOTE CONTROL VALVES WERE CLOSED, EMPCO EMPLOYEES WERE DISPATCHED TO MANUAL VALVES ON EITHER SIDE OF THE SPILL LOCATION TO ISOLATE THE AFFECTED SECTION AS CLOSELY AS POSSIBLE.  MANUAL VALVES WERE CLOSED BY 21:10 9/7/07 ISOLATING APPROXIMATELY 10.8 MILES OF 8 INCH PIPE.  DUE TO SAFETY CONCERNS EMPCO EMPLOYEES WERE NOT ABLE TO ACCESS THE LEAK SITE UNTIL THE NEXT MORNING, AT THAT TIME THERE WAS A SMALL STREAM OF GASOLINE DRAINING FROM THE PUNCTURE.  A CLAMP WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE AT APPROXIMATELY 09:50 9/8/07. LEAK DURATION IS SHOWN AS 16 HOURS, TIME UNTIL CLAMP INSTALLED.

column245: THIS INCIDENT WAS THE RESULT OF THE TERMINAL OPERATOR BEING DISTRACTED BY MULTIPLE OPERATIONS IN PROGRESS AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  THE OPERATOR DID NOT RE-POSITION A VALVE WHEN A SECONDARY PUMP HAD TO BE USED BECAUSE A PRIMARY PUMP FAILED TO START.  THE OPERATOR OVERSIGHT CAUSED BY HAVING TO OVERSEE MULTIPLE OPERATIONS RESULTED IN FLOW TO A PIPELINE AND UNINTENDED FLOW TO TANK NO. 2008.  THIS TANK OVERFLOWED INTO A VAPOR CONTROL SYSTEM FROM WHICH THE PRODUCT WAS RELEASED.    REFERENCE PART A, PARAGRAPH 5. LOSSES (ESTIMATED)AND PART F, PARAGRAPH 2. ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT.  AFTER FURTHER EVALUATION AND TESTING, THE INCREASE IN COST ESTIMATES IS DUE PRIMARILY TO INCLUSION OF REMEDIATION COSTS FOR SOIL AND GROUNDWATER CONTAMINATION AND PROPERTY DAMAGE TO TANK 2008.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 1824 HOURS ON TUESDAY SEPTEMBER 11TH THE CONTROL CENTER STARTED THE LINE 1 UNIT 3 AT EPES STATION.  AT SOME TIME AFTER THIS START UP THE BEARING SEAL ON THE OUTBOARD END OF THE #3 PUMP FAILED AND BEGAN TO ALLOW PRODUCT (GASOLINE) TO FLOW INTO THE PUMPS BUFFALO SYSTEM LEAK CONTAINMENT BOX.  UNDER NORMAL CIRCUMSTANCES THE PRODUCT WOULD BACK UP INTO THE BOX IF A PUMP SEAL IS LEAKING BADLY AND RAISE THE FLOAT IN THE BOX WHICH WOULD ALARM THE CONTROL CENTER AND AUTOMATICALLY SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATE THE PUMP UNIT.  UNFORTUNATELY IN THIS CASE THE FLOAT MECHANISM ALSO FAILED WHICH ALLOWED GASOLINE TO OVERFLOW THE BOX AND SPILL OUT ONTO THE GROUND.  AT THE SAME TIME THE GASOLINE IS SPILLING OUT ON THE GROUND, SOME OF THE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING THROUGH THE DRAIN PIPING TO THE SUMP.  AT 0205 ON SEPTEMBER 12TH THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A HIGH SUMP ALARM AT EPES STATION AND GENERATED A CALLOUT TO THE LOCAL TECHNICIAN. THE TECHNICIAN ARRIVED AT THE STATION AROUND 0322 AT WHICH TIME HE DISCOVERED THE PRODUCT BEING RELEASED FROM THE PUMP UNIT AND NOTIFIED THE CONTROL CENTER WHICH IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED THE UNIT.  THE GROUND AT EPES STATION WAS PUDDLED AFTER A RAINFALL EVENT EARLIER THAT NIGHT AND INITIALLY DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS ABOUT 1 BARREL OF GASOLINE RELEASED. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER AT 03:53 WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER DECIDED TO REPORT DIRECTLY TO THE SCENE UPON NOTIFICATION AND THE DISTRICT LEADER NOTIFIED THE GENERAL MANAGER OF OPERATIONS VIA E-MAIL DUE TO THE TIME OF DAY AND THE RELATIVELY LOW AMOUNT OF THE RELEASE AT THAT TIME. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER ARRIVED ON SCENE SHORTLY AFTER 0600 ON THE 12TH AND BEGAN TO ASSIST THE LOCAL TECHNICIAN WITH THE SITE ASSESSMENT.  AS THE SUN BEGAN TO RISE ALLOWING THEM TO BETTER ASSESS THE SCENE THEY WERE ABLE TO ASCERTAIN THAT THE PRODUCT LEVEL IN THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR WAS GREATER THAN PREVIOUSLY THOUGHT AND THAT THERE WAS STILL SIGNIFICANT VOLUME OF GASOLINE IN THE YARD SUB SURFACE DRAINAGE SYSTEM.  THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER AROUND 0730 THAT THE VOLUME ESTIMATE SHOULD BE INCREASED TO 50 BARRELS. IN ADDITION HE ESCALATED THE RESPONSE EFFORT ORDERING ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT AND RESOURCES.  THE PROJECT LEADER WAS PUT ON STANDBY (LOCATED AT THE TIME IN BATON ROUGE, LA) TO ASSIST.  THE DISTRICT LEADER NOTIFIED THE GENERAL MANAGER OF OPERATIONS VIA PHONE CALL OF THE REVISED VOLUME AMOUNT.  AFTER DISCUSSION IT WAS DECIDED THAT A GROUP 4 PAGE SHOULD BE ISSUED TO INFORM THE REST OF MANAGEMENT OF THE ISSUE.  THE CONTROL CENTER ISSUED THE GROUP 4 AFTER BEING INSTRUCTED BY THE DISTRICT LEADER TO DO SO.  AS THE DAY PROGRESSED AND MORE RESOURCES ARRIVED AT THE SCENE, MINOR EXCAVATIONS WERE MADE IN THE STATION YARD AND THE YARD REPEATEDLY FLOODED WITH WATER.  FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND PUMPED INTO THE UTILITY TANK ON SITE.  AT THE END OF THE DAY ALL THE FREE PRODUCT IN THE YARD HAD BEEN RECOVERED.  A TOTAL OF 63 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED.  WORK CONTINUED ON THE 13TH WITH ADDITIONAL FLOODING OF THE STATION TO SATISFY THE REPRESENTATIVES OF EPA REGION 4 AND THE STATE OF ALABAMA.  NO ADDITIONAL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED.  ALL CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.

THE HIGHWAY WAS BLOCKED OFF, AND OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED.  OPERATIONS BLOCKED IN THE LINE, AND THEN BLEW IT DOWN.  PORTABLE FLARES WERE USED AT BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM BLOCK VALVES.  FIRE DEPARTMENT AND SHERIFF PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE THROUGH THE NIGHT, AND PHMSA PERSONNEL WERE ON SITE LATER ON THE SAME DAY THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED.    THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AT THE TIME OF THE LEAK.  AS DESCRIBED IN EPCO, INC. BYPASS FAILURE MAPL SOUTH LEG (12" BROWN LINE)REPORT BY DEREK GILBOE DATED FEBRUARY 14, 2008, A THREADED CONNECTION OF A 2" VALVE ON A THREAD-O-RING (TOR) FITTING FAILED.    ABOUT 6,000 BBLS OF PRODUCT WAS RELEASED AT THE LEAK SITE, AND A TOTAL OF 14,763 BBLS WAS ESTIMATED LOST, INCLUDING CONTROLLED FLARING AT BOTH BLOCK VALVE SITES.  THE COST SHOWN FOR PRODUCT LOST IS FOR THE 14763 BBL VOLUME.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: THE EVENT OCCURRED AT APPROXIMATELY 1515 MOUNTAIN DAYLIGHT TIME.  UPON DISCOVERY OF THE ABNORMAL OPERATION CONDIDTION; PIPELINE OPERATIONS WERE SHUT DOWN, NOTIFICATION AND CALL DOWN PROCEDURES IDENTIFIED IN THE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WERE INITIATED, AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS WERE MOBILIZZED TO THE SITE.  AN INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE WAS ESTABLISHED WHICH INCORPORTATED A UNIFIED COMMAND AND INCLUDED FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL REPRESENTATIVES.  UPON REQUEST OF THE COMPANY, THE MONTGOMERY COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE EVACUATED 2 RESIDENCES IN THE AREA ( 3 PEOPLE TOTAL) AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE.  EVACUEE'S RETURNED TO THEIR RESIDENCES THE FOLLOWING DAY.    THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A SPLIT SEAM ON THE LONGITUDINAL WELD.  METALLURGICAL STUDIES ON THE PIPE ARE BEING CONDUCTED AND THE RESULTS WILL BE REPORTED BACK THROUGH PHMSA.  THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE ON SEPTEMBER 10TH AND IS OPERATING AT A 20% PRESSURE REDUCTION AS APRPROVED BY PHMSA.   REMOVAL OF CONTAMINATED SOIL IS ON GOING AND IS BEING OVERSEEN BY THE MISSOURT DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES.  THE MAJORITY OF OIL RELEASED WAS CONTIANED WITHIN AN ISOLATED PRIVATE STOCK POND WITH NO INLET OR OUTLET.    THERE WERE A TOTAL OF 4 NRC NOTIFICATIONS MADE FOR THIS RELEASE.  THE PURPOSE OF EACH SUBSEQUENT NOTIFICATION WAS TO PROVIDE UPDATED INFORMATION REGARDING THE RELEASE.  THE NRC NOTIFICATION NUMBERS ARE AS FOLLOWS..  NRC NUMBER 848067 - 9/10/07;   NRC NUMBER 848091 - 9/7/07;  NRC NUMBER 848432 - 9/10/07; AND  NRC NUMBER 849206 - 9/18/07.      THIS 7000-1 FORM IS INTENDED TO MEET THE FOLLOW UP REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL OF THE 4 NRC NOTIFICATIONS.

column245: APPROXIMATELY 1910 ON 10/2/07 A THIRD PARTY NOTIFIED OUR RENO-SPARKS, NV TERMINAL FACILITY, WHO IN TURN NOTIFIED OUR ORANGE CONTROL CENTER CONTROLLER BY TELEPHONE REPORTING A RELEASE OF PRODUCT IN AN INDUSTRIAL AREA OF RENO, NEVADA. THE CONTROLLER HAD BEGUN SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES ON THE LINE SEGMENT (LS 13)  APPROXIMATELY 10 MINUTES BEFORE RECEIVING THE CALL. FIELD PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED AND CONFIRMED THE RELEASE IMPACTING AREAS OF APPROXIMATELY 100 FEET BY 35 FEET ON BOTH SIDES OF RAILROAD TRACKS.     KINDER MORGAN RESPONSE AND REPAIR PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED AND FOUND A 16 INCH ANOMALY AT THE 4:30 OCLOCK POSITION ON THE PIPE. SUBSEQUENT METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS SHOWED THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY A HARD SPOT.    NOTE 1: RE: PART A 6 C.; AMOUNT RECOVERD AS OF 3/31/09; REPORT WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WHEN SIGNIFICANT UPDATES ARE AVAILABLE.    NOTE 2: RE: PART C 5 A.; PRESSUE ESTIMATED TO BE 300 PSIG REASONABLE ACCURATE GIVEN UNCERTAINTY OF TIME OF RELEASE.    NOTE 3: RE: PART F 2 E; AMOUNT OF PRODUCT ON GROUNDWATER UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME.    NOTE 4: RE: PART G 3; LEAK DURATION ESTIMATED FROM TIME OF NOTIFICATION TO TIME PIPE DAYLIGHTED AND CONFIRMED NOT LEAKING.    NOTE 5: RE: PART A 5; PUBLIC/COMMUNITY LOSSES ARE UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME. THE CEMEX BUILDING OWNER WILL BE REIMBURSED AT THE END OF THE REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES.

column245: DURING RECENT RAINFALL, AND THE TESTING OF THE FIRE WATER SYSTEM AT THE BILLINGS REFINERY, OIL SURFACED IN THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD AREA LOCATED WITHIN THE BILLINGS REFINERY. THE PIPELINE SYSTEMS WERE SHUTDOWN AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. THE AREA WAS HYDROVAC AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE THE RELIEF LINE WAS LEAKING. THE RELIEF LINE HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM SERVICE. AT THAT TIME, CPPL WAS UNABLE TO EXCAVATE THE AREA AND FURTHER TO DETERMINE THE EXACT CAUSE OF THE LEAK DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT CONGESTION OF OTHER PIPES, CEMENT PIERS, AND CONDUITS IN THE AREA. ALSO IMMEDIATLEY ABOVE THE RELIEF LINE THERE IS A 1'X3'X100' CEMENT SLAB. CPPL BELEIVES THAT THE RELEIF LINE LIKELY DEVELOPED AN EXTERNAL CORROSION LEAK BASED ON THE EXTREME CONGESTION IN THE AREA AND PRESENCE OF A CONTAINING CONCRETE SLAB, ELECTRICAL CONDUITS, AND PERMANEMT STRUCTURES BUILT ON AND NEAR THE PIPELINE. DUE TO THESE ACTIVITIES, THE PIPE COATING WAS LIKELY COMPROMISED ALLOWING THE CATHODIC PROTECTION TO LEAVE THE LINE.

column245: ON OCTOBER 10, 2007 DURING A ROUTINE STATION CHECK OF BUCKEYE¿S LINDEN STATION A LOCAL OPERATOR NOTICED A WET SPOT NEAR TANK 94.  THE OPERATOR IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED.    AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT PRODUCT WAS WEEPING FROM AROUND THE RING WALL OF THE TANK.  THE TANK WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE IMMEDIATELY.  BUCKEYE IS IN THE PROCESS OF CLEANING THE TANK SO THE INVESTIGATION CAN CONTINUE TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE.    ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS ON SITE DURING THE INITIAL PART OF THE INCIDENT.  ONCE THE TANK IS CLEANED BUCKEYE WILL CONTINUE THE INVESTIGATION TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT AND THE REQUIRED REPAIRS.     INVESTIGATION WAS COMPLETED. A WELD IN THE TANK SUMP WAS FOUND TO HAVE CORRODED. LABORATORY ANALYSIS DETERMINED THE CAUSE OF CORROSION TO BE MICROBIALLY INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC). THE WELD WAS REPAIRED AND THE FLOOR OF THE TANK WAS COATED WITH AN EPOXY COATING. ALL REMEDIATION AND REPAIRS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.

column245: ON OCTOBER 15, 2007 EXPLORER PIPELINE¿S HELICOPTER PATROL LOCATED A POTENTIAL RELEASE AT MILE POST 40.3 ON THE 28 INCH LINE SEGMENT BETWEEN THE HANKAMER, TEXAS PUMP STATION AND THE HOUSTON, TEXAS PUMP STATION.     EXCAVATION AND DIRECT EXAMINATION OF THE PIPELINE INDICATED A SMALL CRACK ASSOCIATED WITH THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE TO THE 28 INCH PIPELINE.     THE SOURCE OF THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE IS PRESENTLY NOT KNOWN. HISTORICAL ONE-CALL REPORTS INDICATE NO ONE-CALL ACTIVITY IN THE AREA THAT WOULD PROMPT THE TEMPORARY MARKING OF THE PIPELINE.      THE LEAK DURATION IS ALSO NOT KNOWN.  THE LINE SEGMENT IS INSPECTED WEEKLY BY HELICOPTER PATROLS AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION OF A LEAK OR EXCAVATION ACTIVITY DURING THE OCTOBER 9, 2007 OR EARLIER PATROLS.       ALL THE PETROLEUM IMPACTED SOIL HAS BEEN EXCAVATED AND WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED.

column245: DRAIN VALVE FOUND IN OPEN POSITION. TEPPCO DOES NOT KNOW WHY THE VALVE WAS FOUND IN THE OPEN POSITION, VALVE WAS DISPOSED OF BEFORE IT COULD BE SENT FOR ANALYSIS.       UPDATE:    ON 11-18-2007 OUR MAINTENANCE CREW HAD JUST FINISHED REPLACING A SEAL ON THE 20” PUMP AT EGYPT STATION. THE WORK WAS COMPLETED, THE PUMP HAD BEEN PRESSURED UP AND PIPELINE CONTROL HAD JUST ISSUED A START TO THE UNIT WHEN THE TECHNICIANS HEARD A LOUD NOISE AND HAD TO EVACUATE THE FACILITY DUE TO A PROPANE RELEASE.  UPON DEPRESSURIZING THE LINE SECTION BETWEEN THE PROPERTY BLOCKS, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE DISCHARGE DRAIN VALVE WAS PARTIAL OPEN.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND HELD FOR TESTING.  AFTER TWO YEARS, THE VALVE WAS ACCIDENTLY DISPOSED OF BY AN OPERATOR CLEANING UP THE WAREHOUSE. OUR TECHNICIANS LOOKED AT THE VALVE AND OPERATED IT AFTER IT WAS REMOVED AND COULDN’T FIND ANY DEFICIENCIES WITH IT.     THE ONLY ASSUMPTION IS THAT AN ICE BALL OR OTHER FOREIGN OBJECT WAS TRAPPED IN THE VALVE AND ONCE THE LINE PRESSURE CAME UP IT RELEASED CAUSING THE INCIDENT.

column145: EXCAVATION TO VERIFY DENT INDICATION FROM INTERNAL
column245: DURING THE EXCAVATION OF A DENT NDICATION FROM OUR PIPELINE INTERNAL TOOL RUN, A WEEPING CRACK WAS DISCOVERED.  THIS INCIDENT WAS CAUSED BY THIRD PARTY DAMAGE TO OUR PIPELINE.  THIS OCCURRED IN A SANDY SOIL AREA & NO FREE STANDING LIQUID WAS DISCOVERED.  GASOLINE WAS IN THE LINE AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED.  A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE DAMAGED AREA.  THE APPROXIMATE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT RELEASED IS STILL BEING DETERMINED.  WE HAVE DETERMINED FROM EXCAVATING DOWN 8' THE AMOUNT TO HAVE EXCEEDED SEVEN GALLONS.  WOLVERINE EMPLOYEES PERFORMED THE EXCAVATION AND REPAIR.  WOLVERINE FOLLOWED UP WITH HAND ARGURED SOIL SAMPLES FROM THE FLOOR AND SIDE WALLS OF THE EXCAVATION AND WE ARE AWAITING THE LAB RESULTS.  WE INTEND TO GO BACK AND TAKE SOIL BORING TO DETERMINE THE DEPTH AND EXTENT OF CONTAMINATION.

column245: ON MONDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 2007 AT 1545 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS LIMA STATION RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE HANCOCK COUNTY SHERIFF DEPARTMENT CONCERNING A FIRE AT BUCKEYE¿S FINDLAY JUNCTION.  THE LIMA OPERATOR CONTACTED THE BREINIGSVILLE CONTROL CENTER AND HAD ALL PIPELINES RUNNING INTO AND OUT OF THE JUNCTION SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY.  BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED AND THE LIMA MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO THE JUNCTION.    ON ARRIVING AT THE JUNCTION IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE FIRE HAD SELF-EXTINGUISHED; HOWEVER, THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT WHICH RESPONDED LAID A FOAM BLANKET OVER THE AREA OF THE SMOKING VALVE PIT FOR SAFETY.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE FIRE HAD OCCURRED ON A 3/8¿ SENSE LINE FOR A PRESSURE TRANSMITTER RUNNING FROM A VALVE PIT.  THE SENSE LINE HAD A PIN-HOLE IN THE TUBING.    THE CAUSE OF THE PIN-HOLE AND FIRE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  THE SENSE LINE TUBING HAS BEEN SENT TO A THIRD PARTY TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE PIN-HOLE AND FIRE.  THE CAUSE OF THIS INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE LIGHTNING.

column245: ON NOVEMBER 1. 2007 A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF EQUIPMENT MALFUNCTION AT KIANTONE PIPELINE'S (KPL'S) BOOSTER STATION LOCATED ON BROADWAY ROAD, IN THE TOWN OF PERSIA, NEW YORK. KPL WAS OPERATING AT A LOWER THAN AVERAGE FLOW RATE DUE TO AN ONGOING REFINERY SHUTDOWN. DURING THIS LOW FLOW, PRESSURE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE BOOSTER STATION MAINLINE PUMPS BECAME ELEVATED. THE SAFETY RELIEF VALVE ON THE PUMPS LIFTED AND RELIEVED PRESSURE TO THE SUMP. THE FLOW ALARM ON THE RELIEF LINE FAILED AND DID NOT SIGNAL THE OPERATOR. A KPL OPERATOR IDENTIFIED THE SUMP AS ACTIVE ON THE SCADA SYSTEM (BUT WITH NO ALARMS) AND CONTACTED KPL MANAGEMENT. KPL PRESONNEL WERE ENROUTE TO INVESTIGATE THE RUNNING SUMP WHEN KPL RECEIVED A CALL FROM CATTARAUGUS COUNTY EMERGENCY SERVICES ABOUT A SPILL AT THE BOOSTER STATION. KPL OPERATORS IMMEDIATELY ROUTED THE PIPELINE PAST THE BOOSTER STATION, LOCKED IN ALL STATION COMPONENTS AND SHUTDOWN ALL FLOW AT THE STATION. PRODUCT HAD ALREADY BACKFLOWED OVER THE PUMP BASES AND OVERFLOWED THE SUMP. EMERGENCY CLEANUP SERVICES WERE IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED AND CLEANUP ENSUED. THE RELIEF VALVE FLOW ALARM WAS REPLACED AND THE HIGH HIGH LEVEL SUMP ALARM WAS RESET AND TESTED.

column245: AFTER SMELLING GASOLINE, SECURITY PERSONNEL AT THE LARAMIE RIVER POWER STATION CALLED THE WYOMING ONE CALL WHO CONTACTED PLAINS. AN INVESTIGATION BY A PLAINS PIPELINE OPERATOR REVEALED A VALVE STEM PACKING FAILURE ON THE SOUTH LARAMIE BLOCK VALVE.    REFERENCE PART A, PARAGRAPH 5. LOSSES (ESTIMATED). THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT  CONCLUDED THAT COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,OOO.  AFTER FURTHER EVALUATION AND TESTING, IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT GASOLINE PENETRATED INTO SHALLOW GROUND WATER WHICH HAS SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED REMEDIATION COST ESTIMATES.

column245: PLAINS EMPLOYEES AND CONTRACTOR WERE IN PROCESS OF REMOVING SOIL TO PREPARE A BELL HOLE FOR THE INSPECTION OF THE PIELINE PRIOR TO THE INSTALLATION OF TEST LEADS FOR CATHODIC PROTECTION.  DURING THE PROCESS THE TRACKHOE OPERATOR (CONTRACTOR)STRUCK AN UNDOCUMENTED TWO INCH VALVE IN THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION ABOVE THE PIPELINE AND CRACKED THE VALVE FITTING CONNECTING THE VALVE TO THE PIPELINE RESULTING IN THE IMMEDIATE RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL.  ALTHOUGH O & M PROCEDURES WERE FOLLOWED TO PROPERLY IDENTIFY AND SAFELY EXCAVATE THE 10" PIPELINE, THIS INCIDENT WAS THE DIRECT RESULT OF STRIKING AN UNDOCUMENTED APPURTENANCE ON THE PIPELINE.

column245: THE LEAK LOCATION OCCURRED AT THE CPL KETTLEMAN FACILITY INSIDE THE TANK BERM ON THE OVERPRESSURE PROTECTION PIPING FROM THE BELRIDGE TO KETTLEMAN PIPELINE. INTERNAL CORROSION CAUSED THE LEAK. LAB RESULTS SHOWED THAT MICROBACTERIA AND WATER ACCELERATED THE INTERNAL CORROSION. CORRECTIVE MEASURES IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE REROUTING THE RELIEF LINE PIPING THAT HAS AN ADEQUATE SLOPE TO PREVENT LOW SPOTS FOR WATER ACCUMULATION. THE ORIGINAL RELIEF PIPING WILL BE TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND REMOVED.

UPON EXCAVATION OF THE SITE, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT 2 PINHOLE LEAKS HAD OCCURRED ON THE LONG SEAM OF LINE 3 AT MP 912.  THE LEAK WAS ISOLATED AND A TIGHT FITTING SLEEVE WAS PUT ON AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR UNTIL PLANS COULD BE MADE TO CUT THE SECTION OUT FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION. THE PIPE SECTION WAS SUBSEQUENTLY CUT OUT ON NOV 28 AND SENT FOR ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE CAUSE.

column245: IN RESPONSE TO A PETROLEUM SHEEN IDENTIFIED ON THE CROSSWICKS CREEK IN THE VICINITY OF THE 16-INCH HARBOR PIPELINE, A NEARBY COLONIAL PIPELINE AND NEARBY BURIED PETROLEUM STORAGE TANKS OWNED BY THE NEW JERSEY TURNPIKE COMMISSION, INVESTIGATION INTO THE SOURCE OF THE SHEEN HAS BEEN ON-GOING BY ALL THREE ENTITIES.  ON NOVEMBER 27, 2007 PIPELINE CREWS STRIPPING OUT THE HARBOR PIPELINE DISCOVERED PRODUCT AND SOFTENED PIPELINE COATING ON THE 16-INCH PIPELINE.  THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND MLV¿S CLOSED.  A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE LEAK AREA AND THE LINE RESTARTED WITHIN 5 HOURS OF DISCOVERY.      FINAL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION HAS NOT STARTED BUT THE COST OF OPERATOR LOSSES INCLUDES $75,000 FOR FUTURE MONEY THAT IS ESTIMATED TO COVER REMAINING ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION TO CLOSURE COSTS.    THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS CUTOUT AND SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL EVALUATION OF THE FAILURE.  THEIR FINDINGS CONCLUDE ¿THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY SEAM ANOMALIES IN THE FORM OF SMALL HOOK CRACKS IN CONJUNCTION WITH A LACK OF FUSION IN A LOCALIZED AREA ADJACENT TO GIRTH WELD NUMBER 46850.  THIS INSTANCE IS MOST LIKELY A UNIQUE AND ISOLATED CONDITION."  EXAMINATION REVEALED THE LEAKING CRACK TO BE ABOUT 1-INCH LONG ON THE PIPE ID AND 0.2-INCHES LONG ON THE PIPE OD WITH "NO EVIDENCE OF CRACK GROWTH DUE TO FATIGUE.¿  THE KIEFNER REPORT ALSO REVIEWED THE FOUR HISTORICAL SERVICE FAILURES THAT OCCURRED ON THE HARBOR PIPELINE OVER ITS LIFE AND NONE OF THEM WERE ASSOCIATED WITH FLAWS IN THE LONGITUDINAL SEAM.

column245: COMPANY PERSONNEL WORKING NEAR THE LINE OBSERVED DEAD VEGETATION AND SMELLED AN ODOR.  THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND PURGED OF PRODUCT.  THE LEAK SITE WAS THEN EXCAVATED, AND THE LEAK WAS FOUND TO BE AT A WELDED REPAIR SLEEVE INSTALLED IN 1980.  THE SLEEVE WAS CUT OUT WITH 15' OF PIPE, AND 8 5/8" OD, 0.156 WALL, X-46 PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH PRETESTED 8 5/8" OD, 0.188" WALL, X-42 PIPE.  THE LINE WAS THEN PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.    THE ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND SOIL REMEDIATION ARE ONGOING AT THE TIME OF THIS 6-26-08 SUPPLEMENTAL FILING.     UPDATED:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column126: REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL
column245: ON NOVEMBER 28, 2007, ENBRIDGE WAS CONDUCTING MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES TO REPLACE A PIPE SECTION ON THE COMPANY'S LINE 3 PIPELINE (APPROXIMATE MILEPOST 912) DOWNSTREAM OF COUINTY ROAD 3 NEAR CLEARBROOK IN CLEARWATER COUNTY, MINNESOTA.  AT APPROXIMATELY 14:45, WHILE COMPLETING REPAIR OPERATIONS, A RELEASE OCCURRED AND THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL IGNITED.  ENBRIDGE INITIATED AND MOBILIZED A FULL INCIDENT RESPONSE TEAM INCLUDING SUPERIOR AND CHICAGO REGIONAL PERSONNEL AS WELL AS CORPORATE INCIDENT COMMAND SYSTEM (ICS) SUPPORT PERSONNEL, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE COMPANY'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN.  LOCAL LAW ENFORECEMENT, FIRE AND RESCUE PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO THE INCIDENT NOTIFICATION PROCEDURES.  THE FIRE ENGULFED THE IMMEDIATE AREA AND BURNED INTENSELY FOR APPROXIMATELY 12 HOURS BEFORE IF COULD BE EXTINGUISHED BY EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL, AT WHICH TIME TWO ENBRIDGE EMPLOYEE FATALATIES WERE CONFIRMED.  REPRESENTATIVES FROM PHMSA CENTRAL REGION AND MN STATE FIRE MARSHAL - PIPELINE SAFETY TEAM WERE ON SITE AND PARTICIPATED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A REMOVAL AND PRESERVATION PLAN FOR THE FAILED PIPE SECTION.  ADDITIONALLY, BOTH AGENCIES CONDUCTED INCIDENT INVESTIGATION PROCEDURES AND ACKNOWLEDGED THE PROPOSED RETURN-TO-SERVICE PLAN.  FORMAL CORRESPONDENCE COMMUNICATING THE RETURN-TO-SERVICE PLAB WAS SYBNUTTED TO PHMSA AND MN STATE FIRE MARSHAL - PIPELINE SAFETY TEAM IN LETTER DATED 12/2/07.  REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON 12/3/07 AND THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PLAN ON 12/3/07.  THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS CURRENTLY UNDERWAY AND A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE FILED UPON COMPLETION.  WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS LEAKED DUE TO INADEQUATE RESTRAINT  THE SEPARATION OF THE NEWLY INSTALLED WELD+ENDS COUPLING OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF INADEQUATE RESTRAINT THAT ALLOWED THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS TO SLIP SUFFICIENTLY RESULTING IN THE RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL WHEN FLOW IN LINE 3 WAS BEING RESTARTED.  THE SLIPPAGE OF THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS WAS THE RESULT OF SEVERAL SPECIFIC DEFICIENCIES WITH THE INSTALLATION.  THESE DEFICIENCIES HAD A DIRECT BEARING ON THE AVAILABLE RESTRAINT, SUPPORT OR ANCHORING, FOR THE REPLACEMENT PIPE AND THE WELD+ENDS COUPLINGS AND INCLUDED:  - LENGTH OF PIPE EXPOSED AND BEND IN THE EXPOSED PIPE  - MODIFICATIONS TO WELD+END COUPLINGS  - INADEQUATE ASSESSMENT OF THE ANCHORAGE OR SUPPORT TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE PRESSURE ON RESTART OF LINE 3

column245: OUT OF SERVICE PIPELINE WAS PURGED OF OIL WITH NITROGEN. OIL WAS PUSHED INTO 14-16 STATION TANK AND HAULED OFF BY TRUCK.  PURGING WAS DONE FROM DECEMBER 5, 2007, TO DECEMBER 11, 2007.  OIL LEAKED FROM 4 SEPARATE PINHOLES DURING THIS TIME. LEAK SITE WERE WITHIN ½ TO ¾ MILE FROM THE STATION.  OIL WAS UNDER SNOW UNTIL WARMER WEATHER MELTED IT AND EXPOSED OIL.  OIL WAS MIXED WITH SNOW AND TOO THICK TO PICK UP WITH VAC TRUCK SO WAS BURNED UNDER PERMIT.  LEAK SITES WERE EXPOSED AND CLAMPED, AND REST OF PURGED LINE WAS SLOWN TO CHECK FOR MORE LEAKS.  NONE WERE SEEN.  THIS SECTION IS PURGED WITH NO PRESSURE ON IT.  MAXIMUM PRESSURE DURING PURGE AT 14-16 WAS 120 POUNDS AND MAXIMUM A ROCKPILE, WHERE NITROGEN WAS INJECTED, WAS 340 POUNDS.

column245: DUE TO POWER OUTAGE AT THE BORGER CRUDE TERMINAL, A POWER OUTAGE PROCEDURE WAS INITIATED IN ORDER TO CONTINUE THE CRUDE OIL TO THE REFINERY. IN THE PROCESS OF BYPASSING THE REFINERY PUMPS, FLOW WAS TEMPORY INTERUPTED. OPERATOR NOTICED THE TEMPORY INTERRUPTION IN FLOW AND IMMEDIATELY INITIATED SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES. UPON INITIATION OF REFINERY CRUDE UNIT SHUTDOWN PROCEDURE, THIS CREATED A PRESSURE SCENARIO THAT ACTIVATED MULTIPLE THERMAL RELEIF DEVICES AND OVERWHELMED THE SUMP CONTAINMENT SYSTEM. PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN MODIFIED TO CORRECT THIS AND KEEP THIS FROM HAPPENING AGAIN.

column245: SMALL BUBBLES NEAR A PIPELINE MARKER WERE REPORTED BY A LOCAL FISHERMAN. PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS SHUT DOWN AS SOON AS IT COULD BE SAFELY COORDINATED UPON VERIFICATION OF THE LEAK.  EMPCO DETERMINED THE BUBBLES WERE COMING FROM INSIDE A CASED CROSSING OF TX. HWY 87.  DECISION WAS MADE TO REPLACE THE CROSSING.  OLD PIPE WAS PULLED OUT OF THE CASING FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS 5 DAYS WITH A TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME WAS LESS THAN 1 GALLON. THERE WAS NO SHEEN OR EMULSION VISIBLE ON THE WATER AT ANY TIME DURING THIS INCIDENT.   METALLURIGCAL TESTING DETERMINED THE LEAK WAS DUE TO A LAMINATION IN THE 4" PIPE.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: ON 12/30/07, COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL PERSONNEL (OC) OBSERVED GRADUALLY DECLINING PRESSURES ON A SEGMENT OF PIPE THAT WAS SHUT IN.  OC CALLED FIELD OPERATIONS PERSONNEL TO CHECK FOR A POTENTIAL LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED IN A REMOTE AREA AT ABOUT 21:15 ON 12/30/07 BY WALKING THE ROW WITH AN LEL MONITOR.  THERE WAS NO VISIBLE VAPOR CLOUD AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. PRODUCT WAS FLARED AND VENTED UNTIL THE LEAK AREA WAS MADE SAFE.  THE FAILURE WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO STORK METTALLURGICAL CONSULTANTS, INC WHO DETERMINED THAT THE FAILURE WAS CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACKING CAUSED BY A BENDING LOAD ON THE EXTRADOS OF A SHALLOW BEND IN THE PIPE.  ABOUT 100 BBLS OF PRODUCT WAS ESTIMATED RELEASED AT THE LEAK SITE, AND A TOTAL OF ABOUT 1900 BBLS WAS ESTIMATED LOST, INCLUDING CONTROLLED FLARING AND VENTING AT THE BLOCK VALVES.  THE VALUE OF PRODUCT LOST WAS FOR THE 1900 BBL VOLUME.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: LINE WA FROM ODESSA, TX TO BORGER, TX HAD A FAILURE AT MILE POST 83.4 BETWEEN WEEMS TO SLAUGHTER. THE FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE LONGTIUDINAL SEAM OF A SEGMENT OF PIPE MANUFACTURED BY A.O. SMITH CORPERATION USING THE ELECTRIC FLASH-WELD (EFW) PROCESS. THE FAILURE ORIGINATED AT AN AREA OF SEAM MISALIGNMENT. A NOTCH-LIKE GEOMETRY WAS FORMED BETWEEN THE PIPE WALL AND THE UNTRIMMED SEAM FLASH ON THE ID PIPE SURFACE. THE STRESS CONCENTRATION AT THE TIP OF THE NOTCH ALLOWED FOR THE INITIATION OF AN ID-SURFACE BREAKING CRACK. PIPE SEGMENT HAS BEEN SENT IN TO BE ANALYZED. A UT CRACK TOOL INSPECTION HAS BEEN COMPLETED FOR THE ENTIRE LINE.  UPDATED THIS REPORT TO REFLECT TOTAL COST FOR CLEAN UP AND DISPOSAL AS OF MARCH 12, 2009. THIS REPORT WILL REMAIN OPEN UNTIL ALL REMEDIATION COST HAVE BEEN ACCOUNTED FOR. THE REMEDIATION PROGRAM IS SCHEDULED FOR 2 YEARS. UPDATED COST FOR REMEDATION AND AMOUNT OF SOIL THAT HAS BEEN TREATED TO DATE. QUARTLEY GROUNDWATER MONITORING SINCE RELEASE INDICATES NO IMPACT TO GROUND WATER. AFTER CONSULTING WITH THE SW REGION OFFICE CPPL WILL CLOSE OUT THIS REPORT NO ADDITIONAL PRODUCT AMOUNTS WILL BE RECOVERED FROM SITE.

column245: ON JAN. 11, 2008 OUR 6" LINE TO ALEXANDER WAS HIT BY NORTHWINDS TRENCHER DOING WORK FOR US. CALL CAME IN TO DON CLARK AT APPROXIMATELY 9 AM AND THE BICENTENNIAL PUMPS WERE IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN. GAUGERS WERE CALLED TO SHUT DOWN ALL FIELD LEASES. LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND BLOCK VALVES CLOSED AT BOWLINE AND NANCE BY 9:30AM.VACUUM TRUCKS WERE ON SCENE BY 11AM AND SUCKED UP APPROXIMATELY 260 BARRELS OF OIL CONTAINED WITHIN ROW. LINE WAS REPAIRED AND BACK IN SERVICE BY 4:30 PM. THE FOLLOWING WEEK CONTAMINATED DIRT WAS HAULED TO INDIAN HILLS LAND FARM IN WILLISTON, ND. FOREST SERVICE WAS NOTIFIED OF SPILL AND SPILL WAS CLEANED UP TO THEIR SPECIFICATIONS. SURVEY STAKES THE OPERATOR WAS FOLLOWING HAD APPARENTLY BEEN MOVED OVER ACTIVE PIPELINE AFTER ROW WAS GRADED. PERSONNEL ARE RELOCATING LINE EACH DAY BEFORE TRENCHER GOES THROUGH.

column245: KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES, INC. SUBMITTED ITS MECHANICAL AND METALLURGICAL TESTING AND FAILURE ANALYSIS OF THE JANUARY 5, 2008 GIRTH WELD FAILURE. THE ANALYSIS CONCLUDES THAT THE FAILURE WAS THE RESULT OF TENSILE BENDING STRESSES ACTING ON THE FILLET WELD OF A BELL AND SPIGOT JOINT. THE BENDING LOAD WAS MOST LIKELY CAUSED BY SETTLEMENT OF AN ADJACENT SECTION OF PIPE WHICH HAD BEEN PREVIOUSLY EXCAVATED AND REPAIRED WITH A 32 FOOT SLEEVE IN JULY 2007.

column245: CONTROL CENTER CPM ALARMED, CONTROLLER TOOK IMMEDIATED ACTION TO SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE.  CRUDE OIL SMELL AND VISIBLE CRUDE OIL IN STORM DRAIN DITCH LINE REPORTED BY LOCAL RESIDENTS AND POLICE / FIRE DEPT.  PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND PERSONNEL DISPATCHED TO LOCATION TO VERIFY.  DUE TO STRONG ODOR  OF CRUDE OIL, LOCAL AUTHORITIES EVACUATED 77 HOMES/TRAILERS.  CRUDE OIL VISIBLE IN STATION PROPERTY AND ADJACENT STORM DRAIN DITCH LINE.  CREWS WORKED THROUGH THE NIGHT AND INTO DAYLIGHT HOURS.  MAINLINE CHECK VALVE #2'S GASKET WAS REPLACED WITH A SPIRAL WOUND DESIGN GASKET AND FLANGE FACES RESURFACED.  NOTE: SHELL GLOBAL SOLUTIONS INVESTIGATED AND DETERMINED THE FLANGE GASKET FAILED DUE TO THE FOLLOWING;  THE GASKET BEGAN TO CREEP AT THE BOTTOM POSITION OF THE FLANGE.  THE GASKET CREEP OCCURRED BECAUSE THE GASKET WAS NOT AS CONSTRAINED IN THIS AREA RELATIVE TO OTHER POSITIONS ON THE FLANGE FACE.  THIS THEN ALLOWED THE CRUDE OIL TO LUBRICATE THE GASKET, THUS REDUCING THE FRICTION FORCES ON THE FLANGED FACES.  NORMAL LINE PRESSUREE EVENTUALLY OVERCAME THE ABILITY OF THE GASKET TO SEAL.  UNDER "A. TYPE OF FAILURE", "POOR WORKMANSHIP" WAS SELECTED AS THE BEST ANSWER SINCE THERE WAS SOME EVIDENCE THAT THE GASKET WAS NOT EVENLY COMPRESSED AROUND THE FLANGE FACE.  THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE TO SUGGEST THAT THERE WAS A "MATERIAL DEFECT" IN THE REMAINING GASKET MATERIAL.

column245: AN INTERNAL TAP ROOTTM INCIDENT INVESTIGATION WAS CONDUCTED BY KPL ENVIRONMENTAL, CORROSION CONTROL AND OPERATIONS PERSONNEL ON FEBRUARY 20, 2008.  PRIOR TO THE INVESTIGATION, THE SECTION OF PIPELINE 409 WHERE THE FAILURE OCCURRED WAS SENT TO ENHANCECO IN MISSOURI CITY, TEXAS, FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS AND CORROSION EVALUATION.  IN CONSIDERATION OF ENHANCECO’S CORROSION ANALYSIS REPORT, THE INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT TO BE INACTIVE EXTERNAL CORROSION WITH METAL LOSS AND ACTIVE INTERNAL CORROSION WITH METAL LOSS. .  ACTION ITEMS WERE ASSIGNED ACCORDINGLY.  PIPELINE WAS FURTHER EVALUATED AND DETERMINED TO BE LEFT IN INACTIVE STATUS.

column245: DEAD VEGETATION IN A REMOTE AREA WAS DISCOVERED AND CALLED INTO PIPELINE CONTROL.  THE LEAK WAS VERIFIED TO BE A PINHOLE LEAK IN A GIRTH WELD.    PRODUCT WAS PURGED OUT OF THE AFFECTED SEGMENT, AND THE LEAK HAS BEEN CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH 6.625" DIAMETER, 0.188" WALL X52 PIPE.    THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN IN THIS REPORT INCLUDES A SMALL CONTROLLED MAINTENANCE RELEASE ON 1/29/08 ASSOCIATED WITH THE LEAK (NRC 860954) AND CONTROLLED PRODUCT VENTING ALONG THE NITROGEN ASSOCIATED WITH THE LEAK ON 2/1/08 (NRC 861190) WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON ITEM 6C UNDER PART A IS THE PRODUCT VOLUME ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED AT THE LEAK SITE.    THE ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND SOIL REMEDIATION ARE ONGOING.    UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column245: THE 5N LINE WAS DELIVERING TRANSMIX INTO PAULSBORO TERMINAL TANK 5 (FILTERS WERE BEING BYPASSED THROUGH MOV 14 WHICH IS NORMAL PROCEDURE FOR TRANSMIX). AT APPROXIMATELY 1215, WHEN THE AVIATION JET FUEL ARRIVED AT PAULSBORO, THE LOCAL OPERATOR TRIED TO OPEN MOV 3 VIA THE LOCAL SCADA TO ALLOW THE JET TO PASS THROUGH THE FILTERS (WHEN MOV 3 OPENS, MOV 14 AUTOMATICALLY CLOSES) WITHOUT HAVING ALL REQUIRED VALVES IN PROPER POSITON. THEREFORE, MOV 3 WOULD NOT OPEN ON THE OPERATOR¿S COMMAND FROM THE HMI SCREEN IN THE CONTROL ROOM. NOT RELIZING THE INCORRECT SCADA OPERATION, THE OPERATOR WENT OUT TO MOV 3, PUT THE VALVE IN ¿LOCAL¿ CONTROL AND THEN OPENED THE VALVE. THE MOTOR OPERATED TANK VALVE DOWNSTREAM OF MOV 3 WAS NOT OPEN ¿ THEREFORE THERE WAS NOT AN OPEN PATH FOR THE PRODUCT FLOW RESULTING IN A PRESSURE SURGE ON THE MANIFOLD. THE CLAY FILTER VESSEL IS RATED FOR A MAX WORKING PRESSURE OF 150 PSI; THE PRESSURE SURGE REACHED APPROXIMATELY 388 PSI. PRODUCT LEAKED FROM THE BOLTED LID CONNECTION ON THE VESSEL INTO THE CONTAINMENT AREA AROUND THE VESSEL AND INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR. THE OPERATOR HIT THE EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN BUTTON TO SHUT DOWN THE OPERATION. APPROXIMATELY 500 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED FROM THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR AND SOIL AND STONE IN THE AREA. THE OPERATOR'S OQ QUALIFICATION FOR THIS COVERED TASK WERE SUSPENDED, THE OPERATOR RETRAINED AND TESTED.  THE OPERATORS OQ QUALIFICATION FOR THE TASK WERE THEN REINSTATED AFTER THE OPERATOR PASSED THE OQ TEST FOR THE INVOLVED COVERED TASK.   AN OSRO WAS CALLED IN AND APPROXIMATELY 11-55 GALLON DRUMS OF ABSORBENT PADS, OIL DRY, SOIL AND STONES WERE COLLECTED AND HAULED OFF-SITE FOR DISPOSAL.

column238: DISCHARGE WAS DUE TO  LEAK IN MAIN FLUID LINE FROM PLATFORM TO BEACH. LEAK WAS DUE TO GENERAL CORROSION.
column245: TEKOIL OPERATORS WAS ON THEIR WAY TO THE PLATFORMS FOR THE DAY. A SLIGHT SHEEN WAS NOTICED AND THEY WENT TO INVESTIGATE WHAT WAS CAUSING IT. THEY NOTICED OIL BUBBLES COMING UP FROM THE BOTTOM. A BARGE WAS USED TO LOCATE THE LINE TO IDENTIFY. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THELEAK WAS COMING FROM THE MAIN FLUID LINE. THE FIELD WAS SHUT IN AND THE LINE ISOLATED. DIVING CREWS WERE CALLED OUT TO FIX AND A CLEAN UP CREW WAS CALLED TO CLEAN UP. DISCHARGE WAS CLEANED AND LINE WAS FIXED, TESTED, AND PUT BACK IN SERVICE.
