column245: YARDS OF SOIL DISPOSED, NOT THE 19052 CUBIC YARDS ORIGINALLY REPORTED. 19052 CUBIC FEET OF SOIL WAS DISPOSED = 705.6 CUBIC YARDS.                              ON FEBRUARY 11, 2008, AT 9:25 AM EST, A CALL WAS RECEIVED AT THE MARATHON PIPE LINE LLC (MPL) FINDLAY OPERATIONS CENTER FROM A CALLER IN RURAL CLARK COUNTY KENTUCKY STATING THAT CRUDE OIL WAS EVIDENT IN AN AREA NEAR THE MPL OWENSBORO TO CATLETTSBURG (OWC) PIPELINE SYSTEM.  THE SYSTEM WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND FIELD TECHNICIANS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  AN INCIDENT COMMAND STRUCTURE WAS PUT INTO PLACE TO CONTAIN AND COLLECT THE RELEASED OIL.    A SIMULTANEOUS EFFORT WAS INITIATED TO LOCATE THE LEAK SOURCE AND REPAIR THE PIPE.  THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A SLEEVE, WHICH RECORDS INDICATE WAS INSTALLED IN 1986 AND IT IS IN AN HCA.  THE HIGH PRESSURE AT THE POINT OF THE LEAK, ESTABLISHED OVER THE LAST 60 DAYS, IS 643 PSI.  ON FEBRUARY 11, 2008, THE PRESSURE AT THE LEAK SITE WAS 479 PSI.  EARLY ON FEBRUARY 13, 2008, THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS EXCAVATED BY MPL AND INSPECTED BY MPL AND KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES.  THE INITIAL ASSESSMENT INDICATED A FILLET WELD CRACK ON A CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELD OF THE FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE.   POST INCIDENT ANALYSIS INDICATED THAT SEVERAL FACTORS CONTRIBUTED TO THE RELEASE:  1. POOR CONSTRUCTION PRACTICES WHEN THE PIPE WAS INSTALLED ALLOWED MANY BOTTOM-SIDE DENTS TO FORM ON THE LINE WHEN IT WAS PLACED INTO SERVICE;  2. STRESS RISERS FROM THE DENT ALONG WITH THE DISBONDED COATING (WHICH SHIELDED CP) AND SOIL CONDITIONS ALLOWED FOR NEAR NEUTRAL PH STRESS CORROSION CRACKING TO START IN THE DENT.  3. THE UPSTREAM SEAL WELD APPLIED IN 1986 WAS POORLY DEPOSITED AT THE 6 O’CLOCK POSITION DUE TO 1) POOR SLEEVE FIT AND 2) LACK OF SUFFICIENT CLEARANCE UNDER THE PIPE FOR REPAIR WELDING.  THIS LED TO WATER INFILTRATION UNDER THE SLEEVE, WHICH ALLOWED A CORROSION CELL TO FORM OVER TIME.  THE EXISTING SLEEVE SHIELDED THIS AREA FROM CP.  4. THE LACK OF STEEL PUTTY IN THE DENT ALLOWED A SLIGHT MOVEMENT IN THE DENT, WHICH ALLOWED FLEXURE FATIGUE.  5. THE COATING REPAIR ON THE SLEEVE FAILED TO KEEP GROUND WATER FROM INFILTRATING INTO THE FAILED UPSTREAM SEAL WELD.    ALL THESE FACTORS TOGETHER RESULTED IN A 5 INCH LONG CRACK FORMING IN THE DENT UNDER THE SLEEVE.  THE SPILL VOLUME WAS ESTIMATED TO BE 63 BBLS.  THE RATE AND VOLUME OF THE LEAK WAS BELOW FOC CPM DETECTION THRESHOLDS. PI REPRESENTATIVES BELIEVE THAT ALTHOUGH THE SLEEVE WAS NOT LIQUID TIGHT, THE SLEEVE WAS SUCCESSFUL IN MAINTAINING THE STRENGTH OF THE PIPING AND PREVENTED A MAJOR RELEASE.  FOR PIPELINE SYSTEMS OPERATED BY MPL, THE RISK OF THE A1 SLEEVE FAILURE IS BELIEVED TO BE UNIQUE TO THE OWC SYSTEM DUE TO 1) THE OWC SYSTEM’S UNIQUELY HIGH DIAMETER/THICKNESS RATIO, AND 2) THE SYSTEM'S SPECIFIC SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SCC.  CAUSAL FACTOR: UPSTREAM SEAL WELD AT BOTTOM OF PIPE WAS POORLY DEPOSITED. ROOT CAUSE: STANDARD FOR APPLICATION OF SLEEVE NOT STRICT ENOUGH. THE SLEEVE PROCEDURE USED ON THIS REPAIR IN 1986 IS NO LONGER USED.    THE LEAKING PIPE AND SLEEVE WERE ULTIMATELY REPLACED WITH APPROXIMATELY 50 FEET OF PRE-TESTED PIPE.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL AND WATER WERE DISPOSED.  MARATHON DEVELOPED A SAMPLING PLAN WITH THE REMEDIATION PLAN ENCOMPASSING 10 YEARS OF MONITORING.    TONNAGE OF EARTH WAS 952.62 TONS AND CALCULATIONS WERE BASED ON WET EXCAVATED EARTH EQUALING 100LBS/CUBIC FT.      THIS REPORT IS BEING CLOSED WITH ESTIMATED FUTURE COSTS BECAUSE THE REMEDIATION PLAN CALLS FOR 10 YEARS OF MONITORING.  ESTIMATE IS BASED ON CURRENT KNOWLEDGE AND AN APPROVED REMEDIATION PLAN.    4/23/2010 - UPDATED AFTER DISCUSSION WHILE FINALIZING THE CLOSURE REPORT FOR KDEP. VOLUME RELEASED AND RECOVERED WAS CHANGED FROM 63 TO 70 BBLS. FINAL CALCULATED VOLUME WAS DETERMINED TO BE 69.7 BBLS, WHICH WAS ROUNDED UP TO 70 DUE TO CONSTRAINSTS ON THIS FORM. ALSO DURING THIS REVIEW, THE CALCULATION FOR THE CUBIC YARDS OF SOIL DISPOSED WAS REVISITED, AND AN ERROR IN THE CALCULATION WAS IDENTIFIED. THE STE P THAT CONVERTED FROM CUBIC FEET TO CUBIC YARDS WAS MISSING. THE REVISED CALCULATION, WHICH IS STILL BASED ON 952.62 TONS OF SOIL DISPOSED EQUALED 705.6 CUBIC

column245: AT 2034 HOURS ON FEBRUARY 25, 2008, BUCKEYE PARTNER¿S MANTUA STATION RECEIVED A CALL FROM A PROPERTY OWNER STATING THAT THEY SMELLED GASOLINE.  THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE CONTACTED THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER TO HAVE THE PIPELINE SHUTDOWN IMMEDIATELY AND ALSO CONTACTED HIS SUPERVISOR.  BUCKEYE¿S SUPERVISOR IMPLEMENTS BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND A CREW IS SENT TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.    AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IS HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT WATER COLLECTED IN A 2" DRAIN VALVE ALLOWING THE PLUG IN THE END OF THE VALVE TO BE PUSHED APART FROM THE VALVE BODY.  A NEW DRAIN VALVE IS INSTALLED AND THE PIPELINE IS READY TO RE-START AT 0310 HOURS ON FEBRUARY 26, 2008.    THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT WAS ON SITE AND ALL CLEANUP ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN COMPLETED.

column245: ON FEBRUARY 27, 2008, THE LOCAL ENBRIDGE TECHNICIAN NOTICED OIL-STAINED GRASS AROUND A CONTAINMENT POND AT CHELSEA STATION.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT AN ESTIMATED 3 BBLS OF OIL HAD LEAKED FROM A TWO INCH DRAIN PIPE INTO THE POND.  VISUAL OBSERVATION CONFIRMED THAT THE RELEASED OIL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN PROPERTY BOUNDARIES.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AND INCLUDED RECOVERY OF ONE BBL OF OIL FROM THE CONTAINMENT POND, THE EXCAVATION/REMOVAL OF IMPACTED SOILS AND OILED VEGETATION, AND THE REMOVAL OF THE DRAIN PIPE.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES WERE COMPLETED MARCH 2, 2008

column245: ON 3/3/08 THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM A PROPERTY OWNER REPORTING A STRONG DIESEL ODOR ON HIS PROPERTY.  THE 8MC PIPELINE HAD BEEN SHUTDOWN THE PREVIOUS DAY DUE TO NORMAL OPERATIONS.  THE CONTROL CENTER DISPATCHED LOCAL PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE SCENE.  AFTER ARRIVING ON SITE, LOCAL PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THAT A PRODUCT RELEASE FROM THE 8MC PIPELINE HAD OCCURRED.  LOCAL PERSONNEL THEN CONTACTED LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS, OSROS AND A MAINTENANCE CONTRACTOR.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS ISOLATED BY LOCAL PERSONNEL CLOSING VALVES.  MITIGATION EFFORTS WERE THEN INITIATED.

column245: THE LINE WAS NOT RUNNING AND A TECHNICIAN WAS OPENING THE VALVE IN QUESTION AS PART OF THE PROCESS OF REVERSING THE DIRECTION OF THE LINE FLOW FOR A SEASONAL PRODUCT CHANGE WHEN PRODUCT EXITED THROUGH A FITTING ON THE SIDE OF THE MAINLINE VALVE. BOTH THE VALVE AND THE FITTING HAD BEEN INSTALLED NEW IN 2007. THE STATION WAS ISOLATED AND THE FITTING IN QUESTION WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW HIGH-PRESSURE RATED HEX NIPPLE, VALVE AND PLUG. THE FITTING THAT LEAKED WAS RETAINED TO DISCUSS WITH VALVE MANUFACTURER.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: 2300 PLT (MARCH 12, 2008) ORIGINATION AT WOODBURY STARTED (JA1-V4-091 - 285,000 BBLS OF 88 GRADE) ¿ CAN PUMP WENT DOWN IMMEDIATELY ON HIGH CASE (WITH A LINE PRESSURE OF APPROX. 190PSI AND A MANIFOLD PRESSURE OF APPROX. 200PSI).  THE CAN PUMP WAS RESTARTED AND UPON SUCCESSFUL START UP, B OPERATOR PERFORMED WALK-AROUND TO CONFIRM THAT THERE WERE NO PROBLEMS WITH THE CAN PUMP.  0025 PLT (MARCH 13, 2008) B OPERATOR PERFORMED WALK AROUND TO CHECK THERMAL RELIEF VALVES AND CAN PUMP AND DISCOVERED PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AROUND THE CAN PUMP.  FUEL OIL WAS COMING OUT OF THE ACCESS WELL AT THE CAN PUMP.  HE NOTIFIED THE A OPERATOR WHO NOTIFIED THE LINE 03 DISPATCHER.  THE ORIGINATION WAS TERMINATED AND LINE 03 WAS SHUT DOWN.   0027 ¿ 0040 PLT A OPERATOR COMPLETED NECESSARY NOTIFICATIONS - OPERATIONS MANAGER, LEAD OPERATOR, DISTRICT LEADER AND ENVIRONMENTAL SPECIALIST.    0037 PLT      A OPERATOR NOTIFIED THE NJDEP (CASE # 080313013536)   0045 PLT WBY OPERATORS EVACUATED THE CAN PUMP LEG OF INJECTION PIPING.  0122 PLT SUSPECTED SOURCE OF LEAK WAS A BLOCK VALVE (OR CHECK VALVE) ON A 3¿ DRAIN LINE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE EVACUATION SYSTEM ON THE CAN PUMP.  A VAC TRUCK WAS DISPATCHED TO RECOVER STANDING PRODUCT FROM THE YARD.    0214 PLT CONTROL CENTER MADE NRC NOTIFICATION.  0315 PLT VACUUM TRUCK RECOVERED STANDING PRODUCT IN THE YARD AND EVACUATED YARD SEPARATOR AND THE ACCESS WELLS.    CONTRACT CREWS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION TO RECOVER PRODUCT AND BEGIN CLEAN-UP OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A DAMAGED GASKET ON 3¿ FLANGED CHECK VALVE LOCATED ON A DRAIN LINE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE CAN PUMP.  THE VALVE WAS EXCAVATED AND THE GASKETS WERE REPLACED ON THE CHECK VALVE FLANGES AND ADDITIONALLY ON THE ADJACENT BLOCK VALVES AND CHECK VALVE.    FINAL CLEAN-UP WAS COMPLETED IN JULY 2008.  CONTAMINATED SOIL HAS BEEN PLACED IN AN IMPERVIOUS ENVELOPE FOR FUTURE TREATMENT AT AN APPROVED OFFSITE FACILITY.

column245: THE DOW CONTRACTOR LINE-WALKERS DISCOVER LEAK AT 9:00 AM ON DOW PIPELINE 145 ON VALVE V-145-4A.    AT 9:10 AM, THE PRODUCT LINE OWNER WAS NOTIFIED.    AT 9:15 AM THE NAPHTHA PRODUCT TRANSFER BETWEEN THE DOW¿S MARINE & SALT DOME OPERATIONS WAS SHUTDOWN.    AT 9:24 AM, THE SITE PIPELINE OPERATION¿S IMMEDIATE RESPONSE LEADER ARRIVED ON THE SCENE.    AT 9:40 AM, DOW¿S IN-HOUSE EMERGENCY SECURITY & SERVICES TEAM ARRIVED ON THE SCENE.    AT 10:05 AM, THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED ¿CATCH-PAN¿ AND PUMPED TO TEMPORARY STORAGE CONTAINERS.  A SERIES OF VALVES HAD TO BE CLOSED TO ISOLATE AND DE-PRESSURE THE PIPELINE.    AT 12:50 PM, THE LEAK WAS COMPLETELY STOPPED.    DPL-145 REMAINED DE-PRESSURED UNTIL VALVE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED ON 03/18/08.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON MARCH 11, 2008,  A 75 BARREL RELEASE OF GASOLINE OCCURRED ON THE SUGAR CREEK TO COUNCIL BLUFF 8-INCH PIPELINE SYSTEM. THE RELEASE RESULTED FROM A DIRECT HIT TO THE PIPELINE FROM A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATION MACHINE WHILE INSTALLING ELECTRICAL CABLE FOR A NEW SUBDIVISION. THE THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR/EXCAVATOR DID NOT PLACE A UTILITY NOTIFICATION ONE-CALL PRIOR TO COMMENCEMENT OF EXCAVATION WORK. AN EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORT WAS MOUNTED AND THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED AND CONTROLLED WITHIN 7 HOURS FOLLOWING THE IMPACT BY THE EXCAVATOR.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  IMPACTED SOILS WERE EXCAVATED, ANALYZED AND PROPERLY DISPOSED OF.

column245: THIRD PARTY MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE AT THE PIPELINE SALES POINT INADVERTENTLY CLOSED RESULTING IN HIGH LINE PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE PRODUCT PUMP HIGH PRESSURE SHUT DOWN SWITCH FAILED TO ACTIVATE AT THE SET-POINT (APPROXIMATELY 1600 PSI.) RESULTING IN THE ACTIVATION OF A RELIEF VALVE AT THE SALES POINT. APPROXIMATELY 14.6 BARRELS OF NGL WAS RELEASED VIA THE RELIEF VALVE AND WAS SENT TO A FLARE WHERE ALL NGL PRODUCT WAS THERMALLY DESTRUCTED. NO NGL PRODUCT WAS SPILLED OR IMPACTED THE SOIL OR WATER.    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 9/15/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column47: RESPONSE, LABOR, REPAIR AND ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING
column154: DENT WITH LOCALIZED CORROSION AND CRACK
column245: ON MARCH 14, 2008 DEAD VEGETATION WAS OBSERVED BY AN EXPLORER PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CONTRACTOR WHILE LOCATING AND STAKING DIG SITES.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND THE SITE WAS EXCAVATED.     THE LEAK ORIGINATED IN AN ACTIONABLE ANOMALY (60 DAY CONDITION) IDENTIFIED AS A BOTTOM SIDE DENT WITH METAL LOSS AND WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A BOLT-ON CLAMP.  THIS ANOMALY LOCATION WAS ONE OF THE DIG LOCATIONS BEING STAKED BY THE CONTRACTOR.      THE DEFECT WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO DNV FOR METALLURGICAL EXAMINATION. THE METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS INDICATED CORROSION AND LONGITUDINALLY ORIENTED CRACKING WERE PRESENT IN THE BOTTOM SIDE DENT. THE LEAK DURATION FOR THE RELEASE IS NOT KNOWN. THE ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING AND REMEDIATION IS ONGOING.     THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY THAT HAS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT HAS YET TO PROVIDE CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, PHMSA HAS REQUESTED A CLOSURE REPORT.  THEREFORE, EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $1,300,000 FOR CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT WITH THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON FRIDAY, MARCH 14TH, OPERATOR WAS PERFORMING A WALK AROUND TANK 304 PRIOR TO TURNING THE FLOW ON THE HEF LINE FROM TANK 286 TO TANK 304. AS THE WALK AROUND WAS BEING COMPLETE, PRODUCT WAS FOUND ON THE GROUND AROUND THE TANK CHIME ON TANK 304. THE TANK WAS JUST BEING RETURNED TO SERVICE FOLLOWING AN M&TE PROJECT. IN LATE 2007, THE TANK FLOOR AND BOTTOM RING OF THE TANK WAS REPLACED AS A PART OF THE PROJECT. ON THURSDAY, MARCH 13TH APPROXIMATELY 1400 BBLS OF RCF 9# CONTANGO WAS MOVED INTO THE TANK. THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND PLANNED TO RESTART AND FINISH FILLING TANK 304 ON FRIDAY, 3/14. WHILE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING INTO TANK 304 ON 3/13, THE TANK WAS CONTINUALLY VISUALLY INSPECTED AND NO SIGNS OF PRODUCT WERE FOUND. APPROXIMATELY 2.83 BBLS OF PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED AT THIS POINT.      THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE AN INCOMPLETE WELD IN THE FLOOR SEAM AT A THREE PLATE LAP JOINT THAT OCCURRED DURING THE FLOOR REPLACEMENT IN 2007.      04/05/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. UPDATED THE AMOUNT RECOVERED FROM 1 BBL TO 3 BBLS, WHICH CORRESPONDS TO THE INFORMATION PREVIOIUSLY SUBMITTED IN THE NARRATIVE ABOVE.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON FRIDAY, MARCH 14TH, OPERATOR WAS WALKING FROM THE TANK FARM AREA TO THE OFFICE BUILDING AND NOTICED A STRONG GASOLINE ODOR. THE OPERATOR WENT INTO THE TANK DIKE TO INVESTIGATE AND FOUND SOME PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AND SOME FROST BALLS FORMING ALONG THE TANK CHIME. THE TANK WAS JUST RETURNED TO SERVICE FOLLOWING AN M&TE PROJECT. IN LATE 2007 THE TANK FLOOR OF THE TANK WAS REPLACED AS A PART OF THE PROJECT. ON TUESDAY, MARCH 13TH RCF 9# CONTANGO STARTED FLOWING INTO TANK 286. THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN AND FINISHED FILLING UNTIL THE ROOF WAS FLOATED ON THURSDAY, 3/13. WHILE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING INTO TANK 286 ON 3/11, 3/12, AND 3/13, THE TANK WAS CONTINUALLY VISUALLY INSPECTED AND NO SIGNS OF PRODUCT WERE FOUND. APPROXIMATELY 1 GALLON OF PRODUCT HAS BEEN RECOVERED WITH ABSORBENT PADS AND BOOM AT THIS POINT.    THE RELEASE WAS RELATED TO AN INCOMPLETE WELD IN THE FLOOR SEAM WELD.

column245: ON THURSDAY, MARCH 20, 2008, AND AERIAL PATROL OF THE 8" CITGO CASA PIPELINE DETECTED A SHEEN ON WATER IN A LOW LYING BASIN ADJACENT TO CHILTIPIN CREEK IN SAN PATRICIO COUNTY, TX.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT A RELEASE HAD OCCURRED.  THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE EXTERNAL GALVANIC CORROSION.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: DNR-008 HAD BEEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR SEVERAL MONTHS. WE WERE PREPARING THE LINE TO BE USED FOR AN UPCOMING SHIPMENT AND WERE IN THE PROCESS OF PRESSURE TESTING THE LINE WITH PROCESS FLUID. WHILE ROUTINELY PATROLLING THE LINE FOR LEAKS DURING THE PRESSURE TEST, WE NOTICED A LEAK IN AN AREA CROSSING OVER OUR PIPELINE. WE HAD ABOUT 135 PSIG (265 PSIG MOP) ON THE LINE WHEN THE LEAK WAS DETECTED. WE IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN THE PRESSURE TEST AND ISOLATED THE LINE. AFTER INITIAL EXCAVATION, WE OBSERVED A SMALL LEAK COMING FROM AN UNDERGROUND FLANGE IN DNR-008. INSPECTION OF THE FLANGE GASKET MATERIAL SHOWS SIGNS OF DETERIORATION AND IS JUDGED TO BE THE CAUSE FOR THE UNDERGROUND LEAK.     NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE ACCORDING TO PROCEDURE, AND WE WERE CONTACTED BY DANE GUIDRY OF LOUISIANA DNR. IN DISCUSSION WITH MR. GUIDRY, WE HAVE DETERMINED TO EXCAVATE ALL OTHER UNDERGROUND FLANGES ON THIS PIPELINE TO INSPECT, CUT OUT THE FLANGES AND THEN REPLACE WITIH WELDED SPOOL PIECES.    UPDATE: ALL UNDERGROUND FLANGES ON SUBJECT PIPELINE WERE EXPOSED, INSPECTED, CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH WELDED SPOOL PIECES.  FOLLOWING REPAIR, THE PIPELINE WAS PRESSURE TESTED AND OBSERVED ON 4/17/2008 AT 414 PSIG FOR 6 HOURS AND READIED FOR SERVICE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.  SINCE THAT DATE, CITGO HAS ANNOUNCED ITS INTENTION TO CEASE PRODUCTION AT CLAW BEGINNING IN JUNE UNTIL INVENTORIES ARE DEPLETED. DNR-008 IS NOT LIKELY TO BE USED FOR PRODUCT SHIPMENTS AFTER JULY, 2008.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: MARCH 21, 2007    DEAR CHARLIE,         YOU ASKE ME TO LOOK INTO ANY LOSS OF OIL BETWEEN NOVEMBER 9, 2007 THRU NOVEMBER 17TH/ I WOULD HAVE A PROBLEM BELIEVEING THAT WE LEAKED OIL FROM OR 4¿ CRUDE OIL FOR THA TLONG A PERIOD WITHOUT US OR ANYONE ELSE SEEING A SLICK OR OIL PAD OF THAT SIZE. FOR ONE REASON BEING THAT ON THE DAY OF THE OIL SPILL SHEEN WAS CLEARLY VISIBLE FROM HIGH ISLAND S/T 60A AT THE TIME OF THE SPILL DURING CLEAN UP. I NOR ANY OF MY OPERATORS WERE TOLD OF ANY LOSS OF OIL OR POSSIBLE SPILLS BEFORE WE DISCOVERED THE PIPELINE LEAK ON NOVEMBER 16, 2006. ON TH EDAY OF THE SPILL WHEN IT WAS FOUND WE ONLY HAD ABOUT A ¼ MILE SLICK COMING OFF THE BEACH. I PERSONALLY FEEL THAT WE SHOULD HAVE HAD A CONTINOUS SHEEN IN THE DIRECTION OF THE CURRENT. ON THAT DAY WE HAD MAYBE 1FT. SEES AT THE MOST. I WENT OVER EVERY POSSIBLE REASON FOR THE LOSS OF OIL AND COULD NOT THINK OF ANYTHING BESIDES BAD READING UNTIL I REMEMBERED THE WORK ON THE 16IN. CRUDE LINE ON 241 PLATFORM. I LOOKED BACK THROUGH THE LOGS AND FOUND THAT WE HAD ONE OF OUR OPERATORS ON THE BEACH ON NOVEMBER 10, 2006. I WAS OFFSHORE PREPARING TO PULL THE 16IN. PIG LAUNCHER OFF THE DEPARTING 16IN. L.P. PIPELINE. WE HAD PERVERSELY BEELD OFF ALL THE PRESSURE OFFSHORE ON THE 16IN. AND WAS TRYING TO LOWER THE FLUID LEVEL TO A SAFE LEVEL ON THE PIPELINE RISER TO PULL AND BLIND OFF THE PIPELINE TO DO A REPAIR ON A LOCKED OPEN 16IN. VALVE ON THE PIG LAUNCHER. I HAD A OPERATOR DRIVE DOWN THE OLD B.P. SHORE BASE TO POSSIBLY BLEED OFF ANY REMAINING PRESSURE ON THE INCOMING TIE-IN ON THE 16IN. PIPELING.I HAD HIM CLOSE THE INCOMING 4IN. LINE AND HE TRIED TO BLEED OFF ANY PRESSURE AT THAT POINT DUE TO IT BEING A OLD OUT OF SERVICE THREE PHASE LINE. AS SOON AS HE TRIED TO OPEN THE VENT HE HAD OIL. I THEN CALLED SHUT-IN BOTH DEPARTNING 4IN. LINES OFFSHORE AND I HAD HIM OPEN UP THE 16IN TIE-IN TO THE 6IN DEPARTING PIPELINES TO STAR LAKE TO SEE IF IT WOULD EQUALIZE TO PLAINS TANKS. I THEN HAD HIM GO BACK TO THE INCOMING 16IN. PIG RECEIVER AND I HAD HIM OPEN UP THE 8FT. BLOW DOWN ON THE TOP OF THE RECEIVER. OUR LEVEL STARTED DROPPING OUT ON OR RISER ON 241. WE DID THIS FOR AROUND 7 ½ TO 8HR. BEFORE WE GOT THE LEVEL AT A SAFE HEIGHT TO PULL AND BLIND FLANGE THE LINE. I CAN NOT SAY THAT WE MIGHT HAVE NOT BACK FILLED THE 16IN. FROM THE OPEN 6IN. CRUDE LINE TO STAR LAKE. IT IS DEFINITELY A POSSIBLE WAY TO MISPLACE THE OIL IN QUESTION DUE TO THE HUGE VOID IN THE LINE FROM ALL THE WATER AND GAS THAT WE REMOVED. THE OTHER PROBLEM IS THA TBEFORE AND AFTER THE JOB THEY DROVE DOWN TO WITH IN 40FT. OF THE FUTURE LEAK AND SAW NO SIGN OF ANY OIL ON THE BEACH OR IN THE WATER. IF THIS IS TRUE THAN ANY OIL THAT WAS LOST IS STILL SITTING IN THE 16IN. BLOCKED OFF LINE AND WILL BE RECOVERED WHEN IT IS PIGGED TO BE PUT BACK IN-SERVICE AS A L.P. CRUDE LINE. THAT WOULD BE THE EXPLANATION FOR THE LOSS OF OIL THAT NO ONE EVER FOUND.        FORREST SHRADER      STERLING EXPLORATION AND PRODUCTION      PRODUCTION SUPERINTENDENT    MARCH 21, 2007    RE: OIL SPILL ON THE 4¿ CRUDE PIPELINE NRC # 818356    ON NOVEMBER 16, 2006 I RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM JASON FAJKUS AT 8 A.M..  HE INFORMED ME THAT HE HAD FOUND AN OIL LEAK ON OUR 4TH CRUDE PIPELINE DURING A PIPELINE SURVEY.  I HAD THEM FLY OUT TO HIGH ISLAND 24L ¿A¿ PLATFORM AND PICK ME UP.  I ARRIVED ON THE LOCATION AT 8:20 A.M...  WHEN I LANDED ON THE LOCATION I FOUND THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM A HOLE ON THE BOTTOM OF OUR 4TH CRUDE LINE THAT HAD CAME IN CONTACT WITH N 8 IN. CROSSING PIPELINE.  THERE WAS A SLIGHT HAZE IN THE WATER SURROUNDING A POOL OF OIL CONTAINED ON THE BEACH.  I ESTIMATED A VOLUME OF 3 TO 5 BBLS.  I CONTACTED MIKE LUND AND INFORMED HIM OF THE SPILL.  I HAD HIM CLOSE THE DEPARTING 4¿ INCOMING LINE TO THE OLD B.P. SHORE BASE.  MIKE CALLED AND LET ME KNOW THAT HE HAD GOT A HOLD OF 55L AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT-IN.  I HAD MIKE CALL PLAINS MARKETING AND INFORM THEM OF THE SPILL AND TO LET THEM KNOW THAT THE SPILL WAS CONTAINED.  WE THEN CALLED GA RNER AND GAVE THEM THE LOCATION OF THE SPILL.  THEY INFORMED US THAT THEY WERE EN ROUTE TO THE LOCATION.  I THEN CALLED MIKE LUND AND HAD HIM CALL IN THE OIL SPILL DUE TO MY LOCATION AND BAD PHONE SERVICE.  I TRANSFERRED INFORMATION AND HAD HE CALL ALL AGENCIES.  I THEN WENT TO WORK TO TRY AND PREVENT ANY OIL FROM LEAKING OUT OF THE PIPELINE.  I WAS ABLE TO GET A TEMPORARY PATCH ON THE LINE AND WAS ABLE TO STOP THE LEAK.  WE THEN FLEW IN TOOLS AND OIL PADS TO HELP CONTAIN ANY OIL GETTING NEAR THE WATER.  WE HAD THE OIL CONTAINED FOR ABOUT 1 ½ HRS. BEFORE THE HIGH TIDE STARTED COMING BACK IN AND BREAKING OUR CONTAINMENT.  GLO WAS THE FIRST TO ARRIVE ON SIGHT.  ONE OF THE GARNER TRUCKS ARRIVED BUT, THE TRUCK WITH THE BOOM WAS STUCK BEHIND A CAR STUCK IN THE ROAD.  THE OTHER TRUCK ARRIVED A SHORT TIME LATER AND A BOOM WAS LAUNCHED TO CONTAIN THE OIL BEING PULLED OUT INTO THE WATER.  WE LOST ABOUT A ½ BARREL OF OIL BEFORE THE BOOM WAS LAUNCHED.  GARNER WENT TO WORK TO CLEAN UP ALL THE CONTAINED OIL WITH OIL PADS.  WE THEN LAUNCHED A HELO.  WITH JASON FAJKUS ON BOARD AND DID A 10 MILE SEARCH BY AIR TO LOOK FOR ANY OTHER PRODUCT IN THE WATER.  NO OTHER OIL WAS FOUND.  WE COMPLETED THE OIL CLEAN UP.  I WENT OVER THE SPILL WITH THE GLO, RRC, USCG AND THE WILDLIFE REFUGE PERSONNEL ON SITE.  I OFFERED FLIGHTS TO EVERYONE TO MAKE A SEARCH IF ANY WAS NEEDED TO CLOSE OUT THE SPILL.  EVERYONE DECLINED ANY FURTHER SEARCHES TO BE MADE.  DEAN WITH THE MCFADDEN WILDLIFE REFUGE INFORMED EVERYONE THAT HE WAS ON LOCATION THE DAY BEFORE, PARKED, WITH IN 50 FT. OF THE LEAK AND THAT IT WAS NOT THERE THE DAY BEFORE.  WE MADE THE CALL THAT IT MUST HAVE HAPPENED THE NIGHT BEFORE DUE TO A BAD STORM THAT HAD PASSED THROUGH.  ALL PAPER WORK WAS CLOSED OUT AND EVERYONE DEPARTED THE LOCATION.  STERLING PERSONNEL STAYED AROUND FOR 4 HRS., TO MAKE SURE THAT OUR TEMPORARY PATCH HELD UP TO THE WAVE ACTION.  I WAS ABLE TO INSTALL AN 18¿ 4¿ SPLIT SLEEVE CLAMP ON THE DAMAGED AREA ON NOVEMBER 19, 2006.  I THEN PRESSURE TESTED THE LINE FOR 24 HRS.  NO PRESSURE WAS LOST OR ANY PRODUCT AND THE LINE WAS PUT BACK IN-SERVICE UNTIL WE COULD DO A MORE EXTENSIVE REPAIR THAT WAS NEEDED TO PROPERLY FIX THE SITUATION.      FORREST SHRADER  STERLING EXPLORATION & PRODUCTION  PRODUCTION SUPERINTENDENT

column245: ON DECEMBER 06, 2007, COLONIAL RECEIVED AN INQUIRY FROM A PROPERTY OWNER ON DRY CREEK VALLEY ROAD IN CHATTOOGA COUNTY GEORGIA CONCERNING THE PRESENCE OF PETROLEUM ODOR IN AN INACTIVE LIVESTOCK WELL.  LINES 18, 19, AND 20 ARE IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE WELL AS ARE BLOCK VALVES ON LINES 18 AND 20.  RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION INDICATED A SOURCE IN THE VICINITY OF THE LINE 18 BLOCK VALVE.  THE INVESTIGATION ALSO DETERMINED EXTENT OF CONTAMINATION IN GROUNDWATER AROUND THE WELL, PIPELINES, AND BLOCK VALVES.   THE BLOCK VALVE WAS EXCAVATED ON MARCH 24, 2008 AND EVIDENCE OF PRODUCT STAINING WAS FOUND AROUND A THREADED 1/2-INCH X 2-INCH NIPPLE LOCATED ON THE BODY OF THE VALVE.  LINE 18 WAS SHUT DOWN TO FURTHER INVESTIGATE AND TO REPLACE  THE NIPPLE.   THE NIPPLE WAS REMOVED AND WAS FOUND TO HAVE A CRACK IN THE THREADS.  THE NIPPLE WAS REPLACED AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED.   IT APPEARED THAT  A LARGE AMOUNT OF FORCE PUSHING STRAIGHT DOWN ON THE RISER PIPE CAUSED THE NIPPLE TO CRACK.  THE SOURCE OF THE FORCE OR THE TIME OF OCCURANCE HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED. THE LINE 18 BLOCK VALVE AT DRY CREEK ROAD IS A 16-INCH DANIEL M303. THIS VALVE WAS PURCHASED WITH THE SECONDARY SEAT LUBRICATION/EMERGENCY SEALANT OPTION.  PRODUCT WOULD ONLY BE RELEASED FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE IF THE VALVE SEATS DID NOT SEAL OR WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPERATED.  IT WAS DETERMINED IN THE FIELD THAT THE O-RINGS AND SEAT FACE SEALS WERE IN EXCELLENT WORKING ORDER AND PRODUCT WOULD ONLY BE RELEASED FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPERATED.  THE VALVE IS OPERATED 10% CLOSED EVERY SIX MONTHS FOR AN ESTIMATED TIME OF 2 TO 3 MINUTES.   THE GEORGIA EPD WAS FORMALLY NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE ON MARCH 24TH, 2008 AT APPROXIMATELY 9:30 AM (REPORT # 51477) UPON FINDING THE SOURCE OF  THE CONTAMINATION.  JIM GUENTERT WITH THE GA EPD WAS NOTIFIED OF THE SITUATION ON DECEMBER 11, 2007 AS A COURTESY DUE TO THE CONFIRMED PRESENCE OF CONTAMINATION IN THE WELL, ALTHOUGH THE SOURCE AND RESPONSIBLE PARTY WAS UNKNOWN AT THE TIME.  BASED UPON THE INFORMATION GATHERED TO DATE, AN ESTIMATED 2 BARRELS OF GASOLINE, KEROSINE, AND FUEL OIL WERE RELEASED INTERMITTENTLY OVER AN UNKNOWN LENGTH OF TIME FROM THE CRACKED NIPPLE.  THE ACCIDENT WAS NOT REPORTED TO THE NRC SINCE THE DAMAGES WERE ORIGINALLY ESTIMATED TO BE LESS THAN $50,000 AND NO OTHER CRITERIA FOR AN NRC REPORT WAS MET.  SUBSEQUENT COST ESTIMATES FOR REMEDIATION WERE $70,000 BUT AT THAT TIME THERE WAS NO EMERGENCY TO REPORT.  ACCESS TO THE SITE HAS BEEN DELAYED BY THE LANDOWNER. THE ACTUAL COST TO REMEDIATE WILL BE DETERMINED AS ADDITIONAL DATA IS GATHERED DURING FUTURE ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE.

column238: FATIGUE RESULTING FROM THERMAL EXPANSION.
column241: BRIAN D MC TIERNAN, PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST
column245: APRIL 21, 2008    ON 18 MARCH 2008, PETROLEUM SHEEN ON OTTER CREEK, LUCAS COUNTY, WAS DISCOVERED NORTH OF THE SUNOCO TOLEDO REFINERY. IMMEDIATELY, SUNOCO EMERGENCY RESPONSE PARTICIPATED WITH OTHER COMPANIES AND INTERESTED PARTIES IN LOCATING THE SOURCE OF THE SHEEN. AT APPROXIMATELY 15:00 18 MARCH SUNOCO DETERMINED THAT THE LIKELY SOURCE WAS ONE OF TWO UNDERGROUND PIPELINES THAT TRANSPORT PETROLEUM LIQUIDS BETWEEN THE TOLEDO REFINERY AND THE BARGE LOADING FACILITY (HOCKING VALLEY DOCK), ALSO OWNED BY SUNOCO. SUNOCO IMMEDIATELY TOOK ACTION TO STOP THE FLOW OF OIL TO OTTER CREEK. THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED: PLACING BOOM, SORBENT MATERIALS AND UNDERFLOW DAMS AT WHEELING AND SEAMAN STREETS AND AT OTHER LOCATIONS WHERE OIL COULD BE CONTAINED, DIGGING SUMPS TO CONTAIN THE OIL AT THE PRIMARY SPILL SITE AND VACUUMING UP THE FREE PRODUCT. BECAUSE THE LEAK SITE WAS WET WITH STANDING WATER, SUNOCO BUILT A 1/4 MILE GRAVEL ROAD IN TO THE AREA TO BEGIN EXCAVATING THE LINES. AFTER EXCAVATION, THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE 8: LINE. THIS LINE TRANSPORTED LIGHT CYCLE OIL, A DIESEL TYPE MATERIAL, TO THE BARGE FACILITY. THE LEAK WAS EXPOSED AT APPROXIMATELY 11:00 20 MARCH AND THE RELEASE STOPPED SHORTLY THEREAFTER. THE LINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY REPAIRED BY 22 MARCH.    --------------  AUGUST 5, 2009    THE 8" PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON APRIL 25 2008.  A FORENSIC INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED ON THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC.  THE FAILURE WAS FOUND TO BE LOCATED AT A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED CRACK ADJACENT TO A GIRTH WELD JOINING A LENGTH OF LINE PIPE TO A TRIMMED ELBOW FITTING.  THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY FATIGUE RESULTING FROM THERMAL EXPANSION AS THE PIPELINE WAS CYCLED BETWEEN NORMAL OPERATING TEMPERATURE AND AMBIENT GROUND TEMPERATURE DURING IDLE PERIODS.  IN RESPONSE TO THE  FORENSIC INSPECTION REPORT, THE PIPELINE WAS IDLED BEGINNING SEPTEMBER 26 2008.  A PIPING FLEXIBILITY ASSESSMENT OF THE ENTIRE PIPELINE WAS PERFORMED BY THE EQUITY ENGINEERING GROUP, INC. (E2G) WHICH IDENTIFIED THERMAL EXPANSION STRESSES AT BENDS, CONSISTENT WITH THE FINDINGS BY KIEFNER.   IN ADDITION,  A NEW TEMPERATURE LIMIT WAS ESTABLISHED  BASED ON THE PIPING FLEXIBILITY ASSESSMENT RESULTS .  IN ACCORDANCE WITH E2G RECOMMENDATIONS, EIGHT BENDS WERE REPLACED TO REDUCE STRESS LEVELS RELATED TO THERMAL CYCLING AND A NEW HEAT EXCHANGER (COOLER) WAS INSTALLED AT 15 PUMPHOUSE.  AN IN-LINE INSPECTION (ILI) AND A HYDROSTATIC TEST WERE ALSO CONDUCTED, SEVERAL CORROSION AND DEFORMATION FEATURES WERE IDENTIFIED AND REPAIRED, AND THE LINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY RETURNED TO SERVICE ON JULY 15 2009.

column245: TANK WAS FOUND LEAKING, REPORTABLE ONLY BECAUSE IT WILL COST IN EXCESS OF $100K TO EMPTY, DEGAS AND FIND OUT WHAT IS WRONG WITH THE TANK AND THEN FIX.   SIX  WELD AREAS EXIST ON THE TANK FLOOR THAT MAY HAVE SOURCED THE LEAK.  THESE HAVE BEEN FIXED AND THE TANK HAS BEEN RETURNED TO SERVICE.  AREA WAS NEVER UNSAFE SO I USED THE MINIMUM TIME, THERE WAS NO APPARENT LEAK DURATION, AGAIN, I USED THE MINIMUM TIME.  COINCIDENTALLY, THIS LEAK WAS OBSERVED THE SAME DAY THERE WAS A EARTHQUAKE REPORTED IN THE AREA.  THE EARTHQUAKE WAS NOT THE CAUSE OF THE TANK LEAK.  NO DEFINITIVE CAUSE COULD BE PINPOINTED FOR THE STAIN AROUND THE TANK.  AFTER TANK WAS PUT BACK INTO SERVICE, IT WAS MONITORED FOR SEVERAL MONTHS AND TANK DID NOT SHOW ANY SIGNS OF LEAKING.

column245: INACTIVE PIPELINE WAS ACTIVATED ABOUT 1000 HRS., AFTER STARTUP IT WAS OBSERVED THAT AN EMPLOYEE SAW A PUDDLE OF CRUDE OIL ON THE GROUND, THE PIPELINE HAD DEVELOPED A HOLE IN IT DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION AND THE CRUDE EVENTUALLY SURFACED.  IT WAS ESTIMATED THAT THIS PIPELINE HAD BEEN LEAKING FOR APPROXIMATELY 30 DAYS BUT IT MAY HAVE BEEN LONGER.  THE PIPE WAS CUTOUT AND ANOTHER JOINT INSTALLED.  THE CUT OUT PIPE AND THE REMAINING PIPE ADJACENT TO THE CUT OUT WAS EXAMINED INTERNALLY.    IT WAS DETERMINED THAT NO FURTHER ACTION WAS REQUIRED ON THE PIPE REMAINING IN THE GROUND.  THE CUT OUT PIPE WAS EXAMINED INTERNALLY AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CORROSION WAS DUE TO MICROBIOLOGICAL FORCES.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 17:08 MST A GAS ALARM WARNING WAS RECEIVED BY THE EDMONTON CONTROL CENTER FOR UNIT 3 ON ENBRIDGE'S LINE 14, EDGEWATER STATION, WHICH WAS IDLE.  PER PROCEDURE THE LINE OPERATOR CALLED OUT THE AREA ON-CALL TECHNICIAN.  UPON ARRIVING AT THE STATION THE TECHNICIAN CONFIRMED THAT THE HORIZONTAL FLANGE CLOSEST TO THE FLOOR ON THE UNIT 3 DISHCARGED ELBOW HAD LEAKED, BUT WAS NO LONGER LEAKING.  IT IS ESTIMATED THAT A TOTAL OF 5 BARRELS OF OIL LEAKED INTO THE CONTAINMENT TROUGH BUILT INTO THE CONCRETE FLOOR.  APPROXIMATELY 4 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS AND THE RESIDUAL WAS CLEANED UP AND APPROPRIATELY DISPOSED OF.  THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A FAILED GASKET.  THE JOINT THAT LEAKED WAS A 20" 600# FLANGE SET CONSISTING OF ONE WELDING NECK FLANGE AND ONE LAP JOINT FLANGE MATED TOGETHER WITH A SPIRAL WOUND GASKET WITH NO INNER RING.  THE UNIT REMAINED ISOLATED AND OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL MAINTENANCE CREWS COULD REPLACE THE FAILED GASKET WITH A NEW SPIRAL-WOUND GASKET WITH AN INNER RING.

column245: CHEVRON PIPE LINE COMPANY (CPL) RECEIVED AN EXCAVATION NOTICE FROM TESS ON 3-18-08, IN THE VICINITY OF OUR 6" SALT CREEK TO SNYDER LPG LINE. CPL PERSONNEL MARKED OUR LINES PRIOR TO THE EXCAVATION. THE EXCAVATOR BEGAN THE WORK TO EXPOSE OUR LINES AND CROSS US ON 3-31-08. A CPL EMPLOYEE WAS ONSITE WHILE THE EXCAVATOR WORKED NEAR OUR LINES TO COMMUNICATE LINE LOCATION INFORMATION AND DOCUMENT THE LINE CROSSING LOCATION FOR OUR RECORDS. THE EXCAVATION BEGAN AT 1350 AND OUR PIPELINE WAS STRUCK APPROXIMATELY 10 MINUTES LATER. THE CPL EMPLOYEE BEGAN ISOLATING THE DAMAGED LINE SEGMENT AND TOOK STEPS TO RELOCATE THE ONSITE PERSONNEL TO A SAFE LOCATION. THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED & BACK IN SERVICE ON APRIL 4, 2008.

column245: ON 4/3/08 A TRAINING SUPERVISOR WALKING THE AREA AROUND TANK 150-9 DISCOVERED PRODUCT NEAR THE FIREWALL SOUTWEST OF THE TANK.  OPERATIONS BEGAN ISOLATION OF VARIOUS PIPE SEGMENTS (BOTH JURISDICTIONAL AND NON JURISDICTIONAL).  THE INVESTATION PROCESS GEGAN TO DIENTIFY THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT, AT 1 PM (1300) ON 4/3/08 IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE 28" EXPOLORER PIPELINE HAD A HOLE, RLEASING THE PRODUCT.  THE PIPELINE WAS LOCKED, STRIPPED AND DRAINED AND A PLIDCO CLAMP FOR TEMPORARY REPAIR WAS PLACED ON THE SEGMENT.      11-11-08:  MATERIALS HAVE BEEN SCOPED FOR ORDER AND ARE BEING PREPARED FOR PERMANANT REPLACEMENT OF THE PIPE SEGMENT.  TOTAL COSTS ARE UNKOWN, CURRENT COSTS ARE ABOVE $55K.     PROJECT COMPLETED WITH THE REPLACEMENT OF 480' OF 28" PIPE, (REMOVAL OF TEMPORARY CLAMP), INSTALLATION OF PIG TRAP AND 2 M303 GATE VALVES.  ALL PROJECT INFORMATION, (TESTING, OQ, ETC) CAN BE FOUND IN THE ENGINEERING PROJECT FILES.

column245: THE TANK APPEARD TO HAVE A SMALL HOLE IN THE FLOOR.  THE TANK WAS PUMPED DOWN, CLEANED OUT AND PREPARED FOR A 653 INTERNAL REPORT.  OIL RELEASED FROM THE TANK WAS COLLECTED AND IMPACTED SOILS WERE REMOVED AND TREATED APPROPRIATELY. VISUAL EXAMINATION SHOWED LOCALIZED PITTING AND THE CAUE OF COROSION WAS AQUEOUS CORROSIVE ATTACH OF CARBON STEEL.

column245: THE PIPE LONG SEAM WAS LOCATED AT THE 0800 POSITION.  CAUSE DUE TO SETTLING OF THE CARRIER PIPE OUTSIDE OF THE CASING ON THE CASED PIPE AT POINT OF THE CASING SPACER.  THE SETTLEMENT CAUSED THE CASING SPACER TO CREATE A 1.4 PERCENT DEFORMATION IN THE LONG SEAM AREA.  THE SPACER WAS IN CONTACT WITH THE DSAW LONG SEAM.  LOCATED WITHIN 3 FEET FROM THE END OF THE CASING.  REPAIR WAS MADE BY INSTALLING A TYPE B FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE WITH THE DENT AREA FILLED WITH EPOXY. column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON APRIL 7, 2008 LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A FAILED SEAL ON THE LINE 13 DENSITOMETER PUMP AT THE GONVICK DENSITOMETER SITE.  THIS IS A SMALL (1") INTERNAL GEAR PUMP THAT CIRCULATES PRODUCT THROUGH A DENSITOMETER.  THE SEAL WAS REPAIRED IMMEDIATELY AND THE FREE OIL IN THE DENSITOMETER BUILDING WAS CLEANED UP.  AT THE TIME THE TOTAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS ESTIMATED TO BE LESS THAN FIVE GALLONS.  ON APRIL 8, A LOCAL RESIDENT CALLED A TECHNICIAN (WHO WAS AN ACQUAINTANCE) DIRECTLY TO REPORT AN ODOR COMING FROM THE SITE.  UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE OIL THAT LEAKED FROM THE FAILED SEAL RAN THROUGH A FLOOR PENETRATION AND ALONG THE BELOWGRADE PIPING INTO A VERTICAL CULVERT ADJACENT TO THE BUILDING.  APPROXIMATELY SIX BARRELS OF OIL WERE RELEASED.  FOUR BARRELS WERE RECOVERED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS AND THE REMAINDER WAS TRAPPED IN THE SOIL, WHICH WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF IN ACCORDANCE WITH LOCAL REGULATIONS.  THE ENTIRE FACILITY IS SCHEDULED TO BE REPLACED THIS YEAR WITH NEW, MORE MODERN PUMPS, LEAK DETECTION AND CONTAINMENT, AND SELF-ACTUATED VALVES.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: THE ARTESIA LATERAL LPG PIPE LINE WAS STRUCK BY A THIRD PARTY DOING EXCAVATION WITH A FOR IRRIGATION LINES ON APRIL 7, 2008 AROUND 17:00 CST.  THE INCIDENT WAS ON THE K&B DAIRY PROPERTY LOCATED AT MP 17.32 (LAT 32.50.77/ LONG 103.13.85).  THE LINE IS A 6" LPG LINE.  CRAIG ELECTRICAL STARTED THE EXCAVATION WORK AT THE NORTHWEST FENCE LINE AND HEADED SOUTHEAST TOWARD A CENTER PIVOT LOCATION OF THE IRRIGATION SYSTEM.  FROM THE CENTER PIVOT POINT, A SECOND TRENCH WAS DUG IN A SOUTH WEST DIRECTION TOWARDS THE WATER WELL PUMP.  THE ARTESIA LATERAL LINE WAS STRUCK BY THE EXCAVATOR WHILE THE SECOND TRENCH WAS BEING DUG. DCP MIDCONTINENT PERSONNEL WERE AT THE BOOSTER STATION LOCATED ON THE K&B DAIRY PROPERTY WHEN THE INCIDENT OCCURRED.  THEY SAW THE VAPOR CLOUD AND CALLED A RONNIE GILCREST, DCP OPERATOR.  DCP ALSO HAS A LINE ON THE PROPERTY IN THE VICINITY OF THE INCIDENT.  THEY MADE THE NOTIFICATION BECAUSE THEY THOUGHT IT MIGHT BE THEIR LINE.  RONNIE GILCREST WENT TO THE LOCATION AND IDENTIFIED THAT IT WAS NOT THEIR LINE.  HE CALLED THE CPL 800 EMERGENCY NUMBER LOCATED ON THE PIPE LINE MARKER INFORMING THE CSC OF THE INCIDENT. THE DAMAGED PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED & PUT BACK IN SERVICE ON APRIL 10, 2008.

column235: FAILURE TO IDENTIFY A RISK DURING PRE PLANNING
column245: ON APRIL 15, 2008, ENBRIDGE EXPERIENCED A RELEASE FROM A ONE INCH THERMAL RELIEF LINE ON THE COMPANY'S TANK 79 INLET PIPING AT OUR GRIFFITH, INDIANA TERMINAL FACILITY, WHILE A CONTRACTOR WAS PAINTING THE TANK SHELL.  THE INTIAL RELEASE VOLUME WAS ESTIMATED AT 40 BARRELS, HOWEVER THE TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME HAS BEEN INCREASED TO 260 BARRELS TO ACCOUNT FOR ADDITIONAL VOLUMES THAT DRAINED WHILE THE TANK WAS PUMPED DOWN (APPX 4 HRS, 40 MINUTES).   THE TOTAL VOLUME RELEASED WAS ISOLATED WITHIN THE TANK BERM AND RECOVERED WITH MINOR SOIL RESIDUALS EXCAVATED, DISPOSED OF AND STATE ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATORY CLOSURE IS PENDING.    CONTRACT PERSONNEL WERE PERFORMING ABRASIVE BLASTING ON A SUSPENDED SCAFFOLD ADJACENT TO THE SUBJECT PIPING.   UPON RELEASE, THE CONTRACTORS LOWERED THE SCAFFOLDING AND EXITED THE AREA HOWEVER, 3 INDIVIDUALS WERE SPRAYED BY THE OIL AND WERE SENT TO THE HOSPITAL AS A PRECAUTION.  NONE SUSTAINED INJURY; POST INCIDENT DRUG AND ALCOHOL TESTING WAS ALSO CONDUCTED.    THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT ALTHOUGH THE PIPING WAS LOCATED UNDERNEATH THE CATWALK/STAIR PLATFORM AND DEEMED TO BE PROTECTED, AND A GROUND LABORER WAS ASSIGNED TO MONITOR RIGGING, AIRLINES AND HOSES, ONE OF THE RIGGING LINES LIKELY SNAGGED ON THE SMALL DIAMETER PIPING AND CAUSED THE LEAK.

column245: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL DETECTED A SLIGHT AMMONIA ODOR.  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN, AND THE SUSPECT AREA WAS EXCAVATED.  THE RELEASE WAS VERIFIED TO BE A MINOR SEEP THROUGH A BLEEDER VALVE ON A BELOW-GROUND STOPPLE FITTING.    THE LEAK WAS REPAIRED BY WELDING A 2" COLLAR OVER THE FITTING, PLACING A PLUG IN THE FITTING, AND WELDING THE PLUG TO THE COLLAR.  THE LINE WAS THEN PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.    ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AND SOIL REMEDIATION WORK ARE ONGOING.    UPDATE:  ALL ENVIRONMENTAL REMEDIATION WAS  HANDLED BY THE OWNER MAGELLAN PIPELINE.  EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2008, TOTAL OPERATORSHIP WAS TRANSFERRED TO MAGELLAN PIPELINE AND ENTERPRISE NO LONGER IS INVOLVED WITH THE MAGELLAN NH3 PIPELINE.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: ON MONDAY, APRIL 21 2008 A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED A WET SPOT NEXT TO BUCKEYE¿S TANK 1 AT ITS BOOTH STATION.  SINCE THIS TANK HAD BEEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR AN API 653 INSPECTION, THE TANK WAS MONITORED DURING THE INITIAL PRODUCT RECEIPT.  IMMEDIATELY AFTER DISCOVERING THE PRODUCT AT THE TANK, THE PIPELINER NOTIFIED THE BOOTH RECEIPT CONTROLLER WHO PROMPTLY SHUT DOWN THE INCOMING FLOW TO THE TANK.  THE PIPELINER THEN NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR OF THE SITUATION AND BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED.    THE PRODUCT WAS ISOLATED TO THE TANK DIKE AND REMEDIATION EFFORTS WERE STARTED IMMEDIATELY.  AFTER THE TANK WAS EMPTED AND CLEANED A ¼ INCH DRILL HOLE IN THE FLOOR OF THE TANK WAS DISCOVERED.  THE HOLE WAS DRILLED AS PART OF THE API 653 INSPECTION TO VERIFY THE AIR QUALITY UNDER THE FLOOR.    THE TANK REMAINS OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL REPAIRS ARE COMPLETED.

column245: A NEW MIXER WAS INSTALLED ON TANK 205 ALONG WITH A NEW PRIMARY SEAL.  DUE TO REPORTED HIGH VIBRATION OF THE NEW MIXER, THE GEARBOX, MOTOR AND PRIMARY SEAL WERE REMOVED FOR INSPECTION.  A NEW GEARBOX, MOTOR, AND PRIMARY SEAL WERE SUBSEQUENTLY INSTALLED.  A LEAK OCCURRED DURING THE INSTALLATION OF THE SEAL BECAUSE THE SHAFT AND PRIMARY SEAL WERE NOT PROPERLY ALIGNED.      04/05/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. column235: OOS LINE NOT RE-BLINDED AFTER MAINTENANCE ACTIVITY
column245: WHILE ON ROUTINE ROUNDS, TWO OPERATING PERSONNEL NOTICED SOIL STAINING AND A PETROLEUM PRODUCT ODOR WHEN WALKING IN THE VICINITY OF THE L4 PIPING MANIFOLD.  THE OPERATORS NOTIFIED THEIR SUPERVISOR WHO THEN STARTED THE NOTIFICATION CHAIN.  REGION 1 PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO ASSIST IN THE EVALUATION OF THE REPORTED SOIL STAINING.    FIELD INVESTIGATION TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF THE PRODUCT THAT WAS STAINING THE SOIL WAS CONDUCTED ON THE EVENING OF 4/25/2008 BETWEEN 7:00 PM AND MIDNIGHT. AT APPROXIMATELY 11:05 PM, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE 8" PIPING SECTION 864 THAT RAN FROM TANK 328, ACROSS THE DIKE FIELD, UNDER THE DIKE WALL AN INTO THE L4 MANIFOLD AREA WAS THE MOST LIKELY SOURCE OF THE LEAKING PRODUCT. THE PIPING SECTION WAS ISOLATED WITH VALVES AND PLANS MADE TO RETURN THE NEXT DAY TO FURTHER EVALUATE AND ISOLATE THIS SECTION. ON SATURDAY, 4/26/2008, COMPANY PIPELINERS, MECHANIC, OPERATIONS AND OSRO¿S VACUUM TRUCK IMPLEMENTED A WORK PLAN TO LOTO THE MANIFOLD AND TANK VALVES SO THAT THE 864 LINE COULD BE EVACUATED. ONCE THE 864 LINE WAS DETERMINED TO BE CLEAR AND LIQUID-FREE, THE PIPING WAS PHYSICALLY DISCONNECTED FROM THE TANK 328 AND BLIND FLANGES USED TO ISOLATE THE PIPE AND VALVES.    INVESTIGATION INTO CAUSE DETERMINED THAT THE LINE THAT LEAKED HAD BEEN HISTORICALLY OOS BY BLINDING.  THE TANK WAS TAKEN OOS FOR MAINTENANCE WORK AND BLINDS REMOVED.  UPON PLACING THE TANK BACK INTO SERVICE, THE BLINDS WERE NOT REINSTALLED.  EVEN THOUGH VALVES WERE CLOSED, THE VALVES LEAKED THROUGH INTERNALLY ALLOWING THE PRODUCT TO ENTER THE OOS LINE WHICH OBVIOUSLY HAS THROUGH WALL FEATURES.

column245: ON 5/23 AT APPROXIMATELY 1010, CHEVRON REFINERY PERSONNEL NOTIFIED KM OF A GASOLINE ODOR FROM OUR LS 69 FROM A CASING INSIDE THEIR REFINERY. THREATENED RELEASE NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE AT THE TIME.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASE WAS LIKELY AND EXCAVATION WAS BEGUN TO UNEARTH THE CASING AND PIPE.  AT APPROXIMATELY 1400 ON 5/24, UPON REMOVAL OF THE CASING, A LEAK IN THE PIPE WAS CONFIRMED. RELEASE NOTIFICATIONS WERE THEN MADE. THE LEAK CAUSED TWO STAINS; ONE 6.5¿ X 13¿ AND THE SECOND 15¿ X 3¿. THE STAINS WERE FULLY CONTAINED AND NO WATERWAY WAS THREATENED. SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION REVEALED A PINHOLE LEAK CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION    NOTE 1: RE: PART A 6 C.; THERE WILL BE NO FURTHER RECOVERD.     NOTE 2: RE: PART C 5 A.; PRESSURE ESTIMATE OF 127 PSIG BELIEVED TO BE REASONABLY ACCURATE GIVEN UNCERTAINTY OF TIME OF RELEASE    NOTE 3: RE: PART C 5 B; MAXIMUM OPERATING PRESSURE OF THE PIPE AT THE POINT OF THE RELEASE IS 296 PSIG BASED ON 80% OF THE HYDROTEST PRESSURE, HOWEVER THE MAXIMUM DISCHARGE PRESSURE SETTING FOR THE SYSTEM IS LIMITED BY THE 273 PSIG RATING OF ITS ANSI 150 LB. CLASS VALVES AND FITTINGS.    NOTE 4: RE: PART G 3; LEAK DURATION IS UNKNOWN.    NOTE 5: RE: PART A 6C; AMOUNT SPILLED IS 4.3 BBLS AND AMOUNT RECOVERED IS 0.4 BBLS TO DATE. ONLINE DATA ENTRY SYSTEM DOES NOT ALLOW FRACTIONS.

column245: AFTER ANNUAL TESTING OF PRESSURE RELIEVING VALVE ON 5/29/08 APPROX. ONE HOUR AFTER TESTING THE VALVE VENTED FOR TWO VERY BRIEF TIMES APPROX. 3 SECONDS EACH. LOCAL PERSONEL TOOK THE VALVE OUT OF SERVICE AFTER DETERMINING THAT PRESSURE HAD NOT EXCEEDED NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE. IT WAS DETERMINED DURING THE REPAIR THAT A 3/16 O-RING ON THE PILOT VALVE HAD FAILED CAUSING A RELEASE OF APPROX. 15 MCF OR 50 BARRELS OF CO2. IT WAS DETERMINED DURING FURTHER INVESTIGATION THAT THE ORIGINAL MANUFACTURE OF THE VALVE HAD SUPPLIED BUNA INSTEAD OF VITON SOFT GOODS FOR THE PILOT VALVE. THE SOFT GOODS ON THE VALVE HAD BEEN REPLACED THE PREVIOUS YEAR.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: KINDER-MORGAN CONTROL ROOM PERSONNEL HAD BROUGHT THE PIPELINE UP TO SHIP ANOTHER BATCH OF JET FUEL WHEN THEY OBSERVED A DEVIATION IN THE LINE BALANCE. THEY SHUT THE PIPELINE DOWN AND CHECKED THEIR FACILITIES SINCE THEY HAD STARTED DELIVERY TO ALAMOGORDO WHILE ENDING THEIR DELIVERY TO TUCSON.    NUSTAR OPERATIONS WAS NOTIFIED OF THE CONDITION AND BEGAN CHECKING THEIR FACILITIES.  THEN PERSONNEL BEGAN SURVEILLANCE OF THE PIPELINE ROW AND DISCOVERED A STAIN AT MP 14.7.  ISOLATION VALVES MBV20 AND MBV30 WERE CLOSED AND DESIGNATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS WERE SUMMONED TO THE SITE.    THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND A TEMPORARY CLAMP WAS INSTALLED.  REMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SOIL BEGAN DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS WITH APPROXIMATELY 150 CU. YDS. OF DIRT REMOVED TO PLASTIC SHEETING NEARBY.    THE PIPELINE REMAINED DOWN UNTIL AFTER PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE 5 DAYS LATER.  NEW PIPE WAS INSTALLED AND THE FAILED PORTION WAS SENT TO A THIRD PARTY LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS.  WHEN ANALYSIS IS COMPLETED A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WILL BE SENT TO PHMSA.    UPDATE    THIRD PARTY LAB ANALYSIS BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES INDICATED THAT, "THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS PREFERENTIAL ERW SEAM CORROSION COMBINED WITH MIC". FURTHER, "THE EXTERNAL CORROSION PREFERENTIALLY ATTACKED THE ERW BONDLINE AND WAS ACCELERATED BY THE BY PRODUCTS OF THE MICROBIOLOGICAL ACTIVITY".      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO EXTERNAL CORROSSION, PER THIRD-PARTY ANALYSIS.

column245: THE LAST EMPLOYEE ON SITE AT THE FACILITY LEFT AT APPROXIMATELY 12:00 ON 5/16/08. THE EDGAR STATION IS NOT MANNED 24/7. THE STATION INSPECTION COMPLETED PRIOR TO PERSONNEL LEAVING THE SITE DID NOT IDENTIFY ANY PROBLEMS. PERSONNEL WERE CALLED TO THE SITE AT APPROXIMATELY 16:15 ON 5/18/08 BY THE CONTROL CENTER DUE TO AN UNRELATED ALARM. THE ALARM WAS FOR A VALVE BEING IN TRANSITION CODITION. THE EMPLOYEE OBSERVED OIL SPRAYING FROM THE CHECK VALVE. THE STATION/PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN.

column7: HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: RENO COUNTY SHERIFF 911 DISPATCHER CALLED COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL THAT A PASSING MOTORIST SMELLED GAS.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION SMELLED AN ODOR BUT DID NOT DETECT GAS WITH A GAS DETECTOR.  ALL PRODUCT LINES AT THE LOCATION WERE BLOCKED IN FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE CALLED NRC (#872636) ESTIMATING A SMALL VOLUME RELEASE OF 1 BARREL PRIOR TO LOCATING THE LEAK.  EXCAVATION LOCATED A SMALL LEAK NEAR A ROAD CROSSING. AFTER REMOVING A BELOW GROUND ICE BALL, A SECOND CALL WAS MADE TO NRC (#872718) WITH A REVISED VOLUME ESTIMATE OF 2 BARRELS.    THE LEAK WAS STOPPED WITH A PLIDCO SLEEVE, BUT AFTER THE SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED, A SMALL CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK CLUSTER WAS DISCOVERED APPROXIMATELY 6" FROM THE PLIDCO SLEEVE AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION.  THE OPERATING PRESSURE WAS TEMPORARILY REDUCED 20% AND APPROXIMATELY 100' OF PIPE WAS EXCAVATED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE LEAK SITE TO EXAMINE THE PIPE FOR ADDITIONAL DEFECTS.  NO ADDITIONAL DEFECTS WERE FOUND.  STOPPLES WERE SET, AND THE LEAK AND CRACK CLUSTER WERE CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH PIPE OF THE SAME DIAMETER, WALL THICKNESS, AND GRADE.  THE LINE WAS THEN RETURNED TO SERVICE.    THE DEFECTIVE PIPE SEGMENT WAS SENT TO STORK METALLURGICAL CONSULTANTS IN HOUSTON FOR ANALYSIS.  THE LEAK WAS LOCATED IN A SMALL CIRCUMFERENTIAL CRACK.  ANALYSIS SHOWED THAT THE CRACKS WERE CAUSED BY STRESS-CORROSION CRACKING AND THAT ORIENTATION OF THE CRACKS IMPLICATED A BENDING LOAD.    DURING JUNE 2010, A SOIL AND GROUNDWATER DELINEATION INVESTIGATION WAS PERFORMED IN ACCORDANCE WITH AGREEMENTS ESTABLISHED WITH KDHE.  ANAYTICAL RESULTS INDICATED THAT SOIL AND GROUNDWATER CONTAIN BENZENE AND GASOLINE RANGE ORGANIC (GRO) CONCENTRATIONS WHICH EXCEED ESTABLISHED REGULATORY ACTION LEVELS.  SINCE THE ELEVATED GRO CONCENTRATIONS WOULD NOT NORMALLY BE EXPECTED TO BE PRESENT IN THE Y-GRADE NGL RELEASED DURING 2008, IT APPEARS THAT OTHER HISTORICAL RELEASES LIKELY OCCURRED AT THIS LOCATION, AND THEREBY, IT IS VIEWED THAT ADDITIONAL REMEDIAL ACTION AT THIS POINT IS BEYOND THE SCOPE OF IMPACT ATTRIBUTED SOLELY TO THE 2008 RELEASE.

column245: ANCHORAGE TERMINAL OPERATOR DISCOVERED CRUDE ON THE GROUND INSIDE THE TERMINAL.  THE OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER WAS CONTACTED AND THE SYSTEM WAS SHUTDOWN.  CRUDE REACHED DITCH THAT CONTAINED WATER ON ADJACENT EXXONMOBIL REFINERY PROPERTY.  BOOM WAS DEPLOYED AND VAC TRUCK MOBILIZED.    LEAK ORIGINATED FROM 16 INCH METER OUTLET PIPING THAT HAS NOT ACTIVELY TRANSPORTED CRUDE IN MORE THAN 1 YEAR.  INVESTIGATION AND LAB ANALYSIS CONCLUDED CAUSE WAS INTERNAL CORROSION, SPECIFICALLY CHLORIDE PITTING WITH MICROBES PRESENT.

column245: DURING HIS MORNING SAFETY CHECK THE OPERATOR OBSERVED CRUDE OIL COMING OUT OF THE PROVER FOR THE EXPRESS PIPELINE. THE PROVER WAS IMMEDIATELY ISOLATED. IT WAS OBSERVED THAT THE O-RING SEAL ON THE 16" END CAP HAD FAILED ALLOWING OIL TO ESCAPE.

column30: OTHER
column245: AS PART OF ITS INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, EXXONMOBIL PIPELINE COMPANY (EMPCO) WAS PREPARING TO DO A PARTIAL PIPE REPLACEMENT ON ITS 16¿ RACELAND TO ANCHORAGE PIPELINE.  A MAGNETIC SEALING PIG WAS BEING UTILIZED AS A BARRIER WHILE DISPLACING 12 MILES OF THE PIPELINE WITH NITROGEN.    CRUDE OIL SPILLED FROM A VENT PIPE AFTER APPROXIMATELY 6 HOURS OF BLOWDOWN. THE SPILL WAS STOPPED WITHIN 5 MINUTES AND CLEAN UP COMMENCED.     IT WAS LATER DISCOVERED THAT A PLUG WAS MISSING FROM THE PIG¿S FRONT NOSE PLATE WHICH ALLOWED NITROGEN TO PASS THROUGH THE PIG.  THE NITROGEN BLANKET IN FRONT OF THE PIG LIKELY EXPANDED AND CAUSED THE PIG TO BACK UP.  ADDITIONALLY, THE PIG WAS THOUGHT TO BE IN A DIFFERENT LOCATION WHEN THE SPILL OCCURRED.     EMPCO HAS MODIFIED PROCEDURES AND INCLUDED ADDITIONAL SAFEGUARDS TO PREVENT RECURRENCE.    *C 5 B ¿ MOP IS SHOWN AS 983 PSI.  AT THE TIME OF THIS ACCIDENT, THE REDUCED MAXIMUM OPERATING PRESSURE  WAS 747 PSI, AS PER 8/10/08 SAFETY RELATED CONDITION REPORT.

column245: ON THURSDAY, JUNE 12, 2008, BUCKEYE PARTNERS PIPELINE IN LANCASTER COUNTY PA WAS STRUCK BY A CONTRACTOR OPERATING A FRONT END LOADER WHILE WORKING FOR A FARMER CAUSING SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE.  NO ONE CALL WAS PLACED BY THE CONTRACTOR PRIOR TO THE WORK STARTING. THE FARMING SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY CALLED INTO BUCKEYE'S CONTROL CENTER TO NOTIFY BUCKEYE OF THE DAMAGED LINE AND RELEASE.  BEFORE BUCKEYE'S CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED THE CALL, THE CONTROLLER HAD ALREADY SEEN INDICATIONS OF LOSS OF PRESSURE AND STARTED TO SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE.  BUCKEYE'S MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DEPLOYED TO PERFORM EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORTS AND INSTALLED AN 8¿ PLIDCO SLEEVE AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR OVER THE 2 ½¿ LONG GOUGE CONTAINING A PUNCTURE.  A TOTAL OF 15¿ OF PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED AS A PERMANENT REPAIR.  ALL APPROPRIATE NOTIFICATIONS TO OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE MADE.

column245: ON JUNE 20, 2008 FOUR-FOUR INC. WAS ENGAGED IN BACKFILL OPERATION AS PART OF A PIPELINE CONSTRUCTION PROJECT FOR WESTERN REFINING SOUTHWEST, INC., SAN JUAN PIPELINE. A FOUR-FOUR OPERATOR WAS OPERATING A D7R CAT DOZER, MOVING SPOIL PILES OF DIRT THAT WAS EXCAVATED FROM THE NEW PIPELINE PROJECT THAT WAS DIRECTLY OVER THE WESTERN REFINING SAN JUAN LOADED LINE IN AN ATTEMPT TO COVER THE NEW SECTION OF 6" PIPE. AT THIS TIME THE DOZER OPERATOR BEGAN MOVING DIRT INTO THE EXPOSED TRENCH WHEN THE BLADE HOOKED THE LOADED LINE WITH THE CORNER OF THE BLADE. THE DOZER CREASED THE LINE CAUSING A COMPLETE SHEAR. THE SHEAR RESULTED IN THE RELEASE OF APPROXIMATELY 100 BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL. THE MAJORITY OF THE PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN THE OPEN TRENCH CAUSING GROUND CONTAMINATION.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON JUNE 25, 2008, CONTRACT EMPLOYEES WERE SETTING PIPE SUPPORTS AT THE SEMINOLE ADAMS JUNCTION VALVE SITE.  THE CONTRACTORS WERE HAND DIGGING UNDER THE PIG LAUNCHER BARREL IN PREPARATION TO SET A PIPE SUPPORT.  THERE WAS A 5000 BARREL PER HOUR FLOW OF PRODUCT THROUGH THIS LAUNCHER BARREL.  A SEMINOLE OPERATIONS DESIGNEE WAS AT THE SITE MONITORING THE HAND DIGGING.  THE OPERATIONS DESIGNEE LEFT THE SITE TO CHECK OTHER WORK THAT WAS ONGOING APPROXIMATELY 500 YARDS DOWN THE PIPELINE.  THE CONTRACTOR DECIDED TO MOVE A SMALL BACK HOE INTO THE SITE TO SPEED UP THE EXCAVATION.  DURING THE PROCESS OF EXCAVATING FOR THE PIPE SUPPORT, THE BUCKET OF THE BACK HOE HIT A 1¿ BLOW DOWN ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIG LAUNCHER.  THERE WAS NOT A SPOTTER ONSITE TO ASSIST THE OPERATOR WITH HIS EXCAVATION.  THE IMPACT KNOCKED THE VALVE OFF OF THE 1¿ NIPPLE WHICH CAUSED PRODUCT TO BE RELEASED INTO THE ATMOSPHERE.  THE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY EVACUATED THE AREA.  PIPELINE CONTROL IMMEDIATELY BEGAN SHUTTING DOWN THE PIPELINE.

column245: VERIFIED THAT THIS WAS A PIN HOLE LEAK BUT IT MAY HAVE BEEN LEAKING MUCH LONGER THAN 14 DAYS AS STATED ABOVE.  A TYPE "B" SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED TO REPAIR LEAK. column245: ON 6/26/08 A FISHERMAN IN BASTIN BAY SPOTTED SMALL BUBBLES IN WATER AND NOTIFIED COMPANY'S CONTROL CENTER VIA 24-HOUR EMERGENCY PHONE NUMBER POSTED ON A NEARBY PIPELINE MARKER SIGN.  FIELD PERSONNEL CHECKED MEASUREMENT METERS AND PRESSURE GAUGES ON BOTH ENDS OF PIPELINE WITH NO INDICATION OF PRESSURE LOSS.  WITH THE DARKNESS ON NIGHT CLOSING IN, A HELICOPTER WAS DISPATCHED TO THE AREA AND THE OVER-FLIGHT CONFIRMED SMALL BUBBLES IN AREA.  THE SIGHTING WAS CALLED IN TO THE NRC (NRC NO. 875467) AS AN UNKNOWN.  THE FOLLOWING DAY (6/27/08) COMPANY PERSONNEL ALONG WITH A UNDERWATER DIVER DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS SUBJECT PIPELINE.  A SUBSEQUENT TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE NRC (NRC NO. 875555) CLAIMING THE LEAK.  A PIPELINE MECHANICAL LEAK REPAIR CLAMP WAS INSTALLED BY THE DIVER AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.    ALTHOUGH THE PIPELINE WAS NOT VISUALLY INSPECTED, IT IS SUSPECTED, AS DESCRIBED BY THE DIVER, THAT LEAK POINT WAS AN ISOLATED CORROSION PIT, THE CAUSE OF WHICH IS PRESENTLY UNKNOWN AND UNDER INVESTIGATION.  AT A LATER DATE THE REPAIR CLAMP ALONG WITH THE LEAK SEGMENT WILL BE CUT OUT AND A NEW SEGMENT OF PIPE WILL BE WELDED IN; AT THAT TIME THE LEAK POINT WILL BE VISUALLY INSPECTED AND EXACT CAUSE WILL BE DETERMINED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON JUNE 26, 2008 AT APPROXIMATELY 1935 HOURS DURING HEAVY THUNDER AND LIGHTNING STORMS, THE BUCKEYE PARTNERS LP (BUCKEYE) UPS FAILED AT PITTSBURGH INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT MIDFIELD TERMINAL (MIDFIELD) CAUSING THE TIOGA PIPELINE CONTROL VALVE TO CLOSE ABRUPTLY.  THE MIDFIELD TERMINAL RECEIVES PRODUCT FROM THE TIOGA PIPELINE WHICH IS CONNECTED TO THE BUCKEYE PIPELINE WHICH ORIGINATES FROM BUCKEYE¿S CORAOPOLIS TERMINAL.   COMMUNICATION WAS LOST BETWEEN MIDFIELD¿S BUCKEYE¿S PLC AND BUCKEYE¿S CORAOPOLIS TERMINAL¿S PLC WHICH ALLOWED BUCKEYE¿S PUMP TO CONTINUE RUNNING AND BUILDING PRESSURE IN THE PIPELINE UNTIL THE RELIEF VALVE WAS ACTIVATED AT MIDFIELD CAUSING AN OVERFLOW OF THE RELIEF TANK.  THE PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE OR TERMINAL PIPING NEVER EXCEEDED THE MOP OF THE PIPING.  AT 1935 HOURS THE BUCKEYE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER RECEIVED MULTIPLE AIRPORT SYSTEM COMMUNICATION FAILURE ALARMS.  WHEN THE ALARM DID NOT CLEAR THE BUCKEYE CONTROLLER CALLED BUCKEYE¿S BREINIGSVILLE CONTROL CENTER WHO TRIED ¿PINGING¿ MIDFIELD TO RE-ESTABLISH COMMUNICATIONS.  THIS ATTEMPT WAS UNSUCCESSFUL AND THE DECISION TO SHUT DOWN THE AIRPORT SYSTEM WAS MADE AT 1949 HOURS.  THE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER CONTACTED AN ASI (AIRPORT) EMPLOYEE AT MIDFIELD TO NOTIFY THEM THAT THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN.    AT 2105 HOURS THE ASI EMPLOYEE NOTIFIED THE CORAOPOLIS CONTROLLER THAT THE RELIEF TANK WAS FULL AND THAT A POSSIBLE OVERFILL FILL ON THE RELIEF TANK MAY HAVE OCCURRED.  WITH THE HEAVY RAIN IN THE AREA IT WAS HARD TO DETERMINE IF PRODUCT WAS ON THE PAD OR NOT.  AT 2107 HOURS BUCKEYE¿S LOCAL SUPERVISION WAS NOTIFIED AND HE IMMEDIATELY ACTIVATED BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND A CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  ON ARRIVAL IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE RELIEF TANK DID OVERFLOW.  ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE.  BUCKEYE¿S CREW AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY STARTED CLEAN UP OPERATIONS.  DUE TO EXPECTED HEAVY RAINS IN THE AREA, BUCKEYE¿S EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR REMAINED ON SITE THROUGH THE NIGHT TO ENSURE NO RUN OFF OF PRODUCT WOULD OCCUR.  ALL CLEAN UP WAS COMPLETED AND A NEW UPS SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED AT MIDFIELD BY BUCKEYE.  BUCKEYE ALSO MADE UPGRADES TO THE AIRPORT PUMP AT BUCKEYE¿S CORAOPOLIS TERMINAL SO THAT IT WILL SHUT DOWN AUTOMATICALLY AFTER THREE MINUTES OF CONTINUOUS COMMUNICATION FAILURE.

column245: ON JUNE 29, 2008 A 1¿ DRAIN LINE ON THE PROVER STRAINER SNAPPED OFF AT THE THREADS AT BUCKEYE PARTNERS TUCKERTON TERMINAL.  THIS EVENT OCCURRED WHILE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEES WERE REFILLING THE PROVER AND PLACING IT BACK INTO SERVICE.  THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEES IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN THE PROVER AND CONTACTED THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER TO SHUTDOWN THE PIPELINE.  THE LOCAL SUPERVISOR WAS NOTIFIED AND THE LOCAL MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO THE TERMINAL TO ASSIST IN THE CLEAN-UP OPERATION.    ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.  THE PROVER WAS ISOLATED FROM THE TERMINAL AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED.

column245: ON JULY 28TH, 2008, WHILE PERFORMING A NORMAL STATION CHECK, OIL STAINED GRAVEL WAS OBSERVED AROUND AN UNDERGROUND 2 INCH VALVE THAT IS PART OF THE STATION DRAIN-UP PIPING. WHEN THE COVER WAS REMOVED FROM THE VALVE PIT, THE PIT WAS FOUND TO BE FULL OF OIL. UPON REMOVING OIL FROM THE PIT, THE SOURCE BECAME EVIDENT. A 2 INCH DRAIN ISOLATION VALVE WAS LEAKING FROM A GASKET ON TOP OF THE VALVE.  THE SOIL AROUND AND BELOW THE VALVE WAS HAND DUG AND SOIL PLACED INTO A 55 GALLON DRUM. THE VALVE WAS REPLACED AND SUBMITTED FOR ANALYSIS.  A VAC TRUCK WAS DISPATCHED TO SITE TO RECOVER OIL DURING THE CHANGE OUT.  ALL IMPACTED SOIL WAS PLACED IN ROLL OFF BOXES AND REMOVED.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: ON JULY 15, 2008, PIPELINE AERIAL PATROL REPORTED OIL LEAK AT APPROXIMATELY 11 AM ON 8 INCH LINE BETWEEN ROCKPILE AND BULL CREEK TANK.  CREWS WERE ON SCENE AT 11:45 AM AND FOUND OIL HAD RAN APPROXIMATELY 200 YDS AND 4 FT WIDE TO STOCK POND RESERVIOR AND RAN OUT DAM OVERFLOW DOWN A SMALL DRAINAGE FOR APPROXIMATELY 200 YDS.  PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED BY CLOSING BLOCK VALVES AND LANDOWNERS NOTIFIED.  LINE HAD BEEN IDLE FOR SEVERAL MONTHS.  CLEAN UP PLAN WAS DEVISED AND CREWS ARRIVED THE NEXT MORNING TO DIG UP AND CLAMP LINE AND START CLEANUP.  TWO OIL SKIMMERS WERE BROUGHT IN AND OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS RECOVERED 525 BARRELS OFF OF THE STOCK POND AND WAS HAULED AWAY BY TRUCK. CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS HAULED AWAY BY TRUCK FOR DISPOSAL.  BOOMS WERE INSTALLED IN THE POND SPILLWAY TO STOP OIL IN CASE OF HEAVY RAIN FILLING POND. AFTER SEVERAL DAYS, SKIMMING WAS COMPLETE AND RESIDUAL OIL WAS BURNED AND ABSORBANT PUT ON THE POND TO PICK UP ANY OIL THAT WAS LEFT.  INTERNAL CORROSION WAS FOUND AT THE LEAK SIGHT ON THE PIPE WHICH WAS CLAMPED AND FENCED AWAITING PERMANENT REPAIR. POND WATER WAS SAMPLED AFTER OIL WAS REMOVED AND SENT TO BE TESTED.  NOW IN THE FINAL STAGES OF CLEANUP AND REMEDIATION.      UPDATE ON 4/22/09 - CLEANUP COMPLETE, THIS SECTION OF PIPELINE HAS BEEN PURGED.

column245: ENID STATION WAS RECEIVING OIL WHEN A TANK SWITCH BECAME NECESSARY.  THE CONTROLLER OPENED THE VALVE TO TANK 602 AND GOT AN INDICATION THAT THE VALVE HAD OPENED.  UPON RECEIVING THIS INFORMATION THE CONTROLLER CLOSED THE VALVE TO TANK 601.  PRESSURE BEGAN TO BUILD AND THE SYSTEM WENT DOWN ON HIGH PRESSURE.  THE VALVE STEM NUT ON THE VALVE TO TANK 602 HAD SHEARED OFF ALLOWING THE VALVE TO REMAIN CLOSED WHILE INDICATING OPEN TO THE CONTROLLER. FINAL REPORT INCLUDES OPERATING PRESSURE REVISION BASED ON ENGINEERING CALUCLATIONS CORRECTING FOR ELEVATION DIFFERENCE.

column245: AT APPROX. 13:30 KINDER MORGAN (KM) NOTIFIED HOLLY ENERGY PARTNERS (HEP)OF THE NEED TO COMPLETE SOME UNSCHEDULED MAINTENANCE ON A HOV.  UPON COMPLETION OF THE MAINTENANCE THE LINE WAS OPENED TO HEP TANK 213.  THERE WAS NOT ENOUGH HEAD PRESSURE TO REMOVE AIR FORM THE SYSTEM AND PREVENT THE KM METER FROM SPINNING.  KM REQUESTED HEP TO BUMP THERE MOTOR/PUMP TO ASSIST IN THE FILLING OF THE SYSTEM.  THE MOTOR/PUMP WAS BUMPED 3 TIME.  1.  PRESSURE TO 250 AND AIR BLED.  2.  PRESSURE TO 250 AND BLED AIR.  3.  PRESSURE TO 450 (LINE WATER HAMMERED DUE TO AIR IN THE SYSTEM) AIR BLED AND LINE FILL COMPLETE AT APPROX 16:30  HEP OPERATOR WENT TO CHECK ALL EQUIPMENT AT 17:10 AND DISCOVERED LEAK (FAILED O-RING)

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 2008, AT 07:00, TECHNICIANS AND AN INSPECTOR ARRIVED AT THE STATION AND NOTICED PRODUCT SPILLING FROM A COLLECTION BOX.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PRODUCT WAS COMING FROM THE LINE 2 UNIT4 CHECK VALVE.  THE PRODUCT WAS FLOWING THROUGH THE SPILL CONTAINMENT TUBING INTO THE COLLECTION BOX AT A RATE FASTER THAN THE DRAIN SYSTEM COULD HANDLE. OPERATIONS MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER WERE IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT.  THE STATION WAS BYPASSED TO STOP PRODUCT FLOW AND INVESTIGATE FURTHER.  ALL OF THE SPILLED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED IN AN OPEN EXCAVATION FROM THE ONGOING FACILITY ASSESSMENT. ALL PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE EXCAVATION. 262 GALLONS OF DIESEL WAS PUT IN THE SUMP AND SOIL ANALYSIS IS BEING CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE IMPACT TO THE SOIL.  GROUNDWATER WAS NOT IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONFINED TO THE EXCAVATION AND CONTAINED WITHIN THE FACILITY.  BASED ON A REVIEW BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER IT WAS DETERMINED THAT NO AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE REQUIRED.    THE STATION WAS DRAINED AND REPAIRS TO THE CHECK VALVE WERE STARTED.  BECAUSE OF THE DAMAGED CONDITION OF THE PACKING , A DECISION WAS MADE TO COMPLETELY REMOVE THE PACKING GLAND.  UPON REMOVAL OF THE PACKING GLAND, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE BUSHING HAD MOVED FROM THE PACKING GLAND CAUSING THE SHAFT TO RIDE ON THE PACKING. THIS CAUSED DAMAGE TO THE PACKING ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE FROM THE VALVE.  THE BUSHING WAS PUT BACK INTO THE PACKING GLAND AND PACKING WAS REPLACED.  THIS IS A PERMENANT REPAIR AND THE VALVE AND STATION WERE RETURNED TO SERVICE WITHOUT FURTHER INCIDENT.

column245: THE BROOME TERMINAL IS A DEACTIVATED/INACTIVE FACILITY THAT IS CURRENTLY BEING DISMANTLED BY ENBRIDGE TO REMOVE TANK FACILITIES, TANK PIPING AND LEVEL TANK BERMS.  UNRELATED TO THE ON-SITE DISMANTLING ACTIVITIES, SITE PERSONNEL NOTICED A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL ON THE GROUND SURFACE NEAR A DEACTIVATED TANK LINE LOCATED WITHIN THE FACILITY.   UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE OIL ORIGINATED FROM A PINHOLE LEAK DUE TO CORROSION ON THE DEACTIVATED PIPE.  IT WAS ESTIMATED THAT 10 BARRELS WAS RELEASED FROM THE LINE.  10 YARDS OF POTENTIALLY CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED, TESTED AND REMOVED FROM SITE.  THE PIPE IN QUESTION WAS CLEANED AND REMOVED FROM THE GROUND.  THIS AREA WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE FINAL SITE RESTORATION UPON COMPLETION OF DISMANTLEMENT ACTIVITIES.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column238: PIGS STUCK IN VALVE WAS HOLDING OIL BEHIND THEM AFTER DRAIN UP TO REMOVE PIGS.
column245: THIS RELEASE WAS NOT DUE TO A LINE OR VALVE FAILURE.  WE HAD THIS SECTION OF LINE ISOLATED AND LOCKED DOWN TO REMOVE 2 PIGS THAT WERE STUCK IN THE UPSTREAM VALVE AT THE FISH STATION INJECTION SITE.  THE FIRST PIG IN LINE WAS A NEW STYLE PIG ON IT'S FIRST TRIP DOWN THE LINE.  BECAUSE OF A DIFFERENT NOSE CONFIGURATION ON THIS PIG WE ASSUME THE PIG WAS DAMAGED DURING IT'S INITIAL LAUNCH AND RESULTED IN IT'S STICKING IN THE VALVE.  THE POPLAR OPERATOR SENT A SECOND PIG OUT AFTER SEVERAL DAYS TO BUMP THE FIRST ONE THROUGH THE VALVE AND IT STUCK BEHIND THE FIRST ONE.  WE WITNESSED NO PRESSURE INCREASES NOR RATE LOSS FROM THE SITUATION BUT MADE PLANS TO REMOVE THE PIGS AND ASSESS WHY THE FIRST PIG BECAME LODGED IN THE VALVE.  CALCULATIONS USING THE ELEVATIONS AND PIPE SIZE INDICATED WE WOULD HAVE APPROXIMATELY 400 BARRELS OF DRAIN UP TO THE NORTH OF THE VALVE TO ENABLE THE VALVE TO BE REMOVED SAFELY.  WE HAD VAC'ED 320 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THE LINE WHEN THE FLOW RATE DWINDLED CONSIDERABLY.  AT THAT POINT, WE REMOVED A COVER ON THE CHECK VALVE DOWNSTREAM OF THE AFFECTED VALVE TO DISCOVER THERE WAS ABOUT 1" TO 1 1/4" OF OIL ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE AND FLOW FROM THE AFFECTED VALVE WAS VERY SLOW.  WE CONSTRUCTED A BELL HOLE UNDER THE VALVE, LINED IT WITH A NEW 50 MIL PIT LINER AND PROCEEDED TO REMOVE A SHORT SECTION OF FLANGED PIPING BETWEEN THE DOWNSTREAM CHECK VALVE AND THE STUCK PIG LOCATION.  DOING SO WAS GOING TO ALLOW US ACCESS TO THE STUCK PIGS AND WE THOUGHT WE COULD PULL THEM OUT WITHOUT REMOVING THE VALVE FROM THE LINE.  WE HAD TWO EMPTY 80 BARREL VAC TRUCKS WITH HOSES READY TO REMOVE OIL FROM THE CATCH BASIN WE HAD CONSTRUCTED.  AFTER ACCESSING THE PIGS FROM THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF THE VALVE, IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO REMOVE THEM BY PRYING OR PULLING WITH A CHAIN AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE VALVE HAD TO BE REMOVED SO THE PIGS COULD BE EXTRACTED WITHOUT DAMAGING THE VALVE.  WHEN WE UNBOLTED THE UPSTREAM SIDE OF THE BLOCK VALVE THERE WAS A WALL OF OIL TRAPPED BEHIND THE SECOND PIG THAT RAN OVER OUR CATCH BASIN AND SETTLED IN THE ADJACENT LOW SPOTS OUTSIDE OF OUR PIT LINED AREA.  WE ESTIMATED IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE RELEASE THAT APPROXIMATELY 80 BARRELS COULD HAVE BEEN POSSIBLE BUT EMPLOYEES AND VAC TRUCK DRIVERS DIDN'T FEEL THERE WERE MORE THAN 60 TO 65 BARRELS RELEASED ONCE THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND WE PICKED UP JUST OVER 50 FROM THE CLEANUP.  THE TRUCKS WERE PICKING THE OIL UP AS IT RAN FROM THE CATCH BASIN TO THE LOWER AREAS.

column245: WHILE MAKING A SWITCH FROM TANK 150-4 TO 170-1 OPERATOR ERROR CAUSED SURGE TO THE PUMP CAN.  OPERATOR SHUT SUCTION VALVE EVACUATING PUMP CAN OF PRODUCT.  WHEN PRODUCT SWITCHED TO NEW TANK, IT SURGES THE PUMP CAN CAUSING OVERPRESSURE.      COSTS OF REPAIR ARE DUE TO HIGH RENTAL COSTS OF 100 TON CRANE TO PULL PUMP UNIT TO GAIN ACCESS TO CAN AND CONFINED SPACE PROCEDURES.  COSTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANUP IS DUE TO LOCATION OF AREA AND NEEDS FOR HAND DIGGING WHICH TAKES MANUAL MANPOWER THAT HAS DRIVEN UP COSTS TO CLEAN UP.  DISPOSAL COSTS ARE INCLUDED IN ESTIMATE.

column245: TANK 1150 AT ABERDEEN JCT WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES ON APRIL 21, 2008.  THE 24" SHELL VALVE WAS REMOVED AND BLIND FLANGES INSTALLED ON BOTH THE TANK SIDE AND MANIFOLD SIDE.   A VENTING MANIFOLD WAS INSTALLED ON TOP OF THE TANK LINE WITH A VALVE AND GAUGE.  THE INTENTIONS WERE TO MONITOR AND BLEED PRESSURE FROM THE LINE IF THE MANIFOLD VALVES ALLOWED PRODUCT TO FILL THE LINE.      INCIDENT   AUGUST 20, 2008, A TECHNICIAN WAS WORKING ON THE AREA AND NOTICED A STAIN ON THE GROUND NEAR THE STAIRS.  HE DISCOVERED PRODUCT ESCAPING FROM A 1/2" PIPE AND VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS NOT 100% CLOSED AND THERE WAS NO PLUG IN THE FITTING.  THE TECHNICIAN CLOSED THE VALVE AND PLUGGED THE FITTING TO SECURE THE RELEASE.  NOTIFICATIONS TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER AND LOCAL OPERATOR WERE MADE.  THERE WAS NO RECOVERABLE PRODUCT, ALL WAS ABSORBED INTO THE DRY SOIL.      AUGUST 21, 2008, THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS EXCAVATED, APPROPRIATELY STORED AND SAMPLES SENT FOR ANALYSIS.  THE TANK LINE WAS DRAINED TO A SAFE LEVEL AND THE MANIFOLD WAS REMOVED AND THE TANK LINE PLUGGED.      AUGUST 26, 2008 PRELIMINARY SOIL TEST RESULTS TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME OF 105 GALLONS OF KEROSENE.      AUGUST 29, 2008 AN INCIDENT ANALYSIS TEAM REVIEWED THE EVENT.  ROOT CAUSE AND APPROPRIATE ACTION PLANS WILL BE FINALIZED AND CAPTURED IN OPIS.     DECEMBER 18, 2008 - FINAL CLOSURE.  INITIAL VOLUME ESTIMATES CAPTURED KEROSENE ONLY.  AN INVESTIGATATION FOR THE SOURCE OF OTHER PRODUCT FOUND IN THE SOIL REVEALED THAT THE MANIFOLD GATE VALVES ALLOWED VARIOUS PRODUCT TYPES TO MIGRAT INTO THE IDLE TANK LINE.  THE FINAL VOLUME TOTAL REFLECTS ALL PRODUCT RECOVERED FROM THE TANK LINE RELEASE.

column245: LINE FLYER REPORTED STUNTED VEGETATION JUST NORTH OF MP 177.  UPON INVESTIGATION A PINHOLE WAS DISCOVERED (VAPOR ONLY, NO LIQUID).  NO ABOVE GROUND LEL WAS DETECTED.  CAUSE PENDING METALLURGY REPORT (POST SEGMENT REPAIR).     AT THIS TIME THE FINAL METALLURGY REPORT HAS NOT BEEN COMPLETED. THIS REPORT WILL NEED TO REMAIN OPEN UNTIL THE FINAL REPORT IS COMPLETED.       DRAFT METALURGICAL ANALYSIS REPORT SUBMITTED FOR APPROVAL 3-12-2009.  FINAL REPORT WILL BE ISSUED UPON APPROVAL OF ANAYLYSIS.      4-13-2009, METALURGICAL ANALYSIS IS COMPLETE AND FINAL REPORT HAS BEEN APPROVED BY CPPL.  REPORT CONCLUDED SEAM DEFECT IN LF ERW PIPE.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: ON AUGUST 10, 2008, MARATHON PIPE LINE LLC'S (MPL'S) PATOKA TO OWENSBORO 20" CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM WAS SHUT DOWN DUE TO A SUDDEN DROP IN PRESSURE FOLLOWING A SUSTAINED PERIOD OF STABLE OPERATIONS.  A RELEASE WAS CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY MILE POST 52.7 OF THIS 138-MILE PIPELINE NEAR GOLDEN GATE, IL.    THE FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE 40-MILE SEGMENT OF 20" OD X 0.219" WT, GRADE X52, ERW (HIGH FREQUENCY AC) LINE PIPE MANUFACTURED BY UNITED STATES STEEL IN 1967 AND INSTALLED BETWEEN MILE POST 25 AND 65 IN 1968.  FAILURE OCCURRED IN THE SEAM, WHICH WAS LOCATED AT THE 2:30 POSITION, AND WAS 38" IN LENGTH.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE FAILURE DETERMINED BY METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS WAS AN INTERNAL SURFACE DEFECT(HOOK CRACK) IN THE LOGITUDINAL ERW SEAM THAT GREW OVER TIME BY FATIGUE.  THE ORIGINAL HOOK CRACK MEASURED 9 INCHES AND WAS ABOUT 30% THROUGHT THE WALL THICKNESS.  THE 4.5 INCH LONG PORTION OF THE HOOK CRACK PRPPAGATED THROUGH THE WALL THICKNESS OVER TIME DUE TO OPERATIONAL PRESSURE CYCLIC FATIGUE.  THE FATIGUE CRACK DUE TO A DEPTH OF 95% THROUGH-WALL PRIOR TO FAILURE.    BECAUSE THIS REPORTING FORM DOES NOT ALLOW FOR THE REPORTING OF MINUTES IN QUESTION G3, THE DATA HAS BEEN INPUT AS 1 HOUR. HOWEVER, THE LINE WAS CLEARLY SHUT DOWN IMMEDIATELY UPON THE RECEIVING AN ALARM.  VALUE OF PRODUCT LOST IS BASED ON CRUDE AT 4112 PER BARREL.    04/05/2010 - UPDATED FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REVIEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE COORDINATES AS WELL AS NAME OF PIPE SEGMENT (MISSPELLING) WERE UPDATED.

column245: ON AUGUST 27, 2008 A 25 GALLON RELEASE OF GASOLINE/FUEL MIXTURE FROM AN INACTIVE SUMP SYSTEM OCCURRED DUE TO HEAVY RAINS.  STORM WATER FLOODED THE SUMP AREA AND ENTERED THE SUMP SYSTEM DISPLACING AND RELEASING PRODUCT TO THE REMOTE CATCH BASIN.  STORM WATER ENTERED THE SUMP SYSTEM THROUGH THE MANWAY CLOSURE AND COLLECTION BOX CLOSURE. THE PRODUCT RELEASED AND CASUED A SHEEN ON THE REMOTE CATCH BASIN.  THE CATCH BASIN OVERFLOWED FROM THE STORM WATER SURGE DURING THE HEAVY RAINS.  HEAVY VEGETATION AT THE CATCH BASIN DISCHARGE KEPT THE PRODUCT SHEEN IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE BASIN DISCHARGE.  SOIL AND VEGETATION WERE REMOVED FOR OFF SITE DISPOSAL.  PRODUCT SHEEN WAS REMOVED FOR OFF SITE DISPOSAL.  SUMP SYSTEM CLOSURES WERE SEALED TO PREVENT POTENTIAL RECURRENCE FROM FLOOD CONDITIONS.  PIPELINE WAS DOWN PRIOR TO RELEASE AND THERE WAS NO DOWN TIME DUE TO EMERGENCY RESPONSE.

INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASED CONDENSATE WAS DUE TO A SHATTERED CERAMIC PLUNGER ON A TRI-PLEX PUMP CAUSING CONDENSATE TO BE RELEASED THROUGH THE VALVE/PISTON TO A SUMP AND A CONTAINMENT DIKE WHICH OVERFLOWED TO COMPANY LAND AND NEARBY ADJACENT PROPERTY.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: BP'S NO. 1 CRUDE SYSTEM WAS STRUCK BY A MONTGOMERY CO., KS, ROAD GRADER PERFORMING ROAD MAINTENANCE ACTIVITIES ON A CLAY COUNTY ROAD NEAR INDEPENDENCE, KANSAS.  NO 1-CALL NOTIFICATION REQUEST WAS PLACED PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT. AT THE TIME OF THE LINE STRIKE THE SYSTEM WAS DOWN AND UPSTREAM VALVE WAS CLOSED DUE TO MAINTENANCE ON THE PIPELINE SYSTEM IN AN UPSTREAM STATION.  AN EXTERNAL CALLER REPORTED THE LEAK TO BP'S CONTROL CENTER IN TULSA, OK. THE CONTROL CENTER NOTIFIED FIELD PERSONNEL.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND VAC TRUCKS WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  THE GRADER WHO HIT THE LINE CONSTRUCTED AN EARTHEN BERM TO CONTAIN THE OUTAGE.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 12:45 PM CENTRAL TIME (11:45 AM MST) ON AUGUST 25, 2008, DURING ROUTINE SITE INPECTION, SUPERIOR TERMINAL OPERATIONS PERSONNEL NOTICED OIL ON THE GROUND CONTAINED IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF THE TANK 9 TANK LOT.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY INCOMING DELIVERY LINES NO. 1,2,3 AND 4 WERE SHUT DOWN, AND THE RELIEF LINE SERVICING THE TERMINAL WAS ISOLATED.  PERSONNEL WAS IMMEDIATELY MOBILIZED TO SECURE THE AREA, INITATE INVESTIGATION AND CLEAN-UP THE SITE.  THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, PHMSA AND WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WERE NOTIFIED.  FREE PRODUCT WAS COLLECTED AND APPROXIMATELY 108 BARRELS WERE RECOVERED (FROM THE 115 BBLS RELEASED).  THE REMAINING VOLUME OF OIL ABSORBED INTO THE SURROUNDING SOIL.  THE CONTAMINATED SOIL (CLAY) WAS EXCAVATED AND 500 YARDS OF MATERIAL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE FOR TREATMENT/DISPOSAL AT A LICENCED FACILITY.      UPON INVESTIGATION THE LEAK WAS CONFIRMED TO ORIGINATE FROM THE 24-INCH TANK 9 RELIEF LINE.  THE LEAK WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 95 FEET NORTHWEST FROM VALVE 301-V-921 WITHIN THE TANK LOT.  AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE LINE PRESSURE WAS LESS THAN 30 PSI.  UPON INITIAL ASSESSMENT THE SUSPECTED CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS INTERNAL CORROSION AT THE UNDERSIDE OF THE PIPE (SIX O'CLOCK POSITION).  THE LINE WAS CLEANED AND REPAIRED USING A 24-INCH PLIDCO SPILT +SLEEVE AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  ALL INCOMING DELIVERY LINES TO THE TERMINAL WERE RESTARTED BY 8:00 PM CENTRAL TIME (7:00 PM MST), AUGUST 25, 2008.    FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT    AN APPROXIMATE 20 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE AROUND THE LEAK SITE WAS EXCAVATED, CLEANED AND ULTRASONICALLY TESTED (C-SCAN) BY A THIRD-PARTY TESTING COMPANY ON AUGUST 28, 2008.  ADDITIONAL CORROSION FEATURES WERE FOUND WITHIN THIS TEST SECTION, HOWEVER THESE CORROSION ANOMOLIES ARE WITHIN ENBRIDGE CORROSION TOLERANCES AND DO NOT REQUIRE IMMEDIATE REPAIR AND THE LINE REMAINS "FIT FOR DUTY".  THE ASSESSMENT RESULTS FOR THIS RELIEF LINE WILL BE FURTHER EVALUATED BY ENBRIDGE AND INCORPORATED INTO THE STATION PIPING PROGRAM AND RISK ASSESSMENT FOR SYSTEM INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: THE FINDLAY OPERATIONS CENTER RECEIVED A SUCTION AND DISCHARGE PRESSURE DEVIATION ALARMS AT ASHMORE STATION. A CPM LEAK ALARM FOLLOWED SHORTLY AFTER AND THE WABASH SYSTEM WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN. SHUTDOWN OF THE SYSTEM WAS INITIATED 36 SECONDS AFTER CPM ALARM AND FLOW WAS STOPPED 11 SECONDS LATER. THE WABASH EXPERIENCED A FAILURE 100 YARDS DOWNSTREAM OF ASHMORE STATION.  THE LINE WAS TURNED FROM CHAMPAIGN TO HAMMOND IMMEDIATELY PRIOR TO FAILURE.  ANALYSIS OF THE PIPE REVEALED THAT THE FAILURE MECHANISM WAS A DEFORMATION ANOMALY THAT WAS CENTERED ADJACENT TO THE LONGITUDINAL ERW SEAM WITH A SHEAR CRACK THAT FORMED ON THE OUTSIDE DIAMTER OF THE PIPE DUE TO RE-ROUNDING OF THE DEFORMATION.    A LONGITUDINAL SEAM SPLIT DID OCCUR, AND WAS THE PRIMARY CONTRIBUTOR TO THE VOLUME RELEASED; HOWEVER, THE SEAM SPLIT WAS SECONDARY TO THE DEFORMATION ANOMALY CENTERED ADJACENT TO THE LONGITUDINAL ERW SEAM. A REVISED FINAL REPORT IS BEING SUBMITTED THIS 23RD DAY OF MARCH, 2010 CHANGING THE CAUSE FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO RUPTURE, LONGITUDINAL SEAM SPLIT.     THE DEFORMATION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE OCCURRED DURING THE ORIGINAL COMMISSIONING HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE TEST. THEREFORE, CONSTRUCTION DEFECT WAS SELECTED THOUGH NEITHER OPTION AVAILABLE IS TRULY REPRESENTATIVE OF THE SITUATION. POOR WORKMANSHIP WAS SELECTED AS THE SPECIFIC CONSTRUCTION DEFECT SINCE THE DEFORMATION OCCURRED DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION AND THE CRACKING PROPAGATION OCCURRED FROM REROUNDING DURING HYDROSTATIC PRESSURE TESTS.     BECAUSE THIS REPORTING FORM DOES NOT ALLOW FOR REPORTING OF MINUTES IN QUESTION G3, THE DATA HAS BEEN INPUT AS LEAK DURATION OF 1 HOUR.  HOWEVER, AS NOTED IN THIS NARRATIVE, THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN UPON THE ALARM SIGNALING A FAILURE. WATER CONTAMINATION IS ESTIMATED AT LESS THAN A BARREL, BUT DUE TO THE CONSTRAINTS OF THE FORM, IT IS LOGGED AS 1 BARREL. RUPTURE PROPOGATION LENGTH WAS DETERMINED TO BE 70 INCHES, WHICH IS 5.8 FEET. DUE TO CONSTRAINTS ON THE FORM, PROPOGATION LENGTH WAS ROUNDED UP TO 6 FEET.  MARATHON REPORTED A SECOND NRC REPORT (#882650) UPDATING SPILL VOLUME.

column245: ON 9/6/08 AT 1400 HOURS THE BUCKEYE PARTNERS HAMMOND OPERATOR WAS CONDUCTING A DAILY PLANT INSPECTION WHEN HE DISCOVERED A RELEASE OF PRODUCT AT THE TRANSFER MANIFOLD. THE MANIFOLD WAS CURRENTLY BEING USED BY EXPLORER PIPELINE TO SHIP JET FUEL TO WEST SHORE PIPELINE. THE OPERATOR WAS ABLE TO TERMINATE THE RELEASE BY CALLING EXPLORER PIPELINE TO SHUT DOWN AND CLOSING THE ½ INCH VALVE THAT THE BROKEN FITTING WAS CONNECTED TO.   THE EMPLOYEE¿S SUPERVISOR WAS NOTIFIED AND THE INCIDENT COMMAND PROCESS WAS STARTED.  911 AND THE HAMMOND FIRE DEPARTMENT WERE NOTIFIED ALONG WITH ALL OTHER OUTSIDE AGENCIES.  THE FITTING WAS REPLACED AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED THE LATER THAT DAY.

column245: ON SEPTEMBER 17TH A T.D. WILLIAMSON FIELD TECH, ASSISTED BY MIDWESTERN CONTRACTORS, BEGAN THE PROCESS OF HOT TAPPING THE WHITING-DUBUQUE PRODUCTS LINE FOR A SCHEDULED TIE-IN TO A NEW SECTION OF PIPELINE. ONCE THE PILOT HOLE PENETRATED THROUGH THE PIPE WALL, THE HOT TAP MACHINE BEGAN TO RELEASE DIESEL FUEL FROM A 3/8¿ PORT ON THE HOT TAP MACHINE THAT HAD NOT BEEN PROPERLY PLUGGED.  AN ESTIMATED 225 GALLONS OF DIESEL WAS RELEASED.  THE TD WILLIAMSON FIELD TECHNICIAN WAS ABLE TO REDUCE THE FLOW FROM THE MACHINE PORT BY WITHDRAWING THE HOT TAP DRILL AND CLOSING THE SANDWICH VALVE BETWEEN THE STOPPLE AND PIPE BODY.  A NIPPLE & VALVE WERE FIT INTO THE PORT AND THE RELEASE STOPPED. A VAC-TRUCK WAS ON SITE FOR THE PLANNED OPERATION AND BEGAN CLEANING UP IMMEDIATELY.  REVIEW OF THE INCIDENT REVEALED THAT THE T.D. WILLIAMSON FIELD TECHNICIAN DID NOT FIELD PRESSURE TEST THE HOT TAP UNIT PRIOR TO BEGINNING THE PROCESS AND THAT HE DID NOT VERIFY THAT ALL FITTINGS AND PLUGS WERE TORQUED PROPERLY AS REQUIRED BY PROCEDURES.

column30: OTHER
column70: A GOUGE IN THE PIPELINE DEVELOPED A 2¿ CRACK
column145: EXCAVATION TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF CONTAMINATIO
column245: THE PIPELINE WAS EXCAVATED TO DETERMINE IF THE PIPELINE WAS A POSSIBLE SOURCE OF GROUND WATER CONTAMINATION. A GOUGE WITH A WEEPING CRACK WAS DISCOVERED. THE GOUGE APPEARS TO BE FROM THE TOOTH OF AN EXCAVATOR BUCKET OPERATING PERPENDICULAR TO OUR LINE. THERE WAS AN 8 INCH STORM WATER DRAIN LINE DIRECTLY UNDERNEATH THE PIPE AT THE AREA OF THE DAMAGE. THIS INCIDENT WAS CAUSED BY THIRD PARTY DAMAGE TO OUR PIPELINE. A DEWATERING SYSTEM WAS BEING USED TO KEEP THE EXCAVATION DRY & NO FREESTANDING LIQUID WAS DISCOVERED. FUEL OIL WAS IN THE LINE AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY. THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED. A LEAK CLAMP WAS INSTALLED OVER THE DAMAGED AREA. WOLVERINE & CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEES PERFORMED THE EXCAVATION AND REPAIR. A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS MADE BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE.     PLEASE NOTE THAT THE INFORMATION PROVIDED IN PART A, QUESTION #2 IS THE DATE & TIME OF THE DISCOVERY OF THE PIPELINE DAMAGE AND NOT THE DATE & TIME OF THE ACCIDENT.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: THE POSEIDON PIPELINE, MMS SEGMENT NUMBER 12740, NEAR THE TERMINATION POINT ON LAND WAS FLOODED DURING HURRICANE IKE.  A LEAKING GREASE FITTING ON PH-5 BLOCK VALVE ALLOWED 1 GALLON OF CRUDE OIL INTO FLOOD WATERS. CONTAINMENT BOOM WAS PUT IN PLACE AND PRODUCT WAS SKIMMED FROM FLOOD WATERS.  THE PIPELINE WAS ALREADY SHUT DOWN FOR HURRICANE IKE.  PIPELINE WAS OPENNED AT HOUMA TERMINAL TO BLED PRESSURE TO ZERO.  REPAIRS WERE MADE TO PH-5 BLOCK VALVE WHEN FLOOD WATERS RECEDED.

column245: CONTRACTOR WAS SPREADING ROCK WITH A SMALL MECHANICAL MACHINE INSIDE THE STATION.  THE MACHINE SANK IN THE SOFT SOIL AROUND THE DISCHARGE MANIFOLD.  AS THE MACHINE MANEUVERED FOR TRACTION, IT FELL FORWARD AND THE BUCKET CLIPPED A ½" NIPPLE AND VALVE ON #3 PUMP UNIT DISCHARGE VALVE, CAUSING THE RELEASE.
