column245: THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED AT APPROXIMATELY 5:30 PM ON SEPTEMBER 4, 2008.  AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY, NO ADDITIONAL PRODUCT WAS BEING RELEASED.      UPON DISCOVERY OF THE PRODUCT, AN INVESTIGATION WAS CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PRODUCT HAD BEEN RELEASED THROUGH AN ABOVEGROUND STORAGE TANK (TANK 1474) ROOF DRAIN SYSTEM.  THE PRODUCT THAT WAS RELEASED HAD ACCUMULATED ON RAIN WATER WITHIN THE TANK DIKE CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE TANK DIKE DRAIN VALVE WAS OPENED TO RELEASE ACCUMULATED RAIN WATER AND EVENTUALLY SOME PRODUCT WAS DISCHARGED TO AN ON-SITE RETENTION POND.  BENGAL DISPATCHED A RESPONSE CREW (UNITED STATES ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES) TO CLEAN UP THE IMPACTED AREAS OF THE RETENTION POND AND TANK DIKE CONTAINMENT AREA.  THE CLEAN-UP PROCESS WAS INITIATED ON SEPTEMBER 4 AND WAS COMPLETED ON SEPTEMBER 5, 2008.    NOTIFICATION MADE TO THE LOUISIANA STATE POLICE REPRESENTATIVE AT APPROXIMATELY 7:00 PM ON SEPTEMBER 4, 2008 AND THE EAST FELICIANA LEPC REPRESENTATIVE AT APPROXIMATELY 7:30 PM.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON OCTOBER 3, 2008 COLONIAL INSPECTOR RECEIVED A CALL FROM A GEO-PROBE CONTRACTOR STATING THAT THEY HIT COLONIAL PIPELINE'S 03 MAINLINE WITH A GEO-PROBE RIG.  AT APPROXIMATELY 11:35 AM INSPECTOR ARRIVED ON SITE AND SAW PRODUCT LEAKING OUT OF THE GROUND ABOVE THE PIPELINE.  AT THE TIME AND LOCATION OF THE STRIKE ULTRA-LOW DIESEL WAS IN THE LINE.  THE INSPECTOR IMMEDIATELY CALL LINDEN OPERATORS AND ASK THEM TO CALL THE CONTROL CENTER TO SHUTDOWN THE LINE BECAUSE OF THE LINE STRIKE AND THE LEAKING PRODUCT.  THE INSPECTOR THEN SPOKE WITH THE OPERATIONS MANAGER TO GIVE HIM INFORMATION ON LOCATION OF THE LINE HIT SO HE COULD REPORT IT TO NJDEP.  AFTER THAT THE INSPECTOR CALLED 911 TO REPORT THE INCIDENT TO LOCAL RESPONSE PERSONNEL.  THE OPERATION MANAGER CALLED NJDEP TO REPORT THE INCIDENT AT APPROXIMATELY 12:00 PM AND WAS GIVEN CASE # 081003-1204-42 BY OPERATOR 33.  THE DISTRICT EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION WAS INITIATED AND RESPONSE EFFORTS WERE STARTED.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORTS CONTINUED FROM FRIDAY OCTOBER 3RD THROUGH MONDAY OCTOBER 6TH.  THE RELEASED WAS CAUSED BY A GEO-PROBE SUBCONTRACTOR WORKING FOR THE ENGINEERING FIRM HANDLING THE NEW JERSEY TURPIKE AUTHORITY'S WIDENING PROJECT.  THE CONTRACTOR WAS NOT AUTHORIZED TO PROBE IN COLONIAL PIPELINE'S ROW.  THE PLANNED PROBE LOCATION WAS 40 FEET OUTSIDE OF COLONIAL'S ROW.  THE SURVEYOR'S STAKE FOR THE APPROVED LOCATION OF THE PROBE LOCATION WAS VISABLE FROM THE LEAK SITE.  THERE WAS NO ACTIVE ONECALL FOR THE WORK THE CONTRACTOR WAS PERFORMING.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY PUTTING A TYPE B STEEL SLEEVE ON SLEEVE OVER THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE.    TO DATE 1372.80 TONS OF SOIL HAVE BEEN REMOVED FROM THE SITE AND SENT TO BE RECYCLED .  AT THIS TIME NO MORE SOIL IS ANTICIPATED TO BE REMOVED.  THE SITE HAS BEEN BACKFILLED, GRADED AND ROAD RESTORED TO SERVICE FOR THE LAND OWNER.  COLONIAL IS WORKING WITH THE THIRD PARTY WHO HIT THE LINE TO RESOLVE PROPERTY OWNER ISSUES.  THE THIRD PARTY HAS ENTERED INTO AN MOA WITH THE STATE FOR FURTHER ENVIRONMENTAL SITE MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT WORK.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THIS ACCIDENT OCCURRED DURING THE TRANSFER OF CRUDE OIL FROM AN INCOMING PIPELINE INTO A TANK AT BARKER STATION.  PRIOR TO COMMENCING THIS TRANSFER, THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR MADE THE PIPELINE FIELD OPERATOR AWARE THAT DUE TO A SCADA COMMUNICATION FAILURE, HE WAS NOT ABLE TO MONITOR AT HIS CONTROL CENTER CONSOLE THE TANK LEVEL 0F THE BARKER STATION TANK BEING FILLED.  THE FIELD OPERATOR ACKNOWLEDGED THE CONTROL CENTER OPERATOR'S REPORT OF THE CONNUNICATION FAILURE BUT FAILED TO PROVIDE LOCAL MONITORING OF THE TANK LEVEL DURING PRODUCT TRANSFER INTO THE TANK.  THE LACK OF LOCAL FIELD MONITORING BY THE FIELD OPERATOR WHILE THE TANK AT THE BARKER STATION WAS BEING FILLED AND A LACK OF COMMUNCIATION WITH THE CONTROL CENTER TO CONTROL PRODUCT TRANSFER INTO THE TANK CAUSED THE TANK TO OVERFILL.

A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE CALLED NRC (#886102).    THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  AFTER IT WAS MADE SAFE, THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH THE SAME STRENGTH PIPE.    KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT AFTER REVIEWING THE ENTERPRISE VOLUNTARY CLEANUP INVESTIGATION REPORT HAS AGREED THAT NO REMEDIAL ACTIONS APPEAR TO BE NECESSARY AT THE LEAK SITE.

column245: A THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR HIT OUR PIPELINE WHILE INSTALLING A SEWER LINE.  OUR PIPELINE HAD ALREADY BEEN EXPOSED AND ITS LOCATION WAS KNOW.  THE THIRD PARTY WAS IN THE PROCESS OF MOVING THEIR SEWER PIPE IN THE DITCH WHEN THEY HIT OUR LINE WITH A TRACK HOE.  THE SURFACE WATER IMPACTED WAS GUN POWDER CREEK WHICH HAD A SMALL SHEEN ON IT WHICH WAS CONTAINED IN BOOMS.     THE SANITATION DISTRICT WHICH WAS LAYING THE SEWER LINE IS INCLUDED IN OUR PUBLIC AWARENESS PROGRAM AND HAD BEEN INVITED TO OUR CONTRACTOR AWARENESS/EXCAVTOR MEETINGS CONDUCTED ON 7-26-07 AND 5-21-08. PREVIOUS REPORTED SPILL VOLUMES REPORTED BASED ON LINE FILL HAVE BEEN CORRECTED TO ACTUALS.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: AN EMPLOYEE FROM NCRA REFINERY IN MCPHERSON AND ACROSS THE STREET FROM OUR MCPHERSON STATION NOTIFIED US OF SOIL DISCOLORATION IN THE AREA OF OUR PIPELINE. THE AREA WAS PROBED AND HIGH CONCENTRATIONS OF GASOLINE WERE PRESENT AND VISUAL SIGNS OF PRODUCT WERE SEEPING THROUGH THE GROUND AND INTO A STORM WATER RUNOFF DITCH INTO A CONCRETE CULVERT THAT LEAD TO A HOLDING POND.  BEFORE THE PRODUCT COULD REACH THE HOLDING POINT THE DITCH WAS BERMED WITH SOIL AND PRODUCT RECOVERY EFFORTS BEGAN.  20 BBLS OF GASOLINE WERE RECOVERED. UPON EXCAVATION OF THE LINE, A PENCIL ERASER HEAD SIZE HOLE WAS FOUND AND A CLAMP WAS PUT ON THE LINE TO STOP THE LEAK.  REPAIRS WERE MADE AND THE LINE PUT BACK INTO OPERATION.BASED ON A CONVERSATION I (GARY HOLLIS) HAD TODAY WITH REFINERY PERSONNEL, THE TOLD ME (GARY) WHEN THE RECTIFIER WAS MOVED OUTSIDE OF THE BUILDING (JUST WEST OF THE TANK) THE CONTRACTOR HOOKED IT UP BACKWARD (REVERSED THE POLARITY) AND IT WAS CONNECTED THAT WAY FOR TWO WEEKS.  SINCE WE KNOW THAT THE ANODE BED FOR THIS NCRA RECTIFIER IS VERY CLOSE TO BOTH THE 8 AND THE 10" PIPELINES, REVERSING THE POLARITY ON THE RECTIFIER WOULD HAVE A MUCH WORSE EFFECT THAN NORMAL.  WHEN THE GROUNDBED IS CONNECTED CORRECTLY THE CURRENT WILL FLOW FROM THE ANODES TO THE PIPELINE AND IF THE CURRENT FLOW IS TOO HIGH COATING DAMAGE WILL RESULT, HOWEVER THE PIPE ITSELF WILL DEVELOP HEAVY MINERAL DEPOSIT (AS SEEN ON THE 10" PIPELINE) AND WILL NOT BE DAMAGED UNLESS THE CURRENT FLOW IS SO HIGH THAT IT CAUSES EMBRITTLEMENT FROM THE FORMATION OF HYDROGEN.  WHEN THE ANODES ARE REVERSED (NEGATIVE TO THE PIPING) THE CURRENT IS FLOWING FROM THE PIPING AND TANK AND TRYING TO RETURN TO THE ANODES TO COMPLETE THE CIRCUIT - SINCE OUR PIPELINE SERVES AS A PATH OF LEAST RESISTANCE IT WILL PICK UP A LOT OF THIS CURRENT AND RETURN IT TO THE ANODES CLOSEST TO THE PIPELINE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: HIGH WINDS CAUSED POWERLINES TO SHORT OUT AND OUR STATION PUMPS TO GO DOWN. DISPATCH DID ESD ON TRUCK LACTS AND CALLED WHITING OIL TO SHUT DOWN, WHICH THEY DID BUT DUE TO POWERFAILURE THEIR VALVE IN OUR YARD DID NOT CLOSE BUT SHOWED CLOSED IN THEIR CONTROL ROOM WHICH THEY PASSED ALONG TO OUR CONTROL ROOM. THIS ALLOWED WHITING LINE TO DRAIN INTO OUR STATION AT ESTIMATED 500 BBL PER HOUR AND CONSIQUENTLY RAN OUR TANKS OVER BEFORE OUR GAUGER ARRIVED ON SITE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 2008 AT 08:00 THE NEW YORK CITY PORT AUTHORITY OPERATIONS PERSONNEL AT JFK AIRPORT WERE PERFORMING A DAILY CHECK OF OUTFALL #12, THEY NOTICED A STRONG GAS ODOR AND SHEEN ON THE WATERS OF JAMAICA BAY.  BUCKEYE¿S SUPERVISION WAS IMMEDIATELY INFORMED AND A MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DEPLOYED TO INVESTIGATE THE SUSPECTED RELEASE.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION BUCKEYE¿S CREW FOUND FREE PRODUCT IN THE IMMEDIATE VICINITY OF A BURIED CHECK VALVE.  THE 12¿ PIPELINE TO BUCKEYE¿S INWOOD TERMINAL WAS SHUTDOWN AND PRESSURE WAS MONITORED.    AFTER EXCAVATING THE CHECK VALVE, BOTH SIDES OF THE SWING ARM SHAFT WERE FOUND TO BE LEAKING.  THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE THE O-RINGS IN THE TWO BUSHINGS ON THE SHAFT OF THE SWING ARM HAD DETERIORATED.    ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE CONTINUING.    THE AMOUNT OUT AND COSTS FOR THIS RELEASE HAS ESCALATED FROM THE ORIGINAL REPORTED AMOUNTS TO THE NRC.    UPDATING THIS REPORT TO REFLECT THE AMOUNT OUT AND RECOVERED TO DATE.     VOLUMES AND COSTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED. REMEDIATION IS ONGOING.    ----------------  UPDATE 12/11/12  VOLUMES AND COSTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT FINAL VOLUME COLLECTED AND FINAL COST. MONITORING WELLS SHOW THAT REMEDIATINO OF DISSOLVED PHASE PRODUCT WILL BE COMPLETED WITHIN 3-6 MONTHS. THIS RELEASE REPORT IS BEING FINALIZED BY BUCKEYE. NO FURTHER UPDATES WILL BE SUBMITTED.

column245: ON 10-21-08 AT APPROXIMATLY 07:15 AM, AN OPERATOR WAS  LINING UP A PIPELIN MOVE AT COLONIAL MANIFOLD AND NOTICED FUEL OIL ON THE GROUND UNDER THE COLONIAL OIL OUTBAND SPILLER VALVES.  THE FIELD CONTROLLER WAS NOTIFIED, LINES SHUTDOWN, TRACED PRODUCT AND IDENTIFIED A 2" BLEEDER VLAVE IN OPEN POSITION. (11-20-08 WRITTEN REPORT MEETS 30 DAY REQUIREMENT FROM 10-22-08 THROUGH 11-20-08).  THIS IS ORIGNIAL REPORT AND SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT OR FINAL WILL BE ADDRESSED ONCE ALL CLEANUP ACTIVITIES ARE COMPLETED.

column238: TANK 452 WAS IMMEDIATELY REMOVED FROM SERVICE, ISOLATED AND CLEANED FOLLOWING THE DISCOVERY OF THE 26-GALLONS OF PRODUCT AT THE WOOD RIVER TANK FARM.  WHEN, OR IF THE TANK WILL EVER BE NEEDED FOR SERVICE, A DETAILED INVESTIGATION WILL BE COMPLETED TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE.
column245: AN INITIAL INVESTIGATION WAS CONDUCTED AT EXPLORER PIPELINES WOOD RIVER (EAST  ALTON) ILLINOIS TANK FARM TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF A POTENTIAL LEAK FROM TANK 452.  THE TANK AND THE DOCUMENTATION WERE REVIEWED WITH PHMSAS CENTRAL REGION DURING A 2009 FIELD AUDIT. THE INITIAL INVESTIGATION COULDN’T LOCATE OR CONFIRM THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE.  TANK 452 WAS IMMEDIATELY REMOVED FROM SERVICE, ISOLATED AND CLEANED FOLLOWING THE DISCOVERY OF THE 26-GALLONS OF PRODUCT. WHEN, OR IF THE TANK WILL EVER BE NEEDED FOR SERVICE, A DETAILED INVESTIGATION WILL BE COMPLETED AND A FOLLOW-UP REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO PHMSA. PHMSA HAS REQUESTED CLOSURE OF THE REPORT AND EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $500,000 IN ASSOCIATED TANK REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT COSTS.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 23, 2008, THE PIECE OF PIPE IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM OF THE PUMP IN PIT 3 FAILED DUE TO A PRESSURE TRANSIENT INITIATED BY A NORMAL OPERATIONAL PROCEDURE.  THE PIPE HAD A PREVIOUS RELEASE IN APRIL OF 2008 AND WAS REPAIRED.  THE RELEASE OF GASOLINE CAUSED A LARGE VAPOR CLOUD THAT WAS IGNITED BY A COMPANY VEHICLE PARKED ON NORTH WITTER ROAD.  THE EMPLOYEE IN THE VEHICLE RECEIVED EXTENSIVE BURNS AND PASSED AWAY APPROXIMATELY 3 WEEKS LATER.    CONTRIBUTING FACTORS:  - THINNING PIPE APPARENTLY CAUSED BY CORROSION ¿ AWAITING ON FINAL RESULTS FROM LABORATORY ANALYSIS.  - PRESSURE TRANSIENT CAUSED BY NORMAL OPERATION OF CLOSING VALVE PRIOR TO SHUTTING OFF PUMP.    INVESTIGATION IS STILL ON-GOING WITH DIRECT INVOLVEMENT OF TRRC. SECTION H (APPARENT CAUSE CANNOT BE COMPLETED AT THIS TIME UNTIL ALL RESULTS FROM LABS/PUMP SHOPS HAVE BEEN RETURNED AND REVIEWED.)        2/25/2011 THE FINAL REPORT FOR THE PIT 3 FIRE INVESTIGATION WAS SUBMITTED ON FEBRUARY 6, 2009.  THE RUPTURE OF THE MANIFOLD WAS CAUSED BY EXTREME REDUCTION WALL THICKNESS DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION (STORK TESTING & METALLURGICAL CONSULTING, INC., REPORT #0073-09-18730).

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 07:30 ON FRIDAY, NOVEMBER, 14, 2008, THE TANK FARM CONTROLLER AT ATLANTA JUNCTION DISCOVERED PRODUCT IN A MAINTENANCE EXCAVATION HOLE AT THE LINE 1 DELIVERY ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LOCAL INSPECTOR, THE LEAD TANK FARM CONTROLLER, THE OPERATIONS MANAGER, CONTROL CENTER OPERATIONS MANAGER, DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECT MANAGER AND THE DISTRICT LEADER.  THE PRODUCT WAS IDENTIFIED TO BE KEROSENE AND AN INVESTIGATION BEGAN INCLUDING CHECKING ACCESS WELLS NEAR THE DISTILLATE MANIFOLD.  AFTER DISCOVERING PRODUCT IN AN ACCESS WELL NEAR THE LINE 2 DELIVERY VALVE (I VALVE) ON TANK 352, INCOMING LINE 2 DELIVERY WAS SHUTDOWN (0945) AND CREWS BEGAN EXCAVATING BY HAND.  ADDITIONAL LABOR WAS CALLED IN TO ASSIST WITH THE HAND EXCAVATION. EXCAVATING WAS SLOW DUE TO THE CONGESTED AREA AND MANY APPURTENANCES IN THE GROUND.  BY 1700, TANK 352 I VALVE AND TANK TO TANK TRANSFER SOURCE VALVE WERE EXPOSED WITH NO SIGNS OF A LEAK. CREWS MOVED DOWN THE MANIFOLD TO TANK 351 I VALVE AND BEGAN EXCAVATING BOTH TANK 350 AND TANK 351 I VALVES.  THE GEORGIA DNR WAS NOTIFIED OF THE RELEASE AT 11:10 AM WHEN IT WAS DETERMINED THAT GROUNDWATER IMPACTS WERE PROBABLE DUE TO THE RELEASE.  AT 1726 NRC NOTIFICATION WAS MADE BASED ON THE ESTIMATED COST EXCEEDING $50,000.  AT APPROXIMATELY 2200 THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED TO BE A FLANGE LEAK ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE TANK 351 SOURCE VALVE ON THE TANK TO TANK TRANSFER SYSTEM.  UPON CLOSER EXAMINATION, TWO BROKEN CAP SCREWS WERE FOUND ON THE BOTTOM SIDE OF THE FLANGE ON THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE SOURCE VALVE.  THE CAP SCREWS ARE ¾¿ X 2¿ LONG PFC^9 WITH 180,000 PSI TENSILE STRENGTH.  THIS VALVE IS AN 8 INCH 150 # CLASS, GENERAL TWIN SEAL REDUCED PORT WITH 8 BOLTS ON THE FLANGE AND IT HAS A 7 FOOT LONG OPERATOR EXTENSION. IT IS APPROXIMATELY 8 FEET DEEP.  THE TOP TWO AND BOTTOM TWO BOLT HOLES ON THE FLANGE AND VALVE ARE JOINED WITH CAP SCREWS. THE SIDE PORTS ARE STUDS AND NUTS.   THE VALVE AND WAFER CHECK VALVE WERE REMOVED, THE BROKEN CAP SCREW ENDS WERE REMOVED FROM THE VALVE BODY, AND THE VALVE REINSERTED WITH NEW CAP SCREWS ON THE SUCTION SIDE BY 0800 ON SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 2008. THIS IS A PERMANENT REPAIR.  THE SYSTEM WAS TESTED AND IS CURRENTLY OPERATIONAL. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.  PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS COMMENCED IMMEDIATELY AT THE MAINTENANCE EXCAVATION WHERE PRODUCT WAS FIRST DISCOVERED AND FROM THE TANK VALVE EXCAVATION VIA HAND BAILING AND VACUUM TRUCK.  PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS CONTINUED THROUGH FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 21 WHEN PRODUCT RECOVERY AMOUNTS DECLINED TO MINIMAL AMOUNTS.  A TOTAL OF APPROX. 167 BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED. AN ESTIMATED 2 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WERE CONTAINED WITHIN THE EXCAVATED SOIL. THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED TO THE MANIFOLD AREA AND DID NOT REACH THE STATION OIL/WATER SEPARATOR OR FACILITY PONDS. ROOT CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE OVERSTRESS OF BOLTS ON FLANGE CONNECTION.

column245: ON MONDAY NOVEMBER 3, 2008 AN ESTIMATED 85 BARREL UNLEADED GASOLINE LEAK OCCURRED AT SPOKANE TERMINAL IN SPOKANE COUNTY, WA.  THE THERMOWELL ON TANK #505 WAS INADVERTENTLY BACKED OUT WHILE TRYING TO EXTRACT A THERMOMETER FOR REPLACEMENT.      THE THERMOMETER WAS SCREWED IN TIGHTER THAN NORMAL, NECESSITATING THE USE OF A CRESCENT WRENCH TO LOOSEN.  WHEN THE THERMOMETER BEGAN TO UNSCREW, THE THERMOWELL INADVERTENTLY BACKED OUT AS WELL, EJECTING BOTH COMPONENTS FROM THE SIDE OF THE TANK.  THE LEAK OCCURRED THROUGH THE 3/4" COUPLING, WHICH WAS LEFT INTACT ON THE TANK WALL.

column245: DIVERS CUTTING PIPELINE AFTER COMPLETING LOCAL DE-OILING.  PIPELINE SPRUNG AT COMPLETION OF CUT AND DROPPED.  RESIDUAL OIL WAS RELEASED AND FLOWED OUT OF CUT AND INTO POLLUTION DOME. OIL OVERFLOWED THE POLLUTION DOME AND RELEASED APPROX. 6 GALLONS OF OIL INTO WATER.  DOME WAS EVACUATED OF OIL AND PIPELINE MOVED APART TO INSTLL PLUMBER'S PLUG IN THE PIPE ENDS STOPPING THE FLOW.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THIS INCIDENT OCCURRED AT A ROAD CROSSING.  IT APPEARS THAT A ROAD GRADER GRADING THE DITCH AREA AT THE PIPELINE CROSSING SCRAPPED THE PIPELINE, LEAVING THREE DENTS AND GOUGES ON THE PIPELINE.    THE RELEASE WAS FROM A FINE VERTICAL CRACK IN ONE OF THE DENTS WHICH CAUSED A SPRAY OF OIL FROM THE PIPELINE.  A REVIEW OF THE COMTROL ROOM DATA DID NOT INDICATE ANY CHANGES IN PRESSURE TO INDICATE THAT A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL HAD OCCURRED BECAUSE OF THE SMALL LEAK RATE FROM THE SMALL VERTICAL CRACK.  THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE CONTROL CENTER BY A THIRD PARTY.  THE FAILED SECTION OF THE PIPELINE IS BEING SENT TO A LABOARATORY FOR AN ANALYSIS AND INVESTIGATION TO FURTHER EVALUATE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED AFTER RECEIPT OF THE LABORATORY ANALYSIS REPORT.    SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.  THE FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS IN REPORT NO. 0129-09-18891 BY STORK TESTING & METALLURGICAL CONSULTING, INC. DATED MARCH 6, 2009, STATE THAT "THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY MECHANICAL DAMAGE IN THE FORM OF A DENT AND GOUGE".  IT ALSO STATES: "SHALLOW CRACKS THAT SLANTED AWAY FROM THE GOUGES RESULTED FROM THE ELASTIC SPRINGBACK OF THE STEEL.  AT THE GOUGE THAT EVENTUALLY LEAKED, THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRACK EXTENSION BY FATIGUE, WHICH PRECEDED THE FINAL BRITTLE FRACTURE OF THE PIPE AND CONSEQUENT LEAK."  THE REPORT SUPPORTS OUR ORIGINAL STATEMENT THAT IT APPEARS THAT A ROAD GRADER  GRADING THE DITCH AREA AT THE PIPELINE ROAD CROSSING SCRAPPED/GOUGED THE LINE.  SINCE THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF CRACK EXTENSION BY FATIGUE, IT INDICATES THAT THE LEAK DID NOT OCCUR IMMEDIATELY BUT AT SOMETIME (DEPENDING UPON SIGNIFICANT PRESSURE CYCLING) AFTER THE HIGH RESOLUTION MAGNETIC FLUX TOOL RUN IN 2005.  THE METALLURGICAL REPORT WAS SENT TO CHRIS MCCLAREN WITH THE SOUTHWEST REGION OF PHMSA ON MARCH 11, 2009.

column245: PELHAM OPERATOR WAS RECEIVING M4 PRODUCT (GASOLINE) INTO PELHAM TANK 211 AT A 5000 BPH RATE.  AT 04:28 A HIGH TANK ALARM WAS RECEIVED ON TANK 211.  VISUAL ALARMS WERE RECEIVED ON BOTH THE ANNUNCIATOR PANEL AND THE SAAB.  PER THE OPERATOR ON DUTY, NO AUDIBLE ALARMS WERE RECEIVED ON EITHER SYSTEM.  NEITHER VISUAL ALARM WAS RESPONDED TO BY THE OPERATOR AT THIS TIME.  THE OPERATOR WENT TO THE SAMPLE HOUSE, AND UPON RETURNING TO THE CONTROL ROOM, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED THAT THE ANNUNCIATOR ALARM FOR TANK 211 WAS ILLUMINATED.  OPERATOR VERIFIED THE ANNUNCIATOR ALARM AGAINST THE SAAB TANK ALARM.  THE OPERATOR THEN SET UP A NEW TANK ON THE TANK SELECT AND CUT TO TANK 214.  AT 06:05, OPERATOR STARTED TRANSFER SYSTEM TO MOVE PRODUCT FROM TANK 211 TO 214.  OPERATOR DID VISUAL INSPECTION ON TANK 211 AND VERIFIED TANK OVER FLOW HAD OCCURRED.  OPERATOR THEN NOTIFIED LEAD OPERATOR AT 06:15.  SUBSEQUENT NOTIFICATIONS WERE THEN MADE TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER, DISTRICT LEADER, AND DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED TO THE TANK DIKE AREA WITHIN FOUR DISCRETE AREAS ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  A CONTRACTOR CREW WAS CALLED TO ASSIST WITH CLEAN-UP EFFORTS AND PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS BEGAN AT APPROXIMATELY 09:00 FROM TWO SMALL POOLS OF PRODUCT ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  IMPACTED AREAS AROUND THE TANK WERE DELINEATED AND PRODUCT RECOVERY SUMP HOLES WERE EXCAVATED ADJACENT TO THE TANK.  FREE PRODUCT RECOVERY OPERATIONS VIA HAND BAILING AND VAC TRUCK CONTINUED THROUGH 11/23/08 FROM THE EXCAVATED SUMP HOLES WITH THE MAJORITY OF PRODUCT RECOVERED BY THE AFTERNOON OF 11/21/08.  APPROXIMATELY 600 TONS OF IMPACTED SOILS WERE EXCAVATED AND STOCKPILED FOR DISPOSAL DURING THE PERIOD OF 11/21/08 THROUGH 12/2/08.  THE MAJORITY OF IMPACTED SOILS WERE REMOVED DURING THE EXCAVATION PROCESS.  DUE TO THE IMPERVIOUS NATURE OF SOILS UNDERLYING THE TANK DIKE, GROUNDWATER IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE WERE MINIMAL.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE TANK DIKE AREA AND SURFACE WATER WAS NOT IMPACTED.  NOTIFICATION OF THE RELEASE WAS MADE TO ADEM (CARY SPIEGEL - HYDROGEOLOGY SECTION, GROUNDWATER BRANCH, LAND DIVISION) AT 12:40 ON 11/20/08.  NO FUTURE REMEDIAL ACTIONS OTHER THAN MONITORING ARE ANTICIPATED AT THIS TIME.  THE RELEASE AMOUNT ESTIMATE, 364 GALLONS, IS BASED UPON THE AMOUNT OF FREE PRODUCT RECOVERED (230 GALLONS), THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT CONTAINED WITHIN IMPACTED SOILS (113 GALLONS), AND THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT LOST TO EVAPORATION (21 GALLONS).  AT THE TIME THE OPERATOR LOSSES WERE ESTIMATED TO EXCEED $50,000 THE EMERGENCY WAS OVER, THEREFORE AN NRC TELEPHONIC NOTICE WAS NOT MADE.

column245: 12 OUT OF 24 BOLTS ON A 6 INCH SMITH POSITIVE DISPLACEMENT METER LID AT THE MIDWAY STATION IN TAFT, CA FAILED.  180 BBLS OF CRUDE WAS RELEASED TO THE GROUND AND SECONDARY CONTAINMENT.      CHEVRON ENGINEERING (ETC) CONDUCTED A FAILURE ANALYSIS AND IDENTIFIED THAT THE BOLTS FAILED DUE TO FATIGUE. THEY INDICATED THAT IMPROPER LOW TORQUE CAN CAUSE THIS TYPE OF FAILURE.  THE METER WAS INSTALLED/PUT IN-SERVICE APPROXIMATELY 3 MONTHS AGO.  AT THE TIME OF INSTALLATION, A TECHNICIAN FROM THE MANUFACTURER WAS RESPONSIBLE FOR TORQUING THE BOLTS.  THE BOLTS APPEAR TO NOT TO HAVE BEEN TIGHTENED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TORQUE SPECIFICATIONS.  THE BOLTS WERE INSTALLED BY A MANUFACTURER¿S TECHNICIAN OR AT THE REGIONAL MANUFACTURING SHOP.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION IDENTIFIED THAT THE LOCAL OFFICE OF THE MANUFACTURER DID NOT HAVE THE TORQUE SPECIFICATION FOR THE EQUIPMENT.  AT THIS TIME, IT IS BELIEVED THAT IMPROPER TORQUE ISSUES ARE A REGIONAL ISSUE WITH THE MANUFACTURER.

column245: ON FRIDAY, DECEMBER 19, 2008 THE LA BASIN EAST HYNES FACILITY EXPERIENCED A SPILL ON THE E-11 LINE, WHICH IS A 12¿ 1440 PSI SYSTEM. APPROXIMATELY 115 BARRELS OF ULTRA LOW SULFUR DIESEL WAS SPILLED TO THE AREA AROUND MAINLINE PUMP P-62, WHICH IS REFERRED TO AS AREA 5, AND IMPACTED APPROXIMATELY 1500  SQUARE FEET OF ASPHALT. THE SPILL WAS DISCOVERED QUICKLY AND THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN AND SECURED. ALL BP AND AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE AND A SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR WAS MOBILIZED TO CLEAN UP THE SITE. THERE WAS NO MEDIA INVOLVEMENT AND NO LONG TERM ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS.  AN INITIAL INSPECTION OF THE EQUIPMENT REVEALED A FAILED GASKET ON THE DOWNSTREAM SIDE OF VALVE V-7224  IMMEDIATELY DOWNSTREAM OF MAINLINE PUMP P-62.

column245: MARYSVILLE PS AND TANK TERMINAL WAS TAKING DELIVERY FROM ENBRIDGE PIPELINE INTO MARYSVILLE TANK 46 WHEN THE SURGE RELIEF SYSTEM WAS ACTIVATED.  THIS ACTIVATION WAS PREMATURELY INITIATED DUE TO FAULTY TANK OVERFILL PROTECTION INSTRUMENTATION THAT INITIATED A CLOSURE OF THE DELIVERY VALVE DUE TO A FALSE HI-HI ALARM.  THE RESULTANT PRESSURE SURGE WAS PROPERLY RELIEVED INTO SURGE RELIEF PIPING AND TANK KEEPING THE PRESSURE AT OR BELOW THE SURGE RELIEF SET-POINT AND WELL BELOW THE MOP OF THE SYSTEM.    COINCIDENTLY, A RELEASE OF CRUDE OIL OCCURRED IN A DEAD-LEG PORTION OF THE SURGE RELIEF PIPING.  UPON EXAMINATION, THE EXTERIOR OF THE PIPE HAD NO EXTERNAL CORROSION AT THE LOCATION OF THE LEAK.  INTERNAL CORROSION IS THE LIKELY CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE BUT WILL NOT BE CONFIRMED UNTIL A PROJECT TO ELIMINATE THE DEAD LEG PIPING IS COMPLETED AND THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE IS EVALAUATED.      A LEAK CLAMP WAS TEMPORARILY INSTALLED TO ALLOW RESUMED OPERATIONS.  MODIFICATIONS TO RTA SYSTEM HARDWARE AND SETTINGS HAS BEEN COMPLETED TO PREVENT FURTHER PREMATURE ACTIVATION OF THE OVERFILL PROTECTION SYSTEM.  A PROJECT HAS BEEN INITIATED TO ELIMINATE DEAD LEG PIPING AT THIS FACILITY.    IMPACTS FROM THE RELEASE WERE LIMITED TO TO SOILS AND STANDING RUNOFF ON THE OPERATORS FENCED PROPERTY.

column245: RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF INTERNAL CORROSION OF THE DRESSER SLEEVE.  POSSIBLE CONTRIBUTORS TO THE INCIDENT INCLUDE A FAILED INTERNAL COATING, THE SLEEVE GEOMETRY, INTERMITTENT FLOW, AND THE PRESENCE OF SULPHATE REDUCING AND ACID PRODUCING BACTERIA.  THE PITTING GEOMETRY APPEARS MOST LIKE THAT ASSOCIATED WITH SRB'S.  THE TANK THAT THE DRESSER COUPLING IS ASSOCIATED WITH IS DEDICATED TO A SINGLE CUSTOMER. WE HAVE DETERMINED THAT THE CUSTOMER HAS NOT BEEN INJECTING INHIBITOR/BIOCIDE INTO ITS CRUDE OIL.  REMOVED A INSPECTED ANOTHER DRESSER COUPLING FROM THE SAME TANK LINE.  THE INTERANL COATING WAS IN GOOD CONDITION AND NO SIGNS OF INTERNAL CORROSION.

column245: ON MAY 17, 2008 THE ONEOK BUSHTON STORAGE FIELD HAD A NUMBER OF SMOKING FLARE EVENTS, STARTING AT 07:41.    WATER AND NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS GOING TO THE FLARE EXCEEDED FLARE CAPACITY, RESULTING IN LIQUIDS IGNITING AT THE TOP OF THE FLARE, AND THEN FALLING TO THE GROUND WHERE THEY WERE IMMEDIATELY CONSUMED.  ONEOK'S INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THE ISOLATION VALVES, FOR THE PROPANE DEHYDRATORS WERE LEAKING,  THIS CAUSED THE DEHYDRATOR VESSEL RELIEF VALVES TO OPEN.  ONCE THE VESSEL RELIEF VALVES OPENED, PRODUCT WAS SENT TO THE FULL FLARE ACCUMULATOR TANK WHICH CAUSED LIQUIDS TO BE PUSHED TO THE FLARE, EXCEEDING THE FLARES BURN CAPACITY.    PHMSA entered this report on 10/11/17.

column245: A 3RD PARY VEHICLE TRAVELLING EASTBOUND ON MICHIGAN HIGHWAY M-86 LEFT THE ROADWAY AND STRUCK AN ABOVE GROUND SCAPER TRAP FACILITY.  THE VEHICLE PASSED THROUGH THE SECURITY FENCING AND STRUCK THE BODY OF THE SCRAPER TRAP.  THE IMPACT WITH THE TRAP SHEARED OFF A 3/4" VENT VALVE ON THE TOP OF THE SCRAPER TRAP BODY RELEASING GASOLINE UPWARD.  THE VEHICLE CAME TO REST ON TOP OF THE SCRAPER TRAP.  THE GASOLINE IGNITED.  AN ALARM WAS DETECTED BY THE CONTROLLER AND THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE NEAREST UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES.  LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS ARRIVED AT SITE TO CONTAIN THE FIRE.  THE HIGHWAY INTERSECTION WAS CLOSED.  A LOCAL BUSINESS AND SEVERAL PROXIMAL RESIDENCES WERE TEMPORARILY EVACUATED AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASURE.  THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED APPROXIMATELY 6 HOURS AFTER THE IMPACT.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THE FOLLOWING EVENTS OCCURRED: EXAMINATION OF THE 2" SAMPLE SHACK DRAIN LINE COMMENCED TO SEE IF IT COULD HAVE BEEN LEAKING PRIOR TO BEING HIT PER THE REPORT FROM THE NIGHT BEFORE. IT WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE CULPRIT, BASED ON THE DUE DILIGENCE THAT OCCURRED WITH PRESSURE TESTING ALL LINE IN THE VICINITY. REPAIR ACTIVITIES OCCURRED. WILLBROS WELDER HAD FABRICATED THE PIECES TO REPAIR THE 2" SAMPLE SHACK DRAIN LINE AND WELDED IT TO EXISTING PIPING. LINE TURNED INTO ZACHARY FROM PLANTATION, LOCAL OPS FOLLOWED WRITTEN PLAN TO CHECK FOR LEAKS ON 20" MAINLINE AND STATION PIPING, 18" TRANSMIX LINE, 2" DRAIN LINE FROM SAMPLE SHACK, AND THE DISCHARGE LINE FROM THE SUMP. ALL TESTED GOOD. MONITORING PLAN WAS INITIATED TO MONITOR AREA 24-7 FOR THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS. ON 12-8-08 THE FOLLOWING EVENTS OCCURRED. AT 6:00 - OPS TECH NOTICED A SEPARATE 2" DRAIN LINE WAS SEEPING INTO WEST SIDE OF EXCAVATION (NEAREST TO METER RUN)DURING TRUCK LOADING OPERATION AT TANK 12. IT WAS VERIFIED THAT A THERMAL RELIEF NEAR TRUCK LOADING ARM WAS STUCK IN OPEN POSITION AND WAS FEEDING THE 2" DRAIN LINE. THE 2" DRAIN LINE WAS EXCAVATED, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE LINE WAS DISCONNECTED AT A COLLAR. THE DRAIN LINE WAS REPAIRED WITH A UNION.     A TAPROOT INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT MPL HAS ISSUES WITH THE TYPE OF THREADED CONNECTION USED TO CONNECT THE DRAIN LINE.  THE ROOT CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE BACKFILLING OPERATION COMMENCED AS PART OF THE ORIGINAL CONTRUCTION.  THE SOIL REMOVED HAS BEEN ESTIMATED AT 5 CUBIC YARDS.

column245: SUNOCO PIPELINE WAS NOTIFIED BY CONOCO PHILLIPS OPERATING PERSONNEL OF THE PRESENCE OF PRODUCT TRACES INSIDE A STORAGE TANK DIKE AT THEIR LINDEN, NJ TERMINAL IN THE VICINITY OF SUNOCO'S 12-INCH TREMLEY POINT SPUR.  SUNOCO AND ANOTHER PIPELINE OPERATOR HAVE PIPELINES RUNNING IN THE SAME RIGHT OF WAY IN THE AREA WHERE THE PRODUCT WAS NOTICED.  BOTH LINES WERE EXCAVATED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE SUNOCO PIPELINE WAS LEAKING THROUGH A SMALL CORROSION PIT.  THE RELEASED PRODUCT REMAINED IN A LOCALIZED AREA WITHIN THE TANK DIKE AND WAS REMOVED WITH A VACUUM TRUCK.  THE LEAK WAS TEMPORARILY REPARIED UTILIZING A MECHANICAL LEAK CLAMP AND THE LINE RETURNED TO SERVICE. APPROXIMATELY 50 YARDS OF SOIL WAS SLIGHTLY IMPACTED.     AN IN-LINE INSPECTION TOOL WAS RUN ON THE SPUR TO DETERMINE IF THERE WERE ADDITIONAL INDICATIONS OF EXTERNAL CORROSION IN THIS 4,100 LF SPUR LINE AND NONE WERE FOUND.  DUE TO IMPACT OF THE PRODUCT RELEASE ON THE PIPELINE COATING, THE SPUR WAS PURGED AND 150 LF OF PIPELINE WAS REPLACED WITH NEW COATED PIPE IN ORDER TO REMOVE THE SECTION OF LINE WITH DAMAGED EXTERNAL COATING.

column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: DURING THE EARLY MORNING HOURS OF DECEMBER 1, GENEVA TERMINAL WAS RECEIVING PRODUCT VIA A 16¿ PIPELINE ORIGINATING AT MCPHERSON PUMP STATION IN KANSAS. AT THE TERMINAL, TWO OUTGOING LINES, LINE 2 AND LINE 4, WERE SET ON ¿BY-PASS,¿ TAKING A PORTION OF THE 16¿ PRODUCT RECEIPT AND SHIPPING DIRECTLY TO OTHER LOCATIONS. THE REMAINING BALANCE OF PRODUCT WAS DELIVERED TO TANKAGE. SIMULTANEOUSLY, AN ADDITIONAL OUTGOING PRODUCT LINE, LINE 7, WAS TRANSPORTING PRODUCT DIRECTLY FROM TANKAGE.   AT AROUND 4:15 A.M. MCPHERSON PUMP STATION LOST POWER, CAUSING THE 16¿ LINE TO SHUT DOWN. TO AVOID AUTOMATIC SHUTDOWN OF LINES 2 AND 4, THE GENEVA TERMINAL OPERATOR HURRIEDLY BEGAN OPERATIONS TO REMOVE THE TWO OUTGOING LINES FROM BY-PASS MODE AND LINE UP THE NECESSARY VALVES TO ALLOW FOR PRODUCT TO BE DELIVERED FROM TANKAGE.  THE VALVE ULTIMATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE RELEASE WAS A BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE ON LINE 2 THAT WAS OPENED DURING THE REALIGNMENT OPERATION. THE BLEED PORT ON THIS VALVE IS NORMALLY LEFT PARTIALLY OPEN WHEN THE VALVE ITSELF IS CLOSED, AS IS THE CASE WITH OTHER VALVES IN THE AREA BECAUSE OF POTENTIAL BUILDUP OF VAPORS FROM PROPANE WHICH IS SOMETIMES DELIVERED THROUGH THIS HEADER SYSTEM. THE PRODUCT LEAKING FROM THE VALVE WAS UNNOTICED BY THE TERMINAL OPERATOR WHEN THE VALVE WAS OPENED FROM TANKAGE. THE PROCESS WAS COMPLETED AT ABOUT 4:20 A.M.  SLIGHTLY LESS THAN TWO HOURS LATER, AT AROUND 6:00 A.M., THE TERMINAL OPERATOR RETURNED TO THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD AREA TO PERFORM A PIPELINE CHANGE ON LINE 7. UPON ARRIVAL TO THE AREA HE NOTICED A PUDDLE OF PRODUCT ON THE GROUND AND DETERMINED THAT THE SOURCE OF THE SPILL WAS FROM THE LINE 2 BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE BLEEDER PORT WHICH HAD FILLED A FIVE GALLON BUCKET AND OVERFLOWED. THE BLEEDER PORT WAS CLOSED, MANAGEMENT WAS NOTIFIED, AND CLEANUP AND INVESTIGATION BEGAN.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: WHEN A THIRD PARTY EXCAVATOR PUNCTURED THE PIPELINE, THEY TURNED OFF THEIR EQUIPMENT AND IMMEDIATELY EVACUATED THE SITE.  THE EXCAVATOR CALLED COMPANY PERSONNEL, AND COMPANY PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THAT OUR NGL PIPELINE WAS HIT.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE THEN CALLED THE INCIDENT TO NRC (# 892262).    THE LINE WAS SHUTDOWN.  AFTER IT WAS MADE SAFE,THE DAMAGED PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH THE SAME STRENGTH PIPE.    THE OPERATOR RECEIVED A ONE CALL NOTIFICATION ON 12/05/08, BUT THE LINE WAS NOT MARKED BY THE OPERATOR BECAUSE IT WAS INACCURATELY MAPPED WHERE THE INCIDENT OCCURRED. AFTER THE INCIDENT, THE LINE WAS RESURVEYED AND REMAPPED, AND NEW MARKERS WERE INSTALLED WHERE THE LINE WAS INACCURATELY MAPPED.    FIELD AND LABORATORY WORK PERFORMED IN 2009 IN ACCORDANCE WITH A CORRECTIVE ACTION PLAN (CAP) APPROVED  BY THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT (CDPHE) AND THE U.S. BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT DELINEATED THAT THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT WAS MINIMAL.  CLOSURE OF THE CAP WAS APPROVED BY CDPHE IN LATE 2009.    DISTURBED AREAS WERE SEEDED IN 2009 WITH A BLM-APPROVED SEED MIXTURE.  THE REVEGETATED AREAS WILL BE MONITORED FOR AT LEAST THREE GROWING SEASONS TO EVALUATE THE NEED FOR SUPPLEMENTAL SEEDING, AND RECLAMATION STATUS REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO THE BLM WHITE RIVER FIELD OFFICE BIANNUALLY TO DOCUMENT ALL ACTIONS RESULTING FROM THE REVEGETATION MONITORING.

column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: ON 12-30-08 AT APPROXIMATELY 14:00 CST THE AERIAL PATROL PILOT MADE AN AERIAL OBSERVATION REPORT TO LOCAL RIGHT-OF-WAY PERSONNEL OF A POTENTIAL PRODUCT SHEEN IN THE AREA OF GRAND PLAINS BAYOU WITHIN OUR LINE-7 PIPELINE RIGHT-OF WAY. BASED ON THIS REPORT AN OIL SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, WAS PLACED ON STANDBY. COLLINS MISSISSIPPI PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED AT APPROXIMATELY 15:00 CST AND ARRIVED IN THE AREA AT APPROXIMATELY 17:00 CST, GROUND INVESTIGATIONS CONTINUED UNTIL DARKNESS AND RESUMED AGAIN ON THE MORNING OF 12-31-08, AND AT 10:50 CST THE RIGHT-OF-WAY INSPECTOR NOTIFIED THE COLONIAL CONTROL CENTER OF THE POTENTIAL LINE-7 LEAK BASED ON THEIR OBSERVATION OF A SHEEN COVERING AN AREA OF APPROXIMATELY 5-FEET BY 10-FEET ON THE WATER SURFACE WITHIN OUR RIGHT-OF-WAY AND ABOVE OUR PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN BY THE CONTROL CENTER  FOLLOWING THEIR ESTABLISHED PROCEDURES. THE INSPECTOR THEN NOTIFIED THE MISSISSIPPI AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER OF THE SITUATION AT 10:51CST AND FOLLOWING THAT NOTIFICATION, THE OPERATIONS MANAGER MADE NOTIFICATIONS TO THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER AT 10:55 CST, DISTRICT PROJECT LEADER AT 10:58 CST AND THE DISTRICT LEADER AT 11:02 CST. AT 11:10 OIL SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR WAS NOTIFIED AND DISPATCHED. THE PIPELINE WAS INITIALLY BLOCKED BY THE CONTROL CENTER USING REMOTELY OPERATED VALVES AT STATION LOCATIONS12+65 AND 2080+81. MANUAL UPSTREAM ISOLATION VALVE STATION 123+18 WAS CLOSED AND LOCKED AT 13:00 CST AND THE MANUAL DOWNSTREAM ISOLATION VALVE STATION 821+66 WAS CLOSED AND LOCKED AT 13:27 CST.     THE MSDEQ WAS NOTIFIED ON 12-31-08 AT 11:45 CST AND THE NRC NOTIFICATION WAS COMPLETED AT 12:30 CST ON 12-31-08, REPORT # 893748. ADDITIONAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE DMR AND ACOE WITH CONFIRMATIONS RECEIVED FROM BOTH AGENCIES ON 1-5-09.     THE ESTIMATED VOLUME OF PRODUCT RELEASED FROM THE PIPELINE SYSTEM WAS DETERMINED TO BE LESS THAN 1-GALLON TO SURFACE WATER. THE SOIL REMOVED FROM AROUND THE PIPELINE DURING EXCAVATION WAS EXAMINED WITH DEQ INVOLVEMENT AND DETERMINED TO HAVE NO CONTAMINATION FROM PRODUCT CONTACT. THE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SURFACE WATER BY NATURAL EVAPORATION.            THE PIPELINE ANOMALY WAS IDENTIFIED AS A LONGITUDINAL CRACK - 1.5" LONG AND REPAIRED USING A PLIDCO SPLIT BOLT ON SLEEVE AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED ON 1-6-09 AT 21:11 CST. THE PIPE SECTION CONTAINING THE CRACK AND REPAIR SLEEVE WERE REMOVED AND REPLACED ON 01-30-09.     THE TOTAL ESTIMATED COSTS AND GPS COORDINATES WERE REVISED ON JULY 13, 2011 FOLLOWING AN INQUIRY FROM PHMSA ON MAY 18, 2011 REGARDING THE HIGH COSTS RELATIVE TO THE SMALL VOLUME SPILLED.  THE ESTIMATED COSTS FOR OPERATOR DAMAGES INCORRECTLY INCLUDED THE COST OF REPLACING THE SECTION OF LINE PIPE FOLLOWING THE ORIGINAL REPAIR USING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE. THE REVISED ESTIMATE OF COSTS OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE, OPERATOR PROPERTY DAMAGES AND PRODUCT LOSSES WERE $870,341.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: A PLAINS CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR AND A CONTRACTOR WERE IN THE PROCESS OF PREPARING TO REMOVE SOIL TO INSPECT AND REPAIR A PIPELINE DEFECT FOUND ON AN INTERNAL LINE INSPECTION(ILI)TOOL RUN.  DURING THIS PROCESS A SMELL OF GASOLINE WAS DETECTED AND THE REMOVAL OF A SMALL AMOUNT OF DIRT INDICATED THAT A RELEASE OF GASOLINE HAD OCCURRED FROM THE PIPELINE.  THE PLAINS CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY HAD THE LINE SHUTDOWN AND CLOSED TWO MANUAL BLOCK VALVES TO ISOLATE THIS SEGMENT OF THE PIPELINE.  AFTER REMOVING THE SOIL FROM THE PIPELINE, IT WAS CONFIRMED THAT A RELEASE OF GASOLINE HAD OCCURRED FROM THE PIPELINE DUE TO A PINHOLE IN THE PIPELINE CAUSED BY EXTERNAL CORROSION.    THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE TELEPHONIC REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  IT HAS NOW BEEN DETERMINED BY OUR REMEDIATION DEPARTMENT THAT THE GASOLINE SPILL HAS REACHED THE GROUNDWATER WHICH IS APPROXIMATELY 20 TO 25 FEET DEEP.  CLEANUP HAS BEEN SLOWED DUE TO WEATHER AND A FINAL ESTIMATED COST CANNOT BE DETERMINED AT THIS TIME.  OUR BEST CURRENT ESTIMATE IS A FINAL COST OF $245,880.    12/9/09.  THIS IS A FINAL REPORT.  BASED UPON THE COMPLETION OF THE SOIL REMEDIATION AND DELINEATION OF THE GROUNDWATER IMPACT, A FIRM AND FINAL ESTIMATED COST TO COMPLETE THE MITIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT IS $565,400.  ALSO, DURING REMEDIATION, 30 BARRELS OF PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT SPILLED IS NOW APPROXIMATELY 100 BARRELS WITH AN ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION OF 5 DAYS AND 12 HOURS (WHICH WAS ESTIMATED WITH AN AVERAGE PINHOLE SIZE OF 1/24" DIAMETER.

CRUDE OIL
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A REPORT WAS RECEIVED FROM A PROPERTY OWNER ALONG THE 16-INCH MARYSVILLE TO TOLEDO CRUDE OIL PIPELINE THAT HE HAD DISCOVERED A POOL OF CRUDE OIL ON OUR ROW.  THE LINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND PIPELINE MAINTENANCE AND SPILL RESPONSE CREWS DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION.  SPILL RESPONSE OPERATIONS BEGAN TO RECOVER THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL AND TO TAKE MEASURES TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF CRUDE OIL ALONG A NEARBY SWALE.  THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A 4-INCH LONG CRACK LIKE FEATURE EXISTED NEAR THE TOP OF AN ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION GIRTH WELD.  A REPAIR CLAMP WAS INSTALLED AS A TEMPORARY REPAIR AND THE PIPELINE WAS RESTARTED THE NEXT DAY UNDER A 20% REDUCTION IN OPERATING PRESSURE UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIR WORK COULD BE SCHEDULED AND COMPLETED.    THE LOCATION OF THE RELEASE IS ALONG A RAILROAD IN A RURAL AGRICULTURAL AREA.  THE RELEASED CRUDE OIL WAS CONFINED TO A SURFACE POOL ON OUR ROW AND ONLY IMPACTED SOIL.  RELEASED CRUDE OIL WAS RECOVERED IN VACUUM DRUMS AND THROUGH EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOILS WHICH ARE BEING TEMPORARILY STORED ON-SITE.    PERMANENT REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE WERE MADE THE FOLLOWING WEEK INCLUDING REMOVAL OF THE CRACKED WELD AND ADJACENT LINE PIPE.  THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE LEVEL UPON COMPLETION OF THE REPAIR.  ADDITIONALLY, TWO UPSTREAM WELDS WERE EXCAVATED AND RADIOGRAPHED WHILE THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED TO OBTAIN MORE INFORMATION ON THE NEARBY WELDS.  THE NEARBY WELDS PASSED RADIOGRAPHY.  THE CRACKED WELD AND ADJACENT LINE PIPE HAVE BEEN SENT TO CC TECHNOLOGY FOR FORENSIC FAILURE STUDY.  THERE IS NO HISTORY OF A SIMILAR FAILURE IN THIS LINE.    THE FAILURE WAS CONFIRMED BY CC TECHNOLOGIES TO HAVE BEEN DUE TO A WELD DEFECT LIKELY PRESENT FROM ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION.  AS A RESULT OF THE FAILURE INVESTIGATION, SUNOCO LOGISTICS IS REVIEWING ITS CURRENT WELDING PROCEDURES TO DETERMINE IF ADDITIONAL WELDING PROCEDURES NEED TO BE CREATED FOR THIS LINE SEGMENT.

column7: HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column238: THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A WELD CONDITION KNOWN AS ¿PENETRATOR¿. PENETRATORS TYPICALLY ARE VERY NARROW AND BECAUSE OF REINFORCEMENT FROM SURROUNDING SOUND METAL, MAY WITHSTAND RELATIVELY HIGH PRESSURE WITHOUT LEAKING. OVER TIME, HOWEVER, THE SLAG BECOMES DISLODGED AND THE WELD LEAKS. ONCE A LEAK DEVELOPS, IT TENDS TO ENLARGE WITH TIME. BECAUSE THEY ARE RELATIVELY SMALL, PENETRATORS THAT BECOME ENLARGED IN SERVICE NORMALLY CAUSE LEAKS RATHER THAN RUPTURES.    THE SURFACE ANOMALIES WERE SHALLOW SLIVERS, WHICH ARE SMALL PIECES OF METAL ROLLED INTO THE SURFACE BUT ATTACHED ONLY ONE END. SLIVERS ARE CAUSED BY INADEQUATE CONDITIONING OF SEMI-FINISHED PRODUCTS THAT ARE NOT OPEN TO THE SURFACE BECOME FUSED DURING HOT ROLLING.
column245: ROW PATROL NOTIFIED OPERATIONS OF A DEAD GRASS AREA ALONG THE ROW ADJACENT TO HWY 225 IN LA PORTE, TEXAS. OPERATION RESPONDED AND NO LEL'S WERE DISCOVERED. OPERATIONS DECIDED TO HOLD PRESSURE BETWEEN ISOLATED VALVES AND MONITOR PRESSURE OVERNIGHT. DISCOVERED A PRESSURE LOSS OF 68 PSI FROM 1230#. LEAK SITE LOCATED AT ENG STAT. 204+19. NO EVIDENCE OF THIRD PARTY DAMAGE. CALCULATED LOSS OF 4.3 GALS. IN OCTOBER 2006, LINE WAS HYDROTESTED AS PART OF ENTERPRISE PI BAP. REVIEW OF THE PIPE SEGMENT REVEALED A CRACK LOCATED IN THE PIPE. PIPE WAS CUT OUT AND SENT TO STORK ENG. LABS. STORK ENG. PRELIMINARY REPORT INDICATED A MILL DEFECT WITH LOW RISK OF RUPTURE. POC IS TO WAIT UNTIL FINAL LAB REPORT FROM STORK ENG. LAB AND RE-EVALUATE. PI-POC MAY HYDROTEST ENTIRE LINE SEGMENT AT NEXT RE-ASSESSMENT DATE AT APPROX. OCTOBER 2011.

column89: NOT POSSIBLE DUE TO PHYSICAL CONSTRAINTS IN THE SYSTEM
column245: IMPORTANT - THE PIPELINE IS SHUTDOWN UNTIL WE RECEIVE THE ANALYSIS REPORT TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE. THIS ELECTRONIC REPORT DOES NOT ALLOW THE OPERATOR TO CHECK INDEFINITE IN PART C.    CONTROLLER DISCOVERED PRESSURE DROP AND STARTED THE SHUTTING DOWN THE PIPELINE. CONTROLLER STARTED NOTIFICATIONS. THE FAILED SEGMENT HAS BEEN SENT TO BE ANALYZED.   NORMAL OPERATING SCENARIO:   1. APPROXIMATELY 8 HOURS BEFORE A SCHEDULE START UP OF THE TWO DIFFERENT RECEIPTS AT REDWASH A PREHEAT IS EXECUTED.  2. VALVES AT REDWASH OPEN ALLOWING LIGHT CRUDE FROM MAINLINE TO FLOW THROUGH REDWASH STATION VIA A 3¿ AND 4¿ 7MI LATERAL.   3. THE LIGHT CRUDE COMES INTO THE STATION AND THROUGH THE HEATERS AND BACK DOWN THE 6¿ TO THE MAINLINE TO ¿WARM¿ THE LINE UP.   4. ONCE THE TEMPERATURE AT END OF THE 6¿ LATERAL AT MAINLINE REACHES 75 DEGREES THEN REDWASH INJECTIONS ARE STARTED WHICH CLOSES THE 3¿ & 4¿ LATERALS AT REDWASH. THIS LEAVES THE LATERALS AS HAVING STANDING MAINLINE PRESSURE ON LATERALS ALL THE TIME.    THIS SEGMENT PIPELINE HAS BEEN SHUTDOWN INDEFINITELY.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column110: METER STRAINER LID AND CONNECTING FLANGES/GASKETS
column245: THE ABSENCE OF A MAINLINE ISOLATION CHECK-VALVE ALLOWED MAINLINE PRESURE BEING GENERATED FROM ANOTHER ORIGINATION SOURCE TO FLOW THROUGH A PUMP BYPASS DEVICE WHICH WAS SET AT 1000 PSI AND OVERPRESURE THE LOW-SUCTION PIPING.  THE BYPASS DEVICE PROVIDES A FLOWPATH FROM THE PUMP DISCHARGE TO PUMP SUCTION, EFFECTIVELY "REGULATING" PRESSURE BY PASSING A PORTION OF PUMP DISCHARGE BACK INTO THE SUCTION, ONCE THE DICHARGE PRESSURE REACHES/SURPASSES THE SET POINT OF THE BYPASS DEVICE.  CIRCUMSTANCES WHICH RESULTED IN THE RELEASE WERE THAT ONLY ONE ORIGINATION SOURCE WAS RUNNING AT THE TIME, THE OTHER, ON WHICH THE RELEASE OCCURRED, WAS DOWN/IDLE.  WHEN MAINLINE PRESSURE EXCEEDED THE 1000 PSI SETPOINT OF THE IDLE PUMP/MANIFOLD BYPASS, THE BYPASS DEVICE PROVIDED A FLOWPATH FROM MAINLINE TO SUCTION PIPING; OVERPRESSURING THE PIPE TO A POINT WHERE THE METER STRAINER LID SEAL AND OTHER LOW PRESSURE FLANGES WERE COMPROMISED RESULTING IN THE RELEASE.  ALL THE GASKETS AND FANGE BOLTS WERE REPLACED, FLANGES WERE EVALUATED AND MAG-PARTICLED, AND PIPING PRESSURE TESTED PRIOR TO RETURN TO SERVICE.  NO PROBLEMS WERE EXPERIENCED UPON TESTING AND RETURN TO SERVICE.  A MAINLINE CHECK/ISOLATION VALVE HAS ALSO BEEN INSTALLED TO PREVENT INCIDENT RECURRENCE.

column126: REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL
column245: ON SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 2009 EXPLORER PIPELINE EXPERIENCED A RELEASE ON A 10 INCH PIPELINE AT COLLEGE STATION, TEXAS FROM THIRD-PARTY MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER WAS CHECKING THE LINE BALANCE ON THE LINE SEGMENT WHEN THE COLLEGE STATION FIRE DEPARTMENT CALLED TO CONFIRM A RELEASE.  THE COLLEGE STATION FIRE DEPARTMENT ISSUED A PRECAUTIONARY AND VOLUNTARY EVACUATION OF APPROXIMATELY 100 PERSONS FROM THE ADJACENT APARTMENTS TO THE APARTMENT CLUB HOUSE FOR APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS AND 45 MINUTES.     AN AUGUST 2008 SURVEY FOR THE APARTMENT DEVELOPER CONFIRMED THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE AND EXPLORER PIPELINE API RP1109 PIPELINE MARKERS EVERY 109 TO 175 FEET WITH APPROXIMATELY 30 INCHES OF COVER OVER THE PIPELINE. HOWEVER, LESS THAN 6 INCHES OF COVER WAS DISCOVERED OVER THE PIPELINE DURING THE INCIDENT INVESTIGATION.      NO VALID ONE CALL TICKET WAS IN PLACE BY THE EXCAVATOR THAT CAUSED THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE.  AN EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS ON LOCATION THE MORNING OF JANUARY 9, 2009 FOR A STRUCTURAL CROSSING FOR A STORM SEWER APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET UPSTREAM OF THE INCIDENT LOCATION. THE EXPLORER PIPELINE EMPLOYEE WAS NOT ADVISED OR CONSULTED CONCERNING THE EXCAVATION ACTIVITY THAT RESULTED IN THE MECHANICAL DAMAGE.     THE SECTION OF THE PIPELINE INVOLVED WITH THE THIRD-PARTY MECHANICAL DAMAGE WAS REMOVED, PRESERVED AND WAS TRANSPORTED UNDER A CHAIN OF CUSTODY.  THE REMOVED SECTION OF PIPE IS BEING STORED IN A CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT AT DNV.      PRIOR TO PLACING THE PIPELINE BACK IN SERVICE THE PIPELINE WAS EXPOSED AND EXAMINED ALONG THE FULL EXTENT OF THE APARTMENT CONSTRUCTION SITE AS WELL AS A RE-START PLAN WAS SUBMITTED TO THE PHMSA SOUTHWEST REGION.  THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION WAS 1 HOUR 7 MINUTES, BUT IS LISTED AS 0 DAYS AND ONLY 1 HOUR AS MINUTES IS NOT PROVIDED IN PART G.3.

column245: ACIDIC CONDITIONS IN THE SOIL CONTRIBUTED TO THE CORROSION AND LOSS OF EXTERIOR PIPE MATERIAL. ULTIMATELY, A PINHOLE DEVELOPED IN THE BODY OF THE PIPE DUE TO THIS CORROSION, RESULTING IN THE LEAK.    UPON REPLACEMENT OF THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE, THE NEW PIPE WAS COATED WITH A PRODUCT POSSESSING SUPERIOR ACID RESISTANT CHARACTERISTICS TO THE ORIGINAL COATING, IN AN EFFORT TO PREVENT FUTURE INCIDENTS OF THIS NATURE.    THE IMPACTED SOIL WAS IMMEDIATELY TREATED WITH A REMEDIATION PRODUCT, AS A CONSERVATIVE MEASURE IN THE EVENT THAT ANALYTICAL SAMPLING INDICATED THAT THE HYDROCARBON LEVELS IN THE SOILD WERE IN EXCESS OF THE ALLOWABLE TX RRC PROTECTIVE LIMITS. HOWEVER, ANALYTICAL RESULTS INDICATE THAT THE SOIL WAS NOT IMPACTED ABOVE THESE PROTECTIVE LIMITS. HOWEVER, ANALYTICAL RESULTS INDICATE THAT THE SOIL WAS NOT IMPACTED ABOVE THESE PROTECTIVE LIMITS AND, AS SUCH, NO FURTHER REMEDIATIONI IS ANTICIPATED.

column245: WHILE GAUGING A PRODUCTION LEASE TANK, OUR PIPELINE OPERATOR OBSERVED THAT A SPILL HAD OCCURRED ON OUR BARKER TO NETTLETON PIPELINE.    THE RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF A LEAKAGE FROM A SMALL PINHOLE IN THE PIPE BODY. THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN REPLACED IN 1989 WITH A 6 INCH FUSION BOND EPOXY PIPE.  OUR ANALYSIS CONCLUDES THAT THERE WAS PROBABLY A SMALL DEFECT IN THE COATING WHICH RESULTED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A CORROSION CELL WHICH LEAD TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PINHOLE AT THE SITE OF THE DEFECTIVE COATING.

column245: D-8 DOZER OPERATED BY A SUBCONTRACTOR CONTACTED AND RUPTURED CPPL'S BLUE LINE NEAR MISSOURI ROUTE 100. THE SUBCONTRACTOR WAS PERFORMING ROAD PREPERATION, GRADING, AND CULVERT INSTALLATION FOR THE MISSOURI ROUTE 100 J6P1004 JOB.    DURING A WEEKLY CONSTRUCTION MEETING IN LATE NOVEMBER, 2008 THE SUBCONTRACTOR WAS TOLD ALL UTILITIES HAD BEEN RELOCATED. SUBCONTRACTOR PERSONNEL ASSUMED A RELOCATED UTILITY MEANT THE UTILITY WAS "OUT OF THE WAY", IN A NEW EASEMENT WITH IT'S ELEVATION AND DEPTH OF COVER SUFFICIENT TO ALLOW THEM TO EXCAVATE AND MOVE EQUIPMENT WITHOUT FURTHER REGARD FOR THE UTILITY.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column241: KENNETH L. LYBARGER, SR. COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 7:45 A.M. OPERATIONS CONTROL RECEIVED A LOW-LOW LINE BALANCE ALARM ON THE SCADA SYSTEM, WHICH RESULTED IN A SHUT DOWN OF THE SYSTEM, INCLUDING CLOSING REMOTE VALVES ON THE LINE SEGMENT, WHICH THEN REVEALED A PRESSURE LOSS BETWEEN HARDY STATION AND WILMOT STATION. SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION VIA AERIAL PATROL AND FIELD PERSONNEL INDICATED A RELEASE HAD OCCURRED. THE LINE WAS REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE AT A VOLUNTARY 20% REDUCTION IN DISCHARGE PRESSURE PENDING DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK. METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS INDICATED CAUSE OF THE FAILURE AS MECHANICAL DAMAGE OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN. THE IMPACTED SOILS ARE BEING REMEDIATED IN ACCORDANCE WITH COMPANY AND STATE EPA GUIDELINES. 1174 BBLS WERE RELEASED, OF WHICH 524 BBLS WERE RELEASED FROM THE PIPE DEFECT, AND 650 BBLS WERE RECOVERED VIA CONTROLLED DRAIN DOWN IN A FIELD CONSTRUCTED TEMPORARY SUMP.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E., COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THE TERMINAL OPERATOR DISCOVERED THE RELEASE ON HIS HOURLY STATION CHECK.    THE CRUDE OIL RELEASE WAS FROM A SAMPLE PROBE TUBING CONNECTION.  AN INTERNAL SHAFT OF THE SAMPLE PROBE SHEARED INTO TWO PIECES APPARENTLY CAUSING A THREADED TUBING CONNECTION IN THE PROBE TO FAIL AT THE POINT OF CONNECTION ON THE PROBE.  THE CAUSE OF THE SAMPLE PROBE FAILURE IS UNKNOWN AND IS BEING ANALYZED AT A METALLURGICAL LABORATORY.    SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.  AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE PROBE FAILURE POINTS TO A VIBRATION FATIGUE FAILURE AND IMPROPER DESIGN CAUSE.  THE MANUFACTURE HAS DISCONTINUED THE TWO PIECE DESIGNED PROBE THAT WAS INVOLVED IN THIS RELEASE.  PLAINS HAS INSTALLED A HEAVY DUTY VERSION OF THE PROBE WHICH HAS A SINGLE PIECE SHAFT DESIGN MADE FROM A 17-4PH STAINLESS STEEL THAT HAS OVER THREE (3) TIMES THE YIELD STRENGTH AND FATIGUE LIMIT OF FAILED PIECE.  IN ADDITION, PLAINS HAS MODIFIED THE PIPING CONFIGURATION FOR INSTALLATION OF THE PROBE, ALLOWING THE PROBE TO BE SHORTENED BY EIGHT (8) INCHES TO REDUCE VIBRATION AND POTENTIAL FOR FUTURE FATIGUE FAILURE.  TWO (2) OTHER PROBES OF THE TWO PIECE SHAFT DESIGN HAVE BEEN REPLACED WITH THE SINGLE PIECE HEAVY DUTY SHAFT DESIGN.

column245: ON FEBRUARY 14, 2009 AT 0741 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL REQUESTED THAT THE PIPELINE BE SHUTDOWN DUE TO HYDROCARBON ODORS COMING FROM A NEARBY FACILITY.  AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE BUCKEYE PIPELINE FEEDING THE FACILITY WAS LEAKING.  BUCKEYE IMPLEMENTED ITS EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND ALL APPROPRIATE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED.    BEFORE PLACING THE PIPELINE BACK IN SERVICE THE LINE WAS PRESSURED TESTED TO ENSURE ITS INTEGRITY.  THE SECTION OF PIPE WHERE THE LEAK OCCURRED WAS REMOVED AND SENT OUT FOR ANALYSIS.  THE RESULTS OF THAT ANALYSIS HAS NOT YET BEEN RECEIVED.    I ENTERED 1950 FOR THE YEAR CP WAS STARTED SINCE THE SYSTEM WOULD NOT TAKE THIS REPORT WITHOUT THIS FIELD BEING COMPLETED.  THE FINAL REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT STATES THAT "IS CONSISTENT WITH THE MORPHOLOGY OF ANOMALIES ORIGINATED BY DC STRAY CURRENT INTERFERENCE".

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: MECHANICAL AND ELECTRICAL TECHNICIANS WERE ATTEMPTING TO THAW THE 1/2" DRAG REDUCING AGENT (DRA) LINE THAT FEEDS INTO LINE 13 AT VIKING, MN STATION. THE WHISTLE CONTAINING THE DRA INJECTION LINE WAS CONFIRMED TO BE GAS FREE AND A PROPANE HEATER WAS LOWERED INTO THE BOTTOM OF THE WHISTLE. THREADED CONNECTIONS AT SUBSEQUENT POINTS ALONG THE 1/2" FEEDER LINE WERE LOOSENED TO VERIFY THAT THE DRA WAS FLOWING. DURING THIS PROCESS, WHILE LOOSENING THE 1/2" ELBOW AT THE TRANSITION FLANGE FROM 1/2" TO 2", A FIRE STARTED WITHIN THE WHISTLE WHEN CRUDE ESCAPED FROM THE LOOSENED FITTING AND WAS IGNITED BY THE PROPANE HEATER. THE FIRE BURNED APPROXIMATELY 15 MINUTES AND DAMAGED THE 2" VALVE AND A PORTION OF THE DRA FEEDER LINE. LINE 13 WAS SHUT DOWN FOR APPROXIMATELY 4 HOURS AND THE REPAIRS AND CLEANUP HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. A FULL INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT ENSUED.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: A PIPELINER PERFORMING A ROUTINE STATION CHECK DISCOVERED A DRAIN VALVE LEAKING FROM A CRACK ON THE VALVE BODY. THE PIPELINER IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER, AND CLOSED THE NEXT CLOSEST UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM VALVES. THE LINE WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME. THE PIPELINER NOTIFIED THE AREA AND FIELD OPERATIONS SUPERVISORS, WHO DISPATCHED A SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR AND A PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW. THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL COORDINATOR WAS NOTIFIED TO ASSIST IN MANAGING THE RELEASE CLEANUP EFFORTS. THE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW MADE THE NECESSARY REPAIRS TO THE DRAIN VALVE, AND THE SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR EXTRACTED ANY FREE-STANDING PRODUCT. LOCAL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL PLACED ALL CONTAMINATED SOIL IN TWO ROLL-OFFS. THE SOIL WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED AFTER SAMPLE RESULTS WERE ANALYZED. THE DRAIN VALVE WAS SENT TO A METALLURGICAL CONSULTANT/LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT, ILLINOIS EPA, AND THE NRC.    REMEDIATION AND CLEANUP IS COMPLETE. THE CAUSE OF THIS RELEASE WAS ATTRIBUTED TO WATER IN THE VALVE BODY FREEZING, CAUSING THE VALVE BODY TO FAIL.

column245: ON 02-21-09 A 44 BBLS CRUDE RELEASE OCCURRED AT CPL¿S BELRIDGE STATION ON THE 31X TO MIDDLE PIPELINE SYSTEM. THE CRITICAL FACTORS INCLUDED A CONTROL VALVE AT MIDDLE STATION FAILING TO CLOSE; THE SJVBU STATION 31X PRODUCTION FACILITY INCREASED FLOW RATES W/O MAKING THE REQUIRED NOTIFICATION TO THE CPL CONTROL CENTER (CC); AND A ¾¿ NIPPLE TO FAILURE. THE ABOVE SEQUENCE OF EVENTS (OPERATIONS) CAUSED THE OVERPRESSURE PROTECTION SYSTEM (PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE)FOR THE 31X TO MIDDLE SYSTEM LOCATED AT BELRIDGE STATION TO RELIEVE SEVERAL TIMES. RELEASE OCCURED ON CPL OPERATED PROPERTY. NO IMPACTS TO HCAS OR WATER.

column245: INVESTIGATION OF THIS ACCIDENT IS ONGOING.  THE FOLLOWING IS PRELIMINARY INFORMATION GATHERED TO DATE:  --A SUMP HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THE ST. JAMES FACILITY APPROXIMATELY ONE YEAR AGO AS PART OF WORK ASSOCIATED WITH THE GARYVILLE REFINERY¿S MAJOR EXPANSION.  THE ST. JAMES STATION SUPPLIES CRUDE TO THE GARYVILLE REFINERY.  --ADDITIONAL PUMPS HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THE ST. JAMES FACILITY TO SUPPORT THE REFINERY'S ANTICIPATED VOLUME NEEDS AFTER THE EXPANSION.  --DRAIN LINES WERE REQUIRED ON THE NEW PUMPING UNITS.  --MPL HIRED WILLBROS CONTRACTING TO INSTALL THE DRAIN LINES.  --THE WORK ON MARCH 10, 2009, CONSISTED OF TYING THE NEW DRAIN LINES INTO THE EXISTING SUMP..  --A WELD ASSOCIATED AT THE TIE-IN, EXECUTED BY A WILLBROS EMPLOYEE, WAS BEING MADE IN AN EXCAVATED AREA  NEAR THE SUMP.    --THREE WILLBROS EMPLOYEES WERE PRESENT NEAR THE SUMP.  -- BASED ON THE COMPANY'S INTERNAL INVESTIGATION, THE MOST PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE ACCIDENT WAS SPARKS OR HEAT FROM A CUTTING TORCH CONTACTING AND EXPLOSIVE MIXTURE OF HYDROCARBON VAPOR AND AIR LOCATED IN THE SUMP AND ASSOCIATED DRAIN LINES.    UPDATED 04/05/2010 FOLLOWING QA/QC DATA QUALITY REIVEW. LATITUDE AND LONGITUDE COORDINATES WERE UPDATED.           UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 9/15/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column245: PINHOLE IN 3/8" TUBING ASSOCIATED WITH THE AUTOMATIC BLEED VALVE MOUNTED ON A TRU-SEAL VALVE ALLOWED AN ESTIMATED 366 GALLONS OF DIESEL FUEL TO LEAK.  THE FAILED PIECE OF TUBING APPEARS TO BE MADE OF CARBON STEEL.  RECORDS INDICATE THAT THE FAILED TUBING CAME FROM THE MANUFACTURER INSTALLED ON THE TRU-SEAL VALVE.  THE TUBING HAD BECOME CLOGGED WITH PIPELINE DIRT AND WATER WHICH MAY HAVE LED TO INTERIOR CORROSION.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 2009 AT 1831 HOURS BUCKEYE PARTNERS DETROIT STATION RECEIVED A CALL FROM A PROPERTY OWNER REPORTING A SMELL OF PRODUCT.  THE STATION OPERATOR REPORTED THIS TO HIS SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY AND A MAINTENANCE PERSON WAS DISPATCHED TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL A SLIGHT SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED IN A CULVERT.  THE BUCKEYE CONTROL CENTER WAS CONTACTED IMMEDIATELY AND THE PIPELINES IN THAT AREA WERE SHUTDOWN.    AFTER FURTHER INVESTIGATION IS WAS DISCOVERED THAT BUCKEYE'S 203 PIPELINE HAD A SLIGHT CRACK AT THE PIPE SEAM.  A TEMPORARY SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AT A REDUCED PRESSURE ON MARCH 13, 2009.  THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE.  THE PIPELINE SECTION HAS BEEN RE-HYDROTESTED AND THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPE SENT OUT FOR ANALYSIS.    ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE CONTACTED DURING THIS INCIDENT AND CLEAN UP OPERATIONS ARE STILL PROCEEDING.    REMEDIATION AND CLEANUP HAVE BEEN COMPLETED. BUCKEYE IS WAITING FOR FINAL APPROVAL FROM MICHIGAN DEQ BEFORE CLOSING THIS INCIDENT. METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS CONFIRMED THAT THIS RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A MANUFACTURING DEFECT IN THE LONGITUDINAL PIPE SEAM.   ----------------  UPDATE 12/11/12  TOTAL COSTS FOR THIS RELEASE ARE REDUCED DUE TO A BOND THAT WAS RETURNED TO BUCKEYE. MICHIGAN DEQ HAS NOT YET PROVIDED ITS APPROVAL, BUT NO FURTHER CHANGES ARE EXPECTED. THIS RELEASE REPORT IS BEING FINALIZED BY BUCKEYE. NO FURTHER UPDATES WILL BE SUBMITTED.

column245: A PERSON WITH THE RECEIPT CUSTOMER NOTIFIED A COMPANY PERSON THAT THE RECEIPT METER SKID WAS ON FIRE AND SAME PERSON CLOSED OFF THE SOURCE AND EXTINGUISHED THE FIRE PRIOR TO ARRIVAL OF THE COMPANY PERSON.  THE FIRE WAS RESTRICTED TO A 3/4" TURBINE METER SKID AND THE CUSTOMER PERSON REPORTED THAT FLAMES CAME FROM A BROKEN PIECE OF STAINLESS STEEL INSTRUMENT TUBING.  THE BROKEN TUBING WAS CONNECTED TO A DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE GAUGE ON A PRODUCT FILTER.  THE FAILED TUBING WAS SENT TO STRESS ENGINEERING SERVICES INC. FOR ANALYSIS.  RESULTS OF THE ANALYSIS CONCLUDE THE FAILURE WAS CAUSED BY LOW STRESS, HIGH CYCLE FATIGUE.    BASED ON ECONOMICS, THE METER SKID IS NOT BEING REPLACED.  PART A OF THIS REPORT INCLUDES AN ESTIMATE OF $175000 FOR REPLACEMENT OF THE DAMAGED SKID IF IT WERE REPLACED.  THE 2" LATERAL THAT CONNECTED THE METER SKID TO THE MAPL MAINLINE HAS BEEN BLOCKED IN AND BLINDED OFF.

column245: AT 1100 ON MARCH 20, 2009, A THIRD PARTY REPORTED A CRUDE SMELL AT LEBEC STATION TO EMPCO'S OPERATIONS CONTROL CENTER (OCC).  THE PIPELINE WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUT DOWN AND EMPLOYEES WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE TO INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL, EMPLOYEES FOUND A CRUDE OIL SPILL, ESTIMATED AT 166 BARRELS.    THE OCC PRESSURE DATA DID NOT REVEAL HIGHER THAN NORMAL PRESSURE READINGS, BUT SINCE THE VALVE BOLTS WERE BOTH SHEARED AND STRETCHED, SIGNIFICANT INTERNAL PRESSURE IS SUSPECTED.  THE VALVE AND THE BOLTS HAVE BEEN SENT TO A VALVE SHOP AND METALLURGIST, RESPECTIVELY, TO BE ANALYZED.    LACK OF THERMAL PRESSURE PROTECTION BY A RELIEF SYSTEM MOST LIKELY CAUSED ELEVATED VALVE PRESSURE, PROBABLY LEDING TO ACCELERATION OF HYDROGEN EMBRITTLEMENT AND CRACKING IN THE BOLTS.

column245: ON MARCH 29, 2009 AT 07:49 THE ILI AND SPHERE LAUNCHER DOOR ASSOCIATED WITH THE 24 INCH PIPELINE AT EXPLORER PIPELINES WOOD RIVER TANK FARM EXPERIENCED A RELEASE OF 252 BARRELS OF RAFFINATE. THE DURATION OF THE RELEASE IS LISTED IN PART G.3. AS 0 HOURS. HOWEVER, THE DURATION WAS 4 MINUTES BASED ON SCADA RECORDS THAT INDICATE THE LAUNCHER BARREL WAS ISOLATED FROM THE PIPELINE IN 4 MINUTES. A MAY 8, 2009 CAUSATION REPORT INDICATES THE FAILURE OF THE BOTTOM YOKE BOLT AND OR NUT CAUSED THE ILI AND SPHERE LAUNCHER COVER TO MOVE SLIGHTLY DAMAGING THE O-RING.  A COPY OF THE MAY 8, 2009 CAUSATION REPORT WAS PROVIDED TO THE PHMSA CENTRAL REGION.

HOWEVER, SINCE THIS WAS A "BACK OF THE ENVELOPE" CALCULATION BASED ON KNOWN INFORMATION, THE LEAK DURATION WAS ROUNDED TO AN EVEN 7 DAYS. CAUSE OF RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE A CRACK IN A DENT THAT FAILED DUE TO CORROSION FATIGUE. THE DENT WAS LIKELY A RESULT OF PIPELINE INSTALLATION, WHICH OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 35 YEARS AGO.

column245: ON 4-9-09 AT 11:32 AM, WHILE CONDUCTING INVESTIGATION OF POTENTIAL LEAK POINT, WITHIN MIXED IN-PLANT PIPING SYTEMS (BOTH POTENTIAL JURISDICTIONAL AND NON JURISDICTIONAL) DETERMINED LEAK TO BE ON A BREAKOUT TANK LINE (TANK 130-7) AT A MITERED WELDED JOINT.  THE CAUSE IS CURRENTLY UNDER FINAL REVIEW BUT INDICATIONS THROUGH VISUAL INSPECTIONS POTENTIAL COULD BE "STRESS CRACKING".  FURTHER MORE, A REVIEW OF ANY STRESS ON THESE SYSTEMS IS UNDERWAY.  THE LINE WAS TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE, GAS FREED, AND THE DAMAGED WELD WAS REMOVED WITH REPLACEMENT OF MANUFACTURED FITTING AND PUPS INSTALLED WITH HYDRO AND 100% X-RAY.       ALL RECORDS AVAILABLE IN PROJECT FILE WITH MAINTENANCE.    UPON DETERMINATION ON 4-9-09, THE TRRC (AND NRC) WAS NOTIFIED OF INCIDENT.  ON 4-9-09 MR. RICKY DANIELS WITH THE TRRC WAS ON SITE TO REVIEW THE TANK LINE.

TANK IS BEING EMPTIED SO THAT A CAUSE FOR THE TANK ROOF FAILURE COULD BE DETERMINED.  TANK DIKE DRAIN WAS LEFT IN A PARTIALLY OPENED STATUS, THIS IS ALSO BEING INVESTIGATED. column89: NOT POSSIBLE DUE TO PHYSICAL CONSTRAINTS IN THE SYSTEM
column245: VINTAGE PRODUCTION CALIFORNIA LLC  ACQUIRED THE SANSINENA PROPERTY IN NOVEMBER 2006 AND IS THE FIFTH OPERATING COMPANY IN 15 YEARS. FIELD RECORDS INDICATE THE PIPELINE FROM SITE #8 TO SITE #9 WAS INSTALLED IN THE 1950¿S. THIS PIPELINE HAS BEEN USED BY PREVIOUS OPERATORS FOR TRANSPORTATION OF VARIOUS PROCESSES FLUIDS INCLUDING PRODUCED WATER PRIOR PRESENT USE AS AN OIL PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY HYDRO-TESTED ON APRIL 3, 2009 BY AN APPROVED HYDROSTATIC TEST COMPANY (CSFM TEST ID# 09-02268.), PREVENTIVE MEASURES INCLUDES EXTERNAL CORROSION PROTECTION BY IMPRESS CURRENT AND CHEMICAL CORROSION TREATMENT..  ULTRASONIC THICKNESS INSPECTION ON THE PIPELINE WALL SHOWED THREE ISOLATED PITS AT THE AREA OF THE LEAK. IT IS LIKELY THAT THE DEEP CORROSION PITTING WAS A RESULT OF PREVIOUS SERVICE SUCH AS PRODUCED WATER.

column245: MAY 13, 2009    THE 6" PIPELINE RUNNING FROM THE REFINERY TO THE HOCKING VALLEY DOCK WAS USED FOR A TRANSFER OF MATERIAL ON APRIL 3, 2009, AND THEN LEFT LIQUID FULL.  SUNOCO FIRST NOTICED UNUSUAL LEVELS OF OIL IN PRE-EXISTING REMEDIATION WELLS AT THE SITE ON APRIL 7, 2009.  THOSE WELLS ARE IN PLACE TO REMEDIATE A MARCH 18, 2008 RELEASE FROM AN 8" PIPELINE THAT ALSO RUNS FROM THE REFINERY TO THE HOCKING VALLEY DOCK.  SUNOCO RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 94 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THOSE WELLS BETWEEN APRIL 7 AND APRIL 14, BUT SOME PORTION OF THAT MATERIAL LIKELY RESULTED FROM THE 2008 RELEASE.   ON TUESDAY APRIL 14, 2009 SUNOCO CONDUCTED AN IN-SERVICE TEST ON THE 6" PIPELINE THAT CONFIRMED A LEAK IN THAT LINE.  RECORDS INDICATE THAT 114 BARRELS OF MATERIAL WAS RELEASED DURING THE TEST.      BETWEEN APRIL 14 AND APRIL 27 SUNOCO HAS RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 218 BARRELS OF OIL FROM THE REMEDIATION WELLS WHICH APPEARS TO BE MOSTLY FROM THE 2009 RELEASE.  ADDITIONAL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED IN THE CONTAMINATED SOIL AND DEBRIS THAT WAS REMOVED FROM THE SPILL SITE.  SUNOCO BELIEVES THAT THE LEAK IN THE 6" PIPELINE BEGAN AFTER THE APRIL 3, 2009 TRANSFER AS NO APPRECIABLE LEVELS OF OIL WERE NOTICED IN THE MONITORING WELLS DURING THE MONITORING EVENT ON MARCH 31, 2009.  BASED ON ALL THE AVAILABLE DATA, SUNOCO BELIEVES THAT BETWEEN APPROXIMATELY 218 AND 320 BARRELS OF OIL LEAKED AND WAS RECOVERED.    --------------  AUGUST 5, 2009    IN RESPONSE TO THE RELEASE, THE PIPELINE WAS IDLED AND THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE WAS REPLACED.  A FORENSIC INSPECTION WAS PERFORMED ON THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE BY KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES, INC.  THE FAILURE WAS FOUND TO BE LOCATED AT A CIRCUMFERENTIALLY ORIENTED CRACK ADJACENT TO A GIRTH WELD JOINING A LENGTH OF LINE PIPE TO A TRIMMED ELBOW FITTING.  THE CRACK WAS CAUSED BY FATIGUE RESULTING FROM THERMAL EXPANSION AS THE PIPELINE WAS CYCLED BETWEEN NORMAL OPERATING TEMPERATURE AND AMBIENT GROUND TEMPERATURE DURING IDLE PERIODS.  THE PIPELINE WAS DE-INVENTORIED AND PURGED WITH NITROGEN.  THERE ARE CURRENTLY NO PLANS TO RETURN THE PIPELINE TO SERVICE.    **UPDATE MADE BY PHMSA ON 4/18/2014 PER DAVID ELLIS ON 3/25/14**  *THE INITIAL REPORT WAS AMENDED TO SHOW A CAUSE CODE UNDER H2, WHICH POINTS TO TEMPERATURE BEING AT FAULT.  THE COMMENTS UNDER "OTHER" (H8) HAVE BEEN REMOVED.  3/25/14 DAVID ELLIS

column238: THIS WAS NOT A PRODUCT RELEASE. THE DEAD VEGETATION WAS DUE TO DECOMPOSITION. SEE NARRATIVE DESCRIPTION.
column245: A COMPANY EMPLOYEE DISCOVERED THE RELEASE DURING A ROUTINE R/W PATROL.  THE EMPLOYEE CONTACTED HIS SUPERVISOR IMMEDIATELY AND BUCKEYE'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN WAS ACTIVATED. A SECTION OF PIPELINE HAS BEEN REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH CERTIFIED REPLACEMENT PIPE. ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE NOTIFIED AND THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK IN SERVICE. UPDATE: AN INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT HAS DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS NO PRODUCT RELEASE. THE SUSPECT PIPE WAS PRESSURE TESTED WITH NITROGEN BEFORE BEING CUT OUT AND NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. AFTER THE REMOVED PIPE WAS CUT OUT IT WAS TESTED WITH HELIUM AND NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. THE REMOVED PIPE WAS THEN HYDROTESTED WITH WATER AND AGAIN NO LEAKS WERE DETECTED. IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT DREDGE MATERIAL FROM THE CANAL HAD BEEN DEPOSITED ON THE RIGHT OF WAY IN THE PAST. THE DECOMPOSITION OF THIS MATERIAL GENERATED SWAMP GAS WHICH GAVE THE INDICATIONS OF A PRODUCT RELEASE.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: TECHNICIANS  WERE PERFORMING MAINTENANCE ON A RELIEF VALVE ON THE EAST GAS MANIFOLD PLAN.  THE VALVE WAS NOT PROPERLY ISOLATED FROM A LINE TO THE FACILITY TRANSMIX TANK.  A CHANGE FROM 74 TO 61 GRADE CAME THROUGH THE FACILITY.  THE CONTROL CENTER DIRECTED THE CHANGE THOUGH THE WEST SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD ONLY.  THIRTY MINUTES AFTER THE CHANGE CAME THROUGH THE FACILITY, THE CONTROLLER BEGAN USING THE EAST OIL SIDE OF THE MANIFOLD WHICH CAUSED THE SYSTEM TO AUTOMATICALLY WASH THE MANIFOLD TO THE TRANSMIX TANK.  THIS CAUSED PRODUCT TO FLOW BACK ON THE SEGMENT THE TECHNICIANS HAD OPEN VIA THE TRANSMIX LINE AND ALLOWED PRODUCT TO ESCAPE.  THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM  THE ADJACENT SHIPPER STATING HE SAW PRODUCT SPRAYING.  THE CONTROLLER CONTACTED THE FACILITY. WITHIN THAT TIME PERIOD THE WASH WAS COMPLETED AND FLOW DOWN THAT SEGMENT STOPPED.  LOCAL OPERATIONS MADE THE NECESSARY CALLS AND ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ENSUED. APPROXIMATELY 67 BARRELS WERE TICKETED DOWN THE LINE.  TECHNICIANS DETERMINED 40 BARRELS WENT TO THE SUMP VIA TWO OPEN DRAIN LINES THAT WERE USED TO DRAIN THE SEGMENT THEY WERE WORKING ON, APPROXIMATELY 10 BARRELS WERE RELEASED AND APPROXIMATELY 17 BARRELS REMAINING IN THE LINE.    ASSESSMENT AND CLEANUP ACTIVITIES DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASED PRODUCT SPREAD WITHIN AN AREA MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 50 X 50 FEET WITHIN THE MANIFOLD.  ACCESS TO THE MAJORITY OF THE IMPACTED AREA WAS LIMITED BY ABOVEGROUND PIPING AND CATWALKS. ASSESSMENT ACTIVITIES DETERMINED THAT THE RELEASED PRODUCT PENETRATED UP TO 5 FEET DEEP WITHIN THE SANDY SOILS OF THE MANIFOLD AND THAT NO GROUNDWATER OR SURFACE WATER WAS IMPACTED.  ALL ACCESSIBLE IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF AT AN APPROVED LANDFILL.  A LARGE PORTION OF THE CONTAMINATED SOILS COULD NOT BE EXCAVATED DUE TO THE OVERHEAD PIPING AND CONCRETE PIERS WITHIN THE IMPACTED AREA.  ALTERNATIVE REMEDIAL METHODS HAVE BEEN NEGOTIATED WITH SCDHEC FOR THE REMAINING IMPACTED SOILS.  THE STATE DHEC OFFICE WAS CONTACTED ON FRIDAY AT 8:20.    A LOCAL REPRESENTATIVE (DEE DETWILER) VISITED THE FACILITY AND MET WITH THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER.  MR. DETWILER APPROVED OF COLONIAL¿S RESPONSE EFFORTS. APPROXIMATELY TEN GALLONS OF FREE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED. AN ESTIMATED TOTAL OF 330 TONS OF SOIL WAS IMPACTED BY THE RELEASE. APPROXIMATELY 97 TONS OF IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED AND DISPOSED OF AT AN APPROVED LANDFILL. PRODUCT IN SOIL CALCULATIONS BASED ON ANALYITICAL RESULTS FOR DIESEL RANGE ORGANICS (DRO) IN THE IMPACTED SOIL DETERMINED A VOLUME OF 442 GALLONS IN THE IMPACTED SOIL. THE VOLUME RECOVERED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL WAS CALCULATED TO BE APPROXIMATELY 130 GALLONS.

column245: TANK 170-4 WAS CLEANED AND THEN PREPARED FOR IN-SERVCIE.  THE TANK WAS FILLED USING THE B LINE AND THE E VALVE CONTINUED IN CLOSED POSITION.  UPON INTIAL MOVEMENT FROM TANK AFTER CLEANING, THE E VALVE WAS OPENED WITHOUT FOLLOWING THE "SLOW FILL" PROCESS TO ENSURE LINE PACK PRIOR TO OPENING FULL OPEN.  IN GENERAL, THE SURGE ON THIS LINE EXCEEDED MOP (HYDRAULIC STUDY RANGES FROM 300 TO 400 PSI POTENTIAL) AND SPLIT THE FLANGES.  THE PRODUCT WAS RELEASED FROM FLANGES AND IDENTIFIED BY OPERATIONS THROUGH TANK LEVEL INIDICATION.  OPERATIONS IDENTIFIED RELEASE, CLOSED E VALVE ON TANK AND RELEASE STOPPED.  PRODUCT WAS IN CONTAINMENT AROUND TANK AREAS.  DUE TO HEAVY RAINS THE DAY BEFORE, PRODUCT WAS FLOATING ON RAIN WATER ALLOWING FOR FULL RECOVERY.  NEW FLANGE GASKET INSTALLED, SYSTEM TESTED AND PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.  INVESTIGATION REPORT ON FILE AT LOCATION.

column245: ON FRIDAY APRIL 24, 2009, PROPANE WAS BEING INTRODUCED INTO THE 12" EASTERN DELIVERY SYSTEM (EDS) PIPELINE AS A PART OF THE PREPARATION PROCESS FOR RUNNING AN MFL INTERNAL INSPECTION TOOL.  THE PIPELINE WAS PREVIOUSLY OUT OF SERVICE AND WITHOUT SCHEDULED PRODUCT MOVEMENTS AS A RESULT OF A RELOCATION PROJECT ASSOCIATED WITH HIGHWAY CONSTRUCTION. AT 1800 ON APRIL 24, 2009, GREEN SPRINGS PERSONNEL RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE SARNIA CONTROL CENTER REPORTING A LEAK ON THE EASTERN DELIVERY SYSTEM (EDS) AT MP 86.5.  SIMULTANEOUSLY, FIELD PERSONNEL, AT THE ANDERSON ROAD CROSSING TO TRACK THE MOVEMENT OF A SQUEEGEE PIG AT THE PROPANE /NITROGEN INTERFACE, WERE APPROACHED BY A HOME OWNER WHO REPORTED THE SMELL OF PROPANE IN THE VICINITY. FIELD PERSONNEL AND THE HOME OWNER IDENTIFIED A VAPOR CLOUD CONTAINED IN AN OPEN FIELD ON THE WEST SIDE OF ANDERSON ROAD. FURTHER INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THE VAPOR CLOUD TO BE VAPORIZED LIQUID PROPANE.  FIELD PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED GREEN SPRINGS OF THE LEAK AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIVITIES WERE COMMENCED.  RESPONSE ACTIVITIES INCLUDED THE EVACUATION OF LOCAL RESIDENTS IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK LOCATION.  SIGNS OF THE VISIBLE RELEASE STOPPED ON APRIL 26, 2009 AS THE GROUND IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK FROZE OVER MINIMIZING THE FURTHER ESCAPE OF PRODUCT.  STOPPLES AND BLOCK VALVES WERE INSTALLED BOTH UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM TO COMPLETELY ISOLATE THE LEAK POINT ON THE PIPELINE.  COMPANY PERSONNEL REMAINED ON SITE TO MONITOR THE SITUATION CONTINUOUSLY FROM THE TIME OF DISCOVERY UNTIL 1800 ON MAY 3, 2009 WHEN THE AREA WAS DEEMED SAFE AND NO THREAT TO PEOPLE OR ENVIRONMENT REMAINED.  EXCAVATION OF THE LEAK SITE TOOK PLACE ON MAY 12, 2009 AND A 0.25" DIAMETER HOLE WAS OBSERVED ON THE TOPSIDE OF THE PIPE.  THE PIPE SEGMENT WAS REMOVED FOR DETAILED METALLURGICAL EVALUATION.  METALLURGICAL EVALUATION RESULTS INDICATE THAT THE CAUSE OF THE PIPE PERFORATION WAS A HIGH VOLTAGE ARC DISCHARGING ENERGY FROM THE PIPE WALL TO GROUND AND IS ATTRIBUTABLE TO ENERGY SOURCES SUCH AS LIGHTNING STRIKE.

column245: ON MAY 6, 2009 A TECHNICIAN DISCOVERED 2-3" OF OIL IN AN ACCESS WELL NEAR THE SAMPLE HOUSE AT CHANTILLY STATION. APPROPRIATE NOTIFICATIONS WERE CONDUCTED AND LINE 04 SHUT DOWN AS A PRECAUTION.  INVESTIGATION AND EXCAVATION BEGAN WITH A TOTAL OF 4 GALLONS RECOVERED FROM THE ACCESS WELL.  EVENING EFFORTS VERIFIED LINE 04 WAS NOT THE LEAK SOURCE AND THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS AT 20:35.  TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED AT 8AM ON MAY 7, 2009 WERE 49 GALLONS.  REQUIRED AGENCY NOTIFICATIONS WERE COMPLETED.  THE INVESTIGATION CONTINUED, INCLUDING VERIFICATION THAT LINE 28A WAS NOT THE SOURCE AND IT WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS AT 13:00.  THE STATION YARD DRAIN AND SEPERATOR ARE WORKING, HOWEVER THE YARD DRAIN IN THE SAMPLE HOUSE AREA IS BLOCKED OR DAMAGED.  ON MAY 8, 2009 TESTING OF THE STATION DRAIN SYSTEM AND ASSOCIATED PIPING WAS CONDUCTED.  WEEKEND ACTIVITES WERE REDUCED TO MONITORING 24/7, DITCHES REMAINED CLEAN.  MAY 11, 2009 EXCAAVTION CONTINUED ON THE DRAIN LINES AND SUMP.       MAY 12, 2009 THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON THE LINE 04 SAMPLE TAP LINE COUPLING WHERE THE FLARED TYPE FITTINGS ENTERED THE SAMPLE HOUSE.  THE FITTINGS WERE REPLACED, TESTED AND RETURNED TO SERVICE.  THE SITE HAS BEEN SECURED AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS.   SUBEQUENT CLEAN UP WAS COMPLETED. NRC NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE WHEN COST WERE ANTICIPATED TO EXCEED $50,000.

column238: PROVER HYDRAULIC RAM SHAFT TO PLUNGER ASSEMBLY FATIGUE FAILURE
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 0320 ON 5/1, AN OPERATOR DISCOVERED A SPRAY AND PRODUCT RELEASE COMING FROM THE PROVER PIPING. SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT THE HYDRAULIC RAM SHAFT TO THE PLUNGER ASSEMBLY FAILED (FATIGUE) RESULTING IN THE 16.8 BARREL RELEASE OF ULTRA LOW SULPHUR DIESEL. ALL FREE PRODUCT WAS PROMPTLY REMOVED VIA VACUUM TRUCK AND THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS PROPERLY DISPOSED.    NOTE 1: RE: PART A 6 C.; AMOUNT SPILLED AND RECOVERED IS ACTUALLY 16.8 BARRELS, HOWEVER, THE PHMSA ONLINE DATA ENTRY SYSTEM DOES NOT ALLOW FRACTIONS SO WE ROUNDED UP TO THE NEAREST WHOLE NUMBER. ALSO THE AMOUNT RECOVERED IS ESTIMATED TO BE RECOVERED VIA EXCAVATION OF SOIL.     NOTE 2: RE: PART G 3 ; ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION IS ACTUALLY 4 MINUTES (0.07 HOURS); WE ROUNDED DOWN TO THE NEAREST WHOLE NUMBER  DUE TO RESTRICTIONS OF THE ONLINE DATA ENTRY SYSTEM.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E. COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THIS RELEASE OCCURRED AS RESULT OF EXTERNAL CORROSION IN THE 12" STATION PIPE APPROXIMATELY 200' FROM THE BOOSTER PUMP.  THE LEAK OCCURRED FROM A CORROSION PIT LOCATED BENEATH A ROAD BED WITHIN THE STATION.  IT IS BELIEVED THE PIT FORMED BECAUSE SOIL CONDITIONS BENEATH THE ROAD BED MADE CP PROTECTION LESS EFFECTIVE.    REF: PART A, PAR. 5.  THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT CONCLUDED THAT THE COST WOULD NOT EXCEED THE TELEPHONIC REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  SUBQUENTLY, THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE REMEDIATION OF THE CONTAMINATED SOIL EXCEEEDED THE ORIGINAL ESTIMATES DUE TO THE VERTICAL MIGRATION OF THE CRUDE OIL IN THE SUBSURFACE SOILS.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: A SECOND PARTY CONTRACTOR DOING LINE LOWERING WORK STRUCK A 2” P&H NIPPLE WELDED ON THE SIDE OF THE SUGAR CREEK TO COUNCIL BLUFFS 8” PIPELINE AT MILE POST 116. THE PIPELINE WAS IN OPERATION AT THE TIME OF THE STRIKE AND RELEASED APPROXIMATELY 1495 GALLONS OF DIESEL INTO THE EXCAVATION. AN IMMEDIATE NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE CONTROL CENTER WHICH SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED THE PIPELINE. THE SITE OF THE SPILL WAS LOCATED IN A RURAL AREA AND CAUSED NO IMPACT TO THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY. THE SPILL CONTINGENCY PLAN WAS IMPLEMENTED WITH EMERGENCY RESPONDERS DISPATCHED AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. NO INJURIES OCCURRED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON FRIDAY, MAY 15 AT 1715 HOURS, TAFT AREA PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO A NOTIFICATION BY THE PIPELINE CONTROLLER OF AN AUTOMATIC EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN (ESD) AT THE SHALE STATION.  UPON ARRIVAL AT THE STATION, AREA PERSONNEL FOUND CRUDE OIL LEAKING FROM ONE OF THE PUMP SEALS (G1).  THE PUMP WAS IMMEDIATELY ISOLATED AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A BOLT THAT HELD THE SEAL PACKING IN PLACE HAD BROKEN, ALLOWING CRUDE TO FLOW FROM THE SEAL.  ALTHOUGH MOST OF THE CRUDE WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE SUMP SYSTEM, SOME OIL OVERFLOWED THE SUMP POT ONTO THE SURROUNDING AREA.  IT WAS ESTIMATED THAT APPROXIMATELY 8 BARRELS OF CRUDE WAS SPILLED AND WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE STATION PROPERTY.  ALL OF THE CRUDE WAS RECOVERED, REPAIRS TO THE SEAL WERE MADE, AND THE STATION WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE FRIDAY EVENING.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: TWIN OAKS PUMP STATION, AN UNMANNED FACILITY, IS THE ORIGIN LOCATION FOR SEVERAL JURISDICTIONAL PIPELINES TRANSPORTING REFINED PETROLEUM PRODUCTS FROM THE SUNOCO MARCUS HOOK REFINERY AND ANOTHER PIPELINE SYSTEM.   THE FACILITY IS LOCATED IN UPPER CHESTER TOWNSHIP, DELAWARE COUNTY, PA ALONG STATE HIGHWAY 322.  ON MAY 8, 2009 AT 2334 HOURS, THE PUMP STATION WENT INTO AN AUTOMATIC SHUTDOWN/LOCKOUT FROM A HYDROCARBON-LEL DETECTION DEVICE.  LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENTS ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 2356 HOURS AS A RESULT OF RECEIVING CALLS FROM PASSING MOTORISTS TO 911 REPORTING GASOLINE ODORS AND GASOLINE SPRAYING.  ROUTE 322 WAS SHUTDOWN BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT. SPLP RESPONSE PERSONNEL FIRST ARRIVED ON SCENE AT 0011 HOURS.  AT 0040 HOURS A MANUAL VALVE ISOLATING THE RELEASE FROM THE MAIN LINE WAS CLOSED AFTER THE AREA OF THE VALVE WAS MADE SAFE FOR ENTRY.    SUNOCO PIPELINE L.P. IMMEDIATELY MOBILIZED LOCAL OSRO’S AND COMPANY EMERGENCY RESPONSE CREWS TO MITIGATE THE IMPACTS TO THE AREA.  AN ICS WAS FORMULATED TO MANAGE THE RESPONSE.  TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO PADEP, NRC AND PHMSA.  PRODUCT WAS CONTAINED BY A SYSTEM OF INTERCEPTOR TRENCHES AND UNDERFLOW DAMS ON THE PUMP STATION SITE AND OFF-SITE ON HARVEY’S RUN BY A SERIES OF CONTAINMENT AND ABSORBENT BOOMS.  GASOLINE FLOWED DOWN HARVEY’S RUN FOR APPROXIMATELY ONE HALF MILE.  APPROXIMATELY 285 SMALL MINNOWS, CRAYFISH AND SNAILS WERE FOUND DEAD ALONG WITH ONE WATER SNAKE AND ONE FROG.    THE RELEASE WAS THE RESULT OF A RED-DYE ANALYZER PROBE BEING EJECTED FROM ITS ASSEMBLY MOUNTED ON THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD FOR THE 14-INCH TWIN OAKS TO NEWARK MANIFOLD PORTION OF TWIN OAKS PUMP STATION. SPLP REMOVED ALL ANALYZERS OF THIS DESIGN FROM THE PIPELINE SYSTEM. THE FAILED ANALYZER ASSEMBLY AND TWO IDENTICAL ANALYZER ASSEMBLIES FROM TWIN OAKS WERE SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT FORENSIC ENGINEERING LAB TO PERFORM BOTH PHYSICAL TESTS AND FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS TO EVALUATE THE DEVICES AND TO DETERMINE THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE TRANSMITTER PROBE BEING EJECTED FROM THE PIPELINE.  THIS REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE ROOT CAUSE FOR THE FAILURE OF THE PROBE COULD BE ATTRIBUTED TO THE DESIGN OF THE PROBE ASSEMBLY.  DESIGN DID NOT CONSIDER THAT BOTH THE LOCKING BOLT AND PACKING GLAND ARE REQUIRED TO ACHIEVE PRESSURE RATINGS AT THE LEVEL REQUIRED FOR THE SPLP INSTALLATION.  THE TESTING PERFORMED INDICATED THAT THE LOCKING BOLT ALONE WAS NOT SUFFICIENT TO RESTRAIN THE PROBE AT THE OPERATING PRESSURES EVEN THOUGH THE MANUFACTURER MARKETED THE DEVICES AS SUCH.  THIS INCIDENT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY AL SCHOEN OF PHMSA AND SUNOCO LOGISTICS ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT AND REGIONAL MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL.

column245: FACILITY PIPING WAS BEING PREPARED TO BE DRAINED FOR MAINTENANCE WORK.  WHILE OPENING VALVES TO DRAIN THE PIPING, A VALVE FROM AN ACTIVE PIPELINE WAS INADVERTENTLY OPENED BY CONTRACT PERSONNEL.  THE SUBSEQUENT FLOW OF PRODUCT BEGAN QUICKLY FILLING THE RECEIVING SUMP.  DUE TO THE RATE OF PRODUCT FLOW, THE SUMP OVERFLOWED AND PRODUCT POOLED ONTO THE SURROUNDING AREA.  THE ESTIMATED LEAK DURATION WAS 6 MINUTES.  THE ONLINE FORM WILL NOT ALLOW DECIMAL SUBMISSIONS.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: A TORNADO HIT THE EAST LEG MAINLINE BARING PUMP STATION THE EVENING OF MAY 13, 2009. OPERATION CONTROL LOST COMMUNICATION AT 1837 HOURS.  A THIRD PARTY CALLED OPERATONS CONTROL AT 1845 HOURS STATING THAT HE COULD SEE A SMALL VAPOR CLOUD AT THE STATION.  THE PIPELINE WAS SHUTDOWN PREVIOUS TO THIS INCIDENT BUT OPERATIONS CONTROL CLOSED THE BLOCK VALVES UPSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE STATION TO FURTHER ISOLATE THE STATION AND MONITOR PRESSURES.  OPERATIONS CONTROL CALLED FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE AND CALLED THE LOCAL SHERIFF AND FIRE DEPARTMENT.  NO LOSS OF PRESSURE WAS INDICATED ON THE ISOLATED LINE AND THEN THE BLOCK VALVES WERE OPENNED AND PUMP STATIONS NORTH AND SOUTH OF BARING STATION WERE OPERATED TO DRAW DOWN THE LINE PRESSURE.  AFTER THE STATION PRESSURE WAS DRAWN DOWN AND PERSONNEL COULD GET TO THE STATION, STATION VALVES WERE BLOCKED IN TO FACILITATE FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND REPAIR.    THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY A LIGHT POLE AT THE STATION FALLING ONTO A 1" FUEL LINE AND CRACKING THREADS ON A 1" PIPE NIPPLE.  THE PIPE NIPPLE AND FUEL REGULATOR WERE REPLACED AND THE STATION HAS BEEN PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.
