column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: 5/11/09 - 11:00 MOSAIC EMPLOYEE NOTICED AMMONIA SMELL OVER NUSTAR'S PIPELINE LATERAL GOING INTO THEIR FACILITY. NUSTAR EMPLOYEES CONTACTED AND CONFIRMED AMMONIA ODOR. THE LINE WAS NOT IN OPERATION AND ALREADY ISOLATED FROM MAINLINE BY CLOSED VALVE. THE PRESSURE WAS IMMEDIATELY REDUCED AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.  A MEETING BETWEEN NUSTAR AND THE LA-DEQ DETERMINED THE SITUATION WOULD ALLOW FOR PERSONNEL AND EQUIPMENT TO BE MOBILIZED FOR EXCAVATION ON 5/12/09.    5/12/09 - RELEASE CONFIRMED BY NUSTAR. DETERMINATION WAS MADE TO FURTHER ISOLATE THE AFFECTED PIPE SEBMENT BY STOPPLING BEFORE FURTHER EXPOSING THE LINE.    5/13/09 - LINE WAS EXPOSED BUT NO IMMEDIATE RELEASE POINT WAS FOUND. A SMALL ANOMOLY WAS FOUND IN THE PIPE LATER IN THE DAY.    5/14/09 - THE PIPE SEGMENT WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED. THE AFFECTED SEGMENT HAS BEEN SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS.    5/15/09 - LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 14:30.    TELEPHONE NOTIFICATIONS MADE:    LA-STATE POLICE (LANETTE) AT 11:20 ON 5/11/09. INCIDENT #09-02323  ST. JAMES PARISH LEPC (JYWANNA CHAMPAGNE) AT 10:10 ON 5/12/09  NRC (P.O. TROY) AT 10:40 ON 5/12/09. INCIDENT #905373  OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY IN HOUSTON, TX ON 10:56 ON 5/12/09       8/31/2009 -- KIEFNER FINAL REPORT RECEIVED. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS MECHANICAL DAMAGE THAT FORMED A DENT, MULTIPLE GOUGES, AND A BUCKLE, WHICH CREATED AN ANGULAR OFFSET IN THE PIPE. A THROUGH-WALL, CIRCUMFERENTIALLY-ORIENTED CRAK FORMED AT THE BASE OF A GOUGE WITHIN THE DENT THAT WAS PROPOGATED BY FATIGUE.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO ROOT CAUSE OF "RUPTURE OF PREVIOUSLY DAMAGED PIPE," PER THIRD PARTY ANALYSIS.

column245: THE BLUE LINE (8" - X-40 SOMASTIC COATING) SEPERATED ON WEST SIDE OF BULL CREEK APPROX MP 417.8. THE SEPERATION RESULTED IN 1718 BBLS OF PROPANE BEING RELEASED TO THE ATMOSPHERE. VAPOR DISSIPATED QUICKLY, WITH NO IMPACT TO THE PUBLIC. THE LINE WAS SHUT DOWN AND ISOLATED QUICKLY. ALL CONSEQUENT INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. EXAMINATION OF THE FAILED WELD BY AN OUTSIDE SOURCE INDICATED THAT THE WELD CONTAINED INCOMPLETE PENETRATION THAT CONTRIBUTED TO ITS FAILURE UNDER STRESS. THIS COMBINED WITH THE LANDSLIDE BROUGHT ON BY HEAVY RAINFALL AND WATER FLOW IN THE CREEK, CREATED SUFFICIENT STRESS ON THE WELD AT THE FAILURE LOCATION TO FRACTURE. CPPL HAS WENT IN AND BORED THE BULL CREEK CROSSING TO REDUCE ANY KIND OF OUT SIDE FORCES.    EXAMINATION OF THE FAILED WELD BY 3RD PARTY INDICATES THAT THE WELD CONTAINED MULTIPLE ANOMALIES (INCOMPLETE PENETRATION AND OR INSUFFICIENT ROOT PASS) THAT CONTRIBUTED TO ITS FAILURE UNDER STRESS. THIS COMBINED WITH THE LANDSLIDE BROUGHT ON BY HEAVY RAINFALL AND WATER FLOW IN THE CREEK, CREATED SUFFICIENT STRESS ON THE WELD AT THE FAILURE LOCATION TO FRACTURE.

column241: JOHN R. JEWETT, PIPELINE COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: TEPPCO CONTRACTORS WERE PREPARING TANK 1303 TO RECEIVE THE INSTALLATION OF A GUAGE POLE WHEN AN EXPLOSION OCCURRED. CONTRACTORS EMPLOYED TO WORK ON TANK 1303 UNSUCCESSFULLY RENDERED THE TANK FREE OF VAPORS BY NOT FOLLOWING COMPANY PROCEDURES AS PART OF THE JOB PLANNING. THE “COMPANY” REQUIRES THAT ALL PERSONNEL HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND ABILITIES TO PERFORM CERTAIN JOB FUNCTIONS IN THE PREVENTION OF ACCIDENTS DURING SKILLED ROUTINE AND NON-ROUTINE WORK. ENTERPRISE WILL SEEK OPPORTUNITIES TO REVIEW ITS ACCEPTED INDUSTRY PRACTICES, IDENTIFY, AND USE ADDITIONAL QUALIFIED LEADING INDUSTRY CONTRACTORS. IN RESULT, ENTERPRISE CONTRACTORS PERFORMING SUCH SKILLED SERVICES WILL MEET INTERNAL AND REGULATORY REQUIREMENTS THROUGH PRIMARY CONTRACTOR INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM PROVIDERS.      UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 9/15/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column70: LEAK OF BLEEDER VALVE ON A BLOCK VALVE
column245: A RELEASE OF 50 GALLONS OF TRANSMIX WAS EXPERIENCED FROM A ONE EIGHTH INCH PORT ON A BLEEDER VALVE INSIDE A REMOTE FENCED BLOCK VALVE ON EXPLORER PIPELINES 28 INCH PIPELINE SYSTEM.   45 GALLONS OF FREE PHASE PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND THE REMAINING 5 GALLONS WAS ENTRAINED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL.  SOIL CONDITIONS REQUIRED OVER EXCAVATION OF THE AREA AND ANALYTICAL SOIL TEST RESULTS CONFIRM THE REMAINING 5 GALLONS OF PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED AND CONTAINED IN THE EXCAVATED SOIL. THE EXACT DURATION OF THE LEAK FROM THE PORT IS NOT KNOWN.  INSPECTIONS WERE CONDUCTED ON THE BLOCK VALVE ON APRIL 9, 2009 AND APRIL 21, 2009 AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION OF A RELEASE. THE HIGHEST PRESSURE EXPERIENCED AT THE VALVE LOCATION THE PREVIOUS 30 DAYS WAS 638 PSIG.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THIS RELEASE OCCURRED DURING ROUTINE TESTING OF SCADA EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN SYSTEMS.  THE CONTROL CENTER CONTACTED A LOCAL TECHNICIAN TO INVESTIGATE THE STATUS OF THE TWO SCRAPER TRAP ISOLATION VALVES, AS THE TESTS COULDN'T BE RUN WITHOUT THOSE VALVES.  THE TECHNICIAN OBSERVED THAT THE VALVES WERE LOCKED OUT BY THE PIPELINE MAINTENANCE CREW.  HE CALLED THE PERSON RESPONSIBLE FOR THE LOCKS AND OBTAINED PERMISSION TO REMOVE THEM AND RESTORE THE FULL VALVES TO REMOTE STATUS.    AFTER VIEWING THE VALVE MOVEMENTS, AS DIRECTED BY THE CONTROL CENTER, ON THE STATION PANELVIEW, THE TECHNICIAN RETURNED TO THE AREA AND OBSERVED OIL FLOWING OUT OF THE TRAP SUMP.  THE TECHNICIAN WAS UNAWARE OF AN OPEN VENT LINE FROM THE TRAP TO THE SUMP THAT WAS LEFT OPEN BY THE MAINTENANCE CREW TO PREVENT THE SCRAPER TRAP FROM OVERPRESSURING DUE TO THERMAL EXPANSION.  WHILE THE CONTROL CENTER WAS EXECUTING THE SCADA CHECKS THE SCRAPER TRAP WAS OPENED TO THE MAINLINE, ALLOWING OIL TO FLOW THROUGH THE TRAP INTO THE SUMP.    THE OIL WAS CONTAINED IN THE TERMINAL CONTAINMENT SYSTEM AND IMMEDIATELY CLEANED UP.  FREE PRODUCT WAS REMOVED WITH VACUUM TRUCKS.  IMPACTED SOIL WAS COLLECTED AND HAULED TO AN APPROVED LANDFILL FACILITY.    THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE FAILURE TO FOLLOW LOCK-OUT PROCEDURES ASSOCIATED WITH ISOLATING THE SCRAPER TRAP SYSTEM.

A TEMPORARY MECHANICAL SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINE ON THE AFTERNOON OF MAY 22ND & PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE MADE AT A LATER DATE.

column245: SUMP ALARM WAS RECEIVED BY CONTROL CENTER AT 20:59, CONTROLLER STARTED SUMP PUMP AT 21:01, AND CALLED TECHNICIAN OUT TO INVESTIGATE.  SUMP ALARM CLEARED AT 21:09. column245: THIS RELEASE OCCURRED FROM A CRACK IN THE CAST STEEL BODY OF A 4-INCH GATE VALVE.  THE VALVE WAS BURIED APPROXIMATELY 12-INCHES AND FORMED A CLOSE COUPLED BRANCH CONNECTION TO AN ACTIVE 10-INCH MAIN PIPELINE.  THE 4-INCH BRANCH PIPELINE UPSTREAM OF THE 4-INCH VALVE WAS ABANDONED.     REMOVAL OF THE VALVE SHOWED THE STEM TO BE NOTICEABLEY BENT.  RIGHTS-OF-WAY BRUSH CLEARING WITH A "BRUSH HOG" AND TREE TOPPING WORK WAS RECENTLY PERFORMED AT THE VALVE SITE.  THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF THE CRACK IN THE VALVE BODY WAS AN EXTERNAL FORCE TO THE VALVE STEM INDUCING A STRESS ON THE VALVE BODY CAUSING IT TO CRACK.  AN EXTENSION ON THE VALVE STEM PROTRUDED ABOVE THE GROUND SURFACE AND WAS MOST PROBABLY HIT BY THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY CLEARING EQUIPMENT.  THE STEM EXTENSION COULD NOT BE FOUND.  THE VALVE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH A HEAVY WALL PLUG.  THE PIPING WAS RECOATED AND REBURIED.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: THE DIAPHRAGM ON THE BACK PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE FOR THE INCOMING METER SKID RUPTURED.  06-03-09 DISCOVERY AT REFUGIO STATION.  AT 07:30 AM, ON THE MORNING OF 6-3-09, THE LOCAL OPERATOR ARRIVED AT REFUGIO STATION AND PERFORMED A STATION CHECK. DURING THIS INSPECTION, A RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED AT THE BACK PRESSURE CONTROL VALVE ON THE INCOMING METER SKID FROM THE NEW QUINTANA /LAMBERT 8¿ LINE. THE LINE WAS NOT RUNNING AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY AND OPERATOR ON SITE CALLED REMOTE OPERATIONS AND MADE NOTIFICATION NOT TO ALLOW THE LINE TO RE-START.  HE THEN MADE COMPANY NOTIFICATIONS TO START THE RESPONSE PROCESS.  LINE WAS KEPT DOWN WHILE REPAIR PROCESS WAS COMPLETED             USING PI, A REVIEW OF DATA ON THE LINE DURING THE PREVIOUS 24 HOUR PERIOD, INDICATED A CHANGE IN FLOW AND PRESSURE OCCURRED AT 17:30 ON 6-2-09.  PRESSURE WAS 76.4 PSI AT NEW QUINTANA DISCHARGE AND 55.0 PSI AT LAMBERT DISCHARGE AND THE FLOW RATE ON THE LINE WAS BALANCED AT 429 BARRELS PER HOUR AT INJECTION AND RECEIPT METERS AT 17:30. THE FLOW RATE STARTED DECREASING AND THE PRESSURE STARTED INCREASING AND THIS APPEARS TO BE THE INDICATOR OF WHEN THE ISSUE DEVELOPED WITH THE CONTROL VALVE AT THE RECEIPT METER. PRESSURE CONTINUED TO INCREASE ON THE LINE SEGMENT TO IT HIGHEST LEVEL OF 158.9 PSI AT NEW QUINTANA DISCHARGE AND 159.4 PSI AT LAMBERT DISCHARGE AND THE FLOW RATE ON THE LINE WAS BALANCED AT 170 BARRELS PER HOUR AT INJECTION AND RECEIPT METERS AT 00:46 ON 6-3-09. AT 00:48 THE NEW QUINTANA PUMP QUIT INJECTING INTO THE LINE, WHICH IS NORMAL OPERATION WHEN THE THIRD PARTY TANK REACHES LOW LEVEL, A RUN LEVEL SWITCH SHUTS OFF THE PUMP. THE PUMP WILL ALSO START REMOTELY WHEN THE TANK LEVEL REACHES A CERTAIN LEVEL. THIRD PARTY TANK LEVELS ARE NOT SHOWN ON SCADA SYSTEM.  AT 01:15 THE PRESSURE ON THE LINE REACHED 0 PSI, WHICH MATCHES PREVIOUS PERIODS OF DOWN TIME ON THE LINE SEGMENT, AND REMAINED AT THIS LEVEL UNTIL DISCOVERY BY PERSON ON SITE.    ON POST REVIEW OF THE DATA, THE TIME PERIOD BETWEEN 17:30 ON 6-2-09 AND 01:15 ON 6-3-09 SHOWS A CHANGE WITH THE PROBABILITY THE RELEASE OCCURRED SOMETIME DURING THIS TIME PERIOD. ONCE THE LINE REACHED 0 PSI THE EVENT STOPPED AND REMAINED STATIC UNTIL DISCOVERY THE NEXT MORNING.    LEAK DETECTION MODEL ON THIS LINE SEGMENT IS A VOLUME BALANCE SYSTEM MEASURING BARRELS INTO LINE VERSES BARRELS OUT OF LINE. LINE BALANCE WAS WITHIN THRESHOLD ALARM LIMITS.

column245: AT 6:35 THIS MORNING WE RECEIVED A SCADA ALARM AT PIPELINE CONTROL OF A SEAL FAILURE ON THE #3 PUMP AT CONROE STATION.  THE ALARM TRIPPED THE STATION ESD AND THE STATION WAS ISOLATED.  THE CONTROLLER ON DUTY CALLED OUT THE FIELD TECHNICIANS.  FIELD TECHNICIANS VERIFIED THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM THE SEAL ON #3 PUMP.  ONCE AREA WAS MADE SAFE, THEN OPERATIONS REPLACED THE SEAL.  THERE WERE NO OTHER CONTRIBUTING FACTORS AND NO FORMAL INVESTIGATION.

column245: SPILL OCCURED AT A LOCATION WHERE THE 12" PIPELINE HAD BEEN EXPOSED FOR THE REMEDIATION OF SOILS DUE TO A LEAK WHICH HAD OCCURED ON A PARRALLEL 8" PIPELINE IN 2001 THAT HAS SINCE BEEN ABANDONNED. THE AREA IS LOCATED IN A MANMADE GRASS DRAINAGE WATERWAY IN A ALFALFA FIELD. THE EXCAVATION WAS APPROX. 170 FT LONG BY 60 FT WIDE BY 25 FT DEEP. 12' PIPE LEAKED ON BOTTOM OF PIPE IN A BEND MADE TO GO THROUGH WATERWAY AND ALL OIL SPRAYED INTO PREVIOUSLY DESCRIBED HOLE. LINE WAS SHUT DOWN WITHIN 5 MINUTES OF NOTIFICATION FROM LANDOWNER THAT HE SAW PIPE LEAKING. AREA PERSONNEL WERE ONSITE WITHIN 1 HOUR OF NOTIFICATION BUT DUE TO THE EXCAVATION A CONTRACTOR HAD TO BE CALLED OUT TO PARTIALLY FILL IN THE HOLE SO THAT CREW COULD REACH THE PIPE TO CLAMP IT OFF WHICH TOOK APPROX. 3 HOURS FROM THEIR ARRIVAL. THERE WAS A SMALL AMOUNT OF SURFACE WATER IN BOTTOM OF EXCAVATION WHICH KEPT THE MAJORITY OF CRUDE OIL FROM SOAKING INTO SOIL.

column245: LANDOWNER WAS APPLYING FERTILZER TO FIELD, WORKING APPROX 6 INCHES DEEP AND IMPLEMENT STRUCK PIPE CAUSING PUNCTURE. LANDOWNER NOTIFIED CONTROL CENTER. CONTROL CENTER NOTIFIED DISTRICT PERSONNEL. LANDOWNER USED HEAVY EQUIPMENT TO DIVERT FLOW FROM SPILL INTO A DRY CATCH BASIN. LINE HAD ALREADY BEEN SHUT DOWN SEVERAL HOURS BEFORE DUE TO HIGH TANK LEVELS AT BEMIS SO PRESSURE ON LINE WAS STATIC HEAD ONLY. WITHIN 1.5 HOURS BLOCK VALVE UPSTREAM OF RELEASE AND BLOCK VALVE DOWNSTREAM AT STATION HAD BEEN CLOSED AND LOTO'D. REMAINDER OF DRAIN-UP WAS CONTROLLED AND DAMGED PIPE WAS REPLACED. 200 FEET OF PIPE WAS EXPOSED TO INSPECT FOR FURTHER DAMAGE AND THEN LOWERED TO A MINIMUM OF 3 1/2 FEET. AREA OF STRIKE WAS ON THE SIDE OF HILL AND OVER TIME, EROSION AND FARMING, LINE HAD BECOME SHALLOW (4" TO 1.5') FOR A DISTANCE OF APPROX 100 FEET.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column70: CRACK IN WELDMENT ON REPAIR SLEEVE
column245: WHILE INVESTIGATING SUSPECTED 3RD PARTY ACTIVITY AT MP 1056.2 NEAR GOWAN MN, PERSONNEL NOTICED A SMALL POOL OF OIL ON THE GROUND. THE AREA WAS EXCAVATED AND UPON INVESTIGATION A CRACK IN A WELDMENT (BOLT SEAL WELD) ON A PLIDCO SPILT + SLEVE WAS DISCOVERED.  THE REPAIR SLEEVE WAS INSTALLED TO REPAIR A PIPELINE LEAK THAT OCCURRED IN 1989.  IT IS ESTIMATED THAT APPROXIMATELY 5 BARRELS WAS RELEASED.  THE NRC AND MN STATE DUTY OFFICER WERE NOTIFIED.  MNOPS PERSONNEL VISITED THE SITE FOR INSPECTION.    ALL THE WELDS ON THE SPLIT + SLEEVE WERE INSPECTED VIA MAGNETIC PARTICLE EXAMINATION AND WITH THE EXCEPTION OF ONE OTHER BOLT SEAL WELD WHICH HAD A SMALL CRACK (NOT LEAKING), ALL WERE FOUND TO BE GOOD.  TO REPAIR THE LEAKING PLUG WELDS, A  2-INCH, 3000 LB SOCKET WELD END CAP WAS INSTALLED (WELDED) OVER EACH OF THE BOLT SEAL WELDS.  THE REPAIRS WERE THEN EXAMINED TWICE PER PROCEDURE (ONCE IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE REPAIR, AND AGAIN 12 HOURS LATER) USING MAGNETIC PARTICLE. BOTH REPAIR WELDS WERE ACCEPTABLE.    ONCE THE REPAIR WAS COMPLETED, THE CONTAMINATED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM THE AREA AND BACKFILLED WITH CLEAN IMPORTED SOIL.

column245: PIPELINE RECEIPT STARTED AT 05:10 INTO AN UNLEADED TANK #127 AT 07:30 OPERATOR #2 PERFORMING DOCK WATCH FOR A BARGE RECEIPT HEARD A TANK LEVEL ALARM. HE IMMEDIATELY RADIOED OPERATOR #1 IN THE OFFICE. OPERATOR #1 IN THE OFFICE. OPERATOR #1 CHECKED THE ENRAF TANK LEVEL SCREEN AND SAW TANK #91 (TRANSMIX) AT 43'3 (NORMAL FILL IS 38'6"). HE WENT OUT TO THE TANK + SAW PRODUCT COMING FROM THE OVERFLOW VENTS. HE PROCEEDED TO THE PIPELINE MANIFOLD AND NOTIFIED THE AIR VALVE TO TANK 91 WAS OPEN WHEN IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN CLOSED. THE OPERATOR CLOSED THE AIR VALVE STOPPING FLOW TO TANK 91 AT 7:45. HE THEN CALLED OPERATOR #2 ON THE RADIO TO HELP HIM OPEN THE INLET VALVE ON TANK 95 (ANTHER TRANSMIX TANK) TO RELIEVE TANK 91 AND DROP THE LEVEL BELOW NORMAL FILL. AFTER ENSURING THE STOPPAGE OF FLOW INTO TANK 91 AND LOWERING THE LEVEL BELOW NORMAL FILL THE OPERATOR CONTACTED THE TERMINAL MANAGER. THE TERMINAL MANAGER CAME ON SITE TO ACCESS THE SITUATION AND THEN STARTED MAKING NOTIFICATIONS.

column245: COATING IN AREA AROUND LEAK SITE FAILED.  LEAK SITE IS IN A LOW LYING MOIST AREA.  LINE WAS PUT INTO SERVICE IN 2009 AND PREVIOUSLY SET INACTIVE UNDER THE CONTROL OF ANOTHER OPERATOR FOR SEVERAL YEARS.  DURING THE INACTIVE PERIOD CATHODIC PROTECTION WAS NOT PROPERLY MAINTAINED BY THE PREVIOUS OPERATOR.  WHEN CHAPARRAL OBTAINED THE LINE MANY REPAIRS TO THE CATHODIC PROTECTION SYSTEM WERE REQUIRED.  THE MOISTURE CONTENT OF THE SOIL, FAILED COATING, AND PREVIOUS LACK OF CATHODIC PROTECTION CONTRIBUTED TO THE EVENT. CHAPARRAL DUG OUT AND INVESTIGATED 850FT OF ADDITIONAL LINE TO ENSURE THAT NO ADDITIONAL COATING FAILURES ARE PRESENT.  ADDITIONAL CORROSION WAS FOUND DURING THIS INVESTIGATION AND THE CORRODED LINE WAS REPLACED AS A PART OF THE REPAIR PROCESS.

column245: THE PIPELINE WAS BEING RELOCATED TO MAKE ROOM FOR A HIGHWAY RELOCATION. THE PROJECT REQUIRED THE LINE TO BE CUT OPEN IN ORDER TO MOVE IT. PRODUCT HAD BEEN DRAINED OUT OF THE LINE. HOWEVER, WHILE THE LINE WAS BEING CUT OPEN THE BOTTOM PORTION OF THE LINE BROKE OPEN AND THE PIPE DROOPED INTO A "V" SHAPE WITH A DEFLECTION OF APPROXIMATELY 3 INCHES, ALLOWING PRODUCT TO FLOW OUT FASTER THAN THE VACUUM TRUCK INTO WHICH PRODUCT WAS BEING DRAINED-UP COULD HANDLE. RELEASED PRODUCT WAS ISOLATED IN THE PIPELINE DITCH AND RECOVERED. IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMEDIATED FOLLOWING COMPANY AND STATE APPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICES. THE LINE WAS REPAIRED WITH PRETESTED PIPE AND THE RELOCATION PROJECT WAS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED.

column245: A CONTRACT PAINT CREW WHILE WORKING AT MP 35.85 AT THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY TAKE-OFF DISCOVERED A SMALL LEAK WITH VAPOR BUBBLING OUT OF THE GROUND AND NOTIFIED THE COMPANY.  TECHNICIANS CLOSED THE NEAREST MAINLINE BLOCK VALVES AND THEN BLED OFF LINE PRESSURE INTO THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY STORAGE TANK UNTIL THE LINE PRESSURE EQUALIZED WITH THE TANK PRESSURE.  THE REMAINING LINE PACK IN THE ISOLATED SEGMENT WAS THEN FLARED AND VENTED TO ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS.  THE LINE WAS PURGED AND EXCAVATED FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION AND REPAIR.      THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE AT A WELD ON THE 8" X 8" X 2" SPLIT TEE AT THE FORT MADISON DELIVERY TAKE-OFF.  THE SPLIT TEE WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH A NEW, TESTED FACTORY TEE AND FABRICATED RISER ASSEMBLY.  THE DEFECTIVE TEE WAS SENT TO STRESS ENGINEERING SERVICES,INC. FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THE LEAK APPEARED TO BE CAUSED BY FATIGUE AS A RESULT OF POOR WORKMANSHIP.    THE COST OF PRODUCT LOST SHOWN ON THIS REPORT INCLUDES THE VOLUMES FLARED AND VENTED UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS AT THE VALVE SITES WHEREAS THE SPILLED VOLUME REPORTED ON LINE 6C UNDER PART A IS THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME THAT WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN RELEASED UNCONTROLLED TO THE ATMOSPHERE THROUGH THE LEAK SITE.  THE TOTAL PRODUCT VOLUME LOST INCLUDING THE CONTROLLED FLARE AND VENT VOLUMES WAS 1850 BARRELS.

column245: ONEOK NGL PIPELINE CONTROL NOTIFIED VIA PHONE FROM A  3RD PARTY WHO OBSERVED A FIRE A THE ONEOK TISHOMINGO STATION.  EMERGENCY CONTROL MEASURES WERE IMPLEMENTED TO SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE SYSTEM, AN AUTOMATED INLET VALVE AT THE LOCATION WAS CLOSED  AND DISPATCH ONEOK RESPONSE PERSONNEL.  THE FIRE WAS CONFIRMED ON THE FACILITY LAUNCHER SCRAPER TRAP ENCLOSURE.  MUTUAL AID ARRIVED AT THE SCENE FROM MULTIPLE FIRE DEPARTMENTS.  THE FACILITY WAS FURTHER ISOLATED BY THE DOWNSTREAM MANUAL STATION VALVE AND PIPING WAS DE-PRESSURED FROM A SAFE LOCATION. THE FLAMES WERE EXTINGUISHED.  UPON THE EXTINGUISH OF THE FIRE THE IMPACTED COMPONENTS WERE REMOVED AND EXAMINED. THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE WAS A FAILED O-RING ON THE SCRAPER TRAP ENCLOSURE.  IGNITION SOURCE WAS NOT IDENTIFIED.

column245: ON SATURDAY AUGUST 1, 2009 AT APPROXIMATELY 5 PM CST, AN OPERATOR FOUND PRODUCT IN AN ACCESS WELL AROUND THE PASADENA MANIFOLD VALVE AT HOUSTON STATION. THE OPERATOR INVESTIGATED THE SITUATION AND NOTIFIED THE LEAD TECHNICAL. THE LEAD TECHNICIAN NOTIFIED THE OPERATIONS MANAGER WHO THEN NOTIFIED THE DISTRICT LEADER. CONTRACTORS WERE NOTIFIED AND BEGAN EXCAVATING AROUND THE VALVE AND THEY CONFIRMED AT APPROXIMATELY 6:15 A.M. THE FOLLOWING MORNING THAT THE GUIDE PLUG ON THE PASADENA VALVE WAS THE SOURCE. TECHNICIANS REPLACED THE GASKET ON THE PLUG AND RETURNED THE LINE TO SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 12:00 PM CST. APPROXIMATELY 25 BARRELS OF WATER AND 8 BARRELS OF FREE PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED DURING THE EXCAVATION AND RECOVERY PROCESS. THE 2 DAYS FOLLOWING THE RELEASE 3 ADDITIONAL GALLONS OF FREE PRODUCT WERE RECOVERED FROM THE EXCAVATION AREA.  APPROXIMATELY 8 YARDS OF CONTAMINATED SOIL WERE REMOVED WHICH CONTAINED AN ADDITIONAL 10 GALLONS OF PRODUCT BRINGING THE TOTAL VOLUME RECOVERED TO 8.3 BARRELS.    AT 5:45 PM CST AUGUST 2, 2009, THE RELEASE WAS REPORTED TO THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY.

column245: THIS TERMINAL DOCK LINE IS U.S. COAST GUARD REGULATED.  THE LINE WAS NOT OPERATING WHEN CRUDE OIL WAS DISCOVERED RELEASED.  THE PIPELINE WAS DE-OILED AND FILLED WITH INHIBITED WATER TO FACILITATE THE REPAIR BY WELDING A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE OVER THE PINHOLE.

column7: CRUDE OIL
column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: THROUGH INVESTIGATION AND LAB ANALYSIS, SPLC HAS DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE CRUDE OIL RELEASE WAS THE RUPTURE OF A LONGITUDINAL CRACK AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION ON THE PIPELINE NEAR THE CROSSING POINT OF A THIRD PARTY PIPELINE.  MECHANICAL DAMAGE OBSERVED AT THE FAILURE POINT NEAR THE PIPELINE CROSSING INCLUDED MULTIPLE SMALL, VERY SHALLOW SURFACE GOUGES IN A CONCENTRATED AREA AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION, ALONG WITH SOME DEFORMATION OF THE PIPELINE IN THE SAME AREA.  THE PRESENCE OF THE SMALL SURFACE GOUGES AND DEFORMATION CAUSED A LONGITUDINAL CRACK TO DEVELOP AND GROW THROUGH METAL FATIGUE WHEN EXPOSED TO NORMAL OPERATIONAL PRESSURE FLUCTUATIONS IN THE LINE, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO FAILURE.    THE GOUGES AND DEFORMATION FORMED AND WERE LIKELY AGGRAVATED AS THE RESULT OF MULTIPLE STORMS (I.E., HURRICANES RITA, GUSTAV, IKE, ETC)  THE SIGNIFICANT FORCE AND ENERGY OF THESE STORMS SCOURED THE SEABED, WASHED OUT THE ORIGINAL PIPELINE SEPARATION AT THE CROSSING, AND DAMAGED THE CONCRETE COATING.  THIS CAUSED THE TWO PIPES TO MAKE CONTACT AND RUB TOGETHER REPEATEDLY CAUSING THE PIPE DAMAGE.

column70: LEAK IN BOTTOM SIDE ROCK DENT
column245: ON AUGUST 17, 2009 DEAD VEGETATION WAS OBSERVED FROM AN AERIAL PATROL INSPECTION AT MILE POST 398.76 IN ATOKA COUNTY, OKLAHOMA ON EXPLORER PIPELINES 28 INCH SYSTEM FROM GREENVILLE, TEXAS TO GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA.      EXPLORER PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT MP 398.76 AT 12:44 AND CONFIRMED DEAD VEGETATION AND SURFACE INDICATIONS OF A POTENTIAL RELEASE.   UPON EXCAVATION OF THE PIPELINE A LEAK WAS CONFIRMED.  THE LEAK WAS TEMPORARILY REPAIRED WITH A PLIDCO REPAIR SLEEVE UNTIL A PERMANENT REPAIR WAS COMPLETED.         NO FREE-PHASE PRODUCT WAS DISCOVERED OR RECOVERED AND THE LEAK VOLUME OF 100 BARRELS IS A CALCULATED ESTIMATE BASED ON INITIAL SOIL SAMPLING AND SOIL VAPOR EXTRACTION.         ALL THE PUMP STATIONS DOWNSTREAM OF GREENVILLE, INCLUDING THE DURANT, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION WHICH IS THE FIRST UPSTREAM PUMP STATION TO THE RELEASE, HAD BEEN DOWN SINCE 08:32.  THE ONLY PRESSURE SOURCE ON THE PIPELINE WAS A PD PUMP THAT BEGAN INJECTING TRANSMIX AT 10:28 OUT OF GREENVILLE INTO THE 28 INCH SYSTEM.      THE EXACT LEAK DURATION IS NOT KNOWN. THE HIGHEST PRESSURE RECORDED THE LAST 30 DAYS OUT OF THE DURANT, OKLAHOMA PUMP STATION WAS 682.50 PSIG.           THE THROUGH WALL CRACK INITIATED ON THE EXTERNAL SURFACE OF THE PIPE IN A BOTTOM SIDE ROCK DENT WITH MINOR EXTERNAL CORROSION.   THE ROCK DENT IS PRESUMED FROM ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION. THE MORPHOLOGY OF THE CRACKING IN ASSOCIATION WITH EXTERNAL CORROSION IS CONSISTENT WITH NEAR NEUTRAL PH STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.        THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY THAT HAS OVERSIGHT OF THE PROJECT HAS YET TO PROVIDE CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, PHMSA HAS REQUESTED A CLOSURE REPORT.  THEREFORE, EXPLORER PIPELINE WILL ESTIMATE A WORST CASE OF AN ADDITIONAL $962,000 FOR CLOSURE OF THE REMEDIATION PROJECT WITH THE STATE ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY.

INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED EMPLOYEES FAILED TO FOLLOW PROCEDURES.  BOTH EMPLOYEES WERE PLACED ON ADMINISTRATIVE LEAVE AND TERMINATED FROM EMPLOYMENT.

column61: CHILTIPIN CREEK, SAN PATRICIO CO, TX
column245: ON WEDNESDAY, 9/9/2009, AT APPROXIMATELY 1010 A.M., CITGO REPRESENTATIVES MET AT SITE WITH REPRESENTATIVES OF 5 CONTRACTORS FOR A PRE-BID MEETING TO REPLACE CREEK CROSSING.  ON ARRIVING AT CREEK, SHEEN WAS DISCOVERED.  AN IN LINE INSPECTION SHOWED SOME METAL LOSS IN AREA OF CREEK AND THOUGH NOT SHOWING TO BE SEVERE ENOUGH TO REQUIRE REPAIR, CITGO HAD OPTED TO MAKE REPAIRS BECAUSE OF CONDITION OF PIPE PREVIOUSLY REPLACED IN AREA.  AFTER LINE SHUT IN AND PRODUCT REMOVED FROM PIPE AT CREEK CROSSING, A PRESSURE TEST WITH NITROGEN INDICATED A SMALL LEAK IN PIPE.  APPROXIMATELY 2 BBLS. ENTERED CREED, BUT RECOVERY OF PRODUCT WAS NOT POSSIBLE.  SUBSEQUENT EXCAVATION ON SOUTH SIDE OF CREEK INDICATED SOME SOIL REMEDIATION MAY BE NECESSARY.  CREEK AREA IS IMPRACTICAL TO EXCAVATE DUE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS.  SUSPECT EXTERNAL CORROSION, FULL PIPE EXCAVATION IMPRACTICAL DUE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS.

column245: WHILE AIR PATROLLING COLONIAL'S RIGHT-OF-WAY A PRODUCT SHEEN WAS NOTICED ON THE FACILITY RETENTION POND AT PAULDING STATION. THE PATROL PILOT ENTERED AN AOR TICKET ON 9-29-09 AT 18:36 EASTERN. THE TICKET WAS PUT IN THE LOCAL AREA FOLDER ON 9-30-2009 AT 07:05 EASTERN. MISSISSIPPI RIGHT-OF-WAY PERSONNEL PICKED UP THE AERIAL OBSERVATION REPORT ON THE MORNING OF 09-30-09 AROUND 07:30 CENTRAL AND IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED LOCAL PERSONNEL TO PAULDING STATION FOR INVESTIGATION OF THE REPORTED SHEEN. INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT THERE HAD BEEN A RELEASE OF PRODUCT. THE FACILITY RETENTION POND HAD A SMALL SHEEN AND THE RELIEF TANK DIKE CONTAINED FREE STANDING PRODUCT THAT WAS BELIEVED, AND LATER CONFIRMED, TO BE FROM A OVERFLOW OF TANK 5056. THE CONTROL CENTER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT AND EQUIPMENT IN OPERATION AT THE FACILITY WAS SHUTDOWN. THE AREA OPERATION MANAGER WAS NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT AT 09:22 CENTRAL. THE AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER INFORMED THE DISTRICT PROJECT LEADER, AREA PROJECT MANAGER AND THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER OF THE EVENT AROUND 09:30 CENTRAL FOLLOWED BY NOTIFICATIONS TO THE AREA EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, LOCAL COLONIAL RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND AREA GENERAL CONTRACTOR. AREA SAFETY PARAMETERS WERE ESTABLISHED BY THE EMPLOYEE REPORTING THE EVENT AND WAITED OUTSIDE OF THE FACILITY FOR RESPONSE AND SUPPORT PERSONNEL TO ARRIVE ON SITE. THE GULF COAST DISTRICT LEADER WAS NOTIFIED AT 09:56 CENTRAL. AT 10:08 CENTRAL A FOLLOW UP NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE CONTROL CENTER BY THE AREA OPERATIONS MANAGER TO CONFIRM FACILITY OPERATION STATUS. NO REGULATORY REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WERE MET FOR MISSISSIPPI; HOWEVER, AT 10:10 A COURTESY CALL WAS MADE TO THE MISSISSIPPI DEQ BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER. CLEAN-UP OF THE PRODUCT CONTAINED IN THE TANK DIKE AND APPROXIMATELY 2-GALLONS ON THE FACILITY RETENTION WERE COMPLETED ON 10-1-09. THE NRC WAS NOT INITIALLY NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT BECAUSE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS OF 49 CFR 195.52 WERE NOT MET OR CONSIDERED SIGNIFICANT BECAUSE THE PRODUCT OTHER THAN THE SMALL SHEEN ON THE FACILITY POND WAS CONTAINED IN THE FACILITY TANK DIKE AND QUICKLY CLEANED UP. ON 10-20-09 AN NRC REPORT WAS FILED WHEN IT WAS FORECAST THAT THE COST OF DAMAGES WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  REPAIRS TO THE TANK AND TANK OVERFILL ALARM EQUIPMENT WERE COMPLETED AND THE TANK RETURNED TO SERVICE ON 11-6-09.

column238: AUTOMATIC PUMP ON OIL-WATER SEPARATOR FAILED TO START.
column245: THE RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY AN OPERATOR AT 0715 ON 9/23/09. DURING A ROUTINE CHECK OF THE STINGWATER SYSTEM, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED FREE PRODUCT (GASOLINE) INSIDE THE CONCRETE WALL SURROUNDING THE STINGWATER OIL WATER SEPERATORS AND A SMALL AMOUNT ON THE ADJACENT SPILLWAY. INCIDENT WAS REPORTED AT 0730 TO THE OPERATIONS MANAGER. CLEANUP BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AND CONTINUED THROUGH SEPTEMBER 28TH.  A LIGHT SHEEN WAS FOUND ON A PORTION OF POND 2.  NO NOTIFICATIONS TO THE STATE OR NRC WERE MADE SINCE THE POND IS NOT CONSIDERED "WATERS OF THE STATE". GROUNDWATER WAS NOT IMPACTED AS A RESULT OF THE RELEASE AND NO PRODUCT OR SHEEN WAS OBSERVED AT THE OUTFALL OF POND 2.  APPROXIMATELY 45 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED USING A PNEUMATIC PUMP INSIDE THE CONCRETE BERM. DIAPERS IN THE AREA COLLECTED ANOTHER 4 GALLONS.  A VERY LIGHT SHEEN WAS OBSERVED ON AN APPROXIMATELY 15' X 80' AREA OF THE POND. HARD BOOM WAS USED TO CONTAIN THE SHEEN AND CONSOLIDATE IT TO THE AREA OF THE SPILLWAY.  ADDITIONAL BOOM WAS DEPLOYED AT THE END OF THE SPILLWAY WHERE APPROXIMATELY 20 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED USING DIAPERS.  APPROXIMATELY 40 TONS OF SOIL WERE EXCAVATED ON THE INSIDE AND OUTSIDE OF THE CONCRETE WALL SURROUNDING THE OIL WATER SEPERATORS.  A MINOR AMOUNT OF IMPACTED SOIL BELOW THE FOOTING OF THE CONCRETE WALL COULD NOT BE REMOVED AND IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN PRESENT PRIOR TO THIS INCIDENT.  THE AMOUNT OF PRODUCT WITHIN THE EXCAVATED SOIL WAS ESTIMATED AT 5 GALLONS BASED UPON LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE SOIL AND VOLUME OF PRODUCT IN SOIL CALCULATIONS.  THE EXCAVATED SOIL WILL BE APPLIED TO THE LANDFARM.  EVAPORATION CALCULATIONS CONSIDERED THE AREA OF POOLED PRODUCT WITHIN THE CONCRETE BERM SURROUNDING THE OIL WATER SEPERATORS AND THE POOLED PRODUCT AT THE END OF THE SPILLWAY.  THE TOTAL AMOUNT LOST TO EVAPORATION IS ESTIMATED AT 14 GALLONS BASED UPON EVAPORATION CALCULATIONS FOR THE POOLED AREAS OF PRODUCT. THE TOTAL SPILL VOLUME IS ESTIMATED AT 88 GALLONS OR 2.1 BBLS WITH 69 GALLONS OF FREE PRODUCT RECOVERED USING PUMPS AND ABSORBENTS, 5 GALLONS RECOVERED WITH THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOIL, AND 14 GALLONS LOST TO EVAPORATION.  AN ESTIMATED 74 GALLONS WERE RECOVERED WITH PUMPS, ABSORBENTS AND THE EXCAVATION OF IMPACTED SOIL.

column241: GILBERT C. SCHUTZA, P.E. COMPLIANCE ENGINEER
column245: THIS RELEASE WAS DUE TO INTERNAL CORROSION ON A 6 INCH "REGULATED RURAL GATHERING" LINE FROM A LEASE SITE TO THE MAIN LINE.  THIS PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS IDENTIFIED AS A JURISDICTIONAL "REGULATED RURAL GATHERING" LINE PER 195.11 ON APRIL 3, 2009.    12/18/09.  THE INITIAL FIELD ASSESSMENT AND ESTIMATE OF THE VOLUME OF CONTAMINATED SOIL AND THE ANTICIPATED COST FOR LAND FARMING ON SITE CONCLUDED THAT THE TOTAL MITIGATION COSTS WOULD NOT EXCEED THE TELEPHONIC REPORTING THRESHOLD OF $50,000.  FOLLOWING THE SUBMITTAL OF THE INITIAL REPORT FOR THIS INCIDENT, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE VOLUME OF SOIL IMPACTED WAS GREATER THAN ORIGINALLY ESTIMATED AND THAT THE ORIGINAL PLAN TO MITIGATE THE SITE BY LAND FARMING  COULD NOT BE PRERFORMED EXPEDIENTLY OR ECONOMICALLY BECAUSE OF STATE PERMITTING REQUIREMENTS AND OTHER COST FACTORS.  THE INCREASED VOLUME OF IMPACTED SOIL WAS REMOVED FROM THE SITE AND DEPOSITED AT A PERMITTED DISPOSAL SITE.  THE REMOVED SOIL WAS REPLACED BY CLEAN FILL.  THIS MITIGATION RESULTED IN A COST EXCEEDING THE ORIGINAL ESTIMATED MITIGATION COST WHICH WAS BELOW THE $50,000 TELEPHONIC REPORTING THRESHOLD.

column110: N/A - 900 CLS ASTM A105 FORGED FLANGE
column241: HENRY L. LEGER - DOT PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST
column245: FAILURE OF THE ACADIAN 6” PIPELINE FLANGE IS ATTRIBUTED TO BRITTLE OVERLOAD CAUSED BY A COMBINATION OF BENDING STRESS AND INADEQUATE MATERIAL PROPERTIES.  THE FORGED A105 FLANGE EXHIBITED LOW YIELD STRENGTH, VERY LOW TOUGHNESS, AND MARGINAL DUCTILITY.    SEVERAL FACTORS CAN CONTRIBUTE TO BRITTLE CLEAVAGE FRACTURE INCLUDING POOR MATERIAL TOUGHNESS, THE PRESENCE OF A STRESS CONCENTRATOR, AND LOW TEMPERATURE.  THE FAILED FLANGE EXHIBITED VERY POOR TOUGHNESS AND THE FRACTURE WAS OBSERVED TO INITIATE AT A GEOMETRIC STRESS CONCENTRATOR WHERE THE  FLANGE BODY TRANSITIONED TO THE WELD NECK.  WHILE CRACK INITIATION MAY NOT HAVE OCCURRED AT LOW TEMPERATURE, THE ESCAPING PRODUCT WOULD AUTO-REFRIGERATE AND PRODUCE VERY LOW TEMPERATURES THAT MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO CRACK PROPAGATION.    THE LOADING RESPONSIBLE FOR FRACTURE INITIATION IS UNCLEAR.  THE FRACTURE  OCCURRED AT THE 6 O’CLOCK POSITION ADJACENT TO A 45 DEGREE UPWARD BEND IN THE PIPELINE.  HIGH BENDING STRESSES WOULD BE ANTICIPATED AT THIS LOCATION IN THE EVENT OF PIPE SETTLING, SOIL MOVEMENT, LONGITUDINAL PIPE MOVEMENT (SUCH AS BY THERMAL EXPANSION), ETC.  IT IS ALSO POSSIBLE THAT PIPELAY OR BACKFILL OPERATIONS AT THE TIME OF CONSTRUCTION SUBJECTED THE FLANGE TO HIGH BENDING STRESS.  REGARDLESS OF THE DETAILS, THE FLANGE FAILURE IS ATTRIBUTED TO THE COMBINATION OF BENDING STRESS AND POOR MATERIAL PROPERTIES.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column245: THIS WAS A VALVE TO TANK 6010 AND IT WAS FOUND TO BE INTERNALLY CORRODED.  DO NOT KNOW CAUSE OF CORROSION BEING SENT TO A LAB TO DETERMINE THIS.  WHILE PERFORMING ROUTINE ROUNDS A TANK FARM UTILITY WORKER DISCOVERED THAT CRUDE OIL HAD SURFACED NEAR A VALVE AT TANK 6010.  FLANGE PORTION OF THE VALVE WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING.     ANALYSIS REPORT OF THE VALVE WAS PERFORMED BY MATERIALS INSPECTION ASSOCIATES.      THE LEAK WAS ATTRIBUTED TO MICROORGANISM INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC)      THE MIC ATTACH WAS ABETTED BY BOTH CARBON DIOXIDE AND EXYGEN PITTING CORROSION  THERE WAS A VISIBLE LEDGE IN THE FIT-UP OF THE LINE PIPE TO THE THICKER FLANGE  AT THE MISMATCH OF THIS LEDGE, WATER COLLECTED RESULTING IN THE LOCALIZED CORROSION WHICH LED TO A THROUGH THE WALL HOLE.     REPLACED THE VALVE ENTIRELY WITH ANOTHER M&J VALVE.

column245: DURING ROUTINE SITE INSPECTION, THE HOWELL STATION ELECTRICAL TECHNICIAN NOTICED OIL ON THE GROUND, OUTISDE OF THE PUMPHOUSE NEAR THE INACTIVE PUMP UNIT #1.  UPON INVESTIGATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE LEAK ORIGINATED IN THE UNIT #1 DISCHARGE PIPING.  THE LEAKING PIPE SEGMENT WAS DRAINED UP AND REMOVED.  A WELD NECK FLANGE AND BLIND WERE INSTALLED.  CLEANUP OF THE SOIL IS BEING MONITORED BY THE ENBRIDGE ENVIRONMENT DEPARTMENT IN CONCERT WITH THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column238: IMPROPER INSTALLATION OF PATCH PLATES.
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 6 AM MST ON OCT 9, 2009, DURING ROUTINE SITE INSPECTION, A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL (LESS THAN 1 QUART) WAS DISCOVERED ON THE WEST SIDE OF TANK 22 WITHIN THE SUPERIOR TERMINAL.  THE TANK WAS MONITORED BY OPERATIONS AND ENGINEERING OVER THE WEEKEND WHILE IT WAS BEING EMPTIED, AND NO FURTHER OIL WAS FOUND AT THAT TIME.  A PLAN WAS THEN DEVELOPED TO CYCLE THE INTERNAL TANK VOLUME TO DETERMINE IF THERE WAS AN ACTIVE LEAK OR IF THE SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL (LESS THAN 1 QUART) WAS HISTORICAL IN NATURE.  ON OCTOBER 27, THE TANK WAS AGAIN CYCLED TO APPROXIMATELY ¾ FULL AND A SMALL AMOUNT OF OIL WAS FOUND IN THE EXCAVATION IN THE AREA OF QUESTION.  BASED ON THESE FINDINGS THE TANK WAS EMPTIED ON OCTOBER 30 IN ORDER TO COMPLETE AN INTERNAL INSPECTION OF THE TANK FLOOR.   IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DUE TO THE PATCH PLATES NOT BEING WELDED ON ALL FOUR SIDES.  THE TANK FLOOR BOTTOM HAS BEEN REPLACED AND THE TANK PUT BACK INTO SERVICE.

column229: BOLTS TWISTED AND SHEARED ON FLANGE DUE TO STRESS
column245: DURING AN INBOUND PIPELINE RECEIPT TANK 57 RECEIVED A SPURIOUS HIGH-HIGH LEVEL ALARM SIGNAL WHICH SENT THE TANK VALVE CLOSED.  AS THE TANK VALVE WAS CLOSING, A PRESSURE SURGE HIT THE FLEXIBLE JOINT IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM OF THE VALVE WHICH CAUSED THE FLEX JOINT TO EXPAND AND THUS CREATED A TWISTING MOTION ON A FLANGE ON THE CONNECT VERTICAL PUMP PIPING CAUSING THE BOLTS TO SHEER.  THERE WERE NO RESTRICTIVE DEVICES IN PLACE TO PREVENT THE FLEX JOINT FROM EXPANDING DURING AN UPSET CONDITION.  ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATION IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE INCIDENT DETERMINED THAT THE INBOUND PIPELINE RELIEF SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED BY A CLOSED VALVE HOWEVER A CHECK ON AVAILABLE PRESSURE READOUTS FROM THE PUMPING SHIPPERS TRANSMITTER AT THE CONNECTION TO THE TERMINAL INDICATES NO PRESSURE SURGE TRAVELED BACK UP THE LINE TO THE RELIEF SYSTEM.  IT IS BELIEVED THE FLEX JOINT EXAPANSION TOOK PLACE IMMEDIATELY UPON BUILD UP OF PRESSURE AT THE TANK 57 VALVE AND FAILED BEFORE ANY SURGE WAS SENT BACK UP THE LINE, THUS THE RELIEF SYSTEM WOULD NOT HAVE HAD AN OPPORTUNITY TO TAKE PRESSURE OFF THE LINE HAD IT'S ISOLATION VALVE BEEN IN THE PROPER POSITION.  THE FINAL DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF FAILURE IS THAT THE DESIGN AND USE OF THE FLEX JOINT WAS INADEQUATE.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: ON SEPTEMBER 3, 2009, AT APPROXIMATELY 2310 HOURS, THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE WICHITA FALLS FIRE CHIEF REPORTING A TANK OVERFILL CONDITION AT NUSTAR'S WICHITA FALLS STATION. THE CONTROLLER SCANNED THE ALARM SUMMARY, NOTED THE "HIGH" AND "HIGH-HIGH" ALARM SUMMARY AND SWITCHED OUT OF TANK 120M1, THEN HE CALLED THE APPROPRIATE FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE THE CONDITIONS REPORTED AT THE STATION. FIELD PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE OVERFILL CONDITION OF THE TANK AT 2330 AND IMMEDIATELY CALLED THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL TO RESPOND AND BRING EQUIPMENT ON SITE. AFTER MONITORING ATMOSPHERIC CONDITION, PRODUCT PICKUP AND REMEDIATION ACTIVITIES WERE BEGUN.  CAUSES CONTRIBUTING TO THE ACCIDENT WERE OPERATOR ERROR AND EQUIPMENT FAILURE. OPERATOR ERROR WAS FAILURE TO RECOGNIZE AND REACT TO ALARM CONDITIONS BY A TRAINEE AND HIS QUALIFIED CONTROLLER. THE TANK GAUGE ON TANK 120M1 MALFUNCTIONED AT 35.2 FEET AND NEVER REACHED A "SOFT" ALARM SET TO TRIGGER IN CHORUS WITH THE "HIGH" AND "HIGH-HIGH" ALARMS.  NUSTAR HAS FULLY INVESTIGATED THE ACCIDENT AND MODIFIED ITS PROCEDURES TO ADDRESS TRAINER RESPONSIBILITIES AND ADDEDD A TANK OVERFILL SCENARIO TO ITS SIMULATOR TRAINING. ALSO THE COMPANY IS RECONFIGURING SCADA ALARMS TO DISPLAY CRITICAL ALARMS WITH UNIQUE COLOR AND SOUND ALONG WITH RE-ALARMS ON CRITICAL ALARMS. THE COMPANY ALSO INVESTIGATED AND REPAIRED THE FAILED TANK GAUGE.     4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: AT 00:40 ON 10/16/09 A WILLBRIDGE OPERATOR DETECTED A RELEASE OF JET FUEL IN THE SOUTH TANK FARM.  THE RELEASE WAS AN OVERFLOW FROM TANK WB-173, A SLOP (“RECLAIM”) TANK. ALMOST IMMEDIATELY DURING THE INITIAL EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN BY OPERATORS, IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT A DRAIN VALVE THAT IS NORMALLY CLOSED BETWEEN THE WB-69 JET FILTER BANK AND THE RECLAIM TANK WAS INADVERTENTLY LEFT IN THE OPEN POSITION. THE VALVE WAS PROMPTLY CLOSED AND THE SOURCE WAS ELIMINATED.  THE RELEASE WAS CONTAINED ON PROPERTY AND DID NOT THREATEN SURFACE WATER.      NOTE 1: RE: PART A 6 C.; AMOUNT RECOVERD TO DATE; REMAINING CONTAMINATION WILL BE REMEDIATED UNDER THE TERMS OF AN EXISTING STATE CLEAN-UP AGREEMENT.    NOTE 2: RE: PART H 23 B.; NO ALCOHOL TESTS WERE CONDUCTED BECAUSE THE ACCIDENT WAS DISCOVERED OVER EIGHT HOURS SINCE THE VALVE WAS LEFT OPEN.

column245: A GASKET FAILURE RELEASED 2 BARRELS OF DIESEL FUEL. FAILURE WAS DUE TO A GASKET FAILURE BETWEEN THE YOKE TUBE FLANG AND THE TOP OF THE BONNET. THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF PRODUCT IN THE STEM YOKE THAT WOULD LEAD TO A STEM SEAL FAILURE. THE STEM PACKING WAS STILL IN GOOD SHAPE WHEN THE VALVE WAS DISSEMBLED. THE LINE HAD ALREADY BEEN SHUT IN FOR REPAIR. A DRAIN PLAN WAS CREATED, THE DRAIN UP OCCURRED AND THE VALVE WAS REPLACED. THE OTHER TOOL WAS A HYDROTEST PERFORMED IN 1989.

column245: ON 11/06/2009 A CONTRACTOR, WORKING FOR A FARMER, STRUCK AND RUPTURED COUNTRYMARK'S 8" PRODUCTS PIPELINE WITH A TILING MACHINE. column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: AT 2338 HOURS ON 11/15/09 NUSTAR CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A PHONE CALL FROM FRONTIER COUNTY SHERIFF’S DEPARTMENT.  THE SHERIFF SAID HE HAD RECEIVED SEVERAL COMPLAINTS OF HYDROCARBON ODOR FROM CITIZENS DRIVING BY NUSTAR’S FARNAM PUMP STATION.  AT 2355 11/15/09, NUSTAR CONTROL CENTER SHUT DOWN THE PIPELINE THE LEADS INTO THE FARNAM PUMP STATION.  AT 2400 11/15/09, NUSTAR OPERATOR ARRIVED ON-SITE AND NOTICED PRODUCT SPILLAGE ON THE PROPERTY GROUNDS.  UPON DETERMINATION THAT IT WAS SAFE TO ENTER THE STATION IT WAS NOTICED THAT THE PRODUCT WAS COMING FROM ONE OF THE TWO PUMPS ON-SITE.  THE SEAL FAILED ON ONE OF THE PUMPS WHICH WERE EQUIPPED WITH A SEAL LEAK ALARM WHICH DID NOT ACTIVATE.  THE PUMP IS ALSO DESIGNED WITH TUBING FROM THE SEAL LEAK DETECTOR DIRECTLY INTO THE ON-SITE SUMP WHICH IS EQUIPPED WITH A HIGH LEVEL ALARM.  PRODUCT IN THE SUMP NEVER REACHED THE HIGH LEVEL MARK.  THIS PUMP IS ALSO EQUIPPED WITH A VIBRATION SENSOR ALARM THAT WHEN ACTIVATED WILL SHUT DOWN THE STATION.  THIS SENSOR DID NOT ALARM.    AT 0210 ON 11/16/09, HAZMAT RESPONSE, NUSTAR EMERGENCY RESPONSE CONTRACTOR, ARRIVED ON-SITE TO BEGIN PRODUCT RECOVERY AND SOIL REMOVAL ACTIVITIES.  HAZMAT RESPONSE RECOVERED APPROXIMATELY 35 BARRELS OF PRODUCT AND AN ESTIMATED 36 BARRELS WERE ABSORBED INTO THE SOILS.  OVER THE NEXT SEVERAL DAYS THE SOILS WERE EXCAVATED AND PROPERLY HAULED AND DISPOSED AT A STATE LANDFILL.  CONFIRMATION CLEANUP SOIL ANALYSES WERE TAKEN (RESULTS ARE NOT IN YET) TO VERIFY CLEAN CLOSURE THROUGH NDEQ.  ANALYSES WILL ALSO BE USED TO FURTHER DEFINE THE QUANTITY OF PRODUCT RELEASED THAT SATURATED THE SOILS.    ON 11/19-20/09, NUSTAR PERSONNEL INVESTIGATED THE PUMP SEAL LEAK ON-SITE GATHERING PERTINENT DATA.  UPON COMPLETION OF THE ON-SITE INVESTIGATION, THE PUMP WAS CAREFULLY REMOVED TO AN OFF-SITE LOCATION FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION.      A REVIEW OF THE BEARING TEMPERATURE DATA GRAPHS GENERATED FROM AN ON-SITE DATA RECORDER INDICATES A RADICAL STEP CHANGE DROP OF TEMPERATURE AT 1800 ON 11/13/09 WHICH MAY BE A SIGN OF THE INITIAL SEAL FAILURE.  THIS COULD BE USED AS THE INITIAL LEAK TIME AND DATE.  WHILE THE INVESTIGATION IS STILL ON-GOING, THE INITIAL INVESTIGATION OF THE PUMP HAS SHOWN:    • SEAL LOCK COLLAR SHOVED ALL THE WAY OUT. SET SCREWS WERE SET AS THE INDENTATIONS ARE ON THE SHAFT AND THEY ARE GROUND OFF ON THE ENDS WHEN THE SLEEVE SPUN. THE CARBON IS GROUND DOWN FLUSH WITH THE RETAINER AND THE TUNGSTEN IS CRACKED IN SEVERAL PLACES.  • THE SEAL LEAK ORIFICE WAS CLEAR.  • THERE ARE SOME METAL SHAVINGS UNDER THE BARREL WHERE THE 4TH STAGE USE TO BE.    • THERE ARE 3 BRONZE IMPELLERS AND 1 SS IMPELLER IN THIS PUMP. THE 3 BRONZE IMPELLERS ARE ALL CRACKED INSIDE THE VANE AREAS.  • ALL THE CASE RINGS SHOW RUBS 180 DEG. AROUND, WHICH IS CAUSED BY UNBALANCE.      4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. SEAL FAILURE SUB-CAUSE CHANGED FROM "OTHER," PER NARRATIVE.

column7: HVLS/OTHER FLAMMABLE OR TOXIC FLUID WHICH IS A GAS AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A THIRD PARTY CALLED COMPANY OPERATIONS CONTROL AND REPORTED AN ICE BALL ON THE GROUND.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL DISPATCHED TO THE LOCATION VERIFIED THE LEAK AND BLOCKED IN THE LINE.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE CALLED NRC (#924366)AND REPORTED AN ESTIMATED VOLUME RELEASE OF 10 BARRELS OF ISOBUTANE.  UPON EXCAVATION, PRELIMINARY NDE REPORTED THE ORIGIN OF THE LEAK AS A LACK OF FUSION ANOMALY LOCATED IN A PRE-1970 LF ERW LONGITUDINAL SEAM.  APPROXIMATELY 97 FEET OF PIPE WAS EXPOSED.  A 62 FOOT 11.5 INCH PIPE SEGMENT CONTAINING THE COMPLETE PIPE JOINT THAT HAD THE LEAK WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH PRE-TESTED 6.625" OD, 0.188" WALL AND X42 GRADE PIPE.  THE CUT OUT WAS THEN SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.  THE KIEFNER REPORT CONCLUDED THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY CREVICE CORROSION THAT OCCURRED INSIDE A LACK OF FUSION DEFECT IN A ERW SEAM.    UPON APPROVAL BY THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA, THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE WITH OPERATING PRESSURE RESTRICTED TO A 20% REDUCTION FROM THE MOST RECENT OPERATING PRESSURE HISTORY.  CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA APPROVED REMOVAL OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE RESTRICTION ON OCTOBER 29, 2010.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: AFTER A LINE UPSET AND RELIEF EVENT, THE OUTSIDE TANK FARM CONTROLLER (TFC) CHECKED THE YARD AND AT APPROXIMATELY 07:25 HE CAME INTO THE CONTROL BUILDING TO INFORM THE TFC THAT THERE WAS PRODUCT IN THE MANIFOLD YARD NEAR THE STRAINERS. OUTSIDE TFC BARRICADED ALL ACCESS ROADS LEADING TO THE RELEASE AREA AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE LEAD TFC AND LEAD TECHNICIANS. AT 07:30 LEAD TFC NOTIFIED OPERATIONS MANAGER AND DISTRICT LEADER. UPON ARRIVAL AT 08:05 AND INVESTIGATING THE AREA OF THE RELEASE, LEAD TFC AND LEAD TECHNICIAN STOPPED THE LEAK BY ISOLATING THE AFFECTED SECTION. THE YARD OIL WATER SEPARATOR WAS CLOSED TO PREVENT DISCHARGE TO POND 2. NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE FIRE DEPARTMENT BY LOCAL OPERATIONS 09:00. THE GEORGIA EPD WAS NOTIFIED AT 09:55 BY THE DISTRICT ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGER SINCE THERE WERE POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO GROUNDWATER. ONCE IT WAS SAFE TO EXCAVATE, A 6” FLANGE WITH A 6 “SKILLET WAS UNCOVERED AND IDENTIFIED AS THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK. THE SKILLET WAS REMOVED AND A BLIND FLANGE WAS INSTALLED FOR THE PERMANENT REPAIR. THE MAJORITY OF THE RELEASED PRODUCT WAS CAPTURED BY THE YARD DRAIN SYSTEM THAT FLOWS INTO THE OIL WATER SEPARATOR. AN ESTIMATED TOTAL OF 95 BBLS WAS RECOVERED WITH DIAPHRAGM PUMPS AND VIA THE SUBSURFACE DRAIN SYSTEM AND OIL WATER SEPARATOR. INITIALLY, PRODUCT WAS POOLED AROUND THE AREA OF THE LEAK COVERING 1800 SQUARE FEET. THE EVAPORATIVE LOSS FROM THE POOLED PRODUCT WAS CALCULATED TO BE 1.2 BBLS. RECOVERY OPERATIONS TOOK PLACE FROM TIME OF RELEASE UNTIL SUNDAY THE 29TH. TOTAL RELEASE VOLUME IS ESTIMATED AT 98.4 BARRELS. VOLUME RECOVERED IS 95 BARRELS. THE LEAK OCCURRED IN AN AREA THAT IS CURRENTLY UNDER REMEDIATION FROM PAST RELEASES. FOLLOWING THE RECEIPT OF LABORATORY ANALYSIS INDICATING THAT STATE IN-STREAM WATER QUALITY STANDARDS WERE EXCEEDED AT THE OUTFALL OF THE ADJACENT POND AS A RESULT OF THE RELEASE, NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER ON 12/18/09.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: ON TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 2009 AT APPROXIMATELY 9:55 A.M., BUCKEYE PARTNERS LINE 601 UNDERNEATH SKILLMAN AVENUE IN QUEENS, NY WAS STRUCK BY A CONTRACTOR OPERATING A DRILLING RIG WHILE WORKING FOR THE NEW YORK CITY MASS TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MTA) CAUSING SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE THAT RESULTED IN A PIPELINE RELEASE.  NO ONE-CALL WAS PLACED BY THE MTA CONTRACTOR PRIOR TO THE WORK STARTING.   A CHRONOLOGICAL SEQUENCE OF EVENTS LEADING UP TO THIS EVENT IS AS FOLLOWS:  THE CONTRACTOR WAS CONTRACTED BY MTA TO PERFORM A GEOPHYSICAL SURVEY CONSISTING OF THE DRILLING OF A NUMBER OF WELLS AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS. DURING THIS PROCESS, THE CONTRACTOR PLACED SEVERAL ONE-CALLS FOR OTHER LOCATIONS BESIDES SKILLMAN AVENUE.  AS A RESULT OF THESE ONE-CALLS,  BUCKEYE PERSONNEL MET WITH THE CONTRACTOR ON OCTOBER 20 AND 21, 2009 WHERE BUCKEYE PERSONNEL EXPLAINED THAT ANY EXCAVATION WITHIN TEN FEET OF A BUCKEYE PIPELINE MUST BE COORDINATED WITH BUCKEYE.  ON THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 2009 THE CONTRACTOR CALLED BUCKEYE’S LOCAL JFK STATION TO REQUEST A MARK-OUT OF LINE 601 AT SKILLMAN AVENUE.  THIS LOCATION WAS NOT COVERED BY THE ORIGINAL ONE-CALLS REQUESTED BY THE CONTRACTOR IN OCTOBER.  A BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE PROCEEDED TO LOCATE THE PIPELINE AND MONITORED THE DRILLING THAT TOOK PLACE ON THAT DATE. THE BUCKEYE EMPLOYEE ALSO NOTIFIED THE CONTRACTOR TO CALL BUCKEYE IF THEY WERE GOING TO BE DOING ANY MORE WORK IN THE AREA.  ON MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 2009 THE CONTRACTOR RETURNED TO THE SKILLMAN AVENUE LOCATION  AND CONTINUED DRILLING. BUCKEYE WAS NOT INFORMED OF THIS ACTIVITY AND THEREFORE HAD NO ONE ON SITE.  THE CONTRACTOR CONTINUED DRILLING ACTIVITY ON TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 2009 USING A LARGER BORE HEAD THAN WAS PREVIOUSLY USED. AGAIN, BUCKEYE WAS NOT INFORMED OF THIS ACTIVITY AND HAD NO ONE ON SITE. AT APPROXIMATELY 9:55 A.M., THE CONTRACTOR STRUCK THE PIPELINE CAUSING THE RELEASE. BUCKEYE JFK STATION PERSONNEL WITNESSED THE PRESSURE LOSS AND LATER RECEIVED A  PHONE CALL FROM THE CONTRACTOR NOTIFYING THEM OF THE LINE STRIKE.  BUCKEYE’S MAINTENANCE CREW WAS DEPLOYED AND PERFORMED EMERGENCY RESPONSE EFFORTS WHICH INCLUDED THE REPLACEMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 4’ OF DAMAGED PIPE.  BUCKEYE NOTIFIED ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES OF THIS INCIDENT.  UPON BUCKEYE’S REVIEW OF THIS INCIDENT, IT HAS DETERMINED THAT ITS PROCEDURE FOR PROPERLY LOCATING THIS PIPELINE WAS NOT FOLLOWED.  BUCKEYE IS CONTINUING ITS INVESTIGATION OF THIS INCIDENT.    ALL REMEDIAION AND CLEANUP HAS BEEN COMPLETED. BUCKEYE'S INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT PROCEDURES WERE NOT FOLLOWED. DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO REINFORCE BUCKEYE'S COMMITMENT TO SAFETY AND THE IMPORTANCE OF FOLLOWING PROCEDURES.

column245: AT 12:01 AM 11/26/09 THE CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A HAZARDOUS VAPOR ALARM FROM THE UNIT #4 VAPOR MONITOR AT YPL STATION BILLINGS, MT. THE OP CORD CALLED THE ON-CALL PERSON TO RESPOND TO THE ALARM AND INVESTIGATE.  UPON ARRIVAL THE ON-CALL PERSON COULD SEE A REFLECTION OF PRODUCT IN THE YARD.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT AN ELECTRONIC CORROSION MONITORING DEVICE FAILED CAUSING AN ESTIMATED 60 BBL RELEASE OF DIESEL / GAS MIXTURE.  THE FAILURE OCCURRED THROUGH ONE 1/4” PROBE HOLE IN THE DEVICE.   A VAC-TRUCK WAS CALLED TO PICK UP ALL FREE STANDING PRODUCT AND CONTRACTORS WILL REMOVE AND PLACE CONTAMINATED SOIL ON PLASTIC DURING DAYLIGHT HOURS.  ALL APPROPRIATE NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE.THE FAILURE AS DESCRIBED ABOVE WAS THROUGH ONE OF THE 1/4" PROBE HOLES IN THE ELECTRONIC CORROSION MONITORING DEVICE.  THIS DEVICE THREADED INTO AN EXISTING THREAD-A-LET ON THE PIPE. RECIEVED REPORT/E-MAIL ON 1/22/2010 THAT REVEALED THE CAUSE OF FAILURE WAS DUE TO FATIGUE ON BOTH PROBES.

column245: COMPANY PERSONNEL WHILE CONDUCTING A GAS PIPELINE LEAK SURVEY WITH A FID GAS DETECTOR DETECTED HYDROCARBON VAPOR.  AFTER PROBING THE GROUND, AN UNDERGROUND ICE BALL WAS DISCOVERED OVER THE LIQUIDS PIPELINE.  OPERATIONS BLOCKED IN THE SEGMENT CONTAINING THE LEAK AND SECURED THE AREA.  A COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE CALLED NRC (#924900) AND REPORTED AN ESTIMATED VOLUME RELEASE OF 10 BARRELS OF ETHANE PROPANE MIX.  APPROXIMATELY 69 FEET OF PIPE WAS EXPOSED.  THE AFFECTED LINE SEGMENT WAS PURGED WITH NITROGEN, AND THE COMPLETE PIPE JOINT THAT HAD THE LEAK WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED WITH 64 FEET AND 7 INCHES OF PRE-TESTED 10.75 INCH OD, 0.250 INCH WALL AND X42 GRADE PIPE.  THE CUT OUT WAS THEN SENT TO KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.    AFTER COMMUNICATION WITH THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA AND SUBSEQUENT TO THE REPAIR, THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.  THE FINAL KIEFNER REPORT CONCLUDED THAT THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY HOOK CRACKS IN A HIGH FREQUENCY ERW LONGITUDINAL SEAM.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: THE RELEASE OCCURRED WHILE PERFORMING AN IN-SERVICE PIPE REPLACEMENT USING DOUBLE STOPPLES, ONE STOPPLE OF EACH SIDE OF THE PIPE TO BE REPLACED.  THE SOURCE OF THE RELEASE WAS THE FLANGED CONNECTION BETWEEN THE STOPPLE TEE AND THE SANDWICH VALVE ON THE UPSTREAM STOPPLE LOCATION.  PRIOR TO THE RELEASE THE STOPPLE TEES WERE WELDED ONTO THE PIPELINE AND THE PIPE HOT TAPS COMPLETED ON BOTH SIDES OF THE PIPE SECTION.  THE PIPE WAS REPLACED THREE DAYS AFTER THE RELEASE.    THE RESULTS OF THE INVESTIGATION BY KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES OF THE FLANGED CONNECTION SHOWED THAT THE GASKET LACKED ADEQUATE COMPRESSION OR CLAMPING FORCE DUE TO INSUFFICIENT BOLT LOAD OR TORQUE.  DIMENSIONAL MEASUREMENTS OF THE STOPPLE AND SANDWICH VALVE GASKET SEALING SURFACES WERE WITHIN TOLERANCES OF ASME B16.5 FOR THE FLANGE SIZE AND CLASS.  THE SEALING SURFACES SHOWED NO OBSERVABLE CORROSION, GOUGES, OR OTHER DAMAGE.    PRELIMINARY CAUSES IN H5- 16A THROUGH 16G, IDENTIFIED IN THE ORIGINAL REPORT HAVE NOW BEEN CORRECTED AND IDENTIFIED UNDER H-7 - INCORRECT OPERATION.

column30: CPM/SCADA-BASED SYSTEM WITH LEAK DETECTION
column245: PIPELINE CONTROL RECEIVED A CALL FROM A CITIZEN STATING THEY SMELLED GAS.  PIPELINE OPERATOR WAS DISPATCHED. UPON ARRIVAL THE OPERATOR VERIFIED THERE WAS FLAMMABLE GAS DETECTION.  AT THAT TIME, THE T-35 8 INCH WAS SHUTDOWN AND MAINLINE VALVES CLOSED.  THE SOURCE OF THE LEAK WAS IDENTIFIED AND IT APPEARS THE PIPELINE MAY HAVE BEEN MISIDENTIFIED AS A WATER LINE AND A LOW PRESSURE CLAMP INSTALLED AND HOT TAPPED BY A UNKNOWN THIRD PARTY. THE UNKNOWN INSTALLATION OF THE CLAMP APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN PLACED MANY YEARS AGO AND NOT A NEW INSTALLATION. THE T35 SEGMENT WAS HYDROTESTED 10 YEARS AGO AND PASSED THE TEST. THE CLAMP INSTALLATION WAS CONFIGURED WITH A VALVE, FITTING AND TUBING COMMONLY USED FOR WATER LINE INSTALLATION.  ADDITIONALLY A 8 INCH WATER LINE WAS IN THE SAME RIGHT-OF-WAY AS OUR PIPELINE AND A WATER CONNECTION FOR A WATER METER WAS DIRECTLY ABOVE THE CLAMP FOUND ON OUR PIPELINE. THE SECTION OF PIPE CONTAINING THE CLAMP WAS CUT OUT AND REPLACED.  THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column245: A PRESSURE SWITCH ON THE BOLIVAR VALVE STATION FAILED.     STRESS ENGINEERING REPORT SUGGESTS THAT FRACTURED SURFACES ON THE SCREWS CONFIRMED THAT THE FRACTURES HAD OCCURRED BY WAY OF HYDROGEN ASSISTED CRACKING.   THE HIGH HARDNESS OF THE ATTACHMENT SCREWS PROBABLY PLAYS A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN THE CRACKING PROCESS.  ZINC RICH DEPOSITS FOUND ON SCREW #1 APPARENTLY DID NOT PRODUCE SIGNIFICANT WEIGHT LOSS CORROSION OF THE SCREW.  THE PRESENCE OF SOLUTIONS CONTAINING ZINC SALTS MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE OBSERVED CRACKING OF THE SCREWS INDIRECTLY BY PROMOTING GALVANIC COUPLING BETWEEN THE SCREWS AND THE MORE CORROSION RESISTANT STAINLESS STEEL HOUSING.      REPLACED FAILED SWITCH AND PUT PIPELINE BACK IN-SERVICE.

column245: PUMPER REPORTED SPILL ON C-14 LINE TO OKC OCC.  LOCAL PERSONNEL FOUND OIL ON THE GROUND SURFACE.  THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND MANAGER WAS NOTIFIED.  REPAIR CREW WAS DISPATCHED AS WELL AS A VACUUM TRUCK.  TWO BARRELS OF CRUDE OIL WERE RECOVERED.  THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND REPAIRED USING A PLIDCO CLAMP.  LINE WAS REACTIVATED AND PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE @ 8:00 PM DECEMBER 18, 2009.  SIZE OF FAILURE WAS 1/4" DIAMETER.  RESULT OF THE STORK ANALYSIS OF THE PIPE RESULTED AS:  THE PIPE SAMPLE EXHIBITED A THROUGH-WALL CORROSION PIT IN A LOCALIZED GROUP OF PITS ON THE INSIDE SURFACE.

column30: REMOTE OPERATING PERSONNEL, INCLUDING CONTROLLERS
column245: AT APPROXIMATLY 10:30PM ON 12.12.2009 THE CONTROL CENTER WAS MAKING A SWITH TO THE REFINERY FOR THE SEMINOE PIPELINE AT BILLINGS STATION. THE MAINLINE STATION WENT DOWN ON LOW SUCTION PRESSURE. THE CONTROL CENTER CALLED OUT THE ON CALL PERSON TO INVESTIGATE. FURTHER LINE ISOLATION WAS PERFORMED TO NARROW DOWN THE SOURCE OF THE LACK OF SUCTION. DURING DAYLIGHT OPERATIONS DIESEL WAS FOUND ON THE GROUND SURFACE IN THE SNOW, AT THIS TIME NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE. THE PIPELINE SPLIT WAS MESSUARED AT 33" LONG BY 1/4" WIDE. REPORTS DUE INDICATE THAT THERE WAS A SMALL UNROUNDED DENT <1% FOUND IN THE HEAT AFFECTED ZONE THAT HAD A SMALL CRACK. PRELIMANARY REPORTS INDICATE THAT THIS MAY HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY THERMAL EXSPANTION DUE TO COOL PRODUCT SETTING IN THE PIELINE. CPPL RECIEVED THE FINAL KIEFNER REPORT ON MARCH 8TH. THE REPORT CONFIRMED THAT THE LEAK DID COME FROM THE REROUNDED DENT. WE HAVE UPDATED COST FOR REMEDATION AS WELL AS AMOUNT RECOVERED. INTERNAL INVESTIGATION HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND SHARED WITH PHMSA. DUE TO THE AMOUNT RECOVERED AND DISCUSSING WITH PHMSA WE WILL FINALIZE THE REPORT. WE WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR THE WELLS BUT BELEIVE THAT THERE WILL ONLY BE TRACE AMOUNTS RECOVERED AT THIS TIME. ALL COST FOR REMEDATION HAVE BEEN ACCOUNTED FOR AND BEEN UPDATED.

CPL CONTROLLER HAD SHUT THE LINE DOWN @ 0355 CST, WHEN HE WAS NOTIFIED BY PHONE OF A POSSIBLE LEAK. THE SITE WAS SECURED & MADE SAFE FOR PIPELINE REPAIRS AFTER DAYLIGHT THURSDAY MORNING. column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 1430 HOURS CDT ON DECEMBER 23, 2009 AN OPERATOR FOR THE EMPIRE TEAM DISCOVERED CRUDE OIL BUBBLES RISING TO THE WATER SURFACE IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA OF THE 16" MAIN PASS CRUDE OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM THAT EXTENDS FROM MAIN PASS 41 TO EMPIRE TERMINAL.  THE SYSTEM WAS ISOLATED AND A VACUUM WAS PLACED ON THE SYSTEM TO PREVENT ANY FURTHER CRUDE RELEASE.  BOOM MATERIAL WAS USED TO CONTAIN PRODUCT AND APPROXIMATELY 15 GALLONS WERE RECLAIMED.  REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE ARE BEING EVALUATED AND REMEDIATION IS EXPECTED.      AFTER FURTHER CALCULATIONS BASED ON ACCURATE AREA MEASUREMENTS AND RECOVERED MATERIAL, THE RELEASED VOLUME IS ESTIMATED @ 2 BARRELS.  ALL RELEASED VOLUME HAS BEEN RECOVERED VIA SKIMMING AND SORBENT RECOVERY.      3/15/2010 -  UPDATED SPILL AND RECOVERY VOLUME IN PART A, SECTION 6C TO 5 BARRELS SPILLED AND 5 BARRELS RECOVERED.    UPDATED ENVIROMENTAL SPILL VOLUME IN PART F, SECTION 2E TO 5 BARRELS.    5/12/2010 UPDATE  THE CYPRESS 16" PIPELINE REPAIR CONSISTED OF A HORIZONTAL DRIECTIONAL DRILL OF 2,375 FT. AT A DEPTH OF 125 FT.  THE TOTAL LENGTH OF PIPELINE REPLACEMENT CONSIST OF 2,400 FT. OF 16" DIAMETER API 5L PSL 2 SMLS DRL LINE PIPE COATED WITH 14-16 MILS FBE AND 40 MILS ARO FOR DRILLING, X52, .500 WT.  THE REPAIR HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND AT THIS PRESENT TIME THE PIPELINE HAS NOT BEEN PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.        8/11/11 FINAL REPORT   THE REPAIR HAS BEEN COMPLETED AND AT THIS PRESENT TIME THE PIPELINE HAS NOT BEEN PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE.

column126: REQUIRED OR INITIATED BY PUBLIC OFFICIAL
column245: ON DECEMBER 29, 2009 AT 10:00 P.M., BUCKEYE PARTNERS’ (BUCKEYE) CONTROL CENTER IN BREINIGSVILLE, PA RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE ASTON, PA FIRE MARSHALL REPORTING GASOLINE ODORS IN THE AREA OF CLEARVIEW LANE IN ASTON, PA. BUCKEYE’S 8” PIPELINE IN THE AREA (CT553JP) HAD BEEN SHUT DOWN EARLIER IN THE DAY AS PART OF A NORMAL, SCHEDULED SHUT DOWN AND THE PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS BEING MONITORED. AFTER NOTIFICATION FROM BUCKEYE‘S CONTROL CENTER, FIELD PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT THE SITE AND CONFIRMED THE PRESENCE OF GASOLINE ODORS.     AT 12:45 A.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION (PADEP) MEASURED GAS ODORS IN SEVERAL ADJACENT SANITARY SEWER MANHOLES  AS WELL AS A FEW NEARBY RESIDENCES. THE FIRE DEPARTMENT REQUESTED THE EVACUATION OF FOUR RESIDENCES AS A PRECAUTION UNTIL THE VAPOR LEVELS SUBSIDED.  AT 1:40 A.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009 A UNIFIED COMMAND WAS ESTABLISHED BY BUCKEYE’S LOCAL OPERATIONS MANAGER. BUCKEYE PERSONNEL PROCEEDED TO WALK THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY AND ALTHOUGH NO VISIBLE PRODUCT WAS SEEN, THEY DID DETECT AN ODOR IN SOME AREAS.  BUCKEYE DECIDED TO WALK THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY AGAIN DURING DAYLIGHT HOURS AND TO DIG TEST HOLES IN THE AREAS OF HIGH VAPOR LEVELS. BY NOON ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, BUCKEYE HAD A TOTAL OF TEN LOCATIONS PROBED BETWEEN CHERRY TREE STREET AND OVERLOOK STREET WITH NO PRODUCT FOUND. THE TEST HOLES DUG ON ARBOR LANE WERE ALSO FOUND TO BE CLEAN OF PRODUCT.     AT 12:28 P.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009, THE PADEP REPRESENTATIVE INDICATED THAT IT APPEARED THAT THE PROBLEM WAS IN THE VICINITY OF SCOTT LANE BECAUSE THE SEWER MANHOLES ON CHERRY TREE STREET AND FRAZER STREET HAD HIGH VAPOR LEVELS. BUCKEYE DECIDED TO EXCAVATE THE GASOLINE TANK LINES INSIDE THE ADJACENT CHELSEA STATION SINCE THESE PIPELINES WERE CLOSER TO SCOTT STREET. AT 10:00 P.M. ON DECEMBER 30, 2009 BUCKEYE PERSONNEL IDENTIFIED HIGH VAPOR LEVELS AND VISIBLE PRODUCT IN THE EXCAVATION AT THE TANK JUNCTION VALVES IN CHELSEA STATION. THE RELEASE WAS DETERMINED TO BE ON THE TANK 701 LINE. AT 1:30 A.M. ON DECEMBER 31, 2009, BUCKEYE INSTALLED A PLIDCO SLEEVE, WHICH STOPPED THE RELEASE.  AT NOON ON DECEMBER 31, 2009, ALL RESIDENTS WERE CLEARED TO SAFELY RETURN TO THEIR HOMES.  ON JANUARY 1, 2010, THE LOCAL SEWER AUTHORITY CONFIRMED AT LEAST THREE BREACHES IN THE SANITARY SEWER LINE LOCATED UNDER CHERRY TREE STREET.  THESE BREACHES ALLOWED GASOLINE FROM THE RELEASE TO GET INTO THE SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM.  THE LOCAL SEWER AUTHORITY IS PRESENTLY IN THE PROCESS OF REPAIRING THE SEWER SYSTEM IN THIS AREA.    BUCKEYE CONTINUES TO MONITOR THE PLIDCO SLEEVE TWICE DAILY UNTIL PERMANENT REPAIRS CAN BE COMPLETED, WHICH IS SCHEDULED FOR THE WEEK OF FEBRUARY 8, 2010.  BUCKEYE HAS DUG NUMEROUS TEST WELLS AND CONTINUES TO WORK ON BOTH THE REMEDIATION OF THE RELEASE AND DETERMINING THE ESTIMATED VOLUME. BUCKEYE NOTIFIED ALL APPROPRIATE OUTSIDE AGENCIES OF THIS INCIDENT.     PERMANENT REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON FEBRUARY 12, 2010 BY CUTTING OUT THE DAMAGED PIPE AND REPLACING IT WITH CERTIFIED PIPE. THE DAMAGED PIPE HAS BEEN SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS.     METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS REVEALED THE CAUSE OF THE EXTERNAL CORROSION TO BE MICROBIOLOGICALLY INDUCED CORROSION. REMEDIATION IS STILL ON-GOING. OPERATION OF THE FACILITY WAS TURNED OVER TO CONOCOPHILLIPS ON 3-1-11.      ----------------  UPDATE 12/11/12  COSTS HAVE BEEN UPDATED TO REFLECT ACUTAL AMOUNTS AFTER TURNING OPERATION OVER TO THE OWNER, CONOCO PHILLIPS. THIS RELEASE REPORT IS BEING FINALIZED BY BUCKEYE. NO FURTHER UPDATES WILL BE SUBMITTED.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 09:15 HOURS, OCT 28, 2003, ONE OF THE COMPANY’S MAINTENANCE CREWS WAS EXCAVATING THE COMPANY’S ROW AT LOLITA STATION TO MODIFY A CONNECTION AND AN UNDERGROUND 1” WELDED COLLAR WITH VALVE WAS BROKEN FROM THE 12” PIPELINE BY THE BACKHOE.  (THE COMPANY HAD MADE NOTIFICATION TO TESS AND WAS ITS OWN EXCAVATOR.)THE CREW IMMEDIATELY REPORTED THE CONDITION TO THE CONTROL ROOM SO THE LINE COULD BE SHUT DOWN.  THE SITE WAS THEN ISOLATED BY MAINLINE VALVES.      INTERNAL ( COMPANY RESPONSE) AND EXTERNAL  (NRC AND RRC) NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE, THEN A NEW FITTING WAS POSITIONED ON THE LINE.  REMEDIATION BEGAN IMMEDIATELY AND THE COMPANY IS NOW AWAITING FINAL RESULTS OF SOIL SAMPLING.  APPROXIMATELY 10 CUBIC YDS. WAS HAULED AWAY FOR REMEDIATION AFTER VACUUM TRUCKS RECOVERED THE MAJORITY OF FREE PRODUCT.  THE LINE WAS RESTORED TO SERVICE 5HRS 25MINUTES LATER.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE.

column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 11:00 HOURS, JANUARY 2, 2004, ONE OF THE COMPANY’S OPERATIONS MGRS. RESPONDED TO A THIRD PARTY REPORT OF AN OIL SHEEN OVER THE HOUSTON 12” REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY AND CONFIRMED A DIESEL FUEL RELEASE IN NUECES BAY.  INTERNAL NOTIFICATION WAS MADE IMMEDIATELY TO THE CONTROL ROOM AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN FOLLOWED BY CLOSURE OF  BLOCK VALVES ON EACH SIDE OF THE BAY.     EXTERNAL  (NRC, TCEQ, GLO, COAST GUARD, U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE, TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE, RRC, THE CORPUS CHRISTI LEPC) NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE, THEN THE SHEEN WAS CONTAINED BY BOOM WITH ABSORBANT BOOM ON THE PRODUCT SIDE.   A REPRESENTATIVE FROM THE TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE AND COMPANY PERSONNEL ASSESSED THE SPILL AND DETERMINED IT TO BE VERY SMALL AND WOULD HAVE MININUM IMPACT IN THE BAY WHILE LIKELY NOT REACHING THE SHORELINE.    THE COMPANY THEN DISPLACED THE PRODUCT INSIDE THE LINE WITH NITROGEN AND DIVERS WERE CALLED ON SITE THE FOLLOWING MORNING.  THE DIVERS WERE OPERATOR QUALIFIED ONSHORE TO INSTALL A TEMPORARY CLAMP AND PROCEEDED TO DO SO IN APPROXIMATELY 4' OF  WATER.   AFTER CLOSELY MONITORING THE LINE, IT  WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 12:00 HRS. JANUARY 4, 2004. IT WAS CONFIRMED BY DIVERS THAT THE LEAK OCCURRED IN A DENT  WHICH WAS ESTIMATED TO HAVE BEEN THE RESULT OF MARINE TRAFFIC IN THE PREVIOUS 2-3 MONTHS.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO OTHER OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE, PER NARRATIVE.

column7: GASOLINE, DIESEL, FUEL OIL OR OTHER PETROLEUM PRODUCT WHICH IS A LIQUID AT AMBIENT CONDITIONS
column30: AIR PATROL OR GROUND SURVEILLANCE
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: AT APPROXIMATELY 13:00 HOURS, JANUARY 7, 2004, ONE OF THE COMPANY’S OPERATIONS MANAGERS RESPONDED TO AN AERIAL OBSERVATION OF AN OIL SHEEN OVER THE HOUSTON 12” REFINED PRODUCTS PIPELINE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  AT 13:30 HOURS, IN WINDY CONDITIONS, HE ARRIVED BY BOAT AND CONFIRMED A UNLEADED GASOLINE RELEASE OF SMALL PROPORTION IN NUECES BAY AT APPROXIMATELY THE SAME LOCATION AS THE RELEASE OF JANUARY 2, 2004. INTERNAL NOTIFICATION WAS MADE IMMEDIATELY TO THE CONTROL ROOM AND THE PIPELINE WAS SHUT DOWN FOLLOWED BY CLOSURE OF  BLOCK VALVES ON EACH SIDE OF THE BAY AT 14:00 HOURS.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION CONFIRMED THAT THE CLAMP WHICH WAS INSTALLED TO REMDEDIATE THE DENT WHICH WAS PREVIOUSLY DISCOVERED JANUARY 2, 2004, HAD PARTIALLY FAILED.  (SEE DOT 7000-1 REPORT ON NUECES BAY RELEASE OF 1-2-04.)     EXTERNAL  NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NRC, TCEQ, GLO, COAST GUARD, U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE, TEXAS PARKS & WILDLIFE, RRC, THE CORPUS CHRISTI LEPC, AND THE SHEEN WAS CONTAINED BY BOOM WITH ABSORBANT BOOM ON THE PRODUCT SIDE.  A REPRESENTATIVE FROM THE TEXAS GENERAL LAND OFFICE AND COMPANY PERSONNEL ASSESSED THE SPILL AND DETERMINED THE AMOUNT RELEASED WAS VERY SMALL AND WOULD HAVE MININUM  OR NO IMPACT IN THE BAY AND WAS NOT LIKELY TO REACH THE SHORELINE.    BECAUSE OF THE DENT IN THE LINE AND THE PARTIAL FAILURE OF THE CLAMP THAT REMEDIATED THE DENT, THE COMPANY ELECTED TO IMMEDIATELY REPLACE THIS SECTION OF THE PIPELINE.  ON JANUARY 7,  THE COMPANY DISPLACED THE PRODUCT INSIDE THE LINE WITH NITROGEN AND BEGAN THE REPLACEMENT PROJECT.  ON JANUARY 8, 2004, REPLACEMENT PIPE WAS HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED, AND ON JANUARY 9, COMPANY PERSONNEL REPLACED APPROXIMATELY 69’ OF PIPE.  DURING THE REPLACEMENT PROJECT PERSONNEL INSURED THAT THE NEW REPLACEMENT PIPE WAS AT LEAST 36” BELOW THE FLOOR OF THE BAY.  AFTER CLOSELY MONITORING THE LINE, IT  WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT 11:55 HRS. JANUARY 10, 2004.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. CAUSE CHANGED FROM MISCELLANEOUS TO COMPONENT FAILURE, PER NARRATIVE AND S.M.E. REVIEW.

column30: A THIRD PARTY
column241: CHAD HAEGELIN,  SR MGR INTEGRITY ENGINEER
column245: A THIRD PARTY ALERTED NUSTAR’S TERMINAL MGR. OF A SMALL AMOUNT OF PRODUCT ON THE PIPELINE ROW NEXT TO THE INTERSECTION OF SIGMOR ROAD AND NAVIGATION BLVD.  THE TERMINAL MGR. THEN CLOSED THE VALVE ON THE STORMWATER DISCHARGE LINE TO CONTAIN THE PRODUCT AND INFORMED PIPELINE MANAGEMENT.  PIPELINE MANAGEMENT CONTACTED EMERGENCY RESPONSE PERSONNEL AND MADE NOTIFICATION TO THE USCG AND THE PORT OF CORPUS CHRISTI OF A POSSIBLE PIPELINE RELEASE.     UPON FULL EXAMINATION OF THE LEAK SITE, TWELVE DIFFERENT PIPELINES WERE DISCOVERED, ALL BELOW CP CRITERIA (-0.600 TO -0.700 VOLTS).  IT WAS ALSO DISCOVERED THAT A LOCAL PIPELINE OPERATOR HAD ABANDONED A 20” STEEL LINE THAT CROSSED NUSTAR’S BTX PIPELINE IN LATE 2007.   THE OPERATOR EXPLAINED THAT ITS NEABY RECTIFIER PROTECTS ITS TANK BOTTOMS ONLY BUT THE 24” CASING HAD A HIGH P/S READING OF -3.00 VOLTS.  THE ABANDONED SEGMENT, CONNECTED TO THE RECTIFIER, WAS SUPPLYING ABNORMALLY HIGH AMPERAGE TO THE ABANDONED CROSSING AND JUMPING TO NUSTAR’S BTX LINE, BECOMING A SOURCE FOR INTERFERENCE CORROSION IN THE OPINION OF CP PERSONNEL.     THE PIPE SPECIMEN WAS SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT LAB FOR ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE.    UPDATE 12-11-09    THE FORM IS UPDATED TO INCLUDE NEW COSTS IN PART A, 5. LOSSES, AND PART H – APPARENT CAUSE.  THE CAUSE WAS VERIFIED TO BE EXTERNAL CORROSION DUE TO INTERFERENCE CURRENTS OR CURRENT DISCHARGE CORROSION CAUSED BY THE ABANDONMENT OF AN OPERATOR’S  20” PIPELINE CROSSING NUSTAR’S BTX PIPELINE IN A SHARED ROW.    4/20/2010 -- REPORT UPDATED PER RESULTS OF LEAK REVIEW SPRING 2010. NO CHANGE IN CAUSE. ORIGINAL REPORT TO TEXAS RAILROAD COMMISION NOT FORWARDED TO PHMSA BY THAT AGENCY.

column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: ON NOVEMBER 18 2009 THE MAINTENANCE OPERATOR PROCEEDED TO DRAIN AND CLEAN THE RECEIPT STRAINER LOCATED AT THE PIPELINE AIRPORT STATION. AT THE COMPLETION OF THE STRAINER CLEANING THE OPERATOR FAILED TO CLOSE THE STRAINER DRAIN VALVE. ON NOVEMBER 19 BEFORE STARTING THE DAILY PUMP SCHEDULE THE LINE OPERATOR VERIFIED THE CONDITIONS OF THE VALVES METERS AND ALIGNMENT BUT FAILED TO VERIFY THE STRAINER VALVE WAS IN THE CLOSED POSITION. ONCE THE TRANSFER BEGAN AT APPROXIMATELY 6:35AM SOME OF THE RECEIPT PRODUCT BEGAN DRAINING FROM THE STRAIN VALVE INTO THE SUMP TANK. ONCE FULL THE SUMP TANK OVERFLOWED THERE WAS APPROXIMATELY 35.21 BARRELS OF PRODUCT THAT CAME OUT OF THE SUMP TANK VENT AND ONTO THE SURROUND AREA. AT 7:05 AM THE LINE OPERATOR WAS CHECKING HIS METER READING AND IDENTIFIED HE HAD A PROBLEM AND BEGAN THE EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN PROCESS. ALL FUEL WAS CONTAINED WITHIN THE COMPOUND AREA AND DID NOT MIGRATE OFF THE PROPERTY. BP AND PIPELINE PERSONNEL CONTAINED THE FUEL SPILL WITHIN THE BP TANK FARM. WE PROCEEDED TO RECOVER THE FUEL SPILL WITH THE HELP OF VACUUM TANKS FROM BP AND TOTAL. THE AMOUNT OF FUEL SPILL OUTSIDE THE SUMP TANK WAS 35.21 BARRELS AND THE AMOUNT RECOVERED WAS 32.21 BARRELS. WE ESTIMATE THAT WE RECOVERED A 100% OF THE SPILL. BY 14:30 THE SAME DAY THE PRODUCT SPILL WAS COMPLETELY COLLECTED AND IT WAS GIVEN THE CLEARANCE TO PROCEED WITH NORMAL PUMPING RECEIVING OPERATIONS. FORTUNATLEY THERE WERE NO PHYSICAL DAMAGES OF CONTAMINATION OF ANY AFFLUENT STORM SEWER COLLECTOR AS THE PRODUCT SPILL NEVER CAME CLOSE TO ANY ONE OF THEM.

column245: PART H - APPARENT CAUSE: SITE CONSTRUCTION AFFECTED ABILTY OF OPERATOR TO SEE VALVE OPEN. DURING THE MORNING OF SATURDAY, DECEMBER 1, THE GENEVA OPERATOR BEGAN TO PREPARE AT 11:15 A.M. FOR PIPELINE/TANK ACTIVITIES SCHEDULED TO BEGIN AT AROUND 12:15 P.M. DURING THIS TIME HE RECEIVED AN EXPECTED HIGH LEVEL ALARM ALERTING HIM TO SWITCH 16" PIPELINE RECEIPTS FROM TANK 30-2 (HIGH LEVEL ALARM) TO TANK 30-4. PRIOR TO OPENING THE 30-4 VALVE, THE OPERATOR FAILED TO CLOSE THE ASSOCIATED BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE THEREBY ALLOWING PRODUCT TO ESCAPE THE VALVE BODY. UNDER NORMAL CIRCUMSTANCES THE PRODUCT FLOWING THROUGH THE BLOCK AND BLEED VALVE WOULD ESCAPE TO THE GROUND NEAR THE OPERATOR'S FEET, HOWEVER, DUE TO CONSTRUCTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE MANIFOLD AREA, THE VALVE HAD BEEN CONNECTED TO A PIPE WHICH CARRIED THE PRODUCT SOME DISTANCE AWAY AND EMPTIED INTO A RELATIVELY SMALL CONTAINER (AROUND 25-30 GALLONS) AND WAS INITIALLY UNNOTICED. THE INCIDENT RESULTED IN A ONE BARREL SPILL TO THE GROUND IN THE MANIFOLD AREA. SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL OCCURRED KEEPING THE PRODUCT ON TOP OF THE WATER WHICH WAS PUMPED INTO THE OIL/WATER SEPARATOR AND ALL PRODUCT WAS RECOVERED. NO SOIL IMPACT.

column30: LOCAL OPERATING PERSONNEL, PROCEDURES OR EQUIPMENT
column63: PUMP/METER STATION; TERMINAL/TANK FARM PIPING AND EQUIPMENT, INCLUDING SUMPS
column245: DURING INSTALLATION OF NEW 16” CONTROL VALVE AT ROSEDALE STATION, FUMES FROM PIPING FLASHED THROUGH A 2" VENT ON TOP OF THE PIPE WHILE WELDING.  EARLIER IN THE DAY THE PIPING THAT WAS NEEDING THE WELD WAS SEALED OFF FROM CRUDE OIL VAPORS BY INSTALLING A MUD PLUG ABOUT 12" - 16" FROM THE WELD.  ROUGHLY 6 HOURS ELAPSED FROM INSTALLING THE MUD PLUG TO THE FLASH INCIDENT DUE TO FITTING & ALIGNMENT OF THE PIPING AND WELD COMPLETION.  THE FLASH TOOK PLACE DURING THE END OF THE LAST OR CAP PASS AND WHILE THE WELDER WAS LOCATED AT THE OPPOSITE POSITION OF THE FLASH.  WELDING WAS STOPPED UNTIL NEW PLUG WAS INSTALLED AND ATMOSPHERE WAS MONITORED FOR SAFETY.    SEVERAL FACTORS COULD HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE FLASH: THE MUD PLUG COULD HAVE BEEN MIXED TOO DRY, INADEQUATE VENTING, TOO MUCH TIME LAPSE, OR PRODUCT MOVEMENT.     **SUBMITTED TO SATISFY REQUIREMENTS OF CPF NO. 4-2010-5013 CONSENT AGREEMENT AND ORDER.**    UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).

column64: ONSHORE PIPE BEING HOT CUT FOR REMOVAL
column66: HOT CUT OF PIPE FOR REMOVAL
column238: RESIDUAL PRODUCT IN THE LINE IGNITED FOLLOWING A HOT CUT TO REMOVE A SECTION OF PIPE.
column245: FOLLOWING A NITROGEN PURGE, COLD CUTS WERE UTILIZED TO REMOVE TWO STOPPLE FITTINGS FROM THE PIPELINE.  THIS ACTION SEGMENTED THE PIPELINE FOR VARIOUS MAINTENANCE CREWS WORKING IN PARALLEL TO REMOVE A TOTAL OF EIGHT SEPARATE STOPPLE FITTINGS DURING THE SHUTDOWN.  PRODUCT HAD NOT BEEN DETECTED AT EITHER OF THE FIRST TWO WORK SITES WHERE COLD CUTS HAD BEEN EMPLOYED.  AT THE THIRD STOPPLE FITTING TO BE REMOVED, THE LINE WAS PROBED AND NO MEASURABLE PRODUCT WAS DETECTED AT THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE.  IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE WORK PLAN, HOT CUTS WERE MADE TO REMOVE THE STOPPLE FITTING.  ALL ATMOSPHERIC MONITORS WERE READING SAFE LEVELS AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.   THE SEGMENT TIPPED AS THE SECOND HOT CUT WAS COMPLETED AND A SMALL QUANTITY OF RESIDUAL PRODUCT, WHICH WAS LIKELY TRAPPED INSIDE THE STOPPLE FITTING, WAS IGNITED BY THE HOT METAL AND/OR THE TORCH FLAME.  THE PRODUCT FLASHED THEN BURNED OUT IN A FEW SECONDS.  A SMALL QUANTITY OF RESIDUAL PRODUCT IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DOWNSTREAM MAINLINE WAS ALSO IGNITED (POSSIBLY PRODUCT SPLASHED FROM THE STOPPLE).  THE FLAME INSIDE THE PIPE WAS EXTINGUISHED WITH A DRY CHEMICAL EXTINGUISHER WITHIN SECONDS.     UPDATED BY PHMSA ON 11/25/2015 (COMMODITY CLASSIFICATION).
